This trend may continue in 2018, as Opec struggles to control the market.

site_title: Kencana Agri's CEO passes on reins to son
summary: Kencana Agri's CEO Henry Maknawi will resign as CEO on January 1, 2018, and be succeeded by his son Albert Maknawi. Henry Maknawi will remain as executive chairman and a member of the nominating committee. His sister Ratna Maknawi will be redesignated as executive vice-chairman. The succession plan is part of the company's efforts to maintain stability and continuity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 17.71 points to 1,796.81. The index saw 489 gainers versus 468 losers, with a trading volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM 2.8 billion.

site_title: Taiwan president warns China against military aggression
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen warned China against military aggression, stating that China's military ambitions are becoming more apparent and tension between Taiwan and the mainland must not be resolved through force. Tsai emphasized the need for peaceful means to resolve cross-strait issues, but also pledged to defend Taiwan's security and way of life. China has stepped up military drills around Taiwan, suspecting Tsai's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party wants to push for formal independence, a red line for Beijing.

site_title: Airbus sprints from behind in bid to upset Boeing order lead
summary: Airbus is making a last-ditch effort to close the gap with Boeing in its annual order contest, announcing deals worth billions of dollars. The company is trying to sell at least 700 jets in 2017, despite a painful year marked by management upheaval and corruption investigations. Analysts say Airbus may need to offer large discounts to close the gap with Boeing, which reported 844 net orders up to December 19. Airbus has announced deals for 705 narrowbody jets since the end of November, with many of these deals being net additions to the order book.

site_title: Prakaikaew Na-Ranong
summary: Prakaikaew Na-Ranong, owner of luxury beach resort The Slate Phuket, shares her vision of a luxury lifestyle resort that honors Phuket's heritage and history. The 35-acre resort, built on a former tin mine, features industrial chic design and offers a range of amenities, including cooking classes and heritage tours. Na-Ranong, a member of an illustrious local family, credits her father with putting Phuket on the world tourism map. The Slate is part of her family's business, which also includes a real estate company, and she aims to showcase Phuket's unique culture and hidden gems to discerning travelers.

site_title: C&G shares up 25% on back of proposed reverse takeover
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings' shares rose 25% on a proposed reverse takeover deal with India's Sainik-Aryan Group, which aims to acquire three Indonesian coal mining assets valued at S$400 million or more. The deal, subject to due diligence and regulatory approval, will allow C&G to remain listed and acquire a new business with growth potential. The shares closed 0.3 cents higher at S$0.015 on a volume of 7.5 million on the last trading day of the year.

site_title: The human-centred side of design
summary: Design has real value in building and enhancing emotional connections, particularly in the digital age where attention spans have decreased. A human-centred approach to design can solve problems and meet user needs, as seen in examples like Extra Space Asia's "click and collect" model and the DesignSingapore Council's efforts to promote design thinking. Despite its benefits, the value of design remains a topic of discussion, with a disconnect between design's potential and its implementation. To address this, embracing design can help positively impact human engagement and interaction with technology, particularly in Singapore's goal to become an innovation-driven economy and a loveable city through design by 2025.

site_title: CapitaLand's subsidiaries, associates divest stakes in six malls in India; 2 Reits make board changes
summary: CapitaLand's subsidiaries and associates sold their stakes in six Indian malls for S$71.5 million, and the property manager of these malls for S$32.7 million. The transaction is expected to be completed in Q1 2018 with no material impact on CapitaLand's net tangible assets or earnings per share. Meanwhile, changes were announced in the boards of directors of two CapitaLand-sponsored Reits, with new non-executive directors and appointments to key roles.

site_title: India likens cryptocurrencies to Ponzi scheme, cautions investors
summary: India's finance ministry has cautioned investors about the risks of trading in cryptocurrencies, likening them to Ponzi schemes. The ministry stated that digital currency investments are not legal tender, have no regulatory permission, and pose a heightened risk of investment bubbles. Investors are advised to avoid participating in such activities entirely at their risk. The ministry also warned of potential use of cryptocurrencies for illegal activities such as money laundering and terror-funding.

site_title: Singapore's STI ends 2017 at 3,402.92 points, up 18% for the year
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended 2017 at 3,402.92 points, a 18% increase from 2016. On the last trading day of 2017, the STI rose 0.1% to close at 3,402.92 points. About 1.13 billion shares worth S$1.03 billion were traded, with Allied Tech being the most actively traded counter. The year saw 232 gainers for every 184 losers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's domestic bank lending rose 0.6% in November to S$654 billion, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Hyflux plans to distribute shares in its consumer business ahead of a possible listing. The city-state's economy is forecast to expand 2.8% next year, with inflation expected to pick up slowly. Meanwhile, C&G Environmental Protection Holdings agreed to a reverse takeover by India's Sainik-Aryan Group. Singapore's STI index ended the year at 3,402.92 points, up 18% for the year.

site_title: Union Gas signs MOU to buy Semgas Supply's retail business of bottled LPG cylinders
summary: Union Gas Holdings has signed a non-binding MOU to acquire Semgas Supply's retail business of bottled LPG cylinders and sale of LPG-related accessories in Singapore. The acquisition aims to grow Union Gas's distribution network and customer base. The vendor has agreed to refrain from discussing or negotiating with other parties for three months. This deal is part of Union Gas's expansion plans, with Teo Kiang Ang and Alexis Teo, Union Gas's founder and non-executive chairman and executive director and CEO, having shareholding interests in Union Energy Corporation, the vendor's parent company.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat ahead of New Year break
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened unchanged on December 29, 2017, ahead of the New Year break, with London's FTSE 100 closing near a record high. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC remained flat at 12,976.40 and 5,334.51, respectively.

site_title: After Trump criticism, China denies selling oil illicitly to Pyongyang
summary: China denies selling oil illicitly to North Korea, contradicting US President Donald Trump's claim that China has allowed oil to reach the isolated nation. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying stated that a ship suspected of transporting oil to North Korea was not docked at a Chinese port, and that China has always implemented UN Security Council resolutions pertaining to North Korea. China will deal with any violations seriously, according to Hua. The US has proposed blacklisting 10 vessels, including the ship in question, for transporting banned items from North Korea, but China and Russia have asked for more time to consider the proposal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end strong year on upbeat note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the year on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index closing 0.19% higher at 29,919.15, up 36% for the year. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.33% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 0.64%, despite a 3.5% decline in the latter over the past 12 months. The positive performance was attributed to a strong global market trend.

site_title: China temporarily waives taxes to get foreign firms to stay
summary: China has temporarily waived income taxes for foreign companies on profits reinvested in the country to retain foreign firms and investment. The tax exemption applies retroactively from January and is aimed at creating a better investment environment. The move follows the US corporate tax overhaul and aims to encourage foreign investment in key sectors such as manufacturing, services, and research and development. The waiver applies to profits reinvested in these areas, with locations in western China prioritized for development.

site_title: Electricity tariffs to increase by 6.3% in first quarter of 2018
summary: Electricity tariffs in Singapore are set to increase by 6.3% in the first quarter of 2018, due to higher natural gas costs. The average electricity tariff will rise to 21.56 cents per kilowatt hour (kwh), affecting households and resulting in a $4.78 monthly increase for families living in four-room HDB flats. The increase is based on quarterly reviews of energy costs, which now make up 73.5% of the tariff.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index recovers to quarter-century high in 2017
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index reached a quarter-century high in 2017, finishing the year at 22,764.94, up 19.1% from the previous year. This marked the sixth consecutive annual gain, with record rallies on Wall Street and strong performances from Japan Inc contributing to the surge.

site_title: India's richest man bails out brother fueling record rally in Reliance Communications
summary: India's richest man Mukesh Ambani has agreed to buy the assets of his struggling brother Anil Ambani's wireless carrier Reliance Communications, providing a cash infusion to stave off insolvency. The deal includes spectrum, mobile-phone towers, and fiber assets, valued at approximately 250 billion rupees, which will be used to pay down loans. The sale is expected to be closed by March, and shares of Reliance Communications surged 21% following the announcement, amid speculation that the deal would help reduce debt from 450 billion rupees to 60 billion rupees.

site_title: Huawei sees slowest growth in years as it takes on Apple
summary: Huawei reported its slowest revenue growth in years, with a 15% increase to 600 billion yuan (S$123.1 billion) in 2017, down from 32% in 2016. The company shipped 153 million smartphones, making headway against Apple in the global market. However, telecoms spending remains stagnant due to slow network construction, Huawei's biggest source of revenue. Despite this, the company continues to compete with local rivals and Samsung, and is banking on its network business to support its smartphone sales.

site_title: With Hershey gone, Canadian town embraces mantle as pot capital
summary: Smiths Falls, Ontario, has experienced a revival in fortunes since medical marijuana producer Tweed Inc set up shop in an abandoned Hershey Co chocolate factory four years ago. The town, with a population of 8,885, is now recognized as the "pot capital of Canada" and has seen a significant increase in younger people relocating, commercial property interest, and new businesses arriving. The town's largest private-sector employer, Canopy Growth Corp, has become the world's largest publicly traded cannabis producer and is tapping local labor and suppliers.

site_title: China says it created a France-sized pile of new jobs since 2012
summary: China has created over 65 million new jobs in urban areas since 2012, equivalent to the population of France, according to a report by the official Xinhua News Agency. The employment rate for college graduates has exceeded 90% and the urban surveyed jobless rate has dropped to 4.83%, the lowest since 2012. The country aims to maintain this rate at around 5% in 2018, with a projected 13.5 million new jobs created. This news comes as China's economy faces challenges, including efforts to close unprofitable state enterprises and meet environmental goals.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares end 2017 with solid annual gains
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares ended 2017 with solid annual gains, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 7.1% and the S&P/NZX 50 index gaining 22%. The Australian financial index declined for the first time since 2011, while the metals and mining index climbed 22.3%. The best-performing stocks included a2 Milk Company Ltd, which gained 261.3% annually, and BHP Billiton, which rose to its highest close since May 2015.

site_title: Current, former SMRT Trains employees face cheating charges amounting to almost S$10m
summary: Four current and former SMRT Trains employees, including Zulkifli Marwi, Zakaria Mohamed Shariff, Jamalludin Jumari, and Akbar Ali Tambishahib, were charged with cheating in a S$10m contract case. The offences took place between 2007 and 2012, with Jamalludin absconding in 2013 and being brought back to Singapore to face charges. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau stated that cheating employees will face the full brunt of the law, with offenders potentially jailed for up to 10 years and fined. All four men will return to court on January 15, 2018.

site_title: Two decades of Federer, and still going strong
summary: Roger Federer will begin his 21st professional season at the Hopman Cup in Perth, Australia, partnering Belinda Bencic in the mixed teams tournament. The 36-year-old Swiss tennis star had a remarkable 2017, winning five titles and reaching number two in the world, with a record eighth Wimbledon title. He will face American Jack Sock and German Alexander Zverev, who had a breakthrough year, winning five titles and beating Federer once. The Hopman Cup will serve as preparation for Federer's Australian Open title defense on January 15.

images.alt_text: The amazing Roger Federer will embark on his 21st professional season when he leads Switzerland in the mixed teams Hopman Cup starting in Perth on Saturday.

site_title: Bitcoin holds above US$14,000 as investors find a bottom, for now
summary: Bitcoin prices rose above US$14,000, rebounding from an 8% drop the previous day, as investors found a temporary bottom. The cryptocurrency had slumped 24% from its record high of US$19,511 due to concerns over speculation and a new futures contract. South Korea's efforts to curb speculation have limited trading volume. Analysts predict a continued downward trend, with potential support levels at US$13,500 and last week's lows around US$12,400.

site_title: South Korea seizes Hong Kong ship for oil transfer to North: Seoul
summary: South Korea briefly seized and inspected a Hong Kong-registered ship, Lighthouse Winmore, for transferring oil products to a North Korean vessel, breaching UN sanctions. The ship, chartered by a Taiwanese company, transferred cargo to the North Korean vessel on October 19, in international waters. South Korean customs authorities took action on November 24, following intelligence sharing with the US. The incident marks a case of North Korea evading sanctions, and the ship's actions will be reported to the UN Security Council sanctions committee.

site_title: Trump's tax overhaul may 'punish' foreign banks with US units
summary: A provision in the US tax overhaul, intended to prevent American companies from shifting profits abroad, may also impact foreign banks with significant US operations, potentially increasing their US tax liability. The Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax (BEAT) provision counts payments made by US businesses to related companies abroad, which could exaggerate US income for foreign banks with US subsidiaries. The US Treasury may provide guidance to eliminate the BEAT disadvantage for banks, but some experts argue that the provision could "punish" big banks.

images.alt_text: The tax overhaul signed into law on Dec 22 by President Donald Trump contains a raft of new rules, including a cut in the corporate tax rate to 21 per cent from 35 per cent and reductions in individual levies across the board.

site_title: Hot stock: C&G Environmental shares surge 25% after reverse takeover proposal
summary: C&G Environmental shares surged 25% following a proposed reverse takeover deal with the Sindhu family, who control India's Sainik-Aryan Group. The deal aims to acquire Indonesian coal mining assets valued at S$400 million or more. The company plans to acquire control of three mining assets and will receive new shares priced at no less than S$0.50 per share. The deal is subject to due diligence, regulatory, and shareholder approval.

site_title: China clampdown on overseas deals crimps Asia Pacific M&A volumes in 2017
summary: China's clampdown on overseas deals led to a 46% decline in its outbound M&A investments to $140 billion in 2017, the lowest in two years. The slowdown was attributed to increased scrutiny of cross-border investments and capital controls, which affected sectors such as real estate and media. Asia Pacific M&A volumes fell 4.3% to $1.08 trillion, with regional dealmakers expecting a cautious recovery in 2018, driven by deals in the $1 billion-$3 billion range.

site_title: Woman who swallowed over 1kg of cocaine held at Phuket airport
summary: A 27-year-old woman from the Ivory Coast was arrested at Phuket airport in Thailand after an X-ray revealed over 1kg of cocaine in her stomach. The woman, believed to be a "mule" for West African smugglers, had 60 small packets of cocaine bound for wealthy clients in Bangkok. This is part of a larger issue of cocaine trafficking in Thailand, where the porous borders and air links make it a popular transit stop. The country has the world's sixth-largest prison population due to harsh drug laws, with more than 70% of convicts jailed on drug-related offenses.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session on higher ground; STI at 3,403.25
summary: Singapore stocks opened the afternoon session on a higher note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,403.25, up 0.1% or 4.15 points. Trading volume was high, with 634 million shares worth S$646.8 million traded. Allied Technologies and Jiutian Chemical Group were among the top gainers, while SingTel and United Overseas Bank were among the top losers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Gold heading for best year since 2010
summary: Gold prices have reached their highest level since 2010, driven by a weaker US dollar and safe-haven buying amid global political uncertainties. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,295.36 an ounce, with the dollar index down over 9% for the year, its largest annual loss since 2003. Analysts attribute the surge to technically-driven momentum and the US dollar downtrend, with gold expected to have its best year since 2010 and its best month since August.

site_title: South Korea students dive into virtual coins, even as regulators crack down
summary: In South Korea, a growing number of young students are investing in virtual currencies, despite warnings from regulators and concerns about security and thefts. A recent club at Sungkyunkwan University in Seoul has over a dozen members who share tips and strategies on investing in cryptocurrencies, with some reporting significant gains. The trend is driven by a dismal economic outlook and the desire for quick profits, but experts warn that it may be a "Ponzi scheme" and that true value is still unknown.

images.alt_text: Hackers have stolen millions, lawmakers are pushing for new taxes and regulations, and a leading financial official has called them a "Ponzi scheme".

site_title: Australia expected to ease visa restrictions on foreign pilots as planes left grounded
summary: Australia is expected to ease visa restrictions on foreign pilots in January, following a national shortage that has left planes grounded and flights cancelled. The move aims to address a global shortage of pilots and alleviate pressure on domestic carriers. With 3% of domestic flights cancelled in November, the government's decision is seen as a relief to rural travellers. The relaxation of visa restrictions will allow foreign pilots to work in Australia for two years, addressing concerns from the aviation industry and opposition parties.

site_title: Hong Kong property market shatters price records for 13th straight month
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 1.08% in November, marking the 13th consecutive month of record-breaking growth. The 13.1% year-on-year increase is the fastest pace since June. The city's flats are among the most expensive globally, with 1 million US dollars only able to buy 200 square feet of prime property. Analysts expect the rise to continue into next year, solidifying Hong Kong's position as one of the world's most expensive property markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares began the day with a 0.17% gain, extending a two-day rally and ending the year on a positive note. The Hang Seng Index rose to 29,914.05, while the Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower.

site_title: China's IMAX rival aiming for No 1 spot with government backing
summary: China Film Digital Giant Screen (CGS), a state-backed cinema provider, aims to surpass IMAX as the top premium large format brand in China by 2019. With a network of 288 screens in China, CGS plans to expand globally, including in Hong Kong, Las Vegas, and Indonesia. The company's flexible business model allows theatre operators to retain a bigger share of ticket sales, differing from IMAX's revenue-sharing model. China's film market is expected to overtake the US in box office revenue by 2020.

site_title: New NUS, NTU presidents among 3 new board members for A*Star in 2018
summary: The Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) will have three new board members in 2018, with Professor Tan Eng Chye and Professor Subra Suresh joining on January 1, the same day they take office as National University of Singapore and Nanyang Technological University presidents, respectively. Dr. Josephine Kwa will join on February 1, replacing outgoing members. Dr. Tatsumi Yamazaki will be re-appointed to the board on February 1.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: US oil prices climb to highest since mid-2015 on surprise output drop
summary: US oil prices rose to their highest levels since mid-2015, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures reaching $60.16 a barrel and Brent crude futures reaching $66.49 a barrel. The price increase was driven by a surprise drop in US oil production to 9.754 million barrels per day and a fall in commercial crude inventories. Opec and Russia's production cuts also supported oil prices, which are expected to remain tight in 2018 due to healthy demand growth.

site_title: India's Reliance Jio to buy RCom's wireless assets in 240b-rupee deal: sources
summary: Reliance Communications (RCom) has agreed to sell its wireless assets to Reliance Jio Infocomm for nearly 240 billion rupees (S$5.02 billion). The deal aims to help RCom cut down its debt, which led to record lows and creditor insolvency proceedings. The sale will also mark the return of telecom operations to Reliance Industries, controlled by Mukesh Ambani's elder brother. The deal will give Jio access to spectrum, towers, fibre optic networks, and a subscriber base of close to 140 million.

site_title: GM wins ruling that could narrow ignition switch litigation
summary: General Motors (GM) has won a court ruling that could reduce private litigation over flawed vehicle ignition switches linked to 124 deaths. US District Judge Jesse Furman dismissed expert testimony alleging the switches caused accidents, citing a lack of evidence of "double switch rotation." The ruling affects 213 cases involving airbag deployments, leaving 1,723 unresolved claims. GM has already paid over $2.6 billion in penalties and settlements related to the defect.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co on Thursday won a court ruling that could reduce the private litigation it faces over flawed vehicle ignition switches, which have been linked to 124 deaths and triggered a big recall.

site_title: Oil resurrection sets stage for another Opec-shale clash in 2018
summary: Oil prices ended 2017 with a second annual gain, rising over 11% for the year, driven by Opec and Russian output cuts and geopolitical tensions. Benchmark futures reached a 2-year high, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) at $60.15 a barrel, amid a decline in inventory levels. However, US shale growth is expected to increase output in 2018, potentially undermining Opec's curbs, and investors will watch for the "tug-of-war" between Opec and US shale.

site_title: Stocks to watch: C&G, Soilbuild Business Space Reit, QAF
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings has entered a S$400 million reverse takeover deal with Param Mitra Coal Resources. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's trustee has signed a S$55 million deal to divest a property. Breadmaker QAF has decided to cease its loss-making Chinese bakery operations. QAF's group financial controller Derrick Lum is resigning, with Derrick Lum being replaced by a former financial controller at M&L Hospitality.

site_title: Twelve dead in New York City apartment fire: mayor
summary: Twelve people, including an infant, were killed in a fire in a New York City apartment building in the Bronx, with four critically injured. The blaze, described as a four-alarm fire, occurred on the third floor of a five-story building around 7pm on Thursday. Few details were immediately available, but officials said the tragedy was "historic in its magnitude." Mayor Bill de Blasio expressed condolences, urging New Yorkers to hold their families close and pray for those affected.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher ahead of holidays
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.19% in the final trading session of 2017, tracking US record highs. The Nikkei 225 index reached 22,827.59, while the Topix index edged up 0.17%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Coffee, tea or bikini? VietJet stands by racy calendar in face of criticism
summary: VietJet Aviation has defended its "bikini" calendar, which features scantily clad female models, amid criticism from conservative South-east Asia and beyond. The airline's managing director, Luu Duc Khanh, said the calendar promotes free choice and emphasizes the right to wear whatever people want. Critics argue the image sexualizes airline staff and undermines efforts to combat harassment and assault. VietJet's marketing push has contributed to its rapid growth, taking market share from Vietnam Airlines. The airline plans to introduce male models in its next calendar, citing a desire to change the content.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.6% in November: MAS
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.6% in November, weaker than the 1.4% gain in October. Domestic lending increased to S$654 billion, with business loans growing 0.5% to S$393 billion and consumer loans increasing 0.9% to S$261 billion. This marked a 7.1% year-on-year increase, stronger than the 6.8% growth in October.

site_title: In Saudi crackdown, there's more than Alwaleed's empire at stake
summary: Saudi Arabia's corruption crackdown, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has resulted in at least $100 billion in assets being seized. Dozens of former officials and businessmen have settled their cases by exchanging wealth for freedom. However, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a key figure, is resisting demands that could see him relinquish control of his conglomerate, Kingdom Holding Co. The case's outcome will define the crackdown for Western investors and highlight the government's motives, with some analysts suggesting it's a shakedown to boost state coffers.

site_title: SoftBank's Masayoshi Son: From chicken feed to Japan's richest tycoon
summary: Masayoshi Son, founder of Japanese telecoms giant SoftBank, has become Japan's richest man with an estimated fortune of $22.2 billion. Under his leadership, SoftBank has embarked on a spree of purchases, including a 15% stake in ride-sharing app Uber, and launched a $100 billion venture capital fund, the Vision Fund. Son's aggressive strategy has dominated the tech world, and he has also invested in various sectors, including solar power and robotics. Born in 1957 to ethnic Korean parents in Japan, Son rose from humble beginnings, collecting leftover food for cattle as a child, to become a successful businessman.

site_title: Uber's SoftBank deal may smooth road ahead for scarred startup
summary: Uber Technologies has agreed to sell a significant stake to SoftBank Group, led by Masayoshi Son, in a deal worth about $48 billion. The investment will provide new cash for the company and prevent SoftBank from investing in rival Lyft. The deal also brings SoftBank two seats on the board and supports new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi, solidifying his leadership. The transaction is expected to close in January and will give early investors the chance to cash out, while SoftBank gains a strategic stake in the company.

images.alt_text: Technology billionaire Masayoshi Son just hitched a ride with Uber. But it's the ride-hailing company that's starting what it hopes is a new, less-bumpy journey.

site_title: Australian dollar set to seal best year since 2010, NZ$ lags
summary: The Australian dollar is on track for its best annual performance in seven years, with gains of over 8% for 2017, driven by strong commodity prices and optimism for global growth. The currency has reached a 10-week high of US$0.7810, surpassing analysts' expectations. However, some experts warn that the Aussie's resilience may be short-lived, as US interest rates are expected to rise, potentially moving against the currency. In contrast, the New Zealand dollar has also gained 2.3% for the year, despite a bout of political uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stock market opens barely changed on last trading day of 2017
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) started the last trading day of 2017 flat, up 0.18 point or 0.01% at 3,399.28. Trading volume was 148.1 million units worth S$425.1 million. The day followed overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Triyards sinks into US$162.5m full-year loss with two shipbuilding contracts cancelled
summary: Triyards Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore marine firm, reported a full-year loss of US$162.5 million due to the cancellation of two shipbuilding contracts worth US$51 million. The company cited funding issues as the reason for the project delays, and loan-repayment problems pose a threat to its going-concern status. Triyards' Vietnam facility, Saigon Offshore Fabrication and Engineering Ltd, received termination notices from the customer for US$10.2 million in reimbursements.

site_title: Australia shares set for downbeat end to cheery 2017; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, marking a downbeat end to 2017, which saw the benchmark index rise 7.5% for the year, its best performance in four years. Investors took profits ahead of the long weekend and ahead of a potential US rate hike in January. Financial stocks, particularly banks, led the decline, with Westpac Banking Corp falling 1.1%. Meanwhile, materials stocks rose to their highest levels since 2013, driven by copper and aluminium price gains.

site_title: China Aircraft to buy 50 Airbus jets valued at US$5.42b
summary: China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Ltd agreed to buy 50 Airbus SE single-aisle airliners valued at US$5.42 billion to meet surging air travel demand in China, which is expected to surpass the US as the world's largest aviation market by 2022. The transaction, which includes significant price concessions, is part of a flying boom that will require China to order 7,240 new planes by 2036. This deal brings China Aircraft Leasing's total order book to 252 aircraft, with deliveries expected in stages starting in 2023.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 1.59 points to 1,780.65. The index saw 116 gainers for every 68 losers, with a total volume of 94.91 million lots worth RM41.83 million.

site_title: C&G Env agrees to reverse takeover by India's Sainik-Aryan Group
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings has agreed to a S$400 million reverse takeover deal with Param Mitra Coal Resources Pte Ltd, backed by India's Sainik-Aryan Group, a coal energy company. C&G, now a cash company, will allot new shares to Param Mitra Coal Resources. The deal aims to provide an opportunity for C&G to remain listed and acquire a new business with growth potential, focused on mining and trading of thermal coals in Indonesia.

site_title: UN bars four North Korean ships from international ports
summary: The UN Security Council has barred four North Korean ships from international ports, bringing the total number of blocked ships to eight. The US requested the ban, which was accepted by China, targeting ships with North Korean flags. US President Donald Trump criticized China for allowing oil to reach North Korea, calling it "caught red-handed." The ban is part of international efforts to curb North Korea's missile and nuclear programs, following three sets of UN sanctions in 2017.

site_title: US dollar wallows near 1-month low, commodity currencies supported
summary: The US dollar hit a one-month low against a basket of currencies, falling 0.4% overnight to 92.659, its lowest since November 27. The dollar is expected to lose 0.5% this month and potentially 9% for the year, its worst performance since 2003. The yen strengthened against the dollar, while the euro and Australian dollar reached two-month highs due to firmer commodity prices. The Canadian dollar also surged, boosted by a rise in crude oil, and is on track for a 2.5% monthly gain.

site_title: Ravi Menon's loud global finance revolution: Gadfly commentary
summary: Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, is leading a global finance revolution with his audacious makeover of Singapore's financial system. Menon's approach involves creating "regulatory sandboxes" to foster experimentation in fintech, while ensuring safety and compliance. He aims to shine a light on Singapore as a hub for regulatory comfort, and the city-state is now home to a thriving fintech and regtech ecosystem, with 25,000 participants from 100 countries attending its second fintech festival in November.

site_title: EasyJet's new CEO aims to follow McCall with 13% boost in passengers
summary: EasyJet's new CEO, Johan Lundgren, aims to increase passengers by 13% in 2018, reaching 90 million travellers. Lundgren plans to widen links with other airlines and test a hybrid-power plane. The airline will also expand its transfer programme with long-haul carriers and purchase assets in Air Berlin's liquidation, increasing its fleet to over 300 single-aisle Airbus planes. Lundgren succeeds Carolyn McCall, who is set to join ITV after stepping down at the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore braces for taxes, central bank tightening, trade talks
summary: Singapore is preparing for potential tax increases and monetary policy tightening in 2018 amid steady economic growth and benign inflation. The economy is expected to expand 2.8% next year, with inflation forecast to pick up slowly. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is considering tightening its policy stance, with some economists predicting a move as early as April. The government is also expected to raise taxes, with the goods and services tax potentially being increased. Trade will remain a priority, with Singapore aiming to boost intra-regional trade.

site_title: Netflix's cash bonuses become salary thanks to new tax plan
summary: Netflix is replacing its cash bonuses for top executives with guaranteed salary payments, following the Republican tax plan's elimination of performance-based bonus deductions for managers earning over $1 million. The change affects executives like Reed Hastings, David Wells, and Ted Sarandos, who will now receive full salary payments regardless of the company's performance. This shift comes after Netflix implemented cash bonuses in 2015 to take advantage of tax deductions.

images.alt_text: Netflix Inc's top executives will now get paid in full no matter how the company does, thanks to the Republican tax plan.

site_title: SoftBank succeeds in tender offer for big stake in Uber
summary: A consortium led by SoftBank Group Corp successfully completed a tender offer to buy a significant stake in Uber Technologies Inc, valuing the ride-services firm at $48 billion. The deal, which includes a $1.25 billion investment, will trigger changes in Uber's governance structure, expanding its board from 11 to 17 members. SoftBank will own approximately 17.5% of Uber, while the company will use the investment to support technology investments, fuel growth, and strengthen corporate governance. The deal marks a significant victory for new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi and provides much-needed funding for the struggling company.

site_title: Japan's factories, retailers rev up; some in BOJ urge debate on rates
summary: Japan's economy is experiencing its best growth in a decade, with industrial production and retail sales showing significant increases. Factories are producing memory chips and semiconductor equipment, and consumers are spending more on electronics and cars. This strong growth has prompted some Bank of Japan (BOJ) board members to debate the possibility of reducing stimulus and raising interest rates. However, inflation remains low, and the BOJ governor has stated that rates will not be raised until inflation reaches the 2% target.

site_title: Europe: Shares drift into year-end as resources stocks glitter
summary: European shares drifted lower on Thursday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index falling 0.3% and the euro zone blue chips slipping 0.7%. The resources-heavy FTSE 100 index ended flat, supported by a rally in commodity prices. Tech stocks fell 0.8% despite a 19% gain for the year, and volumes were muted due to the holiday season. The year saw a positive performance for European stocks, with the Stoxx 600 up 8% in 2017.

site_title: For expats, health and wellbeing matter as much as job prospects
summary: A recent Cigna survey found that expats in Singapore have lower perceptions of their well-being compared to Asian counterparts, particularly in family, physical, and financial well-being. Despite high job satisfaction and economic outlook, expats in Singapore are concerned about their children's and parents' health, finances, and social aspects of life. Only 14% believe they can take care of their children's health, and 11% can care for their parents' finances. The survey highlights the need for employers to prioritize health benefits and wellbeing for expats and their families.

site_title: Apple apologises for slowing iPhones, offers discounted batteries
summary: Apple has apologized for slowing down older iPhone models and offered discounted battery replacements for affected customers. The company acknowledged a feature that aimed to prevent shutdowns due to weak batteries, but admitted that it may have unintentionally reduced performance. Apple will discount battery replacements from $79 to $29 for iPhone 6 and later models, and issue a software update to help customers identify aging batteries. The move comes after an uproar from customers and lawsuits over the battery issues.

site_title: Epson, Apple face French legal pressure over planned obsolescence
summary: French prosecutors have launched an investigation into Epson over alleged planned obsolescence in its products, following a complaint by the association Stop Planned Obsolescence. The probe, led by anti-trust and consumer protection specialists, could lead to the first prosecution for the crime if evidence is found. The investigation comes after Epson was accused of tricking consumers into replacing ink cartridges before they were empty. The case is seen as a test of landmark consumer legislation passed in 2015, which made planned obsolescence illegal and punishable by fines up to 5% of annual sales.

site_title: Land of the freeze: arctic wave hits northern United States
summary: An arctic blast brought record lows to the US Northeast and Midwest, with temperatures expected to remain frigid through the New Year's holiday. A cold front dumped up to 1m of snow in parts of Washington state and the northern Rocky Mountains. The National Weather Service issued wind chill advisories and warnings in areas including New England, northern Pennsylvania, and New York, with temperatures expected to drop below 10°F. The coldest spot recorded was Tioga, North Dakota, at -26°C, and some areas, like Erie, Pennsylvania, were expecting additional lake-effect snow.

site_title: Small RBS investors renew push to set up shareholder committee
summary: Small investors in Royal Bank of Scotland are pushing for a shareholder committee to improve corporate governance after a previous bid failed. Over 100 investors, including ShareSoc and the UK Shareholders' Association, are proposing the creation of a committee that includes shareholder representatives. The proposal aims to improve investor engagement and criticizes the current informal nature of the bank's deliberations. The RBS board must decide whether to include the proposal at the next annual general meeting, where it would be voted on by shareholders, with the British government's backing needed for it to pass.

images.alt_text: Small investors in Royal Bank of Scotland are launching a second attempt to force the state-backed lender to set up a shareholder committee to improve corporate governance after a first bid failed earlier this year.

site_title: US: Dow drifts to fresh record after quiet session
summary: US stocks reached a fresh record on Thursday, driven by a quiet trading session. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 24,837.51, a 0.3% gain. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the S&P 500 up 0.2% and the Nasdaq at 6,950.16. The robust year for US stocks is attributed to an improving labour market, tax cut plan, and economic growth. Analysts expect additional records in 2018, but some predict a return of volatility.

site_title: Airbus ready to axe A380 if it fails to win Emirates deal: sources
summary: Airbus is preparing to phase out production of the A380 superjumbo jet if it fails to secure a key order from Emirates, with the airline having 142 aircraft on order. The A380 has struggled with weak demand, with Airbus having developed the plane at a cost of 11 billion euros. Talks between Airbus and Emirates over a new order for 36 aircraft broke down at the Dubai Airshow, but negotiations have resumed. A deal would be a significant boost for the A380, but Airbus is reluctant to keep factories open without certainty of a bulk order from Emirates.

site_title: The Greatest Showman is not that great
summary: The musical biopic "The Greatest Showman" receives mixed reviews, with its upbeat and catchy songs and choreography overshadowing its unconvincing characters and narrative. The film takes creative liberties with the life of PT Barnum, founder of the circus, and is heavily sanitized for a modern audience. Despite Hugh Jackman's performance, the movie feels like standard holiday fare, easily consumed but easily forgotten. The musical segments, written by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, are central to the film's feel-good core, but lack real depth.

images.alt_text: Hugh Jackman as circus founder Phineas Taylor Barnum.
Hugh Jackman as circus founder Phineas Taylor Barnum.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes blockbuster China tech IPO queue, led by Xiaomi
summary: Hong Kong is poised to host a series of blockbuster IPOs from Chinese technology firms, including Xiaomi and Lufax, with a total market capitalization of $500 billion over the next two years. This could set up a showdown with New York, which has traditionally hosted the world's hottest new-economy companies. Hong Kong's blue-chip Hang Seng Index has gained 35% this year, its best performance since 2009, as the city seeks to revive its appeal as a hub for Chinese tech listings.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong bankers are eyeing a slew of blockbuster IPOs from Chinese technology firms with a total market capitalisation of some US$500 billion over the next two years, in a sharp contrast to 2017 - the city's worst year for raising equity in a decade.

site_title: Hyflux to distribute shares in consumer business ahead of possible listing
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, plans to distribute 70% of its shares in Hyfluxshop Holdings, its consumer business, to existing shareholders in exchange for one Hyfluxshop share for every 10 Hyflux shares held. The move aims to enable the company to potentially list Hyfluxshop on a recognized stock exchange. The distribution is expected to amount to a $14 million payout to shareholders and will allow them to hold direct shareholdings in two distinct entities. The proposed listing is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting scheduled for February 1, 2018.

site_title: VW to try to block emissions audit in constitutional court
summary: Volkswagen AG plans to petition Germany's constitutional court to block an emissions audit, citing a violation of its fundamental rights. The lower court appointed an auditor to investigate management's actions in the "Dieselgate" scandal, which Volkswagen views as a victory for shareholder groups seeking to establish if executives withheld market-moving information. Volkswagen aims to suspend the auditor's work before the constitutional court hearing, arguing that the lower court's ruling was a violation of its rights. The company believes its management complied with German disclosure rules.

site_title: 665°F makes the cut
summary: 665°F Restaurant at Andaz Singapore offers a stylish dining experience, capturing the concept of fire and meat in a unique setting. The food is promising, with standouts including lobster bisque, crab cakes, and lamb chops, although some dishes, like the ribeye, lack tenderness. Vegetables are underutilized, with only asparagus cooked in the oven. The restaurant has potential, but its limitations, such as portioned desserts, hold it back from reaching its full potential. Rating: 6.5/10.

site_title: Investors sing 'My Reit will go on'
summary: Singaporean investors have found a strong affinity for real estate investment trusts (Reits), with the FTSE ST Reit Index reaching its highest level since May 2013. Reits continue to offer yields of 5-6%, significantly higher than benchmark 10-year Singapore government bonds. Despite global economic concerns, investors remain attracted to steady income streams, with notable gains in Reits like Ascendas Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and Mapletree Logistics Trust. Fund manager Schroders notes that only Japan presents a case for value among major markets, while others are expensive relative to their 15-year averages.

site_title: Oil prices near mid-2015 highs on strong China data, tighter 2018 outlook
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by strong data from China, which lifted WTI crude futures to $59.82 a barrel, a 0.3% gain. Brent crude futures also broke through $67 a barrel, the first time since May 2015. The tight market, fueled by Opec and Russia's production cuts, is expected to continue, with traders citing regional chaos and disorder, including pipeline outages in Libya and the North Sea, as underpinning prices.

site_title: Noble raises stake in Mongolian railway firm
summary: Noble Group has acquired an additional 10% stake in Northern Mongolian Railways Limited (NMRL) for US$1.4 million, raising its total stake to 20%. The deal strengthens Noble's position in the Mongolian market and supports the development of Aspire's coal and railway projects. This comes as Noble is in talks with creditors to restructure its US$1.1 billion debt, with its chairman expecting a proposal from creditors in the near future.

site_title: No Signboard's full-year earnings fall 1.3%
summary: No Signboard Holdings Limited, a Singapore-based food and beverage group, reported a 1.3% drop in full-year earnings to S$7.7 million, down from S$7.8 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 7.3% to S$24.4 million. Restaurant sales fell 6.3% to S$21.3 million, but average customer spend increased by 10.6% to S$104 per customer. The group's beer business, acquired in June 2017, generated S$3.1 million in sales.

site_title: Keppel acts against employees involved in unit's Brazil bribery case
summary: Keppel has taken disciplinary action against employees involved in a bribery scandal at its rig-building unit in Brazil, including financial penalties. The company has also separated with the executives deemed "relevant individuals" in the graft probe. This move comes after a statement of facts was released by the authorities.

site_title: Asian blockbusters and more for 2018
summary: mm2, a homegrown film production and distribution company, announced an eclectic slate of Asian titles for the first two months of 2018. Chen Kaige's epic fantasy film "Legend of the Demon Cat" will be released on January 4, followed by Indonesia's highest-grossing film "Pengabdi Setan" on January 18. Other releases include "Shuttle Life" on January 25 and "Wonderful! Liang Xi Mei" in February, starring local comedian Jack Neo. The company also announced "Detective Chinatown 2" for February, the sequel to a 2015 hit.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: US inflation mystery made economists look bad in 2017
summary: In 2017, economists failed to accurately forecast inflation and unemployment rates, with only one prediction coming within 0.3 percentage points of actual results. Despite expecting low inflation, joblessness remained at 4.1% due to strong job gains. The "mystery" of low inflation led economists to reevaluate their forecasting methods, with some suggesting it may be a new paradigm. The 2017 results may influence 2018 forecasts, particularly if the low inflation trend continues.

site_title: At Perfumarie, let your nose do the picking
summary: Mindy Yang, founder of Perfumarie, a "meta-discovery studio" in SoHo, has created a unique fragrance shopping experience where customers can smell perfumes without knowing the brand or price. The store features 32 identical fragrance taps, each containing a mystery perfume, with customers encouraged to sniff and take notes. After selecting two favorites, they can try them on the skin and take home a 5ml sample. Yang aims to empower customers to trust their noses and create a community of fragrance lovers, with over 600 members already registered for her Explorer's Club.

site_title: IRS sets limited conditions for prepayment of property taxes
summary: The IRS has set limited conditions for prepaying 2018 property taxes, allowing taxpayers who have received a tax assessment to make payment by December 31. However, those who have already paid estimated property taxes without an assessment for 2018 may face confusion. The tax bill limits the state and local tax deduction to $10,000 and bans prepayment of local and state income taxes, leaving the prepayment of property taxes unclear until the IRS releases guidance. This decision has added to the scramble among taxpayers to prepay property taxes before the deadline.

site_title: Who's on the rise, and where we're at in BT Weekend
summary: A spotlight on 8 enterprising individuals in Singapore, including a music entrepreneur and a cultural entrepreneur, who are set to make an impact in 2018. The article also covers various topics such as the Singapore economy, art scene in Kuala Lumpur, and fashion trends. Additionally, it features articles on the state of the economy, sports, and car reviews.

site_title: Financial oil trading booming, especially in US
summary: Financial oil trading is booming, with US contracts outpacing growth elsewhere, driven by the US shale oil boom. Trading volumes for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) front-month futures reached a record of nearly 150 million in 2017, more than double the 71 million trades for spot Brent futures. The trend is expected to continue, with US crude output nearing 10 million barrels per day, as producers use derivative markets to lock in profits and hedge against rising prices.

site_title: Clock ticking on third phase of Brexit as 2018 dawns
summary: The UK is beginning formal Brexit negotiations, marking the start of the third chapter in the UK's exit saga from the EU. The UK and EU have agreed on a preliminary deal on divorce issues, paving the way for discussions on transitional arrangements and a new trade deal. The EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, has proposed a framework deal by October 2018 and ratification within four to five months. However, the timeline is tight, and the outcome is uncertain, with some stakeholders predicting a one-in-three chance of no final agreement emerging. The stakes are high, with a smooth departure crucial for both the UK and EU amid global geopolitical turbulence.

site_title: Brighter economic outlook for 2018, but concerns remain
summary: Singapore's economy staged a dramatic turnaround in 2017, growing at its fastest pace in almost half a decade, driven by a surge in manufacturing and exports. The manufacturing sector expanded around 11% in 2017, and the export recovery prompted trade promotion agency IE Singapore to revise its forecast for non-oil domestic exports (Nodx) upwards. While concerns remain about the trade-driven lift being short-lived, economists expect growth to moderate in 2018, driven by a broadening recovery in the services sector, which makes up two-thirds of the economy.

site_title: US dollar slips to 4-week low
summary: The US dollar fell to a four-week low against a basket of currencies, dropping as much as half a percent to its weakest since December 1. The dollar has dropped over 9% this year, its biggest annual slide since 2003, due to worries about US President Trump's policies and other countries' tightening monetary conditions. The US 10-year Treasury yield fell to 2.437%, highlighting concerns about growth prospects for 2018. The euro rose to its highest in a month, and sterling gained a two-week high against the dollar.

site_title: Asean, India to celebrate silver jubilee of partnership in 2018
summary: Singapore will host two major events in January, including the India-Singapore/Asean Entrepreneurship Bridge (InSpreneur) and Pravasi Bharatiya Divas (PBD), ahead of a commemorative summit in India on January 26, marking 25 years of dialogue partnership between Asean and India. The events will focus on startups, fintech, and economic cooperation, with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi set to host the summit attended by all 10 Asean leaders, including Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Hillview, Sengkang private housing sites up for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched two private housing sites in Sengkang Central and Hillview Rise for public tender as part of the second half 2017 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LHN raises HK$79.8 million in its dual-listing in Hong Kong, with plans to use HK$46.5 million to expand its space optimisation business and the rest for general working capital and logistics operations. QAF Limited ceases its bakery operations in China and announces changes to its leadership. SMJ International Holdings rebrands and makes board changes. CWG International is set to receive a conditional cash offer from ELIDOM Investment, which owns 81.1% of the company's shares.

site_title: CapitaLand, Lum Chang buy Frankfurt office building for 234.3m euros in cash
summary: A joint venture between CapitaLand and Lum Chang Holdings has acquired the Main Airport Center office building in Frankfurt for 234.3 million euros (S$375.1 million) in cash. The freehold, multi-tenanted building will be CapitaLand's first office building in Germany, with an agreed value of 245 million euros and 84% occupancy. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity to capitalize on Germany's positive economic outlook and rising demand for commercial real estate.

site_title: Malaysia's rosy economy a winner in election year
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to continue its growth trajectory in 2018, driven by domestic demand and exports, with a projected 5.1% real GDP growth. The dominant theme in the country is the upcoming 14th General Election, which could be a deciding factor in the ruling party's victory. The government's fiscal stance is expected to tighten after the election, while the central bank is likely to hike interest rates to mitigate financial risks. The ringgit is expected to appreciate, but the country's reliance on foreign capital and potential economic slowdowns could pose risks.

images.alt_text: Analysts say the base case is for Prime Minister Najib Razak and his Barisan Nasional coalition to remain in power after the elections. If he loses, it could spell a negative for growth and fiscal accounts.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: Apple CEO gets 74% bonus boost
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a 74% bonus boost, totaling US$9.33 million, as the company posted higher revenue and net income for fiscal 2017. His total payout for the year was about US$102 million, including a salary of US$3.06 million and a previously disclosed equity award of US$89.2 million. Cook's top executives also received significant bonuses, with each receiving about US$24.2 million in total compensation.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc chief executive officer Tim Cook received a 74 per cent increase in his annual bonus for fiscal 2017 as the iPhone maker posted higher revenue and net income, after a rare decline a year earlier.

site_title: Offeror exercises right of compulsory acquisition for rest of shares in Poh Tiong Choon Logistics, plans delisting
summary: Respond Logistics, backed by PTC Logistics chairman Poh Choon Ann and Tower Capital Logistics, has exercised its right of compulsory acquisition to acquire all remaining shares of Poh Tiong Choon Logistics (PTC Logistics) at S$1.30 per share. The company plans to privatize PTC Logistics and delist it from the market, with the exact delisting date to be announced. This move will make PTC Logistics a wholly owned subsidiary of Respond Logistics.

site_title: UPS to return record amount of packages
summary: UPS is on track to return a record number of packages this holiday shipping season, with over 1 million returns daily in December. This surge in e-commerce purchases, combined with a record-breaking peak shipping season, has resulted in a 8% increase in returns compared to last year. The company expects to deliver 750 million packages globally during the peak shipping season, a 40 million increase over the previous year. This indicates a strong demand for online shopping and a significant increase in e-commerce purchases over the holiday season.

site_title: Brexit is not all doom and gloom from a Singapore perspective
summary: Brexit has sparked mixed reviews, but from a Singapore perspective, there are opportunities despite uncertainty. Consumer confidence in the UK has not dropped significantly, and foreign direct investment (FDI) in the UK rose significantly after the Brexit referendum. Singapore companies can tap into the UK's e-commerce market, which remains a significant end market, and consider investments in logistics assets to maintain inventory levels. Tourism and hospitality also received a boost, with the UK being a top global tourist destination. Despite Brexit-related challenges, London remains a leading business hub in Europe, attracting global capital and talent.

site_title: Start weekends earlier with The Business Times
summary: The Business Times will start publishing its Weekend Magazine on Friday, January 5, 2018, offering a head start on leisure reading. The magazine will cover lifestyle trends, including food, shopping, and art, and will be available free with the Friday edition of the newspaper. A new weekend edition of The Business Times, featuring a bigger investing section and other content, will also be launched on January 6, 2018. The changes aim to cater to the lifestyle needs of business professionals who work hard and play equally hard.

site_title: Enterprises need to put digital at top of 2018 agenda
summary: Singapore prepares to enter 2018 with a focus on digital transformation, driven by technological change and its far-reaching effects on the enterprise landscape. Enterprises must be nimble to face challenges and accelerate change through digital transformation, leveraging technologies such as AI, IoT, and machine learning. A recent study shows that 60% of executives believe they are behind in their digital transformation goals, with 20% of CEOs potentially failing to act. Digital transformation is expected to significantly impact revenue growth, with AI having the potential to boost Singapore's annual growth rate from 3.2% to 5.4% by 2035.

site_title: For Oceanus minorities, relief comes too late
summary: Oceanus Group, the world's largest land-based abalone producer, has escaped a financial crisis with its debt-restructuring exercise. The company issued 19.7 billion new shares to clear 85% of its debt, providing S$6 million in fresh capital. Oceanus expects to be debt-free and net cash positive by the end of 2017, thanks to a strategic shift in its business model, which now focuses on being a hatchery rather than a sea-farm. The company's share price has come a long way, from being worth barely a cent to a peak of S$2 billion, but its recent financial struggles have left minority shareholders with a roller-coaster ride of emotions.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Medical aid group makes the trek to Gabon's 'poorest of the poorest'
summary: A medical aid group, SAMU-Social, has been providing free healthcare, lodging, and psychological aid to Gabon's poorest residents since July. The group, launched five months ago, has already undertaken over 7,000 interventions and has a medical and psychological care centre, ambulances, and shelters in the capital city. Gabon has over 38% of its population living below the poverty threshold, with 300,000 having no access to care. The service is state-funded and has received $1.4 million in funding so far, with plans to expand to other cities by the end of January.

site_title: A new growth model for the European neighbourhood
summary: The European neighborhood is experiencing broad-based economic growth, with almost every country in central and eastern Europe, central Asia, the Middle East and North Africa, and Russia and Turkey seeing accelerated growth. However, new challenges loom, including a widening gap in productivity growth compared to emerging economies. To address this, the region must adopt a new growth model based on stronger human capital, innovation, and deeper integration into the global economy. This requires significant investment in infrastructure, greener technologies, and better corporate governance.

site_title: The robots are coming, and Sweden is fine
summary: Sweden's social welfare system and generous unemployment benefits provide a safety net against joblessness, allowing workers like Mika Persson to remain employed despite the introduction of automation. Unlike the US, Sweden prioritizes employee training and job security, with 80% of Swedes expressing positive views about robots and AI. The country's unique approach to innovation, which balances technological advancements with social support, may offer a model for other nations to follow in an era of automation.

site_title: Self-healing glass: a smashing idea from Japan
summary: A Japanese researcher, Yu Yanagisawa, has developed a new type of glass that can repair itself by pressing it back together after cracking. The organic glass, made of polyether thioureas, uses hydrogen bonding to make the edges self-adhesive. This discovery opens the way for super-durable glass that could triple the lifespan of everyday products, such as car windows and construction materials. The self-healing glass can withstand physical stress and fatigue, and its potential lies in making lighter, more durable resin glass, rather than fixing broken screens.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher in muted holiday trading
summary: Wall Street opened higher in thin holiday trading, driven by a rally in commodities and a weaker dollar. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.13%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.2%. Despite ongoing US trade tensions, stocks extended their rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: India share sales next year forecast to top 2017 record
summary: India's equity issuance is forecast to surpass 2017's record of 1.95 trillion rupees next year, driven by a booming stock market and companies seeking growth capital. The fundraising rush, fueled by a rally in Indian equities, has already raised over 762 billion rupees this year. Companies such as Tata Steel and HDFC Bank plan to raise up to 413 billion rupees, with Kotak Mahindra Bank predicting a continued trend in 2018. The surge in share sales signals a revival in corporate investment as India's economy accelerates.

site_title: Samsung looks to cars to drive future growth
summary: Samsung Electronics is looking to drive future growth by expanding into the automotive industry, seeking to capitalize on the growing market's potential worth $645 billion by 2030. The company has already acquired Harman for $8 billion and is considering further investments in autonomous vehicles, semiconductors, and cyber-security. However, a leadership crisis and the cyclical market for memory chips may hinder its progress, and the company needs to act quickly to compete with other major players.

site_title: Malaysian bedroom furniture maker plans Catalist IPO
summary: Malaysian bedroom furniture maker LY Corp plans to list on the Catalist board with an initial public offering. The company designs and manufactures wooden furniture, primarily rebranded by overseas dealers. LY Corp was founded in 1976 and is controlled by Lian Yu Holdings.

site_title: GST and the digital economy - some possible effects
summary: Singapore may consider applying the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to the digital economy, but several issues need to be addressed, including defining digital services, implementing the reverse charge mechanism, and taxing B2C digital services. The government should adopt an exclusive, positive list of digital services to minimize uncertainty and increase compliance efficiency. A vendor collection model, where overseas suppliers collect GST, could also be considered, but it poses challenges, including added compliance costs and potential distortion in pricing. Consistency with global e-commerce regulations is also crucial to reduce compliance burdens and technical complexities, maintaining Singapore's reputation as a free port and e-commerce hub.

images.alt_text: Levying GST on imports of low-value goods (anything under S$400) could be another change and throw up challenges.

site_title: Trump and the Four Policemen of Asia
summary: US President Trump has unveiled two new policies for Asia as part of his National Security Strategy, aimed at countering growing Chinese assertiveness. The Quadrilateral Alliance, comprising the US, Japan, India, and Australia, seeks to maintain regional stability and promote freedom. The second policy elevates India to a leadership role in the Indo-Pacific region, with the US pledging to support India's growing power and relationships. However, India values its strategic autonomy, and the US may face challenges in its efforts to shape the region.

site_title: Homes in US gained US$2 trillion in value this year
summary: The US housing market experienced a 6.5% increase in value, reaching $2 trillion, in 2017, according to Zillow. This growth brings the total value of US homes to $31.8 trillion. Los Angeles is the most valuable housing market at $2.7 trillion, followed by New York. However, the new federal tax law may negatively impact homeowners, reducing mortgage-interest deductions and state and local tax deductions, potentially leading to price declines.

site_title: The Wilshire launches en bloc sale; guide price at S$1,525 psf ppr
summary: The collective sale of The Wilshire, a freehold property in District 10, Singapore, has been launched by Savills Singapore. The indicative guide price is S$98.07 million, working out to S$1,525 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) based on the existing GFA of 64,310 sq ft. The tender is expected to be a significant sale in the District 10 market, approximately 500 meters from Farrer Road MRT Station.

site_title: Noble Group raises stake in Mongolian railways firm in exchange for debt repayment
summary: NOBLE Group acquired a 10% stake in Northern Mongolian Railways Limited (NMRL) for $1.4 million, increasing its total shareholding to 20%. The deal was made in exchange for debt repayment by NMRL's parent company, Aspire Mining Limited. This move strengthens Noble's position in the Mongolian market and consolidates its shareholding interests in Aspire.

site_title: Jokowi heads to 2018 with backing of stronger Indonesian economy
summary: Indonesia's economy enters 2018 with a stronger position, driven by growth above 5% in every quarter this year, forecast to expand 5.4% in 2018, the fastest pace in five years. Foreign investment is picking up, inflation is subdued, and employment rates have increased. The government aims to reduce the budget deficit to 2.2% of GDP and is focusing on fiscal conservatism. However, economists are watching for potential risks, including a slowdown in Chinese investment growth and interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Five oil signals to watch as 2018 pits Opec against US shale
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The oil market is poised for a volatile 2018 as Opec-led supply cuts and rising US shale production threaten to widen the WTI-Brent discount. Geopolitical tensions, including potential disruptions in major oil-producing countries, also add uncertainty. Despite this, market volatility has decreased in recent weeks, with banks expecting a continued slide in volatility due to Opec's proactive management of the market. Oil traders will be watching five key barometers, including timespreads and options contracts, to gauge market sentiment and make informed investment decisions. A balanced market is expected to drive oil prices in 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
RHB Research has ceased coverage on Kingsmen Creatives due to internal resource reallocation and low institutional interest. The company has diversified into affordable luxury retail, fast fashion, and corporate interior segments, which may mitigate the impact of smaller project sizes in the high-end space. Additionally, the group plans to combine its strengths in interior and thematic divisions to create new entertainment concepts. 

RHB Research also ceased coverage on SingHaiyi Group due to a redistribution of internal resources, despite the company's expansion plans, acquisition of Cromwell Property Group, and potential boost to its share price from a strong recovery in the Singapore and US property markets.

site_title: QAF to cease bakery operations in China, changes group financial controller
summary: QAF Limited has decided to cease its loss-making bakery operations in China, a strategic review decision with no impact on net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. The company will focus on trading food-related products in the region. Additionally, group financial controller Derrick Lum will resign on Dec 29, and Goh Kiat Chiang will replace him.

site_title: Sinway-led consortium makes offer for CWG International at S$0.195 each
summary: A Sinway-led consortium has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to buy CWG International shares at S$0.195 each. The consortium, which already owns 81.1% of the company, plans to delist CWG International to gain greater control and management flexibility. The offer provides shareholders with a 29.1% premium over the one-month trading volume average. If the offer is accepted, the consortium will provide irrevocable undertakings and meet the minimum acceptance condition, making the offer unconditional.

site_title: India's SEBI tightens shareholding norms for rating agencies, mutual funds
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has tightened shareholding norms for credit rating agencies and mutual funds to boost governance and resolve conflicts of interest. SEBI limited stakeholding by rating agencies to 10% and prohibited cross-holdings in asset management companies. The regulator also raised the minimum net worth requirement for credit rating agencies to 250 million rupees. Additionally, SEBI relaxed conditions for foreign portfolio investors to enter Indian markets to curb the use of participatory notes, which can lead to misuse, including money laundering.

site_title: Asia rice-markets slow into year-end; Bangladesh awaits India shipments
summary: Bangladesh is awaiting shipments of 150,000 tonnes of rice from India at US$440 a tonne, as part of a deal to import 1.5 million tonnes in the year to June 2018. Rice markets in major Asian centres remained muted due to the holiday season and year-end, with prices unchanged or slightly up in India, Thailand, and Vietnam. The Indian rupee's appreciation has reduced exporters' returns, while the Thai rupee's strength has kept prices firm for overseas buyers.

site_title: Aluminium supplier Soon Lian buys Tuas factory for S$7.8 million
summary: Soon Lian Holdings, an aluminium supplier, has acquired a factory at 6 Tuas Lane in Singapore for S$7.8 million, including a payment of goods and services tax. The 4,800 sq m property is leased from JTC for 30 years and will be used for storage and fabrication of aluminium alloy materials, as well as housing offices. The purchase is expected to be funded by internal resources and bank loans, pending written in-principle approval from JTC and shareholder approval. The company is also disposing of its existing premises at 9 Tuas Avenue 2.

site_title: IAG is remaining bidder for insolvent airline Niki
summary: IAG, owner of British Airways, is exclusively negotiating with Niki's insolvency administrator to take over the collapsed Austrian airline, with a double-digit million-euro offer. IAG is the last remaining bidder and is still in talks, surpassing the other bids. The airline's collapse was announced in December 2017, and the outcome of the negotiations will determine Niki's fate.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit sells Tuas property for S$55 million
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit has sold its Tuas property, KTL Offshore, to a wholly owned subsidiary of Soilbuild Group Holdings for S$55 million. The sale minimizes exposure to credit risk and allows diversification of tenant base. The property has a 60-year leasehold and a remaining term of about 48.6 years. The trust plans to use the net proceeds for new acquisitions, debt repayment, and capital distribution. It is expected to generate an estimated net gain of S$1.7 million from the divestment.

site_title: Labour pains continue
summary: Singapore is establishing a centre for sustainable aviation in Asia, aiming to advance the region's aviation industry. Graduates are advised to stay calm despite initial employment challenges, with better job prospects emerging. Deputy Prime Minister Gan will visit the US for trade talks, while businesses hit by tariffs may receive up to SGD 100,000 in grants. Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. The government also offers support for workers to future-proof their careers amidst potential crises.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall as yen firms
summary: Tokyo shares declined on Thursday as the yen strengthened in thin trade, affecting investor sentiment ahead of New Year holidays. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.56%, while the Topix index fell 0.59%. This decline was attributed to investors squaring positions before the holidays.

site_title: Datapulse co-founder seeks to replace new board directors
summary: Datapulse co-founder Ng Khim Guan's family, led by his daughter Ng Bie Tjin and Uniseraya Holdings, is seeking to oust four newly-appointed board directors due to concerns over the company's diversification plans and recent acquisition of a Malaysian personal care product maker. The family holds a 16% stake in the company and wants to halt any diversification until a complete feasibility study is done and shareholders approve the move. The move comes after the company's new board, which includes the four directors, approved a proposed diversification and name change.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.34 points to 1,779.10. Volume reached 2.6 billion lots worth RM 2.1 billion, with 467 gainers outnumbering 444 losers.

site_title: Beyonce's sister Solange reveals autonomic disorder, cancels show
summary: Solange, Beyonce's sister, has revealed she's been quietly treating an autonomic disorder, a dysfunction of the nervous system that affects the body's functions. The 31-year-old singer had to cancel her New Year's Eve performance in South Africa due to doctors' advice. Solange expressed regret for missing the Afropunk festival, which she has "tremendous meaning for me." She did not disclose further details about her condition, but described the journey as "not easy" and noted that she sometimes feels "cool" and other times "not so cool."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for a 4th session amid optimism in Asian markets
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark stock index rose for a fourth consecutive session, closing up 0.9% at 29,863.71. This followed a bullish sentiment in Asian markets, pushing stocks to their highest level in a month. China's Shanghai Composite index also rose 0.65%, while its CSI300 index ended up 0.7%. The rally came despite uncertainty over US-China trade tensions, with investors instead focusing on positive economic indicators.

site_title: South Korea to impose curbs on digital currency trade
summary: South Korea is imposing curbs on digital currency trade, including banning anonymous trading and closing virtual currency exchanges if necessary. The move aims to prevent a bubble and address money laundering activities. The government will close all anonymous accounts by next month and step up crackdowns on price manipulation and financial fraud. The decision follows a ban on financial firms dealing in virtual currencies and warnings from international banks about the risks of a possible blowout in the bitcoin market.
