site_title: Crowdfunding platform FundTier gets MAS licence; eyes SMEs and investors
summary: FundTier Pte Ltd, a local startup, has obtained a Capital Market Services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), allowing it to provide an alternative source of funding for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). FundTier aims to address the funding gap for underserved SMEs with promising business growth plans, targeting investors seeking unconventional investment tools. The platform was founded by five former bankers in 2015 and is set to launch on January 5, 2018.

site_title: SMJ International announces board changes following disposal of carpet business
summary: SMJ International Holdings has announced board changes effective January 1, 2018, following the disposal of its carpet business, SMJ Furnishings. Executive director and CEO Ho Pei Yuen Rena has been redesignated to a non-executive director, while Peng Fei has taken over as executive director and CEO. The company's two sisters, Rena and Nellie Ho, who sold the carpet business for S$13.8 million, have also been re-designated. These changes align with the terms of the agreement and mark the company's transition to a property company.

site_title: UAE property developer secures 1b dirham loan for mega-project
summary: UAE property developer Arada secured a 1 billion dirham (S$365.11 million) Islamic syndicated loan to fund the 24 billion dirham Aljada project in Sharjah. Construction will begin in 2018, with the first phase delivered by 2019 and completion by 2025. Arada, founded by Prince Khaled bin Alwaleed bin Talal and Sheikh Sultan bin Ahmed al-Qasimi, aims to cater to growing demand for housing and leisure activities in the northern emirates.

site_title: Apple CEO must fly private for 'security, efficiency'
summary: Apple's CEO Tim Cook is required to use private aircraft for "security and efficiency" due to the company's global profile. The decision was made by Apple's board in 2017, and the value of the private flights is considered "imputed taxable income" not reimbursed by Apple. Cook received $12.8 million in compensation in 2017, including a $3 million salary and $89 million in stock awards. This decision comes as Apple's market capitalization has reached nearly $900 billion, up 50% for the year.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2 per cent up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.43 points to 3,399.10, finishing 0.2% higher on Thursday, with 1.16 billion shares changing hands worth S$664.4 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day streak of gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A joint venture between CapitaLand and Lum Chang Holdings acquired a Frankfurt office building for 234.3 million euros in cash. Meanwhile, Singapore-listed LHN raised HK$79.8 million in gross funds from a Hong Kong share offering. A former Keppel lawyer secretly cooperated with US authorities in a bribery probe, and a Malaysian bedroom furniture maker plans a Catalist IPO. Singapore shares closed 0.2% higher on Thursday, while Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3% below forecast.

site_title: Jubilee Industries Holdings gets listing and quotation notice for rights-cum-warrants issue
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings Ltd has received the listing and quotation notice for its proposed renounceable non-underwritten rights-cum-warrants issue. The issue, announced in October, will see up to 336.28 million new ordinary shares offered at 4.5 Singapore cents apiece. The estimated net proceeds of S$15.03 million will be used for general working capital, mergers and acquisitions, and machine capacity expansion. The rights shares come with detachable warrants, and the company's parent, Accrelist, has agreed to offset a portion of Jubilee's outstanding loan.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: India's Reliance Jio to buy all wireless assets of RCom
summary: Reliance Communications Ltd, a debt-laden Indian telecom company, has signed an agreement to sell its wireless assets to Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd, the telecom arm of Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries Ltd. The sale includes spectrum, tower, fibre optic, and other telecom infrastructure assets, subject to regulatory approvals. The deal is expected to slash RCom's debt by 390 billion rupees (S$8.13 billion) and return the company to the fold of Reliance Industries. Reliance Jio will gain access to 4 bands of spectrum, 43,000 telecom towers, and a countrywide fibre optic network.

site_title: Watchdog slams Lufthansa over 'algorithm' price hikes
summary: Germany's Federal Cartel Office (FCO) has criticized Lufthansa for claiming price hikes on domestic routes were due to automated booking software, stating companies can't "hide behind algorithms." FCO president Andreas Mundt said Lufthansa's justification didn't hold up, as the airline's ticket prices jumped 30% on some routes following Air Berlin's bankruptcy. Lufthansa denied cashing in on its dominant position, but the competition watchdog is probing the matter. The FCO's comments come as easyJet prepares to begin operating Air Berlin assets in January, increasing competition in Germany.

site_title: No Signboard's full-year profit falls 1.3%
summary: No Signboard Holdings Limited reported a 1.3% drop in its full-year earnings to S$7.7 million, despite a 7.3% rise in revenue to S$24.4 million. The company's restaurant business experienced a 6.3% decline in sales, while its beer business generated S$3.1 million in revenue after its acquisition in June 2017. Despite a decrease in customer count, the group saw an increase in average customer spend, and restaurant sales rebounded in the second half of the year.

site_title: Investors pile into Italian debt in final auction of 2017
summary: Italian government bonds attracted significant investor interest in a final 2017 auction, with demand exceeding 9 billion euros. The 10-year bond yield decreased to 1.90%, lower than expected, as investors bought up bonds despite concerns over an upcoming election. The rally was driven by a recent sell-off and widening spreads between Italian and German bond yields, making Italian bonds more attractive. The auction's success suggests investors are seeking value in the market ahead of the March general election.

site_title: Tibetan film-maker flees China, arrives in US
summary: Tibetan film-maker Dhondup Wangchen, jailed for six years in China for making a documentary critical of the government, has arrived in the US after escaping from China. Released from prison in 2014, Wangchen was under surveillance but successfully evaded authorities to flee. He expressed gratitude for his newfound freedom but also felt pain for leaving his homeland, Tibet. The film-maker's case highlights China's alleged human rights abuses in Tibet, which Beijing denies.

site_title: The Wilshire en bloc sale tender launched with S$98.07m indicative guide price
summary: The collective sale tender for The Wilshire, a freehold property in District 10, Singapore, has been launched with an indicative guide price of S$98.07 million. Based on the existing 64,310 sq ft gross floor area, the price works out to S$1,525 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, which is zoned for residential use, can be redeveloped into a new 12-storey project. Owners are expected to receive gross sales proceeds ranging from S$3.7 million to S$6.8 million per unit.

images.alt_text: Savills Singapore, the marketing agent for the District 10 property's collective sale, said that the indicative guide price is S$98.07 million, which works out to S$1,525 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) based on the existing gross floor area (GFA) of 64,310 sq ft.

site_title: Apple and Amazon in talks to set up in Saudi Arabia
summary: Apple and Amazon are in licensing discussions with Saudi Arabia to invest in the kingdom, part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's push to modernize the conservative country. Apple is expected to set up its first retail store in 2019, while Amazon's talks are in earlier stages. The move aims to diversify Saudi Arabia's oil-dependent economy and attract foreign investment, with both companies already selling products in the country via third parties.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb on foreign buying, won ends at 32-month high
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.26% to 2,467.49, its largest weekly gain in eight weeks, driven by heavy foreign buying in the IT sector. The Korean won ended at a 32-month high at 1,070.5 per US dollar, up 0.34% from its previous close. The currency has risen 12.8% on a yearly basis, its biggest annual gain since 2004. The Kospi gained 20.2% so far this year and posted its biggest yearly gain in seven years.

site_title: South Korea's Moon says 'comfort women' deal with Japan seriously flawed
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae In said the 2015 deal with Japan over wartime sex slavery was "seriously flawed" and officials should re-examine it. The deal, pushed by his predecessor Park Geun Hye, has been criticized for failing to reflect the views of the victims. The issue of women forced into sexual slavery by Japanese troops during World War II remains a contentious topic between South Korea and Japan.

site_title: China to 'standardise' market access for foreign lenders
summary: China's banking regulator has issued draft measures to standardize market access for foreign lenders, aiming to promote investment in the country's financial sector. The amended administrative measures will cut red tape and create a level playing field for foreign bank activities, including branch openings and equity investments in Chinese financial institutions. The move follows China's vow to further open up its financial sector to outside investors, with the goal of increasing foreign ownership limits in some joint-venture firms to 51%. The goal is to boost competition and economic growth.

site_title: Gamers prowling pyramids bode well for Ubisoft's Christmas bet
summary: Ubisoft's latest game, "Assassin's Creed Origins," is performing well, with strong sales and positive reviews, potentially benefiting the company's fight for independence from Vivendi. The game's sales have stayed "very strong" and ranked third in the UK for the week ended Dec 16, with an 85% positive rating on Steam. This trend is expected to continue, making it difficult for Vivendi to pursue a hostile bid, as Ubisoft's shares have already almost doubled this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares drift lower into year-end as resources stocks glitter
summary: European shares fell 0.1-0.2% on Thursday, weighed down by tech stocks, while resources-heavy indices rose. The FTSE 100 hovered near a record high, driven by a rally in commodity prices. Tech stocks, including chipmakers, were hit by concerns over Apple's iPhone X. Volumes were muted and liquidity was low due to the holiday season. Despite this, European stocks have had a positive year, with the STOXX 600 up 8% in 2017.

site_title: Asia: Stocks near a record high, US dollar declines
summary: Asian stocks near a record high on Thursday, driven by a weak US dollar and rising raw-materials prices. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose, with Hong Kong and Seoul's benchmarks also higher, while Japan's Topix Index fell. US Treasury yields held below 2.5% and oil traded just under $60 a barrel. The Bloomberg Commodity Index edged up, and currencies such as the yen and euro strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: Australia shares edge up to near 10-year high; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares reached a near 10-year high, closing at 6,088.10, driven by gains in financials and materials. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% as Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corp led the gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high at 8,408.530, driven by consumer discretionary and utilities stocks.

site_title: From bitcoin to Belize, here are best and worst assets of 2017
summary: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies had a remarkable year, with bitcoin soaring 1,500% and smaller counterparts gaining at least 6,000%. Emerging-market sovereigns and corporate debt also performed well, while Japanese government bonds trailed behind. The Uzbek soum was the worst performer, after the country removed its peg to the dollar. Other notable losers included stocks in Qatar and Pakistan, and bonds from Japan and Venezuela due to economic instability.

site_title: US Secretary of State defends foreign policy record at year's end
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson defended the country's foreign policy record at year's end, citing progress in curbing North Korea's nuclear ambitions and countering Russia, China, and Iran's challenges. He stated that 90% of North Korea's export earnings had been cut off by international sanctions, and a door to dialogue remains open for Pyongyang. However, Tillerson warned that pressure will continue until denuclearization occurs. He also called on China to pressure North Korea and acknowledged the need to work with Russia where mutual interests intersect.

site_title: US, South Korea to hold trade talks next week
summary: US and South Korean delegates will meet in Washington on January 5 to discuss possible amendments to the US-Korea free trade agreement. The talks follow previous meetings in Seoul and Washington, amid a US trade deficit that has grown from $13.2 billion in 2011 to $27.6 billion in 2016. The US exported less to South Korea in 2016, while imports rose by nearly $20 billion. US President Donald Trump has been critical of free trade deals, and the renegotiation of the agreement reflects his administration's efforts to address the imbalance.

site_title: Bitcoin drops as South Korea says exchange closures are possible
summary: South Korea is considering measures to curb cryptocurrency speculation, including potential exchange closures, amid a frenzy of speculation and concerns over its impact on youth. Bitcoin fell 9% in Asian trading to US$13,828, erasing previous gains, and is down 28% from its record high. The government plans to require real-name transactions, ban virtual accounts, and review measures to address speculation. Regulators worldwide express concerns about private digital currencies, warning of potential losses for buyers and the economy.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin resumed its tumble on Thursday after South Korea said it was eyeing options including a potential shutdown of at least some cryptocurrency exchanges to stamp out a frenzy of speculation.

site_title: Japan's factories, retailers rev up, central bankers flag stimulus reduction
summary: Japan's factories and retailers posted better-than-expected growth in November, with industrial production rising 0.6% and retail sales increasing 2.2% year-over-year. The Bank of Japan's central bankers are considering reducing stimulus, with some members suggesting raising interest rates or lowering ETF purchases to manage the improving economy. The country's growth has exceeded expectations, and its stock markets have rallied due to rising corporate earnings, prompting some to question the BOJ's aggressive monetary easing policies.

site_title: US inflation mystery makes economists look bad in 2017
summary: In 2017, US economists failed to accurately predict inflation and unemployment rates, with only one forecast matching actual results within 0.3 percentage points. Economists' median forecasts for unemployment (4.6%) and inflation (2%) were significantly off mark, with inflation remaining low at 1.5% despite strong job gains. The discrepancy has led some to question the relationship between inflation and unemployment, with many now believing low inflation may be a persistent phenomenon rather than a transitory issue.

images.alt_text: A year ago, Bloomberg asked economists to predict how 2017 would unfurl.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session on higher ground; STI at 3,401.14
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading in the afternoon session on December 28, 2017, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,401.14, up 0.3% or 9.47 points. Gainers outpaced losers 199 to 131, with S$281.4 million in traded shares. Key gainers included Jiutian Chemical Group, Rowsley, OCBC Bank, and DBS Group Holdings, while UOB was down 0.15%. The STI had a marginal decline before the afternoon session, but ended the day on a positive note.

site_title: Insolvent Niki's Austrian workers to get monthly wages
summary: Around 790 Niki airline staff in Austria will receive monthly wages for December, with the new owner expected to take on running costs, including salaries, from January. Administrator Lucas Floether is confident of striking a deal with a new investor within the next few days. IAG, Thomas Cook, and Niki's founder Niki Lauda are among the bidders for the insolvent airline. The talks are progressing rapidly, with the goal of preserving as many jobs as possible in Austria and Germany.

site_title: Malaysian bedroom furniture maker plans Catalist IPO
summary: Malaysian bedroom furniture maker LY Corp plans to go public on the Catalist board with an initial public offering (IPO) through a placement of new shares and vendor shares. The company aims to raise funds for expansion, upgrading machinery, and acquiring new premises. LY Corp's net profit rose 21.6% to RM21.6 million in the six months to June 30, driven by higher sales volumes and average selling price increases. The IPO is expected to be completed in 2018, with UOB Kay Hian serving as the sponsor and placement agent.

site_title: Nomura CEO targets US in push that could include acquisitions
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest investment bank, is targeting the US market with a push that could include acquisitions. CEO Koji Nagai aims to strengthen the bank's presence in the US, where it remains "weak" after losing the Lehman Brothers business to Barclays in 2008. Nagai plans to hire investment bankers or make acquisitions, and may cut jobs in Europe if it decides to focus more on the US. The bank has already eliminated 900 positions in Europe and the Americas as part of its efforts to improve profitability.

images.alt_text: Almost a decade after Barclays Plc beat Nomura to acquire Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc's North American business, the Japanese investment bank remains "weak" there, Chief Executive Officer Koji Nagai said in an interview in Tokyo.

site_title: Taiwan president says China military causing regional instability
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen warned that China's frequent military activity is causing regional instability, citing 16 rounds of exercises close to Taiwan in the past year. China views Taiwan as its sacred territory and has threatened to use force to bring it under control. Tsai emphasized Taiwan's commitment to peace but also preparedness for combat, as Beijing has repeatedly said its drills are routine and not aimed at any third party. Tensions rise amid US warnings to China not to invade Taiwan.

site_title: Hillview Rise, Sengkang Central private housing sites up for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two private housing sites in Sengkang Central and Hillview Rise for public tender. The sites, totaling 51,600 square meters, can yield approximately 1,235 residential units. The tender for Hillview Rise will close on May 3, 2018, while Sengkang Central's tender will close on June 21, 2018. Bids will be evaluated under a concept and price revenue tender system, with the highest bid among accepted concepts winning the tender.

site_title: Zico sells 80% stake in online SME platform to independent director for RM80
summary: Zico Holdings sold an 80% stake in its online SME platform, ShakeUp Online Sdn Bhd, to independent director Chew Liong Kim for RM80. The move aims to strengthen the company's balance sheet by reducing exposure to the loss-making business. Chew was also appointed as a director of ShakeUp.

site_title: Asian shares at 1-month highs, copper at 4-year peak
summary: Asian shares rose to a one-month high, reaching a 32% gain for the year, while copper hit a four-year peak, boosting commodity-driven currencies. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was up 0.1% at 563.86 points, near record highs, and copper prices surged 30% in the calendar year. The strength in metals, including gold, lifted currencies of countries exporting commodities, with the Australian and New Zealand dollars reaching two-month highs.

site_title: 5 large banks in Russia saw outflows from corporate accounts in Nov
summary: Russian households maintained confidence in the country's largest banks in November, while companies withdrew funds from banks rescued by the central bank. The central bank's clean-up programme has led to 62 revoked banking licences, reducing the number of banks to 519. In November, five large banks - Otkritie, B&N Bank, Promsvyazbank, Credit Bank of Moscow, and UniCredit - saw outflows from corporate accounts, with Otkritie losing 25% of its corporate funds and B&N losing 16%. Retail clients, however, increased funds in major banks' accounts by up to 2%.

site_title: Innovative medical aid for Gabon's 'poorest of the poor'
summary: Innovative medical aid has arrived in Gabon's impoverished area of Kolo Ngoum, a suburb of Libreville. The SAMU-Social service, providing urgent medical aid, has brought a much-needed response to the community. Residents, who have gone without medical care for ages, are reassured by the presence of stethoscopes and medical instruments. This initiative aims to improve healthcare access for Gabon's poorest residents, offering a sense of relief and hope for better living conditions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise, won edges up on last trading day of 2017
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.82% on its last trading day of 2017, closing at 2,456.56. The won edged up, reaching 1,072.4 per US dollar, while bond yields fell. Domestic institutions drove the index up, and the Kospi is up 20.2% so far this year.

site_title: Self-healing glass: a cracking discovery from Japan
summary: A Japanese researcher, Yu Yanagisawa, has developed self-healing glass that can be repaired by pressing it back together after cracking. The breakthrough, made while investigating adhesives for wet surfaces, could lead to super-durable glass with tripled lifespan for products like car windows and construction materials. The discovery has potential applications in various industries, including consumer goods and construction.

site_title: WeWork's chinese rival nixes 'UrWork' label in global makeover
summary: WeWork's Chinese rival, UrWork, has rebranded its shared-office service to "ucommune" after dropping the "UrWork" label amid a trademark dispute with WeWork. The rebranding aims to sidestep potential legal issues as UrWork pursues a global expansion. Valued at over $1 billion, UrWork operates 120 locations in 35 cities worldwide and is preparing to expand into Asia, including China and Japan, directly competing with WeWork, valued at $20 billion.

site_title: Nintendo eyes 20m Switch sales
summary: Nintendo expects to sell more than 20 million of its Switch consoles in the next fiscal year, surpassing the sales of its Wii console. The company's president, Tatsumi Kimishima, stated that the momentum for Switch is stronger in some markets, with sales potentially outpacing the Wii's 100 million units worldwide.

site_title: Financial oil trading booms, especially in the United States
summary: Financial oil trading has reached record levels, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) front-month futures volumes exceeding 150 million, more than double those of international benchmark Brent futures. The surge is driven by the US shale oil boom, with US crude output surging 70% over the past five years. As oil producers lock in profits and buyers protect against rising prices, the trend is expected to continue, with Middle East producers and Asian buyers increasingly adopting futures markets. This shift may alter the market share battle between US and Middle East oil producers.

site_title: As online shopping grows, UPS sees record holiday package returns
summary: UPS expects to return a record number of packages this holiday shipping season, driven by e-commerce purchases surging to new heights over the past month. The company has seen a significant increase in delivery volumes, forcing it to invest billions of dollars to upgrade and expand its network. This growth is attributed to the rise of online shopping, with retailers like Amazon.com and Wal-Mart Stores relying on UPS and FedEx for e-commerce deliveries. The record returns are a testament to the growth of e-commerce and the increased demand for package delivery services.

images.alt_text: United Parcel Service (UPS) is on track to return a record number of packages this holiday shipping season, a sign that e-commerce purchases surged to new heights over the past month.

site_title: Oil prices near 2015 highs on tight market
summary: Oil prices near 2015 highs due to a tight market, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures reaching $59.69 a barrel and Brent crude futures at $66.50 a barrel. Opec and Russian production cuts, as well as pipeline outages in Libya and the North Sea, have contributed to the tight market. US oil production, which has soared 16% since 2016, is also a factor countering efforts to prop up prices. Market experts predict further gains, citing geopolitical risks and potential regional chaos in 2018.

site_title: Bali declares 'garbage emergency' amid sea of waste
summary: Bali has declared a "garbage emergency" due to the overwhelming amount of waste on its beaches. Plastic straws, food packaging, and other debris are polluting the shoreline, making it unappealing for tourists and locals alike. The issue is exacerbated by rivers and currents bringing in more waste. Residents, like Austrian traveller Vanessa Moonshine, are expressing concerns about the environmental impact and desire for a cleaner beach. Authorities are calling for action to address the problem and work towards a zero-waste future.

site_title: Ex-Keppel lawyer secretly cooperated with US in bribery probe: documents
summary: A former Keppel lawyer, Jeffery Chow, secretly cooperated with US authorities in a bribery probe, pleading guilty to conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. As part of his deal, Keppel agreed to pay $422 million to settle charges of bribing Brazilian officials. Chow admitted to drafting contracts used for bribe payments, and his US lawyer declined to comment. The case centers on Keppel's payments to Petrobras, a Brazilian state-run oil company, between 2001 and 2014.

site_title: EasyJet's new CEO aims to follow McCall with boost in passengers
summary: EasyJet's new CEO, Johan Lundgren, aims to serve 13% more passengers in 2018, reaching 90 million travelers. He plans to expand airline links and test a hybrid-power plane. Lundgren's strategy builds on Carolyn McCall's efforts to compete with Ryanair and European flag carriers. The airline will also acquire Air Berlin's operations at Tegel airport and introduce a new base at Berlin Schoenefeld airport. Lundgren is working with Wright Electric to develop a nine-seat aircraft that can fly on both standard jet fuel and battery power in 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on December 28, 2017, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 29,690.52. This followed a positive lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.11% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.11%. The gains extended the previous day's advance.

site_title: Australian shares supported by miners; NZ edges up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,075.6, driven by strong metals prices and gains in the mining sector. Copper and gold prices surged, boosting diversified miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. Financials also rose, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia leading the sector up. In New Zealand, the benchmark index edged up 0.1% to 8,387.57, with gains in consumer discretionary and utilities sectors.

site_title: LHN raises HK$79.8 m in gross funds from Hong Kong share offering
summary: LHN, a Singapore-listed real estate management services group, raised HK$79.8 million (S$13.7 million) in gross funds from a Hong Kong share offering. The offering, which was subscribed 5.93 times, will be used to expand its space optimisation business, operate a parking yard in Singapore, and fund general working capital purposes. Trading in Hong Kong is expected to begin on December 29.

site_title: China's yuan rises on US dollar weakness, on track for best year since 2008
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar, on track for its best annual gain since 2008, due to a stronger official midpoint and weak US dollar in overseas markets. The US 10-year bond yields also retreated, contributing to the yuan's rise. The currency's appreciation is seen as a response to the US dollar's weakness, which has been exacerbated by a dip in US bond yields.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Thursday, underpinned by a stronger official midpoint and broad greenback weakness in overseas markets as Treasury yields retreated.

site_title: From pink pussyhats to rape laws, women's rights advance despite adversity in 2017
summary: In 2017, women's rights made significant progress despite adversity. Millions of protesters, including pink hat-wearing demonstrators, marched globally, while celebrities publicly denounced their abusers. Countries like Chile, India, and others passed pro-women legislation. However, the US saw a setback with the inauguration of President Donald Trump, who restricted abortions worldwide. Despite this, a new era of resistance emerged in the US and other countries, with strides made towards ending gender discrimination in the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America. This marked a momentous year for women's rights, showcasing the power of resistance and advocacy.

site_title: China liquor maker Moutai flags strong 2017 sales, sees slower growth next year
summary: China's liquor maker Kweichow Moutai Co Ltd reported a 50% revenue growth in 2017, with sales expected to moderate to a 10% rise in 2018. The company's strong sales growth is attributed to increased demand for its high-end baijiu, driven by a government crackdown on corruption. Moutai's market value reached US$128 billion, surpassing its nearest rival Diageo. The firm expects 2017 revenue to top 60 billion yuan, with profits growing around 58%.

site_title: Dutch experts doubt authenticity of rare 'Hitler' painting
summary: Dutch researchers Bart Droog and Jaap van den Born have raised doubts about the authenticity of a rare watercolour painting signed by Adolf Hitler. The aquarelle, depicting a tower in Vienna, was donated to the Amsterdam-based NIOD wartime institute and initially deemed authentic by the institute. However, Droog and Van den Born believe it may be a forgery created by Reinhold Hanisch, a well-known Nazi dictator artwork forger. The NIOD has issued a statement saying it will continue researching the painting's authenticity, acknowledging that its initial conclusions were "provisional."

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat amid thin holiday trade
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on December 28, 2017, amid thin holiday trade. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.02% to 22,916.56, while the Topix index slipped 0.03% to 1,829.33. The lack of significant economic data and holiday trading contributed to the flat opening.

site_title: Bank of Japan board members press for debate on rates, ETF purchases
summary: Bank of Japan board members are debating the need to adjust interest rates or ETF purchases due to Japan's improving economic outlook. Some members argue that the BOJ should consider raising interest rates or reevaluating its aggressive monetary easing in response to rising stock prices and corporate earnings. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has stated that he will not raise rates as long as consumer prices remain below the 2% inflation target. The BOJ's policy meeting follows solid economic growth and robust industrial production, with Japan's industrial output rising 0.6% in November.

site_title: Blast rips through supermarket in Russia's St Petersburg, 10 hurt
summary: A blast ripped through a supermarket in Russia's St Petersburg, injuring 10 shoppers. The explosion was caused by a homemade bomb packed with metal pieces equivalent to 200 grammes of TNT. Nobody was killed, and a criminal case on attempted murder has been opened. The motive for the blast is unclear, with investigators exploring all possible versions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.03 points to 1,771.79. Trading volume reached 135.25 million lots worth RM45.97 million, with 134 gainers outnumbering 49 losers.

site_title: Billionaire Kotak's unit sees India share sales top 2017 record
summary: India's share sales are expected to surpass 2017's record, with over 762 billion rupees raised by first-time issuers, boosting total issuance to 1.95 trillion rupees. Companies, including Tata Steel, HDFC Bank, and Housing Development Finance, plan to raise up to 413 billion rupees. The fundraising rush is driven by a booming stock market and companies seeking growth capital, with loan growth recovering from a 25-year low. The trend is expected to continue in 2018, with companies planning to list on domestic exchanges and investors willing to invest in the market.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up 1 point on Thursday open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.03% to 3,392.65 at the opening bell on Thursday, driven by Wall Street stocks' edge higher. The benchmark index saw 25 million shares worth S$31.3 million change hands, with gainers beating losers 70-34. The rise follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors maintaining a positive stance despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Jokowi heads to 2018 with backing of stronger Indonesian economy
summary: Indonesia's economy is entering 2018 on a strong note, with growth above 5% in every quarter this year and a forecasted 5.4% expansion, the fastest pace in five years. The economy has recovered from a slowing economy in 2014, with foreign investment picking up, inflation subdued, and more people in jobs. The government's proposed budget is expected to tighten, but economists are optimistic about the economy's growth prospects. The economy's recovery adds support for President Jokowi's potential second term, but the situation could change if interest rates rise.

site_title: Mitsubishi Materials says push for market share led to data falsification
summary: Mitsubishi Materials Corp admitted to falsifying product specification data, driven by a push to expand market share. A subsidiary, Mitsubishi Shindoh, took orders despite being unable to meet customers' product specifications. This scandal is part of a series of compliance issues affecting Japan Inc. in 2017, including Kansai Electric Power's use of possibly falsified parts from Mitsubishi Cable Industries. The incident has damaged the reputation of Mitsubishi Materials and highlights the pressure to expand market share.

site_title: China's Geely eyes Volvo trucks after cars
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co plans to buy a stake in Volvo AB, valued at about 3.25 billion euros (S$5.2 billion), making it the truckmaker's largest shareholder. Geely aims to bulk up outside China and will seek board representation. The deal marks Geely's first foray into the heavy-truck segment and will enhance Volvo's electrification, autonomous driving, and connectivity technologies. Volvo's Class B shares fell 2.9% after the announcement, while Geely's Hong Kong-listed stock rose 0.6%.

site_title: Cofco says blast at Argentine port kills employee, injures others
summary: An explosion at a grains terminal in Argentina owned by Cofco International killed one employee and injured others, affecting shipping activities from the company, a major food supplier. The blast occurred at the loading area of the facility in Rosario, part of Argentina's shipping hub on the Parana River. Cofco International confirmed the incident and described it as a "52,000-square-metre grains processing plant."

site_title: Bitcoin's boom a boon for extremist groups
summary: Extremist groups have found a way to circumvent industry crackdowns on hate speech and online activity by investing in bitcoin, a digital currency that has quadrupled in value since the Charlottesville rally. Experts say bitcoin allows extremists to communicate, organize events, and keep websites online, despite being banned from mainstream hosting services. The decentralized blockchain system makes it difficult for regulators to monitor assets and identify account holders, making it an attractive tool for fringe groups.

site_title: Apple faces lawsuits over tweak to slow down ageing iPhones
summary: Apple faces lawsuits over its decision to slow down ageing iPhones by throttling device performance to compensate for poor battery life, affecting potentially millions of users. Eight lawsuits have been filed in US federal courts seeking class-action status, alleging the company misled users into buying new phones instead of replacing batteries. The lawsuits claim Apple's software update, released last year, artificially slowed down devices to prevent components from overheating, leading users to mistakenly blame processor issues for performance problems.

site_title: Europe: Chipmakers tumble on iPhone demand scare; miners rally
summary: European tech stocks fell 1.1% on Wednesday as chipmakers tumbled due to weaker-than-expected demand for Apple's iPhone X, with Austria Microsystems and Dialog Semiconductor dropping 7.8% and 1.2% respectively. However, mining and oil stocks rose, with the STOXX 600 index inching 0.1% higher. The decline in tech stocks was attributed to profit-taking after a strong year, with investors citing a favorable tax regime for tech companies.

site_title: Fukushima operator gets first safety nod since 2011 crisis
summary: The Nuclear Regulation Authority of Japan has given Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) the formal approval to restart two reactors at the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant, the first since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear crisis. The reactors meet stricter safety standards introduced after the disaster and are situated at one of the world's largest nuclear plants in central Japan. Tepco still needs local consent to bring the reactors online, which could take years, amid concerns from Niigata governor Ryuichi Yone-yama.

site_title: Football: Liverpool land Van Dijk in world record deal for defender
summary: Liverpool has signed Southampton's Virgil van Dijk for a reported £75 million, making him the world's most expensive defender. The 26-year-old Netherlands international will join the club on January 1, 2018, on weekly wages of £180,000. The transfer, which breaks the previous world record for a defender, aims to strengthen Liverpool's leaky defense. Van Dijk will be assigned squad number four and could make his debut in the FA Cup third round tie against Everton on January 5.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Lum Chang, Keppel, Best World International
summary: CapitaLand and Lum Chang Holdings acquired a Frankfurt office building for $375.1 million, with CapitaLand holding 94.9% of the joint venture. Keppel Corporation agreed to pay $422 million to settle bribery charges in Brazil, with a former lawyer cooperating with US authorities. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rallied 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Apple CEO Cook gets 74% bonus boost after sales, profit rebound
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a 74% bonus boost for fiscal 2017, totaling US$9.33 million, following the company's revenue and profit rebound after a decline the previous year. Cook's total payout was approximately US$102 million, including a previously disclosed equity award of US$89.2 million. His top executives also received significant bonuses, with total compensation ranging from US$24.2 million each. The bonuses were paid out above target due to the company beating net sales and operating income goals.

site_title: Congress passes overhaul of Argentina's inefficient tax system
summary: Argentina's Congress passed a bill to overhaul the country's inefficient tax system, aiming to reduce its heavy tax burden and attract foreign investment. The reform, combined with a regional sales tax reduction, is expected to decrease the tax burden by 4% of GDP over five years. The move seeks to boost the economy, which has been hindered by decades of inefficient taxes. The bill was approved by the Senate with 52 votes for and 15 against, following approval by the lower house earlier. The government hopes the changes will improve the business environment and stimulate growth.

site_title: China Sports independent directors still unable to ascertain situation at its factory
summary: Independent directors of China Sports International, unable to access the company's factory, stated they are awaiting updates from CEO Lin Shaoxiong to determine if the factory is operating normally. The directors requested access to the factory but have yet to receive confirmation. China Sports is facing a statutory demand for outstanding payments and has not begun its annual audit, leading to concerns among its directors. The company's shares have been halted since December 4. The board will continue to contact Lin and hold discussions with professionals if updates are not received.

site_title: China's new tax may hit hedge funds more than investment rivals
summary: China's new 3% tax on investment returns, set to take effect January 1, is expected to disproportionately affect hedge funds, which may face a bigger tax burden compared to other asset-management vehicles. The tax is part of a broader shift in China's tax regime, with hedge funds' strategies making them more susceptible to taxation. The move adds pressure on China's hedge fund industry, already under regulatory scrutiny, and raises concerns about the impact on smaller funds.

images.alt_text: Hedge funds may be the biggest losers from a new 3 per cent tax on some investment returns in China.

site_title: KKR, Blackstone sued by Lerach Group over hedge fund returns
summary: KKR and Blackstone are sued by the Lerach Group over alleged misrepresentation of hedge fund returns, with the plaintiffs claiming the firms failed to deliver promised high returns and pocketed excessive fees. The lawsuit, filed on behalf of Kentucky taxpayers and pension plans, alleges that the asset managers breached their fiduciary duties and were negligent in convincing investors to invest in funds of funds that performed poorly. The plaintiffs seek to recoup fees and other payments made to money managers and advisers, and also pursue punitive damages.

site_title: House prices in 20 US cities up by the most since mid-2014
summary: US housing prices in 20 cities rose by the most since mid-2014 in October, driven by low inventories and steady demand. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index reported a 12.7% increase in Seattle and a 10.2% advance in Las Vegas. Home prices outpaced wage gains, limiting affordability and potentially forcing some buyers to consider renting. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike next year may disrupt the market. All 20 cities in the index showed year-on-year gains, with Las Vegas experiencing the largest month-on-month rise.

site_title: In Pakistan, questions raised over GE's flagship power turbines
summary: General Electric's flagship gas turbines experienced issues in Pakistan, causing delays and power outages at three newly built power stations. The problems, described as "teething issues," have raised questions about the turbines' design. Despite GE's claims, the issues coincide with a year of declining shares and poor quarterly results. GE is undergoing major restructuring amid the challenges. There is no evidence of fundamental design flaws in the 9HA-Class turbines.

images.alt_text: General Electric's flagship gas turbines ran into problems in Pakistan earlier this year, leading to delays and lengthy outages at three newly built power stations, according to several senior Pakistani officials and power executives.

site_title: Cashless is king, but will Singapore bow to it?
summary: Singapore may not adopt a cashless society due to consumer preference for cash. Despite the high smartphone penetration rate, 90% of Singaporeans prefer cash, citing lack of interoperability between payment systems and easy access to cash. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is working to establish a regulatory framework to standardize digital payments and simplify electronic payment systems, but the country's cashless revolution may be hindered by consumer resistance and retailer reluctance to adopt mandatory transaction fees.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near multi-week peak on metals, carry trades
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached multi-week peaks due to a rally in metals and low global volatility. The Aussie edged up 0.1% to US$0.7778, near Wednesday's high of US$0.7779, and is expected to end the year about 8% higher. This reverses the losing streak of the past four years. The strong currency is driven by leveraged plays in higher-yielding assets, including metals and carry trades.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hovered near multi-week peaks on Thursday as a rally in metals combined with low volatility globally and a soft greenback encouraged leveraged plays in higher-yielding assets.

site_title: US security strategy confirms Trump's toughness on China
summary: The US National Security Strategy, released under the Trump administration, confirms the administration's tough stance on China, labeling it a top competitor. China and Russia are seen as threats to American power, influence, and interests, while North Korea is considered a regional actor. The strategy highlights China's economic and military expansion, including its South China Sea claims and influence in Africa, Latin America, and Europe. The document pledges to counter China's actions, including reducing illicit technology appropriation and strengthening national security reviews of foreign acquisitions.

site_title: StanChart to retrain 3,000 staff in next three years
summary: Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore has launched a plan to retrain 3,000 employees over the next three years to prepare them for future roles in a changing financial industry. The plan builds on the existing SkillsFuture@sc programme, which aims to equip employees with skills for the future. This move is part of the bank's efforts to adapt to industry changes and ensure its workforce remains relevant.

site_title: Bitcoin price resumes slide after biggest rally in two weeks
summary: Bitcoin's price dropped 6.3% to $14,913 after its largest rally in two weeks, wiping over $9,000 off its value. The cryptocurrency had surged 3.6% earlier, but the decline marked the end of a five-day slump that reached 44% and took the price below $11,000. Investors snapped up shares in companies seen as safer alternatives, while analysts predict further declines, with some predicting prices could drop to $5,700 or $8,700 in coming months.

site_title: NetLink Trust fined S$150,000 for failure to meet standards
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) fined NetLink Trust S$150,000 for failing to meet fibre broadband standards, its sixth fine in five years. The penalty was split into S$100,000 for residential standards and S$50,000 for non-residential standards. This incident highlights NetLink Trust's non-compliance with industry standards, which may impact its reputation and customer trust.

site_title: CapitaLand, Lum Chang acquire Frankfurt office building for 234.3m euros in cash
summary: A joint venture between CapitaLand and Lum Chang Holdings acquired a Frankfurt, Germany office building, Main Airport Center, for 234.3 million euros in cash. CapitaLand holds 94.9% and paid 222.3 million euros. The property is 84% occupied with leases secured for 2018 expected to raise occupancy to over 95%. The building is close to Frankfurt Airport and a new metro station is set to open in 2019, offering a 10-minute connection to the city center. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity to invest in Germany's growing office market.

site_title: The risks of having minority controlling shareholders in firms
summary: Minority controlling shareholders can exploit their control at the expense of the company and other minority shareholders. Initially, the concept of independence in corporate governance was defined as independence from management only. However, as ownership structures changed, especially in Singapore where large shareholders dominate, the definition was revised to include independence from significant shareholders. In 2012, the Singapore Code revised to include independence from 10% shareholders, providing a broader safeguard against exploitation. This shift highlights the need for more stringent rules to protect minority shareholders and promote fair corporate governance.

site_title: Trump's border wall one year into his term is no more than prototype
summary: US President Donald Trump's border wall, a central component of his presidential campaign, remains a prototype one year into his term. No funding has been approved by Congress to advance the project beyond the testing phase, and there is no final design. The wall's construction has been delayed due to opposition from both Democrats and Republicans, with estimates suggesting costs could range from $12 billion to $21.6 billion. Mexico has refused to contribute to the cost, and Trump's promise to have Mexico pay for the wall has largely been dropped.

site_title: Instant gratification: No better time than now for retailers to leverage on web analytics
summary: Retailers can leverage web analytics to enhance customer experiences and drive sales, particularly during the festive shopping season. By integrating online and offline data, retailers can create targeted, personalized recommendations and offers, leading to effective cross-selling and up-selling. Artificial intelligence (AI) can help simplify the shopping process by enabling real-time decision management and predictive analytics through the Internet of Things (IoT) and smart assistants. A well-informed and efficient customer interaction can benefit both customers and businesses, making data analytics a key factor in remaining competitive in the retail industry.

site_title: See two cities for the price of one with layover offers
summary: International airlines are offering free stopovers and incentives on popular routes to make midway hubs a worthwhile second destination. Qatar Airways, WOW air, TAP Portugal, Finnair, and several others are providing complimentary accommodations, transit visas, and shuttle transportation to boost tourism and business at airports. These promotions, which can last from a few days to up to five nights, are available on flights between the US and Europe, Asia, and Africa, allowing travelers to see two cities for the price of one.

site_title: Hong Kong set to be unseated by Busan as 5th busiest container port
summary: Hong Kong is set to lose its ranking as the world's fifth-busiest container port to South Korea's Busan, according to cargo-handling trends. For the second straight month, Hong Kong's sea freight processed dropped in November, with Busan narrowing the gap and poised to overtake it in 2018. China's expanded manufacturing and port capacity, as well as increased direct services to major cities, have contributed to Hong Kong's decline, with its port handling 18.97 million 20-foot containers in the first 11 months of 2017.

site_title: DBS, UOB lift STI 0.4% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,391.67, driven by gains in DBS and UOB, which benefited from economic growth and rising net interest margins. Cosco Shipping International and oil-linked stocks also rebounded, while Keppel Corporation recovered after a fine related to a corruption probe. Analysts maintain positive views, with Deutsche Bank upgrading its target prices for Keppel and Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Citi Singapore backs financial education, youth development
summary: Citi Singapore has committed over S$15.3 million to financial education and youth development programs since 2002. The bank recently hosted 20 students from the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) College East to learn about banking and financial markets. As part of its "e for Education" campaign, Citi donated US$1 for every US$1 million of FX traded, raising US$6.25 million this year. The bank also launched the Citi-TOUCH Youth ASPIRE Programme, offering certification courses and workshops to improve employment prospects for ITE students.

site_title: A new sweetheart
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) has agreed to buy at least 73.8% of Indonesia's Bank Danamon in a US$6 billion deal. The acquisition will be done in three phases, with regulatory approvals needed to increase MUFG's stake to 40% by mid-2018, and then to 73.8% in a later phase. This deal comes after MUFG's rival, DBS, walked away from a similar deal in 2013 due to Indonesian regulatory uncertainty.

site_title: TV Tokyo's New Year's Eve special is to watch a man eat
summary: TV Tokyo is airing a New Year's Eve special featuring a man eating solo, a concept that resonates with Japan's salarymen who often work long hours and struggle to find time for themselves. The show, "The Solitary Gourmet," follows the character Goro Inogashira as he travels to the Setouchi area and enjoys local specialties. The show has become a hit among Japanese audiences, helping to normalize eating alone and challenging traditional societal norms. The special, which will air from 10 pm to 11:30 pm, will feature Inogashira eating at small, family-run restaurants and will be a departure from the usual red-and-white singing contest on NHK that has dominated New Year's Eve programming for over 70 years.

site_title: Xi's tighter grip will put a crimp on Chinese real estate
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is expected to tighten his grip on the country's real estate market, potentially leading to a national property tax that could depress rentals and property prices. The move, which involves bypassing traditional policy shops, aims to accelerate the implementation of a national property tax. This could have significant consequences for China's property market, particularly for rentals and prices. The exact impact is still unclear, but the move is seen as a major shift in China's approach to regulating the real estate sector.

site_title: Turning trash into art at Ghana's toxic dump
summary: In Ghana's Agbogbloshie dumping ground, a group of young men, including 21-year-old Joseph Awuah-Darko, are turning toxic waste into art under a non-profit initiative called Agbogblo.Shine. The group repurposes electronic scraps into high-end furniture, offering training to dump workers and aiming to create a better life for them. The initiative hopes to reduce reliance on burning waste, which poses health risks, and provide a sustainable income for the 40,000 people living in the area.

images.alt_text: Above: A table which Ghanaian artist Joseph Awuah-Darko made from pieces of scrap metal found at the Agbogloshie dumpsite.
Above: A man burning e-waste at the same dumpsite.
Above: Mr Awuah-Darko working on a clock.

site_title: 1MDB has fully paid settlement amount: Abu Dhabi's IPIC
summary: Abu Dhabi's IPIC announced that Malaysian state fund 1MDB has fully paid its settlement amount of US$600 million by December 31, as agreed in a settlement agreement reached in April. This resolves a claim of US$6.5 billion made by IPIC after 1MDB defaulted on its bonds. The payment was made despite 1MDB missing its initial deadline due to regulatory approvals. The move comes amid ongoing money-laundering investigations and civil lawsuits in several countries, including the US, where it's alleged that about US$4.5 billion was misappropriated from 1MDB.

site_title: CCS seeks views on SIA, CAE joint venture
summary: Singapore's Competition Commission is seeking public feedback on a proposed joint venture between CAE International Holdings and Singapore Airlines to establish a commercial flight training centre in Singapore. The deal, announced on December 19, aims to set up, develop, and operate the centre. The public feedback period runs from December 27 to January 10, 2018.

site_title: China's November industrial profit growth slowest since April on weaker price gains
summary: China's industrial profits rose 14.9% in November to 785.8 billion yuan, the slowest growth rate since April at 14.0%. This decline in growth rate is further confirmation of China's slowing economy. Demand and producer price gains also eased, indicating a decline in economic activity. The data suggests policymakers may face increased pressure to stimulate growth.

site_title: Uber working on deal to sell Xchange Leasing to digital car marketplace Fair: source
summary: Uber is working on a deal to sell its US auto-leasing business Xchange Leasing to digital car marketplace Fair. The company shut down the business in September due to heavy losses. Xchange Leasing has started to unwind the business by selling cars at auction. The deal is reportedly in the works, although no official announcement has been made.

site_title: Designing artisanal proteins for your body
summary: Scientists at the University of Washington have cracked the "folding problem" in protein design, a long-standing mystery in the field. Led by director David Baker, the team used a combination of computer simulations and crowd-sourced processing power to design proteins from scratch, resulting in thousands of new proteins with unique shapes. These advancements enable the creation of precise molecular tools for various tasks, such as fighting flu viruses and detecting opioid drugs. The breakthrough has the potential to revolutionize cellular protein design, allowing scientists to construct proteins tailored to specific functions.

site_title: Office market starts shifting in landlords' favour again
summary: Singapore's office market shifted in favor of landlords this year, with the take-up rate for new Grade A space in the CBD exceeding expectations. The rosier economic outlook and a lumpy supply of new developments contributed to this shift. Vacancy rates also increased, further benefiting landlords. This trend is attributed to a robust take-up rate, surpassing initial projections, and a more favorable economic outlook, indicating a potential improvement in the office market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Cybersecurity trends to look out for in 2018
summary: In 2018, cybersecurity trends will focus on resilience over prevention, as security breaches become inevitable. The skills gap in cybersecurity is expected to reach 3.5 million unfilled roles by 2021, requiring collaboration among governments, universities, and businesses. Emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things will drive next-generation security, but also pose new threats. The threat landscape will continue to evolve, targeting vertical industries such as finance and banking, with blockchain technology offering a secure solution. Global cybersecurity spending is expected to reach $93 billion in 2018, with AI security market projected to reach $18.2 billion by 2023.

site_title: Nov pending home sales edge higher; but Dec consumer confidence down
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.2% in November, exceeding economists' forecasts, as the economy strengthens with steady job growth. The National Association of Realtors reported a reading of 109.5, up from October. However, US consumer confidence fell to 122.1 in December, a 17-year high, as optimism about the short-term outlook decreased. Despite this, consumer expectations remain at historically strong levels, suggesting economic growth will continue into 2018.

site_title: Airbus ready to axe A380 if fails to win Emirates deal -sources
summary: Airbus is preparing to end A380 production if it fails to secure an order from Emirates, its largest customer, with 142 aircraft on order. The company has enough orders to last until early next decade but faces weak demand for the four-engined jet. Airbus and Emirates have resumed talks after a breakdown at the Dubai Airshow, but a deal is not imminent. If a deal is not reached, Airbus will phase out production, potentially leaving Emirates' future growth tied to recent Boeing orders.

site_title: Banks to go soul searching for new ways of banking
summary: Banks are facing a significant shift in their business models due to digital disruption. A McKinsey report predicts a 5.2% return on equity (ROE) by 2025 if banks do not adapt. To remain competitive, banks are being urged to consider three paths: scaling up, specializing, or challenging platform companies in the distribution of services. By leveraging technology and data, banks can offer differentiated services, address pain points, and remain relevant in a changing market. However, regulators must also provide room for banks to expand beyond banking to ensure financial inclusion and stability.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up as consumer confidence falls slightly
summary: US stocks edged up on Wednesday as consumer confidence fell slightly to 122.1 in December, down from a 17-year high in November. Despite this, consumer expectations remain at historically strong levels, according to the Conference Board. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh records, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US homeowners rush to pre-pay 2018 tax ahead of deduction cap
summary: US homeowners in states with high property taxes are rushing to pre-pay their 2018 tax bills ahead of a $10,000 cap on state and local levy deductions in the recently signed tax overhaul. Residents in New York, New Jersey, and Washington, D.C. are seeking to deduct 2018 property taxes from 2017 taxes, with some local governments revising rules to facilitate the pre-payments. The move aims to maximize tax savings before the deduction cap takes effect, but may also raise concerns about fairness and the impact on local governments.

site_title: Hotels recast themselves as their city's social hubs
summary: Hotels are revamping their image as social hubs, offering entertainment features to attract non-guests and compete with Airbnb. New hotels, such as the Ramble Hotel in Denver and the Omni Louisville Hotel, are incorporating amenities like screening rooms, bowling alleys, and radio studios. These features aim to boost revenue and provide a unique experience for visitors, mirroring the hotels' role as social gathering spaces in the past.

site_title: A quick look at Singapore's marine and offshore engineering equity market
summary: Singapore's marine and offshore engineering equity market experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Singapore Stock Exchange saw gains, while CGS-CIMB Securities (CGSI) downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in the second half. Meanwhile, MAS and PBOC announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Thong Pak Beow. Additionally, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case, and London's Heathrow considered higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Singapore business not for sale, says AXA's new local boss
summary: AXA's newly installed CEO Jean Drouffe has stated that the company's Singapore operations are not for sale, despite earlier comments from global CEO Thomas Buberl that Singapore was one of 26 markets deemed too small or lacking growth potential. Drouffe notes that Asia is a key growth engine for AXA and that Singapore's life insurance business is a significant contributor to the company's earnings. The CEO plans to focus on expanding AXA's life business in Singapore, targeting the high net worth crowd, and has set a goal to be compared to the "big boys" in the industry.

site_title: Mega-miners will find good things in small packages
summary: Global miners are shifting their focus from size to strategic investments, adopting a mindset similar to private-equity investors and tech companies. Companies like Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton are considering buying small stakes in companies that provide growth or skills, such as lithium miners. With lower debt and increased cash flow, the big four miners have more than halved their net debt since 2013. The industry is also driven by the growing demand for green energy, boosting prices for copper, lithium, and cobalt.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SIIC Environment is set to seek a dual listing on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong, with DBS Group Research maintaining a "hold" rating on the stock due to concerns about valuation. The dual listing is expected to improve trading liquidity but may not enhance valuation. Overseas Education's premises are seen as a disadvantage, and the firm's earnings growth is expected to remain limited due to a challenging operating environment for foreign system schools in Singapore.

site_title: Oil remains near 2015 highs on tight outlook
summary: Oil prices remain near 2015 highs due to a tight market outlook, with Brent and WTI crude futures reaching their highest levels since mid-2015. Pipeline outages in Libya and the North Sea, particularly the Forties pipeline system, contributed to the price increase. However, the disruptions are considered small in the global context, and US oil production is expected to continue to rise, potentially countering efforts to prop up prices.

site_title: Rawabi increases Vallianz stake to 41% following warrant cum rights issue
summary: Vallianz Holdings has completed its rights cum warrants issue, with Rawabi Holding Company Limited emerging as its largest single shareholder, now holding 41.2% of shares. Rawabi increased its ownership from 14.8% after subscribing for 672 million rights shares and 1.34 billion warrants. The total value of Rawabi's subscription is approximately S$48.7 million, offsetting against advances owed to Rawabi. The issue clears the path for Vallianz to resolve outstanding issues and strengthen its balance sheet, with CEO Ling Yong Wah stating exciting opportunities for expansion.

site_title: Allied Tech CEO resigns; new appointments made
summary: Allied Technologies CEO Hsu Ching Yuh has resigned to pursue his own interests, effective Dec 29. The company has announced new appointments, including executive director Darren Chen, COO Tan Siang Keng, and financial controller Ang Lee Ai. These changes follow the resignation of executive director Soh Weng Kheong and the disposal of Allied Technologies (Suzhou) Co for S$25 million. The company aims to diversify its business and invest in technology and services, significantly altering its profile to a high-growth sector.

site_title: Dollar falls as oil price gain boosts commodity currencies
summary: The US dollar fell against a basket of currencies, with the euro rising and commodity currencies like the Canadian and Australian dollars reaching their highest levels in recent weeks. Oil prices surged to 2.5-year highs, boosting commodity currencies, while the euro's rise was driven by volatility in Euro/dollar cross-currency basis swaps. Experts attribute the dollar's decline to the US government's tax reform and potential monetary policy convergence, with some predicting a possible strengthening of the euro into the new year and a potential weakening of the dollar to 108 yen by March.

site_title: Govt trims industrial land supply after market responds to previous spike
summary: The Singapore government has trimmed its industrial land supply for the first half of 2018, after industrial prices and rents responded positively to the previous supply spike. Six Confirmed List and seven Reserve List sites with a total site area of 12.56 hectares will be launched, targeting demand from industrialists and end-users. This move reflects the government's sensitivity to the still fragile industrial property market, with analysts expecting rentals to fall further before bottoming out in 2018.

site_title: Samsung scion denies corruption charges as legal appeal nears end
summary: Samsung's heir, Jay Y Lee, has denied corruption charges as the appeals trial of his five-year jail term nears its end. Lee was convicted of bribing former South Korean president Park Geun-hye to strengthen his control of Samsung Electronics. Lee denies the charge and also disputes allegations of meeting Park one-on-one, instead of three times previously disclosed. The Seoul High Court will rule on the appeal in late January, with a potential Supreme Court case if one side loses. Lee's detention has raised investor concerns about a leadership vacuum, prompting Samsung to appoint new top managers.

site_title: Pre-emptive action will remain key: SGX RegCo CEO
summary: SGX RegCo CEO Tan Boon Gin emphasizes the importance of a pre-emptive approach to securities regulation, aiming to deter corporate malfeasance and regain market trust. In 2017, SGX RegCo oversaw key regulatory initiatives, including the enhancement of "trade with caution" notices and the tightening of IPO admission processes. The regulator will continue to focus on corporate governance, introducing a revised corporate governance code in January and a surveillance handbook for derivatives trading next year. Tan believes a pre-emptive approach, coupled with market buy-in, will be key to successful implementation.

images.alt_text: Tan Boon Gin, chief executive officer of SGX RegCo, shared with The Business Times (BT) recently that the pre-emptive approach to securities regulation, coupled with further improvements in corporate governance, will be extended into the next year
Angela Tan

site_title: Big Tech is carving up turf (and profits) in your healthcare
summary: Big tech companies, including Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Alphabet, are investing heavily in healthcare, aiming to revolutionize the industry with new tools and technologies. They are developing or collaborating on health-tracking apps, investing in health startups, and acquiring companies like Grail and Senosis Health. The goal is to improve healthcare efficiency and reduce costs, but experts caution that it's too early to tell whether these new tools will actually help reduce disease and prolong lives. The market is valued at over $3 trillion in the US, and tech companies are eager to tap into this lucrative market.

images.alt_text: The Apple Heart Study, done with Stanford University, for example, used an app to recruit Apple Watch owners as participants in research into irregular heart rhythms.

site_title: JPMorgan pays US$2.8m fine over improper safeguards for customers
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to pay a US$2.8 million fine to settle charges that its broker-dealer unit lacked sufficient safeguards for customer securities from multiple countries from March 2008 to June 2016. The violations stemmed from defective electronic systems and a lack of supervision, resulting in US$146 million and US$120 million deficits for Italian and Nigerian securities. JPMorgan did not admit wrongdoing, but agreed to address the issues and protect customers from losses.

site_title: Hyundai shipbuilding stocks plunge on grim earnings forecast
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries' shares plummeted by nearly a third after the company announced a plan to issue new stocks to shore up its ailing finances. The company's earnings forecast for 2017 showed sales would be more than halved and operating profit would decrease significantly. Hyundai plans to raise 1.3 trillion won by issuing new shares and listing its refining unit on a local stock market next year. The move aims to cover operating costs and research and development, but will dilute share values. The company's struggles are part of a broader industry-wide slump in the shipbuilding sector.

site_title: SMEs see brighter skies in the new year
summary: Singapore SMEs are increasingly optimistic about future business prospects, with a business sentiment index rising to 51.2 across six industries, indicating an expectation of growth. The industries with the highest optimism are business services, manufacturing, and commerce/trading, with scores of 52.1, 51, and 51, respectively. The survey also shows improvements in turnover expectations, profitability expectations, and access to financing, with SMEs looking to expand and increase output in anticipation of greater demand in the coming year.

site_title: Retailers see biggest spike in sales since 2011
summary: US holiday retail sales increased 4.9% from the previous year, the largest year-over-year increase since 2011, according to Mastercard's SpendingPulse report. Shoppers continued to spend right up until the last minute, with Dec 23 being the second busiest shopping day after Black Friday. Online retail led the way, with a 7.5% increase in electronics and appliances sales, and a 5.9% increase in jewellery sales. Despite a lacklustre year for brick-and-mortar stores, retailers saw a strong holiday season, with the National Retail Federation predicting final sales figures would meet or exceed its October forecast.

site_title: Global economy back to 'normal' after 2017 upside surprises
summary: The global economy rebounded in 2017, with most major developing economies surpassing expectations. The euro area experienced its strongest expansion in a decade, while the UK's growth was stronger than predicted. Central banks began to exit stimulus, with the Federal Reserve forecasting three interest-rate increases in 2018. Despite potential risks from politics and economic slowdowns, Goldman Sachs expects continued support from loose monetary conditions. The global economy appears to have found a 'normal' footing after the 2017 crisis, with inflation starting to return and central banks gradually removing support.

site_title: Trump's 'America First' policy should not be 'America Alone'
summary: US President Donald Trump's National Security Strategy (NSS) emphasizes a "realist" approach to foreign policy, prioritizing protection of US strategic and economic interests over globalist values and multilateral institutions. This shift marks a break with post-Cold War predecessors, who focused on advancing liberal-democratic values and promoting free trade. The NSS aims to deter and contain China and Russia, the two "revisionist powers" deemed threats to US values and interests, by leveraging military and economic power. Critics argue that this approach poses a false dichotomy, as previous administrations have also prioritized American interests through multilateral institutions.

site_title: Chua Hwee Song set to replace Tony Mallek as SPH CFO
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is set to appoint Chua Hwee Song as its new Chief Financial Officer (CFO) on April 1, 2018, replacing Tony Mallek. Chua, founder and managing director of Tembusu Ventures, will assume the role after a month as CFO-designate.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: India to borrow extra 500 billion rupees as revenues slow
summary: India plans to borrow an additional 500 billion rupees (S$10.4 billion) this year due to slowing revenues, with the goal of maintaining spending. This comes after revenue collections from the goods and services tax slowed, raising concerns about fiscal slippage. To offset the borrowing, the government plans to curb treasury bills by over 600 billion rupees. The Reserve Bank of India announced the new borrowing calendar until March 31.

site_title: Tel Aviv toy towers over world record
summary: In Tel Aviv, Israel, a team of municipality workers and volunteers built a 36-meter Lego tower using over half a million donated bricks, aiming to set a new world record. The project was initiated by teachers of an 8-year-old boy who used to build Lego towers during his illness. The previous record was set in 2015 in Milan, Italy, measuring 35.05 meters. The city plans to submit proof, including drone pictures, to Guinness World Records to verify the record.

site_title: China extends tax rebate for electric cars, hybrids
summary: China has extended tax rebates for electric and hybrid cars until the end of 2020, supporting the growth of new-energy vehicles. The move aims to boost innovation and development in the sector, where China is competing with global automakers. NEV sales in China jumped 51.4% in the first 11 months of the year, on track to reach 700,000 units. The extension comes as automakers prepare to meet strict NEV quotas starting in 2019.

site_title: US pending home sales edge higher in November
summary: US pending home sales rose to a reading of 109.5 in November, a 0.2% increase from October, defying economists' forecasts of a 0.4% decline. The housing sector has regained momentum due to a strengthening economy, with the US economy growing at its fastest pace in two years in the third quarter. Sales rose 0.8% from November 2016, with significant gains in the South, Northeast, and Midwest.

site_title: Sats unit in JV for subscription for 49% stake in Mumbai Cargo Service Center
summary: SATS, a mainboard-listed company, has formed a joint venture to acquire a 49% stake in Mumbai Cargo Service Center Airport Private Limited (MCSC) for 49 million rupees. The JV involves Sats Investments II subscribing for 1.4 million shares and 730.2 million rupees of debentures, while Cargo Service Center India Private Limited (CSC) will subscribe for 1.46 million shares and 760 million rupees. The transfer of CSC's business to MCSC is expected to be completed by December 31, 2018.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several Singapore companies reported updates on their financial and operational status. k1 Ventures' subsidiary FSHCO Holdings Pte Ltd will be placed under members' voluntary liquidation, with minimal impact on the company's net tangible assets. Marco Polo Marine expects to complete its debt restructuring exercise early next year. SATS Investments II secured approval for a joint venture in Mumbai, while Vallianz Holdings completed its rights cum warrants issue with Rawabi Holding Company Limited emerging as the largest shareholder.

site_title: Compliance queries drop as SGX seeks to reduce regulatory noise
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) reported a decrease in compliance queries in the July-to-September period, with 97 continuous disclosure queries and 19 unusual trading activities compared to the previous year. The regulator attributed this decline to its efforts to reduce unnecessary alarms and improve transparency. A new query system introduced in November is expected to cut public queries by half.
