summary: South Korean police have arrested the owner and manager of a building where 29 people died in a fire last week, citing multiple safety lapses. The eight-story high-rise in Jecheon had blocked exits and malfunctioning sprinkler systems. At least 20 victims, mostly women, died from toxic fumes in a second-floor sauna. The owner's name is Lee, and the manager's name is Kim. The arrests are a result of an investigation into the fire, which occurred on December 21.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2 per cent down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 7.55 points to 3,378.16 on Tuesday, closing 0.2% lower. The decline was attributed to conglomerate Keppel Corp's announcement of a US$422 million fine as part of a global corruption probe. Despite this, Keppel Corp recovered later in the day. The market saw a higher number of losers (197) compared to gainers (157), with Allied Tech being the most actively traded counter.

site_title: Nippon Paint shopping for big acquisitions, including in Europe
summary: Nippon Paint Holdings is exploring large acquisitions in Europe and the US to expand globally amid industry consolidation. The Osaka-based paint maker's president, Tetsushi Tadoh, stated the company aims to grow through mergers and acquisitions in Europe and the US, following a failed acquisition attempt for Axalta Coating Systems last month. This move is part of Nippon Paint's mid-term plan to expand outside Japan, particularly in China and other Asian countries.

site_title: China's top copper producer halts output after pollution order
summary: China's largest copper producer, Jiangxi Copper Co, has halted all output in the Jiangxi province after the local government ordered curbs to reduce pollution. The move comes as China intensifies its campaign against air pollution and follows a similar order from the nation's second-largest copper producer, Tongling Nonferrous Metals Group Co. The output curbs are expected to reduce smelters' demand for concentrate, supporting their position in annual negotiations with overseas miners. Copper prices surged on the Shanghai Futures Exchange, extending gains from the highest close in two months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.25 points lower at 1,759.99 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of two billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 489 to 387.

site_title: Gold hits over 3-week high on US dollar weakness; palladium at 17-year high
summary: Gold prices reached a three-week high on Tuesday, trading at US$1,278.04 per ounce, due to a weaker US dollar and anemic US consumption data. Palladium also hit its 17-year high at US$1,044.50 per ounce, driven by strong demand from autocatalyst makers. The US dollar index edged down 0.1% to 93.273, while spot silver rose 0.5% to US$16.45 per ounce. Analysts attribute the price surge to risk hedging and physical shortages, particularly in palladium.

site_title: China, Pakistan to look at including Afghanistan in US$57b economic corridor
summary: China and Pakistan discussed extending the US$57 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor to Afghanistan, part of China's Belt and Road plan. The two countries aim to improve relations with Afghanistan, which has been strained due to accusations of Pakistan's support for Taliban insurgents. China hopes the corridor will benefit the whole region and promote development. The three countries agreed to mend their strained relations and tackle smaller projects first to reach a gradual consensus.

site_title: Geo Energy secures US$40m in prepayment for 2018 supply of coal
summary: Geo Energy Resources has secured US$40 million in prepayment for 2018 supply of coal, agreeing to deliver at least 7.5 million tonnes of thermal coal to Engelhart CTP. This is part of a "life of mine" agreement, following previous coal offtake agreements for 4 million and 7 million tonnes in 2017. CEO Tung Kum Hon attributed the demand for SDJ coal to its low sulphur and ash content, and the group's ability to deliver. Geo Energy is also finalizing contracts for its newly acquired Tanah Bumbu Resources mine.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall to 3-month low; won ends at over 2 1/2-year high
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index plummeted to a three-month low, falling 0.54% to 2,427.34. The won reached a two-and-a-half-year high, while bond yields decreased. Individual investors sold major IT shares, citing domestic media reports on Apple's iPhone X sales. Foreign demand boosted the currency, and the KOSPI is up 20.4% this year.

site_title: The sovereign-debt doom loop still threatens banks
summary: The Basel Committee's decision not to act on discouraging banks' concentrated portfolios of sovereign bonds poses a threat to financial stability. Banks holding large amounts of government bonds in their portfolios can be a danger, as they can be severely impacted if investors turn against those bonds. To mitigate this, regulators could set a non-zero risk weight for sovereign bonds from a single country exceeding a certain threshold, linked to the amount of capital held by the bank.

site_title: With a green light from Karachi, Pakistan's women-only taxis eye new cities
summary: Pakistan's women-only taxi service, Paxis, has received a green light from Karachi to expand to new cities, including Sukkur and Peshawar. Launched in March, the service has faced harassment from male road users but drivers say they will persevere. The company aims to double its fleet by the end of the year and plans to introduce Paxis in highly conservative provinces. Despite initial challenges in recruiting female drivers, the service has seen a strong response from women who value the safety and comfort of an all-female environment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation remained subdued in November, with consumer prices rising 0.6%. Manufacturing output increased 5.3% in November, driven by a strengthening global economy. The government will release Q4, full-year advance GDP estimates on January 2. Meanwhile, SembMarine sold its West Rigel rig for $500m, taking a $24m loss, and Keppel's China marina divestment remains stalled due to a legal battle.

images.alt_text: Core inflation, which excludes accommodation and private road transportation costs, was 1.5 per cent.

site_title: Bitcoin rises 10%, recovers from last week's brutal selloff
summary: Bitcoin rose 10% to US$15,049 on Tuesday, recovering from a 30% decline on Friday and its worst week since 2013. The cryptocurrency had previously reached US$19,666 in December and US$20,000 in other exchanges. Despite the recovery, market regulators and central banks have warned of further declines, citing speculation and high risk. Analysts say a natural correction was expected after the rapid price increase.

site_title: South Korea approves LG Display's plan to build Oled factory in China
summary: South Korea's trade ministry has approved LG Display's plan to build an OLED panel production facility in China, conditional on using local materials and equipment, investing in South Korea, and strengthening security checks. This approval comes five months after LG Display announced its investment in large-size OLED production in Guangzhou, China, to meet growing demand for OLED screens in overseas markets.

site_title: Oceanus completes debt restructuring, aims to be net cash positive by end of FY 2017
summary: Oceanus Group has completed its debt restructuring exercise, converting S$71.8 million of debt to equity and issuing 19.7 billion new shares. The group is now debt-free and aims to be net cash positive by the end of FY 2017. This move was approved by shareholders and funded by internal resources, with S$12.8 million remaining to be paid in cash by December 31, 2017. Oceanus' CEO, Peter Koh, described the move as a "watershed moment" and a step towards aggressive business growth and value creation for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Japan considers refitting helicoper carrier for stealth fighters: govt sources
summary: Japan is considering refitting its helicopter carrier, Izumo, to accommodate US F-35B stealth fighters, aiming to bolster defense around its southwestern islands and prepare for a scenario of destroyed runways. The refit would involve adding a curved ramp, improving heat resistance, and reinforcing air traffic control capabilities. Japanese Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera stated that no concrete steps are being taken, but the government is conducting examinations on defense posture, including the introduction of F-35B and remodelling of Izumo-class destroyers.

site_title: Japan's household spending jumps but BOJ seen keeping stimulus
summary: Japan's household spending increased in November, with consumer inflation rising to 1.3% from 0.9% in October. The jobless rate hit a 24-year low, fueling hopes for inflation to reach the 2% target. However, rising fuel costs are seen fading in 2018, keeping the Bank of Japan under pressure to maintain its stimulus. Minutes of the BOJ's October rate review showed policymakers agree to sustain "powerful" monetary easing for the time being, despite no need to ramp up stimulus. The BOJ is likely to keep its stimulus in place for the time being.

site_title: PUB penalises building contractors for discharging silty water into drains
summary: PUB has penalized 74 building contractors in 2017 for discharging silty water into public drains and failing to implement proper earth control measures (ECM). The silty water, generated by rainwater runoff mixing with exposed earth materials, can build up in waterways, affecting their effectiveness and environmental aesthetics. Contractors can be fined up to S$5,000 for silty water discharge and S$50,000 for inadequate ECM. The penalties come after PUB took enforcement action against 100 contractors over the past three years, with two firms, Peng Chuan Engineering Construction and Stallion Development, fined S$7,800 and S$7,000 respectively.

site_title: JTC launches 2 sites under Industrial Government Land Sales programme
summary: JTC has launched two sites under the Industrial Government Land Sales programme. The confirmed list site at Tuas South Link 3 (0.63 hectares) is zoned for Business-2 development with a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. The reserve list site at Braddell Road (0.97 hectares) is zoned for Business-1 development with a 30-year tenure and a maximum gross plot ratio of 2.5. Both sites are open for tender until February 27, as part of government efforts to offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: Pyongyang likely to pursue talks, Seoul says in rosy New Year forecast
summary: South Korea predicted that North Korea will pursue talks with the US over its nuclear programs in 2018, while continuing to seek recognition as a nuclear-armed state. The prediction comes after the UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on North Korea for its recent ICBM test. Despite US President Donald Trump's skepticism, South Korea believes the North will find ways to mitigate the effects of the sanctions, potentially leading to some rapprochement with Seoul.

site_title: China has shut down 13,000 websites since 2015: Xinhua
summary: China has shut down or revoked the licenses of 13,000 websites since 2015 for violating internet rules, according to state media. The country has also closed nearly 10 million internet accounts for violating service protocol. China's internet regulation has strengthened under President Xi Jinping's rule, with new rules requiring foreign tech companies to store user data domestically and imposing content restrictions. The country defends its web censorship as necessary for protecting national security, despite being ranked as one of the most restrictive online use policies globally.

site_title: Singapore November factory output up 5.3% despite drag from pharma
summary: Singapore's factory output expanded 5.3% in November, driven by strong growth in the electronics and chemicals clusters. However, the biomedical manufacturing sector declined 23.3% due to a decrease in pharmaceuticals output. Electronics manufacturing output surged 27.6% and precision engineering grew 19.9% year on year. Overall, excluding biomedical manufacturing, factory output would have risen 13.9%. The results are a slight disappointment to economists, who had expected an 8.1% increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.450 points to 1,755.790. The market saw a high volume of 320.24 million lots worth RM159.75 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 233 to 205, indicating a bearish trend.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 losing 0.20% to 22,892.69, and the Topix index down 0.27% to 1,827.01, due to late profit-taking amid major global markets' Christmas holiday closures.

site_title: China's Fosun exploring sale of Hollywood studio: sources
summary: Fosun Group, backed by billionaire Guo Guangchang, has explored selling its 80% stake in Hollywood production house Studio 8 Inc, valuing the studio at up to $1 billion. Fosun, which acquired the studio three years ago, has approached investors to discuss a potential sale or financing for the studio's upcoming films. The company may retain its holding, but is not in formal talks with potential buyers. Studio 8 has received $1 billion in financing and has released several films, including "Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk" and "White Boy Rick".

site_title: Zimbabwe's farmers brace for return of destructive new pests
summary: Farmers in Zimbabwe are bracing for the return of destructive new pests, including fall armyworm, tomato leafminer, and cotton mealybug, which devastated harvests in 2017. Climate change has created warmer conditions conducive to the pests' spread, and many farmers lack knowledge or resources to control them. The pests, including the fall armyworm, which destroyed 20% of Zimbabwe's maize crop last season, are native to the Americas and have spread across the continent. Zimbabwe's government is preparing for a possible outbreak this season, with agricultural extension officers teaching farmers about the pests and advising them to report sightings.

site_title: China ranks provincial economies with new environment index
summary: China has released a new "Green Development Index" ranking 31 provincial-level regions based on environment-related indicators, such as pollution cleanup efforts and resource utilization. Beijing topped the list, followed by Fujian and Zhejiang, while Ningxia, Tibet, and Xinjiang ranked at the bottom. The index aims to shift away from the growth-at-all-cost model, with heavy enforcement measures to clean up pollution. Results also show residents in Hebei, Beijing, and Tianjin are the least satisfied, while those in Tibet, Guizhou, and Hainan are the most satisfied.

site_title: Analysts cross fingers for 2018 return of biopharma mega-mergers
summary: Analysts predict a potential return of biopharma mega-mergers in 2018, driven by tax reform and lower levies on US companies' overseas cash. Goldman analysts forecast $160 billion in repatriated cash, which could be used for "aggressive capital allocation" through M&A, buybacks, or dividends. RBC analysts also anticipate a boost in M&A activity, citing the need for deal-making to stabilize the sector. The 2017 pause in deal-making may be broken, with analysts hopeful for a rebound in 2018.

site_title: Yandex to expand UberEats in Russia with local acquisition
summary: Yandex NV, Russia's largest search engine, acquired local food-delivery firm Foodfox to expand its UberEats tie-up in Russia, following a July agreement to merge with Uber Technologies Inc. The deal, approved by the Russian antitrust service, aims to control a US$3.7 billion joint venture. Foodfox, which works with 2,000 restaurants in Moscow, will head the venture's food-delivery division. The acquisition seeks to tap into Russia's US$1.3 billion food-delivery market, with Yandex seeking regional expansion using its online advertising power.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; Keppel, SembMarine down on corruption probe
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 5.1 points, or 0.2%, to 3,380.61. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 52. Keppel Corp and SembMarine fell 4.55% and 3.6% respectively, amid a global corruption probe involving Keppel O&M, which will pay US$422 million in fines. The probe also puts SembMarine under scrutiny, as it was awarded US$10 billion of rig-building contracts tied to the scandal.

site_title: China to become world's No 2 LNG importer in 2017, behind Japan
summary: China is set to become the world's second-largest importer of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in 2017, surpassing South Korea with imports rising by over 50% to around 38 million tonnes. This marks a significant boost to Asia's emerging spot market, with Chinese buyers relying on short-term purchases.

images.alt_text: China will become the world's second-biggest importer of liquefied natural gas (LNG) this year as it overtakes South Korea, shipping data in Thomson Reuters Eikon showed.

site_title: Lian Beng unit to sell Australian property for A$90m
summary: Lian Beng Group's wholly owned subsidiary, LBF, has agreed to sell an Australian property, 50 Franklin Street in Melbourne, for A$90.15 million (S$93.5 million), marking a profit of A$38.65 million (S$41.0 million) after purchasing it for A$51.5 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Singapore consumer prices rise 0.6% in November
summary: Singapore's inflation remained subdued in November, with headline inflation rising 0.6% from the previous year, and 0.6% month-over-month. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transportation costs, remained unchanged at 1.5%. This data is seen as a positive sign for the Monetary Authority of Singapore's monetary policy moves, as it indicates a stable economy with low inflationary pressures.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading in negative territory on Tuesday; STI at 3,371.39
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index at 3,371.39, down 0.42% or 14.32 points. The index started the day down marginally, but later fell 0.03% or 1.1 point. 245.1 million shares worth S$271.6 million were traded.

site_title: Taiwan warns Chinese military drills pose 'enormous threat'
summary: Taiwan has warned that China's frequent and increased military drills pose an "enormous threat" to its security, citing a 14th national defense report. The drills, which include warplanes conducting at least 20 exercises around Taiwan this year, have created a "multiple deterrence strategy" for Taiwan's military. Taiwan's defense minister stated that the country cannot match China's military budget and development, prompting Taiwan to review and develop asymmetric warfare to deter Chinese advances. China views Taiwan as part of its territory to be reunified, and the situation remains tense.

site_title: Beijing tops China's first "green development" index, but sinks in public opinion
summary: China published its first "green development" index, ranking regional governments based on environmentally friendly development. Beijing topped the list, but ranked 30th in public satisfaction with the environment. Tibet was the highest ranked in public satisfaction. The index measured 55 statistical parameters, including investment in environmental cleanup and resource use. China plans to conduct the evaluation annually. Despite Beijing's top ranking, the city's poor air quality was highlighted, with Hebei province surrounding it ranking 20th. The government has vowed to reduce air pollution across 28 northern cities by 2020.

site_title: Japan PM Abe urges firms to raise wages by 3% or more
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged companies to raise wages by 3% or more in 2018 to sustain Japan's economic cycle and achieve its inflation target. This comes as companies have been hesitant to raise wages due to concerns about losing customers if they increase prices. The Bank of Japan has also expressed concerns about consumers' reluctance to accept price rises. Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus policies have boosted corporate profits, but firms remain reluctant to raise wages and prices, citing an uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: Pyongyang preparing to launch satellite: report
summary: North Korea is reportedly preparing to launch a satellite, the Kwangmyongsong-5, despite being prohibited from using ballistic missile technology. The launch is seen as a potential disguise for a long-range missile test, as it has been in the past. The move is part of North Korea's 2016-2020 plan to develop practical satellites, which the country claims is in line with international laws. The launch has raised tensions, following recent atomic and intercontinental ballistic missile tests by the isolated regime.

site_title: Iraqi oil minister says expects oil market to be in balance in first quarter
summary: Iraqi Oil Minister Jabar al-Luaibi expects oil market balance by the first quarter of 2018, driven by decreased global inventories and positive signs of improved prices. The country signed a deal with China's Zhenhua Oil to develop the East Baghdad oilfield, with a potential US$3 billion development cost. The new contract links global oil prices and costs, aiming to minimize development costs. Iraq plans to utilize 20 million cubic feet of gas as a by-product of oil production to supply a nearby power station.

site_title: Top India oil explorer to buy, not drill, its way to output goal
summary: India's state-run Oil & Natural Gas Corp plans to acquire producing assets to reach its goal of raising overseas oil output by over 50% in three years, instead of drilling for new reserves. The company spent $2.2 billion last year on a Russian project, increasing production by 44%. Managing Director Narendra Kumar Verma stated that producing assets are the faster route to achieving production goals due to the long exploration life cycle. The move aims to bolster energy security for a country that imports over 80% of its oil.

site_title: US dollar steady in light trade, yen little changed after Japan inflation data
summary: The US dollar remained steady in holiday-thinned trading, unaffected by Japan's inflation data, which showed core consumer prices rose 0.9% year-on-year. The dollar was flat against the yen at 113.29. Despite upbeat economic data, the dollar index edged down 0.1% due to muted market reaction. The euro remained steady at $1.1871, while cryptocurrency bitcoin rose 1.7% to $14,142.33. Market participants await the start of 2018, with the US tax bill and government shutdown averted.

site_title: From big screen to big impact, five celebrities running businesses that give back
summary: Five celebrities are using their businesses to make a positive impact. Hugh Jackman's Laughing Man coffee trades directly with growers, providing fair prices and funding education and community development projects. Rosario Dawson's Studio 189 sells handmade, fair-trade clothing in Ghana, promoting African patterns and fabrics. Pharrell Williams' Bionic recycles plastic into yarn, reducing ocean pollution. Michael Sheen plans to launch a community hub in Port Talbot, supporting community-owned businesses. Jamie Oliver's Fifteen restaurant trains disadvantaged young people as chefs, with over 500 alumni working in kitchens.

images.alt_text: Famous for playing character Wolverine in the X-Men series of films, Australian actor High Jackman first stuck his tungsten talons into social enterprise in 2011 after a trip to Ethiopia.

site_title: South Korea's Hyundai Motor union rejects tentative wage deal
summary: South Korea's Hyundai Motor union has rejected a tentative wage deal, with 50.2% of its members voting against it due to deemed inadequate wage levels compared to previous years. The union, which represents 45,008 workers, had a 88% turnout in the vote. Hyundai Motor has agreed to continue discussions with the union, hoping for an amicable agreement. The union plans to negotiate a new deal within the year.

site_title: Tattooed and proud: Chinese women peel away stigmas
summary: In China, the stigma surrounding tattoos is slowly fading, particularly among women. The influence of celebrity culture and the growing number of tattoo studios in Shanghai, dubbed "China's tattoo mecca," are driving the trend. Women are increasingly embracing body art, with 60-70% of tattoo artists now catering to female clients. The industry has expanded, with estimates suggesting 200,000 tattoo artists in the country, and tattoos are no longer seen as a mark of crime or immorality.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slightly higher
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 4.66 points or 0.19% to 2,445.20 on Tuesday, with the Korean won up 0.14% to 1,078.2 per US dollar. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index was up 0.06%, while Japanese stocks weakened 0.11%. The Kospi is up 20.4% this year, and foreigners were net buyers of 35,980 million won worth of shares.

site_title: VibroPower: 'Misalignment of expectations' behind financial controller resignations
summary: VibroPower Corp, a power generator set manufacturer, attributed the recent financial controller resignations to a "misalignment of expectations" between management and the controllers on job requirements and performance. The company has taken steps to find a suitable replacement and is confident that acting group financial controller Sia Huai Peng can discharge her duties. This comes after the company was placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to failing to meet trading price and market cap requirements.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, December 26, 2017, due to investors keeping to the sidelines as major global markets remained closed for the Christmas holidays. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.06% to 22,925.84, while the Topix index fell 0.07% to 1,830.56.

site_title: Analysts cut iPhone X forecasts, citing lukewarm demand
summary: Analysts have lowered iPhone X shipment projections for the first quarter of 2018, citing weak demand due to the high price point and lack of innovative features. Shipments are expected to be around 25 million units, down from 30 million units in the fourth quarter. This drop reflects concerns that the iPhone X failed to boost global demand, despite being heavily promoted. Apple's market value has soared 51% this year, but the company is facing challenges from Samsung and Chinese brands in emerging markets.

site_title: Pope seeks peace in Jerusalem, highlights plight of war-scarred children
summary: Pope Francis called for peace in Jerusalem and the Holy Land in his Christmas address, highlighting the plight of children affected by conflict. The plea came amid tensions following President Donald Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The pontiff also mentioned other global flashpoints, including Syria, Iraq, and Yemen, and urged the international community to help find harmony, justice, and security in these regions.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis on Monday called for peace in Jerusalem in his traditional Christmas address and highlighted the plight of children scarred by conflict, after urging the world's 1.3 billion Catholics not to ignore migrants.

site_title: Early drama as Sydney to Hobart fleet race to break record
summary: The 73rd Sydney to Hobart yacht race began on December 26, 2017, with Supermaxi LDV Comanche leading the fleet of 102 entries. The event aims to break the record for the fastest vessel, with supermaxis capable of reaching speeds of up to 20 knots. The light east to south-easterly winds favored the large boats, with Black Jack and Wild Oats XI initially leading before Comanche took the lead after a close call near the exit to Sydney Heads. The supermaxis are expected to arrive in Hobart on Wednesday, with conditions on the Derwent River expected to be challenging.

images.alt_text: Supermaxi yacht Black Jack led the Sydney to Hobart fleet out of the harbour Tuesday, chasing a new race record amid "dream" conditions in the gruelling annual dash down Australia's east coast.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Marine, Q&M Dental
summary: Keppel Corp faces fines of US$422 million due to a global corruption probe. The company's planned sale of a China marina stake remains stalled. Sembcorp Marine sold a rig for US$500 million, taking a loss, but faces potential heat from related probes. Q&M Dental Group completed a 10-month strategic review with no changes.

site_title: Japan inflation picks up in November but still below target
summary: Japan's inflation rose 0.9% in November, exceeding expectations, but remains below the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The unemployment rate dropped to 2.7%, the lowest since 1993, while household spending increased 1.7% from a year ago. Despite healthy economic growth, inflation remains muted due to a tight labor market and limited wage growth, leading the Bank of Japan to maintain its monetary stimulus program unchanged.

site_title: Germans must not fear political uncertainty: president
summary: German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier urged citizens not to fear the country's months-long political stalemate, saying "not everything unexpected must scare us". Chancellor Angela Merkel won elections three months ago without a clear majority and is struggling to form a new coalition. Steinmeier stated that the prolonged government formation is "unusual" but not necessarily alarming. The German leader emphasized stability and confidence in the face of uncertainty, assuring citizens that the country will navigate the situation.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed, euro rebounds, bitcoin recovers
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on the last trading day of 2017, with Japanese benchmarks slipping despite reaching a 30-year high. The euro rebounded against the US dollar after briefly sliding on Monday. US equity-index futures opened little changed, while Taiwan's stocks underperformed due to downgraded iPhone X sales estimates. The euro's dramatic moves were attributed to low liquidity, which can be influenced by automated trading programs.

site_title: Kuwait secures LNG deal as Gulf energy exporters hunt for gas
summary: Kuwait secured a 15-year liquefied natural gas deal with Royal Dutch Shell, locking in supplies as Gulf energy exporters consider their own import strategies. The UAE and Kuwait are the only importers of LNG in the region, while Saudi Arabia is exploring imports from Russia, East Africa, and the US. The oil-rich countries are seeking to import more natural gas for power generation and petrochemical plants, as they lose export revenue by using growing quantities of crude in power generation.

site_title: Japan jobless rate lowest since 1993
summary: Japan's unemployment rate fell to 2.7% in November, its lowest level since 1993, as the country experiences seven consecutive quarters of economic growth. The jobs-to-applicants ratio improved, with a slight increase to 1.56, the highest level in nearly 44 years. However, consumer spending remains weak, and deflation continues to affect the economy, with inflation still below the Bank of Japan's two-per-cent target. Strong household spending in November may be a reaction to previous weak figures, but experts warn that strong inflation without wage increases could hurt domestic demand.

site_title: Euro gets lump of holiday coal, briefly slides against US dollar
summary: The euro briefly slid 3% against the US dollar on Christmas Day due to computer-driven trading, according to analysts. The sudden drop, which occurred during a holiday market with limited trading volume, rebounded within hours and ended the day with little change. Hiroshi Yanagisawa, chief analyst at FX Prime by GMO, attributed the event to algorithmic trading and the absence of market-moving news. The euro's value ended the day at US$1.1870, little changed from its previous day's close.

site_title: Israel regulator seeks to ban bitcoin firms from stock exchange
summary: Israel's markets regulator, the Israel Securities Authority, plans to propose a ban on companies based on bitcoin and other digital currencies from trading on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. Chairman Shmuel Hauser stated that if a company's main business is digital currencies, it would not be allowed to trade, and existing listed companies would have their trading suspended. This move comes after the sharp rise and subsequent decline of bitcoin's value, with Hauser expressing concerns over the volatility and uncertainty of the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Singapore to release Q4, full-year advance GDP estimates on Jan 2
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry in Singapore will release its advance GDP estimates for the fourth quarter and full-year 2017 on January 2. The estimates, which were previously upgraded to 3% to 3.5%, show the economy grew 5.2% in the third quarter, its best performance since 2013. Analysts predict a 2.8% GDP growth for the fourth quarter. Looking ahead to 2018, the government expects moderate growth, ranging from 1.5% to 3.5%.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams
For 2018, MTI said last month it expects the pace of growth to moderate, compared with 2017, but "remain firm", tipping growth at 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: First Sponsor to buy second office property in Amsterdam's CBD for 55.5m euros
summary: First Sponsor Group has agreed to acquire a second office building in Amsterdam's central business district, Meerparc, for 55.5 million euros (S$88.6 million). The five-storey property, located in the South Axis, is home to anchor tenant DLA Piper Nederland BV. The deal is part of the group's expansion strategy, with CEO Neo Teck Pheng stating it will enhance recurrent income and offer redevelopment potential due to the property's prime location and freehold tenure.

site_title: China exceeds target for household gas projects, but some left freezing
summary: China exceeded its target of 3.1 million households switching to natural gas or electricity for heating, completing projects for 3.9 million households or 25,220 villages. However, some rural villages, accounting for 16% of the total, have not completed the switch, leaving residents to continue burning coal and facing freezing temperatures. China's LNG imports hit a record 4.06 million tonnes in November, contributing to shortages and price increases. The Ministry for Environmental Protection acknowledged the consequences of the move for the first time, highlighting the challenges of the ambitious programme.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte's son quits as vice mayor of hometown Davao
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte's eldest son, Paolo Duterte, has quit as vice mayor of Davao, citing personal problems from a failed marriage and being linked to a drug smuggling case. Paolo, who testified in a senate investigation into a seized shipment of narcotics, denied any involvement. His resignation comes amid a recent online spat with his 15-year-old daughter from his first marriage, and amid opposition accusations that he may have helped ease the entry of the shipment.

site_title: Japan's Denso considering 50b yen investment in JOLED: Kyodo
summary: Japan's auto parts maker Denso is considering a 50 billion yen ($593.71 million) investment in JOLED, an organic light-emitting diode (OLED) panel maker. JOLED aims to expand its capacity and raise 100 billion yen to meet growing demand for OLED screens. The investment is seen as a response to the shift towards OLED panels, with smartphone makers like Apple and Samsung Electronics leading the charge. Denso's potential investment, combined with others, could total 20-40 billion yen, as JOLED is 75% owned by a state-backed technology investment fund.

site_title: New Silkroutes seeks to extend trading halt
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a Singapore-listed company, has requested to extend the trading halt for its shares, citing ongoing negotiations with "various parties" and the need to prevent leakage of material information. The company expects revenue of at least $500 million for the 2018 fiscal year, a 15% increase from 2017. The trading halt was initially requested on November 29, and the company will maintain the halt until negotiations are completed. This move aims to maintain the integrity of the company's shares during a period of significant negotiations.

site_title: Keppel's China marina divestment remains stalled amid legal battle
summary: Keppel's planned sale of its 80% stake in Keppel Cove, a China marina project, remains stalled due to a legal battle with minority shareholder Sunsea Yacht Club. The Singapore High Court granted Sunsea's request to block the sale, pending an appeal to the Court of Appeal. If the deal goes through, Keppel will recognize a gain of approximately S$290 million.

site_title: China island expansion moves ahead in South China Sea
summary: China's land reclamation efforts in the South China Sea are progressing steadily, with the construction of military facilities and equipment on newly created islands. The process, which began several years ago, is on track to transform even more of the disputed region. China claims nearly all of the sea, which has led to conflicts with neighboring countries. The construction is reportedly being carried out using "giant island-builders" to create more land, further solidifying China's presence in the region.

site_title: Keppel, SembMarine fall 3% by noon in wake of Keppel O&M's corruption fines
summary: Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine shares fell 3% by noon on Dec 26, 2017, following Keppel Offshore and Marine's (O&M) disclosure of a $422 million fine in a global corruption probe. The fine, part of a resolution across Singapore, Brazil, and the US, led to the decline in share prices. Keppel's stock lost 25 cents to S$7.22, while SembMarine shares slid six cents to S$1.88 on high volumes of trades.

site_title: Hong Kong, Australia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Hong Kong and Australian financial markets closed on December 26, 2017, for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China to overtake US economy by 2032 as Asian might builds
summary: China is expected to surpass the US economy by 2032, according to a report by the Centre for Economics and Business Research. By 2032, three of the four largest economies will be Asian, with China, India, and Japan leading the way. India is projected to become the world's fifth-largest economy by 2019 and third by 2027. South Korea and Indonesia are also expected to enter the top 10 economies by 2032, surpassing the Group of Seven nations. This shift in economic power dynamics is attributed to the growing importance of Asia's major economies.

images.alt_text: The growing importance of Asia's major economies will continue in 2018 and beyond, according to a league table that sees the region dominating in terms of size in just over a decade.

site_title: Q&M Dental wraps up strategic review and concludes no changes needed
summary: Q&M Dental Group, a Singapore-based dental services provider, has concluded a 10-month strategic review with no changes to its current strategy. The company, in collaboration with financial adviser Religare Capital Markets Corporate Finance, examined various aspects of its business and submitted its observations to the board. Based on the findings, the board deemed no change in strategy necessary, thus concluding the strategic review.

site_title: Putin critic Navalny barred from Russian presidential election
summary: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was barred from running in next year's presidential election due to a suspended prison sentence. The central election commission, with 12 out of 13 members voting, ruled Navalny ineligible to participate. Navalny plans to appeal the decision and has called on supporters to boycott the election. Polls show incumbent Vladimir Putin is likely to win comfortably, and Navalny has denied any wrongdoing in the case against him.

site_title: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui keen to raise stake in Indonesian bank BTPN to majority
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) is seeking to raise its stake in Indonesian bank BTPN to a majority if regulatory approval is granted. The bank has a 40% stake in BTPN, which it acquired in 2013-2014, and aims to expand its presence in emerging Asia markets. SMFG's CEO, Takeshi Kunibe, said the bank is studying global capital rules to determine its capital policy and shareholder returns. This move comes as Japanese banks face pressure to seek growth drivers due to low interest rates and stricter capital rules globally.

site_title: Peru's pardoned ex-president Fujimori still in hospital
summary: Peru's pardoned ex-president Alberto Fujimori remains in intensive care in a Lima hospital, a day after being granted a pardon for his 25-year sentence for crimes against humanity. President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski ordered the pardon due to Fujimori's progressive and incurable illness and the risk of harm in prison conditions. The pardon applies to Fujimori and seven other prisoners.

site_title: 'The Last Jedi' tops US$100m for second week in holiday bonanza
summary: Star Wars: The Last Jedi topped US$100 million in ticket sales for the second consecutive weekend, with a 54% drop in revenue from the previous week. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle, a remake of the 1995 film, came in second with a 78% favorable rating from critics. Other new releases, including Pitch Perfect 3 and The Greatest Showman, also performed well, while Coco, Downsizing, and Darkest Hour trailed behind. The busy holiday weekend saw a mix of successful and underperforming films.

site_title: Most BOJ policymakers saw need to sustain 'powerful' easing: Oct meeting minutes
summary: Most Bank of Japan policymakers agreed that sustained powerful monetary easing is necessary, but additional stimulus measures are not required at this time, according to the October rate review minutes. Some board members expressed concerns about the effects and drawbacks of ETF purchases, suggesting a need to examine their impact on market functions. The BOJ will continue to pursue its easing policy, but with a focus on maintaining its current approach rather than taking extreme measures.

site_title: Queen praises terror-hit London, Manchester in Christmas message
summary: Queen Elizabeth II praised the resilience of London and Manchester in her Christmas message, following terror attacks in both cities this year. She also honored her husband Prince Philip's retirement from solo public duties and welcomed Meghan Markle, the first American-born fiancée to spend Christmas with the royal family. The Queen described a hospital visit to Manchester patients as a privilege, showcasing their bravery and resilience.

site_title: RBS to pay US$125m to settle California mortgage bond claims
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) will pay US$125 million to settle claims that it made misrepresentations while selling mortgage-backed securities to California pension funds. The California attorney-general's office found that RBS failed to accurately disclose the true traits of thousands of mortgages underlying the securities, leading to millions of dollars in losses. The settlement resolves claims from the 2004-2008 period and comes as RBS seeks to resolve a US Justice Department investigation into its sales of mortgage-backed securities.

site_title: Bitcoin extends selloff as investors pare bets in holiday season
summary: Bitcoin declined further over the holiday weekend, extending its selloff after failing to reach $20,000. The market's recent surge was due to increased investor bets, but traders took profits ahead of the Christmas holiday, leading to a four-day drop that's the worst since 2015. Analysts attribute the decline to increased dollar trading and reduced yen trading, with some speculating that the West's influence is causing the selloff.

site_title: Japan's Nov consumer prices rise for 11th straight month, spending jumps
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.9% in November, the 11th consecutive month, driven by fuel cost increases expected to fade in 2018. Household spending jumped 1.7% in November, exceeding forecasts. The Bank of Japan remains under pressure to maintain monetary support despite a steady economic recovery, as inflation remains below its 2% target. The central bank kept policy steady last week, with its governor assuring markets it will lag behind overseas peers in ending its ultra-loose settings.

site_title: Canada to expel Venezuelan diplomat in retaliatory move
summary: Canada will expel a Venezuelan diplomat and bar the ambassador from returning after Venezuela expelled Canadian and Brazilian envoys for criticizing its human rights record. The move comes amid growing international criticism of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro. Venezuela claims foreign governments are trying to encourage a right-wing coup. Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland announced the retaliatory measure in response to Venezuela's actions.

site_title: US regulator proposes scaling back offshore drilling safety rules: WSJ
summary: A US regulator, the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE), has proposed scaling back offshore drilling safety rules, including relaxing real-time data requirements and cutting third-party inspector certification. The move, aimed at reducing government oversight, comes after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill, which left 11 dead and resulted in a $60 billion fine and clean-up costs. The proposal has not yet been made public, but the BSEE sent it to the White House budget office.

site_title: Bundesbank says no to official digital money for eurozone
summary: The Bundesbank has ruled out the introduction of official digital money for the eurozone, citing risks of losses from investments in cryptocurrencies like bitcoin. Board member Carl-Ludwig Thiele warned of rapid price increases and potential bubble risks. Experts, including the Bank for International Settlements and German economic advisers, have also expressed concerns over the risks of unregulated digital currencies and potential distortions in financial markets. Regulators are still working to understand the topic and build their know-how.

site_title: Kuka's CEO plans for robot domination in China and your garage
summary: Kuka, a German industrial giant, aims to transform its business by expanding into higher-growth robot markets, particularly in China. With 68 robots per 10,000 Chinese manufacturing workers, the country offers significant growth potential. Kuka's chairman, Till Reuter, plans to diversify the company's product line to include smaller-sized robots for electronics manufacturing, logistics warehouses, and consumer-focused robots. The company's 120-year-old parent Midea, China's largest appliance maker, has committed to protecting Kuka's independence and promoting its growth in the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: German industrial giant Kuka is the world's largest producer of robots used to make automobiles, with its signature orange crane-like bots a fixture in automated car factories across the globe.

site_title: Yuan rises to three-month high as thin liquidity magnifies moves
summary: The onshore yuan rose to a three-month high of 6.5406 per US dollar as China's central bank boosted its daily reference rate amid thin liquidity. This move followed a four-day drop in transaction volume, as traders left for the year-end holidays. The yuan is expected to gain 6.2% against the US dollar in 2017, its best year since 2008, with analysts forecasting a domestic exchange rate of 6.55 by year-end. The People's Bank of China's actions aim to limit capital outflows and support the currency.

images.alt_text: The onshore yuan rose to the strongest level in more than three months as the People's Bank of China boosted its daily reference rate for the currency amid thin liquidity.

site_title: N Korea rejects new sanctions, vows vengeance
summary: North Korea rejected new UN sanctions, calling them an "act of war" and vowing vengeance against US sympathizers. The UN resolution cuts petroleum deliveries by almost 90% starting January 1, aimed at curbing its nuclear expansion. North Korea's Foreign Ministry spokesman stated that the US must abandon its hostile policy and "learn to co-exist" to avoid nuclear conflict. The move is seen as a defiant response to the international pressure.

site_title: Tighter US monetary policy ahead: Goldman
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a $1.5 trillion tax-overhaul bill, boosting the economy and potentially leading to tighter monetary policy. Goldman Sachs analysts predict the jobless rate will reach 3.3% by 2019, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The bill's impact on average Americans is disputed, but Republicans claim it will benefit them as unemployment drops to 4.1% and job openings rise. Goldman Sachs chief economist Jan Hatzius expects continued strong growth to push the economy beyond full employment, leading to further monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Ineos starts testing UK's Forties North Sea oil pipeline after repairs
summary: Ineos has started testing the UK's Forties North Sea oil pipeline after repairs, with full flows expected to resume in early January. The closure, which began on December 11, led to oil prices rising above $65 a barrel. The pipeline, which carries 450,000 barrels of crude daily, was shut down after a crack was found. Ineos declared force majeure on deliveries, citing circumstances beyond its control, and expects to bring the pipeline back to normal rates early in the new year.

images.alt_text: Britain's Forties oil and gas pipeline, one of the biggest in the North Sea, is being tested following repairs and full flows should resume in early January, its operator Ineos said on Monday.

site_title: US bull run charges on despite oil gain and bitcoin pain
summary: US stocks finished near record highs last week, setting the stage for a strong year, despite a tax cut that initially caused a sell-off. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 25% for the year, with banks benefiting from lower corporate tax rates and potential infrastructure spending. However, some experts warn that the tax bill's impact may be offset by regulatory changes and rising interest rates, which could lead to inflation.

site_title: Trump tax bill could put Credit Suisse at risk of third straight loss
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG is at risk of a third consecutive annual loss due to a 2.3 billion-franc (S$3.12 billion) hit from the US tax overhaul signed into law by President Trump. The bank had a net income of 1.14 billion Swiss francs after nine months. Unless it makes significantly more than 1 billion francs in the last quarter, the writedown could trigger another yearly deficit. The bank's current position puts it at risk of posting a loss unless it makes a significant recovery.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse is reassuring investors that the policy for returning capital to shareholders remains unchanged and that the one-time accounting adjustment will have a "minimal" effect on its capital position.

site_title: World's most expensive home to hit market at US$500 million
summary: The world's most expensive home, "The One" in Los Angeles, is set to hit the market at $500 million, surpassing the current record of $137 million in the US and $300 million worldwide. Designed by architect Paul McClean, the 100,000-square-foot estate features 20 bedrooms, including a 5,500-square-foot master suite, multiple pools, and a nightclub. Real estate agents question its feasibility, citing a nonexistent market for such high-end homes in California, with only three or four sales over $100 million in the past decade.

site_title: Hamleys opens its largest toy store in Beijing amid Christmas debate
summary: Hamleys, a British toy retailer, opened its largest store in Beijing, China, in the Wangfujing shopping district on December 22, 2017. The five-storey emporium features a teddy bear parade and Santa, but prices are reportedly high, with a stuffed lemur costing 1,619 yuan and a Hello Kitty ornament 2,208 yuan. The opening comes amid debate over whether Christmas should be banned in China, with some officials and families ordered to resist Western festivals and focus on building a socialist culture.

site_title: FCL enters German last-mile logistics sector
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd (FCL) has acquired six German logistics facilities for approximately 257 million euros, marking its entry into the German last-mile logistics sector. The facilities, totaling 75,478 sqm of lettable area, are equipped with above-market specifications and are 100% preleased to Hermes Germany for 15 years. The acquisition is expected to boost FCL's recurring income and complement its European logistics portfolio, while positioning it to benefit from e-commerce logistical requirements.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Home-security startup Blink says it's now Amazon-owned
summary: Amazon has acquired home-security startup Blink, a wireless home security camera specialist, without disclosing financial terms. Blink will continue to operate under the Amazon umbrella, with its products and services expanding into home security. This acquisition marks Amazon's entry into the home security market, following its recent launch of "Amazon Key", a smart lock and camera combination for package delivery. The move opens a new competitive front for Amazon in the home security space, rivaling Alphabet's Nest Labs.

site_title: Barrick Gold eyes deals with rewritten M&A playbook
summary: Barrick Gold is reviewing acquisitions to boost production and drive growth, shifting from a focus on debt reduction. The company is targeting low-cost production assets in the Americas and will prioritize its core gold area. Barrick is also exploring equity financing for deals, aiming to avoid increasing debt. The move comes after the company considered a potential deal for Goldcorp in 2016, which was ultimately not pursued. Barrick's new approach aims to address investor concerns about overspending and high debt levels in the mining sector.

images.alt_text: A series of asset sales, including a 50-per-cent stake in Argentine gold mine Veladero (above) to Shandong Gold Mining for US$960 million earlier this year, has helped put Barrick on a stronger footing and top its debt reduction target this year.

site_title: Women's roles make the jump to light speed in new Star Wars universe
summary: A group of women at Lucasfilm, led by Kathleen Kennedy and Kiri Hart, have created a diverse story group that aims to increase representation in the Star Wars universe. The group, which includes five people of color, has successfully introduced complex female characters, such as Ahsoka Tano, who was initially met with criticism. Analysis of Star Wars films shows a significant increase in female and non-white characters' dialogue, with women now accounting for 27.8% of dialogue in The Force Awakens. This trend is attributed to the Lucasfilm story group's efforts to create more central and nuanced female characters, challenging traditional Hollywood norms.

site_title: Qualcomm opposes Broadcom's board nominee slate
summary: Qualcomm is opposing Broadcom's nomination of 11 new directors as part of the chipmaker's $105 billion hostile offer. Qualcomm's board claims Broadcom's nominees are biased in favor of the bid, undervaluing the company and lacking necessary skills for a lengthy regulatory approval process. The two companies have a history of communication, with a meeting in 2016 suggesting a potential acquisition of Qualcomm by Broadcom. Qualcomm has rejected Broadcom's initial $70-a-share bid and has a separate takeover effort underway for NXP Semiconductors.

site_title: China could play key role in rebuilding Syria
summary: China is considering a key role in rebuilding war-torn Syria, with Chinese companies showing interest in the $250 billion reconstruction effort. Russia and Iran, which backed Bashar Assad's regime, are reluctant to foot the bill, while Western powers, including the US and EU, are hesitant to provide aid due to Assad's continued rule. China's enthusiasm is reciprocated by the Syrian government, and Chinese companies are eyeing projects such as infrastructure development, energy facilities, and hospitals. China's Belt and Road Initiative, a multi-billion-dollar plan to build trade and transportation links across Eurasia and Africa, may also play a role in Syria's reconstruction.

site_title: SembMarine sells West Rigel rig for US$500m, but takes S$24m loss
summary: SembCorp Marine sold its semi-submersible rig West Rigel for US$500 million, taking a S$24 million loss due to the original customer filing for bankruptcy protection. The rig was contracted to North Atlantic Drilling and Seadrill, both of which applied for Chapter 11 restructuring. The sale will allow SembCorp Marine to dispose of the rig and improve its liquidity position, but the loss will reduce earnings per share by 1.2 Singapore cents. The sale is subject to conditions being met by both buyer and seller, with the rig set to undergo works for reactivation at SembCorp Marine's yard.

site_title: Complaints mount over phone searches at US border
summary: US border officials have received over 250 complaints since 2011 about phone searches without warrants, sparking a debate on rights, security, and technology. Those affected described being humiliated and feeling like criminals. The complaints, mostly filed during the Obama administration, highlight concerns over lost privacy and the need for clearer guidelines. The issue has added a personal dimension to the discussion, with advocates calling for reforms to balance security with individual rights.

site_title: Red lights flashing over amber rush in troubled Ukraine
summary: In Ukraine's Rivne region, a crisis has emerged over illicit amber mining, with thousands of tons extracted annually. The illegal mining, which involves applying high-pressure water to the ground, has caused environmental damage and lost the state significant revenue. Authorities are considering legalizing prospecting to encourage miners to pay taxes and adopt safer methods, but a draft law has been stuck in Parliament. The miners, who often live below the poverty line, admit to causing damage but say the work is the only way to make ends meet, with some earning up to $300 per day.

site_title: Aston Martin recalling 5,000 cars in US
summary: Aston Martin is recalling over 5,000 vehicles in the US due to two problems: the transmission park pawl not engaging, causing the vehicle to roll unexpectedly, and damaged battery cables increasing the risk of fire. The recall affects 3,493 vehicles made between 2009 and 2016, as well as 1,953 additional models. The US market, accounting for 20% of Aston Martin's global sales, is the primary focus of the recall. The company is also recalling over 1,500 cars in China due to security risks.

site_title: Frenchman invents lemony oysters in time for the holidays
summary: A French seafood farmer, Joffrey Dubault, has invented lemon-flavored oysters, a delicacy he perfected after four years of trial-and-error experiments. His patented process involves soaking oysters in sea water laced with lemon extract for 2-12 hours, resulting in a 95% success rate. Dubault has already gained recognition at a seafood trade fair in Brussels and is now marketing the novelty to Asian clients, with plans to expand his flavor menu to include grapefruit, mirabelle plum, and truffle oysters.

site_title: Projecting the Baltic into Asia and more
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been operating the Baltic Exchange for over a year, with CEO Mark Jackson and executive vice-president Michael Syn discussing progress. They highlight the value of SGX's regulatory expertise in enhancing the Baltic's freight indices and assessments. Both parties emphasize the importance of learning from each other, with SGX seeking to understand the Baltic's seasoned relationship with market participants and the Baltic appreciating SGX's experience in global commerce. The partnership aims to strengthen the Baltic's position in the market.

images.alt_text: Baltic CEO Mark Jackson and SGX executive vice-president Michael Syn. SGX's acquisition of the Baltic comes at a time of change for the shipbroking industry.

site_title: Singapore golfing pros lack the cutting edge
summary: No Singaporean golfing professional will earn an automatic berth to all Asian Tour events next year due to not finishing in the top 65 of the year's Order of Merit. Quincy Quek, the best performer, finished at 94th position. The Singapore Professional Golfers' Association (SPGA) is under fire, but its president, M Murugiah, defends the association, citing the need for pros to step up and maintain their dedication and discipline. Malaysians dominated the Asian Tour, with Gavin Green becoming the Order's champion and earning a hefty purse of $585,813.46.

images.alt_text: Quincy Quek takes 94th position for this year's Order of Merit.

site_title: Keppel O&M's fines a new blow to resurgent sector
summary: Keppel O&M has agreed to pay a record $422 million in fines as part of a global resolution for a corruption probe in Singapore, Brazil, and the US. This settlement puts pressure on SembMarine, which has contracts with Sete Brasil, a company under investigation for alleged corrupt payments. Industry observers believe it's too early to pull investments by Keppel and SembMarine in Brazil, citing the sector's recent stabilization and Brazil's lead in the oil and gas industry. Both companies maintain their Sete Brasil contracts are still valid.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to recall 1.8 million Ram trucks over rollaways
summary: Fiat Chrysler is recalling 1.8 million Ram pickup trucks due to a potential issue with the brake transmission shift interlock, which can fail to prevent shifting out of park without the driver's foot on the brake. The problem occurs when the truck is idling in park and the driver keeps their foot on the brake, causing heat to build up around the gearshift. Seven people have suffered minor injuries and a "small number" of crashes may be linked to the issue. A fix is being developed and owners are urged to use their parking brakes until the remedy is available.

site_title: Singapore's tourism industry set to finish 2017 on strong note
summary: Singapore's tourism industry is expected to finish 2017 on a strong note, driven by a 5% year-on-year increase in visitor arrivals, with China being the major driver. The nation received approximately 13.05 million visitors in the first three quarters, with China arrivals up 9.5% to 2.49 million. This could surpass the 17 million visitor threshold for the year, with tourism spend expected to be between $25.1 billion and $25.8 billion. However, the retail industry continues to face challenges, with a 0.9% year-on-year increase in retail sales in the third quarter, and a potential slowdown in the peak year-end season.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: World's largest amphibious aircraft makes maiden flight in China
summary: China's AG600, the world's largest amphibious aircraft, made its maiden flight on Sunday from an airport on the shores of the South China Sea. This marks a significant step in the country's military modernization program. The aircraft's development comes as China increases its military presence in the Asia-Pacific region and disputed territories, such as the South China Sea, raising concerns among regional nations and the US. The AG600's capabilities are not disclosed, but its successful maiden flight signals China's growing military capabilities.

site_title: First person to fly untethered in space dies at 80
summary: Bruce McCandless, the first person to fly untethered in space, has died at 80. McCandless, a former US Navy captain and NASA astronaut, made history in 1984 with a 3-hour spacewalk while wearing a bulky backpack with jet thrusters and nitrogen gas. He was part of the Apollo 11 mission and had logged over 300 hours in space. McCandless' iconic photograph, taken during his spacewalk, captured the hearts of those on Earth, with the astronaut joking that he was "representing mankind up there."

site_title: Bitcoin climbs, finding floor after worst sell-off since 2015
summary: Bitcoin experienced a 21% rebound, with second-tier digital coins also seeing significant gains, after a four-day slump. The recovery was partly driven by a pause in bearish news, including a German central banker's comments about the risks of rapid losses in cryptocurrencies. This halt in negative news helped to halt the decline of the $500 billion unregulated market, which had seen a 24% drop in value. The gains were led by Bitcoin Cash and Litecoin, with traders regaining optimism about the market.

images.alt_text: While bitcoin wasn't the most volatile crypocurrency in the past week, it's the largest, and it shook the world of digital-coin trading on Friday when its interday plunge reached 30 per cent.

site_title: FCL to buy six German logistics facilities for abut 257m euros
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Ltd (FCL) has acquired six German logistics facilities for approximately 257 million euros, equivalent to around S$408.63 million. The facilities, totaling 75,478 square meters of lettable area on 426,439 square meters of land, are located in key logistics markets in Heilbronn, Mainz, Berlin, Augsburg, Hamburg, and near Leipzig.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Apple to pay penalty for delays over Qualcomm case
summary: A US judge ordered Apple to pay $25,000 per day for each day it fails to produce documents in a lawsuit against Qualcomm, which accuses the chipmaker of forcing Apple to use its chips exclusively. The penalty is equal to the profit generated by Apple every 16 seconds in the last fiscal year. Apple has until December 29 to turn over the documents or face even steeper fines.

site_title: Italian parliament passes 2018 budget, clearing way for elections
summary: Italy's Upper House Senate approved the government's 2018 budget, clearing the way for national elections in March. The budget aims to lower next year's fiscal deficit to 1.6% of gross domestic product from a targeted 2.1% this year.

site_title: Cheers to US tax cut for cider, craft beer makers
summary: US tax cuts have lowered excise taxes for small producers of craft beer, hard cider, and mead. Craft beer makers will pay $3.50 per barrel on the first 60,000 barrels, while small cider producers will pay $0.07 per gallon, down from $1. The tax overhaul also sets a statutory definition of mead and widens the flavors cideries can use. The lowered tax aims to help small producers expand, experiment, and market their products, potentially leading to lower prices.

site_title: If three's a crowd, what will a fourth telco bring?
summary: A fourth telco is expected to enter the Singapore market, potentially disrupting the industry. Rebel tech companies have already gained victories against telecoms incumbents, citing a "period of civil war" in the industry. This development may lead to increased competition and changes in the market landscape. The emergence of new players could bring innovative services and disrupt the status quo.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Staying relevant to ensure its growth
summary: Sunningdale Tech, a precision plastic component manufacturer, is investing in higher-value added complex projects in Singapore and leveraging automation to boost productivity. The company, which typically spends S$25 million annually on capital expenditure, is investing S$35 million in FY17, including a new plant in Penang and a facility in Chuzhou, China. CEO Khoo Boo Hor emphasizes the need for companies to stay relevant and invest in research and development, training, and automation to drive efficiency and growth. The company aims to achieve S$700 million in revenues this year, with a growing dividend payout.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Holy Land Christians resisting Greek Orthodox Church's land deals
summary: Holy Land Christians are resisting the Greek Orthodox Church's land deals, which have led to the sale or lease of properties in Israel and the Palestinian territories. The church's practice of selling and leasing its properties has caused a split among its followers, who fear it erodes their presence in the Holy Land. Critics claim the church has made secret deals with right-wing Israeli groups and investors seeking profit over preservation. The church's leadership defends its management, saying it needs revenue to sustain its mission and has obtained approval from the Holy Synod.

site_title: An investor's best friend: China's booming pet market sparks international deals
summary: China's pet market is booming, with an estimated 46.3 billion yuan in sales by 2022, growing at 20% annually. The market's growth is driven by demographic changes, including an aging population and declining birth rates, leading to a rise in pet ownership and spending. Global pet food companies, such as Mars Inc and Nestle SA, are benefiting from the surge, while Chinese companies are also expanding their operations. Despite concerns about pet mistreatment and a lack of knowledge about vaccinations and sterilization, the market is expected to continue growing, with entrepreneurs setting up businesses catering to the demand for premium pet products and services.

site_title: Euro dips on Catalan vote; bitcoin plummets
summary: The euro slipped 0.1% to US$1.1858 after Catalan separatists won a regional election, despite analysts not seeing it as advancing the issue of a possible eurozone break-up. Meanwhile, bitcoin plummeted nearly 30% to below US$12,000, losing a third of its value since the previous Sunday. The US dollar index was flat at 93.316, with analysts expecting renewed US dollar weakness later next year as global monetary policy trends shift.

site_title: US charities fear big drop in donations from middle classes
summary: US charities are concerned that the recent tax overhaul bill signed by President Trump will lead to a significant decline in donations from the middle class. The bill's reduction of the charitable tax deduction is expected to result in a 4.5% decrease in donations, totaling $13 billion, with the majority of this decrease coming from middle-class donors. Nonprofits fear this shift will alter their priorities and public perception of donating, potentially favoring wealthy donors. Charities are urging lawmakers to reconsider the bill's impact on philanthropy.

site_title: Peru's Fujimori taken to hospital from prison; life at risk, says doctor
summary: Peru's former president Alberto Fujimori was taken to a hospital by ambulance after suffering a severe drop in blood pressure and abnormal heart rhythm. His doctor, Alejandro Aguinaga, said the condition is "complicated" and recommended his immediate removal from prison. Fujimori's life is at risk, according to the doctor. Cardiologists have advised for his hospitalization to prevent any further complications.

site_title: Fuel shortage in oil-rich Angola tests mettle of new President Lourenco
summary: Angola, a major oil producer, is experiencing a fuel shortage, with long queues at petrol stations in the capital Luanda. The shortage, which has lasted for seven days, is attributed to delays in fuel processing at the country's ports due to payment issues with suppliers. Critics blame the government for the shortages, pointing to the ousting of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and his daughter Isabel dos Santos, who controlled state-run companies. The government has denied any wrongdoing, but the shortage has caused frustration among drivers, who are struggling to access fuel.

site_title: Iraq reaches initial deal with China's Zhenhua to develop East Baghdad oilfield
summary: Iraq has reached an initial deal with China's Zhenhua Oil to develop the southern portion of the East Baghdad oil field. The deal aims to increase oil production to 40,000 barrels per day within five years. Iraq's oil ministry spokesman, Asim Jihad, made the announcement. This partnership is part of Iraq's efforts to boost oil production and meet its energy needs.

site_title: Trump travel ban dealt blow by San Francisco appeals court
summary: A federal appeals court in San Francisco struck down President Donald Trump's travel ban, ruling it continues to illegally discriminate against travelers from six mostly Muslim countries, Venezuela, and North Korea. The court allowed the ban to target individuals without a US-based relationship, but the nation's high court may ultimately uphold the restrictions. This ruling marks a victory for states, advocacy groups, and universities challenging the ban, which has been a central issue in the ongoing legal battle over national security and executive authority.

site_title: Puigdemont mulls return to Catalonia after win despite imminent arrest
summary: Catalan pro-independence leader Carles Puigdemont is considering returning to the region despite an imminent arrest, following the victory of pro-independence parties in regional elections. Puigdemont, who was ousted as president and faces charges of rebellion and misuse of funds, campaigned from Brussels and is now weighing his options with his lawyers. His campaign manager, Elsa Artadi, has called for talks with the central government, while Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has warned that the new Catalan government must fully respect the law.

images.alt_text: Sacked Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont has positioned himself as an equal to Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy.

site_title: MBS's staff and star power drive Sands for Singapore outreach
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has been actively engaging in corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives, dubbed "Sands for Singapore," since 2012. The program aims to leverage the venue space and employee involvement to support underserved communities in Singapore, particularly in special needs and youth-at-risk areas. Since its inception, MBS has raised nearly S$20 million for local charities through events like the Sands for Singapore Charity Festival. The company encourages employee volunteerism and has implemented initiatives to promote inclusivity and equal employment, partnering with organizations such as the Society for the Physically Disabled.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Elon Musk's SpaceX caps record year with satellite launch
summary: SpaceX has concluded its record-breaking year with its 18th satellite launch, surpassing its competitors and exceeding its 2016 launch total of eight. The company is expected to fly 30 missions in 2018, including commercial satellite operators, military customers, and NASA. Elon Musk has announced plans for a larger rocket and crewed missions, including the maiden flight of Falcon Heavy in January and the Crew Dragon spacecraft demonstration in April. This marks a significant milestone for the space industry, with the president of the Commercial Spaceflight Federation calling it the biggest year since 1969.

site_title: Fifty director acquisitions filed; Clearbridge Health debuts on Catalist
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 1.6% from Dec 15 to 21, with 15 stocks conducting share buybacks totaling S$13 million. 66 SGX-listed stocks filed changes in directors' or substantial shareholders' interests, including 50 director acquisitions and one disposal. Ongoing acquisitions were filed for Accrelist, Avi-Tech Electronics, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings. Clearbridge Health listed on Catalist, raising S$24.6 million and opening with a market capitalization of S$134.7 million.

site_title: Trump's design for presidential coin dubbed a disgrace
summary: US President Donald Trump's redesigned presidential challenge coin has been met with criticism, with many calling it "tacky" and a "disgrace". The coin features Trump's campaign slogan "Make America Great Again" and his signature, replacing traditional elements such as the national motto and presidential seal. The coin's design has sparked outrage among service members and the public, with some speculating it may soon be handed out to supporters and campaign donors. The change has been seen as a departure from the traditional design and a reflection of Trump's campaign branding.

site_title: Plenty of fizz factors left after Christmas holiday
summary: Global markets remain closed on Christmas Day, with some exchanges, like Australia and Britain, and Big Four firm PwC, closed until New Year's Day. Despite the holiday, analysts expect profit-taking and seasonal factors to influence the market, particularly with the US corporate tax cuts report. However, Bitcoin's price volatility is expected to continue, with Goldman Sachs joining Bitcoin trading businesses. Meanwhile, regulators are investigating corporate scandals, including JPMorgan's breach of anti-laundering regulations and Keppel Corporation's fines over corrupt payments. Economists remain cautiously optimistic about the start of next year, citing strong data points and a potential capex cycle.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Record crowds celebrate Japan emperor's 84th birthday
summary: Record crowds of 45,900 people gathered at Japan's Imperial Palace to celebrate Emperor Akihito's 84th birthday, marking his first public appearance since the government announced his abdication on April 30, 2019. The emperor, who will be the first to retire in over two centuries, delivered a speech expressing his desire to pass the torch to his son, Crown Prince Naruhito, who will ascend the throne the following day. The event came as Akihito prepares to step down after nearly three decades in the role, citing his age and health problems.

images.alt_text: Record crowds flocked to Japan's Imperial Palace on Saturday to celebrate the 84th birthday of Emperor Akihito as he prepares to abdicate in April 2019.

site_title: Keppel O&M to pay US$422m in fines after reaching global resolution on corruption probe
summary: Keppel O&M, a unit of Keppel Corporation, has agreed to pay US$422 million in fines to settle a global corruption probe involving corrupt payments made by a former agent in Brazil. The resolution covers three jurisdictions, including the US, Brazil, and Singapore, making it an unprecedented settlement for a Singapore company. The company reached the agreement to avoid further litigation and potential penalties. The resolution does not imply Keppel O&M's or Keppel Corporation's involvement in the corrupt payments.
