images.alt_text: In a statement yesterday, the US Department of Justice said that Keppel O&M had engaged in a scheme between 2001 to 2014 to pay US$55 million in bribes to Petrobras officials and the then governing political party in Brazil, the Workers Party of Brazil.

site_title: China closes more than 13,000 websites in past three years
summary: China has closed over 13,000 websites since 2015 for violating laws and regulations, with the vast majority of people supporting the government's efforts to clean up cyberspace. The government aims to ensure national security, social stability, and prevent the spread of harmful content. In the past three years, nearly 10 million internet accounts have also been closed. A recent survey found that over 90% of people support the government's internet management efforts, citing a reduction in harmful online content.

site_title: Hit pay dirt with 'virtual gold' but mining it can be messy business
summary: Bitcoin's recent price surge has propelled it into the global consciousness, with the virtual currency being likened to "virtual gold" due to its creation process called "mining." However, this process requires high-powered rigs that consume significant amounts of electricity, contributing to global warming and air pollution. The mining industry is massive, with hundreds of thousands of machines worldwide, consuming 35 terawatt hours of energy annually, comparable to Denmark's energy output. Experts warn that the industry's environmental impact could pose a long-term threat, but also see potential for greater use of renewables and more efficient hardware to reduce energy consumption.

site_title: Will tax bill help or hurt GOP in 2018?
summary: The Republican tax bill, signed into law by President Trump, is seen as a potential boost for the GOP in the 2018 midterms, with Republicans confident it will help them maintain their majorities in the House and Senate. However, Democrats argue the bill will not change the public's perception of a dysfunctional Congress, and will be portrayed as a giveaway to the rich at the expense of the middle class. The bill's passage comes as Congress ends a year marked by gridlock and dysfunction, with Republicans seeking to capitalize on a perceived resurgence in productivity and a conservative majority on the Supreme Court.

site_title: North Korea rejects new sanctions, vows to avenge sympathisers
summary: North Korea rejected new UN sanctions aimed at curbing its nuclear expansion, calling the move an "act of war" and vowing to avenge US sympathizers who approved it. The new resolution cuts petroleum deliveries by 90% and caps crude imports, with countries allowed to seize and inspect vessels suspected of transporting banned goods. The US praised the Security Council's decision, while China urged all sides to implement the resolutions "in a comprehensive and balanced manner." North Korea has repeatedly defied Security Council resolutions, with the UN's top envoy expressing concern about the prospects of a diplomatic solution.

site_title: Pavillon to issue 3-year, 5% convertible bonds to pay for Johor Baru properties
summary: Pavillon Holdings plans to issue 3-year, 5% convertible bonds worth S$9.84 million to pay for its Johor Baru properties acquisition. The bonds will have a conversion price of RM0.3025 per share, representing an initial conversion premium of 108% against Pavillon's closing price. The move is part of a larger acquisition plan, which also includes issuing 70 million new shares to partially fund the purchase. The company has convened an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval for the bond and share placement.

site_title: Dear employees of Christmas, Inc
summary: Christmas, Inc. published a special edition on December 24, 2017. The article discusses various business and economic topics, including companies' handling of layoffs, the burden of Temasek's SIA investment, the evolution of MAS's climate investing approach, and the prices of Good Class Bungalows in Singapore. Additionally, the article touches on the perverse globalism of Donald Trump and a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit. The article concludes by exploring China's competitiveness in the AI talent war.

site_title: Venezuela frees first of 80 opponents in rare good will move
summary: Venezuelan authorities released around 80 detained opponents, including a dozen police officers, in a rare gesture of goodwill to the opposition ahead of Christmas. The move was announced by Delcy Rodriguez, president of the assembly, who said it was a "moment of reconciliation." The released detainees, including mayor Alfredo Ramos, were held for acts of violence, conspiracy, or treason, and will serve community service instead of imprisonment. This comes after opposition leaders and regional trade bloc Mercosur called for the release of "political prisoners."

site_title: For ailing US nuclear industry, new plants a shot in the arm
summary: The US nuclear power industry received a boost when state authorities in Georgia approved the construction of two new reactors at the Vogtle plant, expected to enter service at the end of 2022. The decision is seen as a step to regain the country's leadership in nuclear energy, but the industry's decline continues. Currently, there are no other reactors under construction and none have come online since 2016. Environmental activists oppose nuclear power due to its risks and radioactive waste, and the project's cost has doubled to $27 billion, prompting calls for its scrapping and transition to clean energy.

site_title: Year-end cheer as Nov consumer spending beats forecasts
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.6% in November, beating forecasts, but savings fell to a 9-year low as consumption outpaced income. The strong spending pace was driven by increases in recreational goods and utilities, but the low savings rate could indicate a unsustainable economic trend. The Commerce Department also reported a 3.2% annualized growth rate in the third quarter, with estimates suggesting a 3.3% pace for the fourth quarter.

site_title: SpaceX launches 10 more satellites for Iridium
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a re-used Falcon 9 rocket carrying 10 Iridium satellites into orbit, bringing the total to 40 satellites. The launch, part of a $3 billion upgrade, aims to replace the world's largest commercial satellite network. SpaceX will launch 75 of the 81 planned satellites. The new satellites are designed to track ships and aircraft in real-time, part of a project called Iridium NEXT.

site_title: Luxe Dining
summary: Resorts World Sentosa's Michelin-starred Joël Robuchon and L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon restaurants offer special Christmas menus. At Joël Robuchon, a three-course menu priced at S$588 per person features foie gras, truffles, and beef. At L'Atelier, a two-course menu priced at S$388 features chestnut veloute and roasted turbot. Bookings can be made through www.rwsentosa.com.

site_title: Europe: Spanish stocks, financials tumble on Catalan separatist gains
summary: Spanish stocks fell 1.2% on Friday after Catalan separatists won a regional election, deepening a political crisis that has hurt the economy and led to a business exodus from the region. The IBEX index ended above its morning lows, but Banco Sabadell and Caixabank, which have the biggest exposure to Catalonia, fell over 3%. The euro zone banks index also fell 1%, and Spain's economy is 9% down from its May peak.

site_title: 'Last Jedi' toy sales outshining 'Force Awakens': Funko CEO
summary: Funko Inc, the toy company behind Star Wars merchandise, reports that sales of Star Wars products are exceeding 2015 levels, despite the release of "The Last Jedi" film. CEO Brian Mariotti attributes this to the franchise's continued popularity under Walt Disney Co. The toy industry had previously feared a decline in demand after the film's release, but Funko's sales indicate that Star Wars fatigue is not a concern.

site_title: Credit Suisse risks 3rd straight loss on Trump tax overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse is at risk of posting a third consecutive annual loss due to a predicted 2.3 billion Swiss francs hit from the US tax overhaul signed into law by President Donald Trump. The bank expects to take a writedown of 2.3 billion francs unless it makes significantly more than 1 billion francs in the final quarter. This charge could trigger a yearly deficit for the lender, despite a net income position of 1.14 billion francs after nine months.

site_title: US tax cuts to cost US$1t after growth, official study finds
summary: The US tax cuts, signed into law by President Donald Trump, will reduce federal revenue by over $1 trillion over the next decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Despite expected economic growth, the tax reductions will generate a $451 billion increase in GDP and result in almost $1.1 trillion in deficits over the 10-year period. This estimate is in line with previous findings from independent analysts, and it marks a significant departure from the Trump administration's claims that the tax cuts would pay for themselves.

images.alt_text: The tax changes that President Donald Trump signed into law will reduce federal revenue by more than US$1 trillion over the next decade, even after accounting for their beneficial effects on the US economy, according to Congress's tax scorekeeper.

site_title: Venezuela reports economy shrank by 16.5% in 2016
summary: Venezuela's economy shrank 16.5% in 2016, according to a government filing to the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The oil sector contracted 9.9% and the non-oil economy 16.1%, while inflation reached 274.4% and unemployment hit 7.5%. Imports dropped to $16.4 billion, half of the previous year's $33.3 billion. The report also noted a sharp rise in poverty, with 11.3% of the population classified as extremely poor in 2014. Venezuela's economic crisis, fueled by a decline in oil prices, continues to worsen.

site_title: Driver charged with attempted murder over Melbourne vehicle attack
summary: A former Afghanistan refugee, Saeed Noori, has been charged with 18 counts of attempted murder after deliberately plowing into Christmas shoppers in Melbourne, Australia. The incident occurred on a busy street and was described as a "deliberate act" by police. Noori, 34, was formally interviewed by police and subsequently charged with the attempted murders. This is the second serious vehicle attack in Melbourne this year, raising concerns about safety in the city.

images.alt_text: The man accused of deliberately ploughing into Christmas shoppers on a busy street in the Australian city of Melbourne was charged on Saturday with 18 counts of attempted murder.

site_title: UN slaps new sanctions on North Korea
summary: The United Nations Security Council has unanimously adopted a US-drafted resolution imposing new sanctions on North Korea, restricting oil supplies vital for its missile and nuclear programs. The sanctions, backed by China, ban 75% of refined oil products, cap crude deliveries, and order the repatriation of North Korean workers abroad. The measures aim to pile pressure on Kim Jong Un's regime to come to the negotiating table, with the US and North Korea showing no signs of willingness to open talks. The sanctions are the third raft imposed on Pyongyang this year.

site_title: Cosco hits 90% acquisition threshold in takeover bid, plans to delist Cogent
summary: Chinese shipping company Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) has hit the 90% compulsory acquisition mark for its S$1.02-a-share cash offer for Cogent Holdings. As of Dec 21, Cosco has received valid acceptances representing 5.68% of Cogent shares. With four shareholders holding 84.33% of Cogent shares, Cosco plans to pursue a delisting of Cogent from the Singapore Exchange, maintaining its existing business activities.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges as 'reality check' hits investors after stratospheric rise
summary: Bitcoin prices plummeted by a quarter on Friday, falling to $12,191 after a stratospheric rise in recent weeks, with a 40% drop from its record high. The crash is attributed to investors cashing out after warnings from analysts and governments about a possible bubble. Other cryptocurrencies like Dash, Litecoin, and Ripple also fell. The sell-off comes after a series of warnings about the market, including comments from the Bank of Japan governor and the US Federal Reserve boss.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin fever has hit the US real estate market, especially that of Florida, offering foreign investors a way to dodge currency controls at home and US economic sanctions.

site_title: Going wireless: Is it all it's cut out to be?
summary: A writer's journey into wireless technology began when their phone's headphone jack became loose, sparking a quest to explore wireless headphones, chargers, and speakers. They discovered the Sony MDR-1000X headphones, Philips Hue Go wireless light, and wireless chargers, which brought convenience and altered their daily life. However, they noted that wireless tech isn't a replacement for traditional accessories, but rather a peripheral improvement. The industry's push towards wireless technology is evident, with phone manufacturers removing headphone jacks and improving Bluetooth protocols, and even virtual reality headsets emerging without cables.

site_title: Two more da Vincis could be hiding in plain sight
summary: Two previously unknown Leonardo da Vinci paintings, "Buccleuch Madonna" and "Lansdowne Madonna", may be hidden in private hands. Both depict the Virgin Mary with the Christ child and are believed to have been created by da Vinci. One, the "Buccleuch Madonna", is valued at around $65 million and has been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland since 2009, while the other, the "Lansdowne Madonna", was last sold in 1999. Experts estimate that both paintings could be worth up to $200 million each, potentially surpassing the record-breaking sale of "Salvator Mundi" for $450.3 million.

site_title: Silicon Sauna sojourn
summary: Finland, dubbed the "Silicon Sauna" for its tech innovation, celebrates its 100th year of independence. The country boasts a thriving startup scene, with venture capital investment exceeding the European average. From self-service Starbucks kiosks to app-controlled juice machines and tablet-based hotel amenities, Finland's tech advancements are on display. The nation's emphasis on technology is reflected in its cultural heritage, with saunas serving as a symbol of innovation and relaxation.

site_title: Engineering services firm Acromec wins 2 contracts worth S$6.6m
summary: Acromec, an engineering services firm, has secured two contracts worth S$6.6 million, expected to grow its order book to around S$28 million. The projects include the fitting-out of a pharmaceutical company's research laboratory and an extensive air-conditioning upgrade for a life sciences sector customer. The company anticipates positive contributions to earnings per share and net tangible assets in the 2018 financial year.

site_title: The Splendours Of Rajasthan
summary: Rajasthan, a state in India, is renowned for its rich cultural heritage, historic forts, and stunning desert landscapes. The state is home to several destinations, including Jaipur, Udaipur, Jodhpur, and Jaisalmer. Visitors can explore the City Palace in Jaipur, the Amber Fort, and the Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur. Udaipur is known for its picturesque lakes and romantic atmosphere, while Jaisalmer is famous for its golden sandstone buildings and camel fair. The state is also home to several luxury hotels, including the Sujan Rajmahal Palace, Alila Fort Bishangarh, and Amanbagh. Aman-i-Khas, a luxury tented resort, offers a unique experience for tiger spotting in Ranthambore National Park.

site_title: An El Clasico with so much on the line
summary: Real Madrid, led by Cristiano Ronaldo, faces off against Barcelona, led by Lionel Messi in a crucial El Clasico match. The Spanish league leaders, Barcelona, hold an 11-point lead over Real, but a win for Real could keep their La Liga hopes alive. The match is also influenced by the Spanish-Catalan political rivalry, with Real's manager Zinedine Zidane emphasizing the importance of a win to remain in the championship fight.

site_title: Oil inches higher ahead of Christmas holiday weekend
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, steadying near their highest levels since 2015, ahead of the Christmas holiday weekend. Brent crude futures ended up 35 cents at $65.25 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled 11 cents higher at $58.47 a barrel. Opec leader Saudi Arabia and Russia pledged a gradual exit from crude output cuts, easing market concerns about oversupply. Analysts expect oil prices to remain balanced, but some predict a potential increase in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: Strong demand powers palladium to 17-year pinnacle, gold firms
summary: Palladium prices reached a 17-year high of $1,042.50 per ounce on Friday, driven by strong demand from autocatalyst makers. The metal is expected to close 2017 up over 50%, its strongest annual performance since 2010. Gold also rose, reaching a 2-1/2-week high, as weak US economic data boosted the metal. Analysts attribute 80% of global palladium demand to autocatalysts for petrol-powered cars, a trend expected to continue despite slowing car sales.

images.alt_text: Palladium prices jumped to 17-year highs on Friday as strong demand from autocatalyst makers reinforced the prospect of market shortages, while gold rose for the sixth straight session to reach a 2-1/2-week high on weak US economic data.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as Trump signs tax cut into law
summary: US stocks declined on Friday as President Trump signed a long-awaited tax cut into law ahead of the Christmas holiday. Despite rising to record highs earlier in the month, stocks fell 0.1% on the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index. The Dow ended the week at 24,754.06, while Nike and Celgene lost 2.4% and 1.4% respectively due to disappointing earnings reports. Analysts attributed the decline to low trading volume ahead of the Christmas holiday.

site_title: Keppel to take hit in earnings, but 'will survive'
summary: Keppel Corporation is expected to take a hit in earnings due to a $422.2 million penalty imposed by the US Department of Justice for bribing Petrobras officials between 2001 and 2014. Analysts predict a 70% decline in earnings for the year, although some believe the impact could be negligible. Keppel has managed to offset the fines through divestments, and the incident may have minimal long-term impact on the company's reputation. Despite this, the penalty is expected to affect Keppel's offshore and marine side in the short term.

site_title: China's trade with North Korea edges up in November
summary: China's trade with North Korea increased to $388 million in November, a 15.9% rise from October, but remains at its lowest levels this year due to ongoing sanctions. The data shows a monthly pickup, despite the imposition of UN penalties on September 5 banning the sale of coal, iron ore, and other goods. This slowdown in trade is attributed to the sanctions, which have significantly impacted business with North Korea.

site_title: Local Delights
summary: Soon Huat Dining House in Chinatown Point is offering local hawker fare at discounted prices, including sambal sotong for S$8.90 (U.P. S$12.90) and fried fish head with spicy black bean sauce for S$12.90 (U.P. S$18.90). The offer is valid for dine-in only until January 31.

site_title: Xiaomi worth US$100 billion? 'Tis the season to be silly
summary: Xiaomi is expected to exceed its revenue target of $17 billion, with some bankers projecting a net income of $1 billion, a margin of 5.9%, making it one of the highest in the market. The company's operating margin of 5.9% would be impressive, but the high net margin would be unprecedented. This has led some bankers to speculate about a potential IPO, with estimates suggesting Xiaomi could reach $100 billion in valuation, although this seems overly optimistic, given the weakening devices market.

site_title: IPO hopeful Xiaomi set to blow past 2017 revenue target: sources
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone maker, is expected to exceed its 2017 revenue target of $15 billion by 18%, with a net profit of at least $1 billion. The company's financials are projected to continue growing sharply into 2019, potentially valuing it at $100 billion at its IPO. Xiaomi has regained its footing after a sales slump, with a resurgence in sales in dozens of countries and a re-launch of its business in new markets.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to divest Genting Lane property
summary: Ascendas Reit to sell its No 84 Genting Lane property in Singapore to Axxel Marketing Pte Ltd for S$16.68 million, a 66.8% increase from its original purchase price of S$10 million. The sale is expected to complete within the first quarter of 2018 and will result in a reduction of approximately S$1.2 million in net property income and distribution per unit for the financial year ended March 31, 2017.

site_title: Winter Kaiseki
summary: Chef Shinichi Nakatake, the new executive chef at Keyaki, has introduced two winter kaiseki menus available for lunch and dinner until December 25. The menus feature seasonal winter delicacies such as yellowtail, tilefish, snow crab, and King crab, which are at their peak during this time. Reservations can be made by calling 6826 8240.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Organic Connection
summary: Chef Jonathan Tam, head chef of the Michelin-starred Relæ in Copenhagen, credits the restaurant's farm, which produces 90% of its organic ingredients, as the heart of its cuisine. He designs menus based on the daily harvest, allowing for experimentation with crops from seed to flowering stage. Tam believes the Nordic cuisine movement is evolving, with young chefs opening their own restaurants incorporating personal and ethnic flavors. As Relæ prepares for the reopening of Noma, Tam is looking forward to the holiday season, where he'll continue to live and cook in Copenhagen, influenced by local traditions.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat
summary: Wall Street opened flat on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.44 points to 24,781.85, while the S&P 500 gained 0.6 points to 2,685.17. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 6.63 points to 6,958.73. Gains in financial stocks offset losses in Nike and technology shares.

site_title: Alex Malcolm
summary: Alex Malcolm, founder of UK-based luxury travel operator Jacada, warns that tourists must be aware of social divisions on beaches in Rio de Janeiro, where locals divide by age, income, and orientation. Malcolm's company, which began in 2008, organizes bespoke tours for discerning travelers, with Asia being the fastest-growing market. Malcolm believes tourism can be a positive experience when managed well, citing Bhutan's model of charging a minimum price to protect the environment and local culture. Jacada prioritizes sustainable travel and has committed to carbon offsetting all client travel.

site_title: Cautious politics in Indonesia as government tackles challenges
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is expected to 'play it safe' with cautious politics as elections approach, amid growing conservatism and policy missteps. With two years left in his term, regional elections in populous provinces may discourage further reforms that could upset voters. This strategy may also be influenced by the need to address policy missteps and maintain public support.

site_title: Mortgage giants cut deal with US Treasury to cover expected losses
summary: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, government-controlled mortgage finance giants, reached a deal with the US Department of the Treasury to retain $3 billion in capital cushion against expected losses due to the corporate tax cut. The arrangement allows the firms to keep profits while still being required to send most of their earnings to the Treasury. The deal aims to minimize the risk of rash decision-making by Congress and address the impact of the tax cuts, but has been criticized by Republicans who argue taxpayers should not prop up the mortgage finance companies.

site_title: Festive Flicks
summary: This article highlights the top Christmas movies, including 'A Charlie Brown Christmas', 'Arthur Christmas', 'The Christmas Tale', 'The Shop Around The Corner', and 'Die Hard'. The films showcase a mix of classic animation, family drama, and action-packed sequences, appealing to both children and adults. 'A Charlie Brown Christmas' is praised for its brief yet meaningful storyline, while 'Arthur Christmas' provides a humorous explanation of Santa's delivery process. The article concludes that these films offer a festive and entertaining way to get into the holiday spirit.

images.alt_text: A CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS (1965)
ARTHUR CHRISTMAS (2011)
THE CHRISTMAS TALE (UN CONTE DE NOËL, 2008)
THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER (1940)
DIE HARD (1988) & DIE HARDER (2000)
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Vard Holdings secures contracts for two freight-and-service vessels in Norway
summary: Vard Holdings secured contracts for two freight-and-service vessels in Norway, to be built by Vard Aukra and delivered in Q3 2018 and Q1 2019. The vessels, measuring 19m in length and 10m in beam, will support the aquaculture industry. The contracts follow the company's recent stock price drop to S$0.25.

site_title: CWX Global sees two new substantial shareholders
summary: CWX Global, formerly Loyz Energy, has seen two new substantial shareholders emerge following its latest rights and warrants issue. Aspial CEO Koh Wee Seng acquired 22 million rights shares and 333.3 million excess rights shares at S$0.009 each, increasing the company's substantial shareholder base.

site_title: Buzzing With Gifts
summary: Starbucks is introducing its festive holiday beverage, the Christmas Tree Dark Mocha, featuring a dark mocha topped with green tea whipped cream and sprinkles of green and red candies. The coffee chain is also offering festive mugs, tumblers, trays, jars, and gift cards as gift ideas. These items are available at Starbucks outlets islandwide.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: BMW i3 (94Ah) review: Assault and batteries
summary: BMW i3 (94Ah) review: Assault and batteries - The BMW i3 is compared to a "nice kid in school" who isn't flashy, but consistently performs well. It's praised for its reliability and efficient battery life, with the 94Ah variant offering a range of up to 320 miles. The car is also noted for its eco-friendly credentials and innovative design. Overall, the i3 is seen as a practical and responsible choice, making it a suitable option for those who value substance over style.

site_title: Crypto, taxes & volatility: What hedge funds are eyeing in the new year
summary: Hedge funds predict a market correction, geopolitical tensions, and volatility in 2018. They see opportunities in macro trading, cryptocurrencies, and tax policy changes. Macro hedge funds have attracted nearly $15 billion in investments this year. Cryptocurrency investments are expected to increase, with a potential bitcoin ETF, and tax policy changes will create price anomalies for traders. European markets are also seen as a positive opportunity, with differing growth outlooks for eurozone countries. Regional banks are expected to benefit from the US tax bill and potential changes to Dodd Frank regulations.

site_title: Of aliens, and an alienating tax reform
summary: The US Department of Defense confirmed the existence of a secret program, Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program (AATIP), to study and analyze unidentified flying objects (UFOs) and other anomalies, which was shut down in 2012. Meanwhile, the Republican-controlled Congress passed a $1.5 trillion tax reform bill, slashing taxes for corporations and the wealthy, with mixed relief for working people. The bill's passage is seen as a significant achievement for President Trump, but critics argue it will exacerbate income inequality and add to the national debt.

site_title: This year's lumps of coal could be 2018's diamonds
summary: US investors who lost money in 2017 on stocks like Under Armour and General Electric may see them rebound in 2018. Contrarian strategies of buying beaten-down names could be successful, as seen in companies like GE and Vertex Pharmaceuticals, which rebounded 69% or more in 2017. Investors are rebalancing portfolios, seeking bargains in sectors like groceries and local businesses, which are less affected by e-commerce. Analysts' predictions also show that some of the worst-performing stocks may see gains above the S&P 500's 20% increase.

images.alt_text: Due partly to increased competition from Nike, Under Armour has slumped 48 per cent year to date, making it the S&P 500's third-worst- performing stock.

site_title: Sincap jumps 6.3% on liability disclaimer, Orion Energy expansion
summary: Sincap Group's shares rose 6.3% after the company clarified its liability to Shandong Luneng, a subsidiary it sold to Advanceleap Corp. Sincap stated it faces no liability for outstanding claims, including a mine refilling project, due to lack of Chinese laws and regulations requiring it to complete the project. The company used the S$10 million sale proceeds from Beijing Raffles to fund Orion Energy Resources' expansion plans.

site_title: The best cars of 2017
summary: The Business Times' top 5 cars of 2017 include the Lexus LC 500, Audi A8 L, Honda Civic Type R, Mercedes-AMG S 63, and BMW 330e iPerformance. The Lexus LC 500 is praised for its luxurious interior, cutting-edge technology, and powerful V8 engine. The Audi A8 L features advanced safety and driving aid systems, while the Honda Civic Type R offers a fun and stable driving experience. The Mercedes-AMG S 63 is a subversive take on the luxurious S-Class, and the BMW 330e iPerformance showcases the potential of eco-friendly cars. These cars embody the year's focus on autonomous driving and electromobility.

site_title: Broadway's Brightest
summary: Dear Evan Hansen, a Broadway musical about a teenager with social anxiety disorder, has captured the world's imagination after sweeping the 2017 Tony Awards with six wins. The musical received a 2018 Grammy nomination for Best Musical Theatre Album. Despite its potentially dour subject matter, the catchy and breezy songs by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul have put a smile on audiences' faces. The musical is available on iTunes and continues to be a hit among musical lovers worldwide.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Big Tech's bad week in Europe signals more problems in 2018
summary: Big Tech faces increased scrutiny in Europe as new privacy rules take effect in 2018. The European Union's top court ruled Uber must be regulated as a transportation service, while German and French regulators criticized Facebook for its misuse of user data. The French privacy watchdog also gave WhatsApp one month to stop sharing data with its parent. These developments signal a tougher stance on Silicon Valley by European regulators, who will have more authority to punish companies for non-compliance. This marks a significant shift in the regulatory landscape for American tech giants in Europe.

images.alt_text: "There is rising pressure in the US to treat Big Tech more aggressively, but it is unclear if that effort will have success." Michael Carrier, co-director of the Rutgers Institute for Information Policy and Law in New Jersey

EU Justice Commissioner Vera Jourova in September branded Facebook's social network "a highway for hatred" and revealed how she deleted her own account on the social network. And on Wednesday the EU's top court ruled Uber must be regulated as a transportation service.

site_title: Bitcoin: A bubble bound to pop?
summary: Bitcoin plummeted after a "reality check" hit investors, following a stratospheric rise. The cryptocurrency fell significantly, potentially signaling a bubble about to pop. Meanwhile, the US stock market reached fresh records despite concerns over US-EU trade talks and tariffs. In other news, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and a Singapore company made a mandatory offer for a peer at a low price.

site_title: Mail Order
summary: The Singapore post office has undergone significant changes since its founding in 1819. Initially, it was operated by three people in the old Parliament House. Over time, the demand for postal traffic grew, and the organization was incorporated as SingPost in 1992, expanding to 808 postal outlets and 722 post boxes. Today, the post system processes a large volume of mail daily, a far cry from the manual sorting that occurred in the past. The post office has adapted to technological advancements and now offers various services, including online shopping and e-cards.

site_title: Does your car have the wrong tyres?
summary: Tyre companies are developing specific tyres for crossover cars, which have become the industry's fastest-growing segment. SUV-specific tyres, such as Bridgestone's Alenza and Pirelli's Scorpion series, cater to their unique characteristics, including noise reduction and cornering stability. Yokohama's BluEarth RV-02 is designed for Compact Utility Vehicles (CUVs) and Multi-Purpose Vehicles (MPVs), addressing their space-maximising designs, noise, and strain on tyre sidewalls. The new tyres have been praised for their quieter ride, improved steering response, and increased cornering stability.

site_title: US consumer spending rises more than expected; savings lowest
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.6% in November, exceeding expectations, driven by increased demand for recreational goods and utilities. Savings dropped to its lowest level in nine years, falling to $426.2 billion, as spending outpaced personal income. This strong spending pace is unlikely to be sustained, but is bolstered by bullish data on the labor market, manufacturing, and housing.

site_title: The Deeper Meaning Of Christmas
summary: Christmas in 21st century Singapore is a time for genuine reflection and real transformation, extending beyond its Christian origins. Gift-giving, a defining feature of the festive season, socializes children and adults alike through programmes run by schools or churches. The commercialization of Christmas, popularized by Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol, has led to a focus on individual character and purpose. This secular meaning of Christmas offers a chance for Singaporeans to reflect on their lives, consider how to be kinder and more compassionate, and make choices as a society about how to contribute to others.

site_title: Bethlehem hotels teem with tourists, defying Jerusalem tensions
summary: Hotels in Bethlehem, a town revered as Jesus's birthplace, are at full capacity for Christmas, defying tensions over US President Donald Trump's labelling of Jerusalem as Israel's capital. A record 2.7 million tourists are expected this year, a 22% increase from 2016. The Palestinian Tourism Ministry credits active marketing in Islamic countries and cultural draws like Banksy's Walled Off Hotel for the surge. Despite concerns that tensions may impact tourism, visitors like Italian tourist Mario Ricci say they feel safe and are visiting for the Christmas spirit.

site_title: Eric Schmidt stepping down as chairman of Alphabet board
summary: Eric Schmidt, 62, is stepping down as chairman of Alphabet's board next month after 17 years, shifting into a technical adviser role. Schmidt, who joined Google in 2001, will remain on the board. He cited his increasing focus on science, technology, and philanthropy. Larry Page, who replaced Schmidt as Google's CEO in 2011, said Schmidt's business and engineering expertise will continue to help the company. Schmidt's departure follows the formation of Alphabet in 2015, a holding company for Google's search products and other ventures.

site_title: Asia markets enjoy pre-Christmas cheer, euro avoids sell-off
summary: Asia markets ended the Christmas week on a positive note, following Wall Street's gains, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore up 0.3%, 0.2%, and 0.3% respectively. However, Shanghai dipped 0.1% and bitcoin sank 20% to briefly reach US$13,000 for the first time since December 7. The euro edged down but held steady after a Catalan separatist victory in Spain's snap poll. Analysts expect US tax reform to boost corporate profits and the economy, but warn of possible headwinds in 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been initiated with a "buy" rating by Maybank Kim Eng, with a target price of S$8.30. The broker attributes this to the exchange's multi-asset strategy, strong cash position, and healthy balance sheet. SGX is expected to benefit from a growing market cap, increased securities trading and derivatives volumes, and a 4% dividend yield. The rating is based on a 23 times FY19E EPS valuation, in line with its P/E mean since 2012.

site_title: Investors shun risk as Christmas nears
summary: Investors in Singapore shun risk as Christmas approaches, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.09% to 3,385.71 points on weak volumes. Companies with debt-fueled acquisitions were punished, possibly due to concerns over US Federal Reserve rate hikes in 2018. The market recovery came after six consecutive days of falls from a year-to-date high.

site_title: Singapore govt's housing market warning may fall on deaf ears
summary: Singapore's central bank warns of potential risks in the property market, citing rising apartment sales and land prices, amid concerns of excessive exuberance and geopolitical developments. Authorities are urging caution, but developers and homebuyers remain optimistic, driven by record-low unsold inventory and perceived affordability. The government may intervene with stricter measures if market instability is not addressed, including limiting development units or curbing bank lending to developers.

images.alt_text: There should be vigilance about risks "including the impact of rising interest rates, geopolitical developments, and excessive exuberance in the property market," Ong Chong Tee, a deputy managing director of the central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said in November.

site_title: Spackman Group buys talent management agency, raises stake in Spackman Media
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group Ltd has acquired talent management company Constellation Agency for S$16.6 million. To fund this, Spackman will issue 144.8 million new shares at S$0.115 apiece. This acquisition is seen as a strategic move to leverage Constellation's expertise and talent management platform for integrated content production. Additionally, Spackman has entered into a share swap agreement to acquire a 3.01% stake in Spackman Media Group Ltd, increasing its shareholding to 32.13%.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Boustead Projects Ltd, a Mainboard-listed company, is expanding its presence in Vietnam through its subsidiary Boustead Projects Land (Vietnam) Co Ltd. The company has subleased land from Thao Dien Real Estate Corporation for the development of industrial leasehold properties. Meanwhile, BreadTalk Group Ltd formed a joint venture agreement with Shinmei Co Ltd, with the new venture being 66% owned by Together Inc and 34% owned by Shinmei.

site_title: Back To His Roots
summary: Chef Simon Rogan, owner of Michelin-starred L'Enclume, has shifted his focus back to the Lake District restaurant after a stint at Fera in London, where his progressive cuisine was met with skepticism by the hotel's clientele. Rogan has since expanded L'Enclume, including a new farm, charcuterie, and butchery, and will also open a new restaurant, Roganic, in London. Rogan credits his London experience with teaching him the importance of a city presence for boosting his profile and that of L'Enclume, which he hopes will one day pay for itself.

images.alt_text: (1) Chefs Simon Rogan and Kirk Westaway.
(2) Jaan's signature egg dish.
(3) The interior of Jaan restaurant.
(4) A taste of L'Enclume.

site_title: A bubble tea brewed from blockchain euphoria
summary: A New York-based company, Long Island Iced Tea Corp, rebranded itself as Long Blockchain Corp, focusing on blockchain technology. The company's shares rose 289% after the announcement, joining other crypto-related companies with similarly high price surges. Experts liken the phenomenon to the dot-com boom, warning of a potential bubble. Long Blockchain has no blockchain partnerships, and its business has been selling non-alcoholic beverages, despite a net loss of $3.9 million in the last quarter.

site_title: Festive Hits
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article highlights the stories behind some of the world's best-loved Christmas records. Wham!'s "Last Christmas" (1984) was written by George Michael, who recorded it entirely by himself in the studio. Vince Guaraldi's "A Charlie Brown Christmas" (1965) soundtrack is a jazz masterpiece that has become a holiday classic. William Hung's "Hung for the Holidays" (2007) is a holiday album featuring his signature off-key croak. Phil Spector's "A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector" (1963) is a classic with a Wall of Sound treatment, but was initially deemed a flop.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Hong Kong: Traders head for Merry Christmas after gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, closing 0.72% higher at 29,578.01, following a positive Asian rally and gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The gains come despite US President Trump's new threats, which traders seem to be brushing off.

site_title: Ascendas Reit divests Genting Lane property for close to S$17m, acquires third suburban office in Australia
summary: Ascendas Reit divests its Genting Lane property in Singapore for S$16.68 million, a 66.8% premium over its original purchase price. The sale is part of the company's proactive asset management strategy to redeploy capital and optimize returns for unitholders. The transaction is expected to reduce aggregate leverage from 33.1% to approximately 33% and will be funded through internal resources and existing debt facilities.

site_title: Santa To The Rescue
summary: A luxury whisky gift, the Bruichladdich 'Wee Laddies' Tasting Collection, is available for S$178 at La Maison du Whisky. The set includes three tasting bottles of the award-winning distillery's core expressions.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Melbourne driver relates attack to mistreatment of Muslims
summary: A 32-year-old Australian-Afghan refugee, identified as Saeed Noori, plowed through a busy Melbourne intersection, killing 18 people, mostly foreigners, in a deliberate act. Noori claimed the attack was to avenge "mistreatment of Muslims." Despite finding no links to terrorism, authorities are investigating and say nothing should be ruled out. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull assured Australians the incident was isolated and urged caution but not to be intimidated.

site_title: Emerging market bonds - brace for lower yields in 2018
summary: Emerging market bond investors can expect lower yields in 2018 due to rising interest rates and expensive valuations. Despite this, there are pockets of opportunities where bond investors can seek value, particularly in BBB/BB rated issuers and subordinated bonds of investment-grade-rated issuers. Selective opportunities outside Asia, such as BB-rated bonds from leading Brazilian or Turkish banks, may also offer attractive valuations. A portfolio positioned predominantly in solid BBB/BB names, with some exposure to subordinated debt and EM bonds outside Asia, can deliver meaningful positive returns in a rising interest-rate environment.

site_title: Ryanair hit with first ever pilots strike
summary: Ryanair faced its first pilots strike on December 22, 2017, as German pilots held a four-hour walkout with little impact on flights. The strike was part of a series of threatened actions across Europe, but Ryanair's decision to recognize unions in Ireland, Italy, and Portugal led to the cancellation of planned strikes in those countries. The airline had sought to avert the strikes by dropping its opposition to union recognition.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.03 points to 1,760.24, closing higher on Friday. The index saw 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion in volume, with losers outnumbering gainers 442 to 400.

site_title: Samudera Shipping completes disposal of Indonesian vessel
summary: Samudera Shipping Line Ltd has completed the disposal of its Indonesian vessel Sinar Panjang for US$1.28 million, with 10% paid as downpayment and the remaining 90% upon delivery in 2017. The proceeds will be used for working capital and business expansion. The disposal results in a net loss of US$23,000, with consolidated net tangible assets per share increasing to US$240.4 million.

site_title: Boustead Projects expands Vietnam presence
summary: Boustead Projects Limited, a mainboard-listed company, is expanding its presence in Vietnam through its subsidiary Boustead Projects Land (Vietnam) Co Ltd. The company has subleased land in Nhon Trach 2 - Nhon Phu Industrial Park in Dong Nai province for the development of industrial leasehold properties. This move aims to increase its presence in the Vietnamese market and capitalize on the growing demand for industrial spaces.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.18 points to 3,385.71 on Friday, closing 0.1% higher. About 1.19 billion shares changed hands, worth S$747.4 million, with Allied Tech being the most actively traded counter. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts to sell 2 Brisbane properties for A$77m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts announced the sale of the Mercure Brisbane and Ibis Brisbane for A$77 million, representing a 43.4% premium over the original purchase price of A$53.7 million. The sale includes two connected properties with 194 and 218 rooms, set to be completed in January 2018. The proceeds will mainly be used to repay existing borrowings and fund future acquisitions. The trust's CEO, Vincent Yeo, stated that the divestment is part of the trust's proactive asset management strategy to enhance returns for stapled securityholders.

site_title: Orders for US capital-goods ease after robust October
summary: US orders for capital goods decreased 0.1% in November after a sharp increase in October, but still indicate an upswing in corporate investment. Non-military capital goods bookings excluding aircraft fell, while durable goods orders increased 1.3% driven by commercial and military aircraft bookings. Core capital goods orders advanced at an 18% annualized rate in the three months through November, suggesting sustained economic growth in 2018. Lower corporate tax rates may fuel further investment, providing a boost to the economy.

site_title: First Reit completes joint acquisition with Lippo Malls Indonesian Retail Trust
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED First Reit has completed a joint acquisition with Lippo Malls Indonesian Retail Trust of a property in Yogyakarta, Indonesia. The collaboration, approved by unitholders, involves an integrated development of Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta and Lippo Plaza Jogja. The deal was initially announced on October 13, 2017.

site_title: Time flies? Not for 81-year-old US air hostess
summary: An 81-year-old US air hostess, Bette Nash, has been working for American Airlines for six decades, earning her the title of the world's most senior flight attendant. Despite retiring at 65, Nash continues to work due to the lack of restrictions on commercial flight attendants. She has seen significant changes in the industry, including the evolution of uniforms, meal services, and the introduction of plastic meal trays. Nash's dedication and professionalism have earned her admiration from passengers and colleagues alike, with many praising her "old-school way of doing things."

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound from previous losses; won gains
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 10.71 points or 0.44% to 2,440.54 at 0630 GMT, rebounding from a near three-month low on Thursday. The Korean won gained 0.28% against the dollar, reaching 1,079.7 per dollar, while bond yields rose. The won also gained 0.9% on a weekly basis, driven by exporters' heavy dollar-selling at the end of the month.

site_title: Number of births in Japan to hit record low in 2017
summary: Japan's birth rate hit a record low in 2017 with approximately 941,000 new babies, a 4% decline from the previous year and lowest since records began in 1899. The country's population is aging and shrinking, with 27.2% of the population aged 65 or older, the highest ratio on record. The number of deaths is expected to rise by 3% to 1.34 million, resulting in a 403,000 natural population decline. The government has been increasing efforts to attract foreign workers and students to mitigate the shrinking population.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on late bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, driven by late bargain-hunting ahead of US President Donald Trump's tax cut plan. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.16% and the Topix index rose 0.35%. The move follows a rebound in US stocks, which resumed their climb after the tax cut plan's passage.

site_title: Cathay pilots favour raising funds as buffer amid anger over bonuses
summary: Cathay Pacific pilots voted in favor of raising funds as a buffer against potential actions by the airline, such as unilateral benefit changes or job losses, amid ongoing anger over bonuses. Despite the airline backing down from a plan to cut housing allowances, pilots remain upset over the lack of year-end bonuses for Hong Kong-based captains. Over 82% of union members voted in favor of resolutions, including raising funds to prepare for "industrial escalation".

site_title: EtonHouse's Middleton International to open Tampines campus
summary: EtonHouse's Middleton International School will open its 1,000-student Tampines campus in May 2018, following a tender win for the site. The campus, previously occupied by ITE Tampines, will offer the International Primary Curriculum, Cambridge IGCSE, and A levels. School fees will be S$15,000 per annum for primary, S$17,250 for secondary, and S$19,837 for Grades 11 and 12, making them "nearly half" the fees charged by other international schools in Singapore. The new campus aims to meet the "strong demand for good quality and affordable international education in Singapore."

site_title: As Bali losses hit US$1b, Jokowi seeks to calm tourists
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo and his deputy, Muhammad Jusuf Kalla, will visit Bali to reassure tourists that the island is safe for Christmas and New Year's celebrations. The visit comes as losses from the erupting Mount Agung volcano near US$1 billion. The tourism ministry has confirmed that tourists are safe outside the exclusion zone, and the administration is desperate to lure tourists back to the island, which accounts for 70% of the province's income.

site_title: UK economy held back by inflation squeeze, Brexit wariness
summary: The UK economy experienced its weakest growth in 4 1/2 years, with annual growth in the third quarter slowing to 1.7%, according to the Office for National Statistics. This is slightly higher than previously estimated but still below pre-Brexit referendum rates. The services industry, which drove growth, rose 0.2% in October, while manufacturing showed a mildly positive performance. This steady growth contrasts with the Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates for the first time in a decade last month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.44 points to 1,752.65 on Friday, with 69.74 million lots traded worth RM13.36 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 42, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: App-based banks follow new business model
summary: British app-based banks, such as Monzo and Starling Bank, are adopting a new business model that generates revenue by allowing other firms access to their customers' data, rather than lending to them. Despite high growth rates, with Monzo's user numbers soaring by 300% to 450,000 in nine months, the banks are still unprofitable due to high costs associated with offering free services. However, they expect to turn a profit by using customers' data to push them towards other financial services, taking a commission whenever it works. This model could disrupt traditional banking and challenge the dominance of big banks.

site_title: China mulls law to punish those who 'slander heroes and martyrs'
summary: China's top legislature is considering a law to punish those who "insult or slander heroes and martyrs." The proposal, known as the "Protection of Heroes and Martyrs Law," aims to promote patriotism and the "spirit of heroic martyrs." This follows China's approval of legislation to punish disrespect to the national anthem with up to three years in prison. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's campaign to infuse education with patriotic spirit and strengthen the Communist Party's legitimacy. The law's specifics have not been released, but it is expected to further tighten control over public discourse.

site_title: EtonHouse's Middleton International School to open Tampines campus in 2018
summary: Middleton International School, part of EtonHouse International Education Group, will open its 1,000-student Tampines campus in May 2018. The site, previously occupied by ITE Tampines, features classrooms, sports facilities, and a field. The campus will offer the International Primary Curriculum and Cambridge IGCSE and A-level qualifications. School fees range from S$15,000 to S$19,837 per annum. The Tampines school is part of EtonHouse's expansion to meet demand for affordable international education in Singapore, following the success of its first MIS campus in 2016.

site_title: BreadTalk's unit partners Japanese trader in F&B JV
summary: BreadTalk Group Limited has established a 66-34% joint venture agreement with Shinmei Co Ltd, forming BTG-Shinmei Venture Pte Ltd to oversee sourcing and supply of raw materials and ingredients for BreadTalk's F&B operations globally. This marks Shinmei's first foray into the Singapore market, with no expected impact on BreadTalk's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2017. The joint venture will also potentially source and supply to third parties in the future.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip; Madrid slammed by Catalan vote
summary: Europe's stock markets declined on the last trading day before Christmas, with Madrid's IBEX 35 index falling 1.54% due to a Catalan separatist victory. The region's ousted leaders were handed a mandate in a snap poll, increasing uncertainty and keeping independence calls on the table. Other European markets, such as London, Frankfurt, and Paris, also dipped, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 declining 0.3%. The outcome is expected to have significant implications for Spain's politics and economy.

site_title: It's A Wrap
summary: A step-by-step guide to gift wrapping is provided in the article, with two methods: the Paper Bag Method and the Diagonal Wrap Method. The Paper Bag Method is considered the most versatile and can be used for various shapes and sizes of gifts, while the Diagonal Wrap Method, popularized by the Japanese, requires practice but can result in a professionally wrapped gift in under 30 seconds. The article also offers tips on choosing the right wrapping paper, tape, and scissors, as well as accessorizing with ribbons and gift tags.

images.alt_text: 01. Place the gift on the wrapper and measure out the paper needed. The two edges should cover the gift.
02. Fold the wrapper, and leave about 5mm from the edge, and use double-sided tape on the edge of the wrapper.
03. Remove the tape and fold the edge of the wrapper over the tape.
04. Place gift on the folder wrapper,and use your fingers to estimate the width of the base.
05. Fold the wrapper (the width of your fingers) inwards, and repeat on the other side.
06. Open up the wrapper, and where the valley fold is, create a mountain fold, by creasing the paper in the opposite way.
07. Join the first crease with the mountain fold.
08. Repeat steps 7 and 8 on other side.
09. Place gift on wrapper and fold edge closest to you upwards, and create a crease.
10. Open up the side, and fold the wrapper to make a crease.
11. Repeat on other side.
12. Turn the wrapper 90-degrees clockwise, and fold down top edge of wrapper. Repeat with bottom edge of wrapper,
13. Use double-sided tape to secure the edges of wrapper. The base is now complete.
14. Place gift in the bag, and fold down the top edge to estimate height of bag and trim off excess.
15. Gather top of wrapper together.
16. Roll excess paper and cut at a 45 degree angle.
17. Unroll the cut wrapper, which now resembles a crown, and place over the crumpled top.
18. Secure the wrappers using tape, and accessorise with a ribbon.
01. Place gift at 45 degree angle to the wrapping paper, with a small corner of the gift outside of the wrapper.
02. Fold the corner of the paper closest to you upwards, and tuck in wrapper against the gift.
03. Pull the left side of the wrapper towards the gift. The crease of the wrapper should align with the corner of the gift.
04. Fold the wrapper over, making sure that the edges are all in line.
05. Repeat steps 2 and 3 for the next corner.
06. Flip the gift onto its side. Tuck the wrapper towards the gift.
07. Flip the gift onto its side again, so that it it lies on the wrapper.
08. Fold the wrapper in to create a corner.
09. Fold the wrapper over the gift.
10. Turn the gift 90 degrees clockwise.
11. Fold the free edge of the wrapper backwards and make a crease.
12. Fold the wrapper forward along the crease, and make a sharp crease.
13. Turn the gift 90 degrees clockwise, and tuck the wrapper to create a corner.
14. Fold the wrapper upwards, and then over the gift.
15. Repeat steps 11 and 12 again with the wrapper.
16. Fold the free edge of the wrapper backwards
17. Roll up the excess wrapper and tuck in into the folded edge
18. Gift is now wrapped, and slot gift tag into the open seam.
Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: GVC to buy online bookmaker Ladbrokes for up to US$5.4b
summary: GVC Holdings Plc agreed to acquire UK bookmaker Ladbrokes Coral Group Plc for up to £4 billion (S$7.1 billion), a 19% increase from Thursday's closing price. The merger aims to create a larger digital gaming business, while Ladbrokes Coral gains exposure to the expanding online market and GVC reaches more customers. The deal follows previous consolidations in the sector and could lead to further industry changes.

site_title: Japan's US LPG imports to hit record in 2017, top the Middle East
summary: Japan's liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) imports from the US are expected to reach a record high in 2017, accounting for around half of its total purchases. The surge is driven by the US's increasing shale oil and gas output, which rivals Saudi Arabia and Russia. This shift displaces Middle Eastern suppliers, particularly Saudi Arabia, as US LPG exports to Japan could reach almost 6 million tonnes by the end of 2017, doubling the previous year's volumes.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on positive ground; STI at 3,391.66
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% in afternoon trading, reaching 3,391.66, driven by gains from Sincap, which rose 12.5% after addressing potential liabilities. Gainers outnumbered losers 169 to 136, with 670.5 million shares traded. Other active stocks included ThaiBev and Singtel, with ThaiBev down 1.6% and Singtel up 0.28%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Bank of Singapore hires bankers to manage Middle East, Indian money
summary: Bank of Singapore plans to hire 20 relationship managers to cater to non-resident Indians and wealthy individuals in the Arab world, primarily in Dubai. The bank has seen "phenomenal growth" in assets under management in the Middle East and from overseas Indians this year. The total wealth in the Middle East grew 5% to US$2.4 trillion last year. Bank of Singapore aims to bolster its non-resident Indian teams in Singapore and Hong Kong, with some staff based in Dubai.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore plans to hire about 20 relationship managers next year to cater to non-resident Indians and rich people in the Arab world.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Bank of Singapore has hired bankers to manage the money of wealthy individuals in the Middle East and India. Cosco Shipping International has hit a 90% acquisition threshold in its takeover bid for Cogent, with plans to delist the company. Pavillon Holdings plans to issue convertible bonds to pay for Johor Bahru properties. CDL Hospitality Trust is selling two Brisbane assets for A$77 million. Spackman Entertainment Group acquired a talent management agency and increased its stake in Spackman Media. Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Friday, closing at 3,385.71.

site_title: Eurozone reform proposals not going far enough
summary: The European Commission's recent proposals for eurozone sovereign crisis management are deemed insufficient, with experts arguing that the proposals do not go far enough in addressing the root causes of bank and sovereign crises. The proposals include measures such as countercyclical policies, GDP-linked bonds, and a European Monetary Fund, but critics argue that these measures are not enough to prevent or mitigate crises. A more comprehensive approach is needed, including stress testing of national economies, contingency planning, and a more independent and transparent mechanism for dealing with nonperforming sovereign debt.

site_title: Australian shares rise on financials and materials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by gains in financials and materials sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,069.7, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Corp leading the gains. Miners also extended their 10th consecutive session of gains, supported by higher iron ore prices. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.4% to 8,396.43, marking its sixth consecutive weekly gain.

site_title: Najib will use all means to fight Trump's Jerusalem move
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak vowed to use all means to protest against US President Donald Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital, a move that is crucial to his support among Muslim voters ahead of a general election next year. Najib, facing a graft scandal, emphasized the sanctity of Islam and vowed to fight for the Palestinian people's right to Jerusalem. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to boost his party's chances in the election, where the ruling party is expected to face a challenge from former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Thinking outside the box to ease Hong Kong's housing crisis
summary: Hong Kong's housing crisis has pushed tens of thousands of families into tiny apartments, with soaring property prices reaching historic records. The city has seen a surge in "inadequate housing," with 115,000 households living in partitioned flats and industrial buildings. To address the issue, architects and manufacturers are exploring creative solutions such as converting shipping containers and water pipes into temporary homes. While these solutions may provide short-term relief, non-governmental groups stress that they cannot be a permanent solution, emphasizing the need for the government to speed up public housing construction.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday as foreign investors shifted to profit-taking ahead of holidays following US stocks' resumption of their climb after the passage of President Trump's tax cut plan. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.03%, while the Topix index rose 0.12%.

site_title: Hong Kong : Stocks start Friday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open of trade on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.47% to 29,505.05, driven by a rebound in US markets. Technology and energy firms led the way, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices dipped. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Catalan separatists win absolute parliamentary majority
summary: Catalan separatists won a snap poll, securing an absolute parliamentary majority with 70 of 135 seats, despite campaigning from exile and behind bars. The pro-independence camp, led by deposed leader Carles Puigdemont, aims to negotiate with Madrid, while the anti-secessionist centrist party Ciudadanos secured the biggest individual result with 37 seats. The election result plunges the region into uncertainty, with the Spanish government and EU backing Madrid's stance on constitutional order.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment buys talent management agency; ups stake in Spackman Media
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group Limited has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire talent management agency Constellation Agency for S$16.6 million. The acquisition aims to leverage Constellation's marketing expertise and talent management platform to deliver integrated content production. Separately, Spackman Entertainment has also entered into a share swap agreement to acquire an additional 920,000 shares of Spackman Media Group Limited, increasing its stake from 29.12% to 32.13%. The group believes the acquisitions will help unlock higher value for its shareholders.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks claw back previous losses, won
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 7.90 points or 0.33% to 2,437.73 at 01.47 GMT, driven by the won's 0.29% gain to 1,079.6 per dollar. The index is up 19.9% this year, while bond yields rose, with the 3-year Korean treasury bond yielding 2.104%. Foreigners were net buyers of 29,095 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar has fallen 10.47% against the won this year.

site_title: Oil little changed despite planned restart of UK North Sea pipe
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Thursday as the operator of Britain's Forties pipeline in the North Sea announced it would restart in early January after repairs over Christmas. The Forties pipeline is a key component of Brent, a benchmark for oil trading in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. The restart is expected to stabilize oil prices, with energy analyst Jim Ritterbusch noting that the complex can absorb reports of the pipeline's return to normal operations.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed on Thursday, erasing earlier losses after the operator of Britain's Forties pipeline in the North Sea said it was expected to restart in early January after repairs over Christmas.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trust to sell two Brisbane assets for A$77m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts announced the sale of the Mercure Brisbane and Ibis Brisbane for A$77.0 million, a 43.4% premium over the original purchase price of A$53.7 million. The sale represents an exit yield of 5.3% and is expected to be completed in January 2018. The buyer is an independent third party, CR Hotel Target.

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy pre-Christmas cheer, euro avoids sell-off
summary: Asian markets ended the week on a positive note, with the euro holding steady despite Catalan separatist wins. The rally follows recent US tax reform, which boosted corporate profits and fueled hopes for a strong US economy. The Dow and S&P 500 also reached fresh records, despite ongoing trade uncertainty. Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff concerns and divided Federal Reserve views.

site_title: US House approves short-term budget to avoid shutdown
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a short-term budget bill, passing 231-188, to fund the federal government for four more weeks until January 19, 2018, avoiding a potential shutdown. The Senate must approve the bill by Friday to keep the government open. The temporary funding extension aims to give lawmakers more time to reach an agreement on the remainder of the 2018 fiscal year. President Donald Trump accused Democrats of trying to block the bill to distract from the tax cuts.

site_title: Eric Schmidt stepping down as chair of Alphabet board
summary: Google's parent company Alphabet announced Eric Schmidt will step down as chairman, shifting to a technical advisor role. Schmidt's tenure as executive chairman ends at a board meeting next month. He will continue on the board, citing a desire to focus on science, technology, and philanthropy. Schmidt, who has been a driving force at Alphabet since its formation, praised the company's structure and the success of its subsidiaries. His departure follows a corporate overhaul two years ago, which created Alphabet as a holding company for Google and other ventures.

site_title: Aspial CEO, ex-executive director of Zhongmin Baihui up stakes in CWX Global
summary: Aspial CEO Koh Wee Seng and former Zhongmin Baihui executive director Low Chui Heng have significantly increased their stakes in CWX Global, a Singapore-based company, after its latest rights and warrants issue. Koh's stake rose from 1.13% to 9.68%, while Low's increased from 0.01% to 8.55%. The company issued 1.95 billion rights shares and 487.5 million warrants to raise S$16.99 million in net proceeds, which will be used to fund new business activities and working capital.

site_title: Hot stock: Sincap jumps 12.5% on liability disclaimer, Orion Energy expansion
summary: Sincap Group shares jumped 12.5% on Friday after the company addressed potential liabilities from a disposed subsidiary. Advanceleap Corp, which bought Sincap's Beijing Raffles Investment Advisory, has given an undertaking not to hold Sincap liable for issues related to a mine refilling project. Sincap's management concluded it faced no liability and had received legal advice stating there were no current Chinese laws requiring the company to complete the project. The company also announced the full use of S$10 million from the sale of Beijing Raffles for its subsidiary Orion Energy Resources' expansion plans.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says she won't blindly obey Beijing's orders
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has stated she won't blindly follow Beijing's orders, expressing concerns over Chinese meddling in the city's affairs. Despite being sworn in by Chinese President Xi Jinping, Lam admitted the government's inability to control rising property prices. Critics accuse her of being a puppet of Beijing, citing concerns over the enforcement of Chinese laws in a high-speed railway station. Lam's comments come amid perceptions of Chinese interference in Hong Kong's affairs, with a recent poll showing she is more popular than her predecessor.

site_title: Officials hope American corporates will bring profits home
summary: US lawmakers have adopted sweeping tax cuts that reduce corporate tax rates and aim to encourage multinational businesses to repatriate offshore earnings. The goal is to bring profits home, as US corporations have accumulated huge profits abroad to avoid high US tax rates. The tax cuts are part of a broader effort to boost economic growth and competitiveness.

site_title: Cosco hits 90% acquisition threshold in takeover bid, plans to delist Cogent
summary: Cosco Shipping International has hit 90% of its acquisition threshold in its S$1.02-a-share cash offer for Cogent Holdings, surpassing the 90% compulsory acquisition mark. The company now plans to pursue a delisting of Cogent from the Singapore Exchange, with the existing business activities continuing unchanged. Cosco's financial adviser, Bank of China, has extended a S$350 million loan facility to part fund the takeover. The four shareholders who have agreed to accept the offer collectively hold 84.33% of Cogent's shares.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges below US$13,000, heads for worst week since 2013
summary: Bitcoin plummeted below $13,000 on Friday, marking its worst week since 2013. The digital currency had surged 20-fold since the start of the year, reaching a peak of $19,666 on Sunday. However, it has since lost nearly a third of its value in five days, falling to $12,560 on Bitstamp. At press time, it was trading at $13,320, down 15% on the day. This decline marks its worst day in over three months, as the currency continues its downward trend.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin prices suffered a dramatic plunge on Friday, dropping 20 per cent at one point towards the US$13,000-mark in volatile Asian trading.

site_title: Asia's most overworked country, South Korea, pushes for right to rest
summary: South Korea, the most overworked country in Asia, is pushing for a "right to rest" by slashing work hours. President Moon Jae In aims to cap weekly hours at 52, down from 68, and give extra 50% pay for weekends. However, lawmakers and labour unions are debating the proposal, with some arguing for doubling weekend pay to 100%. If no agreement is reached by December 23, the proposal may stall until February. Experts warn that shorter working hours could lead to decreased productivity, affecting workers' and employers' income.

site_title: Facebook pulling 'disputed' flags from fake news
summary: Facebook will stop flagging fake news as "disputed" and instead offer up contradictory stories containing facts that have been checked. This change aims to reduce the spread of bogus information on its platform. Research found that strong language and visualizations can backfire and further entrench someone's beliefs. Facebook tested offering fact-checked articles before users clicked on links to dubious stories, finding it more effective in reducing the sharing of hoax articles.

site_title: A weekend of reflection and transformation
summary: A personal essay by Philip Jeyaretnam reflects on the true meaning of Christmas, encouraging readers to engage in genuine reflection and transformation. Meanwhile, the article highlights various topics, including Singapore's pawnbroking industry undergoing changes, Finland's innovation and technology, and the upcoming football match between Real Madrid and Barcelona. The article also features a guide to the best movies and music for the holiday season and gift ideas.

site_title: Sweden won't fight for more power over Nordea's mega bank branch
summary: Sweden's financial regulator, the Financial Supervisory Authority, opposes giving national supervisors additional powers over bank branches, even systemically important ones like Nordea Bank. Deputy director general Martin Noreus states that national regulators risk missing the big picture by focusing on individual entities rather than the whole group. Instead, Sweden advocates for international cooperation among regulators through "colleges" to effectively supervise large European cross-border banks.

site_title: Boeing in talks with Embraer; Brazil backs jetliner alliance
summary: Boeing and Embraer are discussing a potential combination, which could consolidate a global passenger jet duopoly if Brazil's government gives its approval. The Brazilian government would support a partnership but block a takeover attempt. Embraer's shares rose 20% after the announcement, while Boeing shares slipped 1%. The partnership's structure has not been disclosed, and the Brazilian government's veto power over strategic moves at Embraer would be maintained.

site_title: Surge in US shale hedging expected to lift crude output to new high in 2018
summary: US shale producers significantly increased oil hedging in the third quarter, locking in 144 million barrels of production for 2018, exceeding government forecasts. This surge in hedging is expected to propel the country to record crude production of over 10 million barrels per day, potentially pressuring prices. The increase in hedging activity is seen as a leading indicator of future supplies, with traders estimating growth of up to 1.2 million barrels per day in 2018, which could complicate OPEC's efforts to curb global supplies.

site_title: Pavillon to issue 3-year, 5% convertible bonds to pay for Johor Bahru properties
summary: Pavillon Holdings plans to issue 3-year, 5% convertible bonds worth RM29.9 million to pay for its Johor Bahru properties acquisition. The bonds will be issued to Low Eng Heng, a majority shareholder, and will have a conversion price of RM0.3025 per share. The move is part of the company's plan to partially fund the acquisition, which also involves issuing 70 million new shares. The convertible bonds will have an initial conversion premium of 108% against Pavillon's closing price of S$0.048 a share.

site_title: Japan unveils record defence budget against North Korea threat
summary: Japan has unveiled a record defense budget of $46 billion for the next fiscal year to bolster its missile shield against North Korea's threat. This marks the sixth consecutive year of defense spending increases, following two missile launches by North Korea this year. The budget is part of a larger $860-billion national budget, also a record, driven by rising medical and social welfare costs in Japan's aging society.

images.alt_text: Japan's defence budget will swell to a record US$46 billion for the next fiscal year, the government said Friday, as the nation shores up its missile shield against the threat posed by North Korea.

site_title: Europe: Shares find fuel ahead of Catalan election outcome, holiday
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by gains in financials, health, and consumer staples sectors. The Stoxx 600 index hit a record, with Britain's FTSE up 1.1%. The reversal of earlier losses came after a muted response to the US tax overhaul. Meanwhile, a Catalan election outcome and holiday season remain in focus, but investors appear undeterred by uncertainty.

site_title: 'Wearable' computing a growing market: IDC
summary: IDC forecasts the wearables market to nearly double in the next few years, from 113.2 million units this year to 222.3 million in 2021. This growth is driven by increasing demand for Internet-linked watches and step-counting shoes.

site_title: Engineering services firm Acromec bags 2 contracts worth S$6.6m
summary: Acromec, an engineering services firm, secured two contracts worth S$6.6 million, increasing its order book to around S$28 million. The first contract involves the fitting-out of a pharmaceutical company's research laboratory, expected to begin in Q1 2018 and complete by Q3 2018. The second contract involves an extensive air-conditioning upgrade for a research laboratory in the life sciences sector, also set to begin in Q1 2018 and complete by Q3 2018. The contracts are expected to contribute to the firm's growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Acromec, Pavillon, ComfortDelGro, CDL
