summary: Acromec secured two contracts worth S$6.6 million, growing its order book to S$28 million, and rose 19% to close at S$0.25 a share. Pavillon Holdings issued three-year convertible bonds at 5% interest for RM29.9 million (S$9.86 million) to pay for its Johor Bahru property acquisition.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 10.05 points, or 0.3%, to 3,392.58. This follows a day of positive investor sentiment after the US passed a bill to slash corporate tax rates and registered solid third-quarter growth of 3.2%. Trading activity was moderate, with about 45 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 59 to 32, with Sincap Group being the most actively traded counter, rising S$0.001 to S$0.017.

site_title: Deepest India bond rout in 2 decades shows no sign of easing
summary: India's bond market is experiencing its deepest rout in nearly two decades, with the yield on benchmark 10-year notes expected to rise further by the end of March. The yield has surged 78 basis points since July and is up for a fifth month in December. The sell-off is attributed to concerns over the government's fiscal deficit and elevated oil prices, which threaten to fan inflation. The yield is forecast to reach 7.25-7.5% by the end of March, according to a Bloomberg survey.

site_title: A decade after bubble, Spanish real estate a hot buy again
summary: Spanish real estate is experiencing a resurgence in investment, with commercial property sales expected to reach a 10-year high in 2017, driven by banks clearing foreclosed assets and foreign buyers. The economy is outpacing the rest of the continent, and investors are attracted to Spain's cheap property prices and investor-friendly framework. Investment volumes are expected to continue growing in 2018, with Savills predicting 8.9 billion euros in sales by the end of the year, up from 1.9 billion euros in 2011.

site_title: Lotte chief faces corruption ruling, possible jail time
summary: A South Korean court will rule on corruption charges against Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong Bin on Friday, with prosecutors seeking a 10-year jail term for embezzlement and breach of trust. Shin denies the charges, claiming he was not involved in decision-making for two breach of trust charges. A guilty verdict could halt Shin's plans to grow Lotte globally and weaken his position in the company. The ruling could also impact Lotte's struggling business in China, where the company has nearly shut down its stores over alleged fire safety issues and is putting its business on the block.

site_title: Gold holds steady as US data leaves dollar stable
summary: Gold prices held steady at a two-week high, reaching $1,266.35 an ounce, after US data showed a stable economy and a broadly steady dollar. The US GDP, jobless claims, and regional business activity data left traders' views unchanged, contributing to the stability in the gold market. Spot palladium also rose, nearing a 50% gain for the year due to expected demand shifts from diesel to gasoline-fueled cars.

site_title: A Christmas journey through jazz
summary: Local jazz musician Jeremy Monteiro is set to perform his 12th annual "Jazzy Christmas" concert, inspired by the cult TV show "The Twilight Zone." The festive show will feature a diverse lineup of jazz musicians, including Tony Lakatos, Melissa Tham, Alberto Marsico, and newcomer CC Lee, among others. The concert will showcase different genres of jazz with a festive twist, including bepop, blues, and swing, before concluding with a performance by Joanna Dong, a recent Sing! China finalist.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Oil: Skewed to the downside
summary: Oil prices fell amid bearish expectations due to US President Trump's fresh tariffs on Canada and potential threats to other countries. Gold prices rose in response. Meanwhile, China's solar stocks surged as Beijing aims to calm price wars. OPEC announced a reduction in oil demand for the next four years, further contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Sincap says not liable for any claims against disposed unit
summary: CATALIST-LISTED commodity trader Sincap Group has obtained an undertaking from the buyer of Beijing Raffles Investment Advisory, not to hold the company liable for any potential issues or liabilities related to its sale of Shandong Luneng mine operations. Sincap Group sold its entire stake in Beijing Raffles for S$10 million to Advanceleap Corporation in June. The company denies claims made by the management and employees' union of Shandong Luneng regarding outstanding social security insurance payments and mine refilling project requirements. The sale proceeds have been fully used to expand Orion Energy Resources.

site_title: Noble Group gets another credit extension, but future still uncertain
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, received a loan extension until May 18, 2018, as it negotiates debt restructuring with creditors. The firm has already had its loan extended twice before mid-December. The outcome of the discussions remains uncertain, leaving Noble's future still unclear.

site_title: Dealmaking in Singapore reaches highest level since 2014: Reuters
summary: Dealmaking in Singapore reached its highest level since 2014 in 2017, with a 4% increase in year-to-date deal values to $89 billion. The real estate sector led the way, driven by the proposed acquisition of Global Logistic Properties by Nesta Investment Holdings Ltd. Domestic M&A activity also improved, with a 29.9% increase in deal value to $15.4 billion, while cross-border deal activity grew 58.6% to $59.1 billion. The record-high 2014 figure was surpassed, and the sector's value increased by 195.7% from 2016.

site_title: For tea devotees, this little shop is the place to be
summary: Fang Gourmet Tea, a 15-year-old shop in Queens, New York, hosts its annual Tea Tasting Expo, attracting tea enthusiasts from across the US. The event features rare and limited-release teas, including a 1890s fermented liu bao tea, which can be tasted for $180 per person. The expo also serves as a community for tea devotees to share knowledge and experience, with no keynote addresses or sponsors. The shop, owned by Sophia Huang's family, aims to educate and connect tea enthusiasts, rather than solely for profit.

site_title: Aramco embarks on global hunt for natural gas supplies
summary: Saudi Aramco is searching for natural gas assets globally to meet increasing domestic demand, as the kingdom's state-owned energy giant has failed to find sufficient domestic reserves. Chairman and Saudi energy minister Khalid Al-Falih mentioned potential targets in Russia, East Africa, and the US, including liquefied natural gas imports from Russia and investments in the US through its subsidiary Motiva. Aramco aims to reduce crude oil burned in power stations and increase domestic gas production to meet electricity demand.

site_title: Logistics firm Logos buys Tuas property
summary: Logos, a Singapore-based logistics firm, has acquired a property in Tuas for S$79 million to redevelop into a modern food processing and logistics facility. The facility will have 27,000 sqm of net lettable area, with five floors and ancillary office space. Construction will begin immediately after acquisition, with completion scheduled for early 2019. This is Logos' first food sector development in South-east Asia, and it marks the company's fourth asset in Singapore.

site_title: BoJ maintains stimulus as low inflation persists
summary: The Bank of Japan (BoJ) maintained its stimulus package, leaving its policy settings unchanged since September 2016, as low inflation persisted. The economy continues to grow, but inflation remains below the 2% target. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank doesn't need to reconsider its current policy framework, citing the absence of financial intermediation issues. Analysts expect the BoJ to consider policy changes in 2018, but for now, the economy's growth and steady improvement in employment and incomes suggest the current policy framework is producing results.

site_title: Goodbye to one year and welcome to another
summary: The world economy showed resilience in 2017, growing despite expectations of a slowdown. The US tax reforms, European Central Bank's quantitative easing, and positive developments in China, Japan, and India fueled the growth. However, economic cycles typically last six to eight years, and the current recovery may outlast predicted downturns. Economists warn of potential negative consequences, including increased public debt and social welfare cuts, but the current recovery is expected to last longer. Despite this, economic performance has not translated to improved public sentiment, with pervasive gloom in Europe and pessimism in the US.

site_title: Good efforts but more work needed
summary: Two seafood restaurants, FiSK and Uni Gallery, were reviewed in Singapore. FiSK offers a casual gourmet experience with a limited selection of seafood, with dishes averaging around S$20-S$30. The food is generally average, with some standout dishes like seabass and mussels. In contrast, Uni Gallery, run by a Japanese seafood supplier, offers fresh sashimi but at a steep price point, with some dishes exceeding S$30. Despite the high prices, Uni Gallery's sashimi is mostly fresh, but the overall experience is mediocre. Both restaurants have potential but may not live up to expectations.

site_title: iPhone supplier Murata boosting output of foldable circuits
summary: Murata Manufacturing, the exclusive supplier of foldable circuits for Apple's iPhone, is boosting its production capacity to meet higher demand next year. The company's MetroCirc circuit boards are used in the latest iPhone X and 8 models, and factories are already operating at full capacity, forcing Murata to turn customers away. The company expects sales of its multilayer resin substrates to reach 100 billion yen by 2021 as adoption expands beyond smartphones to wearables and data centers.

site_title: US tax reform may mean lower prices for Manhattan buyers
summary: US tax reform passed by President Trump may lower home prices in high-cost New York markets like Manhattan and Westchester County. Buyers demand discounts to cover higher carrying costs, as the bill limits mortgage interest deductions to $750,000 and capping state and local tax deductions at $10,000. This is expected to put downward pressure on prices until equilibrium is reached, with luxury buyers potentially benefiting from the tax break.

site_title: US: Stocks resume upward climb after tax cut passed
summary: US stocks resumed their upward climb after the passage of the $1.5 trillion tax cut bill, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% at 24,782.29. Energy and media shares led the gains, with petroleum-linked shares and major media companies such as Comcast and Twenty-First Century Fox rising. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record high. Analysts credited the tax cut for boosting earnings, citing higher oil prices and corporate tax cuts.

site_title: Russians, Chinese seeking out Greek properties
summary: Russian and Chinese investors are seeking Greek properties, taking advantage of low prices and the potential for future capital gains as the market recovers. A "golden visa" program allows investors to gain residency in Greece, providing access to the European Union's passport-free Schengen area. With property prices 1,000 euros cheaper than in Portugal and 3 times cheaper than in Italy, Greece is attracting buyers from Russia, China, Turkey, and elsewhere, with interest in properties from Greek banks' auctions also rising.

images.alt_text: A view of the cityscape of Athens. Property prices in Greece have fallen more than the 25 per cent contraction in the economy since Europe's sovereign debt crisis began in 2008. However, the market may be poised for a rebound, helping buyers make some money on their purchase.

site_title: Moody's places Lippo Retail Trust's rating for downgrade
summary: Moody's has placed Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) on review for downgrade due to deteriorating credit quality of key entities within the Lippo group, which contribute around one-third of the trust's revenue. The rating agency expects LMIRT's financial metrics to weaken, increasing its exposure to foreign exchange rate fluctuations and asset devaluations. The trust faces high refinancing risk and increased leverage, with a proposed debt-funded acquisition and upcoming debt maturities in 2018. Moody's will review LMIRT's ability to reduce its exposure to the Lippo group and improve its financial metrics.

site_title: Singapore firms fare better than global peers in sustainability reporting
summary: Singapore-listed companies are better at reporting on sustainability, with 84% of the largest firms undertaking corporate responsibility reporting, exceeding the global average of 72%. However, many still fail to address climate change risks and set carbon reduction targets, with only 17% of local firms having set such targets. Globally, only 50% of top 100 companies acknowledge climate change as a financial risk, and Singapore ranks below other major economies such as Taiwan, France, and the US in this regard.

site_title: Stronger deterrence needed to deal with bogus claims on public grants
summary: A Singaporean criminal syndicate allegedly defrauded the SkillsFuture Singapore statutory board of nearly S$40 million by making bogus SkillsFuture Credit claims. The syndicate, using nine business entities, submitted the names of 80,000 individuals to claim a maximum of S$500 each. This is the largest known case of defrauding a public institution. The perpetrators' elaborate ruse went undetected for months, highlighting the need for stronger deterrence against such scams.

site_title: Jesus meets the Fab Four
summary: The Hillsong megachurch in New York recently hosted a musical production that incorporated The Beatles' music to retell the story of the three kings visiting the baby Jesus. The event, led by teaching pastor Nathan Finochio, seamlessly transitioned between the Beatles' songs and the Nativity story, featuring a diverse and fashionable crowd of 2,300 attendees. The production aimed to showcase the church's appeal to young, digitally-savvy members and its ability to blend music and faith in a unique and entertaining way.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sakae Holdings announced a change in its financial year end from December 31 to June 30. The next set of audited financial statements for the period ending June 30, 2018, will cover 18 months from January 1, 2017, to June 30, 2018.

site_title: UK's 2 options: a fake or no Brexit
summary: The UK is facing a Brexit impasse with two options: a fake Brexit, similar to Norway's associate EU membership, or no Brexit at all. The UK's withdrawal notice under Article 50 can be revoked, allowing for a no-Brexit scenario. This would require a collapse of Prime Minister Theresa May's government and a Labour-led coalition promising to "think again" about Brexit. Alternatively, businesses and investors may welcome a Norwegian-style transition, but this would come with significant political costs, including adherence to EU laws and regulations, and potentially enacting a "vassal state" arrangement.

site_title: Kovan Lodge, Ampas Apartments up for en bloc sales
summary: Huttons Asia has launched tenders for the collective sales of Kovan Lodge and Ampas Apartments in Singapore. Kovan Lodge, a freehold property, is up for sale at S$43 million, while Ampas Apartments, also freehold, is being sold for S$105 million. Both properties are zoned for residential use under the Master Plan 2014. The sales are expected to test demand for prime projects in Singapore above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: Indonesia wins Fitch ratings upgrade; investors welcome news
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded Indonesia's credit rating to BBB from BBB-, citing improved economic and monetary policies, making the country resilient to external shocks. The rating upgrade comes with a stable outlook and puts Indonesia on par with the Philippines and Italy. Investors welcomed the news, with the rupiah strengthening and the benchmark stock index rising. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the upgrade would boost confidence in Indonesia, while Bank Indonesia governor Agus Martowardojo emphasized the need to maintain macroeconomic stability to support economic growth.

site_title: Media investor Jay Penske takes controlling stake in Rolling Stone
summary: Media investor Jay Penske has acquired a controlling stake in Rolling Stone magazine, with founder Jann Wenner retaining a role as editorial director. Penske's investment aims to revive the financial health of the iconic publication, which has struggled in recent years. The deal, valued at $100 million, will see BandLab Technologies retain a 49% stake in Rolling Stone. Penske hopes to ensure the magazine's continued success across multiple media platforms, citing its cultural significance and globally recognized brand.

site_title: Q3 growth is fastest in more than two years
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest growth in over two years during the third quarter, with a 3.2% annual GDP expansion driven by robust business spending. This growth is expected to be boosted modestly by tax cuts passed by Congress. The Commerce Department released its third GDP estimate on Thursday, providing a positive outlook for the economy.

images.alt_text: The US economy grew at its fastest pace in more than two years in the third quarter, powered by robust business spending, and is poised for what could be a modest lift next year from sweeping tax cuts passed by Congress this week.

site_title: Corporate Social Responsibility in the era of big data
summary: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) has become a catchphrase, with companies focusing on high-profile initiatives rather than deep-rooted practices. However, CSR must go beyond superficial efforts to become an integral part of a company's standard practices and operations. The recent launch of Facebook's Messenger for Kids and Electronic Arts' inclusion of loot boxes in its Star Wars game have raised concerns about companies exploiting their consumers' data and leveraging their informational advantage to maximize profits. Companies must consider the long-term implications of their actions, genuine needs of stakeholders, and broader societal concerns to truly be socially responsible corporate citizens.

site_title: Big boon for S'pore businesses with operations in US
summary: The US Senate's approval of a tax bill cutting the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21% will benefit Singapore companies operating in the US, particularly those with significant US revenue contributions. While the tax cut may boost investment flows into the US, it could lead to US companies reevaluating their global structures and potentially reassessing their foreign operations. However, the exodus of US companies out of Singapore is unlikely, as Singapore remains a key Asian headquarters for many US firms.

site_title: US move may nudge some countries to play catch-up on corporate tax rates
summary: The US has cut its corporate tax rate to 21%, potentially prompting other countries to review their tax policies to remain competitive. However, Singapore's low 17% headline rate is unlikely to be lowered further, according to tax experts. Instead, targeted incentives or grants may be considered to stay competitive.

site_title: Brexit - the committee designs a camel
summary: Theresa May is facing numerous challenges in Brexit negotiations, despite attempting to project a positive image. The UK's future trading relationship with the EU and rest of the world has yet to be agreed upon, with the UK's only chance of redemption being to succeed in these talks. The parties have agreed on the cost of leaving the EU and the rights of EU citizens, but the UK's departure from the Customs' Union and mutual trade arrangements with the EU remains a significant hurdle, potentially leading to an election in 2018 if a charismatic leader does not emerge to define the UK's future outside the EU.

site_title: Fosun invests in Tsingtao Brewery with eye on middle-class market
summary: Fosun International has invested US$847 million in Tsingtao Brewery, acquiring an 18% stake in the Chinese brewer. The deal aims to cater to China's rising middle-class families and satisfies the government's push for local investments. Fosun's acquisition will help widen Tsingtao's distribution network and potentially optimize efficiency through its restructuring track record. The move is seen as a strategic move by Fosun to tap into the premium beer market and capitalize on China's growing consumer economy.

site_title: No respite for STI as sliding trend continues
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 12.34 points, or 0.36%, to 3,382.53, marking its sixth consecutive day of losses. Low liquidity, partly due to the festive season, and market participants liquidating portfolios ahead of a potentially tumultuous 2018, contributed to the decline. Volume was low, with 1.2 billion shares traded for S$808.5 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 202 to 198, with some energy-related counters, such as CWX Global and GSS Energy, experiencing gains, while others, like Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, remained flat.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Funnyman returns with new tour, TV series
summary: Russell Peters is set to launch his Deported World Tour in February, marking his return to live stand-up after producing and starring in his TV series The Indian Detective. The two-year global tour will feature new material and include stops in Australia and Singapore. Peters' previous tour, Almost Famous, visited 26 countries and played over 200 shows to 300,000 fans. The comedian's homecoming gig in Toronto was released as a Netflix special. Peters will be joined on tour by comedian Jake Johannsen.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: US dollar climbs vs yen as BOJ keeps policy steady
summary: The US dollar reached a nine-day high against the yen, climbing 0.2% to 113.635 yen, after Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda reinforced expectations that the BOJ will maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy. Kuroda stated that the BOJ would continue with monetary easing due to low inflation, and the yen is likely to track bonds lower. The greenback has gained 0.8% against the yen this week, driven by the US 10-year Treasury yield rising to a nine-month high.

site_title: Competition watchdog seeks feedback on proposed rule changes
summary:
The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is seeking feedback on proposed rule changes to the Competition Act. The proposed changes aim to level the playing field among businesses. Key changes include: 

1. Allowing companies to offer legally binding commitments to address anti-competitive conduct, enabling the CCS to enforce these commitments through the courts.
2. Enabling CCS to ask general questions in investigations without first serving a written notice, streamlining the evidence-gathering process.
3. Formalizing the process of seeking confidential advice for businesses considering mergers, providing greater assurance for businesses to assess potential merger implications.

The closing date for feedback is January 11, 2018.

site_title: China's Didi gets US$4b in fresh funds from SoftBank
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing company, has secured US$4 billion in fresh funding from SoftBank, valuing the company at approximately US$56 billion. The funding will support the company's expansion into new markets and development of artificial intelligence, autonomous car technologies, and electric vehicle systems. Didi aims to establish itself as a leader in mobility technology, leveraging its 450 million-plus users and data advantage. The company plans to scale up investments in AI talent and technologies, and build up its network for electric cars.

site_title: Bigger, better, bolder
summary: Netflix is expanding its original content, with 15 projects lined up for the Asia-Pacific region, including a Chinese language series and stand-up specials from local comedians. The video streaming giant reported 109 million subscribers worldwide, with Singaporeans binge-watching 60 movies per day and 50% of viewing hours coming from connected TVs. Netflix is also investing in high-quality content, including Ultra HD 4K and HDR, and competing with traditional entertainment options for viewers. The company aims to offer creators the freedom to tell global stories, citing its success with shows like Narcos.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Easing fears over economy lift Singapore consumer confidence in Q3: Nielsen survey
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence has risen to 94 points in Q3, up 5 points from the previous quarter, driven by easing fears over the economy and expansion in the manufacturing and service sectors. Job security remains a top concern, but fewer people are worried about the economy. The survey also shows improved perceptions of job prospects and personal finances, with 52% of consumers confident in their state of personal finances.

site_title: Controlling unitholder of FSL Trust to divest all shares in its sponsor
summary: The controlling unitholder of FSL Trust, Godan GMBH, is in discussions with strategic investors to divest all shares in FSL Holdings, the sponsor of the shipping trust. This move is seen as a positive development for the trust, potentially improving prospects for refinancing and extending the trust's indebtedness. FSL Trust is seeking to term out a syndicated loan facility through a scheme of arrangement filed with Singapore's High Court, which would not extend to its trade creditors.

site_title: Is Keppel Corp still an offshore and marine stock?
summary: Keppel Corp, a leading offshore and marine company, is shifting its focus away from its struggling offshore and marine business to its growing property sector. Keppel Land is now the key driver of the group's overall earnings, surpassing Keppel O&M. The company's net profit rose 11.2% to S$712.5 million, with the property business contributing 56% of the total earnings. Analysts expect the property business to continue driving earnings growth, potentially making Keppel an "offshore and marine stock" less relevant.

site_title: China, Australia ports clogged as coal, iron ore demand soars
summary: China and Australia ports are experiencing a maritime traffic jam due to soaring demand for coal and iron ore, resulting in over 300 delayed ships. Charter rates have reached their highest in three years, with vessels waiting over a month to load outside Australian ports. The backlog would stretch over 60km, equivalent to the length of the English Channel. This highlights bottlenecks in China's global commodity supply chain as demand peaks during the winter season.

site_title: US union rips Ford plan to move production of electric vehicles to Mexico
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) union criticized Ford's decision to shift production of electric vehicles to Mexico, citing cheaper labor costs. UAW President Dennis Williams expressed dissatisfaction, stating the move misses opportunities for US investment and competitiveness. The decision reverses a previous plan to produce electric vehicles at a Michigan plant, with the company instead focusing on self-driving cars. Williams called for higher wages for Mexican workers and urged other automakers to set an example, suggesting that changes in the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) are not necessary to achieve this goal.

site_title: Lufthansa eyes EU green light for Air Berlin spoils
summary: Lufthansa is seeking EU approval to acquire Air Berlin's smaller LGW subsidiary, a regional carrier employing 500 people, after scaling back its bid due to competition concerns. The deal, worth less than the initially proposed 210 million euros, would see Lufthansa take over LGW's 30 planes and landing slots. The European Commission is likely to give its green light on December 21, following easyJet's recent approval to purchase Air Berlin's operations at Berlin's Tegel Airport.

site_title: Life after Twilight for Robert Pattinson in grim crime caper
summary: Robert Pattinson stars in the gritty crime drama "Good Time" alongside his brother Ben Safdie, playing a mentally-challenged man who tries to free his brother from incarceration through a series of bank robberies and desperate escapes. The film, directed by the Safdie brothers, showcases Pattinson's range as he takes on a complex and troubled character. With its frenetic pace, dimly-lit scenes, and edgy score, "Good Time" is a genre-bending film that pushes viewers out of their comfort zones. Pattinson's performance proves he's moved beyond his "Twilight" status.

images.alt_text: To put it mildly, Good Time is a misleading and manipulative title. The film itself is a genre exercise aimed at pulling viewers out of their comfort zones - and in the Safdie brothers' grimly realistic world, the end more than justifies the means.

site_title: Sabana Reit appoints COO as acting CEO
summary: Sabana Reit appoints COO Aw Wei Been as acting CEO from January 1, 2018, while searching for a new CEO. Current CEO Kevin Xayaraj tendered his resignation in May after a unitholders' revolt. Aw, with over 20 years of experience, will oversee a smooth transition. The board of Sabana Reit's manager will provide updates on a CEO candidate once identified and approved by regulators.

site_title: Apple wins with US tax bill but concerns remain
summary: The US Republican tax overhaul passed by Congress will allow Apple to bring back its $252.3 billion foreign cash pile without a major tax hit. However, a provision could raise cash taxes on patents held abroad, potentially increasing the company's tax bill. The bill's minimum tax on foreign patent income is expected to be around 13%, and a tax break for patents held in the US will lower the tax on licencing income from 21% to 13.1%. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, has said the company intends to bring some overseas cash home, but the company declined to comment on the exact amount.

site_title: Twitter seeks business advertising dollars with live news, CEO tweets
summary: Twitter is launching a 24/7 news network, "TicToc by Bloomberg", to appeal to business users and compete with LinkedIn and Microsoft's professional online network. The service features live news updates and has seven initial sponsors, including AT&T and CME Group. The move aims to attract more advertising dollars to Twitter, which has struggled to turn its popularity into profit. Twitter's shares rose slightly on the news, and the company's CEO tweeted about the launch, further emphasizing the platform's focus on business users.

site_title: CCS seeks public feedback on ComfortDelGro-Uber deal
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is seeking public feedback on its proposed acquisition of a majority stake in Lion City Holdings from Uber Technologies. The deal, which would see Lion operate under joint control of ComfortDelGro and Uber, aims to combine their fleet resources and form a "uberFLASH" booking service. The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is conducting a public consultation from Dec 21 to Jan 8 to gather feedback on the proposed strategic alliance. The rental car market is considered extremely competitive, with multiple existing competitors preventing drivers from seeking alternative labor market opportunities.

site_title: Ryanair says formally recognises Irish pilots' union
summary: Ryanair has formally recognized the Irish pilots' union, Impact, after weeks of talks. The airline has submitted proposals on pay and conditions, and the two sides will meet on January 3 to hammer out a comprehensive recognition agreement. The union's president described the move as a "breakthrough" and said the danger of strikes by Irish pilots had receded for the time being. This comes after Ryanair offered to recognize trade unions and suspended strike action planned over the festive period.

site_title: Australia police don't suspect terrorism after car ploughs into pedestrians
summary: An Australian man of Afghan descent, with a history of mental health issues, drove a car into pedestrians in Melbourne, injuring 19 people, but police do not suspect terrorism. The incident occurred on Flinders Street, a major road in the city's central business district. The 32-year-old driver, who has a history of assault and drug use, was detained by police. Four of the injured were in critical condition, including a pre-school aged boy. Authorities say they have no evidence linking the attack to terrorism, with the incident not being terror-related.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hi-P International is expected to enter a phase of record revenues and improved earnings quality, driven by its key wireless customer and ramp-up of business with IoT customers and Procter & Gamble. The company's EPS CAGR is forecasted at 19% for FY18E-19E, with revenue growth expected at 15% per annum. Hi-P's selectively moved away from unprofitable assembly projects to focus on stable ones from blue-chip customers such as Apple and Keurig, improving returns on equity. The target price is set at S$2.11 based on FY17E P/B of 3.4 times.

site_title: Australia's Mineral Resources to buy AWE for A$526m
summary: Australian gas producer AWE accepted a takeover offer from Mineral Resources Ltd worth about A$526 million, trumping a Chinese state-owned firm's all-cash bid. The offer includes a cash component of A$0.83 per share, contingent on Mineral Resources shares averaging between A$15 and A$21 per share. The deal is expected to be voted on in April.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after US GDP data
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday after data showed the US economy grew at its fastest pace in over two years in the third quarter. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 64.55 points, or 0.26%, to 24,791.2, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Investors were optimistic about corporate tax cuts passed by Congress this week.

site_title: Wells Fargo, AT&T try to show how workers can gain from unpopular bill
summary: US CEOs, including Wells Fargo and AT&T, are attempting to shift public perception of the unpopular tax bill, claiming it will benefit the middle class. However, a majority of Americans believe it will primarily aid the wealthy. In a reversal, CEOs have started making specific promises about using savings from the reduced corporate tax rate to create jobs and invest in the country. The move is seen as an effort to sway public opinion and gain favor with President Trump.

site_title: Karin Technology forms JV with Hong Kong tech firm
summary: Karin Technology Holdings Limited has formed a joint-venture company with Masterson Technology Limited in Hong Kong, MasterKloud Technology Limited. Karin will hold 20% of the new company, offering cloud-related technology services and hosting cloud solutions for corporations and enterprise customers. The partnership aims to leverage expertise and offer comprehensive value-added solutions to corporate customers.

site_title: Short sellers target Asia's booming US dollar bond market
summary: Asian companies are flooding the US dollar bond market with record sales, attracting leveraged investors seeking yield. However, this growth has made the market more vulnerable to higher volatility, with traders experiencing high-profile meltdowns. Short selling, facilitated by banks and financial institutions buying securities on borrowed money, is improving market efficiency but also deepening the repo market, allowing for more trades that can profit from price drops. This shift threatens to disrupt the previously stable market.

site_title: India needs to strengthen RBI's independence: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommended that India strengthen the independence of its central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), and bolster resources for its financial system regulators to address a growing bad debt pile-up at public banks. Indian banks have high levels of debt, hindering fresh investments and growth. The IMF urged improving oversight, including RBI's independence and powers over public sector banks, and expanding financial regulators' resources.

site_title: Pacific Star gets approval for extension of time to hold AGM
summary: Pacific Star Development Limited has received approval from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority to extend its annual general meeting (AGM) to October 31, 2018, from its original deadline. The company had proposed changing its financial year-end to June 30 to align with its controlling shareholder, Chuan Hup Holdings Limited. This change will facilitate the consolidation of financial statements. The updated AGM date and venue will be announced in due course.

site_title: Indian court rejects Congress graft case that propelled Modi to power
summary: An Indian court has acquitted a former telecommunications minister, Andimuthu Raja, of corruption charges related to the sale of airwave licences in 2008, which federal investigators alleged cost the government $6.5 billion. The acquittal is seen as a blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party, which has capitalized on corruption charges against the previous Congress-led government. The verdict may prompt Modi to focus on other issues before the 2019 election, and could also impact the party's anti-corruption plank.

images.alt_text: Mr Raja's supporters celebrating in New Delhi after the hearing on Thursday. The lower court acquitted him on charges of corruption and cheating in the sale of airwave licences in 2008.

site_title: Consideration for ISR Capital's deal with REO Magnetic lowered
summary: ISR Capital's deal with REO Magnetic has seen its total consideration lowered to S$2.99 million from S$4.52 million due to a change in its issued share capital. The consideration price per share is now 0.4 Singapore cent, down from 0.67 Singapore cent, and the number of shares is adjusted to 747.26 million. This follows a conversion of S$1 million of convertible bonds into 250 million shares on December 6. The company will also be placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list due to failing to meet listing criteria.

site_title: US third-quarter economic growth fastest in more than 2 years
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest growth in over 2 years, expanding at a 3.2% annual rate in the third quarter. This growth was driven by robust business spending and tax cuts passed by Congress, which included slashing the corporate income tax rate to 21%. However, some economists caution that the growth pace may overstate the economy's health, and a more moderate boost is expected from the tax cuts.

site_title: Another robust year expected for Singapore bond market
summary: Singapore's bond market is expected to remain buoyant in 2018, driven by improving economic prospects, increasing spending, and funding needs. Economists forecast 3% growth in 2018, with the US also expected to grow faster than expected. Fixed income bankers expect robust issuance levels, with spreads and yields remaining competitive, particularly for high-grade issuers. Developers and banks are likely to be active issuers, while rising interest rates may have some impact on the market. The market has shown resilience, with blue-chip issuers performing well in 2017, and perpetuals being a popular instrument.

site_title: Trump administration proposes steep anti-subsidy duties on Canada's Bombardier
summary: The Trump administration has recommended imposing nearly 300% anti-subsidy duties on Canada's Bombardier Inc. for allegedly unfairly subsidizing its CSeries jets, allowing it to sell in the US market below cost. This move sets up the next round of a trade dispute between the US and Canada. The duties stem from a complaint by Boeing Co. that Bombardier received government support.

site_title: Nestle expects to sell US confectionery business in first quarter
summary: Nestle plans to sell its US confectionery business, including Butterfinger and BabyRuth, in the first quarter of 2018 following a strategic review launched earlier this year. The review, limited to the US market, aims to divest the business and a robust sale process is underway. The decision to sell comes as Nestle faces competition from other major confectionery companies in the US, including Mars, Hershey, and Mondelez International.

site_title: Police say car that hit pedestrians in Melbourne was a deliberate act
summary: A car deliberately plowed into pedestrians at a crowded intersection in Melbourne, injuring up to 15 people, police said it was a deliberate act. The driver and a second man were arrested. The incident bears similarities to recent attacks by militant groups worldwide. A pre-school child suffered a serious head injury, and two people were treated at the scene. This is the second incident of a similar nature in the area, with a January incident that killed four people and injured over 20.

site_title: Lufthansa wins EU nod for Air Berlin spoils
summary: Lufthansa has received EU approval for its scaled-back bid to acquire Air Berlin's assets, including the regional carrier LGW. The deal, which includes taking over 30 planes leased from other companies, was approved after Lufthansa accepted improved remedies to limit its impact on competition. The airline will also forgo some of Air Berlin's prized airport slots. The approval comes after the European Commission approved easyJet's purchase of Air Berlin's operations at Berlin's Tegel Airport. The move is part of Lufthansa's efforts to expand its operations in Europe.

site_title: EU and Mexico say they are "very close" to new free-trade deal
summary: The European Union and Mexico are "very close" to a new free-trade deal, with key issues such as agricultural access and geographical indications still to be resolved. The updated accord aims to cover industrial products, farm produce, government procurement, and investment, and is seen as a strategic move for Mexico to reduce its reliance on the US. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom and Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo both expressed optimism about the deal, with no deadline set but an outline agreement expected before the end of 2018.

site_title: GKE enters into JV for hazardous chemicals warehousing and logistics
summary: GKE Corporation has invested S$0.3 million in a joint venture, G-Chem Logistics Pte Ltd, for hazardous chemicals warehousing and logistics services. GKE holds a 65% stake, with Kleio One-Solution Pte Ltd holding 35%. G-Chem will operate from one of GKE's warehouse premises and pay a monthly management fee to GKE. This partnership aims to provide hazardous chemicals warehousing and logistics services for packed products and chemical drumming.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Sino Grandness incorporates new wholly-owned unit in China
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group Limited incorporated a wholly-owned subsidiary, Garden Fresh (Anhui) Fruit & Vegetable Beverage Co Ltd in Anhui, China, with a registered capital of RMB60 million (S$12.3 million). The transaction is funded internally and is expected to have no material impact on the company's earnings or net tangible asset value for the 2017 financial year.

site_title: Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac receive US$3b capital cushion
summary: The US regulator overseeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac reinstated a $3 billion capital cushion for each of the mortgage guarantors due to the imminent tax overhaul. The cushion will cover "ordinary income fluctuations" and help the enterprises cover a sharp drop in the corporate tax rate. Fannie and Freddie, still in government conservatorship, are expected to pay out quarterly dividends to the Treasury and may require additional government funds to cover the write-down of tax-deferred assets. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the tax overhaul on the two mortgage guarantors.

site_title: Club Med owner Fosun lured by Tsingtao beer guzzlers in China
summary: Fosun International is acquiring an 18% stake in Tsingtao Brewery for $847 million, expanding its presence in China's middle-class market. The deal allows Fosun to enhance Tsingtao's distribution network in over 70 Club Med resorts worldwide and potentially optimize efficiency. Fosun's investment strategy aligns with the Chinese government's push for local investments, and the acquisition is seen as a boost to the domestic economy. This marks Fosun's latest move in its consumer brand acquisition strategy, following previous deals in health care and financial assets.

site_title: UK's Prince Harry and fiancee Meghan Markle release engagement pictures
summary: Prince Harry and his American fiancee Meghan Markle released engagement pictures by photographer Alexi Lubomirski, taken at Frogmore House near Windsor Castle. The couple announced their engagement in November and plans to marry on May 19. Lubomirski described the photos as capturing the couple's happiness together. The announcement comes after Queen Elizabeth's 33-year-old grandson and Markle, 36, who stars in the US TV drama "Suits", got engaged.

site_title: Japfa to acquire remaining interest in dairy business for US$263m
summary: Japfa Ltd plans to acquire the remaining interest in its dairy business through the purchase of AustAsia shares from Black River Funds for US$263.1 million. Japfa currently holds 61.9% and 64.4% stakes in AustAsia's two subsidiaries, while Black River Funds owns 38.1% and 35.6% stakes respectively. The acquisition will bolster Japfa's profile, enabling it to focus on downstream capabilities and align AustAsia's objectives with its long-term strategic goal. The deal will be funded by bank borrowings and is expected to be approved by shareholders at an extraordinary general meeting in April 2018.

site_title: Japan-EU trade deal seen boosting Japan's GDP by 1% per yr over time
summary: Japan is expected to see a 1% annual boost to its GDP over 10-20 years following the implementation of a free trade deal with the European Union, according to a government estimate. The deal, set to take effect early 2019, is expected to lift Japan's GDP by 5 trillion yen (S$59.2 billion) per year and create 290,000 jobs. However, Japanese farmers may face losses due to reduced tariffs on food imports, which could lead to a 60-110 billion yen drop in domestic farm production.

site_title: Eliminating fraud will help restore faith in digital advertising
summary: Digital ad fraud has plagued the industry, with invalid traffic and fake clicks being bought and sold by bad actors. To eliminate this, publishers, ad tech companies, and verification vendors must change incentives that align them with fraudsters. Detection technology can identify fraudulent traffic, but it's not foolproof. A more effective approach is to use a Turing test-like method to distinguish human traffic from AI. Verification companies, like Google and AppNexus, can't end ad fraud due to the high cost of detection and the lack of punitive consequences. Industry-wide solutions, including proprietary anti-fraud solutions and boycotts of non-compliant publishers, are needed to hold the ecosystem accountable.

site_title: Sabana Reit appoints COO as acting CEO
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has appointed COO Aw Wei Been as acting CEO, effective January 1, 2018, following CEO Kevin Xayaraj's resignation amid a unitholders' revolt. Aw Wei Been, with over 20 years of real estate experience, will oversee the transition until a new CEO is identified and approved by regulators. The board will provide updates on the search for a new CEO.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Controlling unitholder to sell all shares in FSL Trust's sponsor
summary: The controlling unitholder of FSL Trust, Godan GMBH, is in discussions to sell all its shares in FSL Holdings, the sponsor of the shipping trust. This would result in a change in beneficial ownership of the sponsor and trustee-manager of FSL Trust. The trustee-manager views this as a positive development, expecting improved prospects for refinancing and/or extending the trust's indebtedness.

site_title: CDL sends out offer documents for M&C Hotels buyout; first close date is Jan 23, 2018
summary: CDL made a final cash offer of 620 pence (S$11.20) per share for M&C Hotels, with the first closing date set for Jan 23, 2018. CDL owns 65.2% of M&C, but needs 50% approval from remaining shareholders to close the deal. Minority shareholders, including International Value Advisers, MSD Partners, and Classic Fund Management, have criticized the "low-ball" offer, but CDL has refused to budge. The deal faces a risk of falling through, with these minority shareholders expected to reject the offer.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence rose to 94 points in the latest Nielsen survey, easing fears over the economy. Moody's reviewed Lippo Malls Retail Trust's rating for a possible downgrade to junk. Noble Group obtained an extension on a waiver for its revolving credit facility until May 18, 2018. The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on the acquisition of OldTown by Jacobs Douwe Egberts. Singapore shares closed down 0.36% on Thursday, marking a six-day losing streak.

site_title: Kobe Steel says senior executives knew about data tampering
summary: Kobe Steel, a Japanese steelmaker, admitted that senior executives were aware of data tampering in their copper and aluminum business, which affected around 500 customers worldwide. The company reassigned three senior officials and plans to complete its investigation by February. The scandal has thrown global supply chains into turmoil, with no safety issues identified. Kobe Steel has also faced Japanese government sanctions and a US Justice Department inquiry, with CEO Hiroya Kawasaki to decide his "ultimate management responsibility" after the investigation is completed.

site_title: EU clears merger of French aerospace suppliers Safran and Zodiac
summary: The European Commission cleared the merger of French aerospace suppliers Safran and Zodiac without conditions. The Commission found the increased market share to be very limited, and the merged group would not gain power over suppliers and customers. Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that competition in the aeronautics market in Europe will remain strong. The deal, valued at $7.7 billion, was aimed at boosting Safran's position in making connected aircraft for planemakers like Airbus and Boeing.

site_title: MAS issues 5-year bans on ex-trader convicted of CFD fraud
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) issued two 5-year prohibition orders against former DBS Vickers trader Dennis Tey, convicted of CFD fraud. Tey was banned from regulated trading and management, as well as providing financial advisory services. He was previously sentenced to 16 weeks' imprisonment for employing a scheme to defraud and unauthorized trading. Tey used manipulated CFD trades to profit from price fluctuations of underlying assets, causing a loss to the CFD providers and a total profit of S$30,239.

site_title: Singapore shares close down 0.36% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 12.34 points, or 0.36%, to 3,382.53 on Thursday, marking a six-day losing streak. The benchmark index saw 1.2 billion shares traded, worth S$808.5 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 202-198.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: China's airlines fly the world riding on 8.6b yuan subsidies
summary: China's airlines are set to become the world's largest aviation market in five years, thanks to government subsidies that allowed them to expand international services. Local governments spent 8.6 billion yuan (S$1.76 billion) on subsidies in 2016, mostly for direct flights to destinations like New York and Paris. However, several carriers have expressed concerns that the subsidies are unsustainable and have little positive economic impact on local economies. This has led to foreign airlines pulling out of smaller cities, citing unsatisfactory performance.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as US tax bill gets muted reception
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Thursday, mirroring US and Asian bourses, as investors reacted mutedly to the US Congress's approval of a tax overhaul. Analysts stated that US tax cuts were already factored into stock prices. Spain's IBEX and Germany's DAX declined, while the Paris CAC 40 fell 0.4%. The dip was attributed to regional election uncertainty in Spain and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo's main stock market closed lower on Thursday, following a decline on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.11% to 22,866.10, despite the Bank of Japan maintaining its ultra-loose monetary policy. This move was largely ignored by traders.

site_title: Samsung skepticism grows as two more analysts slash estimates
summary: Analysts at two firms, HI Investment & Securities Co and Korea Investment Holdings Co, cut their forecasts for Samsung Electronics' fourth-quarter operating profit, citing strong won and bonus payments. This is the sixth firm to lower its estimate in the past four weeks, fueling growing skepticism about the technology industry's gains. The news led to a 2.4% slump in Samsung's stock price, paring its year-to-date gain to 38%. The cuts come just weeks after Morgan Stanley analysts downgraded Samsung due to concerns over valuation, earnings growth, and the memory chip cycle.

site_title: UK's Brexit legislation to return to parliament on Jan 16
summary: The UK's European Union (Withdrawal) Bill will return to parliament on January 16 and 17 for further debate after Prime Minister Theresa May faced an embarrassing defeat last week. The bill has undergone several concessions to ease its passage through parliament. The bill's return to parliament comes as the UK's economy continues to face challenges, including a second consecutive month of shrinkage. The UK's economic woes come as the country navigates its Brexit process, which has been marked by political turmoil and uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on Beijing's pledges on reforms
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.45% on Thursday, driven by gains in mainland markets, following Beijing's pledge to deepen structural reforms and curb financial risks while maintaining steady economic growth in 2018. The Hang Seng index closed at 29,367.06, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises index rising 0.79%.

site_title: Nomura is said to suspend two junk-bond traders in London
summary: Nomura Holdings suspended two London-based junk-bond traders, Shaun Barlow and Jeremy Gosling, over concerns that some of the team's junk-bond positions may have been mispriced. The suspensions come amid Nomura's recent struggles with performance, including a 22% revenue slump in its European investment-bank unit. This follows the lender's decision to shut a proprietary trading unit in the UK and a weaker performance in fixed-income trading, similar to its biggest rivals. The suspensions are part of a broader effort to address so-called mismarking, or misrepresenting the true value of securities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.58 points to 1,751.21. The index saw 2.5 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 481 to 398.

site_title: India acquits ex-telco minister of corruption
summary: India's former telecoms minister A Raja has been acquitted of corruption charges in the 2008 "2G spectrum scam," which cost the state billions in lost revenue. A special court dropped charges against other bureaucrats and corporate executives implicated in the scandal, citing the prosecution's failure to prove allegations of criminality. The acquittal is seen as a major blow to the ruling Congress party, which was accused of under-pricing licenses and favoring certain firms. The verdict has been welcomed by some, including former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, but has also sparked calls for an appeal from the ruling BJP.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar tumbles to weakest level in nearly two years
summary: Hong Kong's dollar tumbled to its weakest level in nearly two years against the US dollar, reaching HK$7.8291 per US dollar on December 21, 2017. The currency declined 0.2% after the Hong Kong Monetary Authority indicated it wouldn't sell extra debt to support the currency. The widening gap between local and US interbank rates, fueled by the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase, contributed to the decline. The HKMA has issued additional Exchange Fund Bills to meet demand, but analysts suggest the moves may be aimed at narrowing the gap between rates.

site_title: Singapore competition panel to seek public feedback on acquisition of OldTown by Dutch peer
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on the proposed acquisition of OldTown by Dutch company Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE). JDE will acquire OldTown, a Malaysian coffee company, for RM3.18 per share, with the offer conditional on holding more than 50% of shares. As of Dec 18, 51.45% of OldTown shareholders have accepted the offer. JDE claims the acquisition won't result in a substantial lessening of competition in Singapore, citing the highly competitive local instant coffee and tea market. The public feedback period runs from Dec 21 to Jan 5, 2018.

images.alt_text: THE Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) will be gathering public feedback on the upcoming acquisition of Malaysian coffee company OldTown by Dutch tea and coffee giant Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) from Dec 21, 2017 to Jan 5, 2018.

site_title: Facebook ads that let employers target younger workers focus of US lawsuit
summary: US employers have been accused of age discrimination through Facebook ads targeting younger workers. The Communications Workers of America filed a lawsuit against companies including T-Mobile, Amazon, and Cox Communications, alleging they placed recruitment ads with age limits, limiting opportunities for older workers. Facebook is accused of engaging in age discrimination in its own recruitment efforts, despite claiming not to do so. The lawsuit seeks class action status and plans to add more defendants.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on negative ground; STI at 3,390.12
summary: Singapore shares ended Thursday's trading at 3,390.12, down 0.1% or 4.75 points, amid negative ground. The Straits Times Index fell 1.47% as 619.4 million shares worth S$360.1 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 171 to 164, with Allied Tech being the most actively traded counter, rising S$0.005 to S$0.073.

site_title: Japan govt raises assessment of output, capex as economy expands
summary: Japan's government raised its assessment of industrial production and capital expenditure, citing a strong external demand and booming earnings for Japan Inc. The economy expanded for the seventh straight quarter, with industrial output and capital expenditure "gradually expanding". The government also upgraded its view on exports, but downgraded its assessment of the housing sector. The positive outlook is seen as a sign that Japan's economy is on a recovery path, with the government set to approve a record budget for the 2018/19 fiscal year.

site_title: CCS seeks public feedback on proposed ComfortDelGro-Uber collaboration
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is holding a public consultation on ComfortDelGro's proposed acquisition of a majority stake in Lion City Holdings Pte Ltd from Uber Technologies Inc. The acquisition, if approved, will see Lion operate as a full-function joint venture under effective joint control of ComfortDelGro and Uber. A strategic alliance will also be formed, integrating Uber and ComfortDelGro's taxi smartphone mobile applications under the "uberFLASH" brand, covering booking services for meter-fared taxi services but not ComfortDelGro's core street hail business. The consultation runs from Dec 21 to Jan 8.

site_title: Wells Fargo, AT&T try to show unpopular tax cut helps workers
summary: Corporate America is trying to sway public opinion on the unpopular tax bill by announcing investments and bonuses. Companies such as Boeing, AT&T, Fifth Third Bancorp, and Wells Fargo have pledged to invest in employee training, infrastructure, and community programs. AT&T plans to give 200,000 workers a $1,000 bonus, while Fifth Third Bancorp raises its minimum hourly wage to $15 and distributes a $1,000 payout. However, critics argue that these efforts are insufficient to address concerns that the tax bill primarily benefits the wealthy, with only 24% of Americans supporting the plan.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks skid to near 3-month low on foreign sell-off, won edges down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 1.72% to a near 3-month low, closing at 2,429.83 points, due to foreign investors taking profits on market expectations of declining fourth-quarter profits. The Korean won also fell, and bond yields dropped, as investors shifted focus to the US following its tax cuts. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.16%, while the US dollar strengthened against the won, reaching a high for the year of 1,075.71 per US dollar on November 29.

site_title: Moody's reviewing Lippo Malls Retail Trust rating for possible downgrade to junk
summary: Moody's is reviewing Lippo Malls Retail Trust's rating for a possible downgrade to junk, citing deteriorating credit quality of key Lippo group entities that generate around one-third of the trust's revenue. The trust's "Baa3" rating, the lowest investment-grade rating, may lead to higher borrowing costs. Moody's expects LMIRT's financial metrics to weaken, making it vulnerable to foreign exchange rate fluctuations and asset devaluations, with a high refinancing risk in 2018. The review focuses on reducing exposure to the Lippo group and improving financial metrics to mitigate risks.

site_title: Russians, Chinese seek out Greek properties for bargains, visas
summary: Russian and Chinese investors are seeking bargains in Greek properties, particularly in Athens, due to the country's low prices and potential for a market rebound. The golden visa program, which offers residency and access to the European Union's passport-free Schengen area, is a major draw for international buyers. Prices in Greece have fallen by over 25% since the 2008 economic crisis, making it an attractive option for investors looking to buy and rent out properties to tourists or students. Several real estate companies, including Tranio.com and Juwai.com, are targeting Russian and Chinese buyers, with prices starting from €250,000 for a residence permit.

site_title: Surge in US shale hedging to boost drilling in 2018
summary: US shale producers significantly increased hedging in the third quarter of 2017, adding 144 million barrels of oil, amid rising oil prices. This surge in hedging is expected to propel the country to record crude production in 2018, potentially exceeding 10 million barrels per day. The increased hedging ratio for 2018 jumped to 27% from 12% in the same period last year, indicating a significant boost to drilling activities. This could lead to record-breaking production growth and potentially pressure oil prices in the near term.

site_title: iPhone supplier Murata boosting output of foldable circuits
summary: Murata Manufacturing, the exclusive supplier of foldable circuits for Apple's iPhone lineup, is boosting its production capacity to meet growing demand. The company's MetroCirc circuit boards, used in the iPhone X and 8 models, are being produced at full capacity, forcing Murata to turn away customers. This expansion aims to address the company's struggles to keep up with orders earlier this year, which led to a cut in its full-year profit outlook. The exact details of the planned expansion remain undisclosed.

site_title: Thai airport misery may last years as Chinese overwhelm upgrades
summary: Thailand's airports are facing years of misery due to an influx of Chinese tourists, which has strained infrastructure to capacity. The country is spending billions to upgrade its airports and image, but experts warn it may not keep up with soaring visitor numbers. Bangkok's two international airports are running at 40% beyond designed capacity, with new terminals and facilities expected to be completed by 2022. The government aims to reach 68 million foreign tourists by the end of the decade, but warns of potential delays and overcrowding.

site_title: HNA buying spree at risk as third deal in six months falters
summary: HNA Group's proposed acquisition of Australia & New Zealand Banking Group's asset-finance business has been rejected by New Zealand, marking the third deal in six months to falter. The conglomerate, struggling with debt, has several major purchases pending, including stakes in SkyBridge Capital and the owner of Brazil's busiest airport. HNA's shopping spree has left the company with $28 billion in short-term debt, prompting regulators to question the accuracy of its statements. This setback raises concerns about the company's ability to complete deals.

site_title: Deepest India bond rout in 17 years shows no sign of abating
summary: Indian bonds are experiencing their fastest decline in 17 years, with a yield on 10-year benchmark notes rising for a fifth consecutive month. Experts predict further increases, potentially reaching 7.5%, due to concerns over a widening fiscal deficit and rising inflation. A recent election victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party has sparked speculation about potential populist measures to boost economic growth ahead of the 2019 general election.

site_title: A decade after bubble, Spanish real estate a hot buy once more
summary: Spanish real estate is experiencing a resurgence, with investment in malls, warehouses, and offices projected to reach its highest level since 2007. Banks are clearing their balance sheets of foreclosed assets, making properties more attractive to foreign buyers. The Spanish economy is outpacing the rest of the continent, with a 3.1% growth forecast for this year, and a 20 million Spaniards in work by 2020 aims to boost consumer and business confidence, driving up rents and occupancy.

site_title: Fresh evidence leads to review of Singapore chicken suppliers' price-fixing case
summary: Singapore's Competition Commission is reviewing the case of 13 chicken suppliers accused of price-fixing after new evidence emerged. The suppliers, who supply over 90% of fresh chicken products, were previously accused of coordinating price increases and non-aggression pacts, restricting customer choices and creating a less competitive market. The review follows claims of leniency from the suppliers, who are seeking reduced penalties. The CCS initially found that the suppliers' actions restricted customer choice and reduced competition in the market for fresh chicken products in Singapore.

site_title: Apple wins big with US tax bill but faces snag on foreign patents
summary: Apple will benefit from the US Republican tax overhaul, allowing it to bring back its $252.3 billion foreign cash pile with minimal tax hit. The corporate tax rate has been reduced from 35% to 21%, a significant boon for the company. However, a provision in the bill may raise cash taxes on foreign patent profits, potentially offsetting some of Apple's tax savings. The company's ability to repatriate cash and reduce debt will be affected by the new tax rules.

site_title: Australia shares slip, weighed down by financial stocks; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.25% or 15.200 points to 6,060.400, snapping a three-day winning streak, due to a subdued Wall Street response to the US tax overhaul. Financial stocks, particularly the "Big Four" banks, declined 0.6-0.9%, while real estate stocks fell 1.9-2%. Miners, however, rose 1% on strong commodity prices, with BHP climbing 1.4% and Rio Tinto ticking up to a one-month high. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2% despite better-than-expected GDP data.

site_title: 'Wearable' computing a growing market: IDC
summary: IDC predicts the wearables market will nearly double from 113.2 million units this year to 222.3 million in 2021. Fitness-oriented wristbands will decline, while smart watches, led by Apple Watch, are expected to grow from 31.6 million to 71.5 million by 2021. Fashion brands and internet-connected watches will become more popular, and clothing will integrate computing smarts, such as earbuds and denim jackets with touch controls. IDC foresees a shift towards multi-functional wearables with health, fitness, communication, and productivity features.

site_title: Easing fears over economy lifts Singapore consumer confidence: Nielsen
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence has risen to 94 points, up five points from the previous quarter, according to Nielsen's global consumer confidence survey. Job security and economy were top concerns, but worries over these issues decreased in the third quarter. Excellent job prospects improved to 41% and spending on holidays increased to 53% of respondents. Meanwhile, 67% of Singaporeans saved for their golden years, placing the country fourth worldwide. The survey was conducted online from September 13-22 and included 502 respondents.

site_title: Japan fund managers increase stock exposure in December: poll
summary: Japanese fund managers increased their stock exposure to 49.7% in December, up from 37.7% in November, amid a strong global economic growth and upbeat corporate earnings. They lifted North American stock holdings to 35.5% and Japanese stocks to 48.8%, while reducing bond holdings to 42.9% from 56.9% in November. The fund managers attributed the shift to a steady footing in the equity market, with domestic manufacturers posting large profits.

site_title: Disney backs Fox's request for more data protection in antitrust trial
summary: Disney and 21st Century Fox have joined forces to request a stronger data protection order for their confidential information in the AT&T-Time Warner antitrust trial. The companies fear that AT&T executives could access their data during the trial, potentially compromising sensitive information. The trial is set to begin on March 19. The request is similar to one made by Fox previously, which sought to withhold certain information, specify who would access it, and bar lawyers from working on matters involving Fox without consent for two years.

site_title: Logistics firm Logos buys Tuas property for S$79m
summary: Logos, a logistics firm, has acquired a property in Tuas, Singapore for S$79 million to redevelop into a modern food processing and logistics facility. The 27,000 sqm facility will have five floors and is near key transportation hubs. Construction will begin immediately and completion is scheduled for early 2019. This is Logos' first food sector development in South-east Asia, with the company focusing on acquiring and developing modern logistics properties in Singapore. The acquisition brings the total fund commitments in Singapore to over S$800 million.

site_title: Bank of Japan maintains stimulus as inflation lags behind growth
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its stimulus, leaving interest rates and asset purchases unchanged, despite Japan's economy growing at a healthy pace. The decision was in line with predictions from 44 economists surveyed by Bloomberg, as inflation remains below the 2% target. The BOJ continues to target interest rates and buy financial assets to achieve its inflation goal, with some speculating that it may join international counterparts in tightening policy next year.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust completes US$753.8m joint acquisition of 14 data centres in US
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has completed a US$753.8 million joint acquisition of 14 data centers in the US, with MIT's investment totaling US$304.7 million. The acquisition was done through an unlisted single-purpose trust, Mapletree Redwood Data Centre Trust. MIT's sponsor, Mapletree Investments, funded the acquisition with US$750 million, minus estimated expenses of US$3.8 million. The trust manager used S$155.7 million from a private placement to partially fund the joint venture and acquisition.

site_title: Sweden won't fight for more power over Nordea's mega bank branch
summary: Sweden's financial regulator says giving national supervisors additional powers over bank branches, including systemically important ones like Nordea Bank, is bad policy. Deputy director general Martin Noreus stated that national regulators risk missing the big picture and that supervisors tend to focus too much on individual entities rather than the whole group. Instead, Sweden prefers a collaborative approach, such as colleges, where regulators from various countries coordinate supervision, with the home country taking the lead.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dipped 0.08% at the open on Thursday, following losses on Wall Street, as analysts say US tax cuts have already been priced into valuations. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,209.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Australia's Mineral Resources to buy AWE for A$526m
summary: Australia's Mineral Resources Ltd has accepted a takeover offer from AWE worth about A$526 million, trumping a Chinese state-owned firm's bid. AWE's board unanimously recommended the offer, which includes a cash component and a promise to pay AWE shareholders the equivalent of A$0.83 a share. The deal is expected to be more palatable to AWE investors and is seen as a good value for shareholders, driven by the company's undeveloped assets, particularly Waitsia, a 50% owned gas find considered Australia's best onshore conventional gas find in four decades.

site_title: Lufthansa eyes EU green light for Air Berlin spoils
summary: Lufthansa is seeking EU approval to acquire Air Berlin's LGW subsidiary, a regional carrier with 500 employees and 30 planes leased from other companies. The proposal, which includes taking over landing and takeoff slots, has been scaled back from its original 210 million-euro bid due to competition concerns. The European Commission is likely to give its green light on the deal, which would allow Lufthansa to expand its budget carrier Eurowings and potentially acquire more assets, including Alitalia's fleet.

images.alt_text: German carrier Lufthansa hopes to win EU approval Thursday to snap up a slice of bankrupt Air Berlin's operations, after competition concerns forced it to scale back its bid for the homegrown rival.

site_title: Most Singapore firms not treating climate change as financial risk: KPMG poll
summary: A KPMG survey found that 75% of Singapore's top 100 companies have yet to address climate change financial risks in their annual reports, despite 84% of the largest companies reporting on corporate responsibility. Only 17% of local firms have set carbon reduction targets, lower than the global rate of 50%. The survey highlights the need for Singapore companies to recognize climate change as a financial risk and integrate sustainability into their corporate strategy.

site_title: Short sellers target Asia's booming US dollar bond market
summary: Asian companies are selling record amounts of US dollar bonds, attracting investors desperate for yield. However, this growth has made it easier for short sellers to target the market, increasing volatility. The rise of financial institutions buying bonds on borrowed money has deepened the repo market, allowing short sellers to profit from price drops. This shift has left banks and brokerages with more notes to lend out, potentially shaking up the stable market. Short selling has improved market efficiency, but increased leverage poses risks.

site_title: AusGroup's COO of marine unit, CEO of engineering arm to leave company
summary: AusGroup announced the departure of two executives, James Stokes, COO of marine unit, and Simon High, CEO of engineering arm, effective Thursday. Stokes, 45, was appointed in 2016 and was responsible for operational activities, while High, 64, was appointed in 2016 and oversaw engineering services. There are no unresolved differences in opinion between the parties and the board, and no impact on the company's financial reporting is expected. The executives do not hold any shareholding interests in the company.

site_title: Indonesia wins Fitch rating upgrade months after S&P move
summary: Indonesia has received a second sovereign rating upgrade this year, with Fitch Ratings raising its assessment to the second-lowest investment grade, BBB with a stable outlook. The upgrade comes months after S&P Global Ratings lifted the nation out of junk status. Fitch cited Indonesia's resilience to shocks and economic stability as key drivers of the upgrade, which may support President Joko Widodo's $62 billion borrowing plan next year.

site_title: Saudi Aramco embarks on global hunt for natural gas supplies
summary: Saudi Aramco is searching for natural gas supplies globally to meet soaring domestic demand. The company, led by Chairman Khalid Al-Falih, is considering imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Russia, the US, and East Africa. Saudi Arabia relies on imported gas to power its electricity generation plants, particularly during peak air-conditioning season. Aramco is also exploring opportunities to expand its presence in the US through its Motiva subsidiary, potentially investing in petrochemical production. This move aims to cut the amount of crude oil burned in power stations and increase domestic gas reserves.

site_title: Investor takes stake in Rolling Stone, keeping on owner
summary: Media investor Jay Penske has acquired a controlling stake in Rolling Stone magazine, spending $100 million, with founder Jann Wenner preserving a role as editorial director. Wenner will step down as publisher, and his son Gus will remain president and COO. The deal aims to revive the magazine's financial health, with Penske praising Rolling Stone's cultural significance and globally recognized brand.

images.alt_text: Media investor Jay Penske on Wednesday announced a stake in Rolling Stone to revive the financial health of the iconic magazine of music and counterculture, with founder Jann Wenner preserving a role.

site_title: K-pop stars carry SHINee singer's coffin after suicide
summary: K-pop star Kim Jong Hyun, a member of the popular boy band SHINee, died by suicide, leaving behind a note about his battle with loneliness and depression. Six of his bandmates carried his coffin to a hearse in Seoul, where his body was taken to the Asan Medical Centre for a funeral. A procession was held, led by a fellow bandmate dressed in black with a crucifix bearing his name, reading "Kim Jong Hyun, believer". The cause of death has not been publicly disclosed.
