summary: Olam International has divested 50% of its stake in Far East Agri, its Indonesian sugar milling and refining unit, to Mitr Phol Sugar Corporation for US$100 million. The deal aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing demand for sugar and will enable Olam to focus on its core businesses. A green-field sugar milling facility will be developed in East Java, with the facility sourcing 1.2 million tonnes of cane from farmers by 2020. The transaction is expected to generate a one-time gain of US$80 million.

site_title: Kurz set to become Austrian chancellor, backed by nationalists
summary: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz is set to be inaugurated on Monday, backed by the nationalist Freedom Party, amidst protests over the new government. Kurz's conservative People's Party formed a deal with the Freedom Party, which has been met with smaller protests. The new government's program aims to reassure the EU and avoid major changes, while critics argue it is too timid. Kurz's cabinet, which includes 31-year-old inexperienced officials, has sparked concerns about the government's ability to govern effectively.

images.alt_text: Sebastian Kurz will become Austria's 14th postwar chancellor on Monday amid protests over his new government to be led by the conservative and nationalists.

site_title: Trump says he won't fire special counsel Mueller
summary: President Donald Trump stated he has no plans to fire special counsel Mueller, contradicting his team's recent attacks on the probe's credibility. Despite allegations of illegality, Mueller's office obtained emails from the General Services Administration (GSA) with the consent of the account owners or through criminal process. Trump's actions have led to speculation about the administration's intentions, with some calling for a new independent prosecutor to investigate anti-Trump bias.

site_title: Trump's tax cut bill will set tone for markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's tax cut bill is set to be voted on by the Senate this week, with Republican lawmakers and President Trump aiming to secure their first major legislative victory. The bill's progress is bolstered by the support of two wavering Republican senators, but it still faces opposition from three uncommitted senators. Investors are closely watching the bill's outcome, which may influence market trends, particularly in the US and regional markets.

site_title: Cityneon's unit partners S Korean firm for Marvel's exhibition
summary: Cityneon's US subsidiary has partnered with Fabulous Inc to create an interactive digital media signage for Marvel's Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N. exhibition in Las Vegas, with a five-year contract worth a minimum of US$15 million. Fabulous, a Seoul-based firm, has the option to renew the term for another five years. The project is part of Cityneon's efforts to expand its digital media business.

site_title: Uber struggles to make inroads in Japan
summary: Uber is struggling to gain traction in Japan, where risk-averse passengers prefer traditional taxi services. Despite having a large and wealthy market, Uber's attempts to enter the Japanese market have been met with resistance, including strict licensing requirements and safety concerns. The company has attempted to partner with taxi firms and launch pilot services, but has faced opposition from local authorities and the traditional taxi industry.

images.alt_text: There are 50,000 taxis in Tokyo alone - instantly recognisable with their impeccable polished exteriors and doors that open automatically to let customers board effortlessly.

site_title: Bitcoin and the art of market manipulation: an inquiry into value
summary: Bitcoin's price surge in 2017 was largely driven by speculation and hype, rather than its intrinsic value. Despite being up over 1,500% this year, the cryptocurrency's underlying value remains uncertain. The introduction of regulated bitcoin futures markets by the Chicago Board Options Exchange (Cboe) and CME Group aims to provide exposure to the asset while mitigating risks. However, concerns persist about market manipulation, with some exchanges lacking basic safeguards and being prone to opaque and potentially deceitful practices. The true value of bitcoin remains to be proven, with many experts warning of a potential dramatic setback in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Many of the platforms used by investors to buy and sell bitcoin are opaque and lack the basic safeguards expected of an exchange, meaning that the market is prone to manipulation, sometimes by the exchange operators themselves.

site_title: Titanic keeps that sinking feeling alive
summary: The film "Titanic" is celebrating its 20th anniversary, 2 decades since its release in 1997. The movie, directed by James Cameron, tells the story of the real-life sinking of the ship in 1912 and features a romance between Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet's characters. The film won 11 Oscars, including best picture and best director, and grossed over $2.2 billion worldwide, making it the most successful movie ever made at the time. The anniversary has been marked with screenings across the US, with audiences still swooning over the iconic love story.

site_title: Year ahead promises a buoyant global economy, uncertainty and confusion
summary: The year 2018 promises the highest economic growth in 10 years, with global business confidence surging despite uncertainty and challenges. The world is grappling with pressing issues, including de-escalating North Korean tensions, regional rivalries, and regulating the digital economy. Digitally fueled populism and nationalist sentiment are fuelling geopolitical drama. Leaders will face intense scrutiny, with governments moving to control data and cyberspace, and businesses navigating fierce competition and regulatory pressures. The year will test leadership and optimism, with a delicate balance between economic growth and stability required to address the complex challenges.

site_title: What Facebook's fight with a former executive says about social media's future
summary: Facebook, worth half a trillion dollars, has acknowledged the negative impact of its massive global platform, citing addictive nature and harming society. Former executive Chamath Palihapitiya softened his criticism after Facebook responded personally, but the company has since released a blog post addressing criticisms, stating it's working to promote users' well-being. The post cites research showing that passive social media use can lead to worse mental health, while more intimate interactions can improve well-being. Facebook is also changing its features to encourage healthier behaviors, such as demoting clickbait and false news.

site_title: Where wind farms meet coal country, there's enduring faith in Trump
summary: President Donald Trump's promise to make the US a dominant energy force in the world has a strong following in Wyoming's Converse County, where coal mining and uranium production coexist with wind farms. Locals believe his pledge will save their jobs. The county has rich energy resources, including the nation's third-largest coal mine and four big wind farms, which could benefit from Trump's energy policies. However, the article does not mention any specific outcome or consequence of Trump's promise.

images.alt_text: The coal-fired Dave Johnston Power Plant (above), outside Glenrock, is like a monument to the county's energy legacy. Its giant chimneys and plumes of smoke dominate the skyline by day, while at night it looks like a small city from the Rocky Mountain foothills nearby.

"I am not convinced on what has caused the change in climate. Doing a fix without finding a root cause? I don't see it . . . So why am I working in the wind industry? I'm not in it for that. I'm in it to produce more American energy, to make it more stable." - Wind farm technician Woody Ricker (above)

site_title: Ascott adds Africa to portfolio following S America addition in April
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence unit of CapitaLand, has entered Africa with the management of two properties in Accra, Ghana. This follows its expansion into South America in April, where it secured its first two franchise properties in São Paulo, Brazil. Ascott plans to open its 220-unit Ascott 1 Oxford Street Accra in phases from 2019 and its 40-unit Kwarleyz Residence in 2018. CEO Lee Chee Koon reaffirms confidence in reaching 80,000 units by 2020, despite the company's shift to an asset-light business model and plans to grow its franchise business through Quest Apartment Hotels.

site_title: Rebound in sight for silver after sell-down
summary: Silver is poised for a rebound after a brutal sell-down, with a near-term recovery likely following an oversold Relative Strength Index (RSI) reading of 25. Historically, mean reversion has resulted in a 12% recovery after the RSI moves above 30, with recent examples in May and July 2017 supporting this trend. The metal is currently near a critical support area of US$15.82-US$15.63, and a bullish engulfing bar after the FOMC meeting has moved the RSI above 30, signaling a stronger rebound is expected.

site_title: Europe's central bank faces decision time in 2018
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is entering the final stretch of his eight-year term, unveiling a more optimistic growth forecast and expressing confidence in the euro zone's inflation target of close to 2%. The ECB is expected to retire quantitative easing and face a debate on its next steps, with some predicting interest rates may remain unchanged for an extended period. A decision is likely to be made in the summer of 2018, which could impact the euro zone's economic outlook.

site_title: Boeing 747 to take its last US commercial flight on Tuesday
summary: The Boeing 747, the iconic "jumbo jet," will take its final US commercial flight on Tuesday on a Delta Air Lines route from Seoul to Detroit. The plane, which has been in service for nearly 50 years, will still be used by other airlines, including Lufthansa, British Airways, and Korean Air Lines. The 747, which can carry up to 600 passengers, was a game-changer in affordable mass market air travel and will be remembered as a symbol of economic power.

site_title: Chile's Pinera takes commanding lead in presidential vote
summary: Chile's conservative challenger Sebastian Pinera won the country's presidential election with 54.5% of the vote, a wider margin than expected. Pinera's campaign focused on ending his predecessor's progressive agenda and promoting economic growth, while his opponent Alejandro Guillier's center-left platform was seen as too extreme. The election marks a shift to the right in South America, with Pinera's victory seen as a referendum on outgoing President Michelle Bachelet's second term and a reflection of Chile's long-standing free-market economic model.

site_title: Disney-Fox transaction puts antitrust enforcers in bind over Trump ally
summary: The US$52 billion Disney-Fox deal has complicated the review process for US antitrust enforcers due to the close relationship between Disney and President Trump. Media mogul Rupert Murdoch, a friend and ally of Trump, would maintain control of the Fox News Channel, a major concern for regulators. The deal's structure, which allows Murdoch to maintain control of Fox News, may put enforcers in an awkward position as they review the transaction. The outcome could be a significant challenge to the government's efforts to enforce antitrust laws.

site_title: Chinese electric-car startup NIO prices debut model at 448,000 yuan
summary: Chinese electric-car startup NIO has launched sales of its first vehicle, the ES8 sports utility vehicle, at 448,000 yuan (S$91,376), undercutting Tesla's Model X price. The ES8 has a range of 500 km on a single charge and competes with BMW's petrol-powered X5. This marks three years since NIO was founded.

site_title: That US$300m chateau? One more jewel for a Saudi reformer
summary: A Saudi Arabian investor purchased the Chateau Louis XIV for over US$300 million in 2017. The luxury estate, known for its gold-leafed fountain, marble statues, and landscaped park, was previously considered the world's most expensive home. The buyer's identity was not publicly disclosed at the time of the sale.

site_title: Breaking in Seoul
summary: South Korea's breakdancing culture has been thriving for 15 years, originating from a visiting Korean-American hip-hop promoter who introduced the dance form to the country in the 1990s. The scene has become a global phenomenon, with Korean breakdancers showcasing their skills and style, often blending traditional Korean fashion with American hip-hop influences. Despite strict social norms, breakdancing has provided an outlet for self-expression and individuality, with many dancers making a living from the sport or teaching others. The South Korean government has even sponsored annual breakdancing tournaments and festivals, recognizing the cultural significance of the dance form.

site_title: Tencent-Yonghui deal sets up clash with Alibaba
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has acquired a 5% stake in Chinese supermarket chain Yonghui Superstores Co for about 4.22 billion yuan (S$860 million), setting up a potential clash with rival Alibaba Group Holding Ltd in physical retail. The deal may drive adoption of Tencent's digital payments service in stores, expanding its reach in the high-frequency purchase category. This follows Alibaba's US$2.9 billion purchase of a stake in grocery retailer Sun Art Retail Group Ltd, highlighting the e-commerce giant's efforts to overhaul the domestic brick-and-mortar retail industry.

site_title: Get crisis-ready by removing wind-down hurdles, EU banks told
summary: The Single Resolution Board (SRB) is urging European Union banks to simplify their corporate structures to make them easier to wind down in a crisis, reducing the risk of taxpayer bailouts. Head of the SRB, Elke Koenig, said that banks must be able to fund their own demise without government assistance. The SRB will adopt resolution plans for nearly all EU banks by 2018 and will identify "substantive impediments" to orderly wind-downs. Banks must respond within four months to address these issues, and the SRB may impose measures such as issuing loss-absorbing liabilities or selling assets.

site_title: What does the future HODL for bitcoin ETFs?
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is reviewing proposals for bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs), which could potentially increase investor access to the cryptocurrency. However, the SEC has previously rejected similar proposals due to concerns over bitcoin's volatility and lack of surveillance to detect fraudulent activity. The Winklevoss twins, who own a significant portion of bitcoin, may benefit financially if bitcoin ETFs take off. The first bitcoin ETF could hit the market as soon as 2018, potentially in a less regulated market.

site_title: Hatten Land unit mops up remaining stakes of firms that own sites in Malacca
summary: Hatten Land Limited, a Malaysian property developer, plans to acquire the remaining minority interests in two development sites in Malacca for about RM28.9 million (S$9.6 million). The company will develop both sites into a 'mixed development'. This acquisition is part of Hatten's strategy to expand its portfolio. The deal, which includes the allotment and issuance of new shares, is subject to shareholders' approval.

site_title: Unilever to sell its spreads business to KKR for 6.83b euros
summary: Unilever has agreed to sell its margarine and spreads business to US private equity firm KKR for 6.83 billion euros, aiming to focus on faster-growing products. The deal includes brands such as Becel, Flora, and Country Crock, and is expected to close in mid-2018. The move is part of Unilever's efforts to reshape its portfolio for long-term growth, following a review prompted by Kraft Heinz's unsolicited takeover attempt.

site_title: Big Data, bullet train drive India-Japan strategic ties ahead
summary: Japan and India are strengthening their strategic ties through a series of partnerships, including infrastructure projects and foreign investment. The two nations aim to counter China's growing regional influence and promote economic growth. Japan is pouring money into India, with lending for development increasing nearly sixfold since 2001, and foreign direct investment reaching $3.7 billion in 2016. The two countries are also working together on a $100 billion industrial corridor and a bullet train between Mumbai and Ahmedabad.

site_title: Google thinks I'm dead
summary: A journalist, Rachel Abrams, attempted to get Google to remove her photo from a biographical detail of someone else with her name after a search revealed her picture was inaccurately linked to a deceased writer. Abrams contacted Google's corporate communications team, but the process was cumbersome, with no customer service hotline and unclear feedback options. After multiple attempts, including submitting feedback from different IP addresses and enlisting the help of others, Abrams's photo was eventually removed. Google acknowledged the issue and promised to overhaul its process for making changes to the Knowledge Graph panel, which may help users in the future.

site_title: New Singapore record set for longest piano performance
summary: A record-breaking 13 hours of piano performance was achieved at the Piano Marathon 2017@ION Orchard in Singapore, raising nearly S$17,500 for charity. Over 120 musicians played more than 200 works at the event, which was organized by Steinway Gallery Singapore and co-organized with The RICE Company Limited. This marked the gallery's inaugural community engagement program and a significant charity fundraiser in Asia. The event supported The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, providing arts training to disadvantaged children and teenagers.

site_title: The stock market is more string than pearls
summary: The stock market is likened to life as a string of mundane moments, punctuated by rare and valuable opportunities. Investing in the market requires discipline and patience, as ordinary investors are more likely to make mediocre returns and be bored by the market's fluctuations. To improve chances, it's essential to educate oneself on how to read balance sheets, avoid debt-ridden companies, and study the market during periods of stagnation. A disciplined approach to saving and investing can help accumulate wealth over time, and the market's value lies in its rarity and unpredictability.

site_title: Cityneon unit partners South Korean firm for Marvel's exhibition in Las Vegas
summary: Cityneon's US subsidiary, Station-LV LLC, partnered with South Korean firm Fabulous Inc to create an interactive digital media signage for the Marvel's Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N. exhibition in Las Vegas. The five-year contract has a minimum guarantee of $15 million, with an option to renew for another five years. A deposit of $500,000 has been paid.

site_title: A look at corporate winners and losers in final US tax bill
summary: The US tax bill's impact on companies is expected to favor shareholders, with a cut in the corporate rate, increased deductions for capital spending, and lower levies on repatriating overseas profits. The final bill is expected to be voted on this week, with many predicting that the bulk of the gains will go to shareholders. The tax cuts are seen as a boon for companies, allowing them to retain cash and potentially invest in growth initiatives.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending December 17, 2017, shows a decline in tanker and dry bulk market rates. Transatlantic timecharter rates dropped to the low US$30,000s daily, while rates in the east remained steady. In the Atlantic, short duration mineral traders drove a spike in rates, but it was short-lived. The Panamax market reached a new high for the year, but slowed noticeably since then. The Handy sector was slow, with most Atlantic routes improving slightly but easing in the Pacific.

site_title: N Korean hackers behind attacks on cryptocurrency exchanges: Seoul newspaper
summary: North Korean hackers are behind attacks on cryptocurrency exchanges in South Korea, according to a report by South Korea's Chosun Ilbo newspaper. The hackers stole 7.6 billion won (approximately $9.43 million) worth of cryptocurrencies, which are now worth about 90 billion won. The attacks included leaking personal information from 36,000 accounts and demanding 6 billion won from Bitthumb in exchange for deleting the information. The National Intelligence Service (NIS) attributed the attacks to North Korean hackers, citing similarities in malware used in previous attacks, including Sony Pictures and the central bank of Bangladesh.

site_title: False paradise? EU is no haven of net neutrality, say critics
summary: The European Union, despite having the most robust net neutrality rules, is not immune to discriminatory practices by telecom firms and internet providers. Critics argue that EU regulations are lax, allowing providers to offer preferential pricing strategies, such as zero-rating, which can favor certain services over others. In Portugal, telecom provider MEO has been accused of splitting the internet into packages, offering attractively priced add-ons tied to popular apps, and denying preferential treatment to other app providers. EU regulators say the practice is not a significant threat to net neutrality, but critics claim it undermines the EU's digital market and creates a false playing field.

site_title: Matching jobs to the jobless key to locating US's missing workers
summary: The US economy is facing a growing mismatch between available jobs and workers with the right skills. Despite a strong job market with over 175,000 new jobs created per month, companies struggle to fill openings, with 6.2 million unfilled jobs nationwide. Innovative programs, such as the West Philadelphia Skills Initiative, are emerging to address this issue by providing workers with specific skills in demand. These programs have shown promising results, with a 90% hire rate and 25% higher retention rate compared to traditional training programs, helping workers like Derek Hobbs find employment and reintegrate into the workforce.

site_title: Trade in goods, services features in tough Brexit negotiations
summary: The UK and EU are in challenging trade negotiations 18 months after the Brexit referendum. Phase one negotiations have been signed off, but official trade talks won't begin until March. British Prime Minister Theresa May wants Britain to leave the EU's single market and customs union, which could harm the financial sector. The EU warns of "huge" economic consequences, while the UK's services trade surplus with the EU is significant, with a surplus of £16 billion in 2016. Brexitiers believe the EU needs Britain more than the other way around.

site_title: STI rebounds; director acquisition to disposal ratio at four to one
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.4% over five trading sessions, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for the year to 23.0%. Fifteen stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$13.3 million, with OCBC and Bumitama Agri leading the list. Meanwhile, 55 SGX-listed companies reported changes in director interests or substantial shareholders, with 37 director acquisitions and nine disposals. Key acquisitions include Viva Industrial Trust's sale of securities by China Enterprises Limited, and DBS Group Holdings' purchase of shares by independent director Nihal Kaviratne.

site_title: China lavishes aid on Pakistan town in bid to extend maritime reach
summary: China is providing extensive aid to the Pakistani town of Gwadar, including a school, doctors, and over $500 million in grants for an airport, hospital, and college. The move is seen as a bid to win over locals and build a commercial deep-water port that could serve the Chinese navy. The port, which is part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, is strategically located near key oil and gas shipping lanes. The US and India have expressed concerns about the port's potential to serve the Chinese navy, fueling regional tensions.

images.alt_text: Gwadar is a dusty town overlooking some of the world's busiest oil and gas shipping lanes. Analysts say China is aware that previous efforts to develop Gwadar port failed partly due to the security threat posed by Baloch separatists.

Gwadar is a dusty town overlooking some of the world's busiest oil and gas shipping lanes. Analysts say China is aware that previous efforts to develop Gwadar port failed partly due to the security threat posed by Baloch separatists.

site_title: After Equifax breach, a bank pushes credit file freezes
summary: Umpqua Bank, a Portland-based financial institution, has launched "Freeze Day" to encourage employees and customers to freeze their credit files in response to the Equifax breach, which exposed the personal data of 145 million Americans. The bank assembled a team to help workers initiate credit freezes and encouraged customers to do the same. The move aims to protect customers from identity theft and credit fraud. Unlike some credit reporting industry executives who have opposed freezes, Umpqua Bank's CEO, Cort O'Haver, supports the concept, calling it the "right thing to do" to protect customers.

site_title: In Kashmir, Pakistan and India race to tap the Himalayas
summary: Pakistan and India are racing to complete hydroelectric projects along the Neelum River in Kashmir, fueling tensions between the two arch-rivals. Thousands of labourers are working underground on a massive project, with both countries nearing completion. Pakistan is concerned that its downstream project will be deprived of water by India, exacerbating the dispute over Kashmir's freshwater supplies. The situation has heightened tensions between the two nations, with both countries competing for control over the region's dwindling water resources.

site_title: Asti's exclusivity deal with China Fortune-Tech Capital expires
summary: Asti Holdings Limited's two-month exclusivity period with China Fortune-Tech Capital Co (CFTC) to divest the STI Group has expired. The exclusivity period, which was extended from Oct 28 to Dec 15, 2017, ended on Dec 15. Asti may now engage in discussions with third parties. The proposed deal, valued between S$105 million and S$115 million, is subject to conditions and negotiations.

site_title: Novel cancer drug stymied by rigid billing system
summary: A US government reimbursement system is partly to blame for the slow uptake of the novel cancer therapy Yescarta, which costs $373,000 and has no billing code in Medicare. Only a handful of patients have received the therapy two months after its approval, while waiting lists have risen to the hundreds at cancer centers authorized to administer the treatment. The issue is that Medicare is not allowed to negotiate prices, and the agency's billing code update process is slow, making it difficult for hospitals to cover the costs.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit rides positive office market dynamics
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit, a US-focused office real estate investment trust, has seen positive office market dynamics. The Reit has an initial portfolio of 11 freehold office properties in seven key growth markets in the US, with a high committed occupancy rate of 90% and stable lease expiry profile. CEO David Snyder attributes the Reit's success to its adaptable leadership style and focus on key growth markets where economic, employment, and population expansion patterns are trending above the national average. The Reit offers a 6.8% distribution yield and is expected to grow its distribution yield by 5.8% in 2019.

site_title: Japan eyes 5.19t yen defence budget to counter N Korea: report
summary: Japan is planning a record 5.19 trillion yen (S$62 billion) defense budget for the next fiscal year to counter the threat of North Korea's nuclear and missile development. This marks the sixth consecutive year of increases in defense outlays, with much of the funding going towards protecting Japan from North Korea's threats. The budget will also cover preparations for the US military's Aegis Ashore land-based missile interceptor system.

site_title: Russia hit by US$3.4b Promsvyazbank bailout in latest bank blow
summary: Russia's central bank may need to provide up to $3.4 billion in a bailout for Promsvyazbank (PSB), the country's 10th largest private lender, following the third rescue this year. The bank's serious difficulties stem from a prolonged period of non-performing loans and excessive loans to its owners. The central bank plans to honour most PSB obligations, except for subordinated debt, and will send in temporary administrators to support the bank's liquidity. The bailout comes as Russia grapples with the economic impact of lower oil prices and Western sanctions.

site_title: Asti Holdings' exclusivity period for term sheet with China Fortune-Tech Capital expires
summary: Asti Holdings Limited's exclusivity period with China Fortune-Tech Capital Co (CFTC) for the potential divestment of the STI Group has expired. The two-month exclusivity period, which was granted after signing a non-binding term sheet on August 29, 2017, ended on December 15, 2017. Asti Holdings may now enter into discussions with third parties. The proposed deal, valued between S$105 million and S$115 million, was subject to certain conditions and negotiations were ongoing.

site_title: SS Teo wants to keep the "street fighter" spirit in PIL
summary: SS Teo, CEO of Pacific International Lines (PIL), describes his company as a "street fighter" in the shipping industry, maintaining its independence from vessel-sharing alliances while achieving the 9th largest capacity globally. PIL has successfully operated in Africa and Oceania, and recently broke into China, benefiting from its long-established trade ties. The company's flexibility and network have allowed it to thrive in challenging markets. Teo's focus is on bolstering connectivity between Western China and South-east Asia, with projects such as the Singapore-Guangxi Integrated Logistics Park.

site_title: India raises tariffs on electronics to curb imports
summary: India has increased customs duty on electronics, including mobile phones and TVs, to curb imports and boost local manufacturing. The duty on mobiles and TVs was raised to 15% from 10%, while digital cameras, video cameras, and projectors saw a 20% increase. This move aims to reduce India's current account deficit and support Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'Make in India' initiative, which seeks to boost domestic production and contain India's trade deficit with China. The move also aims to protect domestic industries from competition from cheaper imports.

site_title: Hatten Land unit acquires remaining minority interests in two Malacca development sites
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysian property developer, is acquiring the remaining minority interests in two development sites in Malacca for RM28.9 million (S$9.6 million). The acquisition involves the purchase of 15% of Rico Development Sdn Bhd and 25% of Rico Ventures Sdn Bhd from Tan Ping Huang Edwin. This move follows Hatten's previous acquisition of 85% stake in RDSB and 75% stake in RVSB for RM46.8 million and RM61.9 million, respectively. The deal is expected to be approved at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Band Boys
summary: Singaporean band The Silver Strings, formed in 1964, achieved significant success in the 1960s with hits like "You're the Boy" and performed alongside The Rolling Stones. The band's music was featured in a 2017 article about the band's influential 1961 concert in Singapore. After disbanding in 1971, the band reunited in 2008 and has since performed at various events, including the upcoming Rock N Roll Music Festival on December 23.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Markets in 'rational exuberance' but risks lie ahead
summary: US stocks rose to record highs last week, with traders betting on massive tax cuts stimulating economic growth. A compromise tax reform bill has been agreed upon, slashing corporate taxes and reducing middle-income family obligations. Federal Reserve officials upgraded their 2018 growth projections, citing the implications of the tax bill. Analysts at Goldman Sachs and Bank of America Merrill Lynch describe the stock market as "rational exuberance," but warn of risks, including geopolitical developments and technological disruptions, that could lead to a market correction.

images.alt_text: Most Wall Street brokerages agree that the Republican government's tax and economic policies and the momentum of global economic growth will probably set the stage for more market gains.

site_title: Inner Glow
summary: Fujifilm's beauty brand Astalift has released Christmas sets of collagen products, including a peach-flavored drink with 10,000mg of high-purity collagen, priced from S$11.90 to S$55. The products are available at Fujifilm's stores in Nex, Wisma Atria, and JEM shopping centers.

site_title: Sealed Air aims to beef up R&D efforts in Singapore
summary: Sealed Air Corporation plans to increase its research and development (R&D) efforts in Singapore over the next two years as part of its expansion into the Asian market. The company, known for inventing bubble wrap, acquired a polyethylene foam maker in Singapore for around US$100 million, which included a small R&D center. This move aims to boost innovation and growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Mr Pesonen says that the focus for R&D would be on boosting headcount and capabilities.

site_title: Diamond Energy first to offer electricity demand response
summary: Singapore's electricity sector took a step forward towards a balanced grid as Diamond Energy obtained approval to manage demand response capacity from wholesale electricity market operator Energy Market Company (EMC). This is the first time a retailer has been registered for this in the country, following the introduction of demand response by the Energy Market Authority (EMA) in 2016.

images.alt_text: Diamond Energy has an initial capacity of 7.2MW registered with the National Electricity Market of Singapore, says Mr Kay.

site_title: UK watchdog to take closer look at initial coin offerings
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) plans to increase scrutiny of initial coin offerings (ICOs) to protect investors, following a £3.7 billion market raise this year. The watchdog has issued an alert on contracts for differences (CFDs) trades linked to digital currencies, citing concerns over potential harm to retail consumers. The FCA will gather evidence to determine if new rules are needed, and has expressed support for EU-wide product intervention to restrict CFDs and binary options.

site_title: Sunac China plans HK$7.82b share sale for working capital
summary: Sunac China Holdings Ltd plans to sell HK$7.82 billion worth of new shares to its major shareholder, chairman Sun Hongbin's Sunac International Investment Holdings Ltd, at HK$31.1 per share. This is the second share placement in five months, as the company aims to slash its debt ratio to 70% by 2019. The proceeds will be used for general working capital, and the sale will not impact the company's debt ratio.

site_title: Hamburger chain Wendy's to reduce antibiotic use in beef supply
summary: Wendy's, the world's third-largest quick-service hamburger chain, plans to reduce the use of antibiotics in its beef supply by buying 15% of its beef from producers that have pledged to reduce Tylosin use by 20%. The company aims to increase beef purchases from these producers and others. This move follows the company's removal of antibiotics from its chicken supply in 2017 and comes as the World Health Organization recommends that meat producers end routine antibiotic use in food production.

site_title: P&G names activist Nelson Peltz to board after proxy battle
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has named activist investor Nelson Peltz to its board after a contentious proxy battle. Peltz, a founding partner of Trian Fund Management, won a seat on the board by a margin of 0.0016% after an initial declaration of victory by the company. P&G also named Novartis CEO Joseph Jimenez to the board, increasing the board size to 13 from 11. Peltz had sought to expand the board to make room for former Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo, who was initially targeted for replacement.

site_title: N Korea must 'earn its way back to table,' Tillerson tells UN
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson told the UN Security Council that North Korea must "earn its way back to the table" for negotiations to end the nuclear stand-off, backing away from earlier unconditional talks. The US has called for a "sustained cessation of North Korea's threatening behavior" before talks can begin, amid pressure from the White House to toughen its stance. The US also urged China and Russia to take unilateral steps to pressure North Korea, as the country continues to carry out nuclear tests and missile launches.

site_title: Nafta Washington talks said to leave major differences untouched
summary: US-Nafta negotiators made some progress on less contentious issues, including energy efficiency standards, but left major differences on autos, dispute settlement, and an expiry clause to be addressed in January's Montreal talks. The US has proposed sharply higher regional content for North American-made vehicles, which Canada and Mexico rejected as unworkable. The talks concluded with no major breakthroughs, and officials warn that the US may withdraw from Nafta if its demands are not met, potentially creating uncertainty for companies and leading to legal challenges.

site_title: Film about poor kids at Disney's gates is fairy tale hit
summary: A low-budget film, "The Florida Project," has become a surprise hit, garnering prizes from US critics and making the lists for best film of the year. Directed by Sean Baker, the film tells the story of homeless children living in the shadow of Walt Disney World in Florida. The film's lead actors, Bria Vinaite and Brooklynn Prince, have received praise for their performances, with Prince being tipped for an Oscar nod for best supporting actress. The film's gritty yet heartwarming portrayal of poverty has resonated with audiences, and its authentic feel has been praised for its subtlety of storytelling.

site_title: May wins Brexit boost, but bigger battles await
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has secured a Brexit deal with the EU after an 11th-hour agreement with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker. The EU's decision to move to the next stage of negotiations with Britain was seen as a much-needed success for May, who has been dogged by doubts since a disastrous snap election in June. However, key issues remain unresolved, and Britain has yet to set out what it wants from the future relationship with the European Union, setting up a potentially challenging phase in the Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) has entered into a 50:50 joint venture with Frasers Centrepoint Limited to acquire Farnborough Business Park in the UK for £174.6 million, a slight discount to the property's valuation. The acquisition is expected to be accretive, with pro forma distribution per unit (DPU) increasing by 1.6% to 9.97 cents. Meanwhile, Suntec Reit is upgraded to "Buy" by DBS Group Research, citing the potential for a turnaround under new CEO Chan Kong Leong and the possibility of privatization by sponsor ARA Asset Management.

site_title: In first, SpaceX launches recycled rocket and spaceship
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a recycled rocket and cargo ship, marking a significant step towards lowering the cost of spaceflight. The Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon spacecraft, both previously flown, soared into the sky and landed safely on solid ground at Cape Canaveral, Florida. This is the first time a reusable rocket has been launched by NASA, with the mission deemed "equivalent risk" to new components. The Dragon is carrying 4,800 pounds of supplies and experiments, including those for studying thyroid cancer and growing barley in space.

site_title: Gold heads to first weekly gain in 4 weeks after Fed rate hike
summary: Gold prices rose for the first weekly gain in four weeks, up 0.6% to $1,255.12 per ounce, following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The Fed's decision to keep its outlook for three rate rises next year unchanged and downplay the impact of proposed US tax cuts helped support gold prices. Weak US inflation also contributed to the gold rally, which was also boosted by demand in Asia and a decline in the US dollar.

site_title: Dow, Nasdaq hit records as US tax cut plan advances
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.6% to 24,651.74, the S&P 500 gaining 0.9% to 2,675.81, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.2% to 6,936.58. The records follow key congressional holdouts signaling support for a US tax cut proposal, which has been tweaked to benefit middle- and low-income taxpayers. The bill has progressed in Congress without Democratic support, despite concerns about its impact on the deficit.

site_title: Oil hovers below 2-year highs with focus on US output
summary: Oil prices remained below two-year highs on Friday, with Brent crude futures settling at $63.23 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures at $57.30 a barrel. The North Sea pipeline outage provided support, while US climbing output and weak gasoline demand limited gains. WTI reached a two-year high of $59.05 on November 24. The prices ended the week slightly down, with Brent falling 0.3% and WTI 0.1%.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to increase fare categories, tweak seat booking, mileage accrual and baggage allowances from Jan 20
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and regional carrier SilkAir will introduce a new fare pricing structure on January 20, 2023, to boost traffic and maximize revenues amid intensifying competition. The changes include a "lite" fare class, revised seat booking, and mileage accrual rates, as well as updated baggage allowances and change and refund flexibility. The new structure aims to attract price-sensitive passengers and capture lost revenue from empty seats.

images.alt_text: Aside from the lite category, SIA's Economy Class will have two other fare types - standard and the highest category, flexi.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia's Eco World acquires 70% in UK sites
summary: Malaysia's Eco World International Bhd acquired a 70% stake in 12 UK sites for £64.9 million, becoming joint development manager with its British partner. The acquisition will be done in two stages and will help Eco World establish a footprint in Britain's build-to-rent subsector. The company plans to fund the acquisition through initial public offering proceeds and borrowings, despite Brexit uncertainty, citing improving sales momentum.

site_title: US dollar index firmer as volumes thin ahead of holidays
summary: The US dollar rose 0.49% to 93.944 against a basket of six major currencies, driven by expectations that the Republican tax overhaul bill will be passed by year-end. The bill's passage is seen as boosting US growth, leading to more interest rate hikes and a higher US dollar. Thin trading volumes ahead of the Christmas and New Year holidays contributed to the dollar's firmer tone. Financial institutions are scrambling to secure funding, leading to a surge in short-term dollar borrowing costs, which could potentially impact the dollar.

site_title: GOP tax plan sets higher rate than expected on offshore earnings
summary: The US GOP tax bill has set a higher top tax rate of 15.5% on offshore earnings, exceeding President Donald Trump's initial target of 10%. This rate applies to an estimated $3.1 trillion in offshore profits, generating approximately $40 billion in revenue. Companies are expected to repatriate their earnings, shifting them from the 35% deferral rate under current law. The higher rate is expected to lead to companies seeking ways to move their cash into the lower 8% tax bracket, though this rate is also considered high.

images.alt_text: The top tax rate that US companies would pay on an estimated US$3.1 trillion in earnings they've stockpiled overseas crept up to 15.5 per cent in the final version of the GOP tax bill released Friday.

site_title: Australia PM, defending slim majority, faces by-election test
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government faces a crucial by-election test in the Sydney seat of Bennelong, where a former tennis star and Liberal MP, John Alexander, is defending his seat against Labor's Kristina Keneally. The by-election was triggered by a constitutional crisis over dual citizenship, which could lead to the government losing its slim majority. If Keneally wins, Labor could defeat the government in parliamentary votes, potentially toppling Turnbull's coalition. The outcome is seen as a key indicator of the government's stability and ability to address falling voter support and internal division.

site_title: TMC Education surges after Fragrance CEO launches takeover bid
summary: TMC Education Corporation Ltd saw its shares surge 120% on Friday after Fragrance Group CEO Koh Wee Meng launched a takeover bid. Koh purchased 85 million shares at S$0.0675 apiece, representing a 69% premium over the stock's last traded price. The offer does not intend to change the company's business, and Koh plans to retain the Catalist listing status.

site_title: Toll rises to two dead after Indonesia quake
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Java island, killing at least two people, a 62-year-old man and an 80-year-old woman, when buildings they were in collapsed. Several hospitals were damaged, and patients were evacuated. At least 100 houses were damaged across West and Central Java provinces. The quake was felt across the island, including in the capital Jakarta, and Indonesia experiences frequent seismic activity due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

images.alt_text: A strong 6.5-magnitude earthquake rocked Indonesia's main island of Java late Friday, leaving at least one person dead and rattling nerves in the capital Jakarta.

site_title: Beijing unveils Winter Olympics emblems with fanfare
summary: Beijing unveiled the emblems for the 2022 Winter Olympics and Paralympics, inspired by Chinese calligraphy, in a star-studded ceremony. The emblems, featuring bold brushstrokes resembling a skier and the Chinese character for "winter", were chosen from 4,500 entries. Beijing will become the first city to host both summer and winter Olympics, with the country aiming to increase its winter sports facilities and participation from 6 million to 300 million. The emblems are meant to represent "a pursuit of excellence" and will be used to promote the games.

site_title: Catch 'Em If You Can
summary: Vacheron Constantin unveiled limited edition timepieces, including the Traditionnelle Complete Calendar Collection Excellence Platine and the Royal Oak Offshore 25th Anniversary. Audemars Piguet also released new versions of the Royal Oak Offshore Tourbillon Chronograph. Other luxury watch brands, such as Graham, Richard Mille, Girard-Perregaux, and Chronomètre Ferdinand Berthoud, showcased unique and festive designs. The watches, each with unique features and complications, are available in limited quantities, making them exclusive collector's items.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: H&M leads European shares lower after sales miss, banks stumble
summary: European shares fell on Friday, weighed down by a disappointing trading update from H&M and weakness in the banking sector. The Stoxx 600 lost 0.2% and posted a 0.3% weekly decline, with H&M plummeting 13% and Ferragamo falling 6.3% after setting uncertain targets. Banks, including Societe Generale and HSBC, also fell, while shares of Belgian biotech Galapagos rose 8.9% after announcing a partnership with Gilead.

site_title: On the trail of London's serial cat killer
summary: A serial cat killer has struck in London, with over 400 suspected victims identified in the past two years, mostly cats but also foxes and rabbits. The killer, dubbed the "Croydon Cat Ripper," has been targeting domestic cats, mutilating their bodies and leaving them in public places. Police, including Scotland Yard and the National Crime Agency, are investigating, with a £5,000 reward offered for information leading to the killer's capture. Experts believe the killer may be a white man in his 40s, skilled and methodical, and potentially escalating their crimes to humans.

site_title: New Yorkers plead guilty to 'movie-like' bank heists
summary: Four New Yorkers, Michael Mazzara, Charles Kerrigan, Anthony Mascuzzio, and Christopher Kerrigan, pleaded guilty to blowing their way into bank vaults in Brooklyn and Queens, stealing over $5 million in cash, jewelry, and collectibles. Using blow torches, they broke into HSBC and Maspeth Federal Savings Bank, hiding their crimes by building a plywood shed in Queens. The burglaries, likened to a Hollywood movie, were described as "well-organized" and "meticulous" by the acting Manhattan US attorney. The defendants face years in prison and will be sentenced next year.

site_title: StarHub to fork out S$122m for Singapore cryptography, digital security firm
summary: StarHub has agreed to acquire Singapore-based cryptography and digital security firm D'Crypt Pte Ltd for up to S$122 million. The acquisition aims to enhance StarHub's capabilities in enterprise solutions, cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things. D'Crypt produces solutions in encrypted communications and high-performance computing, with a notable project behind Singapore's Electronic Road Pricing In-Vehicle Unit. The deal will give StarHub access to a world-class engineering team and expand its enterprise solutions business segment.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Resort Edit
summary: Resort 2018 fashion trends have arrived, with key essentials including the belt's return, easy trousers, oversized blazers, gold hoop earrings, track pants, corporate denim, off-shoulder coats, and kitten heel pumps. These wearable pieces, showcased by top designers like Chanel and Gucci, remain in stores for up to six months, making them perfect for the holiday season or everyday wear. Mixing and matching these trends with timeless staples can create a chic and versatile wardrobe.

site_title: Kia Sorento GT Line review: Uplifting the Seoul
summary: The Kia Sorento GT Line has undergone a facelift, but its Korean origins may still influence perceptions of its quality. The SUV boasts a luxurious interior with features such as a redesigned steering wheel and instrument cluster, as well as an eight-speed automatic transmission made in-house by Hyundai and Kia. The car feels like a product of dedicated engineers, with clever features like adaptive cabin lighting and a Smart driving mode. However, it lacks an enjoyable driving experience and has a gruff diesel engine voice. Despite this, the Sorento is a well-equipped and spacious SUV at an affordable price, rivaling luxury brands like BMW.

site_title: Sales of new homes moderate as yr-end holidays begin
summary: Sales of new homes in Singapore have moderated as the year-end holiday period approaches, with developers focusing on selling existing units rather than launching new ones. In November, only 47 new units were released from previously launched projects, a 76.7% drop from the previous month. Despite a 39% increase in sales from January to November compared to the same period in 2016, the market is showing signs of slowing down. The festive period is expected to continue the trend, with buyers facing reduced options.

site_title: Fed rate hike: no surprise can be a good thing
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the third rate increase this year and the fifth in the normalization cycle, indicating a strong US economy with a solid job market. Fed Chair Janet Yellen expressed optimism for 2018, revising economic growth projections upwards to 2.5% and expecting a jobless rate of 3.9%. The rate hike was seen as "dovish" and did not raise expectations for future interest rate increases, with markets focusing on soft inflation numbers and the ongoing recovery in activity.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: The Rise Of Responsible Consumerism
summary: Singapore's love for shopping has led to environmental issues, despite economic benefits. The country ranked top online shoppers in South-east Asia in 2014. Waste disposal increased to 3.05 million tonnes in 2016, with half coming from food, paper, and textile waste. Households account for over half of the waste, and the domestic recycling rate remains low at 19-21%. The Semakau Landfill is projected to be filled by 2035 if current waste disposal rates continue. The allure of shopping, exemplified by the Great Singapore Sale, has contributed to the country's waste problem.

site_title: Japan expands sanctions aimed at N Korea
summary: Japan has added 19 more entities to its list of organizations and individuals targeted by asset-freeze sanctions on North Korea, bringing the total to 103 entities and 108 individuals. The sanctions target those involved in financial services, coal and minerals trading, transportation, and sending North Korean laborers abroad. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that international sanctions, including a reduction in oil-product imports, are having an impact on North Korea and urged the international community to continue applying pressure until the country changes its policies and seeks negotiations.

site_title: Festive Spice
summary: The one Michelin-starred restaurant Song of India offers a unique Christmas capon dish, the Tandoori Capon, stuffed with Morel Briyani for $68. The large chicken is marinated in yoghurt and spices before being cooked in a tandoori oven, while the real star is the briyani rice studded with morel mushrooms, yoghurt sauce, and tomato-based gravy. To order, call 6836-0055.

site_title: UEL's cash offer for WBL a 'cautious, risk-management approach'
summary: United Engineers (UE) has made a cash offer to pay S$2.07 per share for WBL shares it does not already own, valuing WBL at S$582 million. The offer, made by Yanlord Perennial consortium, appears to be a cautious approach to its investment, as it does not aim to take control of WBL. The deal would reduce YPI's overall investment in UE/WBL by 23.8% and benefit UE shareholders, as they receive their original cost for YPI's stake.

site_title: Future presents from Christmas past
summary: Christmas is a time for charities to emphasize empathy and kindness, but critics argue that focusing solely on empathy can lead to a "guilt-trip" mentality and numb action. Research shows that emotional appeals on social media can repel donors, while planned and positive approaches can be more effective. By setting aside a budget for donations and considering civic responsibility, individuals can make a meaningful impact and avoid emotional manipulation. This approach encourages a sense of community and collective well-being, rather than just individual charity.

site_title: Power Struggle
summary: Singaporean artist Ruben Pang's latest solo show, Swallow Shadow, sold out in one weekend, with nearly all 17 works snapped up. Pang's unique triptych measuring 200cm by 424cm was priced at S$50,000, a significant increase from his early days. Despite success, Pang remains philosophical about it, citing the importance of celebrating a multitude of artistic expressions. He attributes his charisma to his ability to articulate his inspiration and processes, setting him apart from other artists. Pang's show explores themes of power, truth, and the human condition through his abstract paintings.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: How to succeed in art without relying on 'the art world'
summary: Artist John McAllister has gained widespread recognition and sold-out shows without significant institutional support. Despite being represented by six galleries worldwide, he remains outside the mainstream art world, with only the Rubell Collection and Hammer Museum in Los Angeles exhibiting his work. McAllister's paintings, which often feature landscapes and luminous colors, sell for $20,000 to $70,000, with collectors rarely asking for resales. His loyal collectors, including Marty Eisenberg and Gloria von Thurn und Taxis, have driven his success, and his art is now in high demand, with supply meeting but not eclipsing demand.

site_title: New rule to curb credit for borrowers with outstanding debt
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Credit Limit Management Measure, effective January 1, 2018, to curb credit for borrowers with outstanding unsecured debt exceeding six times their monthly income. The measure caps additional unsecured credit at 12 times monthly income, preventing further debt accumulation. This move aims to help borrowers manage their unsecured debt and prevent debt distress.

site_title: 9 in 10 Singapore SMEs successful in securing debt financing: survey
summary: Singapore SMEs were successful in securing debt financing for 90% of applications in the past year, according to a Spring Singapore survey. 60% of SMEs seeking external financing used it for cash flow management. Bank loans were the most popular form of financing, and larger SMEs were more likely to seek external financing due to growth needs. Micro companies faced lower approval rates due to lack of financial documents and weaker business performance. Effective cash flow management is crucial for long-term resilience and competitiveness, according to Spring Singapore.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Interra Resources to raise US$3.47m from private placement
summary: Interra Resources will raise US$3.47 million from a private placement by subscribing to 79.5 million new shares at 5.9 Singapore cents apiece. The placement, valued at a 1.667% discount, will be used for working capital purposes. The move strengthens Interra's strategic partnership with China ZhenHua Oil, which acquired a 40% stake in a joint operating company in Myanmar in 2011. The deal validates the partners' confidence in developing the fields and will allow Interra to leverage China ZhenHua Oil's strengths and resources.

images.alt_text: "We believe ... it is an opportune time to undertake more work in emerging Myanmar as well as regionally," says Mr Tjia.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LHN, a Hong Kong-based property management company, plans to raise up to HK$99.1 million through a share offering. Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore Ltd will prosecute its non-executive chairman for alleged breach of directors' duties. Sapphire Corporation Limited has redesigned its board, with its CEO becoming a non-independent non-executive director and a new executive director. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long to take over as the new CEO.

site_title: Swee Heng Bakery triples capacity with new factory
summary: Swee Heng Bakery has officially opened its new 6,000 square meter state-of-the-art factory in Singapore, tripling its capacity to produce 30,000 cakes and 120,000 bread dough daily. The facility features a central kitchen and research and development division, enabling the bakery to create new recipes and satisfy local flavors. The new plant is equipped with advanced technologies, including cold chain delivery docks and tunnel ovens, to maintain freshness and quality. The bakery, which has grown from a small shop in 1989, now has 40 retail outlets and 600 staff members.

site_title: Christopher Doyle
summary: Renowned cinematographer Christopher Doyle, known for his distinctive visual style and collaborative work with directors like Wong Kar-wai and Zhang Yimou, has built a 35-year career in Chinese-language cinema. Born in Sydney and raised Catholic, Doyle learned Mandarin and photography through self-study, eventually landing his first job as cinematographer in Edward Yang's debut feature. He is celebrated for his "feng shui" approach to filmmaking, which focuses on capturing the unique energy of each location. Doyle, who has never settled down, credits his optimistic pessimism and love for women with driving his creative work, and advises budding filmmakers to find their own unique voice and approach.

site_title: What to buy a billionaire: The holiday gift guide for the .0001%
summary: For the billionaire on your list, consider rare experiences and luxury goods. Options include a historic globe imagining a socialist Utopia on Mars ($60,000), a three-day helicopter flyover to the North Pole ($20,995-$46,900), or an all-inclusive trip to the geographic North Pole ($46,900). Animal relocation safaris, where guests help move endangered species, can also be arranged (starting at $50,000). Alternatively, consider a watch worn by a legend, such as Joe DiMaggio's Patek Philippe ref. 130 ($300,000-$1.8 million), or an Aston Martin submarine ($4 million). Other ideas include sponsoring a collection or exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History ($500,000-$75 million) or purchasing a private island in New Zealand ($14 million-$24 million).

site_title: Falling prices and new mortgage rules boost Canadian home sales
summary: Canadian home sales rose 3.9% in November, driven by a 16% increase in Toronto transactions and moderating home prices. This marks the second-largest increase in two years and a fourth consecutive rise in transactions. The Canadian Real Estate Association projects a 5.3% drop in sales for 2018 due to new mortgage regulations. National home prices fell 0.2% in November, with a 2.7% decline over the past six months. The association attributes the boost in sales to buyers rushing to enter the market before new regulations take effect at the start of 2018.

images.alt_text: Canada's national home prices were down 0.2 per cent in November and have fallen 2.7 per cent over the past six months.

site_title: Hedge funds can't keep up with China's surging stock market
summary: Hedge funds investing in China's stock market have had their best year since 2009, with long-short equity funds returning an average 30% through November 30. Despite this, they remain behind the MSCI China Index by the widest margin on record. The performance puts hedge funds on track to surpass their pre-2009 highs, but still lags the market's rally.

images.alt_text: Some hedge fund managers say their jobs are getting harder as an influx of trend-chasing Chinese individual investors causes Hong Kong share prices to detach from corporate fundamentals for extended periods.

site_title: Deck The Halls
summary: Two Singaporeans, Nick Oxborrow and Audrey Lee, showcase their unique holiday decorations. Nick, an Englishman who celebrates Christmas in hot weather, decorates his shophouse with a 8ft crystal tree and traditional red ornaments. Audrey, an interior designer, creates a winter-themed centerpiece with palm cuttings, pine cones, and crystal balls. Her sons help decide the tree's color theme, while her husband designs ornaments made from cardboard. Meanwhile, Adrian Chua and his family make their own ornaments, including a 12m cardboard tree for the 2015 Singapore Book of Records.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Why the world needs some disobedience
summary: The article highlights the need for disobedience in the face of erratic and belligerent leadership, citing the example of guide dogs trained to disobey orders to ensure their safety and the safety of others. The author argues that disobedience is a higher cognitive skill than obedience and is essential for resisting unlawful orders. The article references historical cases, including the Nuremberg Trials, where obedience to an illegal order was not absolved individual criminal responsibility. It concludes that disobedience may stand between humanity and Armageddon, particularly in the current context of President Donald Trump's actions and rhetoric.

site_title: Airbus puts helicopters chief in line for top job in shake-up
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders is set to step down in April 2019, with Guillaume Faury, head of its commercial plane building unit, being considered to replace him. Faury, 49, provides continuity and a fresh perspective, having spent time away from the company. The move comes amid bribery investigations related to middlemen in military and commercial airplane sales. Airbus is also considering a search for a new CEO, with internal and external candidates to be considered next year. Enders' departure follows a management shake-up, including the departure of COO Fabrice Bregier, who was seen as a potential successor.

site_title: S'pore shares finish the week lower as uncertainty looms
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.55% to 3,416.94 on Friday, erasing earlier gains, amid uncertainty over US tax cuts and rising volatility. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB losing 1.6%, 1%, and 0.4% respectively. Analysts warn of a rich valuation and low dividend yield, and predict no rest for the market before Christmas due to ongoing US tax uncertainty and wavering lawmakers.

site_title: Sustained economic growth seen in 2018 with further upside potential in equities
summary: Global economic growth is expected to remain strong in 2018, driven by advanced and emerging markets. The US, eurozone, China, and India are forecast to contribute to a 3.8% GDP growth rate, with global inflation reaching 2.7%. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank are expected to raise interest rates, leading to less accommodative monetary policy. Investors can expect robust returns for risk assets in 2018, with emerging markets, corporate investment, and supertrend equities emerging as key themes.

site_title: Take Home The Force
summary: Nathan Yong, co-founder of Grafunkt, has collaborated with Disney to create limited edition stools/sidetables inspired by Star Wars: The Last Jedi. The collection, priced from S$5,400, features marble pieces modeled after iconic ships like the Millennium Falcon and TIE-Fighter. The pieces represent the duality of light and dark sides. The collection is available at the Takashimaya Star Wars Pop-up Store, Grafunkt store, and online at www.theartling.com.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Time To Run
summary: Luxury watch retailer Cortina Watch is offering a special Christmas gift to BT racers with an outdoor and adventurous spirit. The Casio G-Shock MR-G watch, priced at S$4,299, comes with an exclusive solar recharging station worth S$299 if purchased at the Chinatown Point outlet, provided a magazine or screenshot of the offer is brought.

site_title: Boogie With The Bee Gees
summary: A Bee Gees tribute band, "Bee Gees Gold," from Las Vegas is set to perform at the Sands Theatre at Marina Bay Sands on Dec 16. The three-part band, consisting of John Acosta, Michael Welsch, and Jee Celentano as Barry, Robin, and Maurice Gibb, will deliver tight harmonies of the Gibb brothers' hits like "Stayin' Alive" and "How Deep Is Your Love." The performance is a nostalgic trip back to the 1970s, with the band's uncanny vocal resemblance to the Gibb brothers. Tickets are available from Sistic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Singapore shares end the week lower
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.55% on Friday, ending at 3,416.94, erasing earlier gains. The week's loss was nearly 8 points. Turnover was 1.5 billion worth S$1.3 billion, with an advance-decline score of 173 to 209. The decline comes amid US tax cuts uncertainty.

site_title: Datapulse not seeking shareholders' approval for proposed acquisition
summary: Datapulse Technology Limited has clarified that it will not need shareholder approval for a proposed acquisition, as the deal's relative figures amount to less than 5% based on its audited financial statements for the 2017 financial year. The company is seeking shareholder approval for the diversification of its core businesses, including haircare product manufacturing and cosmetics. Datapulse will acquire one million ordinary shares in Wayco Manufacturing for S$3.5 million, following an independent valuation report valuing the properties at RM7.3 million.

site_title: Understanding stress CMR
summary: Magnetic Resonance Myocardial Perfusion Imaging (stress CMR) is a safe and accurate test for detecting heart disease. It evaluates blood flow to heart muscles using medication such as adenosine. Stress CMR is used to assess ischemia, coronary artery lesions, and myocardial infarction. The test is recommended for patients with symptoms of chest pain, abnormal ECGs, or previous heart failure. It is also used to evaluate patients with high global coronary artery disease risk, prior coronary artery disease, or poor functional capacity. The test is non-invasive, accurate, and has a high sensitivity and specificity in detecting coronary artery disease, with no ionizing radiation used.

site_title: Pence's Middle East trip shrinks after pushing Trump on Jerusalem
summary: Vice President Mike Pence's Middle East trip has been scaled back after he pushed President Donald Trump to declare Jerusalem the capital of Israel. Palestinian leaders have cancelled meetings with Pence, and he will not visit Bethlehem or the Church of the Nativity in the West Bank. Pence's trip, initially planned for four days, has been delayed and truncated, with some stops removed, amid speculation about the administration's goals for the region and Pence's presidential ambitions. Pence's evangelical Christian views and deep devotion to Israel have been a driving force behind his support for the Jerusalem decision.

site_title: The annual office party isn't the option you think it is
summary: The annual office party is often viewed as a time for team bonding, but many employees dread attending due to social anxiety or preference for spending time with family. Companies, however, continue to host events despite employees' reluctance, emphasizing the importance of collaboration and team player traits. This may be a result of the pressure to maintain a professional image, even outside of work hours. As a result, many employees feel forced to attend, rather than choosing to participate voluntarily.

site_title: Food Of Christmas Past
summary: Chefs in Singapore are offering traditional Christmas recipes from different cultures at their restaurants. Damian D'Silva's Eurasian/Peranakan restaurant Folklore features dishes like Debal and Feng, while Konstantino Blockbergen's bakery-restaurant Firebake offers kugelhopf and melomakarona. La Pepa serves Spanish classics, including suckling pig and torta de turron. Chef Alex Calabro's Casa Tartufo offers a turkey and truffle puff pastry pie, and Brasserie Gavroche features a baked pork terrine with foie gras and black truffles. These special Christmas menus are available from December 15 to 31.

site_title: UK government has no plans to remove exit date in Brexit law to avoid rebellion
summary: The UK government has no plans to remove the exit date from Brexit law, despite losing a vote in parliament. The amendment, which sets a fixed time for Brexit, was inserted by Prime Minister Theresa May's government to avoid another parliamentary showdown. The government is confident in the bill's necessity and will take a pragmatic approach, recognizing parliament's role in scrutinizing the bill.

site_title: 'Congratulations': EU launches next phase of Brexit
summary: The European Union (EU) has agreed to move forward with Brexit negotiations, giving UK Prime Minister Theresa May a formal green light to proceed with talks. EU leaders have agreed "sufficient progress" on citizens' rights, the Irish border, and Britain's outstanding payments, allowing negotiators to move on to the main phase of talks. A two-year transition period to ease Britain's exit is set to start in the new year, with talks on a future free trade pact not to begin until after March 2019.

images.alt_text: Mrs May and Tim Barrow, UK permanent representative to the EU (at right), leaving after attending the EU leaders summit at the Europa Building in Brussels, Belgium, early on Friday.

site_title: Global markets end November with mixed showing
summary: Global markets ended November with mixed results, with the US and Japan posting 2% and 3.3% gains, respectively. The rest of major regions lost ground, with fixed income markets reflecting a risk-off environment. Equity markets saw positive returns from US, Japan, and Emerging Europe, Middle East, and Africa, while Asian equity funds were the worst performers. The year 2017 saw a lack of volatility and rising valuations, with some asset prices outpacing earnings growth, leading to higher price multiples and less appealing valuations.

images.alt_text: Taking the US equity market as an example and using the price-to-estimated earnings ratio (PE), one would see that the market is currently expensive.

site_title: Noble expects creditors' proposal soon: chairman
summary: NOBLE Group is expecting a proposal from its creditors in the near future, which will allow the firm to restructure and retain its key traders. The company's chairman, Paul Brough, emphasized the need to get back to the ordinary course of business quickly to avoid losing customers, suppliers, and employees. Noble has already sold its North America Corp and is looking to sell off its palm plantations, with plans to retain its alumina production plant in Jamaica. The company expects to receive cash proceeds of US$575 million from the sale of North America Corp and is seeking to secure more credit facilities to engage in trading activities.

site_title: National Aerated Water building in Serangoon to be conserved
summary: The National Aerated Water building in Serangoon, Singapore, will be partially conserved by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) after its new owner, Selangor Dredging, expressed support for conservation efforts. The main building, a two-storey L-shaped structure, will be integrated into a new residential development and retained for its architectural and heritage value. The URA will work closely with the owner to guide the reconstruction of a corner of the building and its internal floors to facilitate adaptive reuse and vehicular access. The conservation is welcomed by heritage enthusiasts and experts, who see it as a way to preserve Singapore's industrial heritage.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras to announce revised capex plan next week: CEO
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras is set to announce a revised investment plan next week, according to CEO Pedro Parente. The plan, which was initially projected to spend $74.1 billion from 2017-2021, is expected to be reduced by 25% from the prior five-year plan. The revision will mainly impact oil and gas exploration and production. Additionally, Petrobras Distribuidora, a subsidiary of Petrobras, recently completed an initial public offering that raised $2.03 billion and increased the company's efficiency and independence.

site_title: UK sees £3.8b a year of opportunities in steel sector by 2030
summary: The UK government has commissioned an independent study that estimates the steel sector will have £3.8 billion in annual business opportunities by 2030. The government plans to use three million tonnes of UK steel in infrastructure projects over the next five years, aiming to support the industry. The move follows a launch of an industrial strategy to intervene in key sectors and tackle weak productivity. The strategy targets sectors such as life sciences, construction, and artificial intelligence, which have struggled with weak productivity since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: HK moves towards dual-class shares to attract tech giants
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange has proposed allowing "innovative" companies to list with dual-class shares, which would give founders and management extra voting power. The move aims to attract technology giants like Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, which has listed in the US instead of Hong Kong. The plan, which requires approval from the securities regulator, includes requirements such as a minimum market capitalisation of HK$10 billion and restrictions on secondary listings for mainland Chinese companies. The changes are part of a package to better reflect the "drivers of the new global economy" and could be the largest change to the exchange's listing rules since 1993.

site_title: StarHub to acquire cryptographic technology company for as much as S$122m
summary: StarHub has agreed to acquire D'Crypt Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based cryptographic technology company, for up to S$122 million. The acquisition, set to be completed in two phases, will enhance StarHub's capabilities in enterprise solutions, particularly in cybersecurity and digital security. D'Crypt, founded in 2000, designs and produces solutions for encrypted communications and high-performance computing. The deal is seen as a strategic investment to expand StarHub's enterprise solutions and cater to Singapore's Smart Nation initiatives.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Japan expands sanctions aimed at North Korea
summary: Japan has expanded its sanctions against North Korea, adding 19 more entities and 108 individuals to its list of targeted organizations and individuals. The list now comprises 103 entities and 108 individuals, including those involved in financial services, coal and minerals trading, transportation, and sending North Korean laborers abroad. The move comes amid heightened tensions following North Korea's launch of an ICBM ballistic missile into Japan's exclusive economic zone. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the sanctions aim to increase pressure on North Korea to change its policies and seek negotiations, amid concerns of further provocations.

site_title: Hong Kong venture said to buy into London Gotham City Tower
summary: A consortium of four Hong Kong property companies, including C C Land Holdings, has agreed to buy a majority stake in the 40 Leadenhall office project, nicknamed Gotham City Tower, in London's financial district. The investors will fund the construction of the 905,000 square foot building, which will take four years to complete. The deal is the first sign of Hong Kong investors seeking higher returns by taking on riskier office development projects post-Brexit. TH Real Estate, an affiliate of Nuveen, retains a minority stake and will manage the development.

site_title: Summons for interim relief against Keppel's unit dismissed
summary: Keppel Corporation Limited has won a court case against a minority shareholder, Sunsea Yacht Club (Hong Kong) Company Limited, in a bid to sell its stake in a China marina project. The High Court dismissed Sunsea's summons for interim relief, allowing Keppel to proceed with the planned 2.9 billion yuan (S$0.6 billion) disposal. As a result, the costs will be awarded to Keppel's wholly owned subsidiary, Keppel Land China Ltd. and its fully owned unit, Keppel China Marina Holdings.

site_title: Sapphire makes changes to board ahead of proposed acquisition
