summary: Sapphire Corporation Limited has made changes to its board of directors ahead of a proposed acquisition by Hong Kong International Construction Investment Management Group Co Limited. CEO Teh Wing Kwan has been redesignated as non-independent non-executive director, while Wang Heng, a co-founder of Sapphire's China-based rail engineering subsidiary, has been appointed as executive director and CEO. The changes are part of a planned leadership transition and come as part of a share swap deal between HKICIM and two of Sapphire's largest shareholders.

site_title: Majority shareholder seeks to prosecute action against ETC's non-executive chairman
summary: A majority shareholder of Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore Ltd (ETC) is seeking to prosecute the company's non-executive chairman, Christopher Chong Meng Tak, for alleged breach of directors' duties. The shareholder, Luo Shandong, is also requesting the appointment of special auditors to address unauthorized withdrawals of funds from a subsidiary. ETC has reported losses totaling S$24 million due to these unauthorized transfers, which were made between July and October this year. The company's shares have been suspended since November 20, 2017.

site_title: Japan approves merger in struggling regional bank sector after lengthy review
summary: Japan's antitrust regulator has approved the merger of Daishi Bank Ltd and Hokuetsu Bank Ltd, a move aimed at helping regional lenders struggling to survive due to an aging population and shrinking local economies. The merger, initially delayed by six months, will not be blocked by the Fair Trade Commission, which found no threat to competition. The decision marks the FTC's approval of all 15 proposed regional bank mergers in the past decade, with the resulting entity controlling 55% of lending in Niigata prefecture.

site_title: Luxembourg challenges EU order to recover tax from Amazon
summary: Luxembourg is appealing a European Union order to recover 250 million euros in back taxes from Amazon, citing disagreement with EU state aid regulators' decision that the US online retailer received special treatment. The Grand Duchy believes the Commission did not establish a selective advantage and disputes the analysis on transfer pricing. This challenge comes after the European Commission accused Luxembourg of giving Amazon illegal tax benefits. Luxembourg has also appealed a 2015 ruling on back taxes from Fiat, and employs 1,500 people in the country.

site_title: Perfect 10
summary: Bjork's 10th album "Utopia" is a cathartically dreamlike album that stands out from her usual avant-garde style. Released in 2017, it transports listeners to a transcendental paradise with a lush soundscape of birds, robots, and other sounds. The album is a refreshing escape from the world's cynicism and is worth not being dismissed. "Utopia" is now available in record stores and digital platforms.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle to marry on May 19
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will marry on May 19, 2018, at St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle. The couple, who announced their engagement last month, are living in Harry's cottage on Kensington Palace grounds. Markle, a 36-year-old actress, plans to baptize in the Church of England, apply for British citizenship, and give up international charity campaigning. The ceremony will take place at the chapel where Harry was baptized and has hosted several royal weddings, including those in the 19th century.

site_title: Siemens partners with Amazon as it ramps up industrial software platform
summary: Siemens is partnering with Amazon to accelerate the rollout of its MindSphere industrial software platform, set to launch in January on Amazon Web Services (AWS). The partnership aims to dominate the digital factory automation market. The next version of MindSphere will be available on AWS, a popular cloud system among industrial software developers. Siemens' chief technology officer, Roland Busch, noted that many customers appreciate the partnership. This move aims to expand Siemens' reach in the industrial software market.

site_title: KOP Limited sells wholly owned unit to Cityneon Holdings
summary: KOP Limited is disposing of its wholly owned subsidiary, Scorpio East (SE) Properties Pte Ltd, to Cityneon Holdings Limited for about S$2.9 million. The sale includes assuming a S$23 million loan secured by SE Properties, which Cityneon will repay. The sale consideration is based on SE Properties' net asset value of S$11.9 million and a declared dividend of S$4.95 million. This move comes as KOP Limited's stock closed at S$0.09, up 0.3 Singapore cent, or 3.4 per cent, following the announcement.

site_title: Another action-packed year in sports
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

In 2017, sports fans witnessed an action-packed year filled with memorable moments. The article highlights seven key events, but the content provided does not include the actual events, only a snippet from an unrelated article about sports. The snippet mentions a dramatic F1 collision as one of the events, but the actual list of events is not provided.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: EU launches next phase of Brexit
summary: The European Union (EU) agreed to move forward with Brexit talks with the UK, with EU leaders giving "sufficient progress" on citizens' rights, the Irish border, and outstanding payments. This allows negotiators to move on to the main phase of talks, which will focus on a transition period and future trade relations. The EU is willing to start talks on a two-year transition period in January, but will not begin trade negotiations until March. The UK's Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed the agreement, saying it was a "step on the road to delivering a smooth and orderly Brexit."

site_title: Sterling rises for a 3rd day on Brexit talks hopes
summary: Sterling rose for a third consecutive day on Friday due to optimism over Brexit negotiations. Investors expect a transition period and trade agreements to be discussed in January. The British pound reached $1.3427 against the US dollar, a 0.3% gain for the week. The Bank of England's statement that Brexit talks reduced the risk of a disorderly Brexit boost economic confidence. Investors have turned bullish on sterling, but any Brexit disappointment may see sterling sharply lower.

site_title: London-based investment banks to face closer EU scrutiny after Brexit
summary: EU draft proposals aim to tighten controls on large investment banks, such as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, following Brexit. The European Commission plans to transfer supervision of big investment banks to the European Central Bank to prevent them exploiting laxer EU rules by moving business to lower-capital jurisdictions. This move seeks to maintain stability and prevent potential failures.

site_title: Indonesia, Freeport said to near new deal for Grasberg mine
summary: Indonesia and Freeport-McMoRan are set to sign a new agreement as soon as this weekend that will outline a road-map for the transfer of majority ownership of the Grasberg copper and gold mine to a local firm, Inalum. Under the deal, Inalum will seek to acquire Rio Tinto's joint venture interest in Grasberg by March, with plans to convert the interest into an equity stake. Local ownership of Grasberg is expected to rise to 51% under the framework deal agreed in August, allowing Freeport to continue operating the project through 2041.

site_title: Good times gone: Slower business awaits Chinese steel mills in 2018
summary: China's steel demand is expected to slow in 2018 due to the government's tightening of credit and stimulus measures. The country's steel prices surged in 2017, but analysts predict a downward trend next year. The lifting of winter production curbs and increased steel supply will further contribute to slower demand, potentially leading to downward price moves. Analysts forecast China's economic growth to cool to around 6.6% this quarter and 6.4% in 2018.

site_title: EU set to focus on banking union, bailout fund in eurozone overhaul
summary: European Union leaders will focus on completing a banking union and expanding the eurozone bailout fund when discussing eurozone integration priorities. A banking union to protect bank deposits across borders is gaining broad support, but Germany and the Netherlands want to reduce banking sector risks before moving forward. The eurozone bailout fund is set to be transformed into a European Monetary Fund, with a final name yet to be decided. Contentious issues, such as a eurozone budget and a post of finance minister, remain unresolved.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's MAS introduces a new Credit Limit Management Measure to cap excessive unsecured borrowing starting Jan 1. Developers sold 785 private homes in Nov, slightly higher than the previous month. Noble Group chairman expects a creditor proposal on debt restructuring soon. Singapore Airlines and SilkAir will charge for advance seat selection in Economy Class starting Jan 20. The URA will conserve the National Aerated Water Factory building. About 90% of Singapore SMEs were successful in securing debt financing, according to a survey. The STI index lost 0.55% on Friday, erasing earlier gains.

site_title: Dalai Lama turns to iPhone to spread app-iness
summary: The Dalai Lama has launched a new iPhone app, 'Dalai Lama Official', allowing users to track his travels and teachings. The app promises live video of his teachings, official news, videos, and photos from his office. This move follows his existing large Twitter following, where he announced the app to his 16.6 million followers. The app aims to provide a platform for devotees to stay updated on his activities and teachings.

site_title: Bank of Spain cuts GDP forecasts for 2018, 2019 on Catalonia
summary: The Bank of Spain lowered its GDP forecasts for 2018 and 2019 due to the impact of Catalonia's independence drive, cutting growth estimates to 2.4% and 2.1% respectively. The central bank attributed the downgrade to uncertainty related to Catalonia and increased oil prices. The Bank of Spain also increased its inflation estimate for 2018 to 1.5% and expects inflation to ease to 1.4% in 2019. Unemployment is expected to fall to 11% by 2020. The move reflects the economic uncertainty caused by the Catalan secession crisis.

site_title: Indonesia posts trade surplus for fourth straight month in November
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$130 million in November, its fourth consecutive surplus, driven by 13.18% growth in exports to China and India. Imports rose 19.62% to US$15.15 billion, beating forecasts. The surplus was narrower than expected, with a median forecast of US$920 million. Indonesia has maintained a trade surplus every month this year except for July.

site_title: Ryanair offers to recognise unions as first-ever strikes loom
summary: Ryanair offers to recognize unions as the airline seeks to prevent strikes. The Irish company has written to pilot organizations in six countries, inviting them to talks to establish committees to handle issues related to Ryanair. The unions must establish a representative body for pilots in each country to be recognized. The airline has called on pilots to cancel planned walkouts. This move aims to head off strike action, which was imminent.

site_title: India government ignored warnings over GST roll out: sources
summary: The Indian government ignored warnings from private companies that the Goods and Services Tax (GST) system was not ready for launch, despite complex technology issues and technical glitches. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley had declared the system ready weeks before its July 1 launch, chiding industry experts who said more time was needed for testing. The government's decision has led to chaos and disruptions, blamed in part for a slide in Indian economic growth, and has been criticized by opposition parties.

site_title: Australia shares dragged lower by financials; NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,997.0 points, dragged down by banks due to new anti-money laundering claims against Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Real estate stocks declined, while industrial stocks rose. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high of 8,360.86, driven by gains in utilities stocks.

site_title: China's HNA repurchases some bonds in fresh move to reassure investors
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Group repurchased some of its bonds in a move to reassure investors amid concerns over its liquidity. The repurchases follow HNA's $50 billion in deal-making over the past two years, sparking scrutiny of its opaque ownership and use of leverage. HNA believes its finances are "stronger than ever," with a debt-to-equity ratio of 59.5%. The company has also issued high-yielding domestic commercial paper and agreed to a coupon of 8.875% on a US$300 million one-year bond.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as bonds gain
summary: Europe's stocks declined 0.3% as of 8:08am London time, following a drop in US equity gauges. Bonds gained, with the euro heading for a weekly gain, while the pound swung between gains and losses. European bonds advanced, with yields on UK gilts at their lowest since September amid Brexit speculation. The euro central bank remained cautious about reaching inflation goals, keeping stimulus in place.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.93 points to 1,753.07. The decline was attributed to a higher number of losers (475) compared to gainers (414), with a total of 2.3 billion shares traded worth RM3.5 billion.

site_title: Australia cobalt rush accelerates on electric vehicle demand, DRC troubles
summary: Australia is experiencing a cobalt rush driven by electric vehicle demand, with shares in companies like Clean TeQ and Australian Mines tripling this year. The Democratic Republic of Congo, the world's largest cobalt producer, is facing concerns over artisanal mining practices, prompting companies like Toyota and Volkswagen to seek alternative sources. Australia, with 1.1 million tonnes of cobalt reserves, is attracting investors, with companies like Aeon Metals raising A$30 million to develop a copper-cobalt project. The shift is expected to increase demand for Australian cobalt, which is more costly but less risky than DRC cobalt.

site_title: Singapore export growth seen slowing in Nov, tech sales cooling: poll
summary: Singapore's exports growth is expected to slow in November, with non-oil domestic exports forecast to rise 5.5% year-over-year, down from a 20.9% surge in October. Electronics exports, which drove the previous month's growth, are expected to grow modestly at 4.5%. A high base effect from last year's double-digit pace is cited as the reason for the slowdown, with external demand remaining robust despite the decline.

site_title: H&M falls further behind Zara as online shift trips up retail
summary: H&M reported a 4% drop in quarterly sales, the largest decline in at least a decade, as fewer customers visited stores amid a crisis in brick-and-mortar retail. The Swedish company plans to close more stores and expand its e-commerce presence to counter the trend. In contrast, rival Inditex's Zara reported a rebound in revenue growth for November and early December, outpacing H&M in the online shift. H&M's shares fell 12% as the company struggles to adapt to the changing retail landscape.

site_title: Noble Group chairman expects creditors' proposal soon on debt restructuring
summary: Noble Group chairman Paul Brough expects a creditor proposal on debt restructuring within the next few weeks. The company, struggling with a crisis-wracked three years, aims to keep its business running and has about $3.5 billion in debt. Noble has shrunk from a global commodity trader to an Asian-centric company focused on coal and freight trading, having slashed jobs and sold assets to cut debt. The company remains open to strategic investors and prioritizes avoiding insolvency.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd expects to soon receive a proposal from creditors on its debt restructuring, its chairman said, as the struggling commodities trader seeks to keep its business running.

site_title: Hong Kong moves toward dual-class shares, woos next Alibaba
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange proposes allowing "innovative" companies to list with dual-class shares, giving them extra voting power, to attract tech giants like Alibaba Group. This change, part of the largest update to listing rules since 1993, aims to reflect the "drivers of the new global economy." The move is expected to boost the exchange's appeal, with CEO Charles Li hoping for "a significant number of innovative companies" to list by the second half of 2024.

site_title: China's money rates up after PBOC, taking Fed's cue, lifts market rates
summary: China's primary money rate increased by 5 basis points after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) lifted short- and medium-term market rates, mirroring the US Federal Reserves' tightening policy. The move aims to reduce leverage and curb risky lending. Economists expect further rate hikes in 2018, with some forecasting a total of 35 basis points increase. The PBOC injected funds into the market, offsetting the maturity of loans, and the Shanghai Interbank Offered Rate (Shibor) rose to 2.8710 per cent.

site_title: Beijing evictions leave migrant workers in limbo as winter deepens
summary: Beijing's migrant workers face uncertain futures as winter deepens, with thousands evicted from urban villages after a deadly fire prompted authorities to cut off electricity and heating. Despite efforts to remove them, some workers refuse to leave, citing lack of alternative housing. The evictions have sparked criticism from intellectuals and journalists, who argue the government is unfairly targeting the vulnerable underclass. Migrant workers, who make up a significant portion of Beijing's labor force, are being forced to endure harsh conditions, with some considering fleeing to other cities in search of better living conditions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won both end the week with gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 12.59 points, or 0.51%, to 2,482.07 at 0630 GMT on Friday, ending two straight weeks of losses and gaining 0.7% for the week. The Korean won was quoted at 1,089.8 per US dollar, 0.06% weaker than its previous close, while bond yields fell.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares declined on Friday, mirroring a retreat across Asia and in New York, amid concerns over US tax-cut measures. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.09% to close at 28,848.11, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also dropped 0.80% and 0.72%, respectively. The losses follow a recent rally in the region, with investors weighing the impact of US trade policies on global markets.

site_title: Mugabe visits Singapore hospital on first trip since ouster
summary: Zimbabwe's former President Robert Mugabe, 93, visited a Singapore hospital on his first trip since being ousted from power in November, for a medical check-up. Accompanied by eight people, he walked out of the hospital and was driven away in two cars. This visit comes as Mugabe's new government tries to show him respect, despite his authoritarian 37-year rule and alleged human rights abuses. Mugabe's frail health and recent prostate cancer battles have prompted several medical trips to Singapore, a popular medical tourism destination.

site_title: Uber Eats to offer couriers insurance in Europe
summary: Uber Eats to offer couriers insurance in Europe, providing coverage for personal accidents, hospitalization, property damage, and third-party injury. The insurance package, offered by AXA, will be available to all couriers in Europe starting January 8, 2018, regardless of their employment status. The move aims to address concerns over the treatment of gig economy workers, with Uber Eats promising to reimburse couriers up to €7,500 for medical expenses and provide cash benefits for severe sickness or injury.

images.alt_text: Uber's food-delivery business will begin offering an insurance package to its couriers in Europe, a move to address the conditions of "gig economy" workers.

site_title: UEL's cash offer for WBL helps Yanlord Perennial recover capital in 'more cautious' approach: report
summary: UE made a cash offer of S$2.07 per share for WBL shares it doesn't already own, mirroring the price Yanlord Perennial Investment paid OCBC for their WBL shares in July. This cautious approach suggests a risk management strategy for Yanlord Perennial's UEL investment, differing from previous expectations.

site_title: Airbus reveals management overhaul as Enders plans to leave
summary: Airbus has announced a top management overhaul amid corruption allegations, with CEO Tom Enders planning to step down in April 2019 and COO Fabrice Bregier leaving in February. Guillaume Faury, head of the helicopters business, will take over Bregier's role and potentially succeed Enders. The move aims to restore the company's reputation and address ongoing issues.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks step up, won weaker
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 9.70 points, or 0.39%, to 2,479.18. The won fell 0.03% to 1,089.4 per dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is up 21.9% this year and down 3.02% in the previous 30 days. Foreigners were net sellers of 80 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: URA to gazette National Aerated Water Factory building for conservation
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced that the National Aerated Water Factory building, a two-storey Art Deco-style building completed in 1954, will be gazetted for conservation. The building, which produced soft drinks from the 1950s to 1990s, will be integrated into a new residential development. The conserved building will be kept fenceless and reconstructed to allow vehicular access to the rear of the site. The URA and building owner Selangor Dredging Bhd will work together to guide the reconstruction process.

site_title: Developers sell 785 private homes excluding ECs in Nov, up from 760 units in Oct: URA
summary: Singapore developers sold 785 private homes in November, slightly higher than October's 760 units, but lower than last year's 860. This figure excludes executive condominium (EC) units, where 148 EC units were sold in November. Top-selling projects included Parc Botannia and Queens Peak condo, with median prices ranging from S$1,287 to S$1,694 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: BP to re-enter solar market with 43% stake in Lightsource
summary: BP is re-entering the solar market with a 43% stake in Lightsource for $200 million. The deal marks BP's return to solar energy, 6 years after exiting the market due to intense competition. BP will fund Lightsource's growth pipeline, targeting large-scale solar projects in the US, India, Europe, and the Middle East. The deal is expected to be completed in early 2018.

site_title: North Korea's economy remains tiny, but has some bright spots
summary: North Korea's economy remains small, with per capita income in 2016 estimated at 1.46 million South Korean won, about 4.5% of South Korea's. Despite this, the country showed improvement in agriculture and resource-rich sectors, such as coal and iron ore production, which outperformed South Korea. Mobile phone users increased 11% to 14 per 100 people, but Amnesty International warns that using phones to call abroad risks imprisonment. The country's population is 24.9 million, with a projected birth rate of 1.94 per woman, lower than South Korea's 1.33.

site_title: Sea change: LNG tankers divert to China as winter gas shortage bites
summary: LNG tankers are diverting to China due to a supply crunch in the world's second-largest economy as winter bites. China's surge in natural gas imports has pushed up spot LNG prices by over 80% to above $10 per million British thermal units. Traders are rushing to find cargoes, leading to higher rates for LNG tankers, with daily rates shooting up to $80,000. The demand spike is exacerbated by the La Nina weather pattern and the country's limited gas storage, making it reliant on spot LNG purchases to meet demand.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes lower for fourth straight day
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.62% on Friday, closing at 22,553.22, for the fourth consecutive session. The decline was driven by fresh doubts about US tax cut plans. The broader Topix index also dropped 0.81% to 1,793.47. The US market, however, saw gains as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: South Korea blockchain association announces virtual currency transparency measures
summary: A South Korean blockchain association has announced measures to boost transparency in cryptocurrency trading, agreed upon by 14 exchanges, including Bitthumb. Users will be required to trade through one account after identity confirmation via traditional financial institutions. Exchanges with over 2 billion won (S$2.47 billion) in assets will be allowed to operate starting January 1, 2024. This move aims to prevent illicit activities and promote a more secure cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hold gains as US dollar backtracks
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held gains against the US dollar, with the Aussie reaching a five-week peak of US$0.7680 and the kiwi steady at US$0.6990. Positive economic news at home, including strong jobs figures in Australia, and market expectations for gradual US rate rises, supported the currencies. The US dollar backed off due to a cautious outlook on inflation from the Federal Reserve and uncertainty over US tax reform.

site_title: China lifts pledge financing ceiling to prevent settlement risks
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced new rules to improve efficiency and ward off risks in the country's payment and settlement system. The PBOC raised the ceiling of automatic pledge financing for lenders, allowing them to borrow more money from the central bank using bonds as collateral. The new rules also broaden the types of bonds that can be used as collateral and charge uniform interest rates, starting immediately.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on negative ground; STI at 3,417.05
summary: Singapore shares began trading on Friday afternoon in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,417.05, down 0.55% or 18.73 points. Despite a marginal 0.02% gain in the morning, the index fell as the day progressed. Losers outnumbered gainers 170 to 125, with 567.7 million shares worth S$377.7 million traded.

site_title: South Korea outraged by journalist beating in China
summary: South Korea is outraged after a Chinese security guard severely beat and injured a South Korean photojournalist covering President Moon Jae-In's visit to Beijing. The incident has sparked anger and calls for Mr. Moon to return home immediately. Chinese foreign ministry officials downplayed the incident, stating they are concerned about any injuries. However, South Korean media outlets have criticized China's behavior, calling it "arrogant and violent" and an "appalling use of force." The incident has strained relations between the two countries.

site_title: MAS tightens safeguard against excessive unsecured borrowing
summary: MAS introduces a new Credit Limit Management Measure to help borrowers avoid excessive unsecured debt. Starting January 1, 2018, financial institutions will not be allowed to grant new unsecured credit facilities if an individual's outstanding debts exceed six times their monthly income. The total credit limit will be capped at 12 times monthly income. This measure aims to prevent borrowers from accumulating excessive debt and promote financial stability.

site_title: Interra places out 13.6% stake at S$0.059 per share
summary: Interra Resources has approved a 13.6% stake sale to China ZhenHua Oil Co for S$0.059 per share, raising US$3.48 million. The placement will also allow China ZhenHua to nominate a director to Interra's board. The deal represents a 1.667% discount to Interra's volume-weighted average price. The funds will be used for general corporate purposes, with US$10,000 allocated to placement-related expenses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start the day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, following declines across Asia and the US, as traders worry about the passage of US tax cuts by Congress. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.61%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices slipped 0.15% and 0.13% respectively.

site_title: Meghan Markle adds sparkle to British royal Christmas
summary: Meghan Markle, the fiancée of Prince Harry, will spend Christmas with the British royal family for the first time. She will join the royals at Queen Elizabeth II's private estate in Norfolk, England, where they traditionally spend their winter break. The 36-year-old US actress will be the first non-royal to join the family for Christmas. The invitation shows the confidence the royals have in her, and she will have to adjust to their quirky traditions, including going out shooting on Boxing Day.

site_title: Japan firm says it will pay part of salaries in Bitcoin
summary: Japan's GMO Internet will start paying up to 100,000 yen (S$1,200) monthly to its 4,000 employees in Japan in Bitcoin, starting from February next year. The company aims to improve its understanding of the virtual currency by using it to pay part of its employees' salaries. GMO Internet, which operates various web-related businesses, began a Bitcoin trading and exchange business in May and will join the "Bitcoin mining" business next month to gain new Bitcoins as a reward for helping keep the network secure.

site_title: Cambodia's Hun Sen challenges EU and US to freeze assets
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen urged the US and EU to freeze the assets of Cambodian leaders abroad in response to his government's crackdown on the opposition and civil society. The US and EU have suspended funding for the 2018 election and imposed visa curbs, but no asset freeze has been proposed. Hun Sen dismissed donor criticism of the opposition party's dissolution and stated he has no assets abroad, which he believes would not harm him. The EU has not made a decision on further measures, while China, Cambodia's largest aid donor, has supported Hun Sen's actions.

images.alt_text: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen encouraged the United States and European Union on Friday to freeze the assets of Cambodian leaders abroad in response to his government's crackdown on the opposition and civil society.

site_title: With top-end videos, Quincy Jones opens 'Netflix of jazz'
summary: Quincy Jones launches Qwest TV, a global platform offering on-demand jazz videos, dubbed the "Netflix of jazz". The site features over 400 titles, including rare footage and documentaries by jazz greats like BB King and Wayne Shorter. Jones aims to add 600 more titles in the next three years, with plans for a Japanese version by the end of the year and German and Spanish versions in early 2018. Monthly subscriptions range from $7.49 to $9.99.

site_title: Oracle shares tumble as cloud outlook darkens
summary: Oracle Corp reported disappointing second-quarter sales and forecasted slower cloud revenue growth, sending its shares down 7% after hours. The company's cloud-computing business growth is expected to slow to 21-25% in the third quarter, below analysts' estimates. Oracle's current-quarter profit expectations also fell short. The company's efforts to switch to the cloud have seen its shares rise 30% this year, but it faces intense competition from Amazon, Microsoft, and Salesforce.

site_title: Turning coal into bitcoin? Dirty secret of 2017's hottest market
summary: Bitcoin's rapid growth in 2017 has a hidden cost: massive energy consumption. Private computer networks, like Bitmain Technologies' server farm in northern China, use 25,000 computers to solve encrypted calculations generating each bitcoin, consuming enormous amounts of energy. The production process is equivalent to the energy consumption of 1.7 million homes. This "dirty secret" highlights the environmental impact of the cryptocurrency's rapid rise, sparking concerns about its sustainability and potential long-term consequences.

site_title: Falling prices and new mortgage rules boost Canadian home sales
summary: Canadian home sales surged 3.9% in November, the second-largest increase in two years, driven by falling prices and tougher mortgage regulations. This marks a fourth consecutive rise in transactions, the longest streak since 2016. The average house price fell to C$513,433 in November, down 2.7% over six months. The Canadian Real Estate Association projects a 5.3% drop in sales for 2018, but brokers report a national sales momentum positive heading into year-end.

site_title: Joining Disney and Fox's sports channels may raise antitrust concerns: experts
summary: Walt Disney Co's acquisition of Twenty-First Century Fox's businesses may raise antitrust concerns due to the integration of Fox's 22 regional sports networks into Disney's ESPN, potentially giving Disney significant market power. Experts warn that this could lead to higher prices for cable operators and internet television providers. While regulators are likely to approve the deal, they may require asset sales or conditions to mitigate concerns. The deal's impact on the sports programming market is expected to be scrutinized, with Disney's ESPN already a leading sports channel with 88 million US subscribers.

site_title: Nine in 10 Singapore SMEs successful in securing debt financing: survey
summary: A survey by Spring Singapore found that 90% of Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) successfully secured debt financing, with 13% seeking external financing in the past year. The majority (60%) of those who did seek financing used it for cash flow management, and bank loans were the most popular form of external financing. Larger SMEs were more likely to seek financing, with higher approval rates for debt financing, while micro companies faced lower approval rates due to lack of financial documents and weaker business performance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Fees for advanced seat selection in new fare structure for SIA, SilkAir from January 2018
summary: Singapore Airlines and SilkAir will start charging Economy Class passengers for advance seat selection on January 20, 2018. The advance seat selection will be available under the "Lite" category for US$5 per flight segment. Other changes include revised fare types, baggage allowance, and frequent flyer program mileage accrual rates. The Economy Class will have three fare types: Lite, Standard, and Flexi, with varying levels of advance seat selection and baggage allowance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on worries over US tax cut
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to concerns over US tax cut plans. Despite the Bank of Japan's positive business confidence survey, investors were cautious. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.25% and the Topix index declined 0.37%. The uncertainty surrounding the US tax cut weighed on investors, leading to a decrease in the market.

site_title: Murdoch bets live sports and news will boost new, smaller Fox: analysis
summary: Rupert Murdoch is betting on the success of a new, smaller Fox TV business, leveraging its live sports and breaking news offerings to attract viewers and advertisers. After selling the company's film studios and international operations to Disney, Fox will focus on its US No. 1 news cable network and sports broadcasts, including NFL and MLB. The new Fox aims to boost online audiences with a streaming video service and is valued at at least $20 billion, despite its smaller size. Murdoch is confident that live sports and news will remain valuable to audiences.

site_title: US regulators ditch net neutrality rules as legal battles loom
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted 3-2 to repeal landmark 2015 net neutrality rules, giving internet service providers (ISPs) sweeping powers to change how consumers access the internet. The repeal, championed by FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, allows ISPs to block, slow, or charge more for certain content, sparking concerns about unequal access to web content. Democrats and companies like Google and Facebook have vowed to challenge the decision, while ISPs claim the new rules will promote innovation and competition.

site_title: Japan big manufacturers' mood improves to 11-year high in Q4: BOJ tankan
summary: Japan's big manufacturers reported a 11-year high in business confidence, with the headline index standing at plus 25 in December, outpacing market forecasts. This is the highest reading since December 2006, indicating optimism among manufacturers. The sentiment indexes are expected to fall to plus 19 over the next three months, suggesting a slight decline in confidence.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat led by banks; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.28 points to 5,994.2, led by a decline in banking stocks after the financial watchdog increased money laundering claims against Commonwealth Bank of Australia. This marks a retreat from the benchmark's previous rise above 6,000 points on Tuesday. The index is on track to end the week slightly lower.

site_title: From Colgate Lasagna to the monoski, flops take centre stage at the Museum of Failure
summary: The Museum of Failure in Los Angeles features over 100 exhibits showcasing epic flops in innovation, including the infamous Colgate Lasagna, the monoski, and a failed attempt at Coca Cola coffee. The museum, founded by clinical psychologist Samuel West, aims to prove that failure is an essential part of technological progress and personal growth. West's collection includes failed business ventures, such as Donald Trump's ventures, and encourages visitors to share their own failures, with the goal of promoting acceptance and learning from mistakes.

site_title: TMC Education stock jumps on news of takeover bid by property magnate
summary: TMC Education Corp shares jumped 75% to 7 cents per share after hotel and property magnate Koh Wee Meng launched a S$4.2 million takeover bid. Koh acquired a 51% stake in the company from controlling shareholders Chin Kon Yuen and Yeow Cheng Kim. The mandatory unconditional cash offer represents a 69% premium over TMC Education's last traded price. Koh plans to retain the listing status of TMC Education and perform a strategic review after the offer closes.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: LHN to price HK dual-listing offering at HK$1.90 to HK$2.36 per share
summary: LHN, a Singapore-listed property management and logistics services company, is pricing its dual-listing offering in Hong Kong at HK$1.90 to HK$2.36 per share, raising up to HK$99.1 million (S$17.1 million). Trading is expected to begin on December 29.

site_title: US dollar stutters on wrangling over tax bill, euro hit by ECB stance
summary: The US dollar declined 0.1% to 112.315 yen, reaching an eight-day low, amid wrangling over a tax bill change. The euro also dropped after the European Central Bank signaled it would maintain stimulus for as long as needed. The Federal Reserve's tightening of monetary policy, despite expressing concerns over low inflation, contributed to the US dollar's decline. The euro's fall was attributed to the ECB's stance, which may limit economic growth.

site_title: China says war must not be allowed on Korean peninsula
summary: China's President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for talks to resolve the North Korean crisis, warning against war on the Korean peninsula. Xi stated that the goal of denuclearizing the peninsula must be pursued through dialogue and consultation. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres also warned of the danger of "sleepwalking" into conflict. Meanwhile, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson offered to begin direct talks with North Korea without preconditions, which Russia and China have welcomed. The US has said all options are on the table, including military action, but no negotiations can be held until North Korea improves its behavior.

site_title: Indonesia's Go-Jek acquires 3 fintech firms to boost payment services
summary: Indonesia's Go-Jek has acquired three fintech firms, Kartuku, Midtrans, and Mapan, to expand its payment services. The acquisitions will boost Go-Jek's combined debit, credit, and digital wallet transactions to nearly $5 billion. The move aims to accelerate financial inclusion and stimulate economic productivity in Indonesia, where Go-Jek has 15 million weekly active users and processes 100 million transactions per month. The acquisitions follow Go-Jek's expansion into ride-hailing and other services, competing with Uber and Grab in the South-east Asian market.

site_title: New Zealand finance minister says "comfortable" with trend in NZ dollar
summary: New Zealand Finance Minister Grant Robertson expressed comfort with the current trend of the New Zealand dollar, which has declined after the change of government raised uncertainty over planned policy changes. The currency had slipped from high levels, but rebounded after the appointment of a well-regarded former central banker as the new governor of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. Robertson stated that the government aims for a sustainable exchange rate that benefits exporters, but does not set specific targets for the exchange rate. The New Zealand dollar was up 0.11% against the US dollar at $0.6990.

site_title: Fur flies in Hollywood as Disney goes Fox hunting
summary: Disney has agreed to acquire key film and television assets from 21st Century Fox in a $52.4 billion deal, uniting two of the "big six" Hollywood studios under one umbrella. The acquisition is expected to reshape the filmmaking landscape and challenge Netflix and emerging rivals in the streaming wars. Disney will take over Fox's prestigious movie distribution businesses and gain control of streaming service Hulu. The deal also includes Fox's FX and National Geographic cable channels, as well as movies such as The Revenant and the Avatar franchise. Regulatory approval may not come until 2019, raising concerns about the health of the film industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.93 points to 1,755.07. Volume was 79.43 million lots worth RM21.78 million, with 96 gainers and 65 losers.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS lifts Suntec to 'buy' on optimism about management, retail recovery
summary: DBS upgraded its rating on Suntec Reit to "buy" from "hold", citing confidence in management and a bright outlook for Singapore office rents. The broker raised its target price to S$2.30 from S$1.95, citing improved foot traffic and tenant sales at Suntec Mall under new CEO Chan Kong Leong. A potential recovery in the Singapore retail scene and sustained growth in office rents also support the upgrade. DBS predicts a multi-year upturn in the Singapore office market and lower capital support for Suntec Reit.

site_title: Gold dips, off one-week high after strong US data
summary: Gold prices dipped 0.03% to $1,255.77 per ounce, easing off a one-week high, after strong US retail sales data boosted the dollar. US retail sales increased more than expected in November, with gold prices rallying to $1,256.87 on Wednesday after the Fed raised interest rates. Palladium rose to its highest since February 2001, while platinum and silver fell. The dollar's rebound made dollar-denominated bullion more expensive for holders of other currencies, reducing gold's appeal.

site_title: Why the world should be grateful for Donald Trump: commentary
summary: The article argues that despite Donald Trump's divisive presidency, he has expedited a confrontation with uncomfortable realities, including racism, sexism, and climate change. Trump's lack of inhibition and tact has forced Americans to confront these issues, potentially leading to a new age of progressivism. The article credits Trump with unmasking a decaying social, political, and economic system, and notes that his opponents must develop new strategies to address these issues. Ultimately, the author concludes that Trump's presidency has been a necessary jolt, and he deserves gratitude for this overdue awakening.

site_title: China steel prices sag further, but low stockpiles cap losses
summary: China's rebar steel futures dropped for a second session, falling due to slowing demand over winter and reduced construction activity. Despite lower prices, multi-year low stockpiles limited losses. China's steel output declined to a nine-month low in November due to state-ordered production curbs to limit pollution.

site_title: European car sales rise as economy helps car makers Peugeot, Toyota
summary: European car sales jumped 5.8% in November to 1.26 million vehicles, the highest annual delivery volume in a decade, driven by new SUVs from Peugeot, Citroen, Toyota, and Kia. Economic growth and low interest rates are fueling demand, with 11-month sales reaching 14.5 million cars. The region is expected to post its highest annual delivery volume in a decade, following a comeback from the global recession and sovereign debt crises.

site_title: Hoffman accused of exposing himself to 16-year-old
summary: Actor Dustin Hoffman has been accused of exposing himself to a 16-year-old high school friend of his daughter in 1980, and of assaulting two women on the set of the 1987 movie Ishtar. The accusations come amid a growing wave of sexual misconduct allegations in the entertainment industry, following the scandal surrounding Harvey Weinstein. Hoffman's lawyer has labeled the accounts as "defamatory falsehoods." The allegations bring the total number of women accusing Hoffman of harassment to six.

site_title: ANA seeking Myanmar venture after two failed attempts since 2014
summary: ANA Holdings Inc is attempting to set up a venture in Myanmar for the third time, following previous efforts that collapsed in 2014 and 2016. The airline believes a surge in international travel from Myanmar, driven by economic growth, will create opportunities. ANA's CEO, Shinya Katanozaka, stated the company will find a new partner and launch the venture during its new five-year plan, set to be announced in February. This marks ANA's latest attempt to tap into Myanmar's growing economy and capitalize on the country's emerging middle class.

images.alt_text: "We're going to find a new partner again," Shinya Katanozaka, chief executive officer of ANA Holdings, said in Tokyo on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong's Li & Fung set to open up 6.6% on US$1.1b divestment
summary: Hong Kong-based Li & Fung Ltd announced plans to divest its furniture, beauty, and sweaters businesses for $1.1 billion, with the stock set to open up 6.6% on Friday. The divestment aims to improve the company's capital structure and focus on growth segments. Li & Fung will pay a special dividend of $520 million to shareholders. Analysts at UBS maintain a "buy" rating, citing the potential benefits of the divestment for the company's future growth.

site_title: Asian markets slip with Wall Street as tax reform fears bite
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, following a sell-off on Wall Street, amid concerns over US tax reform. The Nikkei fell 0.9% despite Japan's business confidence reaching an 11-year high. The euro struggled to recover from a disappointing European Central Bank meeting. Traders fear US lawmakers will fail to pass tax cuts, putting the Republican majority at risk. Global markets had rallied earlier this year on hopes of tax cuts and economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.57% to 3,416.29
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.57% to 3,416.29 on Friday, with 78 stocks losing value compared to 44 gainers. The European Central Bank raised its growth forecast but maintained quantitative easing policy steady, contributing to the decline. Active index stocks, such as DBS Group Holdings and Singtel, also decreased 1.2% and 0.3% respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which is expected to be released soon.

site_title: UK housing market stagnates as London price drop continues
summary: The UK housing market remains stagnant, with a national gauge slipping to zero in November, indicating no change in prices. London is a weak spot, with the most negative current reading, and respondents report downward pressure on prices in several regions. Brexit uncertainty and the Bank of England's interest-rate hike are cited as reasons for sluggish sales. House-price growth has cooled this year, and a recent report predicts London's property market will fall another 2% in 2018.

site_title: Theresa May asks EU to be creative when Brexit talks turn to trade
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May urged European leaders to be creative and make speedy progress in agreeing to a transition period after the UK leaves the EU in 2019. During a dinner meeting in Brussels, May emphasized the need for certainty for businesses in the UK and across the EU. She prioritized agreement on the implementation period, stating it would bring greater certainty and move the Brexit talks towards a more ambitious phase. May expressed her desire to reach a deal, saying it was in the best interests of both the UK and the EU.

site_title: Turning coal into bitcoin? Dirty secret of 2017's hottest market
summary: Bitcoin's rapid growth in 2017 was fueled by massive energy use from coal-powered servers in China, a "dirty secret" behind the cryptocurrency's creation. A server farm in northern China, operated by Bitmain Technologies Ltd, uses electricity from coal to power 25,000 computers solving encrypted calculations for each bitcoin. This practice contributes to significant pollution, raising concerns about the environmental impact of cryptocurrency mining.

site_title: Facebook moves to make more video ad money
summary: Facebook plans to test showing short ads before videos on its 'Watch' section, similar to YouTube. The move aims to bolster the platform's appeal and revenue. Pre-roll ads will be shown before videos, while ad breaks will remain in videos lasting over three minutes. Facebook will also update its News Feed content ranking system to prioritize videos from popular publishers or creators. The update is part of CEO Mark Zuckerberg's prediction that video will dominate the platform in a few years.

site_title: Euro steadies at 1-week high as ECB stands pat
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its stance on monetary policy, reiterating its commitment to bond purchases until the end of September and keeping reinvested cash in the market to support growth and inflation. The euro steadied at a one-week high against the dollar, rising 2.5% over the last month. This move contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged, despite a tax bill that may boost the US economy. The euro's performance is attributed to growth expectations overtaking other drivers for the currency.

site_title: May heads to EU summit after Brexit defeat by her own party
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is attending an EU summit after her party's vote to add a "meaningful vote" on the final Brexit deal, a reversal of her original plan. The legislation guarantees a parliamentary vote on the final Brexit deal by the end of 2019, potentially altering the UK's exit timeline. The vote increases the likelihood of the Commons rejecting May's deal next October or November, but few expect her to lose her job, instead suggesting a less dramatic exit than initially feared.

site_title: Japan, UK eye post-Brexit mutual recognition of trade standards
summary: Japan and the UK aim to swiftly agree on mutual recognition of each other's trade standards after the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. The two countries seek to cement their relationship, with Japan being a key investor in Britain's auto and energy sectors. A mutual recognition agreement would simplify trade processes and prevent technical barriers, with Japan's companies having invested over $72 billion in Britain. The UK's Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson, and Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Kono expressed confidence in reaching a deal, which would be specific to the UK.

site_title: US House Speaker Ryan eyeing exit from Congress: report
summary: US House Speaker Paul Ryan, 47, may be leaving Congress by year's end, according to Politico. Despite denying the report, Ryan's hesitation in taking the top congressional job in 2015 and his critical stance on Donald Trump have raised speculation about his future. The White House has expressed dissatisfaction with the news, and some Republicans are anticipating a leadership battle. Ryan's departure could diminish his deal-making leverage and ability to raise money for the party, potentially setting off a scramble for a successor.

images.alt_text: Paul Ryan may be in his final term as speaker of the US House of Representatives and could leave Congress by year end, Politico reported on Thursday, in a report that could set off a scramble for a successor.

site_title: Europe: Shares lag Wall Street, ECB provides no momentum
summary: European shares declined 0.46% on Thursday, lagging US stocks, despite the European Central Bank's positive growth and inflation forecasts. The ECB kept interest rates on hold, failing to provide momentum. European banking stocks fell 0.6%, while Italy's FTSE MIB dropped 0.9% due to political worries. Most sectors were negative, with consumer staples and healthcare stocks also declining. Vestas Wind and Siemens Gamesa rose 7% and 3.5%, respectively, due to the US tax reform package.

site_title: Target to buy Shipt for US$550m as it steps up challenge to Amazon
summary: Target agreed to purchase grocery-delivery startup Shipt for US$550 million, expanding its same-day shipping capabilities. The deal will allow Target customers to order online and have items delivered from nearby stores. This move increases Target's challenge to Amazon's grocery delivery business, with the company aiming to speed up its rollout of same-day shipping. The acquisition is expected to enhance Target's online grocery shopping experience and compete with Amazon's growing presence in the market.

site_title: S Korea plans shift to renewables, but coal, nuclear to remain strong
summary: South Korea aims to gradually shift its power generation mix to renewables and natural gas, aiming for 20% of electricity to come from renewables by 2030. Despite efforts to boost renewables and natural gas, coal and nuclear power will still dominate the mix, with nuclear power expected to decline only after the mid-2020s. The country plans to increase consumption taxes on thermal coal and work on other ways to cap coal power generation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: TMC Education, LHN, KTL Global, United Engineers
summary: TMC Education Corp: Koh Wee Meng, a property tycoon, offers S$0.0675 per share in a general offer for the private education company, planning to retain listed status and review business strategy. LHN: May raise up to HK$99.1 million through a Hong Kong offering. KTL Global: Under investigation by Monetary Authority of Singapore over a possible Securities and Futures Act offence. United Engineers: Made a pre-conditional voluntary unconditional cash offer of S$2.07 per share for WBL Corp shares.

site_title: New twist to old favourites
summary: Hua Ting, a Singapore restaurant, has undergone a renovation. The revamped space allows diners to choose between reasonably priced and luxurious options, ensuring a satisfying meal regardless of choice. The restaurant is open daily from 11.30am to 2.30pm and 6pm to 10.30pm at Level 2, Orchard Hotel, 442 Orchard Road.

site_title: Oil prices up slightly on pipeline outage support
summary: Oil prices rose almost 1% on Thursday, driven by a pipeline outage in Britain and a fire at a US refinery, despite data predicting a global crude surplus in the first half of 2018. The Forties pipeline outage, which is expected to last several weeks, has supported prices. US crude futures settled up 44 cents to $57.04 a barrel, while Brent crude futures remained steady at $62.44 a barrel. The International Energy Agency expects a balanced market in 2018, but prices remain supported by tight market conditions.

site_title: Investors pour cash into US shale despite questions on returns
summary: Investors continue to pour money into US shale oil despite concerns over returns. The US is on track to deliver up to 80% of the world's oil-production gains by 2025, according to the International Energy Agency. Financial levers, such as production hedging and new financing vehicles like DrillCos, are helping producers maintain drilling operations. Hedge funds and private equity firms are providing capital, with private equity firms investing $20.26 billion in energy-related deals this year. Producers are touting efficiency gains and efforts to shed less productive shale acreage as evidence that they can lift returns and output simultaneously.

site_title: Going back to one's roots
summary: A recent dinner featured a selection of Bordeaux classics, including Chateau Troplong Mondot 2000 en magnum, Chateau La Mission Haut Brion 2000, and Chateau Latour 2004. These wines showcased the richness and complexity of Bordeaux, with the 2004 Latour being described as a "classic true-blue Bordeaux at its best." In contrast, a Napa Valley wine, Pluribus 2011, was found to be overly rich and lacking in backbone, highlighting the differences between classic Bordeaux and modern Napa Valley styles. The dinner served as a reminder of the enduring appeal of Bordeaux wines.

site_title: Airbus board to meet in pivotal review of CEO, bribe charges
summary: Airbus' board is set to meet amid bribery allegations, with CEO Tom Enders' future uncertain. Enders may not seek a third term, sparking a leadership contest. The company faces hefty fines and sluggish demand for its A380 model. Airbus shares fell 1.1% after the report, but have advanced 37% this year. The board will consider the impact of potential settlements and the timing of a potential leadership change, with candidates including Patrice Caine and Thierry Breton.

site_title: Property agents roped in to fight money laundering, terror funding
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) has introduced mandatory checklists for real estate agencies and salespersons to combat money laundering and financing of terrorism in property transactions. Starting immediately, salespersons must complete a customer due diligence checklist for every property transaction and submit it to their agencies, which will then be inspected by the CEA. This move aims to enhance the know-your-customer procedures in the industry.

site_title: US: Stocks decline on reports of tax cut opposition
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday as reports of congressional opposition to the tax cut plan and worries about lofty equity valuations ended the Dow's four-day record streak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% to 24,508.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes lost 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively. The decline was partly offset by strong US retail sales and positive earnings announcements from 21st Century Fox and Teva Pharmaceuticals.

site_title: Netflix is less noisy defender of net neutrality as vote arrives
summary: Netflix, once a strong advocate for net neutrality, has become less outspoken as the rules are set to be repealed. The company's growth to a $12 billion online video provider has reduced its reliance on the regulations. Other major web companies, such as Google and Facebook, have also become more powerful and less dependent on net neutrality. The FCC's vote is expected to pass, favoring internet service providers and potentially creating a less diverse internet. The decision is a significant milestone in a decade-long debate over the internet's impact on established communications networks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Goodland Group subscribed for a 17% stake in SL Capital (3) Pte Ltd, while KTL Global received a notice from the Monetary Authority of Singapore regarding an investigation into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The MAS has requested access to KTL Global's bank accounts and accounting documents.

site_title: ESR-Reit acquires property in Ang Mo Kio
summary: ESR-Reit has acquired an 80% interest in a leasehold property in Ang Mo Kio, Singapore, for S$240 million. The 1.07 million sq ft property has a 91.9% occupancy rate and is ESR-Reit's largest acquisition to date. The acquisition was funded by internal cash resources and debt facilities. The company also plans to issue up to 263 million new units to rebalance its capital structure. This follows recent acquisitions, boosting the portfolio value by 31.4% to S$1.75 billion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singapore wins race to house Neste's new renewable diesel plant
summary: Neste, an energy giant, has chosen Singapore as the location for its new large-scale renewable diesel plant. The decision was made after a thorough assessment of the US and Singapore as potential locations. The new facility, which will expand Neste's capacity to three million tonnes by 2020, will produce renewable diesel, aviation fuel, and raw materials for biochemical uses. The project is expected to begin production in 2022, with a final investment decision by the end of 2018.

site_title: Vivienne Tam scales style peaks with China Chic
summary: Vivienne Tam, a 60-year-old Chinese fashion designer, shares her life lessons and career journey in her book "China Chic". Born in Guangzhou, China, Tam began designing clothing at age eight, inspired by her mother who made clothes to save money. She founded her company, Vivienne Tam, in 1982 and staged her first show at New York Fashion Week with her own money, after saving for five years. Tam emphasizes the importance of being humble, passionate, and remembering where you come from, and advises against judging others' worth by price alone.

site_title: US retail sales increase strongly in November
summary: US retail sales increased 0.8% in November, exceeding economists' expectations, as the holiday shopping season started strongly. This points to sustained economic strength. The data also revised October's sales gain to 0.5% from 0.2%.

site_title: Oxley buys Chevron House, Vista Park, stake in Vietnam project in deals totalling over S$1b
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singaporean property developer, has acquired three properties in under 24 hours, totaling over S$1 billion. The deals include Chevron House for S$660 million, a 32-storey office building, and a collective sale site in Vista Park for S$418 million. Oxley also acquired a stake in a residential project in Vietnam for an undisclosed amount. The acquisitions demonstrate the company's expansion plans in the Singapore and Vietnamese markets.

site_title: Showcasing the bounty of Japan's Ishikawa
summary: Ishikawa, a Japanese prefecture, showcased its bounty at a high-end dinner hosted by Kenjiro "Hatch" Hashida's restaurant in Singapore. The dinner featured local seafood, including Koubako crab, and paired with Ishikawa's famous Tengumai sake from Shata Brewery. The prefecture aims to raise awareness of its produce and attractions, such as hot springs and ceramic craftsmanship, to attract visitors. Ishikawa's Tengumai sake, brewed using natural lactic acid, is a rare and labor-intensive method that produces a unique flavor profile. The prefecture's efforts highlight its diverse offerings beyond Tokyo's Tsukiji market.

site_title: Rakuten wants to become Japan's 4th wireless carrier
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce firm, plans to apply for a 4G mobile licence, aiming to become Japan's fourth major wireless carrier. The move is seen as a strategic shift to gain customers, complementing its e-commerce, streaming, and fintech services. Analysts warn of an uphill battle, but Rakuten believes mobile devices will be a key user touchpoint for expanding services. The company hopes to leverage its existing services to gain new customers and drive growth.

site_title: MiFID II will not affect SGX stocks dual-listed in Europe: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has clarified that MiFID II, a European Union financial markets regulation, will not affect Singapore Exchange (SGX) stocks dual-listed in Europe. Trading in these stocks primarily occurs on SGX, thus exempting them from the EU trading obligation. The EU has declared MiFID II equivalence for dual listings in the US, Australia, and Hong Kong, but not for Singapore. EU counterparties can continue to trade SGX-listed shares without restriction.

site_title: Marco Polo wins support for new share issuance
summary: Marco Polo Marine has secured a 98.64% approval vote and 99.94% majority vote at its extraordinary general meeting for two share issuance schemes, clearing the last hurdle for its restructuring plan. The company's controlling shareholder, Lee Wan Tang, and his family have abstained from voting due to related party concerns, but will dilute their shareholding to 6% to pave the way for the new equity injection. The restructuring aims to restructure under two schemes of arrangement filed with Singapore's High Court.

site_title: Climate change and sustainability disclosure is important
summary: Singapore-listed companies CDL, Olam, Singtel, and SGX have endorsed the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations, recognizing the increasing importance of climate change considerations in business decisions. The TCFD's four widely adoptable recommendations allow companies to provide specific climate-related disclosures in their financial filings, enabling them to address climate-related risks and opportunities. DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has also joined the initiative, underscoring the impact of climate change on Singapore companies.

site_title: Bumper crop of new drugs fails to lift big pharma R&D returns
summary: Deloitte reports that the projected returns at 12 top drugmakers have fallen to an 8-year low of 3.2% due to a bumper crop of new drugs. The US FDA has approved 41 novel drugs this year, compared to 22 in 2016. Despite a surge in approvals, research investment returns are down, indicating a challenging year for big pharma.

site_title: Co-working space startup WeWork calls Funan home
summary: WeWork, a co-working space startup, has leased 40,000 sq ft of space in Funan, its third Singapore location. The space will feature smart office facilities, including facial recognition turnstiles and video-based smart car-parking. WeWork plans to use the Singapore spaces as a gateway to its regional expansion into other South-east Asian markets. The Funan development, set for completion in 2019, will also feature retail space, office blocks, and amenities such as a cinema, gym, and rock-climbing facility.

site_title: Extra S$8b worth of liquidity tied up due to poor working capital performance: study
summary: A joint study by PwC Singapore and Spring Singapore found that 8 out of 15 sectors in Singapore have poor working capital performance, tying up an additional S$8.7 billion in liquidity. The main issues are slow cash collection and inventory increases, while some sectors, such as energy & chemicals, are struggling to manage receivables and inventory. The study also found that company size matters, with very large companies performing best and medium-sized companies struggling the most. The study advises businesses to improve cash management to mitigate risks and fund growth plans.

site_title: Facing the challenges of ethics and trust in an AI-driven world
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is consulting with the financial industry on potential ethical pitfalls in AI and data analytics, raising concerns about the impact on the accountancy sector and profession. The consultation may lead to regulatory guidelines, as the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) has been monitoring the issue. Ethics is a key aspect of the accountancy profession, with the public and clients trusting professionals to adhere to high standards of ethical behavior.

site_title: BP's plan to buy Australian petrol pump network blocked
summary: BP's plan to buy a network of Australian petrol stations from Woolworths has been blocked by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission due to concerns it will lead to higher fuel prices. The ACCC stated that BP's prices are significantly higher than Woolworths in major cities and that it hikes petrol costs faster and discounts it more slowly. As a result, fuel prices are likely to increase at the Woolworths sites, putting less competitive pressure on other retailers.

site_title: China raises market rates to fend off financial risks; growth moderates
summary: China's central bank raised market rates to mitigate financial risks without harming the economy. This move, part of a government crackdown on high-risk lending and polluting factories, signals a tighter policy stance for next year. The country's GDP growth has started to cool, with data showing a moderation in output and investment property. The People's Bank of China's decision comes after a US Federal Reserve rate hike, indicating a balancing act between economic stability and financial risks.

site_title: Make Christmas personal and buy for good, in BTWeekend
summary: Christmas is approaching, and homeowners are decorating their homes with festive trimmings. The article features four homes with personal holiday decor, traditional Christmas dishes from around the world, and limited-edition timepieces. It also explores the rise of responsible consumerism and the importance of attending office parties, despite their work-related nature. Additionally, the article looks back on an action-packed year in sports and introduces a Kia car model that aims to overcome badge snobbery.

site_title: ComfortDelGro-Uber tie-up suggests more consolidation
summary: ComfortDelGro has formed a 51% stake in Uber's rental car business in Singapore, Lion City Holdings, valued at S$642 million. This deal marks a significant consolidation in the transport sector, with ComfortDelGro's taxis and Lion City's private-hire cars to be managed under a centralized fleet system. The partnership suggests taxis may no longer be a direct competitor to ridehailing companies like Uber, and could lead to investments in bike-sharing services to enhance first- and last-mile connectivity.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust says Kim Seng Holdings' right of first refusal has ceased
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) managers stated that Kim Seng Holdings' (KSH) right of first refusal has ceased due to KSH's loss of controlling shareholder status. KSH had granted the right of first refusal to VIT for income-producing real estate, but as of the current date, there are no relevant assets subject to the right. KSH shareholder Tan Kim Seng will remain as a non-executive director, and the trust does not expect the cessation to have a material impact on its net tangible assets and distribution.

site_title: Singtel's Optus acquires spectrum in Australia
summary: Optus, Singtel's Australian unit, has acquired A$6.5 million (S$6.7 million) worth of new metropolitan licences for customers in the 2300 MHz and 3500 MHz spectrum bands in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Adelaide. The acquisition complements Optus' 3500MHz metro holdings and strengthens its position in the race towards 5G. The new spectrum will ensure Optus is prepared for the significant changes 5G will bring, with the company already covering 96.5% of the Australian population with its 4G mobile network.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Japan's ruling bloc approves corporate tax cut to encourage wage hikes
summary: Japan's ruling bloc approved a plan to slash the corporate tax rate to around 20% from 30% for companies that raise wages and boost domestic capital spending. The proposal, effective for three years, aims to stimulate consumer spending and combat deflation. However, analysts are skeptical that the tax breaks will prompt firms to spend on higher worker pay, citing concerns about Japan's shrinking population and low growth prospects. The plan, part of a broader tax code revision, also includes tax hikes and new taxes to pay for a bulging welfare bill.

site_title: November retail sales surpass expectations
summary: US retail sales rose 0.8% in November, exceeding expectations, and accelerated 5.8% on an annual basis. This strong performance suggests sustained economic strength, potentially paving the way for further interest rate hikes in 2018. Additionally, the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits dropped to a 44½-year low, supporting the Fed's assessment of a "rising at a solid rate" economy.

site_title: Delta said to favour Airbus over Boeing for order of 100 jets
summary: Delta Air Lines is leaning towards ordering Airbus's A321neo jets for an estimated $13 billion, surpassing Boeing's 737 Max 10 in the deal. This would mark a victory for Airbus in the negotiations for about 100 single-aisle jets. The decision is expected after Delta's board makes a choice, pending a final agreement.

site_title: Veteran German banker to become head of UBS wealth management
summary: Veteran German banker Martin Blessing will replace Juerg Zeltner as head of UBS's wealth management business, effective at the turn of the year. Blessing, 54, has run UBS's Swiss business since 2016 and is now in pole position to succeed CEO Sergio Ermotti. The move is seen as a strategic step, following UBS's 16% pretax profit boost in the third quarter. Blessing will be succeeded by Axel Lehmann, with Sabine Keller-Busse taking over as COO and HR head. Blessing's appointment has sparked speculation about his potential succession to Ermotti.

site_title: Transforming industries through innovation
summary: The world is undergoing rapid transformation due to exponential technological advancements, leading to improved quality of life and sustainability. Companies are embracing disruption and developing adaptable employees with digital skills, international expertise, and multidisciplinary skillsets. The Singapore government has launched a S$4.5 billion industry transformation program to drive innovation and create value for its members. Industry leaders are recognizing the need for collaboration and strategic partnerships to drive growth and solve real-world problems. Disruptive technologies are becoming increasingly prevalent, and businesses must adapt to stay ahead, with some companies already leveraging autonomous robots and artificial intelligence to improve operational efficiency.

site_title: A fitting farewell for Janet Yellen
summary: Janet Yellen's final Federal Reserve meeting as chairwoman concluded with a modest rate hike, marking the third increase of the year and the fifth of the current rate hiking cycle. The move was met with minimal market disruption, with most traders focusing on the Fed's upgraded view of 2018 economic growth prospects. The central bank's dovish stance on inflation and rate hikes sent yields lower, leading to a sell-off in the dollar. Yellen's comments on digital currency bitcoin and her frank assessment of biotech stocks were notable, with some investors speculating that Jerome Powell's successor will be more market-friendly, but likely to follow a similar path.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.34 points to 1,759.00, driven by gains from the sector. Volume reached 2.43 billion shares worth RM3.26 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 631-328.

site_title: Eurozone revival exceeds expectations, but chronic structural, cyclical issues remain
summary: The eurozone economy has exceeded expectations with 2.6% average growth in 2017, despite chronic structural and cyclical issues. Key nations such as Ireland, Spain, and Germany experienced faster growth, while Italy and Greece recovered but grew below 2%. However, eurozone nations' GDPs remain below pre-2007/2008 levels, and unemployment remains high, particularly among young people. State austerity measures and quantitative easing policies have contributed to stagnant wage growth and rising inequality.

site_title: Insurance key in the growth of an on-demand economy
summary: The On-Demand Economy (ODE), also known as the sharing economy, has disrupted traditional businesses over the past three years. Characterized by instant access to goods and services without ownership or long-term commitment, ODE platforms such as Grab, Go-Jek, and Uber have emerged as a global movement shaping the economy and influencing industries like transportation, travel, and retail. Technological and demographic shifts have driven the rise of ODE, with consumers increasingly using internet and mobile technologies to access goods and services without burden.

site_title: Temasek unit, Canadia to launch digital wallet and payment platform in Cambodia
summary: Temasek-owned Fullerton Financial Holdings has partnered with Canadia Investment Holding plc to launch DaraPay, a digital wallet and payment platform in Cambodia. By mid-2018, DaraPay aims to have over 1,000 affiliated merchants, allowing customers to make cashless payments. The platform expects to have 2,600 agents by the end of 2019, providing convenient, low-cost, and seamless services across Cambodia. The move seeks to capitalize on Cambodia's growth in digital payments, with a vision to make DaraPay a key enabler in the retail environment.

site_title: Bought apple stock in 1980? Held it? Don't gloat
summary: Apple went public in 1980 with an initial public offering (IPO) of $22 per share, raising $100 million. Thirty-seven years later, the company's market capitalization has reached $900 billion. Investing in Apple stock at the IPO price would have been worth $632,800 by 2015, a 28,663% gain. However, the article suggests that holding onto Apple stock for more than two decades was necessary to see the company's success, as the stock price sank to 27 cents after Steve Jobs left in 1985.

site_title: IBM taps banks, tech firms in quantum computer push
summary: IBM has selected 12 prominent banks and tech firms, including JPMorgan Chase, Barclays Bank, and Samsung Electronics, to participate in its early access Q Network programme for a 20-qubit quantum computer. The programme will allow companies to experiment with the cloud-based technology, which can theoretically perform over one million calculations per second, but still produces errors. The companies plan to use quantum computers for applications such as trading strategies, material development, and manufacturing processes.
