IBM is competing with other companies like Google, Microsoft, and D-Wave Systems to commercialize the technology, which is still too small and error-prone for most real-world applications.

site_title: US dollar suffers fresh losses as Fed fails to inspire
summary: The US dollar suffered fresh losses after the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, with Asian investors shifting out of the unit despite the central bank's upbeat assessment of the US economy. The dollar fell against most currencies, including the yen, pound, and euro, while other currencies such as the Australian and South Korean won surged. Market analysts attributed the dollar's weakness to a dovish hike and concerns over the Fed's rate projections, as well as the Republicans' loss in the Alabama senate election.

site_title: China November output slows as skies clear
summary: China's industrial output slowed to 6.1% in November, its second-lowest reading since 2016, as the government's war on polluting factories and coal-burning furnaces took effect. The slowdown was partly due to factories in the north halting production until March, while fixed-asset investment grew at its slowest annual pace in 20 years. Despite this, other economic indicators performed well, including retail sales and new construction starts. The government is expected to set a lower GDP growth target for 2018, with some analysts predicting a slowdown in real GDP growth.

images.alt_text: The Shanghai Waigaoqiao Power Generator Company coal power plant in Shanghai. Much of China's factories in the north have had to halt all or part of their production until March.

site_title: SIA receives first of five new retrofitted A380s
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has received its first of five new retrofitted Airbus A380s, featuring updated Suites and Business Class cabins. The aircraft will operate flights to Sydney on December 18, with London potentially as its second destination. The airline has invested $850 million to upgrade the A380s, which will now have 471 seats across four classes. SIA plans to deliver four more A380s by the third quarter of next year, with existing planes to be retrofitted by 2020.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Passengers in the Business class during Singapore Airlines A380 delivery flight from Toulouse to Singapore. The plane is fitted with 471 seats across four classes, of which 78 are Business class (above).

site_title: MAS requests access to documents from KTL Global over ongoing investigation
summary: MAS has requested access to documents from KTL Global for an ongoing investigation into an alleged offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation focuses on KTL Global's bank accounts, accounting documents, and proceeds from a private placement deal in 2015. KTL Global has stated that the business operations are unaffected and will cooperate fully with the investigation. No further details on the investigation have been disclosed by MAS.

site_title: ECB ups growth forecasts but keeps easy money pledge
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised its growth and inflation forecasts for the euro area, predicting 2.4% growth in 2017, 2.3% in 2018, 1.9% in 2019, and 1.7% in 2020. However, the ECB maintained its pledge to provide stimulus for as long as needed, despite the eurozone recovery's strength, and kept interest rates unchanged. Inflation is expected to remain below target into 2020.

site_title: Delta chooses Airbus over Boeing in $12.7b jet deal
summary: Delta Air Lines has ordered 100 Airbus A321neo jets worth $12.7 billion, beating Boeing in a major deal. Deliveries will start in early 2020, replacing Delta's aging planes. This decision comes after a trade dispute involving Bombardier's C Series, with Boeing facing 300% duties on the Canadian plane. The Airbus jets will be powered by Pratt & Whitney engines, replacing the carrier's McDonnell Douglas MD-90, Boeing 757, and Airbus A320 aircraft.

site_title: Disney to buy Fox film, TV businesses for US$52.4b in stock
summary: Disney agreed to buy 21st Century Fox's film, TV, and international businesses for $52.4 billion in stock. The deal includes Twentieth Century Fox movie and cable networks, and Disney will assume $13.7 billion of Fox's net debt. CEO Bob Iger will extend his tenure through 2021 to oversee the integration.

site_title: SGX stocks dual-listed in Europe will not be affected by Mifid II: MAS
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) stocks dual-listed in Europe will not be affected by MiFID II regulations, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Trading in these stocks primarily occurs on the SGX, and the EU trading obligation only applies if trading in the EU constitutes a significant percentage of global trading volume. Stocks such as Jardine Matheson Holdings and Hongkong Land are exempt from the regulation due to their primary trading on the SGX.

site_title: 17,000 BTO flats to be launched in 2018, keeping supply steady
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced that around 17,000 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats will be launched in 2018, maintaining a steady supply similar to 2017. These flats will be available in mature and non-mature towns, including Tengah, with shorter wait times of 2.5 years. The government has also introduced measures to help first-timer families, such as increased CPF Housing Grants and rental subsidies. The BTO supply figure is considered a "safe approach" due to the introduction of the Re-offer of Balance Flats exercise, allowing the authorities to monitor these schemes.

site_title: Tax overhaul could be big win for US real estate investors
summary: US commercial real estate is expected to benefit from the Republican tax overhaul, with a new tax break for "pass-through" entities potentially spurring new investment and increasing demand for rental housing. The 20% deduction for pass-throughs, which account for 61% of US commercial real estate investment, could lead to increased property values and rental income. However, the House bill's reduction of the top tax rate on pass-through income to 25% may limit the boon. The Senate bill's provision tying the deduction to wages could benefit real estate investment trusts.

site_title: CEReit's stabilising manager behind a third of volume since IPO
summary: Cromwell European Reit's stabilising manager, UBS, has purchased 27.89 million units since the trust's IPO on November 30, accounting for one third of the counter's trading volume. The purchases, which include 1.795 million units bought on Wednesday, have helped support the market price and accounted for 58.4% of the counter's trading volume. The units were bought at between 0.54 and 0.55 euro apiece, and UBS has used up 61.4% of its mandate to buy up to 45.454 million units for stabilising action.

site_title: China's new home sales in Nov rebound
summary: China's new home sales rebounded in November, with sales by value increasing 12.4% from a year earlier to 1.02 trillion yuan (S$204 billion). This marks the largest gain in five months, despite government efforts to curb property demand. The rebound is attributed to loosened financing restrictions for developers, which has led to a surge in new starts and investment in real estate development, growing 4.6% year-over-year. Analysts predict a decline in sales next year due to excessive leverage and ongoing curbs on purchases.

site_title: Oxley Holdings awarded Vista Park collective sale at S$418m
summary: Oxley Holdings has been awarded the collective sale of Vista Park in South Buona Vista Road at S$418 million, or S$1,096 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, zoned for residential use, has a 1.4 plot ratio and a 319,250 sq ft site with a 60-year lease. The sale price includes an estimated S$72 million payable to the state to top up the site's lease.

site_title: United Engineers offers to buy up rest of WBL
summary: United Engineers (UE) has made a pre-conditional voluntary unconditional cash offer to buy the remaining shares of WBL Corporation, which it already owns 67.59% of. The offer is final and will not be increased, with UE offering S$2.07 in cash for each WBL share. If the offer is accepted, UE will acquire the remaining shares, making WBL its wholly-owned subsidiary. The move follows Yanlord Land Group and Perennial Real Estate's acquisition of a one-third stake in UE earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CIMB Research estimates private home demand to reach 11,000-12,000 in 2018, with prices rising up to 5% due to replacement appetite and organic household formation. The office sub-sector is expected to support rental recovery, while the hotel industry may see a rate uplift of 2% by 2H18. OCBC Investment Research maintains "overweight" on developers and "neutral" on Reits, recommending UOL, CDL, FCT, FLT, and FEHT. The Singapore market has performed well in 2017, with the STI up 20% YTD, and valuations are expected to remain strong in 2018.

site_title: Bon Jovi leads 2018 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inductees
summary: Bon Jovi leads the 2018 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inductees, marking a historic milestone for the band after years of commercial success and fan devotion. The group, known for hits like "Runaway" and "Livin' on a Prayer," received over 1 million public votes, making it the first time a band has achieved this feat. Alongside Bon Jovi, Nina Simone, the Cars, Dire Straits, the Moody Blues, and Sister Rosetta Tharpe will be inducted at the 33rd ceremony on April 14, with Jon Bon Jovi expressing relief and pleasure at the recognition.

site_title: OUE H-Reit obtains S$980m facilities to partially refinance debt
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) has obtained S$980 million loan facilities to partially refinance its debt. The facilities, comprising two term loans and two revolvers, are provided by BNP Paribas, DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and Standard Chartered. The proceeds will be used to repay existing debt and for working capital. If the trust sponsor, OUE, ceases to own at least 51% of the Reit manager without prior consent, lenders may demand prepayment. The trust's net property income and distribution per stapled security increased in the third quarter, with units closing at S$0.835.

site_title: Fed rate hike dents USD; regional stocks hit by surprise BOC rate moves
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.25-1.5% in a widely anticipated move, citing faster economic growth and lower unemployment. This is the third rate hike this year and the fifth since 2008. Regional markets declined, with the Singapore dollar weakening against major currencies, as investors were unexcited about the rate hike. Analysts expect tempered flow through to Singapore rates, given expectations of rising local currency, and the global move towards interest rate normalization will have a trickle-down effect.

site_title: Bitcoin investors should be cautious, even if it is heading mainstream
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged from under $1,000 in January to over $16,700, with its market capitalization exceeding $280 billion. The launch of Bitcoin futures contracts by Cboe Global Markets and CME Group has helped bring the digital currency into mainstream markets. Despite warnings of a bubble, investors are diversifying into other cryptocurrencies, and fund managers are launching cryptocurrency funds. The US Securities and Exchange Commission remains cautious, but the availability of derivative instruments may lead to the creation of synthetic cryptocurrency exchange-traded funds, potentially attracting more retail investors.

site_title: China says war must not be allowed on Korean peninsula
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged against war on the Korean peninsula, stating that the issue must be resolved through talks. He expressed China's willingness to work with South Korea to prevent war and promote dialogue. Xi reiterated China's position on the Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (THAAD) anti-missile system, saying South Korea should "appropriately handle" the issue. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned of the danger of "sleepwalking" into conflict, emphasizing the need for Security Council unity and diplomatic engagement to resolve the issue.

site_title: FCL, FCOT buy UK business park for £174.6m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) and the manager of Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) have entered into a share purchase agreement to acquire Farnborough Business Park in the UK for £174.6m (S$314.8m). The 46.5-hectare business park has a 98.1% occupancy rate and is expected to be DPU accretive for FCOT. The acquisition marks FCOT's expansion into Europe, with an initial focus on the UK, and is expected to be completed by end-January 2018.

site_title: Housing slump gathers pace in Sweden with buyers losing faith
summary: Sweden's housing market continues to slump, with nationwide apartment prices declining 3% in November and house prices 1%. The market is struggling to absorb a supply glut, driven by stricter mortgage rules and growing apprehension among households. The decline in prices is attributed to increased competition among buyers, leading sellers to adjust prices downward. The Swedish krona has also weakened by almost 5% since August, with officials taking a hands-off approach to the cooling prices, citing natural fluctuations after years of rapid increases.

site_title: STI down 1% on China central bank hike
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.95% to 3,435.78, weighed down by Singtel and Keppel Corporation. The decline was largely due to a surprise move by China's central bank to raise borrowing costs, hours after the US Federal Reserve's decision to tighten monetary policy. Other regional markets also experienced losses, with key indices in Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea ending on a glum note.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as bank stocks gain
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by gains in bank stocks and news of the tax overhaul plan's final votes in Congress. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 47.07 points, or 0.19%, to 24,632.5, while the S&P 500 rose 3.62 points, or 0.135945%, to 2,666.47. The Nasdaq Composite added 11.39 points, or 0.17%, to 6,887.19. The gains came despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BOE holds interest rate, sticks to outlook for modest tightening
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) held interest rates steady at 0.5% on Thursday, as predicted by economists, following a rate hike in November. The decision was unanimous, with Governor Mark Carney's team citing two positive events for the economy, including the UK's Brexit negotiations and Chancellor Philip Hammond's Budget. The BOE reiterated that modest interest rate increases may be needed over the next few years to meet inflation targets, but markets don't expect another increase until late 2018. The pound was little changed after the decision.

site_title: ECB keeps policy, guidance unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy stance, keeping interest rates unchanged at record lows. The ECB will reduce monthly bond purchases to 30 billion euros from January, but stands ready to expand or lengthen purchases if inflation worsens. The bank's president, Mario Draghi, will unveil updated economic projections, including 2020 forecasts. Policymakers expect growth projections to be raised, with inflation likely to remain steady or moderately higher due to higher oil prices and a stable euro.

site_title: Singapore equities end lower on China central bank's surprise rate hike
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended lower by 0.95% on Thursday, closing at 3,435.78, due to a surprise rate hike by China's central bank. The benchmark index fell 32.99 points, with turnover valued at S$980.3 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 196 to 179. The rate hike followed the US Federal Reserve's rate hike, pushing regional markets into red territory.

site_title: Challenges ahead after Democrats' surprise win in Alabama
summary: The Democratic candidate Doug Jones won the special Senate election in Alabama, defeating Roy Moore. Despite the outcome, the article suggests that the result is largely inconsequential, as Alabama is a predominantly Republican state. The state's voting patterns have not shifted significantly, with the last Democrat elected to the Senate 25 years ago. The outcome may lead to increased rivalries and tension within the Republican party, potentially affecting future elections.

site_title: Debt-laden HNA met with Chinese banks for financing talks
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese debt-laden conglomerate, met with Chinese lenders for talks on financing in 2018 after borrowing costs surged. The company secured credit lines of over 800 billion yuan, with unused credit lines of 310 billion yuan. HNA's shares and bond prices rose following the meeting, with some analysts viewing it as a positive sign. However, concerns over refinancing and the company's opaque corporate structure remain, with experts warning that aggressive leverage and liquidity challenges pose risks.

site_title: Japan plans carrot-and-stick tax changes to drive wage gains
summary: Japan plans to boost pay for workers by providing tax benefits to companies that increase spending on wages and investment, while clamping down on firms that don't. Companies that raise pay by 3% or invest in human capital can reduce corporate income tax by up to 20%. The changes, effective from 2018 to 2020, aim to encourage investment and wage gains, but may not drive sustained increases in base wages.

site_title: The Force is strong with The Last Jedi
summary: The Last Jedi, directed by Rian Johnson, exceeded fan expectations with its blockbuster performance, earning praise for its action-packed battle scenes, elegantly-choreographed light saber duels, and nostalgic feel. The film's ambitious storyline juggles multiple plotlines, including Rey's training with Luke Skywalker, Finn and Rose's mission to track down a rogue code-breaker, and Poe's conflict with General Organa. The film delivers on its promise, with standout performances from Mark Hamill, Carrie Fisher, and Adam Driver. With its well-balanced mix of fan service and surprises, The Last Jedi is a thrilling ride that reinvigorates the Star Wars universe, making it a must-see for fans.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Malaysia issues draft regulations for crypto currency businesses
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has issued draft regulations for digital currency businesses, designating them as "reporting institutions" under the Anti-Money Laundering, Anti-Terrorism Financing and Proceeds of Unlawful Activities Act 2001. The regulations aim to secure the country against money-laundering and terrorism financing, but digital currencies remain not legal tender in Malaysia. The public is reminded that the guidelines are for consultation purposes only and do not authorize or endorse any entities involved in digital currency exchange services.

site_title: Singapore wins race to house new renewable diesel plant of energy giant Neste
summary: Neste, an energy giant, has decided to build a new renewable diesel plant in Singapore, after initially considering the US as a location. The decision was made after a thorough assessment of the two locations, with Singapore emerging as the preferred site. The new plant, which will expand Neste's capacity by one million tonnes, is expected to begin production in 2022 and will produce renewable diesel, aviation fuel, and biochemical raw materials. The project's cost and final investment decision are expected to be announced by the end of 2018.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to launch 17,000 BTO flats in 2018, including the first in Tengah town. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MPA) has pumped S$12m to promote Singapore's liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering. Singapore Airlines' new A380 arrives with revamped cabins, while half of Singapore's business sectors' working capital performance has worsened, according to a joint study. Neste has chosen Singapore to house its new renewable diesel plant. The STI ended lower on Thursday due to China's surprise rate hike, while a Malaysian agency is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets.

site_title: Short seller Jim Chanos says Tesla headed for 'brick wall'
summary: Investor Jim Chanos says Tesla is headed for a "brick wall" due to its over-saturation of the electric vehicle market. Chanos, president and founder of Kynikos Associates, has been shorting Tesla for over a year. He believes that while Tesla was a pioneer in making electric cars fun and attractive, others have now followed suit, reducing its competitive edge.

images.alt_text: Mr Chanos says that he also believes that Tesla is behind when it comes to self-driving vehicle technology.

site_title: Dassault to axe and relaunch Falcon 5X jet after engine delays
summary: Dassault Aviation is scrapping development of its Falcon 5X business jet due to engine delays and technical issues. The company will launch a new model, powered by Pratt & Whitney Canada engines, in 2022. The decision comes after repeated delays and a non-cash charge of 654 million euros from Safran, the supplier of the Silvercrest engine. Despite the setback, Dassault maintains a strong market need for a new long-range aircraft with a large cabin.

site_title: Goodland Group unit buys stake in buyer of Parkway Mansion
summary: Goodland Group, a property developer, has subscribed for a 17% stake in SL Capital (3) Pte Ltd (SLC3), a consortium led by Sustained Land Pte Ltd, following the acquisition of Parkway Mansion for S$146.99 million. The deal will be funded through internal resources and is expected to have minimal impact on Goodland Group's financials. This investment marks Goodland Group's entry into the residential development sector, expanding its portfolio.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Europe: Banks drag shares down as investors eye BoE, ECB meetings
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Thursday, dragged down by a weak bank sector, despite a US Federal Reserve rate hike, which is expected to boost lenders. Cautious comments from Chair Janet Yellen on low inflation also eroded investor confidence. Italy's FTSE MIB rose 0.3% due to resurfacing political worries. The US and Asian markets also saw a downbeat open, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's rate hike.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close lower on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index losing 0.28% to close at 22,694.45, and the Topix index down 0.15% to 1,808.14. The decline was attributed to a stronger yen, which shifted investor focus away from the US tax cut plan and the latest US rate hike.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts signs several deals to cut debt
summary: Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator, has signed deals to divest assets and cut debt, including selling a Las Vegas site for $300 million. The move comes after a decade-long retreat from Macau due to a Chinese crackdown on corruption. The company has also faced a class action lawsuit for allegedly failing to inform shareholders about a marketing campaign in China. By divesting assets, Crown Resorts aims to pay off debts and recover from recent setbacks.

site_title: PBOC raises market borrowing costs in surprise move after Fed
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), raised borrowing costs in a surprise move following the Federal Reserve's decision to tighten monetary policy. The PBOC increased rates by five basis points, with the one-year rate raised to 3.25%, to guide the cost of funding in financial markets and prevent excessive leverage. The move is seen as a cautious step towards tightening policy, with the PBOC citing the need to maintain reasonable expectations for interest rates and prevent financial institutions from expanding credit supply.

site_title: UE makes cash offer for rest of WBL
summary: United Engineers (UE) has made a pre-conditional voluntary unconditional cash offer for all WBL Corporation shares it doesn't already own, worth S$2.07 per share. The offer, made through a subsidiary, is subject to the approval of disinterested UE shareholders. The move follows Yanlord Land Group and Perennial Real Estate's acquisition of a one-third stake in UE earlier this year. The offer price is final and won't be increased, with a formal offer to be made upon the satisfaction of a pre-condition.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Shareholders give nod to Marco Polo's debt restructuring
summary: Marco Polo Marine has secured a majority vote at its extraordinary general meeting in favor of its debt restructuring plan. The company won 98.64% approval for issuing new securities to nine incoming investors and creditors, and 99.94% approval for issuing shares to RSM Corporate Advisory as settlement of professional fees. Marco Polo is seeking to restructure under two schemes of arrangement filed with Singapore's High Court and is awaiting approval from the Indonesian court for the restructuring of its Batam-based subsidiary.

site_title: Australia shares fall, ending 5 days of gains; NZ at record high
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.2% on Thursday, ending a five-day gain streak, due to financials and real estate stocks losing value. The S&P 500 declined slightly on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve announced an interest rate hike. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.47% to a record high, driven by broad-based gains in sectors such as consumer staples and materials.

site_title: Temasek unit, Canadia to launch digital wallet and payment platform in Cambodia
summary: Temasek-owned Fullerton Financial Holdings and Canadia Investment Holding plc have launched DaraPay, a digital wallet and payment platform in Cambodia. The platform, launched on December 11, 2017, has over 700 agents and aims to have 2,600 by the end of 2019. DaraPay enables customers to complete local remittances, loan repayments, and withdraw/deposit cash, with plans to expand to 1,000 affiliated merchants by mid-2018. The platform aims to provide convenient, low-cost, and seamless services across Cambodia, with a goal of becoming customers' preferred currency.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish in the red
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended in the red on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.19% to close at 29,166.38. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.32%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.04%. Investors brushed off a record close on Wall Street and the Federal Reserve's upbeat assessment of the US economy.

site_title: To fix inequality, look to EU-style policies: study
summary: A report by economists using data from over 100 researchers from 70 countries found that EU-style policies are best suited to reduce global inequality and poverty. The past 35 years have seen the global top 1% capture twice as much income growth as the bottom 50%. The World Inequality Report, led by Thomas Piketty, warns of a catastrophe if wealth concentration is left unchecked, calling for EU-style policies to address the issue.

site_title: European car sales rise as growing economy helps Peugeot, Toyota
summary: European car sales increased 5.8% in November to 1.26 million vehicles, driven by growing economic growth and new SUV offerings from Peugeot, Citroen, Toyota, and Kia. The European Automobile Manufacturers' Association reported a 4% gain in 11-month sales to 14.5 million autos. Strong demand for SUVs, fueled by low unemployment and economic growth, has prompted major manufacturers to add the models to their lineups. The UK saw a 11% decline in sales, while Germany, France, Italy, and Spain outpaced the region's growth rate.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank accused of more 'very serious' rule breaches
summary: Australia's financial intelligence agency expanded its anti-money laundering probe into Commonwealth Bank, alleging the lender failed to adequately monitor suspected terrorist financiers. The probe includes thousands of transactions and is separate from a civil case filed by Austrac in August. The probe's expansion comes after new claims that the bank engaged in "serious and systemic non-compliance" with anti-money laundering laws. The lender is the country's largest company by market capitalization.

site_title: World record in negative rates transforms a whole generation
summary: Denmark, the country with the longest history of negative interest rates, continues to defy the trend of other major central banks. After five years of negative rates, economists warn that households may become too accustomed to it, potentially forgetting the benefits of higher interest rates. Senior analyst Jens Naervig Pedersen at Danske Bank says the world looks fundamentally different from 10 years ago, and the main risk is that people may become too used to the norm of low interest rates. Denmark's experiment is set to continue for possibly three more years.

site_title: Latest Monsanto GMO seeds raises worries of monopoly
summary: Monsanto's new GMO seeds resistant to dicamba have raised concerns about the company's monopoly on farming, following its acquisition of smaller seed technology companies. The seeds, which have gained popularity for boosting yields, have been linked to damage to neighboring crops due to misuse of the herbicide. As Monsanto targets 50% of the US soybean market, critics warn of a repeat of the glyphosate controversy, with potential long-term effects on the global food system.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks erase earlier gains; won edges up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined 11.07 points or 0.45% to 2,469.48 at 0633 GMT, erasing earlier gains due to expiration day for futures and options. The won gained 0.15% to 1,089.1 per US dollar, while bond yields fell. The KOSPI is up 22.4% this year and down 2.97% in the previous 30 days, despite mild losses in US stocks and Japanese stocks weakening 0.28%.

site_title: IBM taps banks, tech firms in quantum computer push
summary: IBM has signed 12 prominent organizations, including banks and tech firms, to experiment with its quantum computers. The companies, including JPMorgan Chase, Daimler, and Samsung, will access IBM's 20-qubit quantum computer through the cloud. The goal is to test the technology's potential applications, such as creating new chemical catalysts and engineering new materials. Despite the machines' high error rates, IBM aims to hook these companies early on the emerging technology, making them more comfortable with the systems when more powerful machines are available.

site_title: UBS Wealth chief Zeltner to be replaced by Blessing in reshuffle
summary: UBS Wealth chief Zeltner, 50, is stepping down from his US$1.3 trillion wealth-management unit, effective January, after 30 years with the company. He will be replaced by Martin Blessing, former Commerzbank CEO, who will also oversee domestic retail banking and corporate lending. UBS didn't provide a reason for Zeltner's departure, following Julius Baer's Boris Collardi's exit in two weeks. Blessing will be joined by Axel Lehmann and Sabine Keller-Bussem in the executive team.

site_title: Zhongmin Baihui unit sets up new company for China retail business
summary: Zhongmin Baihui unit sets up new company to take over its stake in a Chinese retail joint venture. The new company, formed with Chongqing Sasseur Outlets Commercial Management Co, Ltd, will hold, manage, and operate the joint venture. The joint venture, initially set up between Zhongmin Baihui and Changsha Mingfa City Construction Development Co, Ltd, will be managed by CQ Sasseur. This move is part of Zhongmin Baihui's efforts to restructure its business and focus on its retail operations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: China auto market growth set to slow to 3% in 2018: industry body
summary: China's auto market is expected to experience slow growth of around 3% in 2018, following a year of 3.5% growth in 2017. This would be a second consecutive year of lackluster growth. New-energy vehicle sales, however, are on track to meet a target of 700,000 units this year, with a 51.4% increase in January-November sales. China's policymakers have set production and sales quotas for new-energy vehicles starting in 2019, prompting a surge in electric and hybrid model launches.

site_title: Half of Singapore's business sectors see working capital performance worsen: study
summary: Working capital performance in half of Singapore's business sectors has worsened year on year, with medium-sized companies struggling the most. The study found that seven industries improved their net working capital days, while six deteriorated. Energy & chemicals and information and communications technology & media sectors were among the most affected, with significant revenue losses and increased receivables and inventory. The study emphasizes the importance of constant vigilance over cash management, particularly in the face of increasing interest rates and a volatile economic environment.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed; dollar steady on Fed's outlook
summary: Asian stocks were mixed following the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates and boost its economic growth forecast for 2018, while holding steady on interest-rate hikes. The Australian dollar surged after better-than-expected jobs figures. The S&P 500 Index ended lower, and the Bloomberg dollar index fell as Treasury yields rose. The Fed's outlook suggests inflation will remain below its 2% goal in the near term but stabilize in the medium term.

site_title: Bumper crop of new drugs fails to lift big pharma R&D returns
summary: US officials have approved twice as many novel medicines this year as in 2016, but leading pharmaceutical companies' returns on research investment have fallen to an eight-year low of 3.2%. The high cost of developing new drugs, meager peak sales expectations, and the rise of biotechnology companies are contributing to this trend. Despite this, younger biotech companies are expected to continue their success, with projected returns nearly four times higher than the giants of the pharma world.

site_title: Australia's Myer issues profit warning as Christmas fails to deliver
summary: Australia's department store operator Myer Holdings issued a profit warning due to weaker-than-expected pre-Christmas trading, citing online shopping competition led by Amazon.com. The company expects a "materially below" year-to-date profit compared to the same period last year. Myer shares fell 7.6% to a record low of 63.5 Australian cents. The company is implementing a five-year turnaround plan, including ramping up its online offering and closing underperforming stores.

site_title: BP plan to buy Australian petrol pump network blocked
summary: BP's plan to buy Australian petrol pump network from Woolworths has been blocked by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission due to concerns it will lead to higher fuel prices. The $1.3 billion deal, announced last year, aimed to rebrand and operate 531 existing fuel and convenience stores, as well as 12 under-construction sites. The commission opposed the move, citing potential anti-competitive effects.

site_title: Short seller Jim Chanos says Tesla headed for 'brick wall'
summary: Investor Jim Chanos, president of Kynikos Associates, says Tesla is headed for a "brick wall" due to its declining competitiveness in the electric vehicle market and its struggles with self-driving technology. Chanos, who has been short-selling Tesla since 2016, believes the company's stock price is its biggest asset and will likely plummet when it falls. He predicts Elon Musk will leave Tesla for another company, such as SpaceX, and that the company will need to raise money through new markets to fund its future projects.

images.alt_text: Tesla, a perennial target of short sellers, "is headed for a brick wall," investor Jim Chanos said.

site_title: Bitcoin trading thrives wherever regulators crack down most
summary: Bitcoin trading surged in emerging markets where regulators cracked down, outpacing developed nations like the US. In countries such as China, Russia, and Venezuela, where authorities restricted local exchange trading, demand for bitcoin increased due to inflation and lack of oversight. This trend contradicts the original purpose of bitcoin's creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, who aimed to avoid bank and government oversight. As a result, peer-to-peer bitcoin trading expanded rapidly in these regions.

site_title: Marvel or mishap? Hong Kong's troubled mega bridge
summary: Hong Kong's mega sea bridge, connecting the city to mainland China and Macau, is plagued by delays, budget overruns, and accusations of corruption. The project, estimated to cost over $20 billion, has sparked concerns about its political motivations and the impact on Hong Kong's semi-autonomous status. Critics argue it will boost Beijing's control over the city, while supporters claim it will boost business and cut travel time. The bridge's completion is now uncertain, with officials expecting it to open in 2018.

site_title: World's biggest biometric database grows in India amid doubt
summary: India's Aadhaar biometric database has grown to almost 1 billion users, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi pushing for mandatory linking to various services. The Supreme Court will hear petitions seeking to limit the database's scope, citing concerns over privacy and data leaks. Critics argue the program unfairly excludes genuine beneficiaries and discloses Aadhaar numbers, while supporters claim it saves the government billions by targeting subsidies. The court's ruling may set a precedent for global biometric databases.

site_title: US dollar suffers further losses as Fed fails to inspire
summary: The US dollar experienced further losses as Asian investors shifted out of the currency, following a lackluster Federal Reserve meeting that provided little excitement despite a rate hike and positive economic outlook. The dollar retreated against most currencies, including the yen, pound, and euro, while the Australian dollar surged against the greenback. Market strategists attributed the dollar's weakness to skepticism over the Fed's outlook and rate projections, despite hopes for tax reform.

site_title: Steel tycoon considers bid for Rio Tinto's Dunkirk aluminium smelter: sources
summary: Liberty House, led by Sanjeev Gupta, is considering a bid for Rio Tinto's 200 million euro Dunkirk aluminium smelter in northern France, the largest in Europe. The smelter would add to the Gupta Family Group's portfolio of assets. Neither Liberty House nor Rio Tinto commented on the matter. The potential deal would further expand Gupta's conglomerate, which already owns steel mills and hydro-power plants.

site_title: Investors pour cash into US shale despite questions on returns
summary: US shale oil producers continue to receive significant investment, despite concerns over returns. The International Energy Agency predicts US shale oil output will rise by 8 million barrels per day by 2025, making the US a net exporter of oil. Investors are pouring cash into the sector, with private equity firms and hedge funds providing new financial levers to keep drilling. Despite rising pressure for better profit margins, producers are prioritizing output growth, citing efficiencies from newer well designs and shedding less productive acreage. The sector's resilience has been tested before, with firms adapting to lower prices by using new technologies and financing vehicles.

site_title: Fed, ECB and China pose key danger for Asia US dollar bond boom
summary: Asian borrowers have turned to US dollar bonds, with 2018 expected to see similar sales, unless central banks withdraw stimulus too quickly. The European Central Bank and Federal Reserve are key risks, with investors citing policy mistakes and China's deleveraging campaign as concerns. Chinese borrowers use offshore US dollar bonds for cheaper funding, but this makes it difficult for asset managers to diversify portfolios. Market players expect higher funding costs for borrowers in 2018, driven by a new-issue premium.

images.alt_text: Asian borrowers have turned to US dollar bonds like never before this year, and 2018 is shaping up to be little different - unless the world's key central banks flub their stimulus withdrawal, investors say.

site_title: Housing slump gathers pace in Sweden with buyers losing faith
summary: Sweden's housing market continues to cool, with apartment prices declining 3% in November and house prices falling 1%. The market is struggling to absorb a supply glut, leading to a decrease in demand and confidence among households. The decline in prices is attributed to stricter mortgage rules and growing apprehension among households, with the housing-price indicator showing a majority of Swedes expect prices to fall in the coming year. The cooling market has also led to a decline in the krona, with the currency falling almost 5% since August.

images.alt_text: Sweden's housing slump deepened last month as the market struggles to absorb a supply glut and households lose confidence.

site_title: South Korea plans shift to renewables, but coal, nuclear to remain strong
summary: South Korea aims to gradually reduce its dependence on coal and nuclear power over the next 15 years, with renewables and natural gas expected to make up 20% and 18.8% of power generation by 2030, respectively. The country plans to increase the share of renewables and natural gas, but coal and nuclear power will still account for 60% of electricity in 2030. The government will introduce measures to cap coal power generation, including raising consumption taxes on thermal coal, and will work on a nuclear phase-out, with the nuclear power share gradually declining from the mid-2020s.

site_title: Airbus executive says considering cuts to A380 production, still undecided
summary: Airbus is considering cutting A380 production to 6-7 planes per year, down from its current output of around 10 planes. This decision comes amid sluggish sales and competition from smaller, more efficient twin-engined jets. Airbus chief operating officer Fabrice Bregier stated that the company believes it can produce the aircraft at the reduced rate in an industrial manner. The move is part of Airbus's efforts to adapt to changing market demands and wait for a recovery in A380 sales. A final decision on the production cuts has not been made.

site_title: China not happy about WTO member complaints
summary: China has expressed dissatisfaction with complaints from WTO member nations regarding the organization's functioning. US Trade Chief Robert Lighthizer stated that the WTO is prioritizing litigation over trade negotiations and being too lenient on wealthier developing countries, such as China. In response, China's Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao Feng said China does not support WTO members who deny the organization's usefulness if their appeals are not satisfied. This statement suggests China is taking a defensive stance against criticism of the WTO.

site_title: Premium tea retailer Teabox bags US$7m Series B funding
summary: Premium tea retailer Teabox secured US$7 million in Series B funding from Singapore-based RB Investments and DBS Bank through venture debt. The funding will aid expansion of its back-end infrastructure and support growth in key markets. Teabox, which exports to over 112 countries, attributes its success to its end-to-end supply chain and digital presence. The company plans to use the financing to further redefine the tea industry with its innovative supply chain.

site_title: China's home sales reverse declines for biggest gain in 5 months
summary: China's new home sales rebounded in November, rising 12.4% year-over-year to 1.02 trillion yuan, the largest gain in five months. Despite government efforts to curb excessive leverage and purchases, sales increased. Investment in real estate development slowed 4.6% and new starts surged 18.8%. Analysts predict a decline in sales next year as China tackles property demand. The government has loosened financing restrictions for developers, indicating a shift towards more relaxed policies.

site_title: Wrestler turned actor Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson receives star on Walk of Fame
summary: Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson received his star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, becoming the 2,624th celebrity to be honored. Johnson, 45, paid tribute to his family and career team, thanking them for their support. He also shared a quote from his childhood, "It's nice to be important but it's more important to be nice." The ceremony took place on December 13, 2017, with Johnson struggling to get through his speech due to fans chanting "Rocky."

site_title: Billionaire Mikitani plans to build cell-phone network in Japan
summary: Billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani's Rakuten Inc plans to build Japan's fourth mobile phone network by participating in upcoming government auctions to win its own wireless infrastructure. The company aims to raise 600 billion yen ($7.14 billion) by 2025 to fund the project and attract 15 million subscribers. This move is expected to increase competition and improve efficiency in the market. Shares of existing carriers dropped following the announcement, with SoftBank Group Corp falling 2.8%, while Rakuten's shares dropped 2.9%.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani's Rakuten Inc plans to become the country's fourth big mobile-phone operator by announcing plans to build a network as the government pushes for greater competition.

site_title: China steel prices sag further on slow demand, drag down raw materials
summary: China's rebar steel futures fell 0.9% on Thursday, marking a second straight session decline, due to slow demand over winter and construction activity. Steel output declined to a nine-month low in November, and inventory levels hit a 2011 low. Despite low stockpiles, buyers are hesitant to place orders due to high prices. The decline in steel prices also dragged down raw materials iron ore and coking coal. China's iron ore market is expected to remain saturated, putting pressure on prices.

site_title: Oil slips as US petrol stock build overshadows crude draw
summary: Oil prices slipped for a second day, with US crude settling down 54 cents at $56.60 a barrel, a 1% decline. A larger-than-expected drop in US crude stockpiles (5.1 million barrels) was offset by a rise in gasoline inventories (5.7 million barrels). US crude production hit a record high of 9.78 million barrels per day, while Brent crude fell 1.4% to $62.44 a barrel. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after an unplanned shutdown of the Forties North Sea pipeline and ongoing oversupply in the global market.

site_title: Target to buy Shipt for US$550m in challenge to Amazon
summary: Target agreed to purchase grocery-delivery startup Shipt for $550 million, expanding its same-day shipping capabilities. The deal will allow Target customers to order groceries online and have items delivered directly from nearby Target stores. This move increases Target's logistics operations, building on its earlier acquisition of software company Grand Junction. With this purchase, Target now offers same-day delivery in New York City and can send orders from 1,400 of its stores, challenging Amazon's dominance in the market.

site_title: Co-working space startup WeWork calls Funan home
summary: WeWork, a co-working startup, has leased 40,000 square feet of space in Funan, a Singaporean integrated development. The space will feature smart office technology, including facial recognition turnstiles and card-less entry. The lease marks WeWork's first office tenant in Funan, managed by Capitaland Mall Trust Management Limited. The co-working space will be located across two floors in the North Office block.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, trimming 6.65 points, or 0.2%, to 3,462.12. The decline followed the S&P 500's overnight drop and the Dow Jones' record close. Active stocks included Magnus Energy, which was flat, and GSS Energy, which gained 14.1%. The Straits Times Index ended 0.4% higher on Wednesday, despite investors' concerns over tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singapore shares resume slightly lower on Thursday; STI at 3,438.15
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,438.15 on Thursday, down 0.9% or 30.62 points. Trading volume reached 708.3 million shares worth S$482.8 million. The decline followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US prosecutors confirm Uber target of criminal probe
summary: US prosecutors confirm Uber is the target of a US criminal investigation, following a letter from the US Attorney's Office in Northern California. The investigation was sparked after a former Uber manager, Richard Jacobs, claimed that employees used non-attributable devices to store and transmit information to evade discovery and government investigations. Uber has denied any wrongdoing, and the case has been delayed twice. The investigation is part of a broader probe into Uber's practices, including a cover-up of a 57 million user and driver data breach.

site_title: Australian jobs growth surges, unemployment near 5-year lows
summary: Australian employment surged for a 14th consecutive month in November, with 61,600 net new jobs added, exceeding forecasts of 18,000. The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%, the lowest since February 2013. Full-time jobs climbed 41,900, bringing total gains since November 2016 to 304,600. However, wage growth remains near record lows, limiting consumer spending and inflation, with core inflation forecast to reach the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band in early 2019.

images.alt_text: Australian employment sprinted ahead for a 14th straight month in November, the longest stretch of gains since the early 1990s, while the jobless rate remained at the previous month's near five year low.

site_title: CEReit's stabilising manager behind a third of volume since IPO
summary: Cromwell European Reit's (CEReit) stabilising manager, UBS, has purchased 27.89 million units since the trust's IPO on November 30, accounting for one-third of the counter's trading volume. This round of purchases, worth 1.795 million units, occurred on Wednesday and comprised 58.4% of the day's trading volume. The purchases have helped support the counter's market price, which was trading at 0.55 euro as of noon on Thursday. UBS has used up 61.4% of its allowed 45.454 million unit purchase mandate for stabilising action.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.29% at the open, building on previous gains, as investors took cues from a record US stock market. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,308.02. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index barely moved, and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased. The rally comes despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: China Nov investment growth slows, industrial output beats expectations
summary: China's fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 7.2% in the January-November period, while industrial output expanded 6.1% in November, beating expectations. Private sector investment rose 5.7% and retail sales increased 10.2% in November. Despite a construction boom and robust exports, factory activity has shown signs of cooling due to a crackdown on financial risks. The world's second-largest economy has maintained a 6.9% growth rate in the first nine months of the year.

images.alt_text: China's fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 7.2 per cent in the January-November period, while industrial output expanded at a faster pace than markets had expected.

site_title: SIA's new A380 arrives with revamped cabins, suites; to fly Sydney route from Dec 18
summary: Singapore Airlines' first new Airbus A380 arrived at Changi Airport on December 14, 2017, with revamped cabins and suites. The double-decker jet will operate on the Singapore-Sydney route starting December 18, featuring 471 seats and a reduced number of Suites from 12 to six. The airline is investing US$850 million to retrofit its 19 A380s with the new products, aiming to complete the upgrade by 2020.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, OUE H-Trust, Oxley, Emas Offshore, Far East Group
summary: ESR-Reit acquired a property in Singapore for S$240 million, its largest acquisition. OUE Hospitality Trust obtained S$980 million of loan facilities to refinance debt. Oxley Holdings entered sale and purchase agreements to buy two properties for S$660 million and US$12 million. Emas Offshore Limited narrowed its second-quarter loss by 89% on a 24% revenue increase. Far East Group accepted a letter of offer to sell a land parcel for S$3.80 million. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oxley acquires Chevron House, property developer Centra Cove
summary: Oxley Holdings has acquired Chevron House in Singapore for S$660 million and Centra Cove, a Singapore property developer, for US$12 million. The acquisition of Chevron House includes a 32-storey office building with a land area of 2,777.9 sq m. Oxley expects the acquisition to have no impact on its financials. Additionally, Oxley will have a stake in a Vietnamese residential project with a state-owned construction company. The acquisition is financed through internal resources and bank borrowings, with a deposit of S$33 million paid upfront.

site_title: Broker's take: Possible upward swing for Bukit Sembawang earns Maybank's 'buy'
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has given a "buy" rating to Bukit Sembawang, a Singapore-based property developer, with a target price of S$8.25, representing a 39% upside from its current share price. The broker believes the developer is nearing a cyclical earnings rebound in the 2019-2020 financial years due to stronger homebuying sentiment and a large pipeline of projects. A successful launch of the luxury condominium 8 St Thomas could be a catalyst, despite potential downsides such as overpaying for land and interest rate spikes.

site_title: MPA pumps S$12m more to promote Singapore's LNG bunkering
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has invested an additional S$12 million to promote liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering in the Port of Singapore. The funding will support the development of ship-to-ship LNG bunkering and the building of LNG-fuelled vessels. This move aims to provide greater confidence in the availability of LNG supply across key shipping routes, following the implementation of the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 0.5 per cent global sulphur cap in 2020. Applications for the new fund are now open, with companies able to co-fund up to S$3 million per LNG bunker vessel.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Federal Reserve raises interest rates, keeps 2018 policy outlook unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Wednesday but maintained its 2018 policy outlook unchanged. Policymakers projected a short-term boost in US economic growth from the Trump administration's proposed tax cuts, but judged it would have no lasting impact. The long-run potential growth rate is expected to remain at 1.8%. This contradicts the White House's claim of annual GDP growth of 3-4%. The Fed's decision was seen as a cautious response to the tax overhaul.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Yellen says no risks to stability 'flashing red' as markets boom
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that there are no risks to financial stability "flashing red" despite booming stock markets reaching record highs. She noted that high stock prices are not a current concern and that the banking system is resilient and strong. Yellen also expressed skepticism about digital currency bitcoin, calling it a "highly speculative asset" with a "very small role" in the payment system. The Fed has no role in regulating bitcoin, and it does not constitute a stable source of store value.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly lower after Federal Reserve outlook
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.18% lower on Thursday, December 14, 2017, following the US Federal Reserve's announcement to lift interest rates while maintaining its outlook for further hikes in 2018. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 22,716.74 and the Topix index dropped to 1,808.50.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record on tax bill progress, Fed outlook
summary: The US stock market closed at a record, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 24,591.91, up 0.4% for its fourth straight record close. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates, and a major tax cut bill in Congress moved closer to completion. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached new highs, despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Singtel's Optus wins more spectrum in Australia, including 5G pioneer band
summary: Optus, owned by Singtel, has acquired metropolitan spectrum licenses in Australia, including the 5G pioneer band at 3500MHz, for A$6.5 million. The acquisitions in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Adelaide will strengthen Optus' network to meet increasing data demands. This complements Optus' existing 3500MHz metro holdings and positions the company for 5G development. The move is seen as a strategic move to future-proof the network and enhance its competitive position in the market.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Qantas making network changes to Singapore-Australia flights
summary: Qantas is making network adjustments to its Singapore-Australia flights, starting early March 2018. The airline will switch from an Airbus A330 to an Airbus A380 on the Singapore-Sydney route, increasing services to four times a week. On the Singapore-Perth route, Qantas will increase daily flights to twice a day, while Jetstar Asia will exit the route. Meanwhile, Jetstar Airways will reduce Singapore-Melbourne flights from five to two per week. The changes aim to optimize aircraft usage and reflect changes in demand.

site_title: New Zealand government unveils plans to boost spending, sees slightly lower budget surplus
summary: New Zealand's Labour-led government unveiled plans to boost spending, focusing on families and housing supply, while scrapping tax cuts proposed by the previous administration. The government expects a slightly lower-than-forecast budget surplus in 2018, with a predicted NZ$2.54 billion surplus, down from NZ$2.86 billion. Labour plans to spend NZ$32.9 billion on capital spending over four years, aiming to improve housing supply and social services. The government aims to reduce debt to 20% of GDP by 2022, two years later than planned under the previous administration.

site_title: OUE H-Trust obtains S$980m of facilities to partially refinance debt
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) has obtained S$980 million of loan facilities to partially refinance its existing debt. The new facilities, provided by BNP Paribas, DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and Standard Chartered, will be used to repay existing facilities and for working capital. To avoid default, OUE must hold at least 20% of the stapled securities of OUE H-Trust and obtain prior consent from the lending banks if the trust sponsor OUE ceases to own at least 51% of the Reit manager.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rise to more than 1-week high
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 18.08 points, or 0.73%, to 2,499.29 on Thursday, reaching a one-week high. The Korean won strengthened, while bond yields fell. The won was quoted at 1,085.7 per dollar, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.55%. The Kospi has gained 22.4% so far this year, and foreigners were net buyers of 16,119 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Gold jumps 1% as dollar slips on Fed rate outlook
summary: Gold prices rose 1% to $1,256.87 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points, as expected, but left its outlook unchanged for coming years. The dollar index fell, boosting gold's price. Traders attributed the gains to inflation fears despite mild inflation data. US stocks extended their gains, while Treasury yields dropped to session lows.

site_title: Cancer-battling US Senator John McCain hospitalised
summary: US Senator John McCain, 81, who is battling aggressive brain cancer, was hospitalized for "normal side effects" of his therapy at Walter Reed Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland. McCain, a former prisoner of war and 2008 Republican presidential nominee, has undergone surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. Despite being critical of President Donald Trump, McCain remains grateful for his physicians' care and looks forward to returning to work in the US Senate. His treatment will continue at the National Institutes of Health, allowing him to maintain a regular work schedule.

site_title: Ultra-rare Prince vinyl 'Black Album' resurfaces
summary: A rare, sealed vinyl copy of Prince's "Black Album" has resurfaced, 30 years after the artist demanded its destruction. The record, which was secretly released in 1987, was initially ordered by Warner Brothers but later deemed "evil" by Prince. Only five copies were made, and one has now been sold online for $15,000. The record's resurfacing comes after a former Warner executive discovered the remaining copies in a storage area. This rare find is a holy grail for record collectors, as Prince had previously refused to release the album on vinyl.

site_title: Property recovery can further add to GDP growth in 2018: economists
summary: Singapore's property market recovery is expected to boost the economy in 2018, potentially driving growth to exceed expectations. Economists predict a 1% growth in GDP, driven by en bloc-driven home buying, construction of new homes, and surge in mortgages. A modest rise in property prices and consumer spending are also forecasted. The recovery is seen as a positive factor for the economy, alongside an electronics surge and external growth, and is expected to filter down to other sectors such as finance and insurance.

site_title: 17,000 BTO flats to be launched in 2018: Lawrence Wong
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced that 17,000 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats will be launched in 2018, maintaining a similar flat supply to this year. The new flats will be released in mature and non-mature towns, including Tengah, and will feature shorter wait times of 2½ years. This marks a return to pre-2015 levels, with around 25,000 BTO flats launched annually between 2011 and 2013. Wong emphasized the need to balance flat supply with underlying demand and the stability of the HDB resale market.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Housing Development Board will launch about 17,000 new flats in 2018, National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said in a blog post on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip; Italian stocks fall on political uncertainty
summary: Italian stocks fell 1.4% on Wednesday amid political uncertainty ahead of national elections in March, with sovereign bonds also declining. The Stoxx 600 benchmark fell 0.2%, while UK's FTSE slipped less than 0.1%. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise US interest rates, but the focus is on its plans for further rises next year, which could impact European markets. Despite the uncertainty, analysts expect Italy's FTSE MIB to rise another 13% by the end of 2018.

site_title: Love it or hate it, Libor's rise matters for trillions of debt
summary: The London interbank offered rate (Libor) is surging, reaching its highest level since the global financial crisis in December 2008. The rate increase, driven by the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle, affects trillions of dollars in loans and floating-rate securities, with US$350 trillion linked to the dollar-based benchmark. This rise is already influencing the mortgage market, with younger buyers opting for fixed-rate mortgages over adjustable-rate mortgages. Fed officials are expected to maintain the upward trend, with Goldman Sachs predicting two additional 0.25% rate hikes in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.21 points to 1,737.45. The index saw 70.45 million lots traded worth RM20.67 million, with 111 gainers and 53 losers.

site_title: Economic reality is set to box Mario Draghi into a corner
summary: The European Central Bank is poised to unveil new growth and inflation estimates that could dictate the direction of its monetary policy in 2018. Annual euro zone growth accelerated to 2.6% in the third quarter, and Bloomberg Economics expects the ECB could raise its forecast for 2018 above 2%. ECB President Mario Draghi is unlikely to alter his ultra-dovish line, but the ECB's 2020 estimates may weaken the case for extending quantitative easing beyond September, potentially forcing a change in course.

site_title: Trending searches: hurricane, bitcoin and sex scandal
summary: Google's top trending topics for 2017 included Hurricane Irma, bitcoin, and a sex scandal surrounding TV host Matt Lauer. Irma was the top trending topic globally, while bitcoin was the second most sought-after news. Other top trending topics included the Las Vegas shooting, North Korea crisis, and the solar eclipse. Apple's iPhone models were also a top search topic. The scandal surrounding Lauer, who was accused of harassment, was the fourth most searched topic, along with film producer Harvey Weinstein and actor Kevin Spacey. Meghan Markle and Italian TV personality Nadia Toffa also made the top 5 list.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GIC led a $200 million Series E round of equity funding for Affirm Inc, joined by existing investors. The funding will be used to increase credit distribution capacity, grow merchant partners, and introduce new products. Meanwhile, a Far East Group subsidiary sold a land parcel in Malaysia to Ng Hin Kwee & Sons for $3.8 million.

site_title: Trump's fateful mistake on Washington's financial watchdog
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has made a major tactical mistake by seizing control of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and appointing Mick Mulvaney, a pro-business extremist, as its director. The CFPB was established to protect consumers from financial abuses, and its previous director, Richard Cordray, had done a "terrific job." Trump's move is expected to bring institutional turmoil, freeze CFPB rules, and ultimately harm consumers. The CFPB has successfully returned over $12 billion to 29 million consumers, but Mulvaney's appointment threatens to undermine this progress and expose the administration's flawed economic policies.

site_title: Froome fails urine test; risks losing Vuelta title
summary: Four-time Tour de France winner Chris Froome failed a urine test at the Vuelta a Espana in September, but claims he followed medical advice and didn't exceed permitted limits of asthma medication. The UCI notified Froome of the adverse analytical finding after a sample showed double the permissible limit of Salbutamol, a medication allowed for asthma treatment. Froome denies any wrongdoing and has provided information to the UCI, who are conducting proceedings in line with anti-doping rules.

site_title: HP unveils S$100m campus, home to its first advanced manufacturing centre
summary: HP has unveiled its S$100 million campus in Singapore, featuring its first advanced manufacturing centre, Smarc. The 450,000 sq ft facility, home to over 6,000 sq ft Smarc, aims to boost productivity by 20% through technologies like additive manufacturing and data analytics. The centre is staffed by engineers overseeing 50 global manufacturing lines. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran welcomed the investment, highlighting Singapore's commitment to advanced manufacturing and HP's role in supporting small and medium enterprises.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran receiving a card with greetings written by a robotic arm at the opening of Smarc, where he highlighted Singapore's commitment to ensure the sustainability and competitiveness of its manufacturing sector.

site_title: ESR Reit acquires 80% interest in SPV holding Ang Mo Kio property for S$240m
summary: ESR Reit has acquired an 80% stake in a Singapore property for S$240 million, its largest acquisition to date. The property, located in Ang Mo Kio, has a gross floor area of 1.07 million sq ft and an occupancy rate of 91.9%. The acquisition, funded with internal cash and bank debt, boosts ESR-Reit's portfolio value by 31.4% to S$1.75 billion. The remaining 20% interest is held by vendor Ho Lee Properties, with put and call options granted for ESR-Reit to purchase the remaining interest.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singapore IPOs provide fillip to equity capital markets
summary: Singapore's equity capital markets saw a significant boost in 2017, with US$6.9 billion raised by 67 issuers, a 44% increase from 2016. IPOs raised US$4.2 billion, a 52.7% increase, while follow-on public offerings (FPOs) raised US$2.47 billion, a 36.3% increase. The real estate industry dominated ECM proceeds, accounting for 50.2% of the market, with the technology sector also showing potential, raising at least US$1.7 billion.

site_title: British PM May suffers defeat in Brexit bill
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May suffered a parliamentary defeat on Brexit, with her own MPs rebelling to demand parliamentary approval of the divorce deal with Brussels. The government's EU (Withdrawal) Bill was passed with a narrow margin, with the opposition's amendment to demand a statutory vote on the deal before Britain leaves the EU in March 2019 winning by 309 votes to 305. The defeat is a blow to May's authority and hampers the UK's smooth Brexit transition, with EU leaders set to approve the interim deal at a summit in Brussels.

site_title: Rise in job seekers unemployed for 25 weeks or more: MOM
summary: The unemployment rate in Singapore declined slightly in September, with 87 job openings for every 100 unemployed people, a slight improvement from June. The long-term unemployment rate rose to 0.8% from 0.7% in June. Despite this, the overall unemployment rate remained at 2.2% after accounting for seasonal variations. Retrenchments decreased to 3,400, but total employment contracted by 21,400 in the first three quarters of the year.

site_title: Trends of the day: Of cross-industry forays and blurred sector boundaries
summary: Banks are facing increasing competition from fintechs and other industries as they struggle to adapt to a rapidly changing landscape. Traditional banks are being forced to rethink their business models and consider diversifying into new areas, such as digital banking and lending. Firms like Amazon are already expanding into small business lending, while others, like Tokyo Metro, are exploring new ventures like hydroponic farming. This blurring of sector boundaries raises questions about the core of banking and whether traditional lenders can "go beyond banking."

site_title: S Korea bans its banks from dealing in bitcoin
summary: South Korea has banned its financial institutions from dealing in bitcoin, amid concerns over a cryptocurrency trading bubble fueled by retail speculators. The country, a major hub for bitcoin transactions, accounts for 20% of global bitcoin trades. The ban does not apply to existing holdings, but prohibits buying, possessing, or holding bitcoin as collateral. Non-ICO (initial coin offering) investments will also be outlawed. The move aims to curb speculation and potential fraud, with the government strengthening investor protection rules. Prices on South Korea's biggest bitcoin exchange fell nearly 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Asian shares up, US dollar dips as Republicans lose Alabama race
summary: US shares dipped, while Asian shares rose as Democrat Doug Jones beat Republican Roy Moore in the Alabama Senate race. The outcome could impact US President Trump's policy agenda and the dollar's value, potentially narrowing the Republicans' Senate majority. Asian shares, including the MSCI's broadest index, gained 0.5% on the news, while the dollar index fell 0.2%. Crude oil futures rebounded after a previous surge. The outcome temporarily overshadowed the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike.

site_title: Australia gas supply crunch eases but prices still too high: regulator
summary: Australia's gas supply shortage has eased, but prices remain high due to limited competition and pipeline space. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission says the supply gap for 2018 has narrowed to 33 petajoules, or 5% of demand, from an initial 17%. Gas prices for businesses have dropped to A$8-12 per gigajoule, but wholesale prices remain at A$9.74 per gigajoule, higher than a fair price estimate. The regulator will continue to monitor pipeline access for non- Origin Energy and AGL Energy users.

site_title: Singapore condo rents slip 0.3% in Nov; HDB rents ease 0.5%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents decreased by 0.3% in November, with the Outside Central Region (OCR) seeing a 1% drop and the Rest of Central Region (RCR) a 0.5% decline. HDB rents fell by 0.5% in November, with rentals for three- and five-room flats decreasing by 1.5% and 0.3% respectively. Despite the decline, non-landed private rentals remain 19.8% below their January 2013 peak, while HDB rentals are 14.7% below their August 2013 peak.

site_title: Another 6 years of Putin could be bad news for the rouble
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's expected re-election in March may signal a slowdown in the rouble's appreciation, with forecasters predicting a 2% gain for the currency this year and a decline of 1.7% in 2018. The rouble's growth is attributed to Russia's high returns, but traders may become cautious as the central bank lowers interest rates. Sebastien Barbe, a leading rouble forecaster, expects the currency to stabilize before the end of 2017 or early 2018, driven by the carry trade and potential US interest rate changes.

site_title: Government opts for balanced approach to state land sales for H1 2018
summary: The Singapore government has announced a balanced approach to state land sales for the first half of 2018, offering 8,045 private homes and 63,960 sq m commercial space. This is similar to the current half-year slate, aiming to moderate demand and avoid oversupply in the future. Land prices are expected to remain high, but the increase in state land sales may swing some demand from collective sales. Industry experts predict strong participation in land tenders, with some expecting oversupply fears to ease due to complexities in collective sales and redevelopment projects.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Google opens AI R&D centre in China as rivalry heats up
summary: Google has opened an AI research centre in Beijing, China, amid a growing rivalry in the field of artificial intelligence. Despite being excluded from China's internet, Google aims to tap into the country's talent pool in AI, a key area of focus for tech giants. This move comes as Google, Microsoft, and Facebook compete with Chinese companies like Alibaba and Baidu to master AI and machine learning, considered the future of computing.

site_title: Airbus CEO will not seek third term: Le Figaro
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders will not seek a third term, contrary to earlier speculation. Enders stated his term runs until April 2019 and will be decided by the Airbus board or by consensus between the board and himself. The decision comes amid corruption scandal investigations in France, Britain, Austria, and Germany, with Enders previously saying he'd step down if no longer part of the solution. An Airbus board meeting will confirm his departure on Thursday.

site_title: China property price rally likely to stall in 2018: poll
summary: China's home price growth is expected to stall in 2018, with a slowdown in smaller cities' sales and prices due to tightening measures and credit curbs. Average nationwide new home prices are forecast to flatline by end-2018, with prices increasing 6.8% in 2017 and 3.5% in the first half of 2018. Underlying demand in bigger cities is expected to remain solid, despite stringent curbs, and property investment is estimated to grow 5% in the first half of 2018.

site_title: Ecuador's VP handed 6 years in prison in Odebrecht graft case
summary: Ecuador's Vice President Jorge Glas was sentenced to 6 years in prison for receiving illegal kickbacks from Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht. Glas, 48, had been in preventive custody since October after his immunity was lifted by Congress. He is the highest-ranking politician to be convicted in the Odebrecht graft case, which has cast a cloud over officials in several Latin American countries. Glas was allowed to remain vice-president despite the conviction.

images.alt_text: Ecuador's vice-president, Jorge Glas, was sentenced to six years in prison Wednesday for receiving illegal kickbacks from Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht.

site_title: Manhattan luxury condo sales skew apartment prices: report
summary: A report by CityRealty found that luxury condo sales in Manhattan have skewed apartment prices, masking a decline in transaction volume over the past five years. The number of units sold for over $10 million has doubled since 2013, while those under $1 million have dropped by 35%. The super wealthy have driven up prices, leading to a shift away from more affordable units. The median sales price of high-end apartments increased in 2017, but the average square-foot price for condos declined slightly.

site_title: Promising new drug may stop, and even cure, Huntington's disease
summary: A promising new drug, IONIS-HTTRx, has shown significant potential in stopping and potentially curing Huntington's disease. In an early phase clinical trial, the drug inhibited nerve-cell killing proteins, with no reported side effects. The treatment works by delivering a small piece of genetic material that prevents the creation of a toxic protein that kills nerve cells. The research, supported by Ionis pharmaceuticals, could also have implications for other neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, ALS, and Parkinson's.

site_title: US, EU, Japan slam market-distorting trade practices, take swipe at China
summary: The US, EU, and Japan have issued a joint statement to the World Trade Organization, vowing to work together to eliminate market-distorting trade practices and policies that have fueled excess production capacity, primarily attributed to China's economic system. The statement targets subsidies, state-owned enterprises, forced technology transfer, and local content requirements. The move reflects growing frustration among industrial countries over China's trade practices and concerns that other developing countries will follow Beijing's lead.

site_title: Sustainable investing should be pushed into the mainstream
summary: Singapore must ensure it leads the way in sustainable finance as the global transition to a low-carbon economy gains momentum.
