summary: Oxley Holdings has purchased the freehold Apartment 8 development in Potong Pasir for S$21.53 million. The purchase includes all eight units, with the sellers having already been paid S$1.0765 million in advance. The balance will be paid upon completion in March 2018. Oxley plans to redevelop the 898.1 square meter site, zoned for residential use.

site_title: Exxon to provide details on climate-change impact to its business
summary: ExxonMobil has agreed to provide details on the impact of climate change on its business, following a shareholder resolution that received 62% support. The company's board will release information on energy demand sensitivities, climate scenarios, and positioning for a lower-carbon future. This move aims to appease critics and forestall another proxy fight next year. Exxon faces investigations by state attorneys general into whether it misled the public and investors on climate change risks, and big investors such as BlackRock and Vanguard have backed the resolution.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil on Monday said it would publish new details about how climate change could affect its business in a move aimed at appeasing critics and forestalling another proxy fight next year.

site_title: Japanese solar firm to take on Tesla in roofing-tile competition
summary: Japan's Solar Frontier K K plans to sell solar panels incorporated into roofing and wall materials, competing with Tesla in building technology. The company aims to begin sales in the second half of 2019, offering thin, light, and durable products that can substitute building materials. Solar Frontier is targeting the small-scale market due to grid access issues in Japan, where utilities have capped solar power take-up and demand is expected to decline. The company's CEO, Atsuhiko Hirano, believes the new products will reduce overall cost for customers.

site_title: Danske's wealth management robot now has 11,500 clients
summary: Danske Bank A/S has attracted 11,500 clients to its investment service provided by a robot called June, in just over half a year. The robot helps retail clients and small businesses manage surplus cash, targeting those who normally wouldn't have the resources to invest. June uses an algorithm to provide investment recommendations based on customers' risk appetite and financial data. The bank aims to expand its wealth management operations with this technology, which is expected to spread to other areas of the bank.

site_title: Bitcoin's first 24 Hours on Wall Street feed euphoria and doubts
summary: Bitcoin futures contracts launched on Cboe Global Markets' exchange, marking the cryptocurrency's debut on Wall Street. The contracts saw a 24% price rise in the first session, despite technical glitches, and a 13% premium over the underlying asset. The success of the futures has bolstered skepticism among mainstream financial professionals, with concerns about speculation and the potential for derivatives to act independently. Large banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, remain cautious, and the Securities and Exchange Commission may eventually approve an exchange-traded fund tied to bitcoin.

site_title: Gold steadies below US$1,250 an ounce awaiting Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices steadied below $1,250 an ounce on Monday, ending its biggest weekly drop in over six months, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike meeting. The Fed is expected to lift rates, but its statement will be closely watched for any surprises. Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, which boost the dollar and increase the cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Hedge funds reduced their net long positions in gold and silver contracts, with silver taking its largest drop on record.

site_title: CDL offers compromise but decision lies with M&C Hotels shareholders
summary: City Developments (CDL) has revised its offer to take Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) private, increasing the offer price to 620 pence a share. Minority shareholders now have the final say, with a 50% acceptance threshold required for CDL to proceed. Analysts note that the offer price may be too low relative to the company's intrinsic value, with some valuing the hotels at twice their book values. The revised offer represents a compromise for CDL, but its long-term implications remain uncertain.

site_title: Trump wants US Congress to fix 'lax' immigration after New York attack
summary: US President Donald Trump called for Congress to enact immigration reform, citing the recent New York subway attack as an example of the "lax" system. The suspect, identified as Akayed Ullah, entered the country through "extended-family chain migration." Trump wants to end this system and pass measures such as increasing immigration enforcement officers and ending fraud in the system. He also reiterated his call for harsh penalties, including the death penalty, for terror convicts. Trump sees these reforms as necessary to secure the US immigration system.

site_title: Airbus may cut A380 production to 6 planes a year: sources
summary: Airbus is considering reducing A380 production to as few as six aircraft per year to make the world's largest airliner commercially viable. The company has already announced plans to lower production to 12 aircraft in 2018 and eight in 2019, down from a peak of 30. Airbus is holding out for a demand recovery, but this plan is uncertain amid an order for 36 new aircraft from Emirates. The move aims to address the increasing competition from smaller, more efficient twin-engined jets.

site_title: ANZ Bank sells life insurance arm to Zurich for US$2.14b
summary: ANZ Bank sold its life insurance arm, One Path Life Australia Holdings, to Zurich for A$2.85 billion, making Zurich the country's largest retail life insurer by premiums. The sale is part of ANZ's strategy to streamline operations and follows recent sales by National Australia Bank and Commonwealth Bank. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, will provide customers with access to wealth products from a global insurer and is expected to be completed in late 2018.

site_title: TEE International bags S$65m worth of engineering contracts
summary: TEE International, a MAINBOARD-listed company, has secured engineering contracts worth S$65 million from September to November 2017. The contracts, awarded to its subsidiaries Trans Equatorial Engineering and PBT Engineering, are for mechanical and electrical systems and asset enhancement projects. This brings the group's total outstanding order book to S$318 million. TEE expects to complete the projects by 2020 and the first half of next year, respectively. The company is poised to grow its Building & Construction division through greenfield construction projects and productivity technologies.

site_title: UK workers face renewed hit to spending power in 2018: Korn Ferry
summary: UK workers are expected to face a 0.5% decline in real terms in 2018 due to high inflation and weak wage growth, according to Korn Ferry. This would be the second consecutive year of a decline in spending power for British workers, following a 0.4% decline in the previous year. The Brexit vote in 2016 is cited as a major contributor to the inflationary pressures.

site_title: Emas Offshore enters into revised term sheet with BT Investment
summary: Emas Offshore Limited, a beleaguered offshore support vessel owner-operator, has entered into a revised term sheet with BT Investment after terminating the prior agreement. The company aims to substantially deleverage its balance sheet through schemes of arrangement and strengthen its working capital position with a potential US$25-50 million investment from BTI. Emas Offshore has also filed a scheme application with Singapore's High Court, with a pre-trial conference scheduled for Dec 21. The restructuring exercise is expected to enable the group to continue as a going concern.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sweden braces itself for property market's 'November Noir'
summary: Sweden's housing market is expected to show a significant monthly price drop in November, potentially worse than the 3% decline in October. Analysts predict a 3% monthly decline and 1% annual decline, with prices stabilizing in recent weeks. The market is influenced by a shortage of housing and record cheap mortgages, but a surge in construction has pushed supply to outstrip demand. Experts caution against a repeat of the 1990s real-estate crash, but households remain jittery about the market's outlook.

site_title: Oil gains on Forties Pipeline shutdown, New York blast
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures up 2% to $64.69 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures up 1% to $57.99 a barrel. The gains were driven by a shutdown of the Forties Pipeline in the North Sea, which transports a significant portion of North Sea crude oil output, and a blast at New York's Port Authority Bus Terminal. The pipeline's shutdown is expected to last weeks, adding to supply concerns and supporting oil prices.

site_title: HSBC avoids prosecution as US deal lapses
summary: HSBC has avoided prosecution after the US deal lapse, five years after admitting to money laundering and sanctions violations. The bank agreed to pay a $1.9 billion fine in 2012 and took remedial action to avoid new violations. However, critics argue that authorities failed to prosecute senior executives and allowed the bank to avoid a criminal record. Despite facing penalties for foreign exchange fraud and fresh money laundering allegations, HSBC claims to have "lived up to all its commitments" and is now combating financial crime more effectively.

site_title: SC Global makes maiden acquisition in Tokyo's Ginza
summary: Singapore-based property group SC Global Developments has acquired a 12-storey prime freehold commercial development in Tokyo's Ginza district for an undisclosed price. The 7,785 sqft building has been leased to several high-end tenants, including two Michelin-starred restaurant operators. This marks SC Global's maiden acquisition in Japan, following its earlier purchase of land in the ski resort town of Niseko earlier this year. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to diversify the group's geographical footprint.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Europe: Tumbling techs dominate stocks, despite bank bounce
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1% on Monday, despite a 0.3% climb in the euro. Tech stocks, which have gained the most in Europe this year, tumbled 0.3%, outweighing strong financial sector performances. Investors shifted out of tech and into financials, utilities, and telecoms, which tend to underperform when interest rates rise. Banks, however, gained 0.7% to 0.9% on relief from new global banking rules and anticipation of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

site_title: Is Singapore ready as the GDPR deadline draws near?
summary: Singapore is preparing to comply with the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) as the deadline approaches on May 25, 2018. A Veritas study found that 95% of firms in Singapore plan to drive behavioral changes to meet GDPR requirements, while 56% are concerned they won't be able to meet the new EU requirements. The study also highlights the importance of data management tools and governance strategies to ensure compliance. Organizations must locate, search, minimize, protect, and monitor personal data to avoid penalties of up to four percent of global turnover or 20 million euros.

site_title: Trump and Jerusalem: much ado about nothing
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the US recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's capital, but only West Jerusalem. This move does not contradict current US policy, which does not recognize Israel's annexation of East Jerusalem. The US will relocate its embassy to Jerusalem's West Jerusalem and may open an embassy in East Jerusalem for a future Palestinian Arab State. The decision does not mark the end of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, but rather leaves it to the two sides to determine future negotiations.

site_title: Trial under way for car clearance at checkpoints to go high-tech
summary: Singapore is set to introduce a high-tech car clearance system at its checkpoints, featuring robotic arms, biometric scanners, and facial detection technology, as part of its move towards self-clearance using biometrics. The Automated Passenger In-Car Clearance System (Apics) aims to provide tighter security and free up officers to focus on higher-risk travellers. The trial, which began in July, is expected to be successful if it frees up officers and is user-friendly, with the goal of clearing 25 cars per hour. The system will be rolled out next year if the trial is successful.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records, Apple gains on Shazam buy
summary: US stocks closed at records on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.2% to 24,386.03 and the S&P 500 gaining 0.3% to 2,659.99. Apple surged 2.0% following its $400 million acquisition of Shazam, while other tech shares like Microsoft and Tesla Motors also rose. Analysts attributed the positive sentiment to recent economic reports and the progress of tax cut legislation in Washington. The US central bank is expected to raise interest rates for the third time this year, according to analysts looking ahead to this week's policy meetings.

site_title: Will middle-class Americans notice the tax cut?
summary: A 2009 tax cut for middle-class Americans, worth $800 per year, had little noticeable effect. A February 2010 poll found that only 12% believed their taxes had been reduced, while 53% saw no change. Conversely, 24% thought their taxes had increased, despite the cut. This lack of awareness highlights the difficulty in translating policy changes into tangible benefits for the general public.

site_title: Net neutrality's holes in Europe may offer peek at future in US
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission is set to vote on Thursday to roll back net neutrality rules, potentially allowing internet service providers to charge users more for access to certain content or restrict access to some websites. This move comes as telecom providers in Europe have pushed boundaries with deals that offer unlimited access to popular apps, sparking concerns about the future of internet regulation. European regulators have implemented binding net neutrality rules, but critics warn that the US rollback could lead to a "patchwork" of interpretations and undermine competition, free speech, and privacy.

site_title: Current US policy on Russia and China spurs them to band together
summary: US foreign policy towards Russia and China has sparked a potential alliance between the two nations, contrary to the intentions of the Nixon-Kissinger diplomacy of the 1970s. The current Russia fixation in Washington, fueled by concerns over election interference, has led to a self-fulfilling prophecy that could turn Moscow into an enemy, hindering cooperation on common issues. This policy also creates incentives for Russia to join forces with China, potentially leading to a new Cold War and undermining US global interests.

site_title: US dollar snaps 5-day rising streak
summary: The US dollar snapped a 5-day rising streak against a basket of currencies, falling as investors took profits ahead of a US central bank meeting this week. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates, but sluggish inflation and wage growth may cloud policy outlook. The Swedish crown fell due to pension-related outflows.

site_title: 'Terror' bomber strikes New York subway, three hurt
summary: A 27-year-old immigrant from Bangladesh detonated a homemade pipe bomb on a New York subway during rush hour, injuring three people. The bomb partially detonated, leaving the bomber seriously injured, and authorities attributed the minimal damage to a malfunction. The attack, six weeks after a deadly truck attack, was attributed to the bomber's desire to avenge US airstrikes on the Islamic State group and was influenced by extremist groups. President Trump used the attack to call for tougher US immigration rules, while New York Governor Andrew Cuomo emphasized the threat posed by lone actors inspired by extremist groups.

images.alt_text: Akayed Ullah told police investigators he wanted to avenge US airstrikes on the Islamic State group and was also inspired by Christmas terror plots in Europe, and chose the location for his attack by the Christmas posters on the subway walls, US media reported.

site_title: Fullerton Health to buy 60% stake in Intellicare Group
summary: Fullerton Health has agreed to acquire a 60% stake in Philippines-based Intellicare Group, subject to conditions, with the deal expected to complete in early 2018. The acquisition is expected to tap Intellicare's network and experience in the Asia-Pacific region. This deal follows Fullerton's recent investments in Healthscope's medical centre operations in Australia and a partnership with Ping An Capital in China. The acquisition reinforces Fullerton's strategy of expanding its presence in the region, according to co-founder Michael Tan.

site_title: Fresh beginnings with new fee guide for doctors
summary: Singapore is revisiting fee benchmarks for doctors amid concerns over rising healthcare costs, medical tourism decline, and falling insurance margins. The Ministry of Health is setting up a new committee to establish non-binding benchmarks or fee ranges for common procedures. The goal is to ensure fair charges and prevent overcharging, but experts warn that patients need accompanying measures of quality to determine "value" over price. The move aims to curb rising healthcare costs and is seen as a step towards sustainability in the healthcare system.

site_title: London property market likely to stay weak in 2018
summary: London's property market is expected to remain weak in 2018, with home values forecast to fall 2% after a 1.8% decline this year. The slowdown is attributed to economic and political uncertainty, sluggish economy, and squeezed consumer spending. National house-price growth is predicted to cool further to 1% in 2018, the weakest since 2011. Affordability issues, tighter lending criteria, and increased stamp duty for second-home owners are contributing factors, with some parts of London expected to outperform, particularly the lower and middle sectors.

site_title: Low expectations from WTO Ministerial
summary: The 11th WTO Ministerial Conference in Buenos Aires has started with low expectations due to limited scope for success and high risks of failure. Key issues like trade and environment, intellectual property, and agricultural subsidies remain unresolved, with only minor agreements possible on specific topics like the Indian public stockholding issue and the Singaporean initiative on export restrictions. The US refusal to allow new appointments to the appellate body threatens the dispute settlement system, and the ministerial declaration's production has been abandoned due to deep divisions within the multilateral trading system.

site_title: Bitcoin surges past US$18,000 in debut on Chicago bourse
summary: Bitcoin surged past US$18,000 on its debut on the Chicago board options exchange (Cboe), reaching a high of US$18,850 after opening at US$15,000. Trading was steady, with around a thousand trades made in the first two hours. The launch marks a significant milestone for the digital currency, which has been volatile and has raised concerns among regulators and investors. The Cboe's debut is expected to be followed by a rival listing on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and the move is seen as a step towards mainstream acceptance of bitcoin.

site_title: Philippines defied local specialists' advice in pursuing dengue immunisation programme
summary: The Philippines pursued a dengue immunisation programme despite local specialists' advice, defying their warnings. In 2016, the country's health secretary, Janette Garin, announced plans to immunise one million children with a new dengue vaccine, calling it a "world first." However, the programme's success has been questioned, and its implementation has been met with criticism. The programme's effectiveness and long-term impact remain uncertain, raising questions about the country's decision to proceed with the immunisation programme.

images.alt_text: Dr Garin - pictured here at a hearing on the anti dengue drug Dengvaxia at the Philippine senate in Pasay city, Manila, on Dec 11 - has defended her conduct and a programme that she says was implemented in accordance with WHO guidance and recommendations.

site_title: VW chief says German govt should end subsidies for diesel cars
summary: Volkswagen's CEO, Matthias Mueller, has suggested that the German government should phase out subsidies for diesel cars, citing the need to promote environmentally friendly technologies. This move comes as diesel sales have plummeted since the company's 2015 emissions scandal. Mueller's statement is seen as a significant shift, as diesel was once seen as environmentally friendly. The proposal aims to encourage the adoption of cleaner technologies, but critics argue that it may hasten the demise of diesel.

site_title: Centurion prices Hong Kong IPO shares at HK$3.18; offer 4.1 times subscribed
summary: Centurion Corp priced its Hong Kong IPO at HK$3.18 per share, 4.1 times subscribed, to raise approximately HK$69.7 million. The company will use HK$62.7 million to fund an Australian student accommodation project and the remaining HK$7 million for working capital. The listing aims to increase investor base and establish brand presence in Hong Kong.

site_title: Uber in court to fight for London operation
summary: Uber will defend its right to operate in London in a court hearing after Transport for London (TfL) stripped the app of its licence in September due to concerns over reporting serious crimes and driver background checks. Uber's 40,000 drivers can continue to take passengers until the appeals process is exhausted, potentially taking years. The legal battle is the latest in a series of challenges facing the company, which also faces issues in Sheffield and Brighton, and comes as Uber faces internal controversies and departures of executives.

site_title: At Ailey, a dance set to Coltrane finds a sombre radiance
summary: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed Twyla Tharp's The Golden Section, set to music by David Byrne, to critical acclaim. The dance, returning to the repertory, showcased the dancers' ability to master Tharp's tricky coordinations. While the movement still requires refinement, the performance demonstrated the company's versatility. The Ailey company also showcased Jamar Roberts' new work, Members Don't Get Weary, set to John Coltrane's music, highlighting the company's ability to incorporate a wide range of musical styles into their performances.

site_title: Both public and private sectors must lead in implementing Paris deal
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting a climate summit on Tuesday, the second anniversary of the Paris global warming deal. The meeting aims to re-energize support for the deal, focusing on public and private finance innovation to combat climate change. The Paris deal, agreed by over 190 countries, sets a goal to peak greenhouse gas emissions "as soon as possible" and achieve a balance between sources and sinks by the second half of the century. Macron will meet with leaders, including Bill Gates and Arnold Schwarzenegger, to discuss ways to accelerate the battle against climate change.

site_title: Stronger US economy could spur earlier Fed hike in 2018: survey
summary: A Bloomberg survey of 41 economists found that a strengthening US economy may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates twice in the next 3.5 months. Economists expect three rate hikes in 2018, with one move now expected in March instead of June. The Fed is expected to raise the federal funds rate target range to 1.25-1.5% after its meeting, with most economists believing the path of the Fed funds rate will remain "about the same" in 2018.

site_title: Why business in Asia is changing (for the better)
summary: Business in Asia is undergoing significant changes, driven by increased openness, economic growth, and technological advancements. The "Tiger Economies" of the past are fading, and new players, such as Vietnam and China, are emerging as major manufacturing hubs. Asia's industrial landscape is becoming increasingly interconnected, with countries collaborating and competing across sectors. The region is also seeing a rise in start-ups, e-commerce, and omni-channel sales, which are transforming the retail landscape. As a result, Asia is becoming an attractive destination for production, with the region itself effectively becoming a marketplace of manufacturers.

site_title: Keppel O&M wins S$130m contracts
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) has won two contracts worth approximately S$130 million from repeat customers. The contracts involve hull carry-over work for a floating production, storage and offloading vessel, P-69, from a Petrobras-led consortium in Brazil. This win reinforces Keppel O&M's presence in the global oil and gas industry.

site_title: Hospital operators in merger talks to form US industry leader: WSJ
summary: US hospital operators Ascension Health and Providence St Joseph Health are in talks about a merger to form the largest US hospital chain, surpassing HCA Healthcare Inc. The combined entity would have 191 hospitals in 27 states and annual revenue of $44.8 billion. A deal would create the largest US Catholic health system, following recent mergers in the industry. The talks come at a pivotal time for the US healthcare landscape, with changes to the Affordable Care Act and rising drug prices reshaping the industry.

site_title: China's HNA to acquire all CWT shares from 'dissenting shareholders'
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has acquired all shares from "dissenting shareholders" of Singaporean logistics firm CWT Ltd, valuing the deal at US$1.399 billion. The acquisition, part of HNA's US$1 billion purchase, comes amid concerns about the group's rising financing costs and scrutiny from the Chinese government. Following the acquisition, CWT will become a wholly owned subsidiary of HNA Belt and Road Investments.

site_title: GGP rejects Brookfield Property's US$14.8b buyout offer: sources
summary: GGP Inc, a US shopping center owner, has rejected a $14.8 billion buyout offer from Brookfield Property Partners LP, its largest shareholder. Brookfield made a $23-per-share cash and stock offer, aiming to create one of the world's largest publicly traded property companies. GGP already owns 66% of the company, and the rejection leaves the door open for further negotiations.

site_title: ComfortDelGro rises on Uber deal; analysts keep ratings unchanged
summary: ComfortDelGro's stock rose 6.28% to S$2.03 after the company agreed to take a 51% stake in Uber's car rental business, Lion City Holdings, for S$295 million. The deal includes the purchase of 12,450 cars and will centralize fleet management. Analysts praised the move, citing potential benefits such as lower idling rates and increased earnings for ComfortDelGro's automotive divisions. However, they maintained their "hold" ratings, citing uncertain growth potential for ComfortDelGro's taxi business and pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Myanmar to delay law allowing more foreign investment
summary: Myanmar has delayed a corporate reform law that would allow foreign investment, disappointing businesses and investors who are seeking urgent cash. The delay, potentially until August 2018, is attributed to the need for by-laws and a company registry. The law, which would have allowed foreigners to take up to 35% stake in local companies, aims to bring the country's business regulatory framework closer to international standards. The delay is seen as a blow to investor confidence in Aung San Suu Kyi's administration, which is struggling to implement economic reforms and address growing doubts about the country's economic management.

site_title: China's November vehicle sales edge up; industry body sees weak spell ahead
summary: China's vehicle sales increased 0.7% in November to 2.96 million, driven by a 83% rise in new energy vehicle (NEV) sales. This follows a 3.6% growth in the first 11 months of the year. Industry officials expect car sales to grow no more than 4% this year, weaker than initial forecasts, due to market challenges. NEV sales are expected to reach 1 million vehicles next year, driven by government quotas and a push to shift away from traditional petrol engine cars.

site_title: Small Canadian miners in pole position for electric vehicle battery demand
summary: Canadian cobalt and lithium miners are in a prime position to secure funding for their projects due to high demand for electric vehicle batteries. Toronto-listed companies Ecobalt Solutions and Fortune Minerals are in talks with over a dozen groups, including car and battery makers, for financing. This comes after a surge in demand from the electric vehicle sector, which has driven up cobalt prices. Canadian miners are seen as a safer bet due to the country's stable political environment, with analysts predicting additional transactions in the coming months and years.

images.alt_text: Deficit forecasts due to constrained supply and expected soaring demand from the electric vehicle market has put cobalt miners in their strongest position yet to secure funding.

site_title: Woh Hup unit launches VC fund, invests in co-living startup
summary: Aurum Investments, a venture capital fund affiliated with Singapore's Woh Hup, has launched a double-digit multi-million dollar fund to invest in tech-focused startups, including co-living startup Hmlet, which it has invested $1.5 million in. Hmlet, which has already reached 95% occupancy in its Singapore flagship, plans to expand to Hong Kong and Osaka next year. The investment aims to integrate Hmlet's co-living model into Aurum Land's future developments.

images.alt_text: "As property developers ourselves, we've observed the increasing need to integrate technology into day-to-day spaces to increase productivity and efficiency of brokerage and leasing transactions, to allow owners to focus on face-to-face interactions. - Aurum's Ms Yong.

site_title: SoftBank's Saudi links may mean cash after purge
summary: SoftBank's Saudi connections may provide a steady flow of funds, allowing the company to invest without increasing its debt burden. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who has contributed nearly half of the US$100 billion invested in the SoftBank Vision Fund, is consolidating his power through an unprecedented purge of officials. This could lead to continued investments in emerging technologies, potentially generating revenues to pay down debt. However, any unforeseen reversal in the prince's fortunes may raise questions about the sustainability of these investments.

site_title: Mineral Resources bids for Australian gas firm AWE
summary: Australia's Mineral Resources has made an all-share bid for domestic gas producer AWE Ltd, surpassing a A$442 million offer from China Energy Reserve and Chemicals Group. The bid is targeting AWE's stake in the Waitsia gas project in Western Australia, considered the country's biggest conventional gas find onshore in four decades. The Mineral Resources offer tops the Chinese bid by a slim margin, with AWE set to decide on the proposal in the coming weeks.

site_title: Singapore competition panel lifts curbs on car service and repairs
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has lifted curbs on car service and repairs, allowing drivers to choose workshops for repairs without voiding their warranties. Existing and new warranties will be affected by the change, which aims to facilitate a more competitive market for car repairs and servicing. Independent workshops will now be able to charge lower prices, and car dealers can only void warranties if they establish damage or defects caused by the workshop. The move is expected to give car owners more choice and open up the market, with some industry sources estimating that authorised workshops can charge up to three times more for comparable parts and servicing.

site_title: Three Singapore firms in Deloitte's 2017 ranking of fastest-growing Asia-Pac tech firms
summary: Three Singapore companies, vKirirom, Sense Infosys, and Yourwifi, made it to Deloitte's 2017 Asia Pacific Technology Fast 500, ranking 28th, 151st, and 292nd respectively. The top 10 companies saw average revenue growth of 11,995%, with many focused on mobile entertainment, digital finance, and IoT solutions. Chinese companies dominated the rankings, with 119 of the top 500 positions. Revenue growth across the Asia-Pacific region averaged 600% in 2017, up from 573% in 2016.

site_title: Banks sing auld lang syne amid existential question: what is a bank?
summary: Banks are reevaluating their roles amidst the rise of fintechs. A recent McKinsey report acknowledges that banks have lost significant market share to fintechs, contrary to its previous assessment. This shift raises questions about the future of traditional banking. As fintechs continue to innovate, banks must adapt to remain competitive, potentially exploring new business models, such as becoming platform companies. This transformation could be crucial for banks to maintain their customer base and remain relevant in the years to come.

site_title: Japan's US$150b ETF binge seen slowing next year
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to cut its annual buying target for domestic exchange-traded funds (ETFs) by as much as a third, from 6 trillion yen ($71 billion), due to improved market conditions. The BOJ's ETF buying goal has been criticized for distorting the market. Toru Ibayashi, head of Japanese equities at UBS Wealth Management, predicts the target will be reduced to 4 trillion yen by the end of March, while Soichiro Monji of Daiwa SB Investments Ltd expects a similar reduction.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro forms a joint venture with Uber through the acquisition of Lion City Holdings Pte Ltd, with a cash consideration of S$295 million. Analysts are neutral on the transaction, citing potential synergies and fair pricing, but competition from Grab remains. City Developments Limited raises its privatisation offer for M&C, implying a 25% discount to market value and potential value unlocking through Reit conversion.

site_title: For Berliners, life in techno capital is not always a party
summary: Berlin, Germany's capital city, faces an understaffed and underfunded administration, with chronic understaffing and cost cuts affecting public services for 15 years. Despite its reputation as a vibrant art and techno scene, the city struggles with a heavily indebted budget, leaving some services in disarray.

site_title: New flats and new role for Dakota Crescent estate
summary: Dakota Crescent, one of Singapore's oldest public housing estates, will undergo redevelopment with new public flats built nearby. The historic central cluster of buildings, including the iconic dove playground, will be retained and repurposed for civic and community uses. Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong announced the plan, aiming to provide more public housing options near the city while preserving the estate's historical significance. The redevelopment is part of a larger effort to reimagine Dakota Crescent as a mixed-use area with attractive new flats, community spaces, and amenities.

site_title: Monsanto offers cash to US farmers who use controversial chemical
summary: Monsanto is offering cash back to US farmers who use its weed killer, XtendiMax with VaporGrip, despite regulatory restrictions on its use. The company will refund farmers over half the sticker price of the product if they spray it on engineered soyabeans. The move comes as federal and state regulators require training for farmers and limit when dicamba-based herbicides can be used. Monsanto aims to dominate soyabean production with its Xtend brand, and the cash-back offer may convince farmers to use the chemical despite its potential for crop damage.

site_title: Uber's taxi U-turn sets a better path in South-east Asia
summary: Uber has struck a deal with ComfortDelGro in Singapore, surrendering 51% of a 14,000-car rental subsidiary in exchange for more drivers on its system. This move comes after the company burned through billions in South-east Asia due to intense competition. The deal is seen as a strategic shift for Uber, acknowledging that taxis may not be the main competitor it once thought. The move aims to improve efficiency and revenue, but Uber still faces challenges from rival Grab, which secured $700 million in debt financing to expand its fleet.

site_title: India's Congress party names Rahul Gandhi president
summary: India's Congress party has named Rahul Gandhi as its new leader, succeeding his mother Sonia Gandhi. The 47-year-old, who has been the party's vice-president since 2013, led the party to its worst-ever general election defeat in 2014. Despite criticism, Rahul faces his first test as Congress leader in elections in Gujarat, where the BJP has ruled for over two decades. The move marks the end of Sonia Gandhi's nearly two-decade tenure as party president.

site_title: Clearbridge Health IPO prices 88m shares at S$0.28 each
summary: Clearbridge Health, a Singapore-based medtech investor, is raising S$21.4 million through an initial public offering (IPO) of 88 million shares at S$0.28 each. The company plans to focus on precision medicine services and will start trading on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on Dec 18. The IPO proceeds will be used to expand medical clinics and laboratory testing services, and to acquire a medical centre in the Philippines.

site_title: Minorities in the dark over Datapulse's fate
summary: Datapulse Technology, a Singaporean digital media storage company, has undergone a series of perplexing events in November, including the sudden sale of its majority owner and CEO, Ng Cheow Chye, and the shelving of a key property deal. The company's new majority owner, Ng Siew Hong, acquired a 29% stake for nearly S$35 million, with other executives selling their shares. The changes have left minority shareholders in the dark about the company's future plans and control. The company has since announced a board revamp, including the resignation of independent directors and the appointment of a new CEO.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Comfort needs to reinvent itself before it becomes a museum piece
summary: Comfort, Singapore's largest taxi operator, has acquired 51% of Uber's Singapore car rental unit for S$295 million. The deal gives Comfort access to 12,450 private-hire vehicles, and will integrate all Comfort taxis into Uber's ride-sharing app. The move aims to boost drivers' earnings and validate Uber's strategy in Asia, where part-time drivers are not viable. Comfort's taxi business is expected to decline, with the city's taxi population at an eight-year low, and the operator will reinvent itself as a fleet owner and manager for Uber.

site_title: Model of an agency owner
summary: Bonita Ma, founder of Basic Models Management in Singapore, rose from managing a small agency to grooming supermodels for global runways. The agency, which started in 2012, has produced celebrity models like Fiona Fussi and Aimee Cheng-Bradshaw, and has a steady source of over 70 models. Despite early struggles, Ma's dedication and hard work have expanded the agency to a team of staff, including an artiste manager, booker, and PR manager. Basic Models now has its own studio and has expanded into the Artiste division, with plans to make a dent in the international market with her homegrown stars.

site_title: PE fund aims to fill gap in energy and chemicals sector
summary: A group of Singaporean professionals has formed a private equity fund to attract small European companies with specialized chemicals technologies to the city-state. The fund aims to deliver 15% returns over 10 years, capitalizing on a perceived gap in the current growth strategy for Singapore's energy and chemicals sector. This move seeks to leverage the group's deal structuring expertise and understanding of the global chemicals market.

site_title: IRAS appoints Ng Wai Choong as new commissioner and CEO
summary: IRAS appoints Ng Wai Choong as new commissioner and CEO, succeeding Tan Tee How on Feb 1, 2018. Ng, current Energy Market Authority chief executive, will lead IRAS in fostering an internationally competitive tax environment. He will relinquish his role as returning officer for the Presidential and Parliamentary elections and be succeeded by Tan Meng Dui.

site_title: Blast in Manhattan subway set off by man wearing explosives
summary: A blast occurred in the Manhattan subway near Times Square, injuring four people, including the suspect, who was found to have an explosive device strapped to his body. The incident happened at 7:19 am on Monday morning, prompting a response from emergency services. The suspect was arrested, and authorities are investigating the cause of the explosion.

site_title: Trafigura sees higher volatility in oil market next year
summary: Trafigura Group, a leading independent oil trader, expects increased volatility in the oil and metals markets next year, with a potential supply deficit emerging in oil in 2019. The company's profit margins fell 9% to US$887 million in 2017 due to oversupply and reduced market volatility, despite revenue increasing 39% to US$136.4 billion. Trafigura's CEO, Jeremy Weir, notes that the group's diversified business model and scale will help it navigate the changing market conditions.

site_title: Cathay Pacific extends pilot housing allowances for a year
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has decided to extend its pilot housing allowances for a year, backing down from a proposed cut due to concerns from expatriate pilots who could be priced out of living in Hong Kong. The airline had been aiming to save HK$4 billion over three years through cost-cutting measures. The decision allows time for the airline to agree on a new scheme with the pilots union, which is currently voting on whether to raise funds as a buffer against any changes. The housing allowances, worth up to HK$100,000 per month, were initially set to expire on December 29.

site_title: China rental push spurs new breed of property bonds
summary: China's push to develop the rental housing sector is allowing cash-strapped property developers to access the onshore bond market after restrictions were lifted. Longfor Chongqing, a subsidiary of Hong Kong-listed Longfor Properties, plans to issue special rental housing bonds, raising up to $1.02 billion to fund seven projects in Shanghai and other cities. This move aims to ease upward pressure on property prices by encouraging migrant workers and young couples to rent, a goal challenging China's strong preference for property ownership.

site_title: Everbright Water bags contract for 70m yuan BOT project in Dezhou, China
summary: Everbright Water has secured a 70 million yuan (S$14.3 million) contract for a public-private partnership waste water pipeline project in Dezhou, China. The project, based on a build-operate-transfer model, will last 22 years and is expected to be transferred to the local government upon completion.

site_title: US: Dow flat after Port Authority explosion
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained flat on Monday after a reported explosion at New York's Port Authority, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose slightly. The Dow Jones rose 11.25 points, the S&P 500 gained 0.85 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 6.83 points. Technology stocks contributed to the Nasdaq's gains, despite overall market stability.

site_title: Manhattan blast set off by man wearing explosives
summary: A man wearing an explosive device detonated near New York City's Times Square subway station, injuring four people, including the suspect. The blast occurred at 7:19am and sent ambulances and police cruisers rushing to the scene. The suspect was arrested, and the motivation for the attack remains unclear. The incident occurred at the height of the Christmas season, with the city filled with tourists and commuters. President Trump was briefed on the incident, which was the second attack on New Yorkers in about six weeks.

site_title: Validus licensed to deal in securities in Singapore
summary: Validus Capital, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has received a full Capital Markets Services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), allowing it to deal in securities. The licence enables Validus to offer SMEs project financing and working capital loans, expanding access to financing opportunities. CEO Ajit Raikar said the licence will help SMEs scale and grow their businesses. This move is part of Singapore's focus on fintech and supporting SMEs, demonstrating the government's forward-thinking vision.

images.alt_text: (From left) Vikas Nahata, co-founder & executive chairman, Richard Hoon, co-founder, Ajit Raikar co-founder & CEO

site_title: Asian equities set for 'bullish' road ahead driven by earnings
summary: Asian equities are expected to have a bullish year in 2018, driven by stronger earnings growth and returns. Nomura forecasts 17% returns in Indian equities, 10-15% returns in Chinese equities, and double-digit returns in South Korean equities. Credit Suisse also expects Asian equities to perform well, citing a healthy macroeconomic environment and robust earnings trends. However, rising inflationary pressures and rate hikes in the US may impact global financial markets.

site_title: Chinese steel rebounds as output curbs deepen, iron ore dips
summary: Chinese steel futures rose 1.6% to close at 3,912 yuan (S$799) a tonne, rebounding from a three-day drop, amid tightening supply due to the country's anti-pollution campaign. Output cuts in steel mills and coke plants in top steelmaking province Hebei deepened, while commercial inventories of steel products remained low. Chinese traders' stocks of rebar, a construction steel product, fell to 3.03 million tonnes, the lowest since 2011.

site_title: How safe is 'safe enough' to put driverless cars on the roads?
summary: Fully autonomous cars are not expected to significantly reduce crashes, as they will still collide with each other and conventional cars. According to a 94% statistic, most crashes are caused by driver error. Industry experts say a generally accepted definition of "safe enough" is necessary for the technology to proliferate, but this definition is difficult to establish. A Rand Corporation report warns that requiring autonomous vehicles to be nearly flawless before deployment could cost hundreds of thousands of lives. Experts estimate that autonomous cars could save up to 1.1 million lives by 2070, but delays in deployment due to regulations could result in fewer lives saved.

site_title: The Shape of Water' leads Golden Globe nominations with seven
summary: "The Shape of Water" leads the Golden Globe nominations with seven nods, including Best Motion Picture Drama and Actress Sally Hawkins. "The Post" and "Three Billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri" follow with six nominations. HBO drama "Big Little Lies" leads television nominations with 12, while "Feud: Bette and Joan" and "Fargo" receive four and three nominations, respectively. The 75th Golden Globe Awards will take place on January 7, with Seth Meyers hosting.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 35.8 points, or 1.05%, to close at 3,460.45 on Monday, with 1.5 billion shares worth nearly S$1 billion changing hands. Gainers outpaced losers 254-183. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: STI climbs to 2 1/2-year high
summary: The Straits Times Index reached a 2 1/2-year high on Monday, finishing at 3,460.45, driven by strong US jobs data and the successful conclusion of Brexit talks. Other major Asian bourses also saw gains, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng rising 0.6% and 1.1%, respectively. However, experts warn of potential event risks and caution ahead of key central banker meetings and global macro data releases this week.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Maersk sees falling rates in bearish sign for trade
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, reported a decline in international freight rates, a bearish sign for the global trade recovery. The company cited decade-old oversupply issues and a significant portion of trade (over 90%) being routed through ships as contributing factors. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) also lowered its forecast for world trade volume growth to 4% in 2018, down from a projected 4.2% this year, highlighting concerns about the sustainability of the global trade recovery.

site_title: Brexit-battered Pound as volatile as emerging market currencies
summary: The British pound has experienced high volatility, with realised swings of 9% against the dollar over the past 12 months, surpassing all developed-market peers. It now trades like an emerging market currency, ranking eighth in terms of volatility. The pound's correlation with emerging markets has decreased, suggesting it may not be as vulnerable to global shifts in sentiment.

site_title: Infinio explains Monday's volume jump with exploration of fund-raising avenues
summary: Infinio Group, a mineral oil and gas company listed on the Singapore Exchange, attributed its Monday volume jump to ongoing exploration of fund-raising avenues from existing shareholders and third-parties. The company stated no definitive agreement has been reached and no certainty exists that an agreement will be reached. Infinio clarified that the trading activity cannot be conclusively attributed to the information disclosed, and no new information was announced that may explain the trading.

site_title: China's Tencent plans to buy 5% stake in Yonghui Superstores
summary: China's Tencent plans to acquire a 5% stake in Yonghui Superstores, a department store operator, through an affiliate. The investment aims to take a 15% stake in Yonghui Superstore Co Ltd's supply chain and logistics subsidiary. Trade in Yonghui Superstores remains suspended after a 10% jump in price following local reports of Tencent's investment. This deal marks Tencent's entry into traditional retail, following Alibaba's $2.9 billion investment in Sun Art Retail Group Ltd in November.

site_title: Powering up governance in Asean with digitalisation
summary: ASEAN celebrates its 50th anniversary, marking a significant milestone in its formation of the Asean Economic Community, a platform for economic integration among its 10 member states. The region's huge potential, with a 630 million population and $1.5 trillion consumer market, makes it an attractive destination for foreign investors. However, digital transformation poses challenges, including cybersecurity threats and the need for governments to adopt a "whole of government agenda" to harness the benefits of digitalisation. To overcome these challenges, Asean governments must invest in making the Internet more affordable and sort out regulatory issues to make digitalisation ubiquitous.

site_title: Clearbridge Health prices IPO at S$0.28 a share, trading to start on Dec 18
summary: Clearbridge Health, a Singapore-based medtech investor, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.28 per share, raising S$21.4 million. The company plans to use the funds to expand its medical clinics business and acquire a medical center in the Philippines. Clearbridge, led by former Cordlife Group CEO Jeremy Yee, aims to build a healthcare business focused on precision medicine services. The company expects operating expenses to increase and cannot guarantee profitability. Clearbridge will start trading on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on December 18.

site_title: Uber stays on London Streets until at least April on appeal
summary: Uber Technologies Inc will remain operational in London until at least April 2018 after a judge scheduled an appeal hearing. Judge Emma Arbuthnot proposed two possible start dates for a five-day trial, April 30 or June 25, allowing Uber to continue operating in its busiest European market until the appeal is decided. The decision follows Transport for London's surprise ban citing safety and regulatory concerns, sending a message to tech companies about balancing the interests of the gig economy against workers' rights and traditional operators.

site_title: Keppel O&M bags S$130m contracts
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured S$130 million contracts from repeat customers. BrasFELS shipyard won hull carry-over work for Petrobras' FPSO P-69, while Keppel Shipyard fabricated a turret mooring system for an FLNG vessel bound for Mozambique's Coral gas field. Keppel O&M CEO Chris Ong attributed the wins to the yard's proven track record and expertise in various services and proprietary technology.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore housing authorities will redevelop Dakota Crescent estate for public housing while retaining iconic buildings for civic and community uses. The Competition Commission of Singapore will lift restrictions on car servicing and repairs. Digital healthtech firm Biofourmis raised US$5m in funding. SC Global Developments acquired a Tokyo commercial development, and SingHaiyi took a stake in Cromwell Property Group. Singapore shares closed 1% higher on Monday, with the STI Today index climbing 35.8 points.

site_title: Nokia's COO quits after eight months in the job
summary: Nokia's Chief Operating Officer (COO), Monika Maurer, is leaving the company after just eight months in the role. Maurer will be replaced by Joerg Erlemeier, effective immediately. The move comes as Nokia struggles in a shrinking market and faces tough competition. The company reported a sharp drop in earnings in October, citing weak market conditions and internal problems following its 2016 acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent.

site_title: Saudi Arabia lifts cinema ban, directors and movie chains rejoice
summary: Saudi Arabia lifted its 35-year-old ban on cinemas, allowing the first theatres to start showing films as early as March. The move is part of the government's liberalizing reform drive, which has also opened the door to concerts, comedy shows, and women drivers. The government plans to open over 300 cinemas with 2,000 screens by 2030, creating 30,000 permanent jobs and contributing $24 billion to the economy. Films will be censored to align with Sharia laws and moral values, but the government aims to promote a more tolerant form of Islam and encourage economic growth and diversification.

site_title: Indonesia detains 18 in pre-emptive bid to boost Christmas security
summary: Indonesian anti-terrorism police have detained 18 people with links to militant groups in a bid to boost Christmas security. The detentions, made under anti-terrorism laws, are a pre-emptive strike to prevent potential attacks, with 12 in South Sumatra, four in West Kalimantan, and one in each of East Java and Surabaya. The move comes after a series of small-scale attacks linked to Islamic State since 2016, and follows past incidents such as the 2000 Christmas Eve church bombings that killed nearly 20 people.

site_title: WTO losing focus, must rethink development - US trade chief
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer criticized the World Trade Organization, saying it's losing focus on trade negotiations and needs to redefine developing economies. He accused many countries of not following WTO rules and wealthier members of receiving unfair exemptions. Lighthizer also criticized China's trade practices and called for the WTO to help make markets more efficient. The US is pushing for new WTO rules to address issues like industrial overcapacity and state-owned enterprises, which could lead to tariffs on steel and aluminum. Lighthizer's comments reflect the Trump administration's "America First" trade agenda.

site_title: Japan's Obayashi says offices raided by prosecutors, shares tumble
summary: Tokyo prosecutors raided Obayashi Corp's offices on suspicion of "deceptive obstruction of business", sending the company's shares plummeting 8% amid a suspected bid-rigging scandal related to a magnetic levitation train project. The investigation, which Obayashi declined to comment on, is the latest in a series of high-profile cases targeting Japan's 'big four' construction firms.

site_title: Europe's migrant crisis: the ghosts of Sid
summary: Dozens of young migrants from countries including Afghanistan, Algeria, and Iraq are stranded in the Serbian town of Sid, where they attempt to cross into Croatia daily. Living in dire conditions, they receive minimal aid from volunteers and struggle to survive due to freezing temperatures, lack of money, and scarce options for transportation. With borders becoming increasingly secure, their chances of escape diminish, and some resort to desperate measures, including hiding in trucks or taking enormous risks on foot.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.78 points lower at 1,719.47 on Monday, with a trading volume of 1.64 billion shares worth RM1.96 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 444 to 409. This follows a week of gains, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.45% on Thursday.

site_title: Bluebird, Celgene myeloma therapy improves with time, study finds
summary: A novel therapy from Bluebird Bio Inc and Celgene Corp for multiple myeloma patients appears to become more effective over time, with 56% of patients in remission after nine months. The personalized CAR-T treatment, bb2121, showed a response in all but one of the 18 patients treated at the highest dose, with 27% experiencing a complete response in an earlier look at the data. The study was presented at the American Society of Haematology meeting in Atlanta.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up near 4-week highs helped by banks
summary: European shares rose near 4-week highs on Monday, driven by gains in financial and industrial stocks, with the STOXX 600 index up 0.2%. Banks led sectoral gainers, up 0.6%, following a deal on new global banking regulations. The STOXX 600 has recovered part of its losses from November but remains 2% below its two-year highs.

site_title: Minority languages on the rise in Singapore
summary: Singapore is witnessing a resurgence of minority languages, including Kristang, Baba Malay, and Boyanese, after decades of promoting English and Mandarin. The city-state's ethnically diverse population, with ancestors from China, India, and the Malay archipelago, has led to an array of languages spoken before English and Mandarin became dominant. Efforts by organizations and linguists are helping to keep these languages alive, with many Singaporeans taking an interest in reviving their ancestors' tongues, driven by nostalgia and a sense of cultural heritage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise most in 3 weeks as Tencent rebounds
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.14% to a 3-week high, driven by Tencent's 2.9% rebound for the third consecutive session. The Hang Seng index closed at 28,965.29, while China's Shanghai Composite index rose 0.98%. The rally comes despite US trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: SingHaiyi takes stake in Cromwell Property Group
summary: SingHaiyi has subscribed for 175.1 million units of stapled securities in Cromwell Property Group for A$169.6 million, a 9.9% stake. This represents a 4.9% discount to Cromwell's one-month volume weighted average price. The investment is made in conjunction with Haiyi Holdings, a wholly owned entity of SingHaiyi's controlling shareholders.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for third straight day
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a third consecutive day, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.56% to 22,938.73, driven by a weak yen boosting Japanese exporters. Market participants are awaiting the Federal Open Market Committee meeting this week, which is expected to raise interest rates for the third time this year.

site_title: Oversupply and low volatility in oil market dampen profit margins for Trafigura
summary: Trafigura Group, a leading independent oil trader, reported a 9% decline in net profit to $887 million, despite a 39% increase in revenue to $136.4 billion. The firm's gross profit margin fell to 1.6% due to oversupply and low volatility in the oil market. However, its metals and minerals division recorded a strong year, with volumes doubling. The company's CEO and CFO are optimistic about 2018, citing increasing demand, tightening supply, and potential price volatility, which they believe will drive growth in marketing, logistics, and risk management services.

site_title: Cathay Pacific backs down, extends pilot housing allowances for a year
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has backed down from a plan to cut housing allowances for its senior pilots, extending the benefits for another year. The airline, which is undergoing a cost-cutting transformation program, had proposed reducing the allowances by an unspecified amount. However, this move attracted top pilots from Chinese airlines, leading to a temporary reprieve for the pilots. The airline will continue to pay up to HK$100,000 per month in housing allowances for 12 months to allow for a new agreement with the pilots union.

site_title: Australia shares end flat on Fed caution; NZ hits record
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 3.90 points or 0.07% to 5,998.30, as investors became cautious ahead of a potential US interest rate hike. Banks and materials stocks led the gains, while industrials accounted for most of the losses. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached a fresh record high, driven by gains in Auckland International Airport and Fletcher Building.

site_title: For Berliners, life in techno capital is not always a party
summary: Berlin, the German capital known for its techno scene and vibrant art culture, faces chronic understaffing and drastic cost cuts, affecting public services. The city has been on an austerity drive for 15 years, leaving some services in disarray. Long waiting times for tasks such as registering births, obtaining death certificates, and dealing with city authorities are common. Officials acknowledge the issues, with some attributing them to the city's rapid growth and unpreparedness for the transformation following the fall of the Berlin Wall.

site_title: Golden Globes: Hollywood's test of the Weinstein effect
summary: The Golden Globes nominations will be announced Monday, kicking off an awards season overshadowed by the ongoing sexual misconduct scandal in Hollywood. Predictions suggest "Call Me By Your Name" will be a top contender with six nominations, while "The Shape of Water" and "Get Out" are expected to receive five and four nods, respectively. The Globes are seen as a chance for Hollywood to demonstrate its intolerance of misconduct, following a wave of allegations against powerful figures, including Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, and others.

site_title: Saving for retirement the top financial goal for those in Asia: survey
summary: A survey by Prudential Corporation Asia found that saving for retirement is the top financial goal for Asians, with 50% prioritizing it, followed by traveling with family. 46% of respondents are not confident in saving enough for retirement, and 83% expect to use personal savings in old age. The survey also revealed that money is the leading cause of arguments in relationships, but pooling finances together improves relationships. Overall, relationship satisfaction remains high, but optimism for improvement in love life and finances is at 56% and 67% respectively.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sweden braces itself for property market's 'November Noir'
summary: Sweden's property market is expected to experience a significant decline in November, with home prices potentially falling 3% on a monthly basis and 1% on an annual basis. This follows a 3% drop in October, the steepest decline since the 2008 global financial crisis. Analysts predict a "November Noir," but some argue that the slowdown may be a temporary blip, with prices potentially stabilizing in the coming months. Despite concerns of a repeat of the 1990s real-estate crash, households remain jittery about the market's outlook.

site_title: P2P lending platform Validus Capital gets licence to deal in securities in Singapore
summary: Validus Capital, a P2P lending platform backed by Temasek Holdings, has received a full Capital Markets Services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to deal in securities. This licence will allow Validus to offer SMEs financing products, including project financing and working capital loans. CEO Ajit Raikar stated that the licence will enable the platform to help SMEs scale and grow their businesses, aligning with Singapore's focus on fintech. The licence is seen as a significant step for Validus, expanding its access to financing opportunities for Singapore's SMEs.

site_title: Fired Indian technology workers turn to chatbots for counselling
summary: In India's US$154 billion tech outsourcing industry, thousands of workers are seeking solace in online therapy services amid job losses and automation. Chatbot therapists like Wysa and YourDOST are being used to provide counseling and support to those struggling with mental anguish. The services, which are affordable and anonymous, are helping users process their feelings about career changes and job losses. Experts say that the shift away from long-term legacy contracts and curbs on U.S. work visas is making many Indians feel stigmatized and anxious about their futures.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reverse losses, won edges up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.30% to 2,471.49 at 0630 GMT, reversing earlier losses. The Korean won rose 0.09% to 1,092.3 per dollar, while bond yields also increased. The KOSPI's recovery was attributed to a rebound in the won, which edged up against the US dollar. The onshore settlement platform quoted the won at 1,092.3 per dollar, while offshore trading showed a 0.05% gain.

site_title: Monsanto offers cash to US farmers who use controversial chemical
summary: Monsanto is offering cash back to US farmers who use its XtendiMax weed killer, despite regulatory restrictions on its use due to crop damage concerns. The company is refunding over half the sticker price of the product if sprayed on engineered soya beans. Federal and state regulators are requiring training and limiting when dicamba-based herbicides can be used, but Monsanto's incentive may encourage farmers to use the chemical anyway. The company aims to dominate soya bean production in the US with its Xtend brand.

site_title: Small Canadian miners in pole position for electric vehicle battery boon
summary: Canadian cobalt and lithium miners are in a strong position to secure funding due to a growing demand for electric vehicle batteries, with over a dozen groups, including car and battery makers, in talks to invest in their projects. Toronto-listed companies Ecobalt Solutions and Fortune Minerals are leading the charge, with potential deals worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The interest from downstream players is a game-changer for small miners struggling to develop deposits of critical battery ingredients, with cobalt's price doubling this year due to concerns of multi-year shortfalls.

site_title: Hotly anticipated bitcoin futures surge 21% on debut
summary: Bitcoin futures surged 21% on their US debut, opening at $15,460 and reaching a high of $18,700. The CBOE Global Markets' website experienced an early outage due to heavy traffic. As of 6:30 am GMT, the contract was up 17% from the open, with 2,368 contracts traded. The move is seen as a sign of growing legitimacy for the cryptocurrency, but critics warn of the risk of a bubble and price collapse.

site_title: German intelligence unmasks alleged covert Chinese social media profiles
summary: Germany's domestic intelligence service, BfV, has published the details of allegedly fake Chinese social media profiles used to gather personal information about German officials and politicians. The profiles, found on LinkedIn, were disguised as headhunters, consultants, and scholars. Over 10,000 German citizens were contacted by these fake profiles, with some connected to senior diplomats and politicians from European countries. The BfV warns public officials about the risk of leaking valuable information via social media, following similar concerns from US intelligence circles about Chinese covert activities.

site_title: Maersk sees falling rates in bearish sign for trade
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, reports a decline in international freight rates, signaling a bearish trend for global trade. The company attributes this to a decade-old oversupply issue and a global trade order book at 13.5% capacity. Despite the International Monetary Fund's forecast of 4% world trade growth in 2018, concerns about U.S. protectionism and China's economic rebalancing pose risks to the trade revival.

site_title: US, South Korea, Japan start missile-tracking drill
summary: US, South Korea, and Japan have started a joint missile-tracking drill, following North Korea's longest-range test launch to date. The two-day exercise, the sixth since June, began in waters near the Korean peninsula and Japan, simulating detection and tracking of potential ballistic missiles. The drill comes amid heightened global alarm over North Korea's nuclear ambitions, with the US and its allies seeking to demonstrate a united front against Pyongyang's growing threat.

site_title: Restrictions on car servicing, repairs and parts to be lifted: Competition watchdog
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) announced plans to lift restrictions on car servicing, repairs, and parts, allowing drivers to choose their preferred workshop. Current restrictions, which void warranties at independent workshops, will be lifted, giving consumers more options and potentially reducing prices. The change aims to promote competition among workshops and prevent authorised dealers from charging higher prices. Existing and new independent workshops will be able to compete more effectively with authorised dealers, and car owners will have more choices for repairs and servicing. The change will affect existing and new warranties.

site_title: Singapore shares resume higher on Monday afternoon; STI at 3,445.99, up 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% to 3,445.99, with about 683 million shares changing hands, as gainers outnumbered losers 177 to 166. DBS Group Holdings and UOB shares were among the top gainers, up 1.6% and 1.3% respectively. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached its highest point in five days ahead of upcoming GDP data, with investors seemingly unaffected by US trade tensions.

site_title: Everbright Water bags contract for 70m yuan project in China's Dezhou
summary: CHINA Everbright Water secured a 70 million yuan (S$14.3 million) contract for a 22-year public-private partnership waste water pipeline project in China's Dezhou. The project includes 28 kilometers of waste water pipeline and two lift pump stations. Everbright Water chief executive An Xuesong said the project recognition is a testament to the company's technological capabilities and operational track record.

site_title: Incoming Fed chair Powell faces early test of policy view as tax cuts near approval
summary: Incoming Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is set to let the expected trillion-dollar tax cut run its course through the economy, citing weak wage growth and inflation as signs of an underpowered economy. Despite a 17-year-low unemployment rate, Powell believes the economy remains below full employment, and the Fed should raise rates only gradually. Some policymakers worry that speeding up rate increases could undermine the Fed's credibility and create economic risks. Powell's dovish stance may lead to a surprise when the tax cuts kick in and the Fed stands aside, potentially raising interest rates only twice next year.

site_title: Asia: Traders extend global rally after US jobs data, eyes on Federal Reserve
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday following the US jobs data, which showed 228,000 jobs created last month and a 17-year low unemployment rate. The rally also boosted the Dow and S&P 500 to all-time highs. Investors are now focusing on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later this week, expecting a potential interest rate hike. Bitcoin surged over $1,300, jumping back above $16,000, amid a buying frenzy and concerns about a bubble.

site_title: CAO appoints new CFO; seconded from parent company's audit department
summary: CAO appoints Xu Guohong as CFO, replacing Wang Chunyan, both seconded from parent company CNAF's audit department. The changes are effective immediately, with Xu taking over as general manager of CNAF's audit department.

site_title: Mineral Resources trumps Chinese bid for Australian gas producer AWE
summary: Australia's Mineral Resources has offered A$484 million (US$364 million) for domestic gas producer AWE Ltd, surpassing a sweetened bid from state-owned China Energy Reserve and Chemicals Group (CERCG). The bid is for AWE's stake in the Waitsia gas project in Western Australia, considered the country's biggest conventional gas find onshore in four decades. AWE's shares jumped 15% after the announcement, trading above both offers, while Mineral Resources shares fell 4.8%. The acquisition is expected to provide Mineral Resources with secure energy supplies for its operations.

site_title: Britain's jailed PR mastermind Max Clifford dies
summary: Max Clifford, a notorious British PR mastermind, died on Sunday after suffering a heart attack following a sudden collapse at Littlehey Prison in Cambridgeshire. Clifford, 74, was serving an eight-year sentence for multiple sexual assaults against teenagers, and his death will be investigated by the independent Prisons and Probation Ombudsman. Clifford was convicted in 2014 and had a high-profile career promoting celebrities, including The Beatles and Frank Sinatra, before being jailed under Operation Yewtree, a police investigation into past sex offenses.

site_title: China rental push spurs new breed of property bonds
summary: China's push to develop the rental housing sector has led to the launch of special rental housing bonds, allowing cash-strapped property developers to access the onshore bond market. Longfor Chongqing Enterprise Development has filed a plan to issue bonds worth up to 5 billion yuan to fund seven rental housing projects. The bonds, with maturities up to 15 years, aim to match the long payback period for rental projects and provide developers with a way to raise funds without the stringent scrutiny of the domestic bond market.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge lower, won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.14% to 2,460.59, weakening on Monday. The Korean won rose 0.16% to 1,091.6 per dollar, while bond yields fell. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rose 0.17%. Foreigners sold 64,043 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar has fallen 9.37% against the won this year.

site_title: Snow shuts runways, disrupts flights across UK
summary: Heaviest snowfall in four years hit the UK, causing widespread disruption on Sunday. Runway closures at Birmingham Airport led to flight suspensions, while hazardous road conditions affected travel. London's Heathrow Airport also experienced disruptions. The snow is expected to clear by early afternoon, with flights resuming. The heavy snowfall has caused significant travel disruptions across the UK.

images.alt_text: The heaviest snowfall to hit Britain in four years caused widespread disruption on Sunday, with roads becoming hazardous and flights grounded following runway closures.

site_title: 3 Singapore players in Deloitte's 2017 ranking of fastest-growing tech firms in Asia-Pacific
summary: Three Singapore companies - vKirirom, Sense Infosys, and Yourwifi - made it to Deloitte's 2017 Asia Pacific Technology Fast 500, ranking 28th, 151st, and 292nd respectively. They experienced revenue growths of 1421%, 362%, and 174% over three years. The rankings were led by Tencent-backed Wuhan Douyu Network Technology, which grew at a rate of 70,776% and developed a live game streaming video platform.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat ahead of Fed rate decision, NZ up
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Monday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate decision, despite a strong start and gains in the materials and energy sectors. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.5 points to 5,995.8, with miners and big banks leading the gains. However, losses in the utilities and healthcare sectors, particularly CSL Ltd, offset some of the gains. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.2% to 8,255.44.

site_title: Philippines defied experts' advice in pursuing dengue immunisation programme
summary: The Philippines rolled out a dengue immunization program in 2016, despite warnings from health experts that the vaccine's safety and cost-effectiveness had not been established. The program, which immunized 830,000 children, was suspended after Sanofi Pasteur warned that the vaccine may increase the risk of severe dengue in recipients who had not previously been infected by the virus. Local experts had recommended a slow roll-out and baseline study of dengue prevalence, but these recommendations were ignored. The program's suspension is now supported by the World Health Organization.

site_title: New Zealand names Adrian Orr as new reserve bank governor
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank has appointed Adrian Orr as its new governor, replacing acting governor Grant Spencer. Orr, currently chief executive of the New Zealand Superannuation Fund, will begin a five-year term on March 27. The appointment was welcomed by Finance Minister Grant Robertson, who praised Orr's technical and leadership qualities. The New Zealand dollar rose following the announcement, reaching 68.88 cents against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Adrian Orr has been appointed New Zealand's new central bank governor, finance minister Grant Robertson said.

site_title: Ferry freed after running aground at France's Calais port
summary: A ferry with over 300 people on board ran aground in Calais, France, on Sunday in high winds. The P&O vessel, The Pride of Kent, hit a gangway while reversing and was eventually freed after several hours with the help of three tug boats and the assistance of local authorities. No injuries were reported, and passengers were provided with food and drinks while waiting to disembark.
