The incident interrupted traffic at the port, but sea traffic resumed partially in the afternoon.

site_title: SC Global makes maiden acquisition in Tokyo's Ginza
summary: SC Global Developments, a Singapore-based property group, has acquired a 12-storey commercial development in Tokyo's Ginza district for an undisclosed price. The 7,785 sq ft property, known as GINZA 12, is located near a major metro station and features 13 levels, including one in the basement. The acquisition includes leases with two Michelin-starred restaurant operators, and SC Global plans to diversify into Japan's growing tourism market. This marks the group's maiden acquisition in Tokyo and its entry into the Japanese market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Technics Oil & Gas applies for time extension to release FY2017, Q1 2018 financial statements, hold AGM
summary: TECHNICS Oil and Gas Limited has applied to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority for a time extension to release FY2017 and Q1 2018 financial statements, as well as convene its annual general meeting (AGM). The company, which has been under judicial management since June 2016, cited extensive restructuring and the need for clarity for shareholders and investors as reasons for the delay. The judicial management has been extended until Jan 16, 2018, with the company seeking an additional extension for the financial statement release.

site_title: Bluebird, Celgene Myeloma therapy appears to improve in time
summary: A novel CAR-T therapy from Bluebird Bio Inc and Celgene Corp has shown promising results in a small trial for patients with multiple myeloma, a blood cancer. The therapy, bb2121, generated a response in all but one of 18 patients, with 56% in remission after nine months. The treatment targets the BCMA protein and has persisted for over a year in some patients, although not everyone improved, and the benefit wasn't always durable. A larger study is underway to seek regulatory approval, with the goal of 94 patients.

site_title: London property market likely to continue price drop in 2018
summary: London's property market is expected to continue its price drop in 2018, with home values predicted to fall 2% after a 1.8% decline this year. The real estate website operator, Rightmove, attributes the decline to economic and political uncertainty, as well as tightened lending criteria and increased stamp duty for second-home owners. National house-price growth is forecast to cool to 1% next year, the weakest since 2011, and some areas of London will perform better than others, with first-time buyer properties showing resilience.

site_title: WTO, under fire from US, meets in Buenos Aires
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) opened a conference in Buenos Aires amid US hostility to multilateral trade accords. US President Donald Trump has threatened to pull the US out of the WTO, criticizing its effectiveness in defending American interests. The conference aims to address stalled trade talks and China-related disputes, with expectations for a breakthrough low. WTO Director-General Roberto Azevedo sought "political commitment" from the US to make progress, while the European Union and Japan announced a major trade agreement.

site_title: Chinese steel rebounds as output curbs deepen, raw materials surge
summary: Chinese steel futures rebounded as output cuts deepened in line with the country's anti-pollution campaign, tightening supply and pushing up prices. Iron ore futures jumped nearly three percent and coke climbed over five percent. The most-active rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange rose 1.7 percent to 3,916 yuan (S$800.51) a tonne. China's production cuts in Hebei, the top steelmaking province, further tightened supply, with commercial inventories of steel products remaining low and demand firm. Steel prices are expected to stay strong in the near term due to robust construction activity in east and southern China.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro up on Uber deal; analysts keep ratings unchanged
summary: ComfortDelGro's stock rose 4.2% after the company agreed to take a majority 51% stake in Uber's car rental business Lion City Holdings for S$642 million. The deal values ComfortDelGro's taxis and Lion City Rental's private-hire cars at S$1.99 per share. Analysts praised the move but maintained their outlook, citing pending regulatory approval and uncertain growth potential for ComfortDelGro's taxi business. CIMB Research, UOB Kay Hian, and Phillip Securities all maintained their "hold" and "buy" ratings, citing potential benefits to the deal and the combined fleet's larger size compared to Grab's alliance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with gains, building on the previous week's records on Wall Street and strong US jobs data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.27% to 28,716.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains come despite US President Trump's new threats to extend the stocks rally, with traders brushing off the uncertainty.

site_title: Centurion prices Hong Kong IPO shares at HK$3.18; deal 4.1 times subscribed
summary: Centurion Corp priced its Hong Kong IPO at HK$3.18 per share, 4.1 times subscribed. The 36-million-share offering raised about HK$69.7 million in net proceeds, with HK$62.7 million to fund an Australian student accommodation project. The remaining HK$7 million will be used for general working capital. Trading of Centurion shares in Hong Kong will start on Dec 12, with shares finishing 4.5% higher at S$0.58 on Monday.

site_title: Biofourmis raises US$5m in Series A funding from NSI Ventures, Aviva Ventures
summary: Biofourmis, a Singapore-based digital healthtech firm, has secured US$5 million in Series A funding from NSI Ventures and Aviva Ventures. The company's health analytics platform, biovitals, uses artificial intelligence to analyze physiology data from wearables, enabling medical professionals to intervene before critical medical events. Biofourmis has also partnered with the Mayo Clinic to access anonymized healthcare data and refine wearable biosensor-based diagnostic algorithms. The funding will be used to scale up commercial operations and prepare for the commercial launch of its software as a service platform.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.70 points to 1,722.95 at 9:09am on Monday, driven by gains. The index saw 120 gainers against 78 losers, with a trading volume of 94.73 million lots worth RM39.35 million.

site_title: Fitch upgrades Philippines in win for Duterte's economic plans
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded the Philippines' sovereign rating to BBB with a stable outlook, boosting President Rodrigo Duterte's economic plans, including a tax reform that aims to strengthen the fiscal outlook. The upgrade puts the Philippines on par with Italy and ahead of Indonesia, with the economy expected to remain one of the fastest expanding in Asia. Fitch attributes the upgrade to strong macroeconomic performance, sound policies, and investor confidence. The tax reform plan is expected to boost revenue, spur infrastructure spending, and underpin economic expansion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher following new highs on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, following record highs on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.36% to 22,892.31, while the Topix index increased 0.28% to 1,808.84. The yen's weakness against the dollar contributed to the gains.

site_title: Oil prices drop on increased US rig drilling
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, dropping 0.4% to $57.10 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures and 0.5% to $63.08 a barrel for Brent crude futures. The US rig count rose by two to 751, the highest level since September, indicating a further increase in American production and potentially undermining Opec's efforts to tighten markets. The US crude production has risen by 15% since mid-2016, nearing levels from top producers Russia and Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Monday, pulled down as the latest rise in the US rig count pointed to a further increase in American production, potentially undermining efforts led by Opec to tighten markets.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades MCT to 'buy' on revised optimism in commercial office sector
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) from "hold" to "buy" with a target price of S$1.75, citing strong earnings visibility and resilience in the commercial office sector. The broker believes VivoCity and Mapletree Business City Phase 1 properties will remain resilient despite uncertainty. However, DBS cautioned on VivoCity's weak operational performance, which could be mitigated by revamping the mall's offerings. MCT units rose 0.6% to S$1.59 following the upgrade.

site_title: Bitcoin futures start trading on CBOE exchange
summary: Bitcoin futures started trading on the CBOE exchange, with January futures opening at US$15,460 and reaching US$15,940 after trading 398 contracts. The futures are cash-settled based on the Gemini Exchange's auction price of bitcoin in US dollars. On the same day, bitcoin was up 2.62% at US$14,990 on the Luxembourg-based Bitstamp exchange, and US$15,600 on the Gemini Exchange.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars on defensive as yield premiums dwindle
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained stable on Monday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting and potential US rate hikes. The Aussie was stuck at US$0.7515, while the kiwi dollar retreated to US$0.6854. Yield premiums on Australian and New Zealand debt narrowed, with Australian two-year debt yields just three basis points above US rates, the smallest premium in 17 years. The Reserve Bank of Australia and New Zealand are expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with no chance of a hike before May.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars marked time on Monday as investors waited anxiously to see what the Federal Reserve would project for future US rate rises at its policy meeting this week.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, edging up 13.08 points, or 0.38%, to 3,437.72 by 9:08 am. Gainers outnumbered losers 93 to 50, with local banks City Developments and ComfortDelGro among the gainers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan big manufacturers' mood improves in Oct-Dec: govt
summary: Japan's large manufacturers turned more optimistic about economic conditions in the October-December quarter, with a business survey index of plus 9.7, up from plus 9.4 in the previous quarter. The improvement was driven by a weaker yen and a 12% jump in the Nikkei stock average, along with increased sales and profits led by auto and electronic manufacturers. This upbeat sign supports Japan's record run of growth.

site_title: Same income, but not taxes, in GOP plans
summary: Republicans' tax plans would cut corporations and businesses more significantly than employees, despite similar incomes. This means two individuals working the same job for the same hours but with different tax statuses could see vastly different tax outcomes. The Republican bills would prioritize reducing corporate taxes over reducing employee taxes, potentially widening income inequality.

site_title: Palestinians 'walking away' from talks with Pence snub: US
summary: The US accused the Palestinian Authority of "walking away" from talks by snubbing Vice President Mike Pence's visit to the region. Pence was set to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, but will not meet Palestinian Authority officials, who have reacted angrily to the US decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The US remains committed to achieving peace between Israelis and Palestinians, with a peace team working on a plan despite the setback.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, ComfortDelGro, Centurion, Fullerton Health, Datapulse Technology
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore companies made announcements affecting their shares. City Developments Limited (CDL) raised its offer price for a London-listed hotel to 620 pence per share, valuing the hotel at £2.01 billion. ComfortDelGro acquired a majority stake in Uber's rental car business Lion City Holdings for S$642 million. Centurion Corp priced its secondary-listing offer in Hong Kong at HK$3.18 per share, with net proceeds estimated at HK$69.7 million. Fullerton Health acquired a 60% stake in a Philippine-based healthcare firm. Datapulse Technology's three non-executive directors stepped down after a change in its controlling shareholder, following a stake sale by the firm's deputy chairman.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Heavy snow causes travel mayhem in northern Europe
summary: Heavy snow in northern Europe caused travel disruptions, with over 300 flights cancelled at Frankfurt Airport and ferry services affected in France. In Britain, airports suspended flights due to heavy snow, and trains were delayed or cancelled. The snowfall was the heaviest in four years, with some areas receiving over 30cm. In France, a ferry ran aground in Calais, and 20,000 homes were left without electricity due to strong winds. The weather continued to affect the region, with road incidents reported and forecasts predicting more snow until Monday morning.

site_title: Uncertainty clouds EU-Britain Brexit divorce plan
summary: The European Commission and the British government reached a deal on Brexit divorce terms, clearing the way for a second phase of talks on future trade and other issues. However, numerous questions remain, including the Irish border, financial commitments, and protection of expats' rights. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, warned that work is still needed to consolidate and clarify the deal, while Britain's Brexit Secretary David Davis contradicted earlier comments by finance minister Philip Hammond, stating that London will not honor financial commitments without a trade deal.

site_title: China's top paper says Australian media reports are racist
summary: China's top newspaper, the People's Daily, has accused Australian media reports of being racist and paranoid, labeling them as "hysterical" and "baseless" attacks on the Chinese government and people. The reports, which include concerns about Chinese interference in Australia, have sparked a war of words between the two countries. China denies any intention to interfere in Australian politics, urging the Australian government and media to focus on facts rather than prejudice and bigotry. The comments come as Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull vows to ban foreign political donations to curb external influence.

site_title: Woh Hup unit launches VC fund, invests US$1.5m in co-living startup Hmlet
summary: Singapore-based corporate venture capital fund Aurum Investments, a subsidiary of Woh Hup Holdings, has launched a VC fund and invested US$1.5 million in co-living startup Hmlet. This investment is part of the growing trend of tech-powered proptech startups in the Asia-Pacific region, which have raised over US$4.8 billion in funding since 2013. The fund is expected to support startups that are highly scalable towards local and regional real estate opportunities, aligning with Aurum's strategy to invest in tech-focused companies.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bitcoin futures launch sparks excitement, warnings
summary: Bitcoin futures launch on the Cboe Futures Exchange in Chicago, marking a milestone for the digital currency. The move is expected to be followed by a rival listing on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The Cboe has taken precautions to address wild fluctuations, and trading will be suspended for two minutes if prices go up or down 10%. Critics, including financial commentator Jim Cramer, warn that prices could tumble, while supporters, such as the Winklevoss twins, see the launch as a step towards legitimacy.

site_title: Fullerton Health to acquire 60% stake in Philippine-based Intellicare
summary: Fullerton Health, a corporate healthcare solutions provider, has agreed to acquire a 60% stake in Philippine-based Intellicare Group for an undisclosed amount. The deal is expected to complete in early 2018 and will be funded through a combination of debt, cash resources, and a perpetual bond issuance. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand Fullerton's presence in the Asia-Pacific region, with Michael Tan, Fullerton's co-founder and CEO, stating that the Philippines offers great growth potential. Intellicare will benefit from Fullerton's network and experience across the region.

site_title: Qatar signs US$8b deal to buy 24 Typhoon fighters from UK
summary: Qatar signed a $8 billion deal to purchase 24 Typhoon fighter jets from the UK, its second major defense agreement this week. The deal, worth $8 billion, was signed by Qatar's Defence Minister Khalid bin Mohammed al-Attiyah and British counterpart Gavin Williamson. The agreement follows a $1 billion deal signed with France to buy 12 Dassault Aviation warplanes. The deal aims to boost Qatar's military capabilities and provide security during the 2022 football World Cup, which Qatar will host.

site_title: Berlin police say bags of bullets found near Christmas market not linked to terrorism
summary: Berlin police have ruled out terrorism in the discovery of two bags of bullets near a Christmas market and mosque in western Berlin, saying they were likely from a private individual clearing their cellar. The incident comes nearly a year after a Tunisian Islamist attack on a Berlin Christmas market, which killed 11 people. Experts had previously safely defused a device filled with nails near a Christmas market in the city of Potsdam. The police dismissal of the bullets as unrelated to terrorism has been welcomed, with no reason to suspect a link to the market or mosque.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB unsurprised by ComfortDelGro's Lion City Rental deal, maintains 'hold'
summary: ComfortDelGro has agreed to a 51% stake in Uber's car rental business Lion City Holdings in a deal valued at S$642 million. CIMB Research maintains a "hold" rating on ComfortDelGro's stock, citing potential benefits such as lower taxi idling rates and earnings growth for its divisions. However, the broker believes growth and earnings for ComfortDelGro's taxi fleet may be unlikely due to increased competition. The deal will integrate ComfortDelGro's taxis and Lion City Rental's private-hire cars under a centralized fleet management system.

site_title: Stock market rally set to continue but all eyes on bitcoin
summary: The US stock market continues its record-breaking rally, driven by a strong jobs report and tax cut prospects, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up nearly 25% for 2017. However, investors are increasingly focusing on bitcoin, which has seen unprecedented price gains, with some predicting a massive bubble. The upcoming launch of bitcoin futures on major exchanges could further fuel speculation, but some analysts warn of a potential financial crisis and a speculative bubble bursting.

site_title: Cities tweak house plans to retain millennials
summary: Cities are introducing larger, more affordable housing options to retain millennials, who are leaving downtown areas as they start families and seek more space. The "missing middle" homes, built for single, young professionals, are no longer practical for families. Cities are adapting to this trend, offering bigger homes with more space and privacy to keep millennials in the area and support local economies.

site_title: United 2026 bid needs to build support for US
summary: The United States, Mexico, and Canada's joint bid to host the 2026 World Cup, known as United 2026, faces challenges in winning friends due to declining US popularity and strained relationships with the Arab world. Despite having necessary infrastructure and stadiums, the bid's success depends on its ability to build relationships and overcome global issues, including corruption within FIFA. The bid's commercial viability could help smooth over relationships and replenish FIFA's coffers, but time is running out as the deadline for submitting bids is approaching on March 16.

site_title: Hospital operators in merger talks to form US industry leader: WSJ
summary: Ascension Health and Providence St Joseph Health, two Catholic non-profit hospital operators, are in talks about a potential merger. The deal would create the largest US hospital chain with 191 hospitals in 27 states and annual revenue of $44.8 billion. A merger between the two would surpass HCA Healthcare Inc, the current largest US hospital operator. The talks come as the healthcare industry faces significant changes, including the Affordable Care Act and rising drug prices. A deal has not been reached, and both parties declined to comment on the report.

site_title: VW executive convicted in US may seek transfer to Germany
summary: Volkswagen executive Oliver Schmidt, convicted in the US for his role in the emissions scandal, may seek to serve his 7-year prison sentence in Germany. Schmidt's lawyer has stated that a possible appeal is being explored, but no decision has been made. Schmidt faces additional disciplinary action from Volkswagen, including damages claims and contract termination, due to his role in the emissions scandal. His conviction was part of a plea deal that admitted to conspiring to mislead US regulators and violating clean-air laws.

site_title: Apple to buy music recognition app Shazam
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks to acquire music recognition app Shazam, aiming to compete with streaming leader Spotify. The deal, expected to be announced on Monday, has not disclosed financial terms. This move follows Apple's efforts to expand its services segment and strengthen its presence in the music industry.

site_title: Fire in southern California threatening another city
summary: A fierce wildfire, the Thomas fire, is 15% contained in southern California, threatening the city of Santa Barbara and coastal town of Carpinteria. The fire has destroyed 600 structures and scorched 70,000 hectares, with strong winds easing and conditions becoming less dry. Evacuation orders were issued for parts of Carpinteria, and at least five other blazes in the region are largely contained. Despite the intensity, authorities have reported only one fatality, and US President Donald Trump has issued a state of emergency for California, authorizing federal funds.

site_title: A 'gifted sculptor' for a Diana statue
summary: Prince William and Harry have chosen sculptor Ian Rank-Broadley to design a statue of Princess Diana to commemorate 20 years since her death in a Paris car crash. Rank-Broadley, known for designing the Queen's image on UK coins, will unveil the statue in 2019, a year later than initially hoped. The brothers expressed their gratitude for the outpouring of memories and kindness about their mother, saying it highlights her enduring significance.

site_title: Singapore interest rates finally catching up with US counterpart
summary: Singapore interest rates have finally caught up with the US counterpart, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) increasing the benchmark interest rate by 0.25% to 1.5%. This move follows a 0.25% hike by the Federal Reserve in the US. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of the release of GDP data, while traders in Asia remain optimistic despite new Trump threats. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite uncertainty over tariffs.

site_title: CDL sweetens offer for M&C Hotels
summary: CDL has raised its offer price to 620 pence per share to acquire the remaining stake in London-listed M&C Hotels, with the offer now at 620 pence, up from 552.5 pence earlier. This move comes after M&C's independent directors have agreed to the deal. CDL, a majority shareholder holding 65.2% of M&C, is attempting to acquire the remaining stake in the hotel chain.

site_title: US Fed expected to hike interest rates as Trump tax cut looms
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this week, marking its third hike this year, amid growing inflation concerns despite the current low inflation rate. The move is likely influenced by the looming Republican tax cut, which could boost the economy and prompt faster rate hikes. The central bank's forecast in September indicated three rate hikes next year, but economists suggest the tax cut could accelerate the decision.

site_title: China looks to nuclear power to ease winter heating woes
summary: China is exploring nuclear power to alleviate winter heating woes in its smog-prone north. The country's State-owned China National Nuclear Corp (CNNC) has successfully tested a small, dedicated "district heating reactor" (DHR) capable of warming 200,000 households. The reactor, called the "Yanlong," requires minimal investment and can be integrated into existing heating networks. While the technology is seen as safer and more efficient than traditional nuclear plants, public acceptance remains a concern, and the government is cautious about deploying it too quickly.

site_title: Global brewers line up bids for Vietnam's Sabeco sale: sources
summary: Global brewers, including Thai Beverage, Anheuser-Busch InBev, and Kirin Holdings, are bidding for a stake in Vietnam's largest brewer, Sabeco, in a US$5 billion sale process that opened on December 11. The auction offers access to a growing market with a youthful population and beer-drinking culture. Sabeco is seen as attractive due to its high valuation of 36 times core earnings. International brewers may face challenges due to limited foreign ownership and potential lack of control. The auction is expected to attract bidders, including Asahi Group Holdings, San Miguel, and Heineken, with the sale process set to conclude on December 18.

site_title: Early raves for Last Jedi after glittering premiere
summary: The world premiere of Star Wars: The Last Jedi took place in Los Angeles, with a star-studded cast, including John Boyega, Daisy Ridley, and Mark Hamill, attending the event. Director Rian Johnson paid a heartfelt tribute to the late Carrie Fisher, and the movie is expected to break box office records with a predicted opening weekend of $220 million. Fans have praised the film's unique storyline, emotional moments, and nostalgic value, with many taking to social media to express their enthusiasm. The movie's release marks the final appearance of Carrie Fisher in the series.

site_title: Heeton set for growth after QC pain
summary: Heeton Holdings, a Singapore-based boutique property developer, is poised for growth after clearing its overhang of unsold units. The company incurred significant qualifying certificate (QC) penalties for its luxury condominium project, iLiv@Grange, which had remained unsold despite obtaining its temporary occupation permit in 2013. CEO Eric Teng attributes responsive pricing as key to overcoming this challenge. With this hurdle cleared, Heeton Holdings is expected to move forward with its growth strategy.

site_title: China's top leaders throw weight behind push to control debt
summary: China's top leaders have pledged to effectively control debt and prevent major risks in 2018, with reducing leverage as their top priority. Authorities aim to support the real economy and promote higher-quality development, while also reducing poverty, pollution, and risks. The move signals a more tolerant approach to slower growth during the debt reduction process. China's total debt is expected to reach 327% of gross domestic product by 2022, and monetary policy may remain neutral with a slight tightening bias, according to economists.

site_title: Russian street style fashion goes global
summary: Muscovite designers, such as Gosha Rubchinskiy and Andrey Artyomov, have brought "post-Soviet" style to global fashion weeks in Paris, London, and New York, with Western chains like Urban Outfitters and Topman incorporating the look into their collections. The style, which draws from Russian street fashion and the "gopnik" sub-culture, features graphic T-shirts, football scarves, and sportswear brands, worn with higher-end items. This trend may be linked to perceptions of Russia's increasing global influence and the growing interest in Russian culture among Western shoppers.

site_title: United looking at deal to invest in regional airline ExpressJet: sources
summary: United Airlines is exploring a deal to invest in regional airline ExpressJet, aiming to boost its pipeline of pilots and expand service in the eastern and midwestern US. The potential tie-up would help United close its profit gap with Delta and American Airlines. ExpressJet, an unprofitable subsidiary of SkyWest Inc, would benefit from the investment, and SkyWest's stock jumped in response to the news. United is considering acquiring an ownership stake in ExpressJet, but no financial details have been disclosed, and the talks are still developing.

site_title: Gold to re-establish uptrend after rate hike becomes fact
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates on December 13, with a 98% chance of a 0.25% hike, pricing in a 70% chance of a future rate hike. Historically, gold has bottomed out after interest rate hikes since 2015, with a 98% correlation between rate hikes and gold's price rebound. Market participants are pricing in the rate hike, leading to a selloff in gold. If the Fed follows through, gold is expected to rebound, potentially re-establishing an uptrend.

site_title: India faces a painful move to renewable energy
summary: India struggles with the consequences of its reliance on dirty power, with millions living in areas affected by coal fires and pollution. A farmer, Subedar Singh, suffered severe burns from an underground coal fire caused by a nearby power plant. The government blames a lack of funds to transition to renewable energy sources, such as solar power. India plans to increase its production of rare-earth elements to reduce its reliance on China. The country's painful reliance on dirty power poses significant health and environmental risks to its citizens.

site_title: Fire breaks out at Shell's Pulau Bukom site; no injuries reported
summary: A fire broke out at Shell's manufacturing site on Pulau Bukom in Singapore on Sunday morning, with thick smoke seen for about an hour. The fire was extinguished by the site's firefighters and no injuries were reported. The cause of the incident is under investigation. The fire occurred at around 10am and was brought under control by 11:30am, with the sky clearing by noon.

site_title: Pound to face twin forces of BOE and Brexit again
summary: The pound is expected to face twin forces of Brexit and Bank of England (BOE) decisions, which could impact its value. Despite a Brexit deal, investors may be cautious due to ongoing negotiations and widening gaps between prices and income. The BOE is also expected to keep interest rates on hold, but any hawkishness could support the pound. Meanwhile, France is pushing for an European financial transactions tax to fund climate change efforts, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Nineteen companies conduct buybacks as STI retraces recent gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 1.3% over five trading sessions from Dec 1 to 7, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for the year to 21.3%, compared to 15.9% for Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia. In the same period, 19 companies conducted share buybacks totaling S$13 million, up from S$8.7 million in the previous sessions. This reduced the STI's accumulated gain for the year to 1.5%, less than half the 3.2% reduction for the regional indices.

site_title: Wages in US remain mostly stagnant despite unemployment at new lows
summary: US wages remain stagnant despite a 17-year-low unemployment rate of 4.1% and a strong labor market. Workers' average hourly earnings grew 2.5% since last year, lagging behind pre-recession levels. The lack of wage hikes has frustrated policymakers, particularly as the economy is pulling people back into the labor market. Some industries, like construction and finance, saw year-over-year wage increases, while others, like manufacturing, remained stagnant. The White House predicts a tax cut will boost wages, but many economists are skeptical, citing historical data showing little correlation between tax cuts and increased salaries.

site_title: North West CDC launches SkillsFuture hotline
summary: Singapore's North West Community Development Council (CDC) has launched a SkillsFuture hotline for residents, offering a free 90-minute talk on skills upgrading and career planning. Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung recommends learning languages, info-comm technology, and service excellence as key areas for upgrading. The hotline, 6248-5500, is part of a national outreach programme to encourage lifelong learning and skills upgrading among Singaporeans aged 25 and above, who receive S$500 in training credits. The goal is to reach 20,000 residents over the next three years.

site_title: Central banks in spotlight but no big surprises seen
summary: Central banks are set to make significant decisions this week, with the US Federal Reserve expected to raise interest rates for the first time since June. The decision is anticipated to fuel a rally in US stocks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up by almost 25% for 2017. The Singapore bourse is also expected to rebound, following the release of robust hiring data for November and the prospect of tax cuts. The FOMC meeting will likely capture the bulk of the market's attention, with traders watching for any hints of the monetary stances at the Bank of England and European Central Bank meetings.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: France bids au revoir to Johnny Hallyday
summary: Hundreds of motorcycles and tens of thousands of fans gathered in Paris on Saturday for the funeral procession of Johnny Hallyday, the French rock star who died this past week. The procession, which included crowds singing in unison, was held under vivid blue skies despite the cold weather. Fans held pictures or homemade signs, with many having arrived from around the country to pay their respects. The event marked a farewell to the iconic French singer, who left a lasting legacy in the music world.

images.alt_text: Fans lining the street before Johnny Hallyday's funeral ceremony at La Madeleine Church in Paris.

site_title: Indonesia's nightlife fizzles amid growing conservatism
summary: Indonesia's nightlife scene is experiencing a decline due to growing conservatism, economic slowdown, and difficulties in sourcing alcohol. Revellers are reducing spending on nights out, with youth unemployment at 19% and GDP growth limited to 5%. Many venues, such as nightclubs and restaurants, are struggling to attract customers, with some closing down or relocating to smaller venues. The decline is attributed to a tightening of social spending, particularly during Ramadan, and a shift towards more conservative values in the country.

site_title: German conservatives reject "United States of Europe"
summary: German conservatives rejected the "United States of Europe" vision proposed by the Social Democrats, with whom they aim to form a governing coalition. The SPD, led by Martin Schulz, had called for a unified Europe by 2025. The conservatives, led by Chancellor Angela Merkel, refused to support the plan, indicating a potential obstacle to forming a coalition. This rejection could impact Germany's ability to shape European policies and lead to a hung parliament.

site_title: Looks like a soft Brexit for now
summary: The UK has taken a step towards a "soft Brexit" following the agreement with the EU, as the fine print indicates a temporary solution to the Irish border issue. The UK can continue to be aligned with the EU single market and customs union, allowing trade talks to begin in early 2026. This development marks the completion of the first stage of Brexit, pending agreement from the 27 EU leaders.

site_title: Egypt revives dream of a new desert capital
summary: Egypt is reviving its long-cherished project to build a new administrative capital in the Eastern desert. The city will feature luxury hotels, upscale residential districts, a modern airport, and a 345m tower, touted as Africa's tallest. The project, which has failed in the past, aims to provide a new hub for the country's government and businesses. Construction is underway, with roads being carved across vast expanses of sand, and the city is expected to be complete in the near future.

site_title: Ex-London brokers bet on Marmite in Luxembourg's Brexit haven
summary: Two former London brokers, Mark Hollis and John Heffernan, have opened a grocery store in Luxembourg, catering to financiers fleeing the UK due to Brexit. The store, "Home from Home", offers UK staples like Yorkshire Tea and Marmite, and has seen hundreds of customers since its opening. Luxembourg has become a popular destination for insurers, funds, and banks looking to relocate to the EU after Brexit, with several major companies, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, choosing the Grand Duchy as their new hub.

site_title: With new Internet rules set for vote in US, firestorm won't die
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is set to vote on a plan to rollback its 2015 net neutrality order, which would allow internet service providers (ISPs) to block or throttle rivals, and charge for faster access. The plan, proposed by FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, aims to "restore internet freedom" but critics argue it would lead to ISPs controlling the internet and stifling innovation. The vote is expected to be a 3-2 party-line decision, with opponents citing concerns over price regulation, reduced consumer choice, and potential for ISPs to shut out rivals.

site_title: Technology titans ramp up tools to win over children
summary: Facebook's new Messenger Kids app, designed for children under 12, has launched in the US with safeguards to protect young users. The app, available on Apple iOS devices, allows kids to chat with approved family members and friends, with no ads or in-app purchases. However, advocacy groups have raised concerns about the potential risks of exposing children to online environments and data collection. Meanwhile, tech giants like Google have been targeting schools with their own educational tools, such as Chromebooks, to build a loyal customer base among children.

site_title: First full-day closure of 19 stations on N-S, E-W lines 'well organised'
summary: Singapore's MRT system experienced its first full-day closure of 19 stations on the East-West and North-South lines, with commuters initially caught off guard. However, the closure was well-organised, with prominent directional signage and over 400 staff and crowd marshals directing commuters. Travel times increased significantly, but commuters adapted, with many opting for shuttle bus services or alternative modes of transport. The closure, which affects 17 EWL stations and 2 NSL stations, will recur next Sunday.

site_title: China audit finds some provinces faked data
summary: China's nationwide audit found that 10 local governments in Yunnan, Hunan, and Jilin provinces, as well as Chongqing, inflated fiscal revenues by 1.55 billion yuan (S$316.7 million). This includes 1.24 billion yuan from Hunan's Wangcheng district, where officials faked ownership transfers to boost income. The audit also found that five cities or counties raised 6.43 billion yuan in debts by violating rules, undermining Beijing's efforts to crack down on data fraud and boost economic data credibility.

site_title: With US going rogue, world fumbles for new trade consensus
summary: US trade ministers will meet in Argentina amid concerns about the World Trade Organization's ability to police global commerce. The US, under President Donald Trump, is questioning the benefits of international trade rules it helped forge. The US has withdrawn from several trade pacts, including the Asia-Pacific trade pact, and is threatening to walk away from the North American Free Trade Agreement. The meeting comes as trade volumes are set to grow faster than the world economy for the first time since 2014, but policymakers are worried about the outlook.

site_title: East German village sells for 140,000 euros
summary: A small East German village, Alwine, with a population of 20, was sold to an anonymous buyer for 140,000 euros. The village, once home to a coal briquette plant, has been in decline since reunification in 1990. It was sold at an auction with a starting price of 125,000 euros, mirroring the wider fate of ex-communist east German hinterlands. The buyer's identity remains unknown, and the village's future remains uncertain.

site_title: BlackRock is buying the bonds most at risk from added Fed hikes
summary: BlackRock is buying bonds with the highest risk of added Fed hikes, citing the flattening US yield curve and the shrinking yield spread between 2-year and 10-year Treasuries. The spread has fallen to 50 basis points, the smallest since 2007. This move comes as the Federal Reserve is set to raise rates this week and projects more hikes in 2018.

site_title: Jason Holdings' application for extension of AGM deadline rejected
summary: Jason Holdings Limited, a flooring firm, had its request for an AGM deadline extension by April 30 rejected by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). Acra requested the company to hold its AGM by December 31 this year, warning of enforcement action against directors if not complied with. The company's board is assessing the impact and may appeal to Acra for reconsideration.

site_title: Japan to revise up growth forecasts: Nikkei
summary: Japan is expected to revise up its economic growth forecasts for the current and next fiscal years, possibly to near 2% and 1.5% respectively, according to the Nikkei newspaper. The revised forecasts are attributed to a business spending splurge and buoyant exports in the third quarter, helping Prime Minister Shinzo Abe make the case for his stimulus policies. The projections will inform tax revenue estimates and the state budget for the next fiscal year.

site_title: Singapore, Shandong to further increase trade and investment
summary: Singapore and Shandong province in China agreed to increase two-way trade and investments in areas such as education, healthcare, and energy. This comes after a delegation led by Chee Hong Tat, Senior Minister of State for Communications & Information and Health, visited Shandong from Dec 6-9. The province has a GDP of S$1.35 trillion, driving demand in these sectors. Investments by Singapore companies in Shandong have grown to exceed S$13 billion, with new opportunities for both sides to partner and expand into South-east Asian markets.

site_title: Mixed reactions to launch of bitcoin futures
summary: Bitcoin futures begin trading on Sunday at 6pm EST on Cboe Global Markets Inc's Cboe Futures Exchange, marking the newest way to bet on the cryptocurrency. The launch comes amid the cryptocurrency's stratospheric price rise and wild daily gyrations. The move is seen as a significant development for bitcoin, which has taken Wall Street by storm. The futures will allow investors to hedge against price fluctuations and gain exposure to the cryptocurrency's price movements.

site_title: Pence faces rejections in upcoming trip to Middle East
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the Middle East has been met with resistance, with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and Pope Tawadros II refusing to meet with him. The US declaration that Jerusalem is its capital has been widely condemned, with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and French President Emmanuel Macron agreeing to work together to persuade the US to change its stance. Protests against the US move continue in the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and east Jerusalem, with four Palestinians killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers or by Israeli air strikes.

site_title: Giving Week may be over, but it's not too late to give
summary: Singapore's Giving Week, a nationwide event promoting corporate social responsibility, concluded on December 5. Over 130 companies participated in various initiatives, including donating to charities, hosting fundraising events, and encouraging public donations. Activities included restaurant chains donating proceeds to charities, a blood donation drive, and a social media campaign encouraging individuals to pledge donations. The event aimed to inspire Singaporeans to give back to the community, with a focus on making the city-state a more compassionate and caring nation.

site_title: Getting desired aims in exec compensation
summary: Singapore's pay-for-performance executive compensation models have been questioned, as data suggests that despite increased wages, productivity measures have decreased. Analysis of top 70 SGX-listed companies found that fixed pay for CEOs and senior executives has increased by 2% annually, but total compensation levels have remained flat. The model has also failed to differentiate compensation outcomes among executives, with variations of only 8-10% within the same job grade. Research suggests that executives are driven by low-risk options and meaningful work, rather than compensation and incentives, highlighting the need to redefine performance measures and reward structures to better motivate and retain top talent.

site_title: AnAn banks on parent group to develop investment platform
summary: AnAn International, a fuel oil trader, is developing an investment platform with the backing of its parent group, AnAn Group (Singapore). The firm has formed a joint venture with Chinese state-owned firms to engage in receivables factoring and financial leasing. AnAn International's earnings have increased, driven by a growing trading business, and it plans to monetize its investment in the joint venture if it goes public. The firm aims to leverage its parent group's partnerships and resources to expand its operations and increase investor awareness.

site_title: S Korea's Hyundai says it faces headwinds in 2018 on weaker yen
summary: South Korea's Hyundai Motor faces headwinds in 2018 due to a weakening Japanese yen, which will intensify competition in major markets. The yen's decline is expected to boost rivals like Toyota Motor Corp, making goods cheaper and increasing overseas profits. Hyundai's net profit has tumbled nearly one-third this year, and it's on track to miss its annual vehicle sales target. The think tank projects the Korean won will fetch 978 per 100 yen next year, compared to 1,018 this year, further exacerbating the challenge for South Korean carmakers.

site_title: Datapulse's chairman and two non-exec directors resign from board
summary: Datapulse Technology's chairman and two non-executive directors, Hee Theng Fong, Hillary Quah Lam Seng, and Guok Chin Huat Samuel, have resigned from the board following a change in its controlling shareholder. The firm's deputy chairman and CEO Ng Cheow Chye sold a 22.3% stake, and a new shareholder Ng Siew Hong acquired a 29% stake. The board has expressed uncertainty over the potential for new business, and the company is exploring alternative investments. Datapulse is also considering ceasing its manufacturing activities due to its loss-making nature.

site_title: Snowstorm forces Delta Air Lines to cancels hundreds of flights in US
summary: A rare early winter snowstorm hit the southeast US, forcing Delta Air Lines to cancel 375 flights as of midday Friday, just two weeks before Christmas. The storm is hitting Delta's largest hub in Atlanta, and the carrier encouraged travelers to change plans without incurring a change fee. This move may have a domino effect on travel plans, particularly for those traveling through Atlanta.

site_title: POSH eyes fleet expansion as O&M contracting rebounds
summary: POSH, a Singapore-based offshore services company, is seeing a rebound in its average offshore support vessel (OSV) fleet utilisation, with a 72% utilization rate in the third quarter, up from 64% in the second quarter. The company is experiencing increased enquiries for offshore accommodation (OA) and other business segments, and is even chartering in third-party vessels. Despite charter rates remaining under pressure, POSH has stayed cash flow positive and is poised for a turnaround in its OA segment, with three vessels currently working and two more set to mobilize soon.

site_title: North Korea blames US for tensions in rare UN talks
summary: North Korea blamed the US for soaring tensions over its nuclear program, citing "nuclear blackmail" during rare UN talks with a senior UN official, Jeffrey Feltman. Feltman's five-day visit aimed to defuse the crisis, following a new ballistic missile test capable of reaching the US. The North agreed to regular communication with the UN, but no meetings were held with leader Kim Jong Un. The US and South Korea launched a joint air exercise, which North Korea accused of being a provocation. China called for calm, urging the US to freeze military drills and North Korea to halt tests.

site_title: Dollar rise pushes gold toward biggest weekly fall since May
summary: Gold prices hovered above a four-month low on Friday, on track for their biggest weekly fall since May, after the US dollar strengthened due to optimism about the US economy and tax reform. Stronger-than-expected employment data also fueled expectations of an interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next week. As a result, spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,247.81 an ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Gold prices hovered above a four-month low on Friday and were on track for their biggest weekly fall since May after progress on US tax reform fueled optimism about the US economy and boosted the dollar.

site_title: Coffee glut hinges on selling strategy of top growers'
summary: Vietnamese and Brazilian coffee growers are holding back sales due to low prices, which may disrupt market expectations of a glut. Vietnamese farmers expect to harvest 6-7 tonnes, but only plan to sell a fraction of it until after the Tet holidays. In Brazil, growers are also hesitant to sell, with some planning to hold back until prices reach desired levels. This reluctance could offset forecasts of a larger Vietnamese crop and a bumper Brazilian harvest, potentially leading to a surplus of 5.5 million bags in 2018-19.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records after strong jobs report
summary: US stocks ended at records on Friday, driven by a strong jobs report that showed the US economy added 228,000 jobs and unemployment remained at 4.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5% to 24,329.16, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached new highs. The jobs data, combined with solid economic data from Japan and China, and a breakthrough in Brexit talks, boosted investor confidence. Healthcare and technology shares were particularly strong, with gains in companies like Mylan and Microsoft.

site_title: Big Media scrambles to meet challenge from Big Tech
summary: Major media companies, including Walt Disney Co and AT&T, are forming partnerships and making deals to strengthen their content offerings in response to the growing influence of Big Tech. The shift to online, on-demand services like Netflix is disrupting traditional pay TV models, with streaming services now accounting for 31% of Americans' primary video source. Analysts warn that the tech giants' move to create original content and acquire media assets could lead to further consolidation, with industry fundamentals worsening.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week ending December 8, 2017. Key highlights include:

- Tanker rates in the Middle East Gulf and West Africa to China remained under pressure, with some routes seeing decreases.
- Suezmax rates pushed up five points to WS 95 before easing, with Black Sea rates remaining steady.
- Aframax rates for 80,000 tonnes cross Med were steady at WS 90, while Panamax rates for 50,000 tonnes Caribs up coast market gained 20 points to WS 190.
- Clean rates for 75,000 tonnes from Middle East Gulf/Japan gained four points to WS 110.
- The cape market continued to firm, with the 5TC average pushing to further record levels, and time charter equivalents reaching around US$26,000.
- Supramax rates in the Atlantic basin saw gains, while in Asia, rates eased slightly.
- Handy rates remained unchanged, with limited information available on the period front.

site_title: Britain, EU clinch Brexit "breakthrough" with move to trade talks
summary: Britain and the European Union reached a "breakthrough" in Brexit negotiations, paving the way for trade talks and a two-year transition period. The agreement addresses the Irish border issue, allowing for an alignment with EU rules without full membership. Britain will remain in the customs union and single market during the transition period, but will not take part in EU institutions or have a vote. The move eases pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May and boosts hopes for an orderly Brexit, with negotiations on a trade pact expected to start in January.

site_title: India's PM Modi faces test as his home state votes
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's home state of Gujarat began voting on December 9, 2017, in a key electoral test of his popularity. Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has held power for 22 years, but recent economic reforms have hurt traders and small business owners. The election is seen as a challenge to Modi's leadership, with opposition leader Rahul Gandhi's Congress Party riding a wave of discontent. Despite polls suggesting a narrow BJP victory, the election's outcome remains uncertain due to India's notoriously unreliable opinion polls.

site_title: HSBC is said to step up scrutiny of China's indebted HNA Group
summary: HSBC has instructed its bankers to avoid working with HNA Group due to concerns over the conglomerate's heavy debt load and potential reputational risk. The bank is following other firms like Bank of America and Citigroup, which have also halted advisory and financing work for HNA. HNA is facing increasing difficulties raising funds amid scrutiny over its surging borrowing costs and has considered selling assets to reverse its shopping spree. The conglomerate's debt has more than doubled to a record 15.6 billion yuan in the first half of the year.

site_title: My precious
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels unveils its new high jewellery collection Le Secret, featuring intricate pieces with hidden details and symbols. The collection includes five items: Pégase Necklace, Sous Son Aile Clip, Lune Ring, Colombe Mystérieuse Clip, and Oiseau Sur La Branche Necklace. Each piece showcases the maison's expertise in craftsmanship and attention to detail, with some requiring over 2,200 hours to create. The collection is a tribute to the maison's tradition of creating personal treasures with an element of mystery.

site_title: Uber agrees to settle US lawsuit filed by India rape victim
summary: Uber Technologies Inc has agreed to settle a US civil lawsuit filed by an Indian woman who accused top executives of improperly obtaining her medical records after a company driver raped her in India in 2014. The driver was convicted and sentenced to life in prison. The lawsuit claimed a US Uber executive obtained the woman's confidential medical records, which Uber retained. The settlement resolves a second lawsuit filed by the woman in 2015.

site_title: Chinese co-working unicorn UrWork to open 2nd Singapore branch in Suntec City
summary: UrWork, a Chinese co-working unicorn backed by Alibaba's Ant Financial and Sequoia Capital, is opening its second Singapore branch in Suntec City in the first quarter of next year. The location will cater to South-east Asian and Chinese firms looking to expand into each other's markets. UrWork plans to expand globally into 35 cities with 160 locations over the next three years, positioning itself as a bridge between South-east Asia and China.

images.alt_text: "We know the needs of Chinese entrepreneurs in China and overseas, laying a solid foundation for our fast-scaling and service integration." - UrWork founder and CEO Mao Daqing

site_title: Happy Yule Year
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road light-up tradition began in 1984 as a 20-day event organized by the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board, later extended to 37 days and now lasts around 44 days. Initially, decorations were provided by shopping centers and department stores in the 1960s and 1970s, featuring modest cut-outs and banners. The current elaborate spectacle is a beloved part of Singaporean Christmas celebrations.

site_title: Britain's smaller banks jostle for business banking grants
summary: Britain's smaller banks, including Starling Bank and Tandem, are vying for multi-million pound grants to compete in the corporate banking market. The grants, worth a combined £1.1 billion, aim to reduce the dominance of big banks in SME banking. At least 12 lenders are expected to apply for funding, with Virgin Money and Monzo also planning to enter the sector. The competition is heating up, with Tandem CEO Ricky Knox stating that the market is "kicking off now" and Starling CEO Anne Boden expressing confidence in their ability to win.

images.alt_text: Virgin Money will be able to bid for a pool of grants including one worth £15m and two worth £15m and open to firms new to the sector.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 2% on China demand, but weekly losses loom
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday, driven by increasing Chinese crude demand and threats of a strike in Africa's largest oil exporter. However, US prices fell 1.7% on the week due to concerns about rising US production undermining Opec-led supply cuts. Brent crude settled at $63.40 a barrel, up 1.9% from the previous day. The rise in oil prices was short-lived, with weekly losses still looming.

site_title: Apple to buy music recognising app Shazam: report
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks to buy Shazam, a popular song recognition app, to compete with streaming leader Spotify. Shazam, founded in 1999, has reached 1 billion downloads and recently started seeing profitability. The deal could be announced Monday, but financial terms are unclear. This move comes as Apple seeks to expand its music offerings, following the success of Apple Music, which has over 30 million subscribers. The acquisition would also help Apple compete with SoundHound and integrate with Spotify, which has 80 million free users.

site_title: China's Nov producer prices ease to 4-month low as pollution curbs bite
summary: China's producer prices eased to a four-month low in November, slowing to 5.8% year-over-year, as the government's efforts to curb pollution reduced factory activity and demand for raw materials. This decrease was less than expected, with analysts attributing it to a high base year earlier. Meanwhile, consumer prices also slowed, falling to 1.7% year-over-year, as food prices dropped. The move is seen as a sign of the government's ongoing efforts to trim down the country's bloated industrial sector and address pollution issues.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Halcyon Agri, a natural rubber supplier, is buying an 80% stake in PT Pulau Bintan Djaya in Indonesia for approximately US$0.6 million, according to a conditional share sale and purchase agreement. The purchase was made by PT Hok Tong, the Indonesian subsidiary of Halcyon Agri. The deal does not disclose the purchase consideration.

site_title: Chinese capital controls send tremor through Australian property
summary: Chinese investors are struggling to seal deals in the Australian property market due to Beijing's crackdown on money flowing out of China and restrictions on Australian banks lending to foreign investors. This has led to a surge in discounted property sales, with developers offering 15-20% lower prices to local buyers. As a result, the Australian property market is experiencing a slowdown, with housing starts and completions down, and home values in Sydney falling for the third straight month. The impact is expected to be felt in larger markets, including Sydney and Melbourne, with analysts predicting a similar response to the decline in Chinese buying.

site_title: India invokes rarely-used measure to gain control of embattled developer Unitech Ltd
summary: India's bankruptcy court allowed the government to appoint new management for embattled real estate developer Unitech Ltd, citing allegations of fund diversion affecting public interest. The National Company Law Tribunal agreed to the government's plea, issuing notices to Unitech's existing directors and allowing the government to appoint 10 nominee directors. The move aims to protect the interests of thousands of buyers left in the lurch by Unitech's financial struggles.

site_title: Gift ideas for golfers
summary: BT Weekend provides gift ideas for golfers with only 16 days left until Christmas. The article highlights various gift options, including golfing accessories and experiences, that can make any golfer's Christmas merry.

site_title: Singapore shipping firm mines new value in Guinea
summary: A Singapore shipping firm, Winning International Group, has successfully mined and supplied bauxite to China after Indonesia banned unprocessed ore exports in 2014. The company, which built a river barging port in 100 days, has become one of the world's largest suppliers of bauxite, with production surging to 12.6 million tonnes last year. Winning aims to reach 40 million tonnes by next year and plans to expand its operations in Guinea, including building a shipyard and an aluminium refinery. The company's revenue reached US$292 million last year, and it plans to diversify into other mining ventures and township design.

site_title: M&C Hotels agrees to sweetened bid from CDL valuing it at £2b
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels has agreed to a sweetened takeover offer from City Developments Limited (CDL) valuing the company at approximately £2 billion. CDL, majority shareholder of M&C, offered 620 pence per share in cash to acquire the 34.8% of the company it doesn't already own. The offer has been recommended by M&C's independent directors and was announced before a Takeover Panel deadline. This marks a significant development for the London-listed hotelier.

site_title: HSBC beefs up Asia research team with 15 new analysts in China
summary: HSBC has expanded its Asian research team by hiring 15 new analysts in China, following the launch of its Chinese securities joint venture, HSBC Qianhai Securities. The team will deliver research views across various sectors, including IT, healthcare, and autos. The move comes as China allows foreign ownership in joint-venture firms to rise to 51% from 49%. This expansion aims to help clients navigate the Chinese market, which has seen a slowdown in foreign investment.

site_title: 40 orders collected for Lamborghini's new SUV
summary: Lamborghini unveiled its new Urus SUV, boasting 650hp and a top speed of 305km/h, making it the fastest production SUV in the world. The Urus is designed for daily living, offering a higher seating position, room for five people, and a spacious boot. With 40 pre-orders in Singapore, Lamborghini expects the Urus to double its 2016 sales figures, potentially leading to record sales for the brand.

site_title: STI snaps four-day losing streak on upbeat regional data
summary: Singapore stocks ended the four-day losing streak on Friday, jumping 36.5 points or 1.1% to close at 3,424.64, driven by positive regional data and upbeat US tax reform optimism. The Straits Times Index lost 24.9 points week-on-week. Asian markets also saw gains ahead of US jobs data, while Japan's economy expanded at an annualised 2.5% in the third quarter and China reported strong growth in exports and imports. Analysts expect Asian equities to deliver gains in 2018 due to a global recovery scenario.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: ComfortDelGro to buy 51% of Uber's Lion City rental car firm
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean taxi giant, is acquiring 51% of Uber's rental car firm Lion City Holdings for $642 million. The deal will centralize fleet management, increasing efficiency and reliability for customers. ComfortDelGro's CEO sees the partnership as a "win-win," with benefits for both companies and consumers. The move is expected to help ComfortDelGro stem losses from its taxi rental business and compete against rival Grab in the disrupted transport sector. Regulatory approval is required for the deal.

site_title: Family-friendly paradise
summary: The Maldives, a long-romantic destination, is now welcoming families of all ages. Luxury hotel group Anantara has cornered the family-friendly market, with three out of four resorts catering to guests of all ages. Anantara Dhigu, the largest property, offers a range of healthy activities for children, such as beach and natural wildlife exploration, to burn off excess energy without sensory overload. This approach allows families to enjoy the tropical paradise without sacrificing romance, making the Maldives an attractive destination for couples with kids.

site_title: Bitcoin hasn't replaced cash, but investors don't care
summary: Investors are buying up Bitcoin as a virtual store of value, rather than a means of payment, with the price reaching new highs above $17,000. The cryptocurrency's decentralized nature and limited supply have led to a focus on its gold-like qualities, with many believing it will be used as a hedge against inflation or economic uncertainty. The Bitcoin community is divided on its potential for widespread adoption, with some arguing that it needs to be integrated into traditional payment systems, while others believe it will remain a niche asset.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally after Brexit, banking rules deals
summary: European stocks rallied to a week's high on Friday after Britain and the EU announced a breakthrough in Brexit negotiations and new banking regulations. The European Commission said progress was made on the Irish border issue, lifting the Stoxx 600 0.8% and the euro zone banking index 2.3%. Financial markets were boosted by the news, with the euro zone banking index seeing its best gains in five months. The rally came despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesian Pizza Hut operator said to be planning US$150m IPO
summary: Indonesian pizza chain PT Sriboga Raturaya plans a US$150 million initial public offering (IPO) in the first half of 2018. The company, which operates Pizza Hut and Marugame Udon, is forecast to expand its Indonesian pizza market to 8.81 trillion rupiah by 2021. This IPO could help revive Indonesia's domestic IPO market, which has seen a 30% decline in fundraising this year. Sriboga Raturaya joins other companies, including Hermina Hospital Group and GarudaFood Group, in seeking to list shares on the market.

site_title: Outlier economist
summary: New Zealand Treasury chief executive Gabriel Makhlouf argues that economic orthodoxy, which views globalization and technology as inherently beneficial, is incomplete. He believes that while globalization and technology bring prosperity to those who adapt, the rapid pace of change can lead to global unhappiness. Makhlouf suggests that managing the pace of change, keeping markets open, and improving living standards are key to economic stability. His perspective challenges the conventional view that globalization and technology are solely drivers of prosperity.

site_title: Ziwo to seek shareholders' nod for change of business to green energy
summary: Ziwo Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, plans to seek shareholders' approval to change its business to focus exclusively on green energy in China and Southeast Asia. The company aims to exit its loss-making raw materials production business and pursue more green-energy projects, including electric vehicle charging stations and eco-friendly personal mobility transport. The proposed name change to BM Mobility Ltd is also part of the plan, reflecting its focus on the electric vehicle industry. The company plans to expand its green-energy projects and service capabilities, with potential investments in green energy assets or businesses.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Sweet deal
summary: Harry's CHIJMES is offering a complimentary rum-spiked baked chocolate with any main course for dine-in from Sunday to Thursday until Dec 21, 2017. To qualify, bring a magazine or screenshot of this offer. This promotion is not applicable with other offers or privileges, and terms are subject to change.

site_title: Toronto votes to regulate and restrict short-term rentals
summary: Toronto city council approved regulations governing short-term rentals, requiring operators to register with the city. Homeowners can only rent their principal residence on homesharing sites for up to 180 days per year, with restrictions on listing income properties and secondary suites. The move aims to increase long-term rentals and alleviate the city's affordability crisis, following similar rules in Vancouver. Airbnb welcomed the regulation, saying it legitimizes the activity of most hosts.

site_title: Changing the trend - or not
summary: The Shanghai market has experienced a significant trend-break, dropping below a long-term trend line, head and shoulder, and rounding top price patterns, signaling a potential market collapse. This trend-break pattern is reminiscent of market collapses in the past, but the US indices, including the DOW, S&P, and Nasdaq, do not show this pattern. Historically, these patterns take months to develop, giving investors time to prepare. However, the US indices are currently at record highs, suggesting a potential correction, while the Shanghai Index has smashed through key support levels, indicating a trend-reversal signal.

site_title: Top Glove aims to dominate half of global surgical gloves market
summary: Top Glove Corporation Bhd, a Malaysia-based rubber glovemaker, aims to dominate half of the global surgical gloves market after acquiring Aspion Sdn Bhd for approximately RM1.28-1.44 billion. The acquisition is expected to increase revenue by 20% and position the company as the world's largest surgical glove manufacturer. Top Glove's combined market share will be 30% post-acquisition, with a goal to grow to 40% in the future. The deal is expected to take place by next February, with the new shares to be issued not exceeding 10% in value of the purchase consideration.

site_title: GTS pack adds value to Porsche's Boxster and Cayman
summary: Porsche has introduced the GTS treatment for its 718 Boxster and Cayman models, adding extra features and value to the vehicles. The GTS models typically appear midway through a Porsche's lifespan, providing a premium upgrade for owners. The new additions include upgraded interior materials, sportier exterior styling, and performance-enhancing technologies. The GTS treatment is seen as a worthwhile investment, offering a unique driving experience and increased exclusivity for owners.

site_title: Cambodia goes all-in on China in casino port city
summary: Sihanoukville, Cambodia, is undergoing a significant transformation due to Chinese investment, with the city becoming a focal point for Chinese money and influence. The influx of Chinese investors has led to a boom in the city's casinos, hotels, and real estate, with many landowners benefiting from the increased demand. However, Western visitors and locals are facing eviction and economic displacement, with rising prices and noise from construction discouraging tourism. The close relationship between Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Sen and Chinese President Xi Jinping has strengthened, with China offering over $7 billion in investment, cementing the country's economic ties with China.

site_title: Do good, eat good
summary: Chef for a Cause 2017, a fundraising event for the Special Education Financial Assistance Scheme, will feature 12 chefs cooking 24 signature dishes on December 10 at Novotel & Mercure Singapore. Participating chefs include Daniel Sia and Pang Kok Keong. Tickets are available at projecthappyfeet.org/cfac17, with proceeds supporting the scheme first started by chef Jimmy Chok in 2009.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: JP Morgan Cazenove expects a strong start for equities in 2018, despite concerns over growth momentum peaking and potential liquidity conditions. The firm remains "overweight" on equities, citing robust earnings growth, above-trend activity, and low real interest rates. Central bank tightening is still in its early stages, and a yield curve inversion is unlikely until at least the second half of the year. Emerging markets are expected to consolidate, with Japan being overweight for 2018 due to ongoing central bank support.

site_title: All eyes on Bitcoin's futures trading debut in the wake of latest spike
summary: Bitcoin's price surged past $17,000 this week, driven by the introduction of futures trading, which will begin on Sunday. The move has sparked debate over whether it will be positive for the cryptocurrency, with some predicting a "cooling-off period" and others expecting a "fool's game." Regulators are also expressing concerns about the lack of transparency and regulation of underlying reference products. While some experts believe the move will reduce exchange risk and make Bitcoin more attractive for hedging, others predict it will lead to a bubble and increased scrutiny that will ultimately harm the cryptocurrency.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: The M-pire strikes back
summary: BMW's M cars have found a new home in Singapore with the opening of Performance Munich Autos (PMA) showroom and servicing centre at 315 Alexandra Road. This marks BMW's presence in the city-state, catering to enthusiasts and racing fans. The new dealership is a significant addition to the automotive landscape in Singapore, offering exclusive M cars and services to local customers.

site_title: iFAST unit offering US-listed securities dealing services
summary: iFAST Financial Pte Ltd, a Singapore subsidiary of iFAST Corporation Ltd, is offering US-listed securities dealing services through the FSMOne account, with a commission fee of 0.08% and a minimum of US$8.80 per trade. This move aims to assist investors in Singapore seeking exposure to the US market at competitive pricing. The introduction follows the launch of US-listed stocks and ETFs on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Hong Kong Exchange (HKEX).

site_title: Believe the hype
summary: The article highlights the top picks for 2017, including the best film "A Ghost Story", TV show "Master of None Season 2", and album "Cigarettes After Sex". The year also saw the resurgence of Netflix as the disruptor of the year, with its shows becoming more popular and its personalization system improving. In the world of shopping, the Rolex Oyster Perpetual Sea-Dweller was a must-buy watch, while Dover Street Market in Singapore was a must-visit retailer. The iPhone X was also a highly sought-after item, despite its limited supply.
