site_title: Standout art
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Notable events and releases in 2017 include Pangdemonium's "Dragonflies," a play tackling immigration and xenophobia, and Ong Keng Sen's "Trojan Women," a Korean opera reimagining the Greek tragedy. Other standout works include "Frago" by Checkpoint Theatre, "Medea" by Cake Theatre, and "La Cage Aux Folles" by W!ld Rice. In literature, debut authors Nuraliah Norasid and Dr Gwee Li Sui made a mark with "The Gatekeeper" and "Spiring Singlish," respectively. The year also saw notable art exhibitions, including "The Artist's Voice" at Parkview Museum and "Century of Light" at National Gallery Singapore, featuring works by Marina Abramovic and Yayoi Kusama.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Singapore shares close 1% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 36.5 points, or 1.1%, to 3,424.64 on Friday, snapping a four-day losing streak. Trading volume decreased to 1.5 billion shares worth S$1.05 billion. Gainers outpaced losers, with 238 counters up and 179 down.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Time to look back
summary: IWC Schaffhausen is set to celebrate its 150th anniversary next year. The company's heritage is defined by 10 iconic timepieces, including the Jones Calibre, Pallweber Pocket Watches, Special Pilot's Watch, and Portugieser, among others. The Portugieser, launched in the early 1940s, was IWC's first big watch, while the Ingenieur, introduced in 1955, was the company's first automatic timepiece. IWC has also innovated with the Aquatimer, a diver's watch, and the Da Vinci Perpetual Calendar, a watch with a perpetual calendar and chronograph features. The company's latest creations include the Big Pilot's Watch and the Portugieser Siderale Scafusia, a highly complicated mechanical watch.

site_title: Sonic experiment
summary: The Observatory's annual musical initiative Playfreely is back with "No Man's Land", featuring local and international musicians, including Vivian Wang and Cheryl Koh, who will improvise on stage over two nights. Canadian sound artist Crys Cole will also present a workshop and talk on December 9, inviting participants to bring an object with sonic possibilities. Tickets for Playfreely are available at S$25, while Crys Cole's workshop and talk can be attended for a pay-what-you-want fee.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: KL-Singapore high-speed rail to run every 30 mins: Malaysian govt unit
summary: Malaysia's MyHSR Corp announced the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed express rail service will run every 30 minutes, with an additional domestic service running every half hour. The 350km line, with 8 stations, is expected to start construction by the end of 2018 and complete by 2026. The non-stop express service will reach Singapore in 90 minutes, and passengers will clear immigration before boarding. A public inspection exercise has received over 9,000 comments and suggestions, which will be considered before finalizing the project.

site_title: Seriously fun
summary: Design thinking, a corporate innovation tool emphasizing empathy, ambiguity, and rapid prototyping, is gaining popularity. Matthew Lynch, a consultant for Pracademy, has been promoting design thinking in Singapore and other locations, including a recent workshop for Wilhelmsen, a maritime industry group. Lynch argues that design thinking helps companies innovate by encouraging empathy with customers, creativity, and user-centeredness. By applying design thinking, companies can develop innovative solutions that cater to future needs, and empower staff to innovate within their own companies.

images.alt_text: Many of the activities at Pracademy are not confined to a traditional classroom setting, to give participants the chance to see the "tremendous ambiguity and messiness of creativity and innovation".

"It is a kind of a 'teach a man to fish' approach. We think it is more important to empower staff to know how to innovate so that they can innovate within their own companies and continue to do so long after our engagement with them has ended." -Matthew Lynch (above), consultant at Norway-based DT training company, Pracademy

site_title: Chinese firm makes A$463m bid for Australian gas producer AWE
summary: Chinese state-owned company China Energy Reserve and Chemicals Group (CERCG) has made an A$463 million bid for Australian gas producer AWE Ltd, valuing the company at A$0.73 per share. The bid, which is 34% above AWE's previous close, is focused on AWE's stake in the Waitsia gas field in Western Australia. AWE's board had rejected a similar approach from CERCG, prompting the company to directly approach shareholders. The bid remains below analysts' valuation of AWE, which had previously rejected a A$750 million scrip-based offer from Senex Energy in 2013.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a volatile week with strong gains on Friday, with tech firms leading the rally. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.19% to 28,639.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.55% and the Shenzhen Composite Index advanced 1.24%. The gains came despite US trade uncertainty, with investors tracking a positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: A cut above
summary: Celebrity hairstylist Rossano Ferretti has opened a luxury hair salon in Singapore, redefining the experience with his signature technique "The Method". The salon, Rossano Ferretti Hairspa, is led by hair maestros Diego Fiorucci and Christian Serafini, who offer bespoke haircuts starting from S$375. The salon uses natural products developed over seven years, suitable for Singapore's humid weather. The duo aims to change the hair care scene in Singapore, focusing on delivering a unique experience and promoting well-being.

site_title: Singapore to seek public views on short-term home rentals through Airbnb
summary: Singapore's government plans to seek public feedback on a regulatory framework for short-term home rentals through platforms like Airbnb, following the prosecution of two men for unauthorised short-term letting of apartments. The move aims to balance the sharing economy with concerns over the impact on residential estates. A public consultation will involve stakeholders such as home-sharing platforms and resident groups to ensure a robust framework. This comes after the URA investigated 985 cases of unauthorised short-term accommodation in private homes in 2015-2017, with 750 cases in the first 11 months of 2017.

site_title: Danish wonder
summary: Copenhagen's acclaimed restaurant Relae teams up with Nouri for a four hands dinner on Dec 11-12. Head chefs Jonathan Tam and Ivan Brehm will prepare seven courses for $195++ per person, with lunch available for $115++. Relae, founded by Noma alumnus Christian Puglisi, holds one Michelin star and is ranked #39 in the World's 50 Best Restaurants list, prioritizing sustainability and innovative cuisine.

site_title: Chinese cities rush into risky specialisation
summary: Chinese cities are rapidly adopting specialisation industries in response to Beijing's push to develop the country's hinterland. The city of Zhongxian, once a planned eco-city, now plans to build a 1.4 billion yuan online gaming complex, including a 6,000-capacity stadium and gaming startup incubator, despite lacking basic infrastructure. This trend reflects China's growing focus on e-sports and digital economy development, with local governments seeking to attract investments and stimulate growth in their regions.

site_title: Sky may not be the limit for live TV rights
summary: Amazon and Facebook are poised to disrupt the global broadcasting industry, with the English Premier League (EPL) set to be the next major prize. The two tech giants, with market values of over $500 billion, are expected to drive up the cost of TV rights for the EPL deal, potentially forcing Sky and BT Sport to pay more. Non-traditional players are vying to enter the European football market, with Amazon and Facebook already making significant moves, including a lucrative documentary series deal with Manchester City and a reported $50 million bid for NFL "Thursday Night Football" rights.

site_title: How your current car is about to become obsolete
summary: BMW has introduced a new battery pack in its i8 Roadster, increasing its range by 50km to over 300km on battery power alone. The 11.6kWh battery pack is a significant improvement over the previous 7kWh unit, allowing the car to travel further on a single charge. This development is part of BMW's investment in battery research, with a goal of increasing battery range to 600km by 2021 and potentially reaching 700km in the future. The advancements in battery technology are narrowing the gap between electric vehicles and traditional diesel cars.

site_title: Noble to sell US-based ethanol producer to Mercuria unit for higher price
summary: Noble Group has agreed to sell its US-based ethanol producer, Noble Americas South Bend Ethanol (Nasbe), to Mercuria Investments US for a base consideration of US$15.5 million, with the potential to yield US$18 million after adding working capital and inventory. The sale comes as Noble seeks to offload its global oil liquids business to Vitol for US$1.4 billion. The deal is part of Noble's efforts to tackle its mounting debt burden, with its debt standing at US$3.5 billion and cash holdings falling to US$256 million.

site_title: Season to give
summary: The Civil Service Club is hosting the Eco Christmas Fiesta Weekends, a socially conscious and eco-friendly Christmas market featuring handmade items and organic treats. The market collaborates with The Mustard Tree, a social enterprise that supports individuals with special needs. Workshops on recycling and upcycling are also available, and the event includes festive activities such as "snowfall" and caroling. By shopping at the market, attendees can support a good cause and enjoy a unique and environmentally friendly holiday shopping experience.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Low Kee Hong
summary: West Kowloon Cultural District (WKCD) is set to revolutionize Hong Kong's arts scene with its 40-hectare complex featuring theatres, concert halls, and exhibition spaces. Low Kee Hong, 48, Singapore's head of theatre programme, is leading the initiative, which aims to boost industry expertise and attract mainland Chinese audiences. Under his direction, WKCD has launched long-term courses and collaborations with international artists, promising to be a major draw for the region. The district is expected to be a game-changer for Hong Kong and the region's arts landscape.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: BMW X3 M40i review: Practical matters
summary: The BMW X3 M40i is a fast and practical SUV that offers sportscar-like performance without significant compromises. With a 360hp engine, beefed-up brakes, and a firmer suspension, it accelerates to 100km/h in 4.8 seconds. The car features a luxurious interior, a spacious boot, and a direct steering system, making it a strong contender in the segment. While it falls short of the Porsche Macan Turbo as a driver's car, the X3 M40i excels in its practicality and overall package, making it a winner in its class.

site_title: US: Strong US jobs growth data lifts Wall Street
summary: US stocks rose on Friday after strong jobs growth data lifted Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.31% to 24,285.64. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reached fresh records, driven by the US economy's resilience despite uncertainty over interest rates and tariffs. The jobs data bolstered the case for a December interest rate hike, supporting the stock market's rally.

site_title: A brave new world
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The standout designers, products, and buildings of 2017 are showcased in this year-end review. W. Atelier's two showrooms in Singapore feature elaborate designs and top designer brands. Industrial designer Olivia Lee's work is highlighted for its unique spin on familiar items, such as smartphone holders and leather home accessories. The Victoria & Albert Mandello 114 vanity is a standout product, while Karst Stone Paper notebooks made from recycled crushed stone are a sustainable option. The Marina One building in Singapore's Marina Bay financial district is a futuristic mixed-use development with a biodiversity garden.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US job growth strong in November, wages rebound
summary: US job growth surged 228,000 in November, surpassing expectations, with wages rising 0.2% and average hourly earnings increasing to 2.5% annually. The unemployment rate remained steady at 4.1%, near a 17-year low. The strong labor market and rising wages contrast with President Trump's proposed fiscal stimulus, with economists arguing that tax cuts are not needed at this time. The report also showed broad gains in hiring across various sectors, including construction, manufacturing, and retail.

site_title: Schroders turns substantial shareholder of Venture Corp
summary: FUND manager Schroders has become a substantial shareholder of Venture Corporation after acquiring shares, increasing its interest to 5% from 4.99%. Venture's third-quarter net profit more than doubled to S$111.4 million, with shares closing at S$20.26.

site_title: Brexit breakthrough in Brussels
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a breakthrough in Brexit talks, allowing the EU and Britain to move on to the next phase of negotiations on a transition period and future trade relationship. The deal includes guarantees on no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, protection of EU citizens' rights, and a financial settlement. This breakthrough comes ahead of a meeting of EU leaders next week, and the UK can now begin discussing relations with the EU after the UK leaves the EU in March 2019.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Lloyd's of London pushes ahead with Brexit plans
summary: Lloyd's of London plans to establish a foothold in the European Union despite uncertainty over the UK's future trading relationship with the EU. The insurance sector needs certainty on market access, and Lloyd's CEO Inga Beale expressed a desire for a transition period and a broad post-Brexit free trade agreement. This move comes as the UK and EU agree on trade talks, with industry groups welcoming the development. Meanwhile, Liberty Specialty Markets is redomicifying its insurance company to Luxembourg due to uncertainty over the UK's future.

site_title: A bird's eye view of royals and their swans
summary: The British royal family has owned mute swans since the 12th century, with the law dating back to that time. As a member of the royal family, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle can eat swans, while commoners are prohibited from killing them. The Crown's ownership of mute swans is due to their historical association with royal banquets and feasts, and the law has been amended to protect the swan population. However, harming a swan can still result in serious consequences, including prosecution under the Wildlife and Countryside Act of 1981.

site_title: EU and Japan have finalised free trade deal
summary: The EU and Japan have finalized a free trade deal, dubbed the Economic Partnership Agreement, after four years of negotiations. The deal, expected to be signed and ratified by 2019, will create an economic zone of 600 million people and 30% of global GDP. Japan aims to boost its economy, while the EU seeks access to the world's richest market. The agreement includes provisions for Japan's auto industry and EU farming products, particularly dairy. EU officials hail the deal as the largest trade agreement in EU history, while anti-trade activists may influence ratification in the bloc's more than 30 regional and national parliaments.

site_title: George Yeo steps down from Wilmar board
summary: Former Singapore Minister George Yeo has stepped down from Wilmar International's board to make way for two new independent non-executive directors, Lim Siong Guan and Weijian Shan, as the company aims to comply with the Code of Corporate Governance 2012. The move takes effect from December 31 and January 1, respectively. Wilmar's chairman Kuok Khoon Hong is also its chief executive officer. The changes bring the company to have two executive directors, four non-independent non-executive directors, and six independent directors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, up 2.2 points to 1,721.25. The index saw 1.8 billion lots traded worth RM2.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 490 to 328.

site_title: EU ready to start Brexit transition talks early in 2018
summary: The European Union is ready to start Brexit transition talks early in 2018, with details on rules and regulations to be discussed first. The talks will last for around two years, after which the EU will draw up guidelines for future negotiations on a full free trade agreement. EU negotiator Michel Barnier believes a full trade agreement can be negotiated in three years, but a "cliff edge" scenario for trade relations is possible if negotiations are not completed on time. The EU has accepted Britain's divorce terms, paving the way for early discussions on the transition period.

site_title: Why is Woody Allen exempt from sexual assault allegations?
summary: Woody Allen, accused of molesting adoptive daughter Dylan Farrow as a child, remains largely unscathed despite the #MeToo movement. In an op-ed, Farrow questioned why Allen, unlike other accused celebrities like Harvey Weinstein, has not faced similar consequences. Allen has denied the allegations and declined to comment, while some of his co-stars, including Kate Winslet, have distanced themselves without publicly condemning him. Farrow argues that the system has historically protected men like Allen, citing his recent lucrative Amazon deal.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government plans to seek public feedback on a regulatory framework for short-term home rentals. ComfortDelGro will acquire a 51% stake in Uber's car rental subsidiary Lion City Rentals. Noble Group sold its US-based ethanol producer to Mercuria Investments US for a higher price. Swissco Holdings' creditors will meet on January 30 to consider a proposed scheme of arrangement. The Singapore shares closed 1% higher, snapping a four-day losing streak. Meanwhile, international news includes Malaysia's plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: China Inc defies debt fears as profits boost balance sheets
summary: China's non-financial companies have improved their debt-to-earnings ratio, with an average of 1.8 times debt relative to earnings, the best shape in over a decade, according to Bloomberg data. This improvement, driven by supply cuts, price rebound, and global trade growth, gives policymakers more room to push through debt reduction measures without sparking contagion. Chinese companies' profitability conditions have improved significantly, with operating profits covering 18 times interest expense, and profit margins rising to 8.2%, the highest in five years.

site_title: Swissco creditors to meet on Jan 30 over scheme of arrangement
summary: The judicial managers of Swissco Holdings announced a court meeting on January 30, 2018, to consider a proposed Scheme of Arrangement to address the company's debt issues. Swissco, a rig and vessel chartering company, was placed under judicial management in November 2017 after its main lenders rejected its debt restructuring plan.

site_title: Ode to the past
summary: IWC Schaffhausen is celebrating its 150th anniversary with a limited-edition collection of 27 watches, featuring classic icons from the brand's history. The Jubilee collection includes a digital jumping hours and minutes wristwatch, a Portugieser Constant-Force Tourbillon, a Portugieser Perpetual Calendar Tourbillon, and a Da Vinci Automatic Moon Phase watch. The collection will be unveiled at the 2018 Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie Geneve watch fair, with prices ranging from $38,600 to $38,000.

images.alt_text: Tribute to Pallweber, the wristwatch copy of IWC's jumping hours and minutes pocket watch launched in 1884.
Probaly the most affordable of the Jubilee collection, the Da Vinci Automatic.
IWC's first perpetual calendar-tourbillon watch, the Portugieser Perpetual Calendar Tourbillon.

site_title: VW halts multivan deliveries amid emissions "uncertainties"
summary: Volkswagen halted deliveries of its T6 multivan model amid concerns over excessive nitrogen oxide emissions, which reportedly exceeded legal limits. The company detected the issue after internal tests and reported it to Germany's automotive watchdog. VW attributed the problem to "uncertainties" in technical data, ruling out engine management software as the cause. The company has agreed to run further tests with the KBA and did not comment on the number of vehicles affected or when they were built.

site_title: RBS CEO says US settlement could slip into next year
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland's CEO Ross McEwan said the chances of reaching a US settlement over toxic mortgage-backed securities by the end of 2017 are "diminishing". McEwan previously expected a settlement this year, which could allow the bank to return to full-year profit in 2018. Analysts estimate the bank could pay up to $12 billion to settle the case.

site_title: Former LafargeHolcim CEO charged with Syria terrorism funding
summary: Former LafargeHolcim CEO Eric Olsen was charged with funding terrorist groups in Syria as part of a French probe into the company's operations in the war-torn country. Olsen, who resigned in April, faces charges of terrorism funding, putting someone else's life in danger, and was placed under judicial supervision. The investigation, which has been unfolding for months, was triggered by Lafarge SA's now-shuttered operations in Syria, where the company paid armed groups to keep a cement plant operating. Olsen denies any wrongdoing and his departure was attributed to "strong tensions" over the Syria case.

site_title: Najib to stand unopposed in next party leadership contest
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), has unanimously decided that Prime Minister Najib Razak can stand unopposed in a party leadership contest due next year. This decision comes despite the ongoing 1MDB corruption scandal, which has plagued Najib's premiership for two years. Najib has consistently denied any wrongdoing, and the party's leadership ballot will not be contested, with his deputy Ahmad Zahid Hamidi also set to retain his post. The decision has raised concerns about the party's loyalty and Najib's ability to win a third term in the upcoming general election.

site_title: Healthway expects independent report over loans in question in Q1 2018
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation expects an independent report on loans extended to its subsidiaries in Q1 2018 to determine if there were breaches of listing rules. The report will investigate loans given to Healthway Medical Enterprises Pte Ltd and Wei Yi Shi Ye Co Ltd. The outcome will be crucial in establishing any wrongdoing and determining the company's compliance with regulatory requirements.

site_title: Europe: London stocks steady after Brexit breakthrough deal
summary: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index remained nearly unchanged at 7,322.44 points following news of a breakthrough Brexit deal. The pound slightly increased, while the Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 added 0.8%. Britain and the EU reached a historic deal on the terms of the Brexit divorce, paving the way for EU leaders to open the second phase of negotiations, covering trade talks and a transition period, at a summit on December 14-15.

site_title: China's HNA pushes back against liquidity concerns, won't sell assets "blindly"
summary: China's HNA Group has pushed back against concerns of a liquidity crisis, stating that it will not sell its assets "blindly" and has been disposing of non-core businesses as part of its strategy. The company's head of tourism division, Zhao Quan, said adjustments to the portfolio have started earlier and that HNA has been selling non-core businesses. HNA has significant debt maturities and higher funding costs, but has characterized its recent acquisitions, including a stake in Hilton, as "successful" and "profitable" investments. The company denies "outside speculation" of a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says posts Q3 revenue rise in tough operating environment
summary: Malaysia Airlines reported a 3.5% rise in third-quarter revenue despite facing challenges from overcapacity and lower fares. Revenue per available seat kilometre increased 2%, while load factor fell to 77.5% from 79% last year. The airline cited higher fuel costs and an unfavorable exchange rate as contributing factors. CEO Izham Ismail attributed the improvement to clearer customer segmentation and improved revenue management, while also highlighting the impact of new leased Airbus jets expected in early 2018. The airline aims to return to profitability in 2018 and list on the stock market the following year.

site_title: It's a man's world: Women scarce in Nobel Prize annals
summary: Women have been underrepresented in the Nobel Prize annals, with only 5% of the 896 laureates being women, excluding organizations. The economics prize has been the most unattainable for women, with just one woman receiving the award since 1969. However, the number of women laureates has risen in recent decades, and some disciplines, such as literature, are showing improvement. The peace prize has also seen an increase in female winners, with 15.4% of laureates being women since 2000. Efforts to increase diversity and representation are underway, with a goal of achieving parity in the future.

site_title: Coffee glut hinges on whether top growers will hold back sales
summary: Vietnamese and Brazilian coffee growers are holding back sales due to low prices, potentially upsetting market expectations of a coffee glut. Top growers in Vietnam and Brazil are selling only a fraction of their harvests, with some planning to wait until after the Tet holidays for better prices. A surplus of 5.5 million bags is predicted for 2018-19, but growers' reluctance to sell cheaply could temporarily withdraw excess from the market. Weather conditions and disease also pose a threat to global production, which is concentrated in Brazil, Vietnam, Colombia, and Indonesia.

site_title: Food for thought
summary: In 2017, notable dining trends and awards emerged, including Aoki Japanese Restaurant's stunning makeover, Andre Chiang's surprise closure of Restaurant Andre, and Ivan Brehm's Michelin-starred Nouri. Folklore Restaurant was named Restaurant of the Year, with Damian D'Silva's high standards and dedication to Peranakan cuisine. Wolfgang's Steakhouse took the top spot for best new steak, and Han Li Guang earned a Michelin star for his innovative Labyrinth restaurant. Newcomers Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar and Aeron Choo's Kappou Japanese Sushi Tapas Bar also made headlines, with Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar offering reasonably priced fine dining and Choo's dedication to her craft earning her the title of hardest-working chef.

site_title: Sinwa settles dispute involving two units
summary: Sinwa Ltd has settled two disputes, one involving units Sinwa SS (HK) and Nordic International Limited (NIL), for a total of US$1.25 million. The settlements, involving payments from BGP Geoexplorer Pte Ltd and Morten, are expected to positively impact Sinwa's income statement for the fourth quarter of 2017. The reversal of impairment loss will remove a previous provision, resulting in increased income. The settlements also involve the transfer of Sinwa SS's shareholding in NIL to Morten.

site_title: EMAS Offshore's auditor cites disclaimer of opinion over 'material uncertainties'
summary: EMAS Offshore's auditor, Ernst & Young, has issued a disclaimer of opinion due to "material uncertainties" casting doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The group reported a US$535 million loss and a net current liabilities position of US$679 million as of August 31, 2016. The auditor cited the company's cash flow challenges, missed payments, and letters of demand from vendors and financial institutions as reasons for the disclaimer.

site_title: FEO Hospitality transfers stapled securities in Far East H-Trust to Golden Development
summary: FEO Hospitality Asset Management has transferred 550,000 stapled securities in Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) to Golden Development Private Limited. The transferred securities, priced at S$0.6985 each, comprise one unit in Far East Hospitality Real Estate Investment and one unit in Far East Hospitality Business Trust. The move does not affect the total number of stapled securities in issue, which remains at 1.9 billion.

site_title: George Yeo steps down from Wilmar's board to make way for independent directors
summary: Former Singaporean Minister George Yeo has stepped down from Wilmar International's board to allow for additional independent directors, as required by the Code of Corporate Governance 2012. Lim Siong Guan and Shan Weijian, an independent director, will join the board from January 1, increasing the number of independent directors to six. This change will meet the 50% independent director requirement for the company, which has the same CEO and chairman. Yeo's resignation takes effect from December 31.

site_title: Halcyon Agri acquires crumb rubber factory in Bintan
summary: Halcyon Agri, a natural rubber supplier, has acquired an 80% stake in PT Pulau Bintan Djaya (PBD) in Bintan, Indonesia, for approximately US$0.6 million. PBD produces Standard Indonesian Rubber and has a licensed capacity of 60,000 tonnes per year, supplying major tyre companies. This acquisition expands Halcyon Agri's natural rubber processing segment, increasing its total processing capacity to 1.55 million tonnes per year.

site_title: KL-Singapore high-speed rail service to have a train every 30 minutes
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail service will have a train every 30 minutes, with an express service reaching Singapore in 90 minutes and a domestic service stopping at all stations along the route. Eight stations will be built along the 350km line, with the project scheduled for completion in 2026. The domestic service will take 120 minutes, and a shuttle train service will be available from Iskandar Puteri to Jurong East. The project's public inspection exercise has received over 9,000 comments and suggestions.

site_title: May heads for last-ditch Brussels talks on Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May rushed to Brussels for last-ditch talks with EU officials to finalize a Brexit deal by Sunday, ahead of a Dec 14-15 leaders' summit. May's government had previously faced objections from Northern Irish allies over the border with Ireland, but negotiations resumed after a late-night meeting between May and EU Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker. A deal must be reached to unlock the second phase of negotiations, which will include a transition period and a future EU-UK trade deal.

site_title: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong could become Apsil's controlling shareholder if rights issue undersubscribed
summary: Billionaire businessman Oei Hong Leong could become Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments Limited's (Apsil) controlling shareholder if the company's right issue is substantially under-subscribed. Oei plans to take up 7.79 billion new shares, potentially holding 66.7% of the firm's enlarged issued share capital. Apsil's rights cum warrants issue, partially underwritten by UOB Kay Hian and sub-underwritten by Oei, aims to raise up to S$42.7 million for expansion into China's property sector.

site_title: BOJ's tankan set to show big manufacturers' mood improving: poll
summary: The Bank of Japan's quarterly tankan business sentiment survey is expected to show a significant improvement in big manufacturers' mood, with a forecasted increase of two points to plus 24 in December, the strongest reading since 2006. Service-sector sentiment is also expected to remain steady, driven by solid domestic demand and growth in foreign visitors. However, labour shortages may weigh on the sector's spirits. Economists forecast a 7.5% increase in capital spending plans for big corporations in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges 15% in wild trading
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 15% to below $14,500 on Friday, following a record-breaking week of highs. The currency briefly reached $17,000 before falling to $14,480. Analysts attribute the surge to growing acceptance among traditional investors and US regulators' decision to allow Bitcoin futures trading. However, concerns about financial stability and a potential bubble have increased, with some warning of a 50% decline if the launch is marred by issues. Despite this, a strategist predicts Bitcoin's value will reach $50,000 to $100,000 within 18 months.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to acquire 51% stake in Uber's car rental subsidiary Lion City Rentals
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore taxi giant, plans to acquire a 51% stake in Uber's car rental subsidiary, Lion City Rentals, for $642 million. The deal, valued at $295 million in cash, is subject to regulatory approval and will allow Lion City Rentals to benefit from ComfortDelGro's fleet management and operations. Uber will retain the remaining 49% stake. The joint venture aims to increase earnings for drivers and provide customers with an option to book ComfortDelGro taxis through the Uber app, countering rival Grab's efforts to poach ComfortDelGro's taxi drivers.

site_title: Britain and EU reach historic deal on Brexit divorce terms, paving way for trade talks
summary: Britain and the EU reached a historic deal on Friday on the terms of the Brexit divorce, paving the way for trade talks. The agreement addresses separation issues, including the Irish border, Britain's divorce bill, and citizens' rights, with Britain agreeing to pay a settlement of 45-55 billion euros. The deal also guarantees no hard border in Northern Ireland and protects the rights of three million European citizens living in Britain. EU leaders will discuss the agreement at a summit on December 14-15, allowing for the start of trade talks and a transition period.

site_title: Japan to acquire air-launched missiles able to strike North Korea
summary: Japan plans to acquire medium-range air-launched cruise missiles, capable of striking North Korea, to bolster its defense. The missiles, including the Joint Strike Missile (JSM) and the Joint Air-to-Surface Standoff Missile (JASSM-ER), will be mounted on F-35A and F-15 fighter jets. The purchase is expected to face criticism, but it comes amid growing concerns about North Korea's ballistic missile threats, including recent tests over Japan. The move aims to deter North Korea from launching an attack and is seen as a step towards a more robust military.

site_title: Singapore shares resume 1% up on Friday afternoon
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 33.54 points to 3,421.68. About 749.3 million shares worth S$472 million changed hands at an average unit price of S$0.63 per share.

site_title: China exports jumped in November as import gains signal strength
summary: China's exports rose 10.3% in November, while imports increased 15.6%, resulting in a trade surplus of $54 billion. Global demand for Chinese products remained firm, with demand for commodities continuing unabated. Despite uncertainty from trade frictions with the US, China's economy is expected to remain robust, driven by domestic demand and a global tech boom ahead of the holiday season.

site_title: India said to seek control of realty firm
summary: India's corporate affairs ministry is seeking approval to take over management control of real-estate giant Unitech Ltd due to mismanagement and fund diversion. The government has filed a petition with the bankruptcy court to suspend Unitech's existing board of directors and CFO, citing public interest. Thousands of buyers are affected by the company's financial struggles, with over 19,000 awaiting possession of flats and 15,000 small depositors unpaid. The government aims to replace Unitech's board with its own nominee directors and recover undue gains made by the management.

site_title: Ziwo to seek shareholders' approval to pursue green energy business
summary: Ziwo Holdings, a mainboard-listed company, plans to seek shareholder approval to transition its business to focus exclusively on green energy in China and South-east Asia. The company aims to exit its loss-making raw materials production business and pursue more green-energy projects, including electric vehicle charging stations and electric scooters. Ziwo also seeks to rename itself BM Mobility Ltd, which will be its main operating entity. The company plans to expand its green-energy pipeline and consider investing in assets or businesses in the sector.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.34% to 28,400.01 on Friday, building on the previous day's gains, as investors tracked a bounce on Wall Street. Technology firms saw fresh buying, driving the gains. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.23% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.14%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won steady; both end the week down
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the won remained steady on Friday, ending the week down 0.5%. The won lost 0.6% for the week, its largest weekly percentage drop since late September. Bond yields fell, with the benchmark 3-year Korean treasury bond yielding 2.096%. The KOSPI is up 21.5% this year and has a current price-to-earnings ratio of 12.10.

images.alt_text: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the won held steady on Friday while bond yields fell. At 06:32 GMT, the KOSPI was up 2.02 points or 0.08 per cent at 2,464.00. The benchmark index fell 0.5 per cent for the week.

site_title: Finance, energy sectors lift Australia shares; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares rose for a second day, driven by gains in the finance, energy, and tech sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 0.3% higher, its third consecutive weekly gain. The New Zealand market also reached a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index up 0.8% to close at 8,235.09. Strong oil prices and a rally in tech stocks, such as Facebook, contributed to the gains.

site_title: Oil stable as stronger dollar weighs while China's relentless oil thirst supports prices
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Friday, influenced by a strengthening US dollar and China's increasing demand for crude. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures and Brent crude futures were little changed at $56.68 and $62.21 per barrel, respectively. Despite a strong dollar, which attracts traders away from commodities, China's booming oil demand will soon surpass the US as the world's largest crude importer. Oil prices are expected to rise due to tight supplies and Opec-led production cuts, with Brent crude predicted to reach $70 per barrel by mid-year.

site_title: UN aviation agency not eyeing 'no-fly' zone around North Korea: sources
summary: The UN's International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is not considering a "no-fly" zone around North Korea due to unpredictable missile test directions. Airlines are already avoiding North Korean airspace, with some re-routing flights to avoid the Sea of Japan. ICAO has condemned North Korea's missile tests, but a no-fly zone would be ineffective and disruptive to carriers. The organization has urged airlines to take precautions, but no action is being taken to impose a zone.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close up on weaker yen, strong GDP
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.39% on Friday, driven by a weaker yen and a strong revision to Japan's third-quarter GDP growth to 0.6%. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,811.08, while the Topix index gained 0.98%. The dollar strengthened against the yen, supporting exporters. Key players like Sony and Toyota rose, while Nintendo lost on profit-taking. The market's gain was attributed to favorable factors, including a US government shutdown and the revised GDP figure, according to analysts.

site_title: Nearly all European coal-fired power plants will be loss-making by 2030: research
summary: European coal-fired power plants will be loss-making by 2030 due to rising carbon prices and stricter air quality rules, according to a Carbon Tracker Initiative report. Nearly all plants will be unprofitable, resulting in potential losses of 22 billion euros (S$35 billion) for the EU. Germany and Poland could save billions by phasing out coal power, with RWE and Uniper expected to save 3 billion and 1.7 billion euros, respectively. The EU aims to limit global temperature rise to below 2 degrees Celsius by 2030, aligning with the Paris Agreement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points to 1,718.88. Volume reached 47.26 million lots worth RM26.15 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 66. This marks the first day of the week for Malaysia's market.

site_title: Asian markets on course for broad gains after volatile week
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, ending a volatile week on a positive note, driven by tech firms' rebound and US President Donald Trump's plans to unveil a big-spending public works plan. Global equities had struggled due to profit-taking, fears over Russia's US election meddling, and Brexit talks. However, the US tax overhaul bill's passage and Trump's infrastructure plan promises boosted markets, with tech stocks and the dollar rallying. Asian markets closed higher, with Tokyo up 1.2%, Hong Kong 0.6%, and Shanghai 0.2%, while the US dollar pushed up against most other units.

site_title: Gene editing advance reverses disease in mice
summary: Scientists have made a breakthrough in gene editing using CRISPR/Cas9, reversing diseases in mice by changing gene expression instead of cutting genes. Researchers used mice with kidney injuries, type 1 diabetes, and muscular dystrophy and successfully improved kidney function, lowered blood glucose levels, and alleviated muscular dystrophy symptoms. The technique avoids unwanted mutations and has shown promise for treating diseases, with further safety trials planned in animals before human trials.

site_title: Public consultation soon to regulate short-term home rentals
summary: Singapore plans to seek public feedback on a regulatory framework for short-term home rentals, aiming to balance encouraging new industries with safeguarding residential estates. The move comes after strict rules led to complaints and a recent prosecution of two men for unauthorised short-term letting of four apartments. The government will review safeguards to ensure the "amenity" of residential estates is maintained. The public consultation will involve stakeholders, including home-sharing platforms and resident groups, to develop a robust framework addressing concerns of all parties.

site_title: China, Panama to start talks on free-trade deal in June 2018
summary: Panama and China will begin negotiations in June 2018 to sign a free-trade deal, solidifying their relationship after Panama ended diplomatic ties with Taiwan. China has pledged to provide Panama with aid, and talks aim to deepen commercial links and stimulate trade. This move is part of China's efforts to consolidate its influence in the region, having previously poached allies of Taiwan. The talks will focus on infrastructure development, including ports, and are seen as a key step in strengthening bilateral ties.

site_title: North Korea prize money frozen at Asian football tournament
summary: North Korea will not receive prize money at the upcoming East Asian football championships due to economic sanctions. The decision was made by tournament organizers, Japan and East Asian football chief Kozo Tashima, citing UN resolutions. This move comes as tensions remain high following North Korea's recent nuclear test and missile launches. The tournament's winners will still earn $250,000 for the men's competition and $70,000 for the women's competition.

images.alt_text: North Korea will not be entitled to any prize money at this month's East Asian football championships due to economic sanctions imposed on Pyongyang, tournament organisers have said.

site_title: 'Grinch bots' may steal Christmas by snatching up prized toys
summary: An online army of "Grinch bots" may spoil Christmas for kids by using automated software to scoop up prized toys and resell them for huge profits. These bots can rapidly check retail websites for sales and complete multiple orders in a second, leaving human shoppers unable to compete. US Senator Charles Schumer has called for the National Retail Federation and Retail Industry Leaders Association to investigate and block the bots, which have also been used to resell tickets to hit shows at exorbitant markups.

site_title: Advance SCT granted extension to meet listing requirements for removal from SGX watch-list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Advance SCT Limited a 12-month extension to March 3, 2018 to meet listing requirements for removal from the SGX watch-list. The company must announce the extension, reasons for the extension, and conditions required under the listing manual. Advance SCT has been on the watch-list since March 2015 and had previously sought an extension due to discussions on a proposed acquisition, which has since been terminated. The SGX has no objection to the company's application to resume trading, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: GE's 12,000 job cuts highlight uneasy shift to renewable energy
summary: General Electric (GE) is cutting 12,000 jobs, approximately one-fifth of its power division's global workforce, due to a shift towards renewable energy. The company, which had invested heavily in the gas-power business, is struggling to adapt to a market favoring renewables. GE's new CEO, John Flannery, aims to cut $1 billion in costs and reshape the manufacturing icon. The company's power division, which generated $26.8 billion in revenue last year, is expected to face significant competition from wind and solar energy.

site_title: Wildfires rage across southern California, first death reported
summary: Wildfires rage across southern California, forcing tens of thousands to flee their homes, including residents near Los Angeles. Despite intense blazes fueled by hurricane-force winds, only one fatality has been reported. Six major fires are burning, with flames heading south toward Santa Barbara and San Diego. Over 4,000 firefighters and dozens of aircraft are deployed to combat the fires, which have already destroyed multi-million dollar mansions in Bel Air. The strong winds are forecast to last through Saturday, making conditions extremely dangerous.

site_title: Australian dollar propped up by strong China data; NZ$ range bound
summary: The Australian dollar gained ground on Friday after China's November imports exceeded expectations, lifting the currency to a six-month high. The Aussie steadied at US$0.7513, rebounding from a two-day loss. China's trade data showed annual gains of 17.7% in imports, driven by strong demand for industrial commodities. The news supported the Australian dollar, which is seen as a proxy for China's economic performance.

site_title: JPMorgan's Dimon taking customer pricing hints from Amazon
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co CEO Jamie Dimon plans to offer more price discounts to customers who buy multiple products, similar to Amazon's Prime discounts. This strategy, known as "relationship pricing," aims to retain customers and expand the bank's business. Dimon also stated that JPMorgan will invest in mobile banking services, despite spending billions on new technology, to satisfy increasing customer demand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Fu Yu Corporation, Ellipsiz, GuocoLand
summary: Fu Yu Corporation Limited plans to privatize its subsidiary LCTH Corporation Berhard through a selective capital repayment (SCR) exercise valued at RM61.3 million. Ellipsiz Ltd has ceased discussions with a potential buyer for its shares. GuocoLand is not mentioned as having any new developments.

site_title: Millions would lose mortgage, gift write-offs under US tax bill: study
summary: A US tax bill under consideration by Congress would deny tax write-offs to millions of households, including up to 29 million, for charity donations, mortgage interest payments, and property tax. The bill would fundamentally transform these deductions, making them "worthless for most people." The standard deduction would double, reducing itemized deductions, and the deduction for state and local taxes would be curtailed, leading to a decline in charitable donations and mortgage interest claims. The Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy estimates that the percentage of households claiming these deductions would fall to 8% from 26%.

site_title: Bangladesh Bank, NY Fed discuss suing Manila bank for heist damages
summary: Bangladesh's central bank has asked the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to join a lawsuit against Rizal Commercial Banking Corp of the Philippines for its role in a $81 million cyber-heist in 2017. The heist, which occurred when hackers stole funds from Bangladesh Bank's account at the New York Fed, was sent to accounts in the Philippines and then disappeared into the casino industry. The Fed has not responded formally, and there is no indication it would join the suit.

site_title: YouTube is said to plan new music subscription service for March
summary: YouTube is set to introduce a paid music subscription service, Remix, in March, its third attempt to compete with Spotify and Apple Music. Major record labels, including Warner Music Group, Sony Music Entertainment, and Universal Music Group, are on board. The service will offer on-demand streaming and incorporate elements from YouTube, such as video clips. YouTube aims to address the music industry's concerns about insufficient compensation for music usage on the platform. The service is part of Alphabet Inc.'s efforts to catch up with rivals and boost revenue from the music business.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking rallies in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.73% and the Topix index up 0.37%. The yen remained cheaper against the dollar, contributing to the gains. The benchmark indices rose despite uncertainty over US trade policies and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

site_title: Executives arrested as Hong Kong steps up 'Enigma Network' probe
summary: Hong Kong authorities have stepped up their investigation into the "Enigma Network", a group of 50 listed companies with complex cross-shareholdings. Three senior company executives were arrested and eight locations searched in connection with the probe, which follows a dramatic stock crash in June. The Enigma Network was highlighted by activist investor David Webb for its potential role in wild price swings and concentrated ownership in Hong Kong's US$5.1 trillion equity market. The investigation aims to address concerns about market integrity and potential corruption.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won take a breather
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index weakened on Friday, down 2.85 points or 0.12% at 2,459.13. The Korean won slightly fell, quoted at 1,094.9 per dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is up 21.5% this year, but down 0.75% in the previous 30 days. Foreigners were net sellers of 51,328 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar has fallen 9.3% against the won this year.

site_title: Bitcoin surges above US$16,000 as concerns mount
summary: Bitcoin surged above $16,000 on Thursday, with prices reaching $16,777 in European trading before pulling back. The cryptocurrency's value has soared over 50% in one week, driven by growing acceptance among traditional investors. Concerns about financial stability and a potential bubble have increased, with some warning that the price may correct once the hype slows down. The US Federal Reserve has also expressed concerns about bitcoin, while a US regulator cleared the way for bitcoin futures to trade on major exchanges, sparking further speculation.

site_title: iFAST unit offering US-listed securities dealing services
summary: iFAST Financial Pte Ltd, a Singapore subsidiary of iFAST Corporation Ltd, is now offering US-listed securities dealing services to investors through its FSMOne account. This expansion allows investors to access over 2,000 ETFs and US stocks at a competitive pricing structure of 0.08% commission fee, with a minimum of $8.80 per trade. The move aims to assist investors in diversifying their portfolios without high barriers to entry. This follows the introduction of SGX-listed and HKEX-listed stocks and ETFs.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on financials, energy; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, tracking a gain on Wall Street and higher oil prices, with financial and energy stocks leading the way. The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 11.577 points, and was set to log a third straight weekly gain. Tech stocks, including Facebook, and the 'Big Four' banks also contributed to the gains, while energy stocks rose alongside oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.4%, its fourth straight weekly gain.

site_title: IE Singapore chief to join Mapletree next year
summary: IE Singapore chief Lee Ark Boon is joining Mapletree Investments in a senior role in China, overseeing logistics development projects. He will leave IE Singapore on December 31 and be stationed in China from January, replacing someone in a similar role. Mapletree aims to double its logistics GFA in China from 2 million sq m to 4-5 million sq m, capitalizing on the growing e-commerce industry. Lee will manage 20-30 warehouse development projects across China.

site_title: Europe: Comeback in banks, tech lifts stocks as Steinhoff collapses
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Thursday, driven by a recovery in financial and tech stocks, while troubled furniture retailer Steinhoff sank 45% amid an accounting scandal. Euro zone banks jumped 1.1%, with ING, Santander, and Unicredit leading gains, as investors regained confidence in the sector. The tech sector also edged up, with investors reversing recent losses, and shares in wind turbine makers Siemens Gamesa and Vestas Wind rose after a bullish note on the renewables sector.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% up on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,401.2 points. About 53.2 million shares changed hands for S$79.7 million, with 71 gainers for every 37 losers. The market's rally continued ahead of GDP data, with no major disruptions despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: US House advances funding bill to avert government shutdown
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a stopgap federal spending extension, known as a "continuing resolution," to avert a government shutdown. The measure, which extends funding at current levels until December 22, was passed in a 235-193 vote. The bill now heads to the Senate, where it is expected to pass later Thursday, and then to President Trump's desk. Congressional leaders and Trump met at the White House, with Democrats expressing hope for a deal on a long-term budget and the fate of young immigrants, a top priority for Democrats.

site_title: Japan Oct price-adjusted wages mark first rise since Dec 2016
summary: Japan's October price-adjusted wages rose 0.2% from the previous year, marking the first increase since December 2016, according to the labour ministry. This rise is attributed to a tight job market, which is expected to push up incomes and help consumer inflation reach its target rate of 2%. The data is seen as a positive sign for the government's efforts to encourage companies to invest in wage increases to boost consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Japanese wages rose 0.2 per cent in October from a year earlier after adjustment for inflation, the labour ministry said on Friday, marking their first rise since December 2016 in a sign a tight job market may finally be leading to higher salaries.

site_title: IMF approves US$251m payout to Sri Lanka
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a US$251 million payout to Sri Lanka, bringing the total released to US$760 million under a three-year loan. The loan was approved in June 2016 following a balance of payments crisis. The IMF noted progress in reducing the country's deficit but emphasized the need for further reforms, including tax collection and strengthening foreign reserves, to address high debt and weak state-owned enterprises.

site_title: China winter gas binge pushes it towards 2nd biggest LNG buyer
summary: China has surged ahead of schedule to become the second-largest importer of liquefied natural gas (LNG), surpassing South Korea's total imports for the year. China's demand for LNG has increased by 19% through October, driven by efforts to reduce smog by promoting gas over coal at industrial sites. The country is now neck and neck with South Korea, both lagging behind Japan, which imports more than their combined totals. China's emergence as an LNG power is seen as a sign of its "golden age of gas".

site_title: Fullerton to manage NTUC Income's assets
summary: Fullerton Fund Management Company, a Temasek-owned firm, has been appointed as the investment manager for NTUC Income's S$23 billion assets. This partnership aims to increase yield in a low-interest environment. Fullerton's holding company, FFMC Holdings, will issue new shares to NTUC Income, giving the insurer a significant minority stake in FFMC while maintaining Temasek's majority stake.

images.alt_text: In its quest for yield amid a low-interest rate and volatile financial environment, local insurer NTUC Income has appointed Temasek-owned Fullerton Fund Management Company as investment manager of its assets, worth around S$23 billion.

site_title: Japan Q3 GDP revised up to 2.5% annualised growth
summary: Japan's economy expanded at an annualised rate of 2.5% in the July-September quarter, revised up from a preliminary estimate of 1.4% growth. This compares to the median forecast of 1.5% growth. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP rose 0.6% in price-adjusted terms, exceeding the preliminary reading of 0.3% and the median estimate of 0.4%. The revised GDP figure is the highest since 2016.

site_title: Gold falls below trading range, touches 4-month low as dollar firms
summary: Gold fell 1% to a four-month low of $1,251.11 an ounce, below its recent trading range, due to a strengthening US dollar and optimism about the passage of a US tax overhaul. The decline follows a week of trading between $1,265 and $1,300 an ounce. Investors are also wary of potential US interest rate hikes and geopolitical threats.

site_title: To save climate, stop investing in fossil fuels: economists
summary: Top economists have called for an end to investments in fossil fuels to avoid the worst effects of global warming. In a declaration, they urged a shift to renewable energy and an immediate stop to new fossil fuel production and infrastructure. The economists warn that exhausting developed fossil fuel reserves is incompatible with capping global warming at two degrees Celsius. The call comes ahead of the Paris climate summit, where leaders will focus on marshalling public and private money for a low-carbon economy, particularly in developing countries. The declaration also highlights the need to phase out ongoing fossil fuel finance.

site_title: Has pay-for-performance differentiation worked?
summary: A study in Singapore found that conventional pay-for-performance executive compensation models may not be achieving their objectives, despite being widely accepted by shareholders. Over the past five years, employee wages increased by 20%, but productivity measures decreased. Fixed pay levels for CEOs and senior executives have increased by 2% annually, yet total compensation levels have remained flat. The study suggests that pay-for-performance models have failed to differentiate compensation outcomes between executives and that variable pay is not truly variable. Instead, executives prefer low-risk options and are motivated by factors such as doing meaningful work and building a successful team. To strengthen pay-for-performance models, boards should define key performance measures, implement individually-oriented scorecards, and link rewards to individual performance.

site_title: United Airlines PR boss to step down after tumultuous tenure
summary: United Airlines' top communications executive, Jim Olson, is stepping down after a tumultuous two-year tenure. Olson, senior vice-president of corporate communications, will resign on January 8 to pursue other opportunities. He led the airline's public-relations strategy through a period marked by a corporate turnaround, a battle with activist investors, and a media firestorm over a passenger being dragged off a flight. The airline is searching for his replacement, amid a year of declining stock performance and a competitive market.

site_title: Saudi crown prince bought US$450m Da Vinci: report
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is the buyer of Leonardo da Vinci's "Salvator Mundi" painting sold for a record-breaking $450 million at auction. The prince used an intermediary to purchase the painting, citing US intelligence and unnamed sources. This sale is seen as part of Prince MBS's efforts to consolidate power and implement his Vision 2030 plan, aiming to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy.

site_title: Rex Int'l aims for higher revenue from wells, proprietary RVD technology
summary: Rex International Holding aims to increase revenue from 2018 onwards with its Norway and Oman discovery assets and proprietary Rex Virtual Drilling (RVD) technology. An appraisal well is planned in Norway's Edvard Grieg South prospect and an appraisal well in Oman's GA South#1 discovery. The company has also cut costs and will market its RVD technology as a service for oil exploration companies. With a cash reserve of US$46.62 million, Rex is targeting higher revenue and improved profitability in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Oil rises over 1% on threatened Nigeria strike, short covering
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Thursday due to a threatened strike in Nigeria and short covering in the market. A key oil union in Nigeria threatened a nationwide strike from Dec. 18 over mass sackings of union members. The strike, which could impact Nigeria's status as Africa's top oil exporter, provided support to oil prices.

site_title: CapitaLand inks S$10m tie-up with EDB to upskill staff, test new technologies
summary: CapitaLand has launched a S$10 million programme, CapitaLand ELEVATE, to upskill its staff in areas like data analytics, digital marketing, and digital product management. The programme aims to explore new technologies to create people-centric products and services. At least 200-300 staff will be trained, enabling the company to accelerate its innovation push and create innovative products and experiences.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: SIA, Air NZ to launch third daily S'pore-Auckland flight from Oct 2018
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Air New Zealand will jointly launch a third daily flight between Singapore and Auckland on October 28, 2018, boosting capacity by 40% and adding over 165,000 seats annually. This move will increase flight options and provide more travel choices for passengers.

site_title: Sharp to seek all-Japan OLED alliance to counter S. Korea firms
summary: Japan's Sharp Corp plans to form an all-Japan OLED alliance with Japan Display Inc to counter South Korean firms, citing the need to develop the technology domestically. Sharp's CEO, Tai Jeng-wu, aims to create a Japan alliance to produce OLED panels, which are thinner, more flexible, and offer richer colors than LCD panels. Sharp and Japan Display plan to start OLED panel production next year, while South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co Ltd already supplies OLED panels to global smartphone vendors.

site_title: Reducing carbon footprint is an area of focus for Shell
summary: Shell aims to cut the net carbon footprint of the energy it sells in half by 2050, in line with the Paris Agreement's goal to limit global warming to under 2 degrees Celsius. The company will review and report on its progress every five years. This initiative is part of Shell's efforts to address the energy transition puzzle, which requires piecing together a solution to reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: Noble to sell US-based ethanol producer to new buyer Mercuria unit for higher price
summary: Noble Group has agreed to sell its US-based ethanol producer, Noble Americas South Bend Ethanol, to Mercuria Investments US, Inc for a base consideration of $15.5 million, $3 million higher than its previous offer from Zeeland Farm Services. The sale comes as Noble seeks to pay off debt and follows the sale of Noble Americas Gas & Power Corp to Mercuria Energy for $102 million. The deal is expected to result in a net proceeds of approximately $18 million for Noble, after deducting a termination fee of $2 million.

site_title: 1MDB still a weak spot for Malaysia, given pending probes overseas
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB scandal remains a vulnerable spot for the country, despite the economy showing strong growth and the government preparing for elections. Investigations in the US, Singapore, and other jurisdictions continue to uncover billions of dollars allegedly siphoned from the state-owned enterprise. US Attorney-General Jeff Sessions has called the scandal "kleptocracy at its worst," and the US Department of Justice is seeking to seize $1.8 billion in assets linked to 1MDB. Malaysia has yet to charge anyone and 1MDB has denied any misconduct, leaving the government vulnerable to regulatory actions from abroad.

site_title: Fosun to list tourism arm to raise US$500m; HK likely to be listing venue
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International is in talks with banks to list its tourism arm, which includes Club Med, to raise at least $500 million. The listing is expected to be in Hong Kong, and the business unit includes a joint venture with Thomas Cook Group and a luxury hotel in Hainan province. This move is part of Fosun's efforts to rationalize its portfolio and boost finances, following other asset sales by fellow conglomerate HNA.

site_title: China's banks need to boost capital buffers: IMF
summary: China's banks face a capital shortfall equivalent to 2.5% of GDP in a severely adverse scenario, according to IMF stress tests. 27 of 33 banks tested were under-capitalized, with smaller lenders appearing vulnerable. The IMF recommends increasing capital buffers to protect against sudden economic downturns. China's top four banks have enough capital, but smaller lenders need more. The assessment highlights risks during China's transition from an export-oriented to a service-based economy.

site_title: US: Stocks gain ahead of November jobs data
summary: US stocks rose ahead of the November jobs report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.3% to 24,211.48. Analysts expect 190,000 new jobs and a 4.1% unemployment rate. The S&P 500 advanced 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5%. Despite struggling momentum this week, investors remain bullish, with tech stocks like Apple, Facebook, and Alphabet rising. Large companies like General Electric and Lululemon Athletica also saw gains.

site_title: Poll finds Japan manufacturers' mood largely steady
summary: Japan manufacturers' confidence held firm in December, with a slight increase from three months ago, according to the Reuters Tankan poll. Service-sector morale also remained steady, signaling steady economic growth driven by external and domestic demand. This positive reading is expected to influence the upcoming Bank of Japan's tankan survey.

site_title: Fu Yu proposes RM61.3m selective capital reduction plan to take Malaysian unit private
summary: Fu Yu Corporation Limited proposes a selective capital reduction plan (SCR) valued at RM61.3 million to take its Malaysian unit LCTH Corporation Berhard private. The plan involves a capital repayment of RM0.58 for each LCTH share, resulting in the cancellation of 106 million shares held by entitled shareholders. Upon completion, LCTH will become a fully owned subsidiary of Fu Yu. The SCR will be funded via the group's existing cash balance and internally generated funds.

site_title: Philippines plans to sue Sanofi over dengue vaccine
summary: The Philippines plans to sue Sanofi over its dengue vaccine, Dengvaxia, after regulators suspended the vaccine due to concerns that it could worsen symptoms for vaccinated people who contract the disease for the first time. The country's health secretary stated that the vaccine's effectiveness and safety had been compromised. The move comes after Sanofi warned that the vaccine could lead to severe infections in some cases. The suspension of the vaccine's sales has halted the country's world-first public dengue immunization program.

site_title: Halcyon Agri buys four more Indonesian rubber factories for $105.3m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation has acquired four Indonesian rubber factories for $105.3 million, becoming the largest producer and exporter of crumb rubber in Indonesia. The factories, owned by Liauw Chiang Sioe and Sjahrir Iskandar, have a total annual licensed export capacity of 132,000 tonnes. The acquisition increases Halcyon Agri's natural rubber processing segment and processing capacity to 1.55 million tonnes per year, with expected synergic benefits through shared infrastructure and economies of scale.

site_title: The multilateral rules-based trading system faces erosion
summary: The multilateral rules-based trading system is facing erosion due to increasing globalisation tensions, exemplified by the US under President Donald Trump's leadership. The US, EU, and China, the three dominant economies, have similar trade volumes and are reluctant to pursue explicit cooperation. The US trade policy has shifted from manufacturing to energy self-sufficiency, reducing its reliance on manufactured goods exports. China's leaders are hesitant to reinforce the system, believing their country will dominate the global economy within the current generation. The world should prepare for the erosion of the rules-based trading system enshrined in the WTO.

site_title: The priceless beauty of old things
summary: Hong Kong's China in Print exhibition showcases Asia's rarest books and manuscripts. Among the featured items is a 1607 map by Theodor de Bry, considered the oldest known map to depict Singapore. The map, part of the Grand Voyages account, shows Singapore as a small island joined to the Johor mainland in 1603. The exhibition, held at the China in Print fair, is a must-visit for collectors of antiquities, offering a glimpse into Asia's rich history and exploration.

site_title: Two-year revamp yields banner year for GE
summary: Great Eastern Holdings, Singapore's largest insurance group, has reported a banner year despite a two-year restructuring under new CEO Khor Hock Seng. Business and profits have increased, with new products selling well and the company's digitalization journey progressing. The revamp, which included high-profile departures, has allowed for better synergy and the implementation of group-wide strategies. The company's headcount has remained steady, and its agents have been supported by a larger business development team. Growth is expected to be sustained in 2018, with the company aiming to be the undisputed market leader.

site_title: Sheeran tops class of 2017
summary: ED Sheeran tops Spotify's 2017 year in music, becoming the most streamed artist with 45 million monthly listeners and 3.1 billion plays for his album ÷ (Divide). His single "Shape of You" is the most streamed track, with over 1.4 billion spins, and a remix of Luis Fonsi's "Despacito" is the second most streamed track globally. Despite missing Grammy nominations, Sheeran dominated the year with hip hop, Latin, and K-pop genres also experiencing significant growth.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Broadcom projects robust sales on strong smartphone demand
summary: Broadcom has reported robust sales of $5.3 billion for the period ending February 4, exceeding analysts' estimates of $4.83 billion. The company, which has been expanding through acquisitions, expects higher profitability and is sticking to its 5% annual sales growth target. Its wireless communications business saw 33% revenue growth, driven by increased demand for components from a "large North American smartphone customer," likely Apple. Broadcom's CEO, Hock Tan, is optimistic about the company's prospects and expects to close its proposed $105 billion acquisition of Qualcomm within a year.

site_title: Roche drug cocktail doubles chance of holding lung cancer at bay
summary: Roche's immunotherapy Tecentriq, combined with Avastin and chemotherapy, doubled the percentage of lung cancer patients surviving a year without disease progression to 37% in a clinical trial. This surpasses previous results and could potentially lead to Roche gaining ground on rivals Merck & Co and Bristol-Myers Squibb in the lung cancer market. The trial's results, released at the European Society for Medical Oncology meeting, also showed a 38% reduction in disease progression risk and an average survival of 8.3 months without disease worsening.

site_title: Using data analytics can benefit the social services sector
summary: Data analytics can help the social services sector achieve social outcomes with limited budgets. By analyzing data, organizations can prioritize interventions, maximize impact, and reduce waste. A case study in New Jersey used data analytics to predict child abuse cases, allowing case workers to target high-risk children. A/B testing is also being used in the social sector to evaluate program effectiveness, with results showing that only 25-10% of skills-training and education programs have strong effects. However, implementing data analytics in the social sector raises concerns over privacy, ethics, and cost, requiring careful consideration of trade-offs between data analysis and direct service delivery.

site_title: Carmakers want the tech without its patent wars
summary: Carmakers are teaming up to avoid patent wars, joining forces to jointly license technology, use non-proprietary software, and buy or challenge patents. Companies like Ford, Toyota, and Hyundai are banding together to share technologies and reduce litigation costs. This approach is inspired by the smartphone industry's resolution of patent disputes, with carmakers seeking to avoid costly court battles. By working together, companies aim to create a more collaborative and efficient approach to intellectual property management.

site_title: RBI betting on India investment turnaround
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is betting on an investment turnaround in India, citing benchmark interest rates at seven-year lows and a record $32 billion government injection into struggling state lenders. Governor Urjit Patel urged banks to pass on previous rate cuts to customers, aiming to revive private investment from a six-year slowdown. Economists forecast growth to rebound to 7.5% in 2019, driven by higher private consumption and investment demand, with some warning that the RBI's decision to leave rates unchanged may stymie the recovery.

site_title: Singapore now top destination for China overseas investments
summary: Singapore has surpassed the US to become the top destination for Chinese overseas investments, according to the China Going Global Investment Index 2017. The report found that Singapore and Malaysia are attractive destinations for Chinese investments, particularly in the Belt and Road Initiative. Despite a drop in Chinese overseas direct investment in 2017, the report suggests that the drivers behind ODI remain in place, and the drop is likely to be temporary. Developed markets remain the most attractive destinations, but developing economies have seen notable gains.

site_title: Independent adviser says Cogent offer price is 'fair and reasonable'
summary: Independent financial adviser CIMB Bank has stated that the offer price in the Cogent Holdings buy-out bid is "fair and reasonable" under prevailing conditions. The mainboard-listed logistics provider's independent directors have agreed with this assessment, recommending shareholders accept the deal. The offer price of S$1.02 per share is a significant premium over Cogent's net asset value, with some critics pointing out that a similar offer was made by another logistics company in September for S$1.30 per share.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: ASX to start using blockchain to process equity transactions
summary: The Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) announced it will start using blockchain technology to process equity transactions, with Digital Asset Holdings supplying the technology. The move is seen as a significant bet on the technology, with proponents citing its potential to be more efficient and less expensive. The ASX will begin transitioning from its existing Clearing House Electronic Subregister System (Chess) in the future, with no specific date announced. The switch is expected to introduce new services and lower costs for customers.

site_title: Indonesian ride-hailing firm Go-Jek to expand to Philippines in 2018
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing firm Go-Jek plans to expand to the Philippines in early 2018, with other South-east Asian countries to follow later in the year. Go-Jek competes with Uber and Grab in the region, home to 600 million people. The company's chief technology officer, Ajey Gore, stated that the Philippines will be the first country to test Go-Jek's services, with a focus on transportation and payments. Go-Jek is backed by private equity firms and venture capitalists, and plans to roll out new services, including charging stations and a laundry pick-up service.

images.alt_text: Go-Jek competes with Uber Technologies and Singapore-based Grab to lure customers in the South-east Asian market, home to 600 million people.

site_title: Uber paid Florida man to keep data breach secret: sources
summary: Uber paid a 20-year-old Florida hacker $100,000 to destroy the data of 57 million users, including 600,000 drivers in the US, after a data breach in 2016. The payment was made through a "bug bounty" program, which rewards security researchers for reporting vulnerabilities.
