The crisis has exacerbated existing divisions between parties, including the arrival of new parties and disagreements over proposals. Experts predict an exceptionally unproductive legislature, with a researcher stating that a constitutional reform will be difficult to agree on.

site_title: Lithium giant SQM eyes new project to tackle electric-car boom
summary: SQM, a Chilean lithium producer, is expanding into a new country amid record-high lithium prices. The company is considering opportunities in a fourth country, following its development of mines in Argentina and an Australian joint venture. SQM aims to diversify geographically to meet growing demand, with prices expected to remain tight until 2018. The company's shares have jumped 82% this year, driven by the lithium-producer rally.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.89 points to 1,722.95. Volume reached 59.93 million lots worth RM48.83 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 112 to 74.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won down on Wall Street losses
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 6.58 points, or 0.26%, to 2,503.54, while the won weakened 0.5% to 1,091.3 per dollar. The decline followed a third consecutive session of losses in the S&P 500 index. The Kospi is up 23.9% this year, but down 0.79% in the past 30 days. Foreigners were net sellers of 65,235 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar has fallen 9.52% against the won this year.

site_title: Casa proposes disposal of unit's shares to substantial shareholders worth RM24.42m
summary: Casa Holdings has entered into sale and purchase agreements with substantial shareholders to dispose of shares in its unit, Fiamma Holdings Berhad (FHB), for RM24.42 million. The disposal aims to raise funds to reduce bank borrowings and working capital. The agreements involve the sale of 16.4 million and 28 million shares to two substantial shareholders, resulting in Casa holding about 74.89 million ordinary shares of FHB, representing 14.72% of the company. The proposed disposal is conditional upon various conditions and is expected to reduce loss per share.

site_title: Luxury home builder Toll Brothers declines most since 2008 after earnings miss
summary: Toll Brothers Inc, the largest US luxury home builder, fell 7.3% to $46.95 after reporting quarterly earnings that missed analysts' estimates. The company's net income was $191.9 million, or $1.17 a share, down from $114.4 million, or 67 cents a share, a year earlier. The decline is the largest in nine years, surpassing its drop in 2008. The company cited delayed sales of three expensive New York City condo units as the reason for the earnings miss.

site_title: Australia's economy expands on exports, business spending
summary: Australia's economy expanded 0.6% in the third quarter, boosted by exports and business spending, reaching an annual rate of 2.8%. The growth is in line with central bank forecasts, extending the economy's uninterrupted growth to 26 years without a recession. Household expenditure, however, showed weak growth. The data contradicts the previous quarter's revised 0.9% expansion.

site_title: Amazon to launch Prime membership for Singapore, ends free shipping for non-members
summary: Amazon is launching its Prime membership program in Singapore, ending four years of free international shipping. The program, which costs S$8.99/month, offers benefits such as free international shipping, streaming services, and gaming subscriptions. Existing Amazon Prime Video subscribers will no longer be able to subscribe as a standalone service. The program is the 16th country to launch Amazon Prime, with Singapore being the first in South-east Asia. Free shipping to Singapore ended on Monday, and Prime Now, a fast delivery service, will also be exclusive for members.

site_title: US hits Vietnam with huge duties on steel made with Chinese material
summary: The US imposed duties of up to 265% on steel imports from Vietnam, targeting products made with Chinese material. The move aims to compensate for Chinese steel dumped into the US market. Imports from Vietnam have increased significantly since the initial duties on Chinese steel, with corrosion-resistant steel rising to $80 million and cold-rolled steel to $215 million annually. The decision is part of the Trump administration's aggressive trade enforcement steps, targeting China and other countries. A final decision will be announced in February.

site_title: Full Apex: impact of unit's outstanding US$46m loan minimal
summary: Full Apex Holdings, a Chinese plastic bottle maker, has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding the liquidation of its unit Jetzen Investment, which failed to settle a US$46 million loan. Full Apex stated that the loan's impact is now minimal, despite being a joint guarantor of Jetzen's debts. The company is seeking legal advice and exploring debt restructuring options, and trading can continue on an informed basis. Full Apex's share price closed up 14.63% at S$0.235 per share.

site_title: 3 bareboat charters of Emas Offshore's unit terminated
summary: Emas Offshore Limited's subsidiary has had three bareboat charters terminated, affecting the Lewek Ariel, Lewek Lynx, and Lewek Alkaid vessels. The terminations were due to breaches of material obligations and various termination events by the company, which is majority-owned by Ezra Holdings Ltd, now filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The affected owners have requested immediate delivery of the vessels at a safe anchorage in Singapore or other designated ports. Both companies are seeking legal advice and exploring new commercial arrangements.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, shedding 0.4% or 14.57 points to 3,423.49. This comes amid Wall Street's decline on Tuesday due to concerns over Senate tax reform legislation. The Straits Times Index saw 54.1 million shares change hands, with Allied Technologies rising S$0.001 to S$0.083. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 44, with the most actively traded counter being Allied Technologies.

site_title: Don't expect fireworks for gold in 2018, just a nudge higher
summary: Gold prices are expected to rise marginally in 2018, averaging around $1,313 an ounce, as real interest rates remain low and the US dollar weakens. Despite the Federal Reserve's potential rate hikes and European Central Bank's tapering of bond purchases, analysts predict a modest increase in gold prices. A shift in investment demand, driven by fear-based investors pulling away from equities and bonds, is also supporting bullion. However, some analysts, including Citigroup, predict a more bearish outlook, citing a hawkish Fed and sluggish Asian jewelry demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street retreat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a retreat on Wall Street and weak US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.51%, and the Topix index fell 0.40%. The decline comes amid global market uncertainty, with US President Trump's new threats to stocks not appearing to deter investors. The US stock market had edged to fresh records earlier in the day, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Broadway unit sells industrial property in US for US$3.69m
summary: Broadway Industrial Group's subsidiary Compart Engineering, Inc. sold an industrial building in San Bernardino, California for US$3.69 million. The property, valued at US$3.17 million, was leased to Compart Engineering, LLC, and will continue to be leased after the sale. The company plans to use the proceeds to strengthen its balance sheet and provide working capital. The disposal is part of a plan to dispose of underperforming assets and improve its financial position.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as materials stocks weigh; NZ declines
summary: Australia's shares fell on Wednesday, led by materials stocks, as lower base metal prices and a choppy Wall Street influenced the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 0.22% to 5,958.8, with BHP Billiton, South32, and Rio Tinto falling 1.4%, 2.8%, and 1.5%, respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia left interest rates unchanged, and GDP data showed a 0.6% quarterly rise, falling short of expectations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Broadway Industrial Group, Alliance Mineral Assets, SIA
summary: Broadway Industrial Group sold an industrial building in the US for $3.69 million, disposing of an underperforming asset to strengthen its balance sheet. Australian miner Alliance Mineral Assets' shares were seized by Singapore's High Court due to a $5.48 million debt, but the seizure is limited to the substantial shareholder's shares.

site_title: Nearly 50 injured in Germany train crash
summary: A passenger train crashed into a freight train near Duesseldorf, Germany, injuring at least 47 people, with three suffering "badly hurt" injuries. The train was carrying 155 passengers and was traveling at around 7:30 pm when the accident occurred. The cause of the accident is unclear. Rescue services were deployed, and those injured were transferred to hospital. The driver of the regional train, operated by National Express, was freed from his mangled cab and appears unharmed but in shock. Chancellor Angela Merkel has been briefed on the crash and is following the situation closely.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip in cyclical-defensive tug of war
summary: European shares slipped 0.2% on Tuesday, with cyclical stocks falling and financial services providers weighed down by US tax bill concerns. Consumer staples and utilities rose, while tech stocks rebounded. Eurozone banks fell 0.5% after their best gains in two months, and mining companies were the worst-performing sector. The healthcare sector was also bruised, with Sanofi leading the decline.

site_title: Veteran private banker to chair EFG International's advisory board for Asia
summary: Veteran private banker Tee Fong Seng, with 40 years of international banking experience, will chair EFG International's advisory board for Asia, set to be established later this month. He will also be nominated for the bank's board of directors at its next annual general meeting in April. Seng's experience includes leading roles at UBS and Credit Suisse, and he will provide guidance and expert advice to support EFG's expansion in Asia. His nomination underscores the importance of the Asia region for the bank, according to Chairman John Williamson.

images.alt_text: Ven Sreenivasan

site_title: Singapore will reach critical demographic crossroad in 2018, says UOB economist
summary: Singapore's population is expected to face a demographic crisis in 2018, with the share of 65-year-olds matching those younger than 15 for the first time. The elderly population is projected to make up over double the share of the youngest residents by 2030. Economist Francis Tan warns that this could lead to changes in taxes, immigration rules, and social services, and may require the government to increase the goods and services tax to 8% from 7% next year to mitigate the effects of aging.

images.alt_text: Next year marks an ominous turning point for Singapore's graying population, according to research by Francis Tan, an economist at United Overseas Bank.

site_title: Alliance Mineral's substantial shareholder's shares seized
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets reported that a writ of seizure and sale was issued by Singapore's High Court, seizing approximately 40.03 million shares belonging to substantial shareholder Living Waters Mining Australia. The seizure is related to a debt of around S$5.48 million to Grande Pacific. The seized shares will be sold to satisfy the debt, with any remaining shares being transferred back to LWMA. The company expects the sale to fully pay the debt, after which the injunction over frozen shares will be discharged.

site_title: The case for sovereign green bonds
summary: Singapore can become a green finance hub in South-east Asia by leveraging its financial infrastructure and geography, and can encourage green bond issuance by setting up a green bond listing platform, leveraging China's Belt & Road initiative, and taking a leading role in setting standards for the green bond market. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also providing subsidies and incentives to promote green bond issuance and market participation, with the goal of developing a wider range of sustainability-oriented benchmarks and products.

site_title: Google blocks YouTube access from Amazon's streaming devices
summary: Google has blocked YouTube access from Amazon's streaming devices, citing Amazon's failure to make Prime Video available and the halt of Nest product sales on its website. The move affects YouTube on Amazon's Fire TV set-top box and Echo Show smart speaker. Google previously blocked YouTube support for Echo Show in September and resolved the issue in November. The rivalry between Google and Amazon has intensified as both companies compete in hardware, internet services, and video streaming.

site_title: US trade hits nine-month high; oil prices lift imports
summary: The US trade deficit reached a nine-month high in October due to rising oil prices and widening deficits with China and Mexico. Despite strong exports to China and Mexico, the trade deficit persists, challenging the Trump administration's argument that the US is being disadvantaged in trade. The US trade deficit has increased, contradicting the Trump administration's goal to improve unfair trade terms.

images.alt_text: The US trade deficit increased to a nine-month high in October due to rising oil prices and the widening of America's long-standing deficits with China and Mexico.

site_title: Trump, Obama dominate Twitter year, but chicken nuggets prevail
summary: US President Donald Trump dominated Twitter in 2017 with 44 million followers, while former President Barack Obama's tweets were more liked. However, a man's quest for free chicken nuggets gained the most likes and retweets. Twitter revealed its most liked and retweeted tweets, showing a nation divided on social media. Trump was the most tweeted about world leader and US elected official, but his ranking on the platform was 21st.

site_title: Malaysia election could be as soon as Jan, Umno leaders hint
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, Umno, is hinting that the country's general election could be held as soon as January 2018. Deputy Prime Minister Zahid Hamidi stated that Umno must receive a decisive victory, while Prime Minister Najib Razak mentioned January as a potential election month. However, Umno's information chief, Annuar Musa, clarified that January is not the exact date, but rather a call to prepare for the election. The party is seeking to resolve internal tensions and address issues such as the rising cost of living and housing problems.

site_title: Nissan, DeNA to hold public trials of self-driving car service in Japan next year
summary: Nissan and DeNA, a Japanese gaming software maker, plan to hold public trials of their self-driving ride-sharing service in Japan next year, starting in March. The service, called "Easy Ride," will allow users to summon self-driving Nissan Leaf electric cars to travel to pre-mapped destinations via an app. The trial marks a step towards the companies' goal of launching a full-service, self-driving ride-sharing service in Japan in the early 2020s. Nissan and DeNA join a growing list of global carmakers and tech firms leveraging automated driving technology into new mobility services.

site_title: Toxic air puts 17m babies' brains and lungs at risk: Unicef
summary: UNICEF warns that 17 million babies worldwide, primarily in South Asia, are at risk due to toxic air pollution exceeding six times the recommended limit. This exposure can harm developing lungs and potentially damage brain development, affecting their futures. Air pollution is linked to respiratory infections and has not yet conclusive evidence on brain development, but growing evidence suggests a significant concern. Brain development between 1,000 days is crucial for learning, growth, and overall well-being.

site_title: Gold at two-month low as dollar bounces on US tax plan support
summary: Gold prices dropped 1% to a two-month low on Tuesday as the US dollar rose and investors assessed the US tax overhaul legislation. The dollar's gain boosted US technology stocks, while gold futures settled down 1% at $1,264.90 per ounce. Analysts attribute the decline to the dollar's strength, which makes gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, and the expected hike in US interest rates.

images.alt_text: Gold dropped 1 per cent to a two-month low on Tuesday as the dollar rose against a basket of currencies and US stocks rebounded as investors assessed details of the US tax overhaul legislation.

site_title: Natixis banks on fixed income, equity derivatives to boost sales in Asia
summary: Natixis aims to boost its Asia share of corporate and investment banking sales to over 15% over the next couple of years. The French bank plans to expand in fixed income and equity derivatives, increasing headcount in Asia by 10% annually for the next three years. This growth comes amid heightened competition among Wall Street banks and local firms for investment banking services. Natixis aims to focus on specific sectors such as aviation, energy, and infrastructure, and has established a strong presence in Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan.

site_title: Saudi, allies snub Qatar at crisis-hit Gulf summit
summary: Saudi Arabia and its allies snubbed Qatar at a Gulf Cooperation Council summit in Kuwait City, with Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani attending but not joined by Saudi Arabia's King Salman and the leaders of the UAE and Bahrain. The summit, which came six months into a rift between Qatar and the Saudi-led bloc, saw Kuwait vow to continue mediation efforts. The future of the six-nation GCC appeared to be hanging in the balance, with experts warning that the Qatar crisis could lead to the demise of the once-powerful bloc.

site_title: Drugmakers give post-Brexit UK science vote of confidence
summary: Britain has secured a vote of confidence from the life sciences sector, with five major drug companies committing to invest in the country despite Brexit. The investments include £40 million from GlaxoSmithKline in genomic research and plans by Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca for new clinical trials. The move is a welcome boost for Prime Minister Theresa May, who has struggled to win over industry leaders. However, regulatory alignment with the EU remains a challenge for the highly regulated sector.

images.alt_text: Britain won a vote of confidence from its economically important life sciences sector on Wednesday as five drug companies committed to invest in the country under the government's industrial strategy plans after Brexit.

site_title: Criminalisation of seafarers is troubling
summary: Thirty-five Indian seafarers, including six Britons, three Ukrainians, and 14 Estonians, were acquitted and freed after serving five-year prison sentences for allegedly smuggling arms into India. The men were detained in 2013 while refuelling in Indian territorial waters on the Sierra Leone-flagged anti-piracy ship Seaman Guard Ohio. The acquittal comes after a long and slow judicial process, with the men's families still awaiting permission to leave India. Seafarer charities and unions, such as the International Transport Workers Federation, provided crucial support to the men and their families during their ordeal.

site_title: New Facebook app for children ignites debate among families
summary: Facebook introduces Messenger Kids, a new app for children aged 13 and younger, allowing them to message, add filters, and doodle on photos. The app aims to provide a controlled environment for family communication. The move has reignited a debate among parents, with some expressing concerns about the early adoption of technology and its impact on children's development, while others see it as an inevitability. Facebook has consulted with parenting groups, child behavioural experts, and safety organisations to develop the app, which complies with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

site_title: Oil rises in anticipation of another US crude drawdown
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as strong demand and expectations of a drop in US crude inventories supported the market. The American Petroleum Institute reported a 5.5 million-barrel drop in crude stocks, while the US Energy Information Administration is expected to show a 3.4 million-barrel drop. Analysts believe Opec's efforts to cut output will continue to clear the glut, with demand expected to outpace supply in 2018. Brent crude settled up 41 cents at $62.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 15 cents to $57.62 a barrel.

site_title: Deutsche Bank is said to receive Mueller subpoena over Trump
summary: Deutsche Bank has received a subpoena from special prosecutor Robert Mueller over its dealings with President Donald Trump, demanding it share data on its client relationship with Trump. The bank must submit documents detailing its business with Trump and his family, amid Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the US election. This development comes as Trump's former national security adviser Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to FBI agents, and Mueller's team is interviewing White House aides. Trump owes Deutsche Bank approximately $300 million from real estate dealings.

site_title: Artificial Intelligence, limited by input, not a game changer: scholars
summary: Artificial intelligence researchers released an annual report, the AI Index, stating that current AI methods, such as deep learning, are limited by input data and do not replicate human intelligence. Despite advancements, AI systems excel in narrow contexts but struggle with common sense reasoning and adapting to new situations. The report highlights the need for caution in relying on AI, citing potential risks of biased data and misuse. Experts emphasize the importance of responsible AI development and data sharing.

site_title: SMRT chairman Seah Moon Ming steps down as CEO of Pavilion Energy
summary: SMRT Corp chairman Seah Moon Ming is stepping down as CEO of Pavilion Energy to focus on resolving SMRT's issues. Frederic Barnaud, a former Total SA executive, will take over as Pavilion CEO from February 1. Seah leaves Pavilion on the same day, citing a need to devote more time to his role at SMRT, which he was appointed to in July. Under his leadership, Pavilion Energy has built a global liquefied natural gas (LNG) value chain, with joint ownership in three LNG carriers and a storage tank at the Singapore LNG terminal.

site_title: Values, good governance crucial for Singapore's future: Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of clear values, good governance, and leadership in navigating the country's future. He stated that Singapore must focus on building a fair and just society, maintain trust and open communication, and build social and cross-cultural capital to provide a foundation for good governance. Heng cited cautionary examples in developed countries where a lack of trust and good governance led to negative consequences.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Two Jason Holdings Ltd directors had bankruptcy applications withdrawn on Tuesday. Choo Chiang Holdings executive chairman Thomas Lim Teck Chuan attended a Monetary Authority of Singapore investigation on September 29, 2017, related to an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. Heeton Holdings sold The Woodgrove for S$55.85 million to a Singapore-based purchaser. Sembcorp Marine signed a letter of intent with Shell Offshore Inc to build a floating production unit in the US. Mapletree Logistics Trust plans to sell a Malaysia property for S$9.2 million, and Keppel Corporation saw BlackRock become a substantial shareholder.

site_title: Trade deficit rises to nine-month high in October
summary: The US trade deficit rose to a nine-month high in October, increasing 8.6% to $48.7 billion. Rising oil prices and imports of goods and services contributed to the widening deficit. The real trade deficit, adjusted for inflation, reached $65.3 billion, its highest level since January. This suggests that trade could subtract from gross domestic product in the fourth quarter. The US trade deficit has garnered attention from President Donald Trump, who has called for renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: The US tax reform is good politics, but at the cost of prudence
summary: The US tax reform is being touted as a political victory, despite concerns over its prudence. The bill, aimed at boosting economic growth, is expected to add $1 trillion to the federal budget deficit from 2018 to 2027, according to nonpartisan estimates. Critics worry that this will lead to higher debt and potentially slow down the economy in the long term. While economic growth may mask the issue initially, the bill's long-term impact on the economy remains uncertain, and the government will need to address the resulting budget challenges.

site_title: US House, Senate Republicans brace for clash over corporate AMT tax
summary: US House and Senate Republicans are at odds over the corporate alternative minimum tax (AMT) as they work to reconcile competing tax bills. The Senate bill retains the AMT, while the House bill repeals it, sparking a potential clash over revenue and tax rates. Removing the AMT could require a $40 billion revenue loss, possibly by scaling back the planned 20% corporate tax rate. Lawmakers face challenges in covering the loss and maintaining economic competitiveness, with some calling for the tax to be eliminated.

site_title: China coal cities secure US$310m ADB loan to revitalise economies
summary: Four cities in northeast China, Hegang, Jixi, Qitaihe, and Shuangyashan, have secured a US$310 million loan from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to revitalize their economies. The loan is part of a US$1 billion project to support small to medium-sized enterprises and address environmental damage caused by decades of coal mining. The project is scheduled to be completed in early 2023, with contributions from the European Investment Bank and local banks and government departments.

site_title: ArcelorMittal's Ilva bid stalled, but EU steel to benefit either way
summary: ArcelorMittal's bid to buy Italian steel major Ilva has stalled due to a court appeal and EU antitrust authorities' full inquiry. However, the European Union's steel sector is expected to benefit from the uncertainty, as a rally in steel prices since last year is unlikely to be derailed. A successful appeal could temporarily shut down Ilva, driving up spot prices, while a successful takeover would improve pricing power for EU steelmakers in the long term.

site_title: Citi appoints former eBay chief data officer as Asia-Pac data head
summary: Citi has appointed Zoher Karu, former eBay chief data officer, as the head of Asia-Pacific data and analytics, based in Singapore. Karu will report to Anand Selva and oversee data-driven customer value and business growth in 17 markets worldwide. This appointment marks Citi's first Big Data role within its consumer banking unit in Singapore, as part of its digital transformation strategy.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower as tax bill haggling continues
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as investors continued to weigh the impact of a tax overhaul on corporate earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.5% and the S&P 500 losing 0.4%. A Senate version of the tax package reinstates an alternative minimum tax, benefiting the tech sector, and a federal agency warned of mounting risks of a sudden drop in stocks and bonds. Market risks are high, with the S&P's price-earnings ratio in the 97th percentile relative to the last 130 years, according to the Treasury Department's Office of Financial Research.

site_title: Everyone's in the know while on the go with Dropbox Business
summary: Dropbox Business is a cloud-based platform that enables businesses to communicate and collaborate across devices and time zones. Characterist LLC, a law firm in Singapore, adopted Dropbox Business to streamline document management, reduce storage costs, and increase productivity. The firm's lawyers can now access and share documents easily, both in and out of court, and can also use features like comments and remote wipe to enhance collaboration and data security. Simitri Group International, a consulting firm, also adopted Dropbox Business to facilitate global collaboration and improve productivity among its staff members. Both firms report significant increases in productivity and efficiency since adopting the platform.

images.alt_text: Chantal Sajan

site_title: Falcon's attack strategy could inspire new drones
summary: Researchers say Peregrine falcons' attack strategies could inspire small drones that can take out rogue drones. Contrary to popular belief, falcons' trajectories don't follow geometric rules, making their attacks unpredictable. This unique approach could lead to the development of visually guided drones that can evade detection and neutralize threats. The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, aims to explore the potential of nature's fastest predators to inform drone technology.

site_title: Fox leaning towards Disney as buyer for studio and media assets: sources
summary: Fox is reportedly leaning towards Disney as a potential buyer for its studio and media assets, including the 20th Century Fox film and TV studio and a stake in the UK pay-TV provider Sky Plc. The deal would expand Disney's global reach, giving it control of Sky, Star India, and US cable channels like FX and National Geographic. The Murdochs are considering a sale as the market values the group below slower-growing peers, with a potential deal worth around $50 billion.

images.alt_text: The Fox assets in play are said to be worth almost US$50 billion and could translate into a 25 per cent stake in Disney if they agree to a stock deal.

site_title: SGX, stakeholders roll out new guide to prevent insider trading
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and various stakeholders have launched a guide to prevent insider trading, outlining recommendations and best practices for companies and advisers. The guide, a collaborative effort, aims to deter insider trading by providing principles and guidelines on confidential information handling, balancing staff dealing restrictions, and creating a culture of compliance. The document is non-prescriptive and customizable to each company's unique profile, with stakeholders welcoming the move as a valuable resource for ensuring best practice standards and safeguarding interests.

site_title: Adidas wins World Cup race, but Nike kicks back at ground level
summary: Adidas has won the sponsorship deal for Germany's World Cup team, but players like Sami Khedira are still wearing Nike shoes. This marks a strategic shift in the decades-old sneaker wars, as Adidas gains a high-profile victory but Nike maintains its ground-level presence through its product offerings. The article suggests that Adidas' success may be a result of its high-profile partnerships, while Nike continues to focus on its core business.

site_title: Choo Chiang's CEO questioned by MAS over "personal matter" relating to SFA case
summary: Choo Chiang Holdings CEO Thomas Lim Teck Chuan was questioned by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on September 29, 2017, regarding a personal matter related to a Securities and Futures Act (SFA) case. Lim stated that the investigation is unrelated to the company's shares or business activities. His passport was impounded, and he will attend further interviews. Lim remains the company's executive chairman and CEO.

site_title: Two Airbnb hosts in Singapore charged over illegal home-sharing
summary: Two Singapore men, Terence Tan En Wei and Yao Songliang, were charged with providing unauthorized short-term stays on Airbnb. They allegedly rented out four units at Leedon Heights for under six months without permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The charges, under the new Planning Act, carry fines of up to S$200,000 and jail time of up to a year. The cases will be heard again in January, marking the first court action under the new regulations against home-sharing since May 15.

site_title: Two tender closings signal developers' unabating land appetite
summary: Two Singapore government land sales (GLS) tenders for residential sites at Jiak Kim Street and Fourth Avenue saw intense competition, with Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) securing the Jiak Kim Street site with a S$955.4m bid, setting a new price benchmark of S$1,733 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). Allgreen Properties topped the Fourth Avenue site with a S$552.96m bid, despite concerns over market exuberance. Despite warnings from the government, developers' appetite for prime sites remains strong, with half of bidders for the Jiak Kim Street site submitting bids within a tight band.

images.alt_text: Two residential land parcels at Jiak Kim Street and Fourth Avenue under the government land sales (GLS) programme saw keen contest on Tuesday, with Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) setting a new price benchmark for the Jiak Kim Street site.

site_title: Don't fight the Fed, says Denmark's biggest pension fund
summary: Denmark's largest pension fund, ATP, is sticking to its investment strategy despite market volatility, saying "don't fight the Fed" is its guiding principle. The fund, with $120 billion in assets, has delivered its highest quarterly return in five years, citing low inflation expectations and central banks' control. ATP's chief investment officer, Kasper Ahrndt Lorenzen, views the Fed's new chair, Jerome Powell, as a "good choice" for continuity, and is skeptical of market warnings about a sudden asset-price correction. The fund is also considering increasing its use of automated investments.

site_title: Dollar steadies after Monday's bounce
summary: The US dollar steadied on Tuesday after a 0.3% gain the previous day, its largest daily rise in a week, as investors awaited the outcome of the US tax bill. Sterling fell 0.8% to $1.3375 due to disappointment over a Brexit deal, while the Australian dollar rose 0.6% after strong retail sales data. The Russian rouble also strengthened despite an increase in foreign currency purchases by the finance ministry. The Senate must now reconcile its version of the tax bill with the House of Representatives, with caution expected to prevail before further movement.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to codeshare on budget unit Scoot
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir will codeshare on Scoot-operated flights between Singapore and over 30 destinations, starting with 8 unique destinations. The codeshare agreement will offer greater choice and convenience to passengers, with SIA and SilkAir customers able to travel on single-ticket itineraries. Passengers will receive checked baggage allowance, a complimentary meal and beverage, and the option to select seats on Scoot flights. The agreement is part of SIA's multi-brand strategy and is expected to be managed to minimize brand dilution.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Telco tie-ups always on Mobike's radar, says co-founder
summary: Mobike, a bicycle-sharing company, has partnered with the Singtel Group to enhance its technology-driven global expansion strategy. The deal covers mobile payments, IoT, data analytics, and marketing, reaching 585 million mobile customers in the Asia-Pacific region. Mobike's co-founder, Joe Xia, sees regional telcos as critical partners, with Singtel being the strongest in Asia. This partnership is Mobike's first with a telco outside China, where it has a long-standing relationship with China Mobile. Mobike is now seeking telco partners in Europe, North America, and Latin America.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Japan Airlines invests US$10m in supersonic jet company Boom
summary: Japan Airlines has invested $10 million in supersonic jet company Boom, which is developing a 55-seat plane capable of flying from New York to London in just three hours and 15 minutes, 10% faster than Concorde. Boom's aircraft is expected to produce a 30 times quieter sonic boom and have 75% lower operating costs. The deal also includes Japan Airlines' knowledge and experience to refine the aircraft design and passenger experience. Boom has received 76 pre-orders from airlines, excluding the option of up to 20 aircraft from Japan Airlines.

site_title: Don't be lulled by low volatility
summary: Market risk is expected to unfold despite low volatility, which is the lowest in over 53 years. The S&P 500 Index's realised volatility is on pace to finish below 7%, while 10-year Treasury yields have remained within a 60 basis-point range since 1965. This stability is vulnerable to market disruption, with John Templeton warning that saying "this time is different" can be costly. As a result, monetary policy makers and investors should be cautious, as the assumption of permanent low volatility may lead to risk-taking that is highly susceptible to a future market downturn.

site_title: Del Monte chases avocado dollar amid shift in tastes
summary: Del Monte Pacific, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, is shifting its focus towards healthier snacks, including avocados, in response to changing consumer preferences. The company plans to form a joint venture with Fresh Del Monte Produce to produce refrigerated fruit snacks, chilled juices, and avocado products. This move comes after Del Monte posted a net loss of $2.82 million in the fiscal second quarter, citing one-off expenses related to its underperforming vegetable business and a soft US market. The company expects to be profitable for fiscal 2018 on a recurring basis.

site_title: Time to unite at national level to fight cyber terrorism
summary: Nation states must act now to protect themselves from advanced cyber threats. Recent ransomware attacks, such as WannaCry and Petya, demonstrate the growing danger of cybercrime. Nation states are employing hacker services to damage governments and influence politics. The global cyber threat landscape is becoming increasingly sophisticated, with nation states at risk of devastating cyber attacks. Businesses, financial institutions, and governments should prioritize cyber defenses to prevent financial loss and reputational damage. Immediate action is necessary to counter this emerging threat.

site_title: Reality check for China's natural gas push to cut air pollution
summary: China's push to use natural gas to cut air pollution has led to rising prices and limited supplies of the cleaner fuel, prompting the government to intervene. The National Development and Reform Commission ordered eight regions to meet with natural gas producers, traders, and terminal operators to ensure prices don't rise too much. Domestic natural gas output has increased, but imports from central Asian suppliers are also rising, with LNG imports surging 48.9% in the first 10 months of the year. China is expected to boost supplies by importing more LNG, but the current market is showing signs of being under-supplied for the northern winter.

site_title: Australian retailers rally as Amazon gets cool reception
summary: Amazon's Australian arm launched on Tuesday, taking its first orders and easing market fears about its potential to devastate brick-and-mortar retailers. Despite being competitive on price, analysts found some items were more expensive on the US company's website. Retail stocks rallied, with shares of JB HiFi and Harvey Norman Holdings jumping 5% and 2%, respectively. Amazon's initial offer was described as "patchy" and "not compelling," with analysts predicting it won't be disruptive to Australian retailers this Christmas.

site_title: The next big short: Hedge funds prepare to trade against bitcoin
summary: Hedge funds are preparing to trade against Bitcoin as futures contracts are set to debut at CME Group, Cboe Global Markets, and Nasdaq. The introduction of these contracts will make it easier for investors to bet on a decline, with some predicting a significant shorting opportunity. However, others argue that the market is too volatile and that short sellers risk getting "stung" like those who bet against the internet bubble in the late 1990s. The launch of these futures contracts on December 18 is expected to open up a new frontier for investors to short the cryptocurrency.

site_title: Carrefour and Fnac Darty to form French purchasing partnership
summary: French retailers Carrefour and Fnac Darty announced a purchasing partnership for domestic appliances and consumer electronics in France. The agreement aims to cut costs and boost earnings for Carrefour, which hired Fnac Darty's former CEO Alexandre Bompard in July. The partnership follows similar deals between Casino and Conforama and Casino and Ocado. Analysts expect cost savings of 90 million euros and increased firepower to invest in the French business. The deal is seen as a response to the threat posed by Amazon in the European market.

site_title: Joint venture with Ronaldo spurs Portugal hotel chain's overseas growth
summary: Portugal's hotel chain Pestana has partnered with Cristiano Ronaldo in a joint venture to expand globally, with plans to open two hotels under the Pestana CR7 brand by end-2018. The partnership aims to tap into Asian and US markets, following the success of the first Pestana CR7 hotels in Madeira and Lisbon. The venture, worth 75 million euros, will also see Pestana roll out new establishments in Europe and the US, with further expansion dependent on the success of the CR7-branded hotels.

site_title: EU blacklists 17 tax havens
summary: The European Union has adopted a blacklist of 17 non-EU tax havens, including Panama, South Korea, and the UAE, after a year of negotiations. The list includes countries that have failed to fight tax evasion effectively, following a Paradise Papers leak that exposed intricate tax avoidance schemes. The EU has also identified 47 "grey list" countries, with enforcement being a major concern. The move aims to clamp down on tax avoidance, with some countries expressing concerns about scaring off multinationals and others advocating for tougher measures, such as financial sanctions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to see a sustainable improvement, driven by recovering tender prices, improved construction GDP, and a rebounding property sector. Analysts recommend small- and medium-sized contractors, such as Chip Eng Seng, APAC Realty, and Lian Beng, citing their strong capabilities and proven track records. The Singapore consumer sector is also forecasted to rebound, with analysts giving "buy" ratings to supermarkets Sheng Siong and Dairy Farm, and homegrown curry puff chain Old Chang Kee.

site_title: YouTube to expand teams reviewing extremist content
summary: YouTube plans to expand its team of content reviewers to over 10,000 in 2018 to address extremist, violent, and disturbing content. The company aims to improve its automated software to identify hate speech and unsuitable videos for children. Uploaders whose videos are flagged may be ineligible for ad revenue. YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki announced the move in response to criticism and advertiser concerns, amid stepped-up enforcement and the launch of new comment-moderation tools. The goal is to provide more accurate content review and address online radical material.

site_title: Heeton subsidiary enters sale agreement for The Woodgrove at S$55.85 million
summary: Heeton Holdings' subsidiary has entered into a sale agreement for The Woodgrove in Singapore for S$55.85 million. The property has a leasehold term of 99 years, with an unexpired lease term of approximately 78 years. The sale is expected to result in a net gain of approximately S$22 million for the company, which will enhance its cash flow and direct resources to higher-yield investments.

site_title: Carrefour and Fnac Darty form French purchasing partnership
summary: French retailers Carrefour and Fnac Darty have formed a purchasing partnership to buy domestic appliances and consumer electronics, aiming to cut costs and boost earnings. The agreement will take effect in 2018, with Carrefour's CEO Alexandre Bompard seeking to boost the group's France-based hypermarkets. Analysts estimate the deal will generate 90 million euros of savings and give Carrefour "additional firepower" to invest in its French business. The partnership follows similar deals between Casino and Conforama, and comes amid concerns about Amazon's expansion into the European market.

site_title: Ossia International, BH Global put on SGX watch-list
summary: Ossia International Limited and BH Global Corporation Limited have been placed on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list from Dec 5, 2017. Ossia was added due to consecutive pre-tax losses and low market capitalization, while BH Global was added for failing to meet the minimum trading price (MTP) entry criteria. Companies on the watch-list may be removed if they meet specific requirements within 36 months, including maintaining a volume-weighted average price of at least S$0.20 over six months.

site_title: China's Sinochem seeking to sell logistics unit for 3.5b yuan
summary: Sinochem International Corp is selling its logistics unit for 3.5 billion yuan (S$713 million) as part of efforts to respond to Beijing's push for a slimmer state sector. The unit, which owns nearly 80 tankers, is being auctioned off to a consortium led by Ordos City Junzheng Energy & Chemical Co Ltd, with some private equity firms also interested. The sale aims to improve the efficiency of the state sector and transform Sinochem into a conglomerate with a strong foundation in petrochemicals and growth driven by material science and life science businesses.

site_title: STI loses steam as sell-off in US tech bites
summary: The Singapore bourse's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Tuesday, closing 0.41 points or 0.01% lower at 3,438.06, despite a strong year-to-date gain of 19.4%. Asian markets, influenced by a US tech stocks sell-off, saw mixed returns, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 1%, and China's Shanghai Composite losing 0.2%. Local stocks, including City Developments and CapitaLand, fell, but banking stocks like DBS Group and OCBC advanced. Analysts attribute the sell-off to investors rotating out of valuation-rich sectors and locking in profits amid the US tax overhaul.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Noble in intense talks to repackage debts holistically
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, is in talks with unsecured creditors in Hong Kong and London for a "holistic" restructuring of its US$3.5 billion debt pile. A resolution could be reached by Christmas, without extending repayment, as the group aims to resolve the issue promptly. Asset disposals are key to Noble's survival bid, according to sources.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Glencore bets big on car battery metals
summary: Glencore, a Swiss mining company, has increased production of electric car battery metals such as cobalt, copper, and nickel, doubling its output in five years. The company's core profit is now 50% electric vehicle metals, more than double its major competitors. However, Glencore's strategy also comes with risks, including high debt levels and reliance on the Democratic Republic of Congo for cobalt. Analysts see the benefits of the company's efforts as a potential long-term threat to its ambitions, but a rapid pace of technological development may also undermine the need for these metals.

site_title: Italy launches probe into Gucci for alleged tax evasion
summary: Italy's tax police have launched a probe into Gucci, investigating the luxury fashion brand for alleged tax evasion, potentially totaling up to 1.3 billion euros. The investigation centers on Gucci's Swiss operations, where the brand declared profits that should have been reported in Italy. Gucci has confirmed its cooperation with authorities, but the case is notable due to the brand's reputation and significant growth. The probe is part of a series of tax investigations targeting prominent Italian companies, with similar cases settled in the past.

site_title: Russian tycoons, fearing new sanctions, float idea of new treasury bond: sources
summary: Russian wealthy individuals, fearing US sanctions, have proposed a special treasury bond to bring foreign cash assets back to Russia, allowing anonymous holders. The bond would be forex-denominated, offering higher yields and greater liquidity than Eurobonds. However, the Russian government has shown little interest in the idea, with the finance ministry declining to comment. Wealthy Russians face risks of tax evasion, economic crashes, and prosecution if they don't bring assets home, prompting them to explore alternative options.

site_title: SPH fulfil wishes of 300 children under Boys' Brigade project
summary: The Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) fulfilled the wishes of 300 children through its Boys' Brigade Share-A-Gift Project, which focuses on granting the "wishes" of the less fortunate. The project, now in its 30th year, received over 9,000 wishes from children and adults in Singapore, with SPH management and staff contributing approximately S$20,000 to fulfill about 300 wishes. The event, held at the SPH News Centre Auditorium, featured games, food, and a party for the children, promoting the importance of sharing and kindness.

site_title: North Korea's nuclearisation: a dilemma for China
summary: North Korea's successful test of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) on November 29 has sparked a global crisis, with the US, Japan, and South Korea urging China to take action. US President Donald Trump called Chinese leader Xi Jinping, urging him to cut off oil deliveries to North Korea, but China has rebuffed the request. The UN Security Council held an emergency meeting, with Nikki Haley warning of war, while China's representative called for restraint and dialogue. The situation is critical, with the US and other countries considering military action, and China facing pressure to contain the crisis without escalating tensions.

site_title: Tech glitches leave Fidelity, Schwab, TD Ameritrade, Wells Fargo customers fuming
summary: Tech glitches affected customers of Fidelity Investments, Charles Schwab, TD Ameritrade Holding, and Wells Fargo & Co, preventing them from accessing account information and causing frustration. The issues occurred on Monday morning, with Fidelity reporting "issues with our website" and resolving them by the afternoon. Similar glitches occurred at Fidelity two weeks prior, and it's unclear if the issues are related. The companies, including Schwab and Wells Fargo, stated that trading was not impacted and functionality has been restored.

site_title: China steel maker Delong says it's hit by production halt; expects fall in revenue
summary: China steel maker Delong Holdings reported a production halt at its subsidiary Delong Steel due to air pollution policies. The shutdown will reduce revenue by 696 million yuan (S$141 million) and 1.49 billion yuan in fiscal 2017 and 2018, respectively. The production halt will last until March 31, 2018, and reduce the group's production capacity by 232,000 tonnes and 498,000 tonnes in the financial years ending December 31, 2017, and 2018, respectively.

site_title: Singapore's first bitcoin dispute goes to trial
summary: Singapore's first bitcoin dispute is headed to trial at the Singapore International Commercial Court after a summary judgment hearing was declined. Electronic market maker B2C2 sued bitcoin exchange operator Quoine over trades that were allegedly wrongfully reversed, resulting in a loss of potentially over US$30 million. B2C2 sought to recover 3,084.78582325bitcoins, but Judge Simon Thorley declined to grant summary judgment, directing the case for trial to determine if B2C2 is entitled to recover the bitcoins or their value, considering the surge in bitcoin's value.

site_title: RWS grants 440 kids their Christmas wishes
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) granted Christmas wishes to 440 underprivileged children from the South West District, providing an exclusive preview of the A Universal Christmas event at Universal Studios Singapore. The children, aged 5-12, joined local officials to witness the lighting up of the World of Stars and were treated to an acrobatic fairy appearance. The event aimed to bring festive cheer to the children, marking a special moment for them during the holiday season.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Australian new vehicle sales notch a record November
summary: Australian new vehicle sales reached a record high in November with 101,365 units sold, up 2.5% from the same month last year. The commercial sector drove sales, with a 7.9% increase in light vehicles and a 22.7% surge in heavy vehicles. Passenger car sales declined 7.3%, while sports utilities gained 8.6%. Toyota maintained its lead with 18.6% market share, followed by Mazda at 9.2%. The year-to-date sales are 0.6% ahead of the same period in 2016.

site_title: Eurozone businesses sprinting to year-end after busy November
summary: Eurozone businesses are ending 2017 on a high note, with growth accelerating in November as firms struggled to meet booming demand. The IHS Markit composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 57.5, its highest level since 2011, with the services sector experiencing a six-month high. This suggests the eurozone economy will end the year strong, with fourth-quarter growth predicted at 0.8%. However, the UK's services sector declined, and Brexit uncertainty is expected to continue to impact growth in 2018.

site_title: The good and bad news for President Trump
summary: President Trump's legislative fortunes see-sawed last weekend between a landmark tax overhaul bill and the plea bargain of former national security advisor Michael Flynn. The Senate passed the tax bill 51-49, with every Republican except retiring Senator Bob Corker voting in favor, despite concerns over the bill's impact on the federal budget and potential implications for the 2020 presidential election. The passage of the bill is seen as a major legislative triumph for Trump, with market watchers predicting a "super-bull" stock market and an economic boom, which could boost his re-election chances.

site_title: Shanghai exchange to hold practice session for crude oil futures
summary: The Shanghai International Energy Exchange (INE) will hold a practice session for its crude oil futures contract on Dec 9-10, using real customer data and seeking feedback from members. This comes after China, the world's second-largest oil consumer, sought to establish a crude futures contract to influence global oil pricing. The Shanghai Futures Exchange (ShFE), INE's parent, had previously planned to launch the contract in May but missed targets. The practice session aims to ensure a steady launch of the contract, which has been delayed multiple times.

site_title: Repeated warnings on property market exuberance may have muted impact
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued its third warning on property market exuberance, but its impact may be muted as land bids continue to be bullish. Despite the warnings, developers are still seeking to acquire land at high prices, with recent sales exceeding expectations. The MAS cites a potential mismatch between supply and occupation demand, but developers argue that pent-up demand and improved buying sentiment are driving sales. The government's projection of new units on en bloc sites and government land sales sites may not come to pass, and vacancy rates are expected to find some relief in the near term. The series of warnings may not be enough to calibrate developer and homebuyer behavior, and the MAS will need to take further action to prevent prices from over-shooting.

site_title: US trade gap broadens in October on all-time record imports
summary: The US trade gap widened to its highest level in nine months in October, reaching $48.7 billion, driven by record imports and higher oil prices. The increase was 8.6% from September, surpassing analyst expectations. Higher imports from China, particularly ahead of the holiday shopping season, contributed to the surge. This marks the largest trade deficit since January.

site_title: Nam Cheong sweetens terms for US$336m debt restructuring
summary: Nam Cheong has released a revised proposal for its debt restructuring, with improved terms for US$336 million unsecured debt and note issuances. The revised proposal calls for 35% of non-sustainable debt to be converted to equity at US$1 to 30 shares, and offers two options for the remaining sustainable debt, including a term loan facility or a cash recovery rate of 5-20 cents per dollar. However, retail noteholders have expressed disappointment with the revised conversion ratio, citing a share price that is three times the rights share subscription price.

site_title: EU says 'show now in London' as onus on UK for Brexit progress
summary: The European Commission has stated that the UK government must show readiness to resume Brexit negotiations before talks can begin again. Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said, "The show is now in London," as UK Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to return to Brussels later this week. Talks broke up on Monday due to disagreements over the Irish border question. EU officials expect further talks to take place on Wednesday evening.

site_title: Reserves help Singapore weather crises and keep economy stable: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's reserves provide long-term economic stability and firepower to weather crises, such as the global financial crisis. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that the reserves were accumulated over many years through prudent spending by past generations and should not be tapped lightly. The reserves, which have generated over S$15 billion in returns, are managed through a net investment returns framework, allowing the government to spend up to half of expected returns. Heng stressed the importance of fiscal sustainability and responsible spending to ensure the country's long-term economic security.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng giving his speech at The Straits Times Global Outlook Forum 2018: Facing the challenges of a new world order.

site_title: Indonesia to keep Opec membership frozen: deputy energy minister
summary: Indonesia will maintain its Opec membership freeze, following President Joko Widodo's direction, according to Deputy Energy Minister Arcandra Tahar. The freeze was imposed in 2016 due to disagreements over production cuts. Indonesia is seeking to rejoin Opec if it's not subject to output cuts, but Tahar declined to comment further. Indonesia pumps around 800,000 barrels of crude per day and Opec producers have agreed to extend oil output cuts until the end of 2018.

site_title: Western European car sales rise 5.4% despite UK woes
summary: Western European car sales rose 5.4% in November to 1.144 million, with France and Germany driving the increase, while the UK market declined 11.2% amid Brexit uncertainty. The region's sales are expected to rise 2.7% this year and 0.8% in 2018, contrasting with the UK's predicted 5.8% decline and 5.1% drop in 2018.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific reverses into the red in Q2 on weak veggie business
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$2.82 million in Q2 due to one-off expenses related to its underperforming vegetable business, including shutting production facilities in Arkansas and Indiana. Excluding these items, net profit stood at US$10.2 million, down 50.8% from the prior year period. Sales fell 1.8% to US$625 million, mainly driven by lower sales in the US.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens lower as tech selloff continues
summary: The Nasdaq Composite index opened lower on Tuesday, following a second day of tech selloff, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 54.91 points. The S&P 500 lost 0.02 points. Investors sought stocks that would benefit from potential corporate tax cuts, driving the Dow higher. The Nasdaq's decline was attributed to the tech sector's selloff, with the index dropping 18.40 points.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite index opened lower on Tuesday as selloff in tech stocks continued for the second day, while the Dow was higher as investors looked to profit from stocks that would benefit more from potential corporate tax cuts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.71 points to 1,724.84 on Tuesday, closing higher. The index saw a trading volume of 1.8 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 624 to 298.

site_title: Erdogan says he'd cut Israel ties if Trump acts on Jerusalem
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan threatened to cut ties with Israel if US President Donald Trump recognizes Jerusalem as its capital, citing it as a "red line" for Muslims. Erdogan's statement came after Trump was expected to decide whether to renew a waiver allowing the US embassy to remain in Tel Aviv. The move has sparked concerns from Muslim-majority nations, including Saudi Arabia and France, and has been met with criticism from Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, who has called for demonstrations across the West Bank and Arab world.

site_title: Pavilion Energy CEO Seah Moon Ming steps down to focus on SMRT role
summary: Pavilion Energy CEO Seah Moon Ming is stepping down to focus on his role as chairman of SMRT Corp. Effective February 1, Frederic Barnaud, currently employed by Gazprom Marketing and Trading, will take over as CEO. Seah had indicated his desire to devote more time to SMRT's chairman role, which he was appointed to in July.

site_title: Greek banks beat target in push to shrink bad loan mountain
summary: Greek banks made progress in reducing their exposure to doubtful and non-performing loans, with non-performing exposures (NPEs) falling by 1 billion euros to 104.8 billion euros at the end of December, meeting a target of 50.5% of banks' overall loan book. NPEs comprise non-performing loans and restructured loans, and their reduction is expected to free up capital for productive sectors of the economy. The reduction in NPEs is part of a plan to shrink them by 38% to 66.7 billion by end-2019.

site_title: Equities rally piles on wealth for Indonesia's richest
summary: Indonesia's 50 richest individuals saw their collective wealth surge by 25% year-over-year to $126 billion, according to Forbes Indonesia's annual list. The surge was largely driven by the country's tax amnesty, which uncovered $479 billion in previously hidden assets. Many of the top 10 richest Indonesians saw significant gains, with the Riady family's fortune increasing to $3 billion and the Hartono family's nearly doubling to $32 billion. The country's reliance on royalties from mining companies contributes to its lower tax take, with only 11% of GDP going towards personal income.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina targets higher crude output as fuel price rise eyed
summary: Indonesia's state oil company Pertamina plans to increase crude oil production by nearly 20% to 400,000 barrels per day in 2018, and natural gas output by 52% to 3,069 million cubic feet per day. The company also aims to raise upstream capital expenditure by 21% to US$3.32 billion. Pertamina seeks fuel price adjustments following a sharp increase in crude oil prices, but the government has held prices below market levels due to fuel subsidies.

site_title: BMW guns for a 50% increase in 2018 electric vehicle sales
summary: BMW aims to increase plug-in hybrid and battery car sales by 50% in 2018 to 150,000 units, a significant rise from this year. The company targets mid-double-digit sales growth to stay ahead of competitors like Mercedes-Benz and Volkswagen. To achieve this, BMW will launch new models, including the X7 SUV and 8-Series coupe, priced at around $159,937. The company also plans to expand its luxury segment and introduce a suite of 12 all-electric cars by 2025, with the goal of taking more market share.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to sell Malaysia property for S$9.2m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust plans to sell a property in Malaysia for approximately S$9.2 million. The 11,494 sq m air-conditioned warehouse and annexed office building is located in the Senai Industrial Estate in Johor. The sale is part of the trust's efforts to diversify its portfolio and optimize its asset utilization.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat; STI down 0.4 points
summary: Singapore's stock market closed flat on Tuesday, with the STI down 0.4 points to finish at 3,438.06. Trading volume was 1.7 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion. Losers outpaced gainers, with 175 counters up and 286 counters down.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Ossia International, BH Global put on SGX watch-list
summary: Ossia International and BH Global Corporation have been placed on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list, effective December 5, 2017. The move is due to Ossia's consecutive pre-tax losses and low market capitalization, while BH Global failed to meet the minimum trading price entry criteria. To avoid delisting, both companies must meet the requirements within 36 months, including maintaining a volume-weighted average price of at least S$0.20 and recording volume of at least S$0.20 over the last six months.

site_title: Deutsche asset management unit to rebrand to DWS, plans KGaA structure
summary: Deutsche Bank is planning to rebrand its asset management arm to DWS ahead of its stock market flotation. The unit will assume a partnership limited by shares structure in Q1 2018, ensuring Deutsche Bank retains control, even if its shareholding falls below 75%. The goal is to achieve management fee margins of over 30 basis points and a dividend payout ratio of 65-75%. This move comes as the bank seeks to recover from costly lawsuits and trading scandals.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp gets union ultimatum on jobs, plants in Tata merger
summary: Germany's biggest union, IG Metall, has given Thyssenkrupp until December 22 to guarantee jobs and investments in a joint venture with Tata Steel. The union submitted a 10-point catalog of demands, including assurances that Tata won't flood the European market with steel. The proposed merger aims to create the region's second-largest steel producer and tackle industry overcapacity, potentially resulting in 4,000 job losses.

images.alt_text: Germany's biggest union has given Thyssenkrupp until Dec 22 to guarantee jobs and investments before the labour group will give its blessing to a joint venture with Tata Steel.

site_title: "Smart bags" may not fly if battery cannot be removed
summary: Global airlines body Iata may issue industry-wide standards on "smart suitcases" due to concerns over lithium ion battery fire risks. Some US airlines, including American Airlines, Delta, and Alaska Airlines, have already restricted the use of these bags, requiring the battery to be removed before boarding. Manufacturers, such as Away and Raden, claim their batteries can be easily removed. Iata's Nick Careen expects guidance to be issued this week, potentially setting a precedent for other airlines to follow.

site_title: Singapore, China deepen bilateral economic ties at IPC meeting in Beijing
summary: Singapore and China have strengthened their economic ties, with both countries committing to deepen investment and cooperation. The Investment Promotion Committee meeting in Beijing saw the affirmation of bilateral economic ties, including cooperation in government projects and growing investments by Singapore companies in China. China expressed interest in supporting the internationalization of Chinese companies under the Belt and Road initiative, and negotiations on an upgrade of the China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement are ongoing, with a goal of completion by next year.

site_title: SGX, partners launch guide to help firms prevent insider trading
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a guide to help firms prevent insider trading, in partnership with several industry organizations. The guide provides recommended principles and guidelines to retain control over confidential information, restrict staff dealings, and create a culture of compliance. It includes areas such as confidential information handling, trading restrictions, and awareness promotion. The guide is non-prescriptive and customizable to each company's unique profile, aiming to deter insider trading through a preemptive approach. Industry stakeholders have welcomed the move, citing its potential to enhance trust and safeguard organizational interests.

site_title: Qatar says 2018 budget will focus on resisting economic boycott
summary: Qatar's 2018 state budget will focus on developing local industries and the private sector as the country works to make itself self-sufficient in the face of an economic boycott by other Arab states. Finance Minister Ali Sherif al-Emadi stated that the economy has escaped serious damage, but Qatar is determined to avoid being vulnerable again. The government plans to use subsidies to boost growth, make the business environment more competitive, and attract foreign capital, with a focus on dairy and poultry farming. Qatar's sovereign wealth fund may not sell assets to raise cash, and the government expects to raise $9 billion through international bond issuance in 2018.

site_title: Apple, Facebook find something to praise China for amid internet clamp
summary: Top executives from Apple and Facebook praised China's efforts to open up its internet at a conference in Wuzhen, despite the country's strict censorship and data storage rules. Apple CEO Tim Cook and Facebook vice president Vaughan Smith commended China's leadership on data management, citing government bodies such as the Cyberspace Administration of China. The conference, attended by high-ranking officials from US tech firms, aimed to promote a digital economy for openness and shared benefits. Despite concerns about propaganda and censorship, the event saw diplomatic efforts, with neither Smith nor Cook addressing issues of regulation or online criticism of the government.

site_title: Indonesia plans to acquire Rio Tinto interest in Freeport Indonesia mine
summary: Indonesia plans to acquire Rio Tinto's 40% participating interest in the Grasberg copper mine, operated by Freeport-McMoRan, under a framework agreement announced in August. The Indonesian government aims to complete the acquisition in 2018, along with buying a 51% stake in Freeport Indonesia and a 9.36% stake held by PT Indocopper Investama. The move is expected to give Indonesia control over the mine, with the government expecting a written agreement and new fiscal terms in a special mining permit in the near-term.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to acquire Rio Tinto's 40 per cent participating interest in the giant Grasberg copper mine operated by the local unit of Freeport-McMoRan, the mining minister said.

site_title: Talent acquisition the biggest hurdle for Asian tech companies: survey
summary: Asian tech companies face significant challenges in acquiring and retaining talent, with 40% citing retention as the top challenge. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) can help enhance productivity and augment the workplace. Millennials dominate the workforce, with 66% of companies having them as the top or joint top employee age group. Prime office locations near central business districts (CBDs) are essential to access talent pools, particularly for internet and IT experts. India, China, and Japan have the greatest growth potential in the next 10 years, with China and India being key markets for technology groups.

site_title: Kobe Steel's Chofu aluminium plant loses JIS certification
summary: Kobe Steel's Chofu aluminium plant has lost JIS certification due to falsified specifications in products supplied to major customers, including cars, planes, and trains. This is the latest blow to the embattled steelmaker, which has already had certifications revoked for copper products at another plant. Approximately 500 customers have received products with falsified specifications, contributing to one of Japan's biggest industrial scandals.

site_title: Delong expects revenue hit from prolonged halt in production
summary: DELONG Holdings, a Chinese steel manufacturer, expects a revenue hit due to the shutdown of two blast furnaces at its subsidiary. The shutdown, which began on Dec 1, 2017, is expected to continue until March 31, 2018, resulting in a 696 million yuan (S$141 million) revenue reduction in 2017 and 1.49 billion yuan in 2018. This production halt will impact Delong Steel's annual production capacity of 920,000 tonnes.

site_title: ECB QE data offers further incentive to snap-up Italian bonds
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) data showed favoritism towards Italy and France, with investors demanding lower premiums for holding Italian bonds compared to German peers. The ECB bought fewer German bonds than needed, while France and Italy received nearly a billion euros above their 'capital key'. This data suggests the ECB is front-loading purchases ahead of the year-end period, providing support for eurozone government bonds, particularly Italian and French ones. The premium gap between Italian and German bond yields narrowed to 137 basis points, its lowest since October 2016.

site_title: HNA is said to be probed over Deutsche Bank stake reporting
summary: Deutsche Bank's largest shareholder, HNA Group, is being probed in Germany over whether it accurately reported its stake in the bank. Financial supervisor BaFin is investigating HNA's voting rights communications, following a capital increase in April that made HNA the top investor. The probe comes amid concerns over HNA's sources of funding and ownership structure, which have led some Wall Street banks to shun the investor. The European Central Bank is also considering an owner control procedure against HNA, which could impact its reliability as a shareholder.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks sink on tech sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined on Tuesday, mirroring a sell-off in the tech sector on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.01% to 28,842.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.18% to 3,303.68. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.89% to 1,866.98. The decline was largely due to a sharp drop in the Nasdaq, which left it sharply lower.

site_title: UK's Cineworld to buy US Regal Entertainment for US$3.6 bln
summary: Britain's Cineworld Group Plc has agreed to buy US movie theatre operator Regal Entertainment Group for $3.6 billion in cash. The deal aims to strengthen Cineworld's position against US industry leader AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc and compete with growing competition from digital outlets. The combined company is expected to deliver pretax benefits of $100 million and additional annual benefits of $50 million. Cineworld plans to fund the deal through a rights issue and committed debt facilities. The acquisition is currently expected to close in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: Tokyo stocks end down as tech firms track US losses
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.37% on Tuesday, closing at 22,622.38, as investors tracked a selloff in US technology firms. The broader Topix index rose 0.23%. The decline was attributed to the worsening overall sentiment due to the high-tech selloff.

site_title: Dalian Wanda sold major China ski resort in June: report
summary: Dalian Wanda Group sold its Changbaishan International Resort in northern China to Dalian Yifang Group in June, reportedly as part of the conglomerate's efforts to scale back large debt-fuelled acquisitions. The resort, valued at US$3 billion, was Wanda's first tourism project and largest ski resort. Wanda retained management and operational rights, and the sale follows several other asset sales by the group this year. The move is seen as a response to Beijing's crackdown on large debt-fuelled acquisitions overseas.

site_title: SembMarine signs letter of intent with Shell for floating production unit
summary: SEMBCORP Marine signed a letter of intent with Shell Offshore Inc to build the hull and topside of Shell's Vito floating production unit. The unit, with a capacity of 100,000 barrels of oil per day, will be located in the Mississippi Canyon, US, and will be integrated by SEMBCORP Marine. The deal is dependent on Shell sanctioning the project, and is expected to have minimal impact on SEMBCORP Marine's net tangible assets and earnings.

site_title: McDonald's new 'dollar' menu to intensify fast-food price war in 2018
summary: McDonald's plans to introduce new "dollar" menus with US$1, US$2, and US$3 items in early January to intensify the fast-food price war. The move comes after the company dropped its "Dollar Menu" in 2013, and will include items like cheeseburgers, soft drinks, and Happy Meals. The goal is to protect franchisee margins while offering value to customers, a strategy that has contributed to McDonald's recent US recovery.

site_title: Two Airbnb hosts in Singapore charged over illegal home-sharing in first case under new laws
summary: Two Singaporean men, Terence Tan En Wei and Yao Songliang, have been charged with illegal home-sharing under new laws. They allegedly rented out four units at Leedon Heights condominium on Airbnb without permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority for under six months. The charges carry fines of up to $200,000 and up to one year in jail. This is the first case under the new regulations, which were introduced on May 15.

site_title: Falcon's attack strategy could inspire new drones: study
summary: Researchers studying peregrine falcons' attack strategies found that their trajectories do not follow geometric rules, but instead use visual guidance to line up with a moving target. This approach, similar to proportional navigation used by guided missiles, could inspire the development of small drones to safely remove rogue drones from no-fly zones. The study, funded by the US Air Force Research Laboratory, aims to design visually guided drones that can adapt to the falcons' attack strategy, offering a solution to the growing problem of drone interference in protected airspace.

site_title: Philippines aims to issue permit for US$2b LNG facility in 2018
summary: The Philippines plans to award a permit for a US$2 billion liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility by 2018, aiming to replace depleting local gas reserves. State-owned Philippine National Oil Company (PNOC) will hold a minimum 10% stake in the project, with dozens of domestic and foreign companies, including China, Japan, and South Korea, interested in participating.
