This bias is evident in everyday choices, such as buying generic products or trying new restaurants, as well as in professional settings like hiring and policymaking. Experimentation is often hindered by overconfidence and the tendency to prioritize immediate comfort over future benefits. Breaking this habit requires acknowledging the limitations of current knowledge and being willing to take calculated risks.

site_title: Catwalk goes online with 'first ever' runway auction
summary: A California auction house, GWS Auctions, hosted the "first ever" online runway fashion show auction in Beverly Hills, featuring a vast collection of Chanel-labelled fashion and accessories worth over $25 million. The collection, consisting of 225 pieces, including 139 Chanel items, was from a former honorary consul of Liechtenstein and included items formerly owned by Elizabeth Taylor, such as a ring valued between $20,000 and $40,000. The auction was streamed online, allowing bidders worldwide to participate, marking a modern take on the traditional auction format.

site_title: Turnbull flags personal tax cuts before 2019 election
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull aims to introduce personal income tax cuts before the 2019 federal election, contingent on the government maintaining a budget surplus by 2021. The planned cuts are part of efforts to trim corporate tax rates and boost wages, which remain stagnant. Turnbull stated that the government can reduce both business and personal taxes, but the exact timing will depend on budgetary circumstances. The government has already proposed reducing the corporate tax rate from 30% to 25% by 2026-27.

site_title: Equity market has further room to rise until yield curve inverts
summary: The 2s10s spread, a proxy for the yield curve, has fallen to 0.57% as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates, signaling a potential recession. Historically, when the spread falls below zero, the yield curve inverts, leading to market panic and anaemic growth. A negative spread can also lead to liquidity shortages and exacerbate market selloffs. Based on past data, the 2s10s spread is expected to drop to zero in 34 weeks, suggesting the equity market has room to rise until then.

site_title: Greenback drops on Flynn report
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.15% against a basket of currencies after a report suggested former adviser Michael Flynn was prepared to testify that President Donald Trump directed him to make contact with Russians during the presidential campaign. This news sparked concerns about the administration's involvement in the investigation. Meanwhile, US Senate Republicans gathered the votes needed to pass a tax overhaul bill, causing the dollar to reverse course sharply. The euro remained weaker against the dollar, while the Canadian dollar posted its biggest gain in about 20 months against its US counterpart.

site_title: Nissan seeks payments from India for unmet tax-break promise
summary: Nissan Motor Co is seeking $770 million in payments and damages from the Indian government for unmet tax breaks promised after the company set up a factory in the country. The move comes despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to improve India's image among foreign investors. Nissan has started international arbitration against the government and has invested over $938 million in the factory, which has created over 40,000 jobs. The dispute raises concerns about India's business-friendly environment and its ability to attract foreign investment.

site_title: Sweeping US tax reform package draws mixed reactions
summary: The US Senate passed a sweeping tax reform package with a 51-49 vote, reducing corporate tax rates from 35 to 20% and increasing some individual deductions while eliminating others. The bill aims to spur growth, increase wages, and encourage companies to repatriate profits. However, economists are divided on the package's impact, with some arguing it will boost productivity and others claiming it will balloon the national debt and primarily benefit the wealthy. The bill now needs reconciliation with the House of Representatives before being sent to President Trump for signature.

site_title: Vard Holdings secures S$113.6m worth of Icelandic contracts
summary: Vard Holdings has secured S$113.6 million worth of contracts from Icelandic shipowners to design and construct seven stern trawlers. The contracts, valued at 700 million Norwegian Krones, will be constructed and outfitted by Vard Aukra in Norway for deliveries in 2019. The vessels will be designed for more efficient fishing operations in Iceland, marking a new concept development by Vard Holdings and the Icelandic parties.

site_title: Always on the lookout for the next big thing
summary: JK Tech Group, founded by chairman Lennon Tan, is expanding into the Asean region and moving up the value chain. The company, which started in China, moved its headquarters to Singapore after China's growth rate slowed down. Tan, who won the EY Entrepreneur of the Year award in 2017, believes in diversifying into new markets and investing in research and development. JK Tech is now involved in fintech smart cards business process outsourcing and automated solution services, aiming to improve people's quality of life through technology.

images.alt_text: "We didn't want to put all our eggs in only one basket and looked into expanding into the Asean market. Asean is a mix of different economies, making it interesting for us to grow in the markets there," says Mr Tan.

site_title: Internet must have security, humanity, Apple CEO tells China
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook emphasized the need for future internet and AI technologies to prioritize privacy, security, and humanity during his keynote speech at China's World Internet Conference. Cook acknowledged the importance of China as a major market for Apple but also expressed concerns about the country's efforts to control the internet. He called for technology to be infused with humanity, values, and safeguards to protect users. Cook's comments come at a pivotal point for Apple's future in China, where it relies heavily on the country's market for revenue and profit growth.

site_title: When bitcoin meets conservative, relatively speaking
summary: A bitcoin-focused hedge fund, BitSpread, is gaining interest from Asian family offices seeking conservative bitcoin exposure. The fund, run by BitSpread's CEO Cedric Jeanson, aims to offer a market-neutral strategy, distinct from other cryptocurrency funds that bet on the asset's direction. With assets estimated at US$40 million, the fund expects to double to US$80 million by the end of the year and approach US$200 million in six months. Jeanson notes that family offices are willing to invest 2% of their portfolio in bitcoin, and the fund's conservative approach is attracting demand from traditional institutions.

site_title: Not cheap if you buy with bitcoin in New York
summary: A New York bakery, Melt, is now accepting bitcoin as a payment method for its ice cream sandwiches. While the novelty comes at a cost, several other US stores are also embracing the cryptocurrency. The move is seen as a step towards bitcoin's potential as a widely accepted form of currency.

site_title: Diversification, the Midas curse
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singaporean company that produces aluminium products and train car bodies, is facing significant financial struggles. The company's shares have plummeted to a historic low of S$0.14, and its debt and receivables have increased by over 400% and 500% respectively. Despite investing billions of yuan in diversifying revenue sources, the company's profits have failed to recover, and its working capital statistics show a significant decline. The company's diversification attempts, including the acquisition of Huicheng, a Chinese aluminium products manufacturer, have not yielded the expected results, and investors are now questioning the company's future prospects.

site_title: Dublin holds key to Brexit talks breakthrough: EU's Tusk
summary: EU President Donald Tusk stated that the European Union will not accept Britain's Brexit offer if Ireland is not satisfied with proposals for future border arrangements. Tusk met with Ireland Prime Minister Leo Varadkar, emphasizing the need for British guarantees that there will be no hard border between Ireland and British-controlled Northern Ireland after Brexit. The EU wants to hear British proposals by Monday, and a breakthrough in talks is seen as crucial for advancing the Brexit process.

site_title: Leading patron of art UOB steadfast in support of social development
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is a leading patron of art, supporting social development through its corporate giving initiatives. As a Patron of the Arts, UOB has run the UOB Painting of the Year (POY) Competition for 36 years, promoting local artistic talent and championing South-east Asian art. The bank also partners with schools and charities to encourage children's interest in art and makes financial literacy accessible to under-served communities. UOB's commitment to social development is reflected in its extensive volunteer work and community initiatives.

site_title: US automakers report mixed sales for November
summary: US auto sales in November showed mixed results, with Ford reporting a 6.7% increase, Honda and Nissan posting strong sales increases, and Toyota seeing a 2.3% rise in light trucks. However, GM and Fiat Chrysler posted declines, with GM's sales falling 2.9% and FCA's dropping 4%. Analysts say the varied results may indicate that US demand for autos has peaked, with average prices reaching an all-time high of $35,870.

site_title: Sports Hub a massive project that 'cannot fail': Oon Jin Teik
summary: Singapore Sports Hub CEO Oon Jin Teik remains optimistic about the project's long-term success, despite early teething problems and negative publicity. He has been instrumental in the project's development since its conception a decade ago and has a deep understanding of its complexities. The Sports Hub has secured major contracts with the Women's Tennis Association and the International Champions Cup, and has hosted numerous high-profile events, including concerts by Coldplay and Britney Spears. Oon is committed to ensuring the project's success, but has declined to discuss his long-term position as CEO.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mr Oon makes it clear that, so long as he is in charge, he would do all he can to ensure the Sports Hub continues to thrive.

site_title: India's Infosys taps Capgemini exec Parekh as CEO
summary: Infosys, India's No 2 IT services company, has named Salil Parekh as its new CEO, effective January 2, 2018. Parekh, a former Capgemini executive, has been tasked with reviving growth and resolving a public spat between the company's founders and board. Parekh joins with a 5-year term and will oversee the departure of interim CEO UB Pravin Rao, who is re-designated as chief operating officer. Parekh brings nearly three decades of global IT experience and a strong track record of executing business turnarounds.

site_title: China cracks down on online micro-lending firms with new rules
summary: China's financial regulators have introduced new rules to crack down on online micro-lenders, aiming to rein in the rapidly growing financial sector. The rules prohibit unlicensed organizations and individuals from conducting lending businesses, and restrict lending to borrowers with no income or misleading consumers. The regulations also limit interest rates, debt collection, and data protection, with maximum allowed annualized interest rates of 36%. The move is part of a campaign to address risks in internet finance, including over-lending, repeat borrowing, and privacy violations.

site_title: North Korea holds mass celebrations for latest missile test
summary: North Korea held mass celebrations for its latest successful long-range missile test, with thousands of soldiers and civilians applauding in Pyongyang's Kim Il-Sung square. The celebration featured fireworks and propaganda-filled displays, with banners proclaiming the country's "power and greatness" to the world. The successful test launch of the Hwasong-15 missile was seen as a demonstration of North Korea's capabilities, further escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Venezuela political two-day talks end without deal; new meeting on Dec 15
summary: Venezuela's government and opposition coalition failed to reach a deal in a two-day talks session in the Dominican Republic. The talks aimed to resolve the country's protracted political crisis, but both sides remain at odds. A new meeting is planned for December 15. Mediation efforts have previously failed, with President Nicolas Maduro accusing the opposition of preferring violence and the opposition accusing Maduro of buying time.

site_title: Saudi retailer Jarir expects moderate growth in 2018
summary: Saudi retailer Jarir Marketing Co expects single-digit growth in sales in 2018, following a double-digit pace in 2017. The company's chairman attributes the growth to taking market share from smaller rivals, who struggled to absorb the financial impact of government regulations requiring retailers to hire Saudi citizens instead of foreigners. Jarir plans to expand its store network and hire 400 people, including 300 Saudis, despite a conservative outlook due to the introduction of a 5% value-added tax in Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries.

site_title: Paying with bitcoin comes at hefty cost; use still far from widespread
summary: Paying with bitcoin is becoming more accessible, with AT Melt Bakery in New York allowing customers to use the digital currency. However, the process still comes with a hefty cost. Industry insiders view bitcoin as an alternative financial instrument for those without access to traditional services. The novelty of using bitcoin for everyday transactions is still limited, but its potential to expand financial inclusion is being explored.

site_title: Golf: Woods in hunt as Hoffman romps
summary: Tiger Woods fired a four-under-par 68 at the Hero World Challenge in the Bahamas, remaining in contention in his comeback event. The 41-year-old superstar vaulted up the leaderboard with a blistering front nine, going eight-under for the tournament. Woods' performance marked a strong start to his comeback, with 14-time major champion continuing to show signs of his former dominance.

site_title: Sports Hub remains open to hosting National Day Parades
summary: The Singapore Sports Hub's acting CEO, Oon Jin Teik, supports the decision to host the National Day Parade (NDP) on the Marina Bay floating platform, calling it a plus for Singapore. The platform, renamed "NS Square," can seat up to 30,000 people and commemorates National Service. Oon expressed openness to the possibility of the NDP returning to the Sports Hub in the future, stating that both venues are world-class and can compete in hosting events.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report from December 3, 2017, discusses the tanker and dry bulk market. VLCCs (Very Large Crude Carriers) were fixed at WS 57.5 for China discharge and WS 56.5 for Singapore. A 2001-built tonnage was agreed at WS 48 to South Korea, based on 270,000 tonnes cargo. Meanwhile, the market in the US Gulf was boosted by a Koch deal for the Boston, priced at WS 26.5. These prices indicate a complex market with varying demand and supply pressures.

site_title: American Air reaches deal with pilots over scheduling error
summary: American Airlines has reached an agreement with its pilots union, the Allied Pilots Association, over premium pay for December flights following a scheduling error that resulted in too many pilots receiving holiday time off. The airline offered 150% of hourly pay to cover flights, but the union complained of contract restrictions. The deal will allow American to maintain its full December schedule, with only a few hundred flights remaining unstaffed. The agreement comes amid rising labor costs for airlines, following a mid-contract pay increase earlier this year.

site_title: Pope Francis wraps up Asia tour after meeting Rohingya
summary: Pope Francis concluded his Asia tour after meeting Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh, a symbolic gesture of solidarity with the persecuted Muslim minority. The Pope addressed the issue directly in Bangladesh, referring to the refugees as "Rohingya" and seeking their forgiveness. Despite walking a diplomatic tightrope in Myanmar, the Pope expressed support for the Rohingya and appealed to Buddhist leaders to overcome prejudice and hatred. The visit marked a significant moment in the Pope's efforts to champion the rights of refugees.

site_title: Russia breathe sigh of relief after drawing 'ideal' World Cup group
summary: Russia avoided a potentially disastrous draw in the World Cup, being paired with Saudi Arabia and Egypt for the final round. The draw, which was considered "ideal" by the Russian government, could give Russia a favorable path to the knockout stage. The team will face Uruguay in the next round, led by Luis Suarez and Edinson Cavani, but is expected to have an easier start against Saudi Arabia. Russia has not advanced beyond the first round in three World Cup appearances since the Soviet Union's breakup in 1991, and coach Stanislav Cherchesov is under pressure to repeat Russia's dream run at Euro 2008.

images.alt_text: Russia breathed a collective sigh of relief on Friday after avoiding Spain and looking like favourites to make it out of their group in their first home World Cup.

site_title: Netflix renews 'Stranger Things' for third season
summary: Netflix has renewed 'Stranger Things' for its third season, with no release date announced. The popular 1980s-set supernatural drama has gained critical acclaim and instant fame, attracting 15.8 million viewers within the first three days of its second season's launch. The show has won five primetime Emmy Awards and earned 18 nominations, including one for breakout star Millie Bobby Brown. The renewal comes after the show's success in its first two seasons, solidifying its position as one of the most popular television shows in the United States.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as tax cut progress limits Flynn worries
summary: US stocks closed the week with a decline, dropping 0.2% after former White House National Security Advisor Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI, raising concerns about potential collusion with Russia. However, the Dow Jones Industrial Average recovered from session lows as Senate Republicans near passage of a massive tax cut, boosting investor confidence. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, but still ended above session lows. The tax cut concessions appear to have alleviated concerns, with investors optimistic about the bill's passage.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare enters into sub-lease deal with Healthway Medical Corporation
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare has entered into a sub-lease deal with Healthway Medical Corporation, agreeing to sub-lease office premises at OUE Downtown 2 for a 36-month period starting August 1, 2017, and expiring July 2020. The sub-lease agreement, worth approximately S$653,107, is below 3% of the company's latest audited net tangible assets value. The original lease was set to expire in July 2018, and both parties have agreed to end the lease early without penalties.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 feedback welcomed
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance is seeking public feedback on the 2018 budget, inviting individuals, households, and businesses to provide input on various issues. The feedback can be submitted through the ministry's website, www.singaporebudget.gov.sg. The public is encouraged to share their thoughts on how to support Singaporeans, promote business competitiveness, and plan for future needs. The feedback will be used to inform the budget-making process.

site_title: SingPost revises rates for global delivery of small packages
summary: SingPost is revising its rates for international delivery of small packages starting January 2, 2018, due to new rates set by the Universal Postal Union (UPU). The changes include a maximum increase of S$3.40 per item or S$1.10 in savings, depending on destination and item weight. The UPU introduced the new rate structure to reflect rising e-commerce volumes and higher delivery costs. SingPost expects the changes to have minimal impact on its business, as international small packets currently make up a small portion of its volumes.

site_title: Cookie Alert
summary: Yoku Moku, a Japanese cookie maker, will open its Singapore flagship store in ION Orchard in January. The company, founded by Noriichi Fujinawa, is known for its buttery thin sable cookies and cigar rolls. Two pop-up stores are currently running in ION Orchard and Takashimaya until the end of the month. Yoku Moku's name is inspired by a small town in Sweden, Jokkmokk, where Fujinawa was influenced by the strong sense of community and hospitality among the indigenous Sami people.

site_title: Three Uber security managers resign after CEO criticises practices
summary: Three senior security managers at Uber Technologies Inc. have resigned amid criticism of past security practices, following the company's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, disclosing a massive data breach that compromised 57 million customers' data in 2016. The resignations come after the firing of Uber's former chief security officer, Joe Sullivan, and amid mounting frustration within the security team over the company's handling of the breach. The departures include most of Sullivan's direct reports and follow a high-stakes legal battle with self-driving car company Waymo.

site_title: European stocks sink on Flynn guilty plea after choppy session
summary: European stocks plummeted on December 1, 2017, after US national security adviser Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI, sparking concerns about President Donald Trump's ability to implement tax cuts or survive the political storm. The euro and pound rose, hurting stocks, while oil and gas sectors saw gains. Healthcare and telecom stocks also outperformed, while the tech sector fell due to investor anxiety. European indices fell 0.36% and 1.06%, respectively.

site_title: Exxon merging oil refining and marketing units
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is merging its refining and marketing divisions to boost profits from its downstream businesses. The merger, set to take place in the first quarter, will be overseen by a new company, ExxonMobil Fuels & Lubricants Co. Neil Chapman, head of global chemicals operations, has been named to Exxon's management committee. The move aims to squeeze more profits from the fuel and lubricant businesses, which have grown in prominence since Darren Woods took over as CEO in January. Exxon is investing $20 billion in its refining division through 2022.

site_title: Oil settles up but off highs as Flynn news spooks Wall St
summary: Oil prices settled up slightly, with Brent crude reaching $63.73 a barrel, but pared gains after Wall Street stocks slid following a report that former national security adviser Michael Flynn was prepared to tell investigators that President Trump directed him to make contact with Russians. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.7% to $58.36 a barrel, despite earlier gains approaching 2015 highs. The news spooked markets, with crude prices down for the week, amid concerns about the impact of US shale production on global supplies.

site_title: Disney opens first toy store in Russia
summary: Disney has opened its first toy store in Russia, occupying around 300 square meters in a central Moscow children's department store. The move is part of a plan to open at least five more stores in the country, with partnerships with local manufacturers to keep prices competitive. The stores will only sell Disney, Star Wars, and Marvel toys, with no clothing or decor available. Three more stores are planned for Moscow, St Petersburg, and Russia's south, with a focus on deepening the brand's presence in the underserved Russian toy market.

site_title: IPO funds raised this year double that of 2016
summary: Singapore's initial public offerings (IPOs) raised S$4.6 billion in the first 11 months of 2017, doubling the S$2.3 billion raised in 2016. This marks a significant increase in IPO funds raised, with 19 IPOs contributing to the total. The surge in IPO funds is attributed to a strong market, with the market capitalisation almost doubling that of the previous year.

site_title: Let It Snow!
summary: Club Med's Tomamu resort in Hokkaido, Japan, offers 29 ski runs for all levels, along with mountain biking, trekking, and sledding. Guests can also relax at the resort's indoor wave pool, Mina Mina Beach, which maintains a consistent water temperature of 30 degrees regardless of the weather. The resort is located 90 minutes from New Chitose Airport and is Club Med's second property in Hokkaido, following Sahoro.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: US Senate Republicans trim tax bill to secure needed votes
summary: US Senate Republicans have passed a tax overhaul bill after several key changes secured votes from moderate senators. The bill, which aims to lower corporate and individual tax rates, now has the necessary votes to pass. The bill's passage is seen as crucial to Republican hopes of retaining control of Congress in the 2018 elections. The bill's final details, including a proposed 20% corporate income tax rate, remain unclear. The bill will now be sent to the White House for President Donald Trump's signature, with talks with the House of Representatives expected next week.

site_title: US dollar slumps on report ex-adviser Flynn to testify against Trump
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.15% against a basket of currencies on Friday after reports that former adviser Michael Flynn was prepared to testify that President Donald Trump directed him to make contact with Russians as a presidential candidate. This development raised concerns about the administration's involvement in the investigation and led to a sharp reversal in the dollar's upward trend. Despite this, US Senate Republicans gathered the votes needed to pass a sweeping tax overhaul bill, which had previously supported the dollar's rise. The euro and Canadian dollar also saw fluctuations, with the euro down 0.09% and the Canadian dollar posting its biggest gain in 20 months.

site_title: Cluny Hill bungalow sets record psf price for GCB area
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore's Cluny Hill area has been sold for S$35.5 million, setting a record price of S$2,350 per square foot (psf) based on land area. The 15,105 sq ft property, rebuilt in 2012, features 10 rooms and a pool, and has surpassed the previous record of S$2,190 psf set in 2015. The sale, made by a Singaporean in his mid-twenties, indicates a growing demand for GCB properties, with 37 transactions in GCB areas totaling S$767 million in the year to date.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Upgraded Singapore-Australia FTA takes effect
summary: Singapore and Australia have upgraded their free trade agreement, allowing Singaporean businesses to bid for Australian government contracts and reducing regulatory barriers for goods such as wine and medical devices. The agreement also provides greater facilitation for investments, improved mobility for business persons, and enhanced access to each other's services sectors. The upgraded agreement is expected to boost bilateral trade, with Singapore and Australia's trade reaching S$18.2 billion in 2016.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Billionaires are buying art by Laura Owens; will everyone else?
summary: Billionaires are increasingly lending their art collections to museums, including a midcareer retrospective of painter Laura Owens at the Whitney Museum. The show features works from notable collectors such as François Pinault, Mario Testino, and Maja Hoffmann, as well as lesser-known individuals. The trend highlights the growing influence of private collectors in the art world, with many seeking to showcase their collections in high-profile exhibitions. This shift may leave others wondering if they can afford to participate in the lucrative art market.

site_title: Broadcom said to be delaying higher Qualcomm bid to next year
summary: Broadcom is delaying its potential increase in its US$105 billion offer for Qualcomm Inc to next year, according to people familiar with the matter. Broadcom plans to nominate directors to Qualcomm's board ahead of a Dec 8 deadline. The company is currently leaning on a direct appeal to Qualcomm's shareholders, hoping to put pressure on the company to reconsider its stance. Broadcom's CEO Hock Tan is still seeking friendly engagement with Qualcomm's management and board, but investors are demanding a US$10 increase in the offer price.

site_title: Recent dealmaking driving Allied Tech shares
summary: Allied Technologies, a Catalist-listed firm, saw its shares hit a 5-year high of S$0.084 on Thursday due to recent dealmaking, sparking speculation about the company's expansion into new business areas. The stock was the most active on Friday with over 135 million shares changing hands.

site_title: High jewellery admirers today, clients tomorrow?
summary: Luxury jewellery houses are shifting their marketing strategies to target younger shoppers, as the luxury market is expected to grow 5% this year. To appeal to a new generation, high-end brands are showcasing their haute joaillerie collections in more accessible ways, such as free exhibitions and interactive displays. This approach aims to build brand equity and create a desirable image, while also introducing younger consumers to the world of luxury jewellery. By showcasing high-end pieces in a more approachable way, brands hope to groom the next generation of luxury shoppers.

site_title: Sci-fi literary act of resistance
summary: A collection of 15 short stories, "The Obama Inheritance: Fifteen Stories of Conspiracy Noir," takes aim at conspiracy theories surrounding the 45th US president, mirroring the right-wing delusions that surrounded the 44th president. Edited by Gary Phillips, the book features tales of talking dogs, space aliens, and flesh-eating lizard people, blending noir, pulp, and science fiction elements. The stories aim to address the current political climate, exploring themes of racism, Islamophobia, and greed, and serve as a "thrill ride of weirdo, noirish, pulpy goodness."

site_title: Forget Bitcoin, here are four stocks up more than 1,000% in 2017
summary: Four lesser-known stocks have seen their share prices surge at least 1,000% in 2017, matching Bitcoin's gravity-defying ascent. The stocks are: Pepper Food Service Co. (Japan), HEG Ltd. (India), Indiabulls Ventures Ltd. (India), and China Investment Fund (Hong Kong). These companies have seen significant growth in their respective markets, with some reaching market values of over $1 billion. Their stock prices have outperformed major cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, offering alternative investment opportunities for investors.

site_title: US warehouses get bigger, taller and faster
summary: US warehouse developers are investing record amounts in new, larger structures to meet the growing demand for e-commerce. These warehouses are being built bigger, taller, and faster to accommodate the increasing need for online shopping. The trend is driven by the rise of e-commerce and the use of robots in the logistics industry.

site_title: Flying High
summary: Luxury travel operators in Singapore are catering to affluent travelers seeking unique experiences. The definition of luxury has changed, with a focus on bespoke, transformative, and adventurous travel. The rise of luxury travel operators in Singapore is driven by the country's growing wealth, with Singaporeans having the highest average wealth per adult globally. Companies like Jacada Travel, Lightfoot Travel, and A2A Safaris/A2A Journeys offer exclusive experiences, such as private villas, yacht charters, and unique itineraries. The demand for luxury travel has led conventional tour operators to offer high-end options, with prices ranging from $2,775 to $500,000 per person. Emerging destinations like Ethiopia, New Zealand, and Poland are gaining popularity among luxury travelers.

site_title: What's in a brand? More than you think
summary: A brand's perception can significantly impact a company's success, influencing pricing, market share, and hiring decisions. Experts agree that strong brands enable companies to stand out, attract the right talent, and weather crises better. This is evident in the world's most valuable brands, which have successfully differentiated themselves from rivals over time. Effective branding is crucial for long-term success, allowing companies to navigate challenges such as tariffs and economic fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore to deepen business collaboration with Zhejiang: minister
summary: Singapore aims to deepen business collaboration with Zhejiang, China, through trade, e-commerce, professional services, and innovation, according to Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Sim Ann. Bilateral trade between the two regions grew 20% year-on-year to S$3.6 billion from January to September 2017. Collaborations will focus on the Zhejiang Free Trade Zone, cross-border e-commerce, and innovative projects, including partnerships with companies like Ninja Van and Venturecraft. Two memoranda of understanding were signed to support the Belt and Road Initiative, with Singapore firms partnering with Zhejiang companies to expand in the region.

site_title: Unique identifiers to curb manipulation on HK-China Stock Connect
summary: Hong Kong's Stock Connect programme, linking its exchanges to those in Shanghai and Shenzhen, is introducing unique identifiers for investors to curb manipulation. Starting from the third quarter of 2018, the program will align with mainland practice, giving regulators real-time access to investor identities. This move aims to address the issue of 1,900 mainland stocks being traded in Hong Kong, many of which have low market values and are potentially vulnerable to manipulation. The change is a response to the notorious example of Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd, which collapsed amid suspected manipulation.

site_title: Bitcoin interrupted in white-knuckled ride
summary: Bitcoin experienced a wild and volatile ride on Wednesday, with prices soaring past $11,000 before plummeting nearly 20% in under 90 minutes. The market outage in the US captivated Wall Street, and analysts warn that this could be one of the biggest bubbles in investing history. The cryptocurrency's price has more than doubled since September, leaving many to question whether the recent setback represents a brief correction or a more significant downturn. The market's volatility underscores the rapidly changing landscape of the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Your Apple watch may soon be able to warn you of a coming stroke
summary: A new wristband for the Apple Watch, KardiaBand, uses a neural network to predict and analyze the wearer's heart rate based on their history and cardiovascular data. The device can detect abnormal heart rhythms and prompt users to record their heart's electrical activity, potentially helping to prevent strokes. The KardiaBand, priced at $199, requires a $99 annual subscription. Apple has also launched its own research initiative, the Apple Heart Study app, to collect data on irregular heart rhythms and identify users at risk for stroke.

site_title: Central banks find post-crisis bubble tool helping to tame financial risks
summary: Central banks worldwide are finding success with macroprudential limits, tools used to curb financial risks and property price bubbles, in countries such as New Zealand, Canada, Australia, China, and Singapore. These measures have helped slow risky borrowing and temper housing market bubbles, giving central banks more flexibility to tighten monetary policy. While results vary, the tools have been shown to reduce vulnerabilities in the financial system and promote stronger growth in countries that frequently use them.

site_title: Japan emperor to abdicate on April 30, 2019
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito will abdicate on April 30, 2019, marking the first retirement in over two centuries. The decision was made after a special meeting of the Imperial Council, with Crown Prince Naruhito expected to ascend the throne the next day. Emperor Akihito, 83, cited age and health problems as reasons for his decision, following a nearly three-decade reign. This move will be the first abdication in Japan's imperial history in over 200 years.

site_title: S$142m in unclaimed prize money in last 3 years: S'pore Pools
summary: Singapore Pools reported that S$142 million in unclaimed prize money was left unclaimed in its last three financial years, with S$48 million unclaimed in the most recent year. This accounts for less than 1% of the total prize money paid out each year. Winners have 180 days to claim their prizes, and unclaimed sums will be channeled to the Tote Board, which donates funds to various causes. Experts suggest that some people may forget to check their tickets or buy prizes out of habit, leading to unclaimed prizes.

site_title: New Zealand examines Matt Lauer's ranch purchase after his firing
summary: New Zealand's Overseas Investment Office is reviewing Matt Lauer's 16,000-acre farm purchase due to his firing from the Today morning news show amid allegations of sexual harassment. Lauer's purchase was initially approved in February, but officials are seeking further information after NBC fired him. The agency can require buyers to dispose of the property if it believes the rules have been violated, and Lauer has not been charged with wrongdoing. The review comes as the country struggles with surging house prices and foreign buyers are scrutinized in an increasingly expensive market.

site_title: Art Close & Personal
summary: Local artists are offering unique Christmas gift ideas, including embroidered hoop portraits, personalized pet illustrations, and customizable artwork. Inez Tan creates embroidered portraits using photographs, while Melissa Tan paints pet illustrations on baubles. Natalie Kwee's Festive Folks offers customizable illustrations, and Carlyn Law creates artwork inspired by food and cooking. These artists offer affordable and personalized gift options, with prices starting from S$15 for Melissa Tan's pet illustrations and S$45 for Natalie Kwee's customizable artwork. Their unique gifts make for a thoughtful and personalized Christmas present.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Five takes from F1 season
summary: The 2017 Formula One season concluded with Mercedes securing both the drivers' and constructors' titles, with Lewis Hamilton winning his fourth championship. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel had a promising start but struggled with reliability issues and mental lapses, ultimately failing to challenge Mercedes. Other notable performances included Fernando Alonso's impressive drives despite a disappointing Honda engine, and Esteban Ocon's standout rookie season at Force India. The season marked the final of Felipe Massa's career and the iconic F1 logo, with Bernie Ecclestone's legacy coming to an end.

site_title: HMI appoints new independent director
summary: Health Management International Ltd (HMI) has appointed Chong Ton Nen, also known as Peter Chong, as a new independent non-executive director. The appointment was recommended by the nominating committee and approved by the company's board following a review of his qualifications and suitability. This comes after a letter from substantial shareholder Maju Medik (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd nominating Mr Chong for the role.

site_title: Singapore's alternative investment industry is alive and kicking
summary: Singapore's alternative investment industry continues to grow, with the hedge fund sector increasing by 16% to S$138 billion in assets under management. Private credit is a key area of growth, driven by rising investor demand. Institutions such as pensions and sovereign wealth funds are seeking diversification and downside protection, while private wealth managers are diversifying their investments in hedge funds, real estate, and other alternative investments. The industry is expected to continue evolving amid regulatory change, government support, and increased allocations from local and international investors.

site_title: Home Decor Emporium
summary: Weekend Pop-Up, a specialty home décor and lifestyle market, is set to open in Singapore on December 9th at The Spare Room @ The Fabulous Baker Boy Café. The bi-annual event features unique home décor items sourced and curated by local entrepreneurs, offering a variety of products including dinner plates, vases, and more. The market aims to provide a unique shopping experience for those looking for a Christmas gift or home decor items.

site_title: Singapore home loan rates start upward climb
summary: Three major Singaporean banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - have increased their home loan rates, with DBS and UOB raising rates by 10% a year on fixed-rate loans, now at 1.85% per annum. Mortgage advisers warn of further rate hikes, citing rising interest rates and tight liquidity conditions. The banks' floating-rate packages have also been adjusted, with DBS' floating-rate package now at 1.65% per annum. Experts advise home buyers to secure rates quickly due to potential future rate increases.

site_title: Fashion First
summary: Japanese fashion brand 45R, known for its high-quality, classic apparel, adopts a "materials first" approach by sourcing finest materials and hand-making each product. No two items are alike due to the thorough hands-on process. BTWeekend readers can enjoy a 10% discount and an exclusive denim bag with any purchase at Capitol Piazza, presenting a copy of the magazine or its digital version.

site_title: Bitcoin goes ballistic
summary: Bitcoin surged to US$11,000 mid-week, up 11 times since the beginning of the year, amid mainstream acceptance and planned trading operations by major US exchanges. Goldman Sachs is considering a trading operation, while the CME Group plans to launch a bitcoin futures contract by the end of the year. Nasdaq and broker Cantor Fitzgerald also plan to launch derivatives on Bitcoin in the first half of 2018, fueling the latest frenzy.

site_title: Picture Of The Past
summary: Local artist William Sim has contributed an exclusive heritage-themed drawing to BTWeekend's new colouring series. The illustration, titled "Tiong Bahru", captures his favorite memories of the neighborhood, featuring signature conservation flats, a dancing sculpture, and heritage elements like gem biscuits and an ice kachang machine. As a partner at visual arts studio Amphibios, Sim has showcased his work in various exhibitions in Singapore and beyond, and has also illustrated four books. His artwork is available for coloring and keepsake purposes, celebrating the unique charm of Tiong Bahru.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Keppel, partner win HK$31b deal for HK's 1st integrated waste management plant
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings and China Harbour Engineering Company have won a HK$31 billion contract to design, build, and operate Hong Kong's first integrated waste management facility. The project, through Keppel Seghers Hong Kong and Zhen Hua Engineering Co, will reinforce Keppel's lead in waste-to-energy technology. This marks a significant milestone for Hong Kong's waste management sector, with the integrated facility expected to play a crucial role in reducing the city's waste output.

site_title: Uncertainty looms at North Korean hub in China
summary: North Korean-owned businesses in China, particularly in the city of Shenyang, face uncertainty due to looming United Nations sanctions. The Chilbosan Hotel, North Korea's largest overseas investment, and North Korean restaurants and shops in the city's "Korea Town" are expected to be shut down in January. Local Chinese businessmen report a decline in North Korean shoppers and a reduction in Pyongyang-owned businesses due to growing tensions between China and North Korea. The sanctions will restrict trade and lead to the closure of joint ventures, potentially forcing North Korean partners to sell out ahead of the deadline.

site_title: US formally opposes China market economy status at WTO
summary: The US formally opposed China's bid for market economy status at the World Trade Organization (WTO), citing concerns over China's state-led economy and subsidies. The US argues that China's domestic prices are distorted and not market-determined, making it unfair to use third-country price comparisons to determine anti-dumping duties. A victory for China would weaken trade defenses and put western industries at risk, according to US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer. The US submitted a brief in support of the European Union in a WTO dispute with China, calling for China to be treated similarly to communist eastern European countries.

site_title: Myths and facts about Lasik surgery
summary: Lasik surgery, a popular treatment for vision correction, is still a type of surgery requiring consideration. Common myths about Lasik include it being cosmetic surgery, equal to other laser eye treatments, causing dry eyes, and being the only treatment option. In reality, Lasik is a high-tech procedure using a femtosecond laser and excimer ablative lasers, with advantages including reduced downtime and improved recovery. The treatment can be repeated if necessary, but careful measurement and assessment are required to rule out potential weaknesses. Each eye is unique, and the best treatment option depends on individual needs, making it essential to seek advice from a surgeon.

site_title: Commodity prices threatened more by tweets than China
summary: Commodity prices are more vulnerable to global market uncertainty than China's slowdown, according to Oscar Landerretche, chairman of Chile's state-owned miner Codelco. Despite China's efforts to deleverage its economy, Western politicians' focus on short-term decisions, such as tweets, poses a greater threat to commodities markets. Landerretche contrasts China's long-term strategy with Western politicians' self-inflicted uncertainty, citing accelerating growth in the developed world and a demand rebound in China as key factors driving commodity prices up 22% this year.

site_title: A Crystal Clear Lucky Strike
summary: Chopard's minute repeater watch, LUC Full Strike, has won the Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve, considered the watch industry's equivalent of an Oscar. The watch features a crystal clear sound produced by sapphire crystal, which was a first in the industry. After six years of development, Chopard's co-CEO Karl-Friedrich Scheufele revealed that the company used sapphire crystal to improve sound quality and volume, overcoming the challenges of working with a hard and expensive material. The watch, priced at $351,330, is equipped with world-first features, including three security devices.

images.alt_text: Karl-Friedrich Scheufele

site_title: Manafort reaches new bail agreement with prosecutors
summary: US President Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, reached a new bail agreement with prosecutors, forfeiting four properties worth $11.7 million if he fails to appear in court. Manafort will be released from electronic monitoring and can travel to Florida, New York, and Virginia. He has surrendered his passports and agreed not to travel overseas. Manafort and business associate Rick Gates are accused of lying to US authorities, laundering millions, and hiding offshore accounts, both pleading not guilty.

site_title: SPH to step up transformation process to seek growth
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) will step up its transformation process to rejuvenate its business model and seek new growth areas, chairman Lee Boon Yang said. The group will focus on strengthening its core media business with quality content, strategic partnerships, and technological innovations to deal with digital competition. Despite a 32% net profit jump, operating revenue shrank by 8.2%. SPH plans to re-engineer its newsrooms and form an integrated marketing division to regain lost advertising dollars. The company's total dividend for FY2017 is 15 cents, down from 18 cents in FY2016.

site_title: Listen Up
summary: La Boite Concept releases all-in-one speaker systems that double as furniture, including the Cube series, which features a chic coffee table design and wireless music streaming capabilities. The company, founded by Marie Cagniard Yeramian in 1938, offers products with prices ranging from S$1,600 to S$2,300. Meanwhile, noise-cancelling headphones like the AKG N60NC offer rich bass and superior sound quality, while the JBL Boombox is a portable device with 24-hour battery life and IPX7 waterproofing.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: China's October PMI remains strong, but cracks appearing
summary: China's manufacturing sector performed well in October, with the official PMI rising to 51.8, driven by new orders and output. However, a private PMI survey showed mounting difficulties for smaller firms, with a decline in new orders and a record low confidence in the business outlook. The divergence between the two PMIs suggests increasing difficulties for some firms as China cracks down on polluting industries and informal lending. Analysts expect the economy to slow in the months ahead due to slower credit growth, reduced fiscal support, and environmental crackdowns.

site_title: STI ends rollercoaster week on a subdued note
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended a rollercoaster week on a subdued note, up 16 points, or 0.47%, at 3,449.54. Despite gains in real estate stocks, the market remained flat, with about 2.1 billion shares changing hands. The Dow and Nasdaq closed higher, but Asian markets were cautious due to uncertainty over the US tax reform debate.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Mike Horn
summary: Mike Horn, a 51-year-old South-African-born Swiss explorer, is currently circling the globe via its poles in a two-year expedition called Pole2Pole. The mission, which began in May 2017, aims to educate the young about the importance of protecting the planet. Horn has completed numerous feats, including swimming the Amazon River, traveling 20,000 km around the Arctic Circle, and climbing to the peak of Makalu without oxygen. He is being supported by Officine Panerai, which has created a special edition watch in his honor. Horn emphasizes the importance of taking care of the environment and living life to the fullest, encouraging others to change small things in their lives to lead better lives.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and Maybank Kim Eng recommend an "overweight" stance on Singapore's property sector, citing expected outperformance in residential, hotel, and office segments. They are cautious on retail and industrial spaces. The analysts also note that real estate investment trusts (Reits) can transform into growth vehicles in an inflationary interest rate environment. Key stock picks include City Developments, Wing Tai, CDL Hospitality Trusts, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, and Ascendas Reit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ALLGREEN Properties acquired two freehold sites in Bukit Timah for S$658.59 million, while Olam International sold its California orchards to Farmland Partners Inc for US$110 million. Keppel Infrastructure Holdings secured a HK$31 billion contract to design and build Hong Kong's first integrated waste management facility. Real estate tycoon Koh Wee Meng's bid to take over New Wave Holdings fell through. Singapore's expertise in international commercial mediation will aid Japan's capabilities, and MAS proposes a framework to determine SGS and MAS bills' closing prices.

site_title: 'Tis The Season To Feast
summary: Resorts World Sentosa and Shangri-La Hotel Singapore are offering special festive menus for Christmas and New Year's Eve, featuring Michelin-starred chefs and luxurious settings. Options include Joël Robuchon's eight-course menu for S$588, Osia Steak and Seafood Grill's seafood platters for S$148, and CURATE's Alpine menu for S$188. Other hotels, such as the St Regis, Orchard Hotel, and Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay, also have festive offerings, including buffets, takeaways, and special menus. The Fullerton Hotels are also offering a range of festive options, including afternoon teas and degustation dinners.
