site_title: Allgreen scoops up 2 Singapore land parcels after 6-year hiatus
summary: Allgreen Properties has acquired two land parcels in Singapore's upscale Bukit Timah area through collective sale tenders, buying Royalville for S$477.94m and Crystal Tower for S$180.65m. The bids, which drew intense competition, set a bullish tone for future government land sales, with analysts estimating breakeven prices of S$2,500-S$2,600 psf for Royalville and S$2,400-S$2,500 psf for Crystal Tower. The acquisitions are expected to yield up to 323 and 130 residential units, respectively, and could influence the upcoming GLS tender closing at Fourth Avenue site.

site_title: Michael Flynn charged as Mueller intensifies Russia probe
summary: Michael Flynn, former US national security adviser, has been charged with lying to FBI agents as part of the Mueller investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US election. Flynn, 58, is scheduled for a plea hearing in a Washington D.C. court. This charge adds to the list of prominent defendants in Mueller's investigation, including former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and a junior foreign policy adviser. The development marks another escalation in the probe, which has already secured indictments against several key figures.

site_title: The selfish gene
summary: Audi has introduced an entry-level version of its iconic TT 1.8 coupe, offering a driver-centric driving experience at an affordable price. The 1.8-litre engine produces 180hp, making the car extremely agile and fun to drive, despite its lightweight aluminum construction and lack of all-wheel drive. While the ride can be busy and the cabin is minimalist, the TT prioritizes driving involvement over speed and is one of the most efficient sports cars on the market. The 1.8 model is $35,000 cheaper than the 2.0-litre version, making it an attractive option for those who want a driver-focused sports car without breaking the bank.

site_title: UK landed record foreign investment in year of Brexit vote
summary: The UK received a record £145.6 billion in foreign direct investment in 2016, the year of the Brexit vote, surpassing the previous record of £25.3 billion in 2015. Despite anti-Brexit warnings, Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed major takeovers as a sign of confidence in Britain.

site_title: US: Dow open flat as tax bill weighs
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened flat on Friday, following a record day for stocks, amid concerns over the Republican tax overhaul's impact on the federal deficit. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also experienced minor fluctuations, with the Dow rising 40.27 points to 24,312.62, while the S&P 500 lost 1.29 points to 2,646.29, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 28.57 points to 6,845.41.

site_title: YTL Starhill Global Reit appoints new lead independent director
summary: YTL Starhill Global Reit has appointed Tan Bong Lin as the new lead independent director, replacing Lim Kok Hoong who stepped down due to personal reasons. Both changes take effect from January 1, 2018. Tan, 61, will also serve as chairman of the audit committee, similar to Lim's role. He previously held similar positions at APAC Realty Limited and Parkway Life Reit from 2007 to 2016.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit trustee prices 5 billion yen bonds
summary: Parkway Life Reit has priced 5 billion yen in senior unsecured notes due 2023 at 100% of the principal amount, with a fixed interest rate of 0.57% payable every half year. The notes will be used to refinance existing borrowings, investments, and general working capital of the real estate investment trust.

site_title: Too cold for a theme park, Disney looks to toy stores in Russia
summary: Walt Disney Co plans to open at least five toy stores in Russia, with the first outlet in central Moscow, alongside British toy retailer Hamleys. The stores will only sell toys and represent the Disney, Star Wars, and Marvel franchises. Local manufacturers will supply merchandise, with some imports from other countries. The company has been focusing on localizing production due to the rouble's sharp fall and lower consumer spending on imported goods. Despite the cold climate, Disney does not plan to build a theme park in Russia, citing the country's limited efficiency and seasonal weather.

site_title: LHN expects proposed Hong Kong listing to be on or around Dec 29
summary: LHN Limited expects its proposed Hong Kong listing to occur on or around December 29, pending an in-principle approval from the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK). The company's application to list its shares in Hong Kong was convened for a hearing on November 27. The exact listing date is considered indicative and subject to further review.

site_title: Central banks find post-crisis bubble tool is doing the job
summary: Central banks are seeing promising results from macroprudential limits, which curb risky borrowing and temper property price bubbles, in countries such as New Zealand, Canada, and Australia. These tools, added to monetary policy toolboxes after the global financial crisis, have helped slow down financial risk and property price growth. While not all countries have seen uniform success, the measures have given central banks more breathing space to be more gradual in tightening monetary policy. Experts believe these tools will remain a permanent feature in counter-cyclical credit tightening.

site_title: Australia home prices stall as Sydney hits air pocket
summary: Australia's major cities saw flat home prices for a second month in November, with Sydney's prices dropping 0.7% and annual growth slowing to 5%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's efforts to curb investment lending and speculation have led to a reversal in the once-euphoric Sydney market. Melbourne remained resilient, with prices rising 0.5%, while Hobart saw a 11.5% annual increase. The RBA is expected to keep interest rates steady at its December policy meeting, citing concerns about debt-fuelled speculation and its impact on consumers and banks.

site_title: Face it - appearances matter at work
summary: A study has found that attractive people tend to earn more and get hired and promoted faster than those with below-average looks. Christina Ong, who was bypassed for promotion, discovered that changing her appearance helped her gain respect and confidence, leading to a promotion within a year. Experts say that appearance matters in certain roles, such as sales and marketing, and that confidence and charisma are also valued by employers. A good impression can make a significant difference in career advancement, and people's perceptions of others are often based on visual cues.

site_title: Imperium Crown's independent director resigns, firm appoints new one
summary: Imperium Crown Limited's independent director Pok Mee Yau has resigned, effective December 1, due to increased work and personal commitments. The firm has appointed Danny Oh Beng Teck, 55, as the new independent director, who will also be a member of audit, nominating, and remuneration committees. Oh will replace Pok Mee Yau, and existing director Hau Khee Wee will become the new chairman of the remuneration committee.

site_title: Bali volcano burns wedding dreams, threatens economy
summary: A volcano on the Indonesian island of Bali is threatening the island's economy and wedding dreams, with Mount Agung's recent eruption forcing hundreds of flights to be cancelled and causing widespread travel chaos. The volcano's activity has also affected the tourism industry, with millions of visitors cancelled or postponed, and local businesses, including wedding planners and farmers, struggling to cope. Indonesia's tourism minister warns that the island could lose up to $896 million in visitor-related revenue if the volcano's activity doesn't die down before the end of the year.

site_title: Ocean Sky International appoints former Guocoland CEO as independent director
summary: Ocean Sky International has appointed Chia Boon Kuah as an independent director, effective December 1. Chia, 60, held senior positions at Far East Organisation and Guocoland Ltd, including group president and CEO. He will join the audit, nominating, and remuneration committees.

site_title: Fincantieri increases stake in Vard to 79.49%
summary: Fincantieri, an Italian shipbuilding group, has increased its stake in Vard Holdings Limited to 79.49% through a voluntary delisting offer. The group initially made a 25 Singapore cents offer for all shares on November 13, up from 24 cents per share in November last year. As of Friday, Fincantieri owns approximately 938 million shares, with Vard shares closing 2% higher at 25.5 cents. This move solidifies Fincantieri's control over Vard.

site_title: SGX grants Marco Polo additional month to release FY2017 results and hold AGM
summary: Marco Polo Marine has been granted an additional month by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to release its unaudited full-year results for the financial year ended Sept 30 by Dec 31, and to hold its AGM by Feb 28, 2018. The firm was initially required to meet these deadlines by Nov 29 and Jan 31, 2018, respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation Limited has signed a master lease agreement with Alkas Realty for two units at OUE Downtown for 36 months. The agreement includes a four-month rent-free period from August to November 2017. The transaction is considered an interested party transaction due to Lippo's indirect 40.82% stake in Healthway Medical. Additionally, Healthway Medical has appointed Chong Ton Nen as a new independent non-executive director, nominated by substantial shareholder Maju Medik.

site_title: Boxer Mayweather 'adopts' panda, names it after himself
summary: Floyd Mayweather, a 40-year-old American boxer, adopted a baby giant panda in China and named it "TMT Floyd Mayweather". The adoption fee of 100,000 yuan will go to the research centre where the panda lives. Mayweather, who retired from boxing to improve his record to 50-0, visited the panda at the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding and will be able to visit and receive greeting cards from the panda for a year. This is part of Mayweather's tour of China, which also includes stops in Beijing, Hong Kong, and Macau.

site_title: SingPost raises rates for international small packets
summary: SingPost is raising rates for international small packets starting January 2, 2018, following new rates set by the Universal Postal Union. The changes reflect rising e-commerce volumes and increased delivery costs. The maximum price increase is S$3.40 per item, while customers may also save up to S$1.10. SingPost will no longer accept international small packets by ship due to declining demand and the shift to airmail. The firm expects minimal impact on its postal business.

site_title: Obama digs at Trump over climate change
summary: Former US President Barack Obama criticized his successor Donald Trump's stance on climate change, stating there's a "pause in American leadership" on the issue. Despite Trump's threat to leave the 2015 Paris climate accord, Obama noted that some US states, companies, and cities are working to meet the agreement's goals. Obama also attacked "destructive populism" that threatens modern democracy, without directly commenting on Trump's administration.

site_title: SPH to step up transformation via wide-ranging projects: chairman
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) plans to transform itself through wide-ranging projects to address challenges from social media and digital advertising. Chairman Lee Boon Yang announced the group's strategy to strengthen its core media business with quality content, strategic partnerships, and technological innovations. SPH will also explore new areas such as healthcare and education to create new value. The company has reorganized its newsrooms to prioritize digital content and has made significant job cuts. Shareholders approved the group's resolutions, including a final and special dividend, and Chairman Lee expressed support for the appointment of new CEO Ng Yat Chung.

site_title: US$300b Saudi state sell-off moves slowly
summary: Saudi Arabia's $300 billion privatisation programme, launched by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has stalled 19 months after its unveiling due to heavy bureaucracy, inadequate legal framework, and changes in government priorities. Investors are also wary due to uncertainty surrounding an anti-corruption campaign. A "wait-and-see" approach among investors has contributed to the slow progress, with some attributing it to fatigue and concerns about the campaign's fallout. The programme's slow pace has raised concerns about its future prospects.

site_title: Booming orders help UK factories to best month since 2013: PMI
summary: UK factories experienced their best month since 2013 in November, with a PMI index of 58.2, driven by surging orders at home and from Europe's recovering economy. This boost to manufacturing could provide a real boost to the country's sluggish economy in 2018, as it approaches its departure from the EU in March 2019. While the services sector remains the dominant driver of the economy, the PMI suggests manufacturing production is rising at a quarterly rate approaching 2%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down for fifth straight day
summary: Hong Kong shares fell for the fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.35% to 29,074.24. The decline was driven by losses in technology firms and concerns over US tax reforms. The Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.79%. The losses followed a record close on Wall Street, which was overshadowed by market volatility.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific subsidiary purchases Melbourne property for A$33.02m
summary: Roxy-Pacific's subsidiary, Roxy-Pacific Melbourne House Pte Ltd, has acquired a Melbourne property for A$33.02 million (S$33.72 million). The property, Melbourne House, is a six-storey commercial building in the central business district. The subsidiary plans to redevelop it into a mixed-use development with hotel and retail units. A 10% deposit has been paid, financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with the remaining amount to be secured through a loan.

site_title: Nissan's Japan car sales slide for second month after compliance scandal
summary: Nissan's Japan car sales declined for the second consecutive month, with domestic passenger car sales dropping almost half in November. The slump follows a compliance scandal, resulting in a 1.2 million-car recall and production halt for Japanese market vehicles. Nissan expects production to return to regular levels in about a month.

site_title: Sterling gets brief boost from strong UK manufacturing data
summary: Sterling experienced a brief surge after UK manufacturing data showed a 58.2 reading in November, the best in over four years, beating forecasts. The data suggested a potential boost to the country's sluggish economy in 2018. Sterling reached a high of US$1.3550, its strongest since September 25, before slipping back to around US$1.3515. The pound's gains were largely due to US dollar weakness.

site_title: Japan budget outline seeks to combine monetary and pro-growth fiscal policies
summary: Japan's top economic advisory panel has released a budget outline calling for a combination of monetary easing and "growth-oriented" fiscal policy, aiming to boost nominal GDP to 600 trillion yen. The plan prioritizes childcare, human capital, productivity, and innovation, while balancing the budget. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces pressure to spend more on social welfare, public works, and defense, despite a goal of trimming bulging social-welfare spending. The government aims to control expansion of social welfare spending, but faces opposition from doctors and medical institutions.

site_title: Parallel-imported car sales down 14%
summary: Parallel-imported car sales in Singapore decreased by 14% in the first nine months of the year, with 13,312 cars registered from January to September, compared to 15,448 in the same period last year. This decline is attributed to reduced demand from private-hire operators, increased competition from authorized agents, and negative publicity surrounding parallel-imported vehicles.

site_title: Verizon encroaches on AT&T's turf with Sacramento 5G broadband
summary: Verizon is set to introduce a 5G broadband service in Sacramento, California, starting next year, targeting AT&T and cable providers. The service will be faster and more convenient than traditional home broadband internet, with the potential to persuade consumers to abandon their cable and phone modems. Verizon has been running trials in 11 cities and has chosen Sacramento due to its progressive municipal leaders, who are open to letting Verizon install network equipment on public property. The cost of building the 5G network in Sacramento is expected to be lower than digging trenches for fiber-optic cable.

site_title: Global manufacturing buoyed as focus shifts to rate hikes
summary: Global manufacturing expanded at its fastest pace in years, driven by robust demand, and bolstering the case for central banks to shift to tighter monetary policy. Factory activity surveys showed a strong expansion in the euro zone, following interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank, US Federal Reserve, and Bank of Korea. The Bank of Korea's rate hike marked Asia's first major central bank to do so in three years, potentially influencing other countries like Malaysia and the Philippines to raise rates next year.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.47% on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.47% on Friday, closing at 3,449.54, driven by a 16-point gain. About 2.1 billion shares were traded, worth S$1.21 billion. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: "You're right: We're a threat," British Labour leader warns Morgan Stanley
summary: Britain's Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn warned Morgan Stanley that bankers view him as a threat to their power due to his socialist policies. Corbyn stated that he wants to transform the economy, which he claims is rigged in favor of speculators at the expense of ordinary people. Morgan Stanley previously warned that Corbyn's potential victory could lead to significant changes in Britain's free-market economy, making it a bigger threat than Brexit for domestic investors.

site_title: Barclays announces final sale of stake in Barclays Africa
summary: Barclays has announced the final sale of its 7% stake in Barclays Africa Group, marking the end of its nearly 90-year presence on the continent. The sale, set to occur on December 5, will leave Barclays with a 14.9% stake in the division, aligning with its desired long-term goal. This move is part of the bank's strategy to refocus on its UK and US businesses, following a series of sales since 2016.

site_title: European stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Friday, with London and Paris flat and Frankfurt up slightly. London's FTSE 100 index opened at 7,328.77 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gained 0.2% to 13,044.15 points. The Paris CAC 40 index remained stable at 5,374.13 points. The steady market performance was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Maersk Oil, partners to invest $3.4 bln in North Sea gas field Tyra
summary: Maersk Oil, along with its partners in the Danish Underground Consortium, has invested $4.52 billion in redeveloping the Tyra gas field in the North Sea. The investment will enable the field to operate for at least 25 years and produce 60,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is the largest investment in the Danish part of the North Sea. The deal comes after France's Total agreed to buy Maersk's oil and gas business in a $7.45 billion deal in August.

site_title: AI-Aided Elixir
summary: Anastasia Georgievskaya, a 24-year-old Russian bio-engineer, is co-founder of Youth Laboratories, which uses AI and machine vision to tackle skin aging. The company has developed an app that tracks age-related facial changes and a beauty contest judged by robots. Additionally, their machines are used in European clinics to diagnose illnesses and skincare issues in seconds. Georgievskaya's work aims to advance "digital health" and apply AI to medical diagnostics, marking a new generation of AI in the medical field.

site_title: Nippon Life to buy 25% of US asset manager TCW from Carlyle
summary: Nippon Life Insurance Co, Japan's largest private sector life insurer, agreed to buy 24.75% of US investment firm TCW Group from Carlyle Group LP for approximately $660.62 million. The deal is part of Nippon Life's push to build scale in asset management amid low interest rates and stricter regulations. TCW, which had $191.6 billion in assets under management, will retain 31.2% ownership after the deal, with Nippon Life holding two board seats. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the month pending regulatory approval.

site_title: The other side of the economy
summary: Singapore's economy appears to be performing well, with a GDP growth rate of 3-3.5% in 2017, but many are struggling to find jobs despite the improved economic conditions. A recent survey found that 60-year-old HR veteran Bernard Cruz was unable to find a full-time job, despite having experience and being open to taking a pay cut. Economists attribute this to the perception that older workers are less desirable, and the lack of job opportunities in certain sectors such as offshore and marine, and construction. The unemployment rate for Singaporeans and permanent residents has been creeping up over the past few years, with the long-term unemployment rate reaching 0.8% in September. Experts warn that improvements to the labour market are unlikely until the second half of 2018, and that the pace of change and uncertainty are major factors contributing to the gloomy sentiment among workers.

site_title: Gold hits 1-month high as US dollar weakens further
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-month high on Thursday, reaching US$1,289.92 an ounce, due to a weakening US dollar and thin holiday trade. The metal has gained for a ninth consecutive day, with potential further gains expected if the dollar continues to decline. Investors are seeking gold as a safe-haven asset amid uncertainty over the US economy and North Korea's nuclear programs.

site_title: Record exports help lift Vietnam's 2017 GDP growth to 6.81%
summary: Vietnam's economy grew 6.81% in 2017, exceeding the government's expectation and the highest since 2011. Record exports reached $213 billion, driven by stronger international demand and rising domestic spending. Retail sales increased 10.9% and the average inflation rate was 3.55%. The government's economic reforms and higher exports contributed to the growth, with the last quarter showing a 7.65% expansion.

site_title: Family of Datapulse's co-founder files requisition notice to oust directors
summary: The family of Datapulse Technology co-founder Ng Khim Guan is seeking to replace four directors on the company's board, citing a need to re-evaluate the firm's diversification strategy. Uniseraya Holdings Pte Ltd and Ng Bie Tjin, who hold a combined 16% stake in the company, have filed a requisition notice for an extraordinary general meeting. The meeting will consider removing four directors, including chairman Low Beng Tin, and appointing new directors, including Ng Bie Tjin. The company is also expected to evaluate its diversification and investment strategy.

site_title: RBS to shut 259 more branches amid shift to digital banking
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to close 259 more branches in Britain, resulting in about 680 job cuts, as customers shift to online banking. The closures will be implemented in mid-2024, with savings used to invest in its mobile banking platform, which has seen a 70% increase in transactions since 2014. This marks the latest round of cuts for the bank, which has been shrinking since its nationalization in 2008, with competitors such as Lloyds Banking Group also moving customers online.

site_title: See A New Singapore
summary: Singaporean cult photographer Nguan has released a beautifully-designed photo book titled "Singapore" in 2017, showcasing the city-state's streets and buildings in a dreamy, candy-coloured light. The book has garnered praise for its unique perspective on the mundane and its ability to evoke patriotism in readers. The book can be purchased online at Nguan's website.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore-listed New Silkroutes Group has called for a trading halt to continue negotiations with various parties on potential investments and acquisitions. Lian Beng Group has sold an Australian property for A$90.15 million, while Oceanus Group has completed a debt restructuring exercise to become debt-free. Geo Energy Resources has agreed to supply coal to Engelhart CTP and appointed a former Indonesian chief justice as a special adviser. Food Empire has entered into an agreement to redeem a loan to Caffe Bene Co, and OCBC has announced the retirement of its CEO and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as successor.

site_title: Broker's take: Rise in customer orders, earnings momentum get Hi-P a 'buy' rating
summary: Hi-P International, a contract manufacturer, has received a "buy" rating from broker Maybank Kim Eng due to a rise in customer orders and strong earnings momentum. The company's revenue is expected to grow at a 15% compound annual growth rate from 2017-2019, driven by its key wireless customer and the Internet of Things segment. Hi-P's share price has reached a 52-week high, and the firm is ramping up production for bluechip customers, including Apple. A 12-month target price of S$2.11 is set with a 19% upside potential.

site_title: Singapore cryptocurrency cafe launches as regulators sound warnings
summary: A cryptocurrency cafe in Singapore has launched, accepting bitcoin and its own virtual currency, Ducatus, as payment. The cafe, near the central bank, aims to promote the use of digital coins through commercial enterprise. This comes as the Monetary Authority of Singapore warns investors to exercise "extreme caution" towards the cryptocurrency market. The cafe's CEO, Ronny Tome, believes the use of cryptocurrencies is here to stay and plans to expand to other countries. Regulators in Singapore and globally are concerned about the risks associated with cryptocurrencies, including money laundering and speculative behavior.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's IPIC says Malaysian fund 1MDB has paid settlement amount in full
summary: Abu Dhabi's IPIC said Malaysian state fund 1MDB has made the required payments of US$600 million as part of a settlement agreement. The payments were due by December 31, following a default on 1MDB's bonds and a London court arbitration over a US$6.5 billion claim. This settlement resolves a claim made by IPIC, which had originally sought US$1.2 billion in two instalments. 1MDB is under investigation for money laundering in several countries, including the US, and has denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: VibroPower: 'Misalignment of expectations' behind financial controller resignations
summary: VibroPower Corp, a Singapore-based manufacturer of power generator sets, attributed recent resignations of its group financial controller to a "misalignment of expectations" between management and the controllers. The resignations follow a string of changes in the financial controller position, with two previous controllers leaving the company in less than a year. The company has appointed an acting group financial controller and is searching for a replacement. There are no unusual reasons for the resignations, according to the company.

site_title: Out with the old
summary: Singapore's pawnbrokers have undergone significant changes to attract a younger and wealthier clientele, with bold moves that have boosted profits. The industry has doubled in number to over 220 since 2008, and pawnshop loans have risen to S$7 billion. New players, such as Maxi-Cash and MoneyMax, have listed on the Singapore Exchange, injecting life into the trade. Pawnshops now offer competitive interest rates and modern facilities, including online platforms and mobile apps. However, the industry faces challenges, including increasing rental costs and volatility in the gold price. Despite these headwinds, pawnbrokers remain optimistic about the future, with some seeing opportunities in the growing demand for pre-owned luxury goods.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Memories Gp placing out shares to keep public float
summary: Memories Group, the former SHC Capital, has launched a compliance placement of up to 50 million new shares at 25 Singapore cents each to maintain a minimum public float. The placement follows the company's reverse takeover of MM Myanmar Pte Ltd and acquisition of tourism-related businesses in Myanmar. The company plans to expand its tourism-related business, seeking to develop new destinations and manage third-party tourism assets. Trading in Memories Group's shares has been suspended until January 5, and the company expects to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by then.

site_title: 2018 will be a massive year for elections - and consultants
summary: In 2018, numerous high-stakes elections will take place across the globe, with foreign consultants playing a significant role in shaping the outcomes. The elections in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, the Americas, and Africa will have far-reaching implications for domestic politics, economics, and international relations. US consultants, in particular, are expected to be heavily involved, with some firms already working in over half of the world's countries. The globalisation of politics has led to a lucrative industry, with consultants providing polling, campaign strategy, and branding advice to governments and leaders.

site_title: MPA pumps S$12 million more to promote S'pore's LNG bunkering
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has injected S$12 million to promote liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering in the Port of Singapore. The funding will support the building of new LNG bunker vessels and top up existing co-funding programmes for LNG-fuelled vessels. The move aims to boost ship-to-ship LNG bunkering in the port, providing greater confidence in LNG supply across key shipping routes. The funding is in line with the MPA's goal to be "LNG bunker-ready" by 2020.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Iran reopens border posts with Iraqi Kurdistan
summary: Iran has reopened all its border crossings with Iraq's autonomous Kurdish region, following their closure after a controversial independence vote. The border crossings, which had been closed since September, began working again after the Bashmaq frontier post resumed operations in October. The move comes after the Iraqi supreme court ruled the poll to be "unconstitutional" and the federal government demanded the handover of border posts and airports in the Kurdish region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.42% to 29,173.26, tracking a record finish on Wall Street due to optimism over a US tax cut bill. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index inched down 0.06%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.06%. The gains come as traders brush off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Rowsley acquired Thomson Medical for S$1.6 billion and a 70.36% stake in Malaysia-listed TMC Life Sciences. ThaiBev's unit registered to bid for Sabeco with an estimated US$4.8 billion offer. The STI reached its highest annual price gain since 2012, opening at 3,423 points, 542 points above the 2016 year-end level. Non-oil exports in November rose 9.1% from a year ago, down from October's 20.5% growth. Spring Singapore will apply to the High Court for a declaration and/or injunction against SG Vehicles group of companies.

site_title: Job loss insurance not a panacea for impact of economic disruption
summary: Singapore lacks a wage loss insurance program to protect workers from sudden job loss or retrenchment. Although the idea was first proposed over two decades ago, it has never been implemented. Insurers prefer to offer secondary benefits that exempt policyholders from premiums or provide one-time payouts for shorter-term unemployment. Research on wage insurance in North America has shown inconsistent results, and more sustainable measures, such as training and re-skilling schemes like SkillsFuture, may be more effective in addressing job loss.

site_title: Recapturing Ericsson's mojo
summary: Ericsson CEO Börje Ekholm is leading the company's turnaround efforts, aiming to regain its position as a leader in telecom technology. After a 140-year history, Ericsson faces significant challenges from Chinese telecom equipment makers such as Huawei and ZTE. Ekholm is investing in research and development (R&D) to maintain Ericsson's technology lead and reduce costs. The company is focusing on 5G technology, IoT devices, and smart cities, with a goal to double its operating margin to 12% by 2018. Ekholm believes that 5G will bring about significant changes, including low latency and high bandwidth, enabling new applications such as augmented reality and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Euro zone businesses to start 2018 on near seven-year high
summary: Euro zone businesses ended 2017 on a near seven-year high, with demand and price pressures increasing and forward-looking indicators pointing to a strong start to 2018. The IHS Markit composite flash Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 58.0, its highest since February 2011, and the euro zone economy is expected to have expanded 0.8% in the fourth quarter, the strongest official quarterly growth rate since 2015. The European Central Bank is set to cut its asset purchases to 30 billion euros, but the latest survey suggests continued price pressures will be welcomed.

site_title: Vietnam orders prosecution of PetroVietnam official in corruption crackdown
summary: Vietnamese police have ordered the prosecution of PetroVietnam official Phan Dinh Duc on suspicion of violating state regulations, causing serious consequences, related to a loss of 800 billion dong (S$47.7 million) in Ocean Bank. This is part of a high-level corruption crackdown at the state energy firm, which also led to the arrest of former PetroVietnam chairman Dinh La Thang in December. The corruption scandal has made headlines globally, including the alleged kidnapping of Trinh Xuan Thanh, a former PetroVietnam chairman, in Berlin.

site_title: PetroChina to take on global rivals in major expansion drive
summary: PetroChina's oil and gas trading arm plans to expand globally, aiming to buy petrol stations and fuel storage facilities in West Africa, Brazil, and Pakistan. The move, led by Vice-President Tian Jinghui, seeks to establish a foothold in emerging markets and grow market share locally. The expansion, expected to start next year, aims to tap into growing transportation fuel demand in these regions, mirroring moves by international rivals Vitol and Trafigura.

site_title: In major shift, Rakuten plots to become Japan's No 4 wireless carrier
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce firm, plans to apply for a 4G mobile license to become Japan's fourth major wireless carrier. The company aims to start offering mobile services in 2019 and secure at least 15 million subscribers. However, analysts are skeptical about its prospects due to a fully penetrated market, high network build-out and customer acquisition costs, and potential losses until it gains customers. Rakuten's move could negatively impact Japan's biggest carriers, with SoftBank potentially being the worst affected.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank admits some claims, denies others in money laundering
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia admitted it was late in submitting suspicious-transaction reports but contested many charges made by the financial-crimes regulator, Austrac. The bank failed to adequately check on money laundering risks when installing automated teller machines in 2012, but denied eight separate law violations. Austrac alleged 53,700 breaches of anti-money laundering laws, which the bank admitted to some charges but denied many. The bank's CEO, Ian Narev, will leave next year amidst the scandal.

site_title: UOB partners Shanghai home rental platform Mamahome
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Shanghai-based startup Mamahome, a property technology firm, in its first move outside of China. The partnership aims to support Mamahome's expansion into Singapore by integrating UOB's Virtual Account Solution into its online platform. Tenants will receive a unique virtual account number to pay rent, enabling quick and easy reconciliation. The move will provide end-to-end property rental services in Singapore, including property searches, lease signing, and payments for add-ons.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally ahead of Fed decision
summary: Hong Kong shares rose on December 13, 2017, as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, boosting financials. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.49% to close at 29,222.10, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The expected rate hike lifted market sentiment, with the benchmark indices rising ahead of the Fed's policy meeting later that day.

site_title: US, EU team up against China in blasting world trade order
summary: The US and European Union have expressed concerns about the effectiveness of the World Trade Organization (WTO), arguing that it is too focused on refereeing disputes and not enough on expanding commerce. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer stated that the WTO is losing its essential focus and becoming a litigation-focused organization. European Union Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom echoed these concerns, saying the WTO is not living up to its potential. China defended the existing order and urged countries to forge ahead with globalization, while the US and EU join forces to push for changes to the WTO's rules and practices.

site_title: At Screen Actors Guild Awards, it will be women first
summary: The Screen Actors Guild Awards (SAG Awards) will feature an all-female presenter lineup, with 13 acting awards to be presented by women, including host Kristen Bell. The decision was made by executive producer Kathy Connell, who cited the #MeToo movement and the industry's efforts to address sexual misconduct allegations. The move comes after a year of prominent figures being accused of misconduct, including Harvey Weinstein. The SAG Awards will also have a first-ever female host and will celebrate women more than any other awards show.

images.alt_text: From left: Sandra Dewey, Kristen Bell and Kathy Connell in Burbank, California on Dec 11. Bell will be the first host for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, which Dewey and Connell also filled with all female presenters.
Niecy Nash (left) and Olivia Munn onstage during the 24th Annual SAG Awards nominations announcement at the SilverScreen Theater at Pacific Design Center on Dec 13 in West Hollywood, California.

site_title: SoftBank's Saudi ties could mean cash after kingdom's crackdown
summary: Billionaire Masayoshi Son's SoftBank Group Corp may benefit from Saudi Arabia's crackdown on officials, as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's consolidation of power could lead to steady flows of Saudi money into the SoftBank Vision Fund. The fund has raised $93 billion, with Saudi Arabia committing $45 billion, making it the largest investor. A stronger Prince Mohammed could mean reduced debt burden for SoftBank, but an unforeseen reversal in his fortunes may raise questions about the sustainability of his investments.

site_title: Pregnant woman wants seat on Tokyo metro: there's an app for that
summary: A new app is being trialled in Tokyo's metro to help pregnant women find seats, as the city struggles with low birth rates. The app connects women in need of a seat with willing passengers who have pre-registered to give up their seats. The service aims to address issues of people being glued to their phones and talking being frowned upon on public transportation. The app will be expanded to assist elderly and disabled people, and its rollout is yet to be decided.

site_title: Jaguar F-Type 2.0 Coupe review: How to save S$46k on this exquisite coupe
summary: Jaguar's F-Type 2.0 Coupe is a sleek yet powerful vehicle, but its high performance can be intimidating, causing it to fishtail wildly when driven without traction control. The 2.0 model offers a more affordable option at S$46,000, making it an attractive choice for those seeking a luxurious coupe. However, its high price point and potential for reckless driving may be a concern for some buyers.

site_title: Asia-Pacific to remain most active region for new IPOs as Singapore retains hub status: EY
summary: The Asia-Pacific region, particularly Singapore, will remain the world's most active region for new IPOs in 2018, with a total of 1,624 IPOs registered and US$188.8 billion raised, a 49% increase in deals and 40% in proceeds compared to 2016. The US$3.3 billion raised in Singapore made it the most active IPO market in South-east Asia, driven by companies like NetLink NBN Trust. EY expects an "exceptional" year for IPOs globally, driven by economic growth and buoyant investor confidence.

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific will remain the world's most active region for new listings in 2018, with Singapore retaining its status as a hub for Asean companies, EY said in a global report on initial public offerings (IPOs).

site_title: Dakota Crescent to get new flats, retain public housing role: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Dakota Crescent estate will undergo redevelopment, with new public housing flats built while retaining the iconic "Dove" playground for civic and community uses. Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong announced the decision, stating it will provide more public housing options near the city and allow future generations to create memories at the estate. The central cluster of buildings will be repurposed for community spaces, making Dakota Crescent a mixed-use area with new flats, amenities, and vibrant community spaces.

images.alt_text: The central cluster of buildings around the courtyard, including the playground, will be retained and repurposed for civic and community uses.

site_title: Trading sombre ahead of US jobs report
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 0.3% to 3,388.14, marking its fourth consecutive loss, ahead of the US jobs report on Friday. Despite some stability in US stock indices overnight, a risk-off mode persists due to concerns over a US government shutdown and US non-farm payroll data. Markets are also cautious about US President Donald Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, which could lead to increased tensions and risk aversion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Petrofac wins US$800m BP contract for Khazzan gas field in Oman
summary: British oilfield services company Petrofac Ltd has won a US$800 million contract from BP to develop the second phase of the Khazzan gas field in Oman, increasing production capacity to 1,500 mmscfd. This follows the successful completion of the first phase, which was also worked on by Petrofac. The contract is part of a larger project to develop an estimated 10.5 trillion cubic feet of recoverable gas resources. BP, which has a 60% stake in the project, is working with Oman Oil Company Exploration & Production, which holds 40%.

site_title: SingHaiyi, shareholders take 9.9% stake in Cromwell for A$169m
summary: SingHaiyi, a Singapore-based real estate group, has subscribed for 175.1 million units of Cromwell Property Group's stapled securities for A$169.6 million, a 9.9% stake. The deal will provide SingHaiyi with a 3.45% stake in Cromwell and exposure to its high-quality income-producing assets across Australia, New Zealand, and Europe. This move aims to diversify SingHaiyi's income streams and geographical exposure, delivering stable and visible earnings for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Shark-spotting drones on patrol at Australian beaches
summary: High-tech shark-spotting drones are patrolling Australian beaches this summer, scanning the ocean to quickly identify underwater predators and deliver safety devices to swimmers and surfers. The drones use artificial intelligence to differentiate between sea creatures, including sharks, with over 90% accuracy. The technology allows for real-time alerts to be sent to swimmers and surfers, enabling them to be rescued faster than traditional lifesavers. The system aims to make beach recreation safer, and experts are also adapting the technology to spot crocodiles in northern Australia.

site_title: Noble sells coal unit for US$34.5m
summary: NOBLE Group has sold its coal unit, MR Coal Marketing and Trading, to an unnamed buyer for US$34.5 million. The sale was made by a Noble unit, Noble Americas Emerald Corp, after the buyer exercised a call option granted in 2015. The transaction was not considered a disclosable event at the time of grant. The sale marks a strategic move for Noble, allowing it to focus on other business interests.

site_title: China unhappy as Philippines signs investment deal with Taiwan
summary: China expressed concern over the Philippines' signing of a bilateral investment agreement with Taiwan, which China claims as its own territory. The agreement was signed in Manila, despite China's opposition to any official exchanges with Taiwan. China hopes the Philippines will stick to the "one China" principle to avoid damaging relations. This move comes amid strained relations between China and the Philippines, which have largely improved following a territorial dispute in the South China Sea. China views Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen as a threat to its sovereignty.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TECHNICS Oil & Gas Limited has applied to the Singapore Exchange for an extension of time to release its financial statements and convene its annual general meeting. The company is undergoing extensive restructuring and needs more time to finalize its financial accounts. Meanwhile, China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp has appointed Xu Guohong as chief financial officer, replacing Wang Chunyan. Infinio Group's stock price surged after the company responded to a query about "unusual volume movements" in its shares, stating it is exploring fundraising avenues but no definitive agreement has been reached.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings and Kimly are recommended to "buy" by analysts, with Roxy-Pacific's fair value estimate increasing to S$0.60 due to its mixed-use redevelopment plans in Melbourne and a strong landbank in Singapore. Kimly is seen as a strong cash generator with a clean balance sheet, and its expansion of a central kitchen is expected to boost efficiency. Both companies are expected to benefit from a turnaround in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Ngiam Shih Chun named EMA chief, to take over from Ng Wai Choong who will be IRAS commissioner, CEO
summary: Ngiam Shih Chun has been named as the new chief executive of the Energy Market Authority (EMA), succeeding Ng Wai Choong, who will take over as commissioner of inland revenue and CEO of IRAS. Ng Wai Choong will retire on Feb 1, 2018. Ngiam Shih Chun's appointment is expected to equip him to lead EMA in forging a progressive energy landscape. This move comes as part of a staff reorganization within the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Deutsche Bank wealth arm hires 6 Singapore relationship managers from BNP Paribas, Nomura
summary: Deutsche Bank's wealth management arm in Singapore hired six relationship managers from BNP Paribas and Nomura to support its growth strategy in Asia. The hires, led by Jonathan Ng and Gregory Goh, will cover clients in South-east Asia. The bank has made over 50 new hires globally and plans to invest 65 million euros in digital technology to enhance client-focused services. This move follows earlier announcements of talent and technology investments in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: This time it's different
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The collective sale market in Singapore is experiencing an unprecedented pace, driven by motivated owners seeking to capitalize on rising land values and minimize maintenance costs. Agents report faster consensus rates, with owners achieving 80% minimum consent in under three months. The current boom is fueled by a confluence of factors, including a dwindling stock of unsold units, a rosier economic outlook, and government land sales program changes. However, concerns over supply and demand, as well as potential government intervention, may impact the market, with experts predicting the boom will last at least until the end of 2018.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: SGX to hike derivatives member fees as much as 10-fold from January
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to significantly hike derivatives membership fees by up to 10 times, with some members facing a fee increase from S$2,000 to S$25,000 per year. The fee hike, the first in 15 years, aims to align with the growth in membership value, following investments in new trading technology and infrastructure. The changes will take effect on January 2, affecting a few hundred derivatives members, who have expressed concerns about the impact on smaller players.

site_title: Soft finish to the Singdollar in 2017 but here's to next year
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to stay muted against the US dollar in the last few weeks of 2017, but a policy shift from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is likely to bring a fresh start in the New Year. Economists predict internal tailwinds, such as rising consumption from improved employment, will drive the economy in 2018. The MAS may consider tightening monetary policy if inflation is expected to pick up in the next 18 months, and a policy shift could occur in April or October.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q3 net profit more than doubles on stronger margins
summary: Low Keng Huat, a construction firm, reported a more than doubling in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$6.62 million, driven by stronger margins. Revenue rose 9% to S$13.5 million, while cost of sales fell 51% to S$3.55 million, resulting in a 92% increase in gross profit to S$9.94 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of good governance and leadership in navigating Singapore's future challenges. Ossia International and BH Global were placed on the SGX watch-list. GuocoLand's subsidiary entered into a joint venture to participate in a land tender. Singapore Airlines and SilkAir will codeshare on Scoot-operated flights. Pavilion Energy's CEO Seah Moon Ming stepped down to focus on his SMRT role. Q & M Dental sold its medical aesthetic and laser unit for $242,000. The STI closed flat, down 0.4 points, as Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%.

site_title: How to grow when you have 100% market share, Swedish CEO asks
summary: Swedish electronics company Mycronic AB, which supplies masterplates to manufacturers of advanced flat-panel displays, has achieved 100% market share since CEO Lena Olving took over in 2013. Despite this, Olving faces a challenge to grow faster than the market. To address this, she has focused on expanding Mycronic's offerings through acquisitions, with a goal of doubling sales to 5 billion kronor (S$800.75 million) by 2023. The company is targeting growth in autonomous driving and advanced safety features in cars, as well as expanding its Assembly Solutions unit.

site_title: Asia-Pacific carriers en route to higher profits in 2018: Iata
summary: Asia-Pacific carriers are expected to rake in US$9 billion in profits in 2018, driven by a rebound in the cargo market and strong passenger demand. The global aviation industry is projected to clock a record profit of US$38.4 billion, with North American carriers leading the pack at US$16.4 billion. Fuel costs are expected to rise, but airlines have leveraged positive cash flow to pay out dividends and pare debt. Cargo volumes are expected to expand 4.3% to 62.5 million tonnes, driven by e-commerce growth, while passenger demand is forecast to reach 4.3 billion passengers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump, Obama dominate Twitter in 2017; but chicken nuggets win
summary: US President Donald Trump dominated Twitter in 2017, with 44 million followers, despite former President Barack Obama's tweets being more liked. However, a 16-year-old named Carter Wilkerson's campaign for free chicken nuggets from Wendy's garnered 3.6 million retweets, outdoing Trump's tweets. The top tweeted news outlet was Fox News, with CNN coming in second, sparking a counterpunch from Trump who derides CNN as "fake news."

site_title: To digitalise, or not to digitalise: That is not the question
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must embrace digitalization to stay competitive in the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Early developments include unmanned factories in China and e-procurement platforms in Singapore, enabling SMEs to increase productivity, reduce costs, and improve supply chain management. A comprehensive "SMEs Go Digital" program was launched in 2017 to support SMEs in adopting digital technologies. Digital maturity is linked to profitability, with digitally mature firms being 26% more profitable than their peers. SMEs must overcome the mindset barrier to digitalization and tap into Singapore's digital transformation ecosystem to unlock growth opportunities.

site_title: General Electric to cut 4,500 jobs in Europe
summary: General Electric will cut 4,500 jobs in Europe, primarily in Switzerland, Germany, and Britain, after reviewing its assets purchased from Alstom in 2015. The US firm cited a need to ensure its operations are "best positioned to respond to our market realities and for long-term success." The job cuts are part of a broader review of GE's European operations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat amid Russia probe jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Monday, following three days of gains, amid concerns over the FBI probe into alleged Russian meddling in the US election. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.01% and the Topix index gained 0.16%, but investors' cautious mood prevailed. The flat opening was in line with global markets, which also saw gains despite uncertainty over US trade policies and the ongoing probe.

site_title: Bitcoin now bigger than Buffett, Boeing, NZ economy
summary: Bitcoin's market capitalization has surpassed that of US billionaires, Boeing, and the New Zealand economy, reaching over $190 billion. The cryptocurrency has surged 1,000% this year, solidifying its position above the $11,000 level. Goldman Sachs and UBS have taken a hands-off approach to bitcoin, while Warren Buffett has called it a "real bubble." Despite the debate over its bubble status, bitcoin continues to grow in value, eclipsing the annual output of some economies and the estimated worth of top billionaires.

site_title: FCL tops bids for former Zouk site; Allgreen tops bids for Fourth Ave site
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited topped bids for a 13,482 sq m site in Jiak Kim Street, the former Zouk site, at S$955.4 million, with a land rate of S$1,732.55 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). Allgreen Holdings emerged top among seven bidders for a 18,532.2 sq m site at Fourth Avenue, securing the site at S$552.96 million, with a land rate of S$1,540 psf ppr. Both sites were previously on the Reserve List of the Government Land Sales programme and were triggered for public tender after minimum acceptable bids were received.

site_title: 'Our course is set,' says SingPost's new chief executive
summary: SingPost's new CEO, Paul Coutts, has stated that the company's course is set despite inheriting challenges, including a significant impairment on a US e-commerce unit and declining mail volumes. Coutts has overseen a strategic review and is implementing transformation plans focusing on e-commerce and logistics. A rate hike in international terminal dues and a new rate structure for small packets are expected to impact the company's operations, with Coutts warning that the effects won't be felt until the end of the first quarter of next year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Half a year into the job, Mr Coutts has overseen a strategic review of the company, which is implementing its transformation plans with an eye on the e-commerce and logistics business.

site_title: China's 2018 steel output seen rising even after mill closures
summary: China's crude steel output is expected to rise 3% to 832 million tonnes in 2017 and 0.7% to 838 million tonnes in 2018, despite mill closures. This growth is attributed to major mills ramping up operations, offsetting the impact of outdated plant shutdowns. The increase is also linked to Beijing's crackdown on illegal low-grade steel products, which has led to a stronger rebound in industrial activity.

site_title: Retaining its shine
summary: Sentosa Cove, a luxury residential enclave in Singapore, remains a desirable destination despite intermittent traffic congestion and limited accessibility. The area, modelled after the French Riviera, boasts beautiful sea views and a resort atmosphere. Its unique aspect is the relaxation of foreign-ownership restrictions, drawing foreigners to own homes on the island. The Sentosa Cove market has seen strong interest from developers and buyers, with prices consistently hovering above the Harbourfront cluster prices. However, recent reports of unlit condominiums and distress sales have cast a pall on the sub-market, with buying volumes showing a gradual uptick.

site_title: Court gives nod to withdraw bankruptcy applications against Jason Holdings' directors
summary: Singaporean court withdraws bankruptcy applications against Jason Holdings' directors Sim Choon Joo and Jason Sim Chon Ang, following a request from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) to withdraw the proceedings. The applications were filed amid a government investigation into Jason Holdings and its subsidiary over a potential offence under the penal code. The company's shares remain suspended.

site_title: South Korea's Moon to visit China next week
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In will visit China next week for a four-day state visit, amid tensions over North Korea's growing nuclear and missile threats. This trip comes after North Korea tested an intercontinental ballistic missile, prompting Washington to press Beijing to take a tougher stance. The visit aims to discuss ways to peacefully resolve North Korea's nuclear issue. Moon's trip also seeks to improve ties strained by Seoul's deployment of the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Moon Jae In will visit China next week, his office said Wednesday, as tensions soar over Pyongyang's growing nuclear and missile threats.

site_title: US manufacturing activity stays strong in November: ISM
summary: US manufacturing activity remained strong in November, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) reporting a 58.2% index, above the average for the past year. Output and employment continued to grow, despite a slight decline in the index from October. The sector's growth was attributed to improved conditions following hurricanes, with transportation issues being overcome. Industries reported increased prices and strong demand, with many expecting robust activity in 2018.

site_title: UK agrees to 'regulatory alignment' on Irish border after Brexit
summary: The UK has agreed to maintain "regulatory alignment" with the EU on the Irish border after Brexit, allowing for no frontier and avoiding customs and infrastructure that could jeopardize the peace in Northern Ireland. This commitment, made by Prime Minister Theresa May, paves the way for free trade talks between the UK and EU. The agreement follows intense negotiations and raises hopes that the UK can strike a deal in Brussels to start post-Brexit trade discussions.

site_title: Broadcom moves to unseat Qualcomm board, escalates takeover fight
summary: Broadcom, a Singapore-based computer chip maker, has proposed a new slate of board members for Qualcomm in a bid to support its $130 billion hostile takeover offer. The move comes weeks after Qualcomm rejected the offer and reaffirmed its plans to stay independent. If successful, the new board could oust Qualcomm's management, which has opposed the tie-up. Qualcomm has stated that the proposal is a "blatant attempt" to seize control and undervalue the company. The deal faces regulatory issues and could face scrutiny from Qualcomm shareholders and US authorities.

site_title: Star Wars sisters hail girl-powered galaxy
summary: The women of Star Wars: The Last Jedi gathered in Los Angeles to honor Carrie Fisher's legacy, with the film set to open next week. Director Rian Johnson, along with cast members Gwendoline Christie, Daisy Ridley, and Laura Dern, discussed the film's focus on female characters and complex traits. The cast emphasized the importance of representation and the impact of Fisher's legacy on their roles, with Ridley stating that her response to the film was "so beyond anything I could have imagined." The Last Jedi picks up where The Force Awakens left off, with Rey seeking to learn from Luke Skywalker about the Force.

site_title: Nasa successfully fires Voyager 1 thrusters after 37 years
summary: NASA successfully fired Voyager 1 thrusters after 37 years, extending the spacecraft's lifespan by two to three years. The thrusters, which turned the spacecraft by firing tiny "puffs," had degraded, but were successfully tested using backup thrusters. The test results showed the backup thrusters worked fine, allowing NASA to switch over to them in January. The Voyager 1 spacecraft, launched in 1977, will continue to send communications and transmit data for another decade, and will eventually orbit the center of the Milky Way galaxy after running out of fuel.

site_title: Cutting Edge Footwork
summary: Singapore's T.H.E. Dance Company presents "Three Kin," a triple-bill performance featuring works by company founder Kuik Swee Boon, guest choreographers Kim Jae Duk and Dimo Kirilov Milev, and artist-in-residence Milev. The performance explores themes of human-nature relationships, compassion, and environmental awareness, with Kuik reworking his 2009 commission "Water Bloom" and Kim and Milev premiering new works. "Three Kin" runs from Dec 7-9 at the Esplanade Theatre Studio, with standard tickets available at S$35.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares opened with gains, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.40% to 28,366.14, following a recent sell-off. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.32%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.22%. The gains in Hong Kong were attributed to bargain buyers entering the market after a six percent sell-off.

site_title: Sembmarine stands to offload West Rigel rig in US$500m resale deal
summary: Sembcorp Marine is set to offload its West Rigel semi-submersible rig in a US$500 million resale deal, potentially resolving the overhang on its yet-to-be-delivered rig-building order book. The rig was commissioned by Seadrill's subsidiary North Atlantic Drilling in 2012 for US$568 million. The resale deal, if finalized, would be a significant step in resolving Sembmarine's exposure to the rig-building contract, which also includes US$5.5 billion worth of drillship construction contracts at risk with Sete Brasil.

images.alt_text: A deal involving the resale of the West Rigel semi-submersible rig, pegged at around US$500 million, from a subsidiary of John Fredriksen-controlled Seadrill to a US-based fund house is in the works, spelling possible progress in resolving the overhang on Sembcorp Marine's yet-to-be-delivered rig-building order book.

site_title: Fragrance CEO's offer for New Wave lapses
summary: Singaporean real estate tycoon Koh Wee Meng's bid to acquire New Wave Holdings, an electronic component supplier, has fallen through due to the lapse of his voluntary conditional cash offer. The offer, made at S$0.013 per share, was short of the required 50% stake, with only 19.2% of shares tendered. As a result, all shares tendered in acceptance will be returned to shareholders. Koh, CEO of Fragrance Group, had sought majority control but intended to keep New Wave listed.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Supertall Skyscrapers: Vision Or Vanity?
summary: The world is expected to see over 100 more supertall buildings by 2020, with Asia leading the charge, driven by rapid urbanization. China is expected to have the most supertall buildings, followed by the UAE and the US. Despite criticism of their excesses, including astronomical construction costs and inefficient floor plates, supertall buildings are seen as a symbol of global visibility and economic value. Proponents argue that they create lasting economic value, optimize space, and boost local branding. However, critics point out that the costs are high, with construction costs increasing by 20% for every 300m added to a building, and operational costs, such as energy consumption and security issues. The economics of building tall are being reevaluated, with developers considering mixed-use developments and flexible construction plans to mitigate risks.

site_title: Elite US government hacker charged with taking secret information
summary: A 67-year-old US National Security Agency (NSA) veteran, Nghia Hoang Pho, has been charged with removing and retaining top-secret documents from the agency. Pho, a 10-year veteran of the NSA's Tailored Access Operations unit, agreed to plead guilty to a single charge. He allegedly accessed and stole documents via Kaspersky software, which Russian hackers used to gain access to the NSA's hacking operations. Pho faces up to 10 years in prison. This is the third NSA employee charged in the past two years for taking home top-secret information.

images.alt_text: According to The New York Times, it was Vietnam-born Pho's computer that apparent Russian hackers accessed via his use of Kaspersky software to steal files and programs the NSA developed for its own hacking operations.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan make their first royal visit
summary: Prince Harry and his fiancée Meghan Markle embarked on their first joint royal visit in Nottingham, England, marking the beginning of a six-month tour of Britain. The couple, who announced their engagement on Monday, met with members of the public, attended a charity fair, and visited a school combating youth violence. Meghan, a mixed-race American actress, has sparked controversy with her outspoken views, but the royal family has welcomed her with open arms, with Queen Elizabeth II congratulating the couple. The visit comes ahead of their May wedding at Windsor Castle.

site_title: Dow passes 24,000, giving positive lead to Singapore
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassed 24,000 for the first time, with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index also reaching a fresh record. The US tax-reform plan is moving closer to passage, with the Senate voting to launch a debate on the bill. Analysts believe US stocks may still rise if the bill becomes law, providing a positive lead for the Singapore market, which is also buoyed by strong corporate earnings. The Singapore market is expected to continue growing, with analysts predicting a 6.9% increase in the Straits Times Index by year-end.

site_title: Flynn pleads guilty to lying on Russia, cooperates with US probe
summary: Former US national security adviser Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about contacts with Russia and agreed to cooperate with the investigation into President Donald Trump's inner circle. Flynn, who faces up to five years in jail, admitted to lying about asking the Russian ambassador to delay a UN vote and instructed a senior official, identified as Jared Kushner, to contact Russia and other countries to influence their votes. The guilty plea marks a major escalation in the special counsel investigation, led by Robert Mueller, and raises questions about Kushner's potential liability under the Logan Act.

images.alt_text: Former US national security adviser Michael Flynn pleaded guilty on Friday to lying to the FBI about contacts with Russia and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors delving deeper into the actions of President Donald Trump's inner circle before he took office in January.

site_title: How the ferry is changing the Brooklyn-Queens waterfront
summary: The East River ferry is experiencing a revival in Brooklyn-Queens waterfront, with ridership up and rents increasing in previously neglected areas. The NYC Ferry service, launched in May, connects Brooklyn, Queens, and Manhattan on four lines, averaging 12,000 passengers a day. The ferry's success has brought new development to the area, with 38 condo or rental projects underway, exceeding existing inventory. Sales data suggest that waterfront living has increased in value, with some units selling for nearly double the original price. The ferry's effect on rents is uniform, with growth rates 1.5% faster in areas closest to ferry lines, compared to other parts of Brooklyn and Queens.

images.alt_text: A ferry on the East River carries passengers from stops in Brooklyn and Queens to Midtown Manhattan. The East River ferry is luring developers to a long-neglected stretch of the city's industrial waterfront, from western Queens to south Brooklyn.

site_title: China quietly building more facilities in the South China Sea
summary: China has quietly built infrastructure on 29 hectares of land in the South China Sea, including underground storage areas, hangers, and radar arrays, on reefs in the Spratlys and Paracels chains. The development is part of Beijing's efforts to strengthen its claim to 80% of the area, which has strained ties with Vietnam, the Philippines, and the US. The construction is a significant expansion of China's existing outposts, with the aim of establishing fully-functioning air and naval bases. The move raises concerns about China's growing military presence in the region.

images.alt_text: China has begun work or completed building infrastructure on about 29 hectares of land on outposts in the South China Sea this year, according to a report by the Washington-based Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative.

site_title: Transforming Allianz
summary: Allianz CEO Oliver Bate is driving transformation from the inside out at the 128-year-old German insurer, aiming to bring the company into the digital age while improving profitability, customer satisfaction, and inclusivity. Bate's five-pronged "Renewal Agenda" focuses on digitalization, customer-centricity, technical competence, growth engines, and a culture change to a more inclusive meritocracy. The plan aims to achieve 75% of businesses scoring above market average in customer satisfaction, increase customer transparency, and enhance technical competence. Bate emphasizes pulling staff along the change path, rather than pushing them, and has already seen results, including a 200 million euro increase in new business value in Asia between 2013 and 2017.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

"I always believe that organisms that don't grow even slowly, die. We need to train ourselves to grow again on many levers - organically taking market share from competitors and acquiring and consolidating businesses. Because in a mature industry, that's what you do to take excess capacity out and create efficiency." - Oliver Bate.

site_title: EMS Energy narrows loss in Q2
summary: EMS Energy narrowed its net loss in the second quarter to S$2 million, a significant improvement from a net loss of S$5.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 9.1% to S$3.3 million, driven by project billings from Koastal Industries Pte Ltd in Vietnam. The company is currently implementing a scheme of arrangement, which is expected to improve its financial position with debt-to-equity conversion upon completion.

site_title: Building Scale
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye emphasizes the importance of scale in the financial industry, not just size. He notes that SGX's strong passport allows it to reach more countries than any other, and its derivatives market is a key area of growth. Despite concerns about the equity market being a "sideshow," Loh believes it is crucial for companies to raise capital and that the market has shown resilience. He also addresses criticisms about the TR model and the need for remisiers to adapt to robo-advisers, seeing them as complementary rather than replacement. Loh also discusses the challenges of balancing roles between SGX and its regulator, RegCo, and the need for a flexible approach to governance.

images.alt_text: "We're a small country but we have the number one passport - that's the scale I've been talking about! "Scale means we can reach more countries than any other. And it's important to understand scale does not mean size; in fact, scale can be more meaningful than size.''

site_title: Despite Flynn's plea, jobs data and tax accord can lift stocks
summary: US stocks finished near record highs last week as tax-cut legislation passed in the Senate, offsetting concerns about the scandal surrounding former national security adviser Michael Flynn's guilty plea. Despite the uncertainty, economists predict strong jobs data and a potential tax accord will continue to drive market growth. The market may be resilient due to strong economic fundamentals, with GDP growth revised higher and a possible rate hike in December. Technology stocks have been volatile, but financials and cryptocurrencies are gaining traction.

images.alt_text: If Mr Flynn (above) testifies against Mr Trump, as a report from ABC television indicated he was prepared to do, the likelihood of a downfall for the president will cause a selloff in stocks.
